HEADLINE: Sept. 11-17;
Texas Is Back, Without the Gusher

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
THE Texas boom of the mid-1990's is taking shape in the streets of North Dallas, crowded with construction machinery and flowing with mud. Homes selling for less than $1 million are being torn down to make way for homes often selling for millions more.
 Inside one $4.5 million Georgian mansion going up to replace a $700,000 shack, scrollwork, friezes, acanthus leaves and rosettes march along endless moldings. The Christmas-gift-wrapping room and decoration storage closet await their annual visits. The movie theater and the surround-sound system throughout the house have the same designer who wired Steven Spielberg's place. The closets, with their own Beaux Arts trim and automated inventory systems, offer enough space maybe for a Neiman Marcus branch or two.
 
 No buyer for this house yet. But other houses nearby have sold for more, noted Roy W. Bailey, a prime investor. "What we've got here," he said, "is good value."
 Texas optimism has indeed returned as the state's economy has rebounded, and then some, in recent years. The recession of the early 1990's was hardly felt here, and despite low oil prices this year, the state's 3.2 percent annual growth rate through July is still slightly better than the nation's. The North American Free Trade Agreement, stealing the jobs of Midwestern factory workers but giving Texas a vast new market next door, is the state's most popular wealth transfer since the savings-and-loan bailout.
 But the buoyant future here often fights to a standoff with an obstinate past -- the oil price bust, S.& L. and bank failures and real estate collapse of the 1980's. The depression remains on display in Dallas, where the once-prosperous skyline made famous in the opening credits of "Dallas" lies just a 20-minute drive from the mansion. Today, downtown office buildings are more than a third vacant, with several taller than 30 stories abandoned and boarded over. Downtown property owners root for these buildings to be blown up, thereby improving the embarrassing vacancy statistics. In the meantime, Dallas has the nation's first skyscraper slum.
 If the future has a headquarters, it's less Dallas than Austin, the capital turned Silicon Prairie. Texas has swiped so many of California's technology jobs that California has resorted to ads warning of "hurricanes, tornadoes, floods and mosquitoes that require runways to land."
 In Houston, however, the past lingers. City boosters like to say that they no longer depend totally on oil. But as for alternatives, the Texas Medical Center, the nation's largest, has had to become less concerned with developing advanced heart operations than with doing them at Wal-Mart prices. And the Johnson Space Center is forced to target the planet Washington, not Mars, to keep what's left of its budget and its reputation.
 Even where Texans are becoming rich again, they are doing it with less of their distinctive bravado. Texas has long been becoming more like the rest of the country, but it's not quite that simple. Nicholas Lemann, a former editor of Texas Monthly who now writes for the Atlantic Monthly, speaks of the recolonization of Texas.
 Once just a source of raw materials for the rest of the nation -- cotton, cattle, oil -- Texas in its boom years developed its own proud institutions. Now buyouts, bankruptcies and failures have transferred many banks and department stores to owners in other states or abroad.
 Stanley Marcus, once the master of Neiman Marcus, grumbles that no longer can he get anything done -- raising a quick $500,000 for a civic project, say -- by calling a handful of local business chiefs. "Now," he says, "the decisions are made in Tokyo, or Hartford, or Kalamazoo."
 This year pressure from television networks broke apart what is perhaps the state's most sacrosanct institution, the Southwestern Conference. The four best football teams in the conference will be shotgun-married to a Big Eight that includes distant Iowa and Missouri.
 In the energy business, would-be wildcatters find that the only huge new strikes in the region are deep in the Gulf of Mexico, too costly for them to reach. Texas now sells less oil than natural gas, which qualifies as America's Most Boring Natural Resource except when a pipeline explosion blows away a New Jersey county or two.
 Dallas, where appearances usually count for more than reality, is dealing with the past by dressing it up as the future. Buildings that arose in the 1970's as glass boxes have been tarted up with pointy towers and hey-look-at-me lighting.
 The Dallas area's most noted renovation of late has been the Circle T Ranch. Nelson Bunker Hunt said during the 1970's that he wouldn't sell it for less than $200 million. Last year, Ross Perot Jr. -- a developer with a famous dad who has snapped up much of the land between Dallas and the Oklahoma border -- bought the ranch for $20 million from Mr. Hunt's bankruptcy estate. The ranch house was overhauled, with not a day to spare, before the Perots hosted the annual Cattle Baron's Ball last weekend.
 The Hunt family, of course, made money the old way, using roughnecks to find oil. The Perot family did it the new Dallas way, with starch-necked computer whizzes.

HEADLINE: The Nation: New Cops Need Help;
The Perils of Police Hiring

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

 BODY:
ANTICIPATING 100,000 new cops on their streets, city officials from across the country praised Congress for passing the $30 billion anti-crime package. But even before President Clinton signed the bill on Tuesday, criminologists warned that while quick hiring of police officers could make a dent in crime, it could also lead to more police brutality and corruption.
 In one city after another -- New York, Washington, Miami, Philadelphia, Houston and Detroit -- quick expansions of the police forces have led to careless screening and hasty training. Criminal justice experts say that the rush to hire contributed to an increase in incidents like high-speed traffic accidents during chases, perjury by police officers and sloppy handling of evidence -- not to mention behavior that is outright criminal.
 
 "All known cases of hiring unusually large numbers of police very quickly have been total disasters," said Lawrence W. Sherman, a University of Maryland professor who is chief criminologist for the Indianapolis police. "You tend to lower standards of training and selection."
 The nation's capital offers an egregious case study of how the best of intentions can spawn unfortunate results, as reported in a recent Washington Post series. Five years ago, when open-air drug markets seemed as common in Washington as cherry blossoms, Congress voted to withhold $430 million in aid until the District government expanded its police force.
 The city government shortened background checks for recruits and hired 1,500 officers in 20 months. Then it cut back on police academy classroom time in such areas as driving skills and investigative techniques. Not long thereafter, one in 14 of the new officers was arrested for crimes that included forgery and murder. Dozens more were found to be so untrustworthy that prosecutors refused to have them testify. And traffic accidents involving rookies led to nine deaths.
 Roughly a decade before, the Reagan Administration encouraged Miami to expand its force to stem the tide of cocaine from the Caribbean. Miami obliged by hiring 600 new police officers in 1981 and 1982. The patchwork hiring may have slowed the drug trade, but the rookies accounted for most of the 60 officers suspended or dismissed in the mid-1980's for various drug-related offenses.
 "Patches don't work sometimes, and that's what I think happened," Fred Taylor, director of the Metro Dade Police Department, said in a 1988 interview with Law Enforcement News.
 One contributing factor, experts say, is the change in the pool of young men and women from which recruits are drawn. Gone are the days when most police officers were immigrants or sons of immigrants who had few career options and saw police work as a way of establishing themselves in American society. More recently, recruits entered police ranks after years of military training.
 But without the draft, more and more police officers come from a less disciplined pool of high school graduates. "We have to be concerned," said Bernard Cohen, a Queens College professor of sociology and criminology. "We're bringing in a large number of very young officers who have been exposed to a culture of drugs and violence, and who in many ways lack the discipline of their predecessors."
 The crime bill provides localities with $8.8 billion to add 100,000 officers -- a nationwide increase of nearly 20 percent -- over six years. Most of the recruiting will come in the first three years, with the Justice Department projecting that 20,000 new officers will be walking their beats within 16 months. And some cities are expected to extend their forces beyond increases allotted under the new Federal subsidies.
 Alexander Weiss, a professor of criminal justice at Indiana University, said he expected that police forces with good screening and training programs would be able to handle large increases, but that forces with "systemic problems," like Washington's and New York's, would continue to have trouble.
 New York plans to use its Federal money not to hire new officers but to buy computer equipment to free desk-bound people for street duty. Commissioner William J. Bratton has acknowledged that supervision of young officers is insufficient. He wants to increase the number of sergeants and strengthen training on standards of integrity that police officers are supposed to meet.
 Despite the comment of Professor Sherman of the University of Maryland, police forces in several Western cities with less complex social problems, including Salt Lake City, Phoenix, San Diego and Colorado Springs, did grow in recent years without suffering scandals.
 Few experts dispute that the country needs more and better-trained police officers. Through the 1980's, as the crime rate spiraled along with sales and use of crack cocaine, Federal aid to local law enforcement was eroded by inflation to lower and lower levels. As many cities found themselves strapped, the police were neglected.
 The 31,000-member New York City Police Department, for example, is only 25 percent larger than the force of 40 years ago, when the annual murder rate in the city was one-sixth what it is today. Expansions of the New York force came mostly in spurts in the late 1960's and early 1990's, when city leaders responded to political pressures and declared new "wars" on crime. The New York Police Academy class of 1968 was rushed through its instruction. For the next 15 years, its ranks were plagued with corruption and brutality scandals and dismissals due to alcoholism.
 The jury is still out on the most recent expansion of the New York City police (including transit and housing officers), the addition of 13,000 recruits since 1990. Rookie officers have been implicated in a cocaine-related corruption scandal that has plagued the 30th Precinct in Harlem, but so have more seasoned officers.
Senior New York personnel officials in the New York police department say that, if a young officer is going to go bad, it usually happens in two to four years. One internal police memo said sergeants viewed the rookies as "afraid to take action" and added that many rookies, in the sergeants' view, "are controlled by their social calendar rather than the demands of the job."
 Another recent internal report was even more disturbing: "Many patrol officers questioned the integrity and the character of the rookies, and are reluctant to work with them for this reason."

HEADLINE: New Feud on the Range: Cowman vs. Tourist

SERIES: Who Owns the West? -- Second article of a periodic series.

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOAB, Utah

 BODY:
Just outside the wind-polished walls of Arches National Park, D. L. Taylor is counting heads moving through the canyon at sunset. There's a pair from New York. A batch from the Midwest. A couple of strays from San Francisco.
It's feeding time in the Virtual West, and you can almost hear the ranch hands humming the latest version of the cowboy classic: "Whoopee ti yi yo, get along, little tourists." 
 For more than 120 years, the Taylor family has been grazing livestock amid the rust-colored skyscrapers of Southern Utah's canyon country. A few years ago, Mr. Taylor, who is 62 years old, was about ready to give up, burdened by low beef prices, poor grass, and a host of other problems.
But then, in an effort to save his ranch, he came up with the idea of letting city folks act out their cowboy fantasies on his property. They ride, they rope, they eat beans, they sleep on the ground. Mr. Taylor used to have to pay good money to find people to do that. Now, they pay him.
He does not feel completely at ease with what he is doing -- mixing a real cattle operation with a lucrative tourism side business -- even though he makes more money herding visitors than he ever did just corralling cattle. "I don't really like doing it," he said, "but it sure pays."
Tourism, in all forms, is the fastest-growing industry in the West and the largest private employer in seven of the 11 Western states. But for every faux cowboy who drops a thousand dollars on a ranch like Mr. Taylor's for a week or so, there is an incremental effect on the land and culture in a region where people have always been overwhelmed by place -- and not the other way around.
Tourism has brought visible prosperity to hundreds of hamlets, including many places where traditional industries like mining or logging left exhausted, near-ghost towns in their wakes. Tourists, in many cases, have returned as home buyers, part of a remarkable surge of urban dwellers into the Western back country. Throughout the West, pockets like Moab are growing at three times the national average.
But now a reckoning of sorts has arrived in the new boomtowns of the West. Even many new arrivals are not happy with some of the detritus of what is being called "industrial tourism."
They wonder if hordes of tourists are any better for fragile land than herds of cattle. They worry about what happens when mountain bikes cause just as much damage to the little stream bed as does a strip-and-run mining operation.
They fear that their hamlets are being "Aspenized," a reference to the Colorado ski town where the average home now sells for $1.4 million and workers are bused in from 50 miles away.
Once, the outdoors was the great equalizer, a class-free zone. But now there are canyons where the locals cannot float down the river without applying for a permit two years in advance, and trails are overrun with bicycles that sell for up to $4,000.
"Recreation is turning into our biggest problem," said Bill Stringer, the acting manager of the six million acres in southeastern Utah run by the Bureau of Land Management. "Jeeps, four-wheel drives, motorbikes, mountain bikes and movie companies are overrunning this desert ecology. If it continues like this, we won't recognize the place."
Horror stories abound. Earlier this year, a plastic surgeon from California. looking for a place to relieve himself, was fined $100 after he landed his helicopter atop the delicate sandstone palace of Canyonlands National Park. The incident became a battle cry for a group called Citizens for a Heli-free Moab.
Two years ago, several thousand four-wheel-drive enthusiasts, after a long night of draining beer kegs and using their eight-cylinder engines to yank trees out of the ground for a bonfire, confronted a handful of Federal officials keeping guard over the public domain. There was a standoff, followed by gunfire, and then a small riot. The Federal officials retreated, calling in law enforcement officers from around Utah. Dozens of people were jailed.
The Moab riot has become one of many cautionary tales in the story of this town. When people here talk about how Moab set out to become a New West tourism mecca, they evoke the parable about never wishing too hard for something, because it might come true.
"Our community leaders went fishing for a little tourism to revive and diversify our economy, and they hooked a great white shark," said Bill Hedden, vice chairman of the Grand County Council, which governs the Moab area. "This monster has swamped the boat and eaten the crew. At stake is not merely the community we used to be, but also some of the best and most fragile country anywhere."
 
The New Cowboys And Their Toys<HE
Once, the West was big enough to accommodate everybody. And all that open space managed by the Bureau of Land Management, the 270 million acres that neither the railroads nor the homesteaders wanted, was left to the cattlemen, the mining companies and their supporters in the local Federal offices.
But now that the West is once again the geography of hope for restless Americans, it is at war with itself. There are tensions at work in virtually every prosperous town -- the kind of strains that almost no one imagined 10 years ago.
Choose your toys, and a fight soon follows. Mountain bikes or off-road vehicles. Hang gliders or helicopters. Backpacks or gun racks. Rafts or jetboats. Fly rods or shotguns. And for every significant gathering of gear-users, there is a lobby.
With the new people and new jobs catering to visitors comes a fresh way of looking at the land. Whether it is in the red rock canyon country of southern Utah, the dry mesas of western Colorado, the Sonoran Desert draws of Arizona or the green river valleys of Montana, the pattern is the same.
Newcomers from bigger cities move to a small, scenic Western town after visiting it on a vacation. They open businesses or work at home with computers or wait tables at the latest mesquite grill. They send their children to local schools, and they write letters to the editor. On the weekends, they hike, fish, ride bikes, hunt or take pictures.
At some point, they start looking closely at the public land around them and find out that bighorn sheep have died from disease spread by all the livestock that have free rein of the place. Or they wonder why the forest has been so badly clear-cut that silt fills up their trout streams. Or they react with shock at the mine waste that contaminated the river.
Then they realize that their tax dollars are subsidizing grazing, logging and mining on public lands, and before you know it, they have joined the local environmental group.
What they advocate -- a Western economy built around living and playing amid great scenery -- naturally scares the proponents of the old extractive economy. And now some of the newcomers' baggage -- the excess, the high prices, the gilded subdivisions -- is starting to scare some environmentalists.
"I spend more time dealing with tourism damage than cattle damage," said Scott Groene, who moved to Utah six years ago from Kansas and now leads the major environmental group in the canyon country. "It's really scary what's happened."
The new Westerners are vilified by senators like Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington, who tells loggers that the tourists from Seattle are trying to get rid of them, or Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, who rails against "cappuccino cowboys."
In Montana, a popular T-shirt carries the slogan "Montana sucks -- now go home and tell your friends." But judging by the urban sprawl in places like Bozeman and Kalispell, Mont., people are telling their friends something entirely different.
 
Uranium Miners And Film Crews
 Perhaps no place is more emblematic of the struggles between the old life and the new than Moab, a town of 4,000 people on the Colorado River, wedged between two national parks.
Mormon pioneers drove the Ute Indians out of this red rock canyon country in the late 1870's. It is dry, averaging about seven inches of rain a year. The Indians and the bison were replaced by white ranchers and their cow herds. Then the Government carved two national parks, Canyonlands and Arches, out of this country.
The Colorado was dammed downstream, burying one of the more breathtaking canyons in the West and creating Lake Powell, a recreational mecca. In the early 1950's, uranium miners overran Moab, looking for the raw materials of the cold war. That boom and the subsequent bust loom over old-timers here as the Dust Bowl does for survivors of the Depression.
In the 1980's, Moab's leaders decided to diversify their economy, vowing to free themselves from the extractive boom-and-bust cycle that has been such a scourge to many Western towns. They advertised the area as a desert paradise for the outdoor adventurer.
It worked beyond anyone's wildest dreams.
Off-road-vehicle enthusiasts came to roam, and soon they had carved their own dirt roads on public land, rutted paths nicknamed "metal smashers" or "steel benders." In the spring, as many as 5,000 of them converge at one time, posing a huge problem for a windswept terrain where few plants can take hold.
Soon Moab was billed as the mountain biking capital of the world. At the same time, the number of rafting companies quadrupled. Land prices soared, going from $5,000 an acre 10 years ago to more than $30,000 an acre now.
Then came the movie companies. Film makers like John Ford had always made effective use of the rust-colored bluffs and open vistas of the desert. Last year, the crews of "City Slickers II" and "Geronimo" came to town. All temporary housing was occupied for two months; a double-wide trailer could fetch $6,000 for a summer rental.
The movie crews nearly destroyed an Indian archaeological site, and they bulldozed a wilderness section on Federal land. They left a lot of dollars behind, but the housing shortage and a new attitude that was evident around town seemed to grate on a lot of people.
People say the canyon country had always been a hard place to get rich but a very good place to be poor. But suddenly, Moab became a town where you could buy a pair of $189 mountain bike shoes but not a pair of $40 work shoes. The nearest general shoe store is two hours away, in Grand Junction, Colo.
Mr. Stringer said mountain bikers "hammered" a once pristine area just outside of town. Vandals, he said, "chipped away at Anasazi ruins." The off-road-vehicle users and Jeepers "completely denuded" a large section of public land, he said. And the rafters have become such a problem that the biggest threat to the purity of the Colorado River is contamination from human feces.
"We're putting in toilets at an unprecedented rate," he said.
Earlier this year Mr. Hedden, the County Council vice chairman, spoke before Congressional leaders who were exploring the changing needs of the West during a series of hearings. "This is a tragedy," he said. "There is no other country like this on Earth, and we should be extremely cautious and protective of this land until we have a better understanding of how to control our own well-meaning desire to love it to death."
 
The Search For a Threshold
 The future may lie in a concept known as sustainable tourism, which means allowing only enough people to keep the charms, wonder and ecological balance of a place intact. But defining that threshold is difficult.
Some towns have found that by stretching their peak visitor seasons and directing people to areas other than the most overrun places, they can lighten the impact on the land. Those voluntary efforts have proved successful in some places, including Montana and Colorado.
What they run up against, though, is Westerners' traditional loathing of any sort of Government planning or imposed limits, as Mr. Hedden said in the Congressional hearing.
But some areas are imposing mandatory restrictions. And Federal land managers are considering doing what the National Park Service now does, which is to limit entry into certain fragile areas.
In Montana, environmental groups have been buying up large tracts of ranch land, which would otherwise be carved up and sold as ranchettes. They then keep it as open forage country for wild animals.
Andy Kerr, a firebrand environmentalist who has moved to a small town in Eastern Oregon from Portland, said, "I reject the choice of old land abusers or new yuppie scum." Instead, he said, something between the two extremes can emerge.
For all the anxiety over losing a way of life in the Western small towns, few people talk of going back to the way things were. Mr. Taylor, the rancher, said there is tension between the new people and what he calls "the rednecks." But he said, "On the whole, I'd rather have a boom town filled with bikers than a ghost town of old miners and ranchers."

HEADLINE: SHOWDOWN WITH HAITI: ARISTIDE;
Aristide Adopts a New Role: From Robespierre to Gandhi

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The subject was the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, and the House Intelligence Committee wanted some answers.
In a closed-door briefing by Administration officials last month, several lawmakers cited transcripts of secretly taped telephone conversations in which Haiti's ousted President vowed not to let Washington push him around and joked that he found it amusing when American officials thought of him as stubborn. 
 "How could the United States advance the interests of a man who clearly holds us in such contempt?" one Congressman wanted to know, according to a participant in the meeting.
Anthony Lake, President Clinton's national security adviser, and William H. Gray 3d, Mr. Clinton's special Haiti representative, staunchly defended Father Aristide. "Would you expect the President of any nation in the world to tell one his confidants that he wants to be pushed around by the United States?" Mr. Lake asked.
But the fact the National Security Agency was listening in on Father Aristide's phone calls to Haiti in the first place, and picking up negative vibrations in the process, suggests how uneasy Washington is about the man American troops are poised to restore to power.
The White House insists that the 41-year-old Roman Catholic priest has grown into a statesman in his three years of exile. Aides to Mr. Clinton say he was greatly relieved that Father Aristide pledged in writing to uphold the Hatiian Constitution and agree to hand over power to an elected successor in February 1996.
But American officials acknowledge that ultimately they cannot be certain exactly how Father Aristide will govern, and his own plans remain sketchy.
Will he be the kind of leader who will make the Administration proud when he rides in on the backs of American soldiers? Or will he, upon returning, feel so pressured to assert his independence that he will turn on his liberators?
In recent weeks, the Administration has had to conduct intense negotiations with Father Aristide on issues ranging from the content of his American-financed radio broadcasts to Haiti to the composition of the police force that will patrol the streets of Port-au-Prince after his return to his promise to step down from office when his term expires.
So it is not surprising that at times the Administration treats the soft-spoken priest as a volatile chemical that needs to be handled with care.
"Who is Aristide?" Mr. Gray asked rhetorically in an interview. "He's a Haitian. A priest. An intellectual. An ideologue. Not your practical pol who's lived in an functioning democracy."
 
A Crusader Who Can't Fix the Lights
 Father Aristide's brief tenure as the popularly elected President of Haiti before his ouster in the fall of 1991 offers an impressionistic if inconclusive look at how he will govern when given a second chance. During that period, he made no secret of his distrust of the outside world.
As head of a team of election observers during the 1990 Presidential campaign, Jimmy Carter asked the young candidate if he would accept the results if he lost. Father Aristide was so incensed by the suggestion that he might lose that he accused the United States of plotting to prevent his victory.
When Mr. Carter declared him a winner a few days later -- he received two-thirds of the vote -- Father Aristide immediately called him a friend.
As President, he followed what Administration officials view as a relatively responsible economic policy, reduced the public payroll and abolished the jobs of the rural sheriffs who ruled the countryside with impunity.
But as a populist leader suspicious of authority, he could not resist terrifying the military with threats of mob vengeance. And charges that he condoned the practice of "necklacing" political opponents with burning tires continue to dog him. He later explained his threats against the armed forces by saying that the people were his only defense against the military elite that ultimately overthrew him and tortured and killed his supporters.
He also surrounded himself with ministers who were deeply suspicious of foreign meddling and often knew even less than he did about their portfolios.
"There was one time when Aristide called President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela because the lights had been out in the capital for three days and he didn't know how to requisition oil even though the two countries had an oil agreement," said one senior Administration official who has known Father Aristide since before his election. "He was practically weeping."
 
A Relationship Built on Mistrust
 The Administration's relationship with Father Aristide has improved considerably since the days in mid-1993 when Mr. Clinton angrily told aides he might abandon him if he did not sign a United Nations-brokered peace plan for Haiti.
Policymakers have had an easier time dealing with Father Aristide since Mr. Clinton announced a policy shift last May that included a halt to pressuring Father Aristide to make concessions to the ruling junta. Instead, the Administration has bent more and more to Father Aristide's will.
In the process, officials have sought to circumvent the phalanx of advisers who remain convinced that Father Aristide needs protection from the Americans.
Last summer, for example, Father Aristide had all but signed a one-page agreement to begin broadcasting messages back home by way of an American-financed radio station. But he changed his mind after a news report quoted Adminstration officials as saying he would have to urge Haitians to stay home and halt their efforts to flee the country by sea.
His aides responded with a long document listing new demands, and it took another week of cajoling and convincing by Mr. Gray before Father Aristide agreed to sign the original document. Under the agreement, both sides have the right to censor the remarks of the other.
And after Father Aristide refused to allow the Americans to broadcast messages for Haitians to stay home on the radio, the Americans had to seek permission from President Joaquin Balaguer to use radio frequencies from the Dominican Repubic.
Administration officials have often succeeded with Father Aristide in rather unconventional ways.
For months, for example, he had promised American officials that he would step down from office when his Presidency runs out in February 1996. Under Haiti's Constitution, he cannot run again for five years after that.
But it took a chance encounter at a reception at the White House last Sunday between Mr. Lake and the Pulitzer prize-winning author Taylor Branch, who is a confidant of Father Aristide, before the pledge was put into writing.
Mr. Branch told Mr. Lake that Father Aristide had repeatedly stated that the most important election in a democracy was the second election and looked forward to the day when his Presidency ran out and he could pass the mantle of power to his successor. Would President Aristide put that on paper, Mr. Lake wanted to know.
Two days later, Mr. Branch and Father Aristide drafted a statement and turned it over to the White House.
Part of the difficulty in dealing with Father Aristide, Administration officials say, is that as a man who sees himself as a missionary of God and views the world through the lens of liberation theology, he remains difficult to fathom.
Certainly his years in exile have helped him master the art of speaking to different audiences.
The Administration is heartened, for example, by his public statements that stress love rather than vengeance, capped by his carefully-scripted speech from the White House East Room on Friday that included all the right code words to all the important constituencies back home.
Do not be afraid of me, he told the Haitian military that ousted him, and fear the retribution of the masses. Let free enterprise and privatization reign, he told the business elites who have not forgotten that he once labeled capitalism a mortal sin.
By contrast, in his messages in Creole over "Radio Democracy," he speaks solely to the Haitian masses who elected him. Instead of comparing himself to Robespierre, as he did in his autobiography, he now compares himself to Gandhi. He has pledged to bring foreign tourists to the country along with electricity and roads and clean water. He talks of cement plants, salt-producing complexes and shrimp fishing projects.
He also speaks in proverbs and riddles, and his reversion to the rich imagery of Creole may have contributed to intelligence assessments of him as mentally unstable. "We have been struggling nonviolently in this way ever since back before the devil was even a corporal," he said in his first radio message back home, "ever since way back when the ginger root was still fighting the eggplant."
Even on the eve of a possible invasion to restore him to power, there are fierce arguments within the Administration on how to deal with Father Aristide.
The Central Intelligence Agency remains convinced that despite its factual flaws, the conclusions of a much-criticized report that Father Aristide is mentally unstable are true. Vice Adm. William O. Studeman, the deputy director of intelligence, continues to promote the line that Father Aristide will be an unpredictable leader at best, according to senior policymakers.
Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and some other senior officials were so concerned early this week about accusations that a former Haitian police chief, Col. Pierre Cherubin, was guilty of human rights abuses, that they tried to prevent him from flying on a United States Government aircraft to Guantanamo Bay to recruit refugees for the new police force. But Mr. Gray countered that since Father Aristide was a democratically elected head of state, the United States had no right to tell him whom to choose as his advisers.
When American officials raised the matter with Father Aristide, he replied that the claims were unfounded. After considerable internal debate, Colonel Cherubin flew to Guantanamo.
 
A Crash Course In Economics
 To help prepare Father Aristide for his return, Administration officials have tried to force feed him large doses of economics and theories of public administration.
Using a 400-page World Bank-Agency for International Development study as a blueprint, two of his most trusted aides drafted an eight-page document that provides the basis for an $800 million package of social and economic reforms that Father Aristide expects to carry out after he is restored to power. The plan is a relief to international financial institutions: it calls for the abandonment of import quotas and most tariffs, the divestment of state-owned enterprises, a 50 percent reduction of the government bureaucracy and the professionalization of government and the strengthening of local authority.
As for Father Aristide himself, his vision for rebuilding the nation remains long on theology but short on specifics.
He has not disclosed whom he will name as his Prime Minister, who under Haiti's Constitution wields even more power than the President. His rupture with Robert Malval, whom he named as Prime Minister last September but who resigned in exasperation with Father Aristide three months later, is said by Administration officials to be irreparable.
There is speculation that his two top economic advisors, former World Bank economists Leslie Voltaire and Leslie Delatour, will emerge in important cabinet positions. Such a move would delight Administration officials, who are eager that this time, Father Aristide fill his cabinet with technocrats not theologians.
"When we first met him when he was running for president, he was a person with a real attitude about the United States and the West," said J. Brian Atwood, the Administrator for the Agency for International Development. "But I think he has really grown. He knows all the practical issues now."
"On the other hand," he added, "he is not a technician. He is clearly a spiritual leader."

HEADLINE: Cuba to Allow All Farmers to Sell Some Food on the Open Market

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Sept. 17

 BODY:
In a step away from the highly centralized Communist system that has defined its economy for more than three decades, Cuba announced today that it would allow all farmers to sell part of their produce on the open market.
Government officials said they were acting to ease the crushing shortages of meat, chicken, most vegetables and other food, which have set the black-market price of a big fish at the equivalent of a mechanic's monthly wage. 
"Today, the political, military and ideological problem of this country is to look for food," Cuba's Defense Minister and second-ranking leader, Gen. Raul Castro, said in an interview published today in the Communist Party newspaper Granma.
Several foreign experts on the Cuban economy said the measure could be an important step toward a more productive economy driven by material incentives, depending on how liberally it was applied.
But they cautioned that the move was still a small one when set against the overwhelming problems that have plagued Cuba since the fall of its Soviet-bloc trading partners in 1989 and the tightening of the American embargo three years later.
In interviews, senior Cuban officials said the move would go far beyond the so-called free farmers' markets that Cuba created in 1980 and then abolished in 1986 as a bourgeois threat to Communism.
Unlike that experiment, in which only small farmers were permitted to sell their surplus produce on the open market, the new policy will encompass everything from state farming cooperatives to the Cubans who grow vegetables in their front yards.
Farmers will still have to sell the Government a fixed amount of their harvest, based on what they grow and where they grow it. They will be allowed to sell anything they produce above those quotas at whatever price supply and demand dictate. The producers will be licensed, officials said, and their profits will be taxed.
Cuban officials denied that the announcement was tied to pressure from the Clinton Administration, which has said that it will ease the 32-year-old American economic embargo against Cuba only if the Government of General Castro's brother, President Fidel Castro, moves toward free markets and democratic politics.
Indeed, Raul Castro said that while "much more" democracy was needed within the Cuban Communist Party, "any other party would belong to imperialism, and that we will never permit."
Yet in laying out the agricultural changes just a few days after they began trumpeting their successful halt to the flight of thousands of refugees under an immigration agreement with the United States, Cuban officials said they hoped the measure would contribute to an improvement in the long-hostile relationship between the countries.
"This is not being done to seek a reaction" from the United States, the President of Cuba's National Assembly, Ricardo Alarcon, said in an interview with foreign reporters on Friday night. "But I think it will have some repercussions."
Andrew Zimbalist, a professor of economics at Smith College who has studied the Cuban economy for years, said: "It would be taking things out of perspective to simply applaud this as a positive, which it is. It is welcomed. But at this moment the economy is a disaster. They need to take bolder measures."
Mr. Zimbalist and other economists said that although the announcement was being made at the start of the planting season for many vegetables, it would still take months to show any significant increase in food over what is already available on the black market. A drop in prices, they suggested, could take even longer.
But diplomats and other political analysts said the move could have an important psychological effect in the meantime.
"After all the rafters, people needed some sign that changes were going to be made," a European diplomat said. "This is a sign."
The scarcity of food and other basics like soap was the central factor in the flight of more than 30,000 Cubans after President Castro reacted to the hijackings of some state-owned vessels and a riot against the security forces in Havana on Aug. 5 by allowing people to leave the island freely in homemade rafts.
Much of the country's industrial plant has been paralyzed for lack of fuel and spare parts; agricultural yields have plummeted along with supplies of fertilizer, and oxen have replaced tractors on many farms.
Mr. Alarcon, Cuba's chief negotiator in eight days of talks with American officials in New York this month, denied that there had been any secret agreement to extend the discussions beyond the subject of immigration at a later point.
There has been considerable speculation in both countries about the possibilities of such a deal, in part because Cuba was widely seen to have agreed to stop the flood of refugees on terms favorable to the Clinton Administration.
Under the New York accord, the United States is to issue at least 20,000 visas to Cuban immigrants each year. The agreement also ratified Mr. Clinton's reversal of the longstanding American policy of taking in any Cuban who wanted to emigrate to the United States.
But American officials refused to lift new restrictions on travel and the sending of money from the United States to people in Cuba, or to even discuss the embargo that Cuban officials blame for most of their economic troubles.
Havana has nonetheless been unfailingly enthusiastic about the accord. In part, Cuban officials have seemed to want to reassure disgruntled citizens of some light at the end of their long sacrifice. They have also clearly hoped to show Americans that they can be counted on to respect what they sign.
"The fact that we have been able to negotiate this agreement calls into question the argument that Cuba is not serious," the head of the Communist Party's Americas Department, Jose Antonio Arbesu, said in an interview on Friday.
"We have made changes here that are important," he went on. "What is absurd is to think that this is a quid pro quo, that they can lift the blockade in exchange for this, that and the other. If they want to influence Cuba and changes in Cuba, the best way to do that is not with a policy that has shown for 30 years that it does not work."
The move toward free markets for agricultural products follows a series of changes over the last three years that have included a wide opening to foreign investment, the creation of some semi-autonomous and private companies and the establishment of a parallel economy in American dollars.
Economic planners led by Carlos Lage, who heads the Executive Committee of the Council of Ministers, have struggled lately to sop up some of the 11 billion excess of Cuban pesos that has driven inflation in the black market. The inflation has raised prices for items like cigarettes and rum and resulted in workers and schoolchildren being charged for the lunches that were previously free. The peso now trades on that market at about 100 to the dollar.
Alluding to the reduced peso surplus, first steps toward taxation and the creation last year of new state cooperatives in which farmers are allowed to use some Government land for themselves, Mr. Lage said in a brief conversation on Friday, "There are conditions now for an agricultural market."
Neither he nor other officials provided details about how or precisely when the markets would be established, or how the authorities would deal with the emergence of intermediaries between farmers and consumers. In abolishing the peasant markets in 1986, President Castro said they had become "a source of enrichment for neo-capitalists and the neo-bourgeois."
Several officials said the Government would probably try to control the transportation of products from larger farms, but they added that the food problem was so severe they had no choice but to tolerate the likely enrichment of some farmers, truck drivers and others.
"At essence, supply and demand should be at play, as well as regulations and taxes that we should apply," Raul Castro said. But he added, "We must be clear about one thing: If there is food for the people, the risks do not matter."

HEADLINE: SHOWDOWN WITH HAITI: THE PRESIDENT;
Behind the Scenes at the White House: Clinton Takes 'Last Best Chance' to Avoid Invasion

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Minutes after telling the nation on Thursday night that he had exhausted diplomacy in his standoff with Haiti, President Clinton went into his small study off the Oval Office and made a round of telephone calls to enlist emissaries for the high-level mission that Mr. Clinton today called the "last best chance" for peace.
That he did so surprised some top Administration officials, most of whom learned only Friday afternoon that Mr. Clinton had decided to send Jimmy Carter to Port-au-Prince. Some of them expressed concern today that the mission -- which also includes Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia and retired Gen. Colin L. Powell, the former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff -- could turn into the kind of negotiating session for which Mr. Clinton had said the time was long past. 
 The White House previously rejected Mr. Carter's request that he serve as an intermediary. But aides to Mr. Clinton said today that even as he addressed the nation on Thursday night, he and his top advisers believed they had no political or moral option but to try one more time to bring an end to the crisis through talk, not war.
"None of us wants to send U.S. troops in harm's way if it can be avoided," William Gray 3d, the special adviser on Haiti, said today.
Even as his emissaries were landing in the Haitian capital, the President was taking pains to maintain an image of toughness. He traveled from the White House to the Pentagon, where he returned a salute from Gen. John M. D. Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, then headed into an underground chamber at the Pentagon called the National Military Command Center, for what the White House said was a briefing on the status of military preparations. He also conferred by video-conference with admirals and generals aboard Navy ships and at Army bases.
His aides also noted that in a meeting this morning Mr. Clinton proclaimed that he would be neither delayed or deterred. And in his weekly radio address to the nation, he declared: "We still hope to end this journey peacefully. But let me say one last time -- the cause is right, the mission is achievable and limited, and we will succeed. The dictators must leave."
What most worried Mr. Clinton and his top advisers, aides said today, was the prospect that a mission to Haiti by Mr. Carter would send the same mixed signals as the former President sent earlier this summer on a quasi-official trip to North Korea in which he made clear that he opposed the Administration's policy.
Since Thursday night, when Mr. Clinton told Senator Nunn and General Powell that he would like them to join Mr. Carter in a final mission, aides said that the President has taken extraordinary steps to keep the mission on a short rein.
Mr. Carter, who had been accompanied to North Korea only by his wife and a translator, was joined on the trip to Haiti by top officials from the State Department, the Pentagon and the White House. The team flew into Port-au-Prince today aboard a United States Air Force jet loaded with secure communications equipment to allow the emissaries to keep in touch with Washington.
Even on Friday night, aides said, Mr. Clinton placed telephone calls to Mr. Carter, Senator Nunn and General Powell one by one to review their instructions with them. The President told them their job was to tell the three Haitian leaders firmly that they must relinquish power, and to discuss the arrangements the United States might make for them to leave the country only if they were asked about it.
Some officials worried aloud today that such talks have a way of gaining a momentum of their own, noting that Mr. Carter, Senator Nunn and General Powell have all questioned the wisdom of the invasion that Mr. Clinton has said will soon be his only recourse.
But Mr. Gray, when asked about that prospect during an interview on Cable News Network, replied: "The Administration has said: 'Here is the boundaries of any discussions and negotiations. If anyone goes outside of those boundaries, don't expect us to be supportive of that.' I don't think President Carter's going to do that."
By coincidence, Mr. Clinton spoke tonight at a dinner in honor of the Congressional Black Caucus, whose members were outspoken in criticizing the Administration's policy toward Haiti earlier this year. More than any other factor, their complaints that the Administration was being inhumane in turning back Haitian refugees prompted the White House to change course last May by tightening sanctions, providing havens for the refugees and threatening to use force unless Haiti's leaders stepped down.
Now some members of the caucus, including Representative Maxine Waters, the California Democrat, have become his most ardent champions in the face of criticism that military action would be unwise.
Another supporter of an invasion has been Representative Kweisi Mfume, a Maryland Democrat who heads the caucus. Earlier this month he said: "It's no longer a question of whether or not it's inevitable. It's a larger question of whether or not we find ourselves with reasons as to why we should not invade."
But that feeling is by no means universal even among the group. Many of its members, including Representative Ronald Dellums, the California Democrat who is now chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, have long been wary of the use of force, and some have expressed reservations about the dangers that an American-led invasion might pose for Haitian civilians, who are overwhelmingly black.
In his address, Mr. Clinton called on the Black Caucus to "say a prayer for peace and for success of our effort" in Haiti.
 "Let us hope for its success," he said, "but whatever happens, let us resolve that we will stand against violations of human rights in our neighborhood, we will stand for democracy, we will keep our commitments and expect others to keep theirs."

HEADLINE: For Queens, a Place in the Sun;
Hollywood Is Suddenly Zooming In, With a Vengeance

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
"Queens is not New York!"
Thus bellows Martin Scorsese in a scene from the new movie "Quiz Show," explaining why the perspiring game-show winner Herbert Stempel is about to return to Forest Hills a loser. As far as the movie is concerned, his geography is absolutely right. 
 The New York of 1956 -- that is, Manhattan -- is depicted in "Quiz Show" as a bright, fast-moving world of unlimited promise and unlimited deceit, where betrayal comes at the end of a fancy restaurant meal. Queens, where Herbie Stempel steeps in anger, is seen as a brooding borough of dark brick where the ungroomed sit around in their underwear, mainlining rugelach.
Such is the lot of New York's second-most-populous borough (after Brooklyn), which seems fated for a lifetime of character-actor parts calling for a quarrelsome, overweight relative. But that character actor, in the last few years, has been getting the call for a lot of work.
Queens, barely acknowledged as a fellow borough by Manhattan, is suddenly very popular in Hollywood. Four of the top-rated prime-time television shows feature characters from Queens who regularly muse about the borough, and a new nationally televised talk show on Lifetime cable broadcasts daily from Long Island City and proudly entitles itself, simply, "Queens." In addition to "Quiz Show," more than half a dozen movies have been set completely or partly in Queens in the last three years, which is a lot more than can be said by any other "outer" borough.
"All of a sudden, everyone in Hollywood is coming out of the closet and admitting they come from Flushing," said Fran Drescher, the creator and star of the CBS hit "The Nanny," whose overflowing accent and hair have come to symbolize Queens for a curious nation. "It used to be that Brooklyn was the borough everyone made fun of, but all the Brooklyn jokes are done. Now everyone knows the most colorful characters come from Queens."
Ms. Drescher, who actually comes from Kew Gardens Hills, may be the most deliberately colorful of the lot, but she is hardly alone in celebrating the showbiz ascendancy of her native land. Producers and actors who come from Queens say it's about time the borough is recognized for generating its singular form of wit and wisdom.
"It was always the younger sister or son of the other boroughs," said John Turturro, who plays Mr. Stempel in "Quiz Show" and grew up around Hollis and Rosedale. (His mother still lives in Richmond Hill.) "But now that it's grown up and become more populated, it's starting to have its own history to look back on. That's why you're seeing it more featured these days."
If Brooklyn and the Bronx long ago lived through both their heyday and their nostalgia for that heyday, the far newer and more suburban borough of Queens remains somewhere vaguely between those two periods. Most of its growth came after World War II, to some degree at the expense of the older boroughs, and it is currently enjoying a renewed prosperity as the destination of choice for the city's middle-class immigrants. Many baby boomers who grew up in Queens and quickly left are now reaching their prime, and some of those who are in show business are now able to look back at Queens with the same affection that earlier generations had for Flatbush or the Grand Concourse.
"A lot of writers came from Queens, and their thoughts kind of return there like homing pigeons," said William Finkelstein, a Hollywood producer from Bayside who created the extremely Queens character of Denise Iannello (played by a native, Debi Mazar) on the former prime-time dramas "Civil Wars" and "L.A. Law." "Maybe it won't have the kind of mythic status that Brooklyn used to have, but anyone who's from there knows that it's rich in lore."
Of course, by the time that lore is filtered through Hollywood's distaste for complexity, it seems to separate into two distinct and oft-repeated strains. The first and most common is represented by George Costanza, the schlemiel of "Seinfeld," who spent most of the last season unemployed and living amid the lunacy of his parents in Queens, where his father's idea of entertainment was poring through his collection of old TV Guides. The stereotype of Queens characters as loud, obnoxious and lovable originated with the best-known show set in the borough, "All in the Family," and continued with the cuddly losers of "Dear John," the 1988 singles-group show set in Rego Park; the bickering eccentrics in the 1992 film "Used People," starring Shirley MacLaine; and the portrayals of Herbie Stempel and Ms. Drescher's Fran Fine.
While affectionate, such depictions are often more condescending than flattering, says Rochelle Slovin, executive director of the American Museum of the Moving Image, the film and broadcasting museum in Long Island City.
"In one sense, Queens has become a metaphor for a kind of distaste of the working class," she said. "It's no longer the romantic and attractive working-class neighborhood of Woody Allen."
Mr. Allen's 1987 comedy, "Radio Days," set in the Rockaways of the 1940's, is considered an exception to the caricature, one of the most fond and authentic portraits of life in Queens, along with last year's "Mac," Mr. Turturro's directorial debut and tribute to his father.
If they're not ethnic eccentrics, Queens characters on screen generally fall into one other broad category: those coping with an overwhelming urge to get out of the borough, usually into Manhattan. In "Queens Logic," the critically well-received 1991 movie set in Astoria, a group of thirtyish friends tries to juggle their love for the neighborhood with the pull of the more glittering outside world. On "NYPD Blue," the ABC police drama, Detective John Kelly's ex-wife moves from Sunnyside to Manhattan, telling her former husband, "I finally made it out of Queens."
It takes the bitter Alaskan winter to move Dr. Joel Fleischman, the main character of CBS's "Northern Exposure," to reflect nostalgically on his warmer life as a Jewish boy from Flushing, from which he was always eager to escape. A similar desire to flee is also voiced by Rosie Perez in this year's film "It Could Happen to You," and by Julie Kavner in Nora Ephron's 1992 movie "This Is My Life."
Those who stay in Queens, then, are a bit nutty, a bit gross, a bit pathetic, according to Hollywood, while anyone halfway normal wants nothing more than to get out. Such a shorthand, says Ms. Slovin, shouldn't be too surprising from an entertainment industry not known for its subtlety.
"In a 95-minute movie, you have to move things along quickly," she said. "You have to accept that they'll be filled with stereotypes." She noted that few Queens movies deal with the new reality of the borough, including the large black middle class communities of southeast Queens, or its large Asian population. (An exception is Tony Chan's 1993 movie "Combination Platter," about a waiter from Hong Kong dealing with immigration problems amid the comic, frenetic life in the kitchen of a Chinese restaurant in Flushing.)
The one show that does deal with the Queens of the moment, if glancingly, is the aptly named "Queens," a daily variety talk show broadcast live at noon from Lifetime's studios in the Kaufman-Astoria complex in Long Island City. The loose-limbed show, aimed at women across the country who are home at that hour, is not precisely about the borough, featuring soap opera stars and such authors as Jackie Collins. But the show's host, Sissy Biggers, regularly gets takeout from Queens restaurants on the air, and sometimes welcomes borough chefs of a variety of ethnicities.
When the program goes clothes shopping on location, it goes to Queens stores rather than Madison Avenue boutiques, said the executive producer, Lynda Lou Kane-Kraft.
"Queens seems to translate better around the country than the other boroughs of New York," she said, unknowingly echoing the sentiments expressed by Mr. Scorsese. "It's more like the rest of America."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Row houses line the block of 28th Street near 34th Avenue in Long Island City, Queens. (Chang Lee/The New York Times); The borough, the city's second largest, has suddenly become popular in Hollywood -- it is the place to live for a rising number of characters in movies like "Queens Logic," below left (New Visions Pictures), and on television shows like "Seinfeld," below. (NBC)
 
Chart: "OVERVIEW: Queens on Screen"
 New York's second-most-populous borough, barely acknowledged by Manhattan, is suddenly popular in Hollywood and on television, after first achieving fame in "All in the Family" in the 70's. "All of a sudden, everyone in Hollywood is coming out of the closet and admitting they come from Flushing," said Fran Drescher, the creatorand star of the CBS hit "The Nanny."
 
TV shows:
 The Nanny: A Queens hairdresser with an accent the size of Long Island becomes the nanny for a rich Manhattan household headed by a proper British playwright. Queens native Fran Drescher, who created and stars in the show, uses the borough as the seat of an earthy if slightly nutty wisdom that holds lessons for superficial Manhattanites. At one point, the family is trapped in her mother's Flushing home; her mom says, "If you'd called, I would have Windexed the couch."
 Seinfeld: For much of the last season, George Costanza -- the star's schlemiel friend, played by Jason Alexander -- lived in agony at his parents' home in Queens. The household is depicted as a constant series of lunatic arguments between George's father, who collects TV Guides and lives in old sportshirts, and his mother, a meddling Mrs. Portnoy who is proud of her baloney sandwiches. Jerry Seinfeld, a Queens College graduate, and his gang hate nothing more than taking the subway to the Costanza residence.
 NYPD Blue: Though set in Manhattan, the show has a number of characters who live in Queens, including the former wife and former girlfriend of the former lead character, Det. Kelly. Both of them seem to live near the 7 train, which also courses through the show's opening credits. The show refers to the borough mostly as a place to get out of; at one point, after Kelly's ex-wife moves to Manhattan, she tells him, "I finally made it out of Queens."
 Northern Exposure: The Alaskan winters force Dr. Joel Fleischman to become nostalgic for his native Flushing, an emotion he would not earlier have imagined. Figures from his neighborhood occasionally come back to haunt him, including his rabbi, who appears to make the trip from Queens in a whale's belly.
 704 Hauser St.: This followup to the granddaddy of all Queens sitcoms, "All in the Family," was cancelled after a few weeks last spring. It depicted the Cumberbatches, a black family living in the Bunker's old house, set approximately in Corona. Norman Lear spent more time refashioning the original's racially jarring humor than he did creating a sense of place to the neighborhood, but 23 years later, the novelty had worn off and few people watched.
 
Movies:
 Quiz Show (1994): Herbert Stempel, a contestant on the rigged NBC show "Twenty-One," lived in Forest Hills in the 1950's, and still does. The new Robert Redford movie contrasts the vulgar lower-class Queens -- where Stempel and his family sit around in their underwear eating rugelach -- with the leafy, WASPy suburbs of Charles Van Doren, the patrician quiz show winner who supplanted Stempel and was also on the take. Because Forest Hills itself is an attractive neighborhood, the Queens scenes were actually shot in the more proletarian Astoria.
 Queens Logic (1991): An ensemble film shot in the shadow of the Hell Gate bridge in Astoria about a group of young friends struggling with a series of life decisions. Written by Astoria native Tony Spiridakis, it contrasts the characters' deep loyalty to their neighborhood with the lure of Manhattan and the outside world. The film, considered one of the few authentic portraits of the borough, did poorly at the box office.
 It Could Happen to You (1994): The tale of a police officer who wins the lottery after agreeing to split his ticket with a waitress, as her tip. The officer and his wife (Nicholas Cage and Rosie Perez) live in Queens, and her life's dream, as she states repeatedly in the movie, is to get as far from the borough as she can.
 This is My Life (1992): Nora Ephron's directorial debut concerned a single mom Dottie Ingels (Julie Kavner) living with her two daughters and an aunt in Ozone Park. Dottie works the cosmetic counter at Macy's on Queens Boulevard and dreams of becoming a stand-up comedienne; when her dream begins to come true, she moves to the Upper West Side as fast as she can. The movie includes a scene of the family singing, "If you live in Queens, you don't know beans."
 Used People (1992): A Queens family of Jewish eccentrics (the daughter is constantly dressing up a movie-star vamps) comes to terms with a widow's courtship by an Italian. The noisy family is mostly seen bickering, even over the proper route to a cemetery. (pg. 52)

HEADLINE: A Renewed Sense of Mission Is Rousing the U.N.

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 16

 BODY:
A fresh sense of optimism is seeping through the bureaucracy here, a feeling that the end of the cold war is belatedly goading the United Nations into a unity of purpose. At the same time, however, American critics contend that change is still slow and that constant pressure is needed to keep the world body lumbering in the right direction.
Discussions with middle-level administrators over the last month found a consensus that the staff is renewing the idealism on which the United Nations was founded and that there has been a drop in the cynicism that gripped the headquarters building for years. 
This shift in attitude, however, is tempered by a sense that the United Nations does not have the money and muscle to meet the world's expectations of what it should be doing and by the slow pace of efforts to make the bureaucracy more efficient.
"The U.N. makes the U.S. Congress look as though it runs like a Swiss watch," said Timothy E. Wirth, the Under Secretary of State for Global Affairs, who served in the House and Senate for 15 years.
Another critic, Dick Thornburgh, the former Attorney General, who has studied the United Nations in detail, said: "The United Nations slumbered for years during the cold war and now there is a greater interest in performance because of its peacekeeping operations. I want to see the place run more efficiently."
A year ago, Mr. Thornburgh concluded in a report commissioned by officials of the United Nations that ithad indeed "shifted its focus from passively refereeing ideological differences to actively addressing pressing challenges in peacekeeping, humanitarian endeavors, economic and social development and human rights."
But he also concluded that "new blood" should be recruited to replace "deadwood" among the staff and that extensive changes in management were needed to make the United Nations run more smoothly.
Yet some middle-level officials maintain that change for the better is really taking place, even in the face of such responsibilities as 15 peacekeeping operations in the Americas, Africa, Asia and Europe involving 35,000 troops under United Nations command.
"Many United Nations workers are seeing themselves today in a different light -- as doers, not just talkers," said Mohammed Oummih, the Moroccan who heads the staff union representing 20,000 workers.
Krzysztof Wilski, a Pole who has been helping to plan the General Assembly session that starts next week, said the United Nations had not been given enough credit.
"Thornburgh looked for fraud, waste and mismanagement and of course it is here because there is a constant demand for our services and we do cost a lot," Mr. Wilski said. "But what he did not look at too closely was what is expected of us."
Sensitivity to criticism was expressed by Zohreh Tabatabai, an Iranian who has worked here for 20 years, most recently as a public policy adviser. For a long while, she said, she felt like a pariah.
"For years my New York friends and neighbors thought of us as a bunch of layabouts who had seven-hour, martini-filled lunches," Ms. Tabatabai said. "There is little understanding, even in New York, that the United Nations is representative of a group of states."
"In 1945 the United Nations had a meaning for the man in the street -- stop wars -- and people understood this," she said, adding that today's mission had been expanded into social issues and economic development "and we have failed to explain this lately."
"We here know that the world has to come together for a common future and that the United Nations is a cheaper, more logical, more judicial organization to bring this about."
Kofi Annan of Ghana, the Under Secretary General for Peacekeeping Operations, said the renewed sense of idealism should also be expanded into widespread changes in United Nations policies toward its increasing role as a world police force, if indeed that is what the member states want.
Mr. Annan said that despite some successful peacekeeping operations, the member nations had not faced up to the need for the money, the troops and the political will that peacekeeping requires.
"No one doubts that many thousands of lives could have been saved in Rwanda" if there had been a rapid deployment of troops under United Nations command at the start of the violence there, Mr. Annan said.
"The United Nations needs a short-response-time contingent of troops," a unit that would have is own arms and transportation, he added.
He also wants a permanent fund to pay for the start of any peacekeeping action as well as authority to carry it out. This authority must be considered by the General Assembly and the request acted upon because, Mr. Annan said, "the United Nations is arriving at its crossroads."

HEADLINE: Jury Finds San Francisco Police Violated Newspaper's Rights

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Former Chief Richard Hongisto and two police officers committed civil rights violations by seizing 2,000 copies of a free newspaper that lampooned Mr. Hongisto, a jury decided on Friday.
The Federal District Court jury awarded $5,600 to the paper, The Bay Times, for economic losses and $30,000 to its editor and publisher for emotional distress. The jury also said the City of San Francisco must pay all the damages as well as both sides' legal fees, which have been estimated by lawyers at $500,000. 
 The hearing will continue on Monday on possible punitive damages against Mr. Hongisto.
The Bay Times, a gay weekly, ran a cover story in May 1992 about Mr. Hongisto's ordering of the arrests of 2,000 demonstrators after the verdict in the first trial of four policemen accused of beating Rodney G. King in Los Angeles. A front-page cartoon showed the Chief holding a nightstick in a lewd manner.
Officers seized papers from news racks in the early morning but the newspaper got them back four days later. Mr. Hongisto, who was known for his liberal views and was appointed by Mayor Frank Jordan less than two months earlier, denied responsibility.
But the Police Commission dismissed Chief Hongisto a week after the incident, finding that officers acted in response to his orders or suggestions. Three officers served suspensions without pay; two, Gary Delagnes and Tom Yuen, were found liable in the civil suit with Mr. Hongisto.
During the trial, Mr. Hongisto testified that he had not ordered or expected large-scale seizures of the newspapers, but merely let Mr. Delagnes know that he wanted other officers to see the article. Mr. Hongisto said he considered the article fair because it quoted his defense of his actions during the arrests.
Lawyers for the officers argued that they did not violate the constitutional rights of The Bay Times or its readers by temporarily taking 2,000 of a press run of 40,000 papers. No one was deprived of a chance to read the article, said Mr. Hongisto's lawyer, Robert Moore.
But William Bennett Turner, lawyer for the newspaper and its editor, said the verdict showed that jurors believed the three men had interfered with the newspaper's circulation. It was not clear whether jurors held Mr. Hongisto responsible for ordering all the seizures, Mr. Turner said.
"We're supposed to have a free press," The Bay Times's editor, Kim Corsaro, said after the verdict. "Police can't go rounding up papers that aren't complimentary of them."
Mr. Moore said he would ask Judge D. Lowell Jensen to dismiss the claim for punitive damages.
Judge Jensen ruled early in the case that the city could not be sued for damages, because it had no policy of seizing newspapers based on their content. But the city was still held responsible the three men's damages and legal fees, because the judge found that they were carrying out their official duties during the incident.
The city plans to appeal that finding, Chief Assistant City Attorney Dennis Aftergut said. He said the jury's verdict was consistent with the city's view that "stealing newspapers is not within the duties of a police chief."
The jury rejected the city's claim that Mr. Hongisto acted with malice, or personal hatred, toward The Bay Times. A finding of malice would have required Mr. Hongisto to pay his own legal fees.
Mr. Turner said the jury could award punitive damages if it found that Mr. Hongisto had acted with reckless disregard of the constitutional rights of the newspaper and its editor.

HEADLINE: Korea Talks: Hint of Thaw

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 17

 BODY:
On the surface, it was not a good week for the barely thawed relationship between the United States and North Korea. In response to America's offer of economic assistance if North Korea halts its suspected nuclear weapons program, Pyongyang set its price so high that the once promising talks appeared to have gone into reverse. The North asked for a modern, $4 billion nuclear reactor of Pyongyang's choosing, an energy supply until the new reactor is completed and a few billion dollars in cash.
"It is ludicrous on the face of it that the D.P.R.K. suggests that they will decide the architecture and the United States will pay," Robert L. Gallucci, America's top negotiator, said at a news conference in Seoul. "I don't take it seriously." He was referring to the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, North Korea's official name. 
 But like many things related to the closed country, behind the hostile appearances was a more complex and not entirely discouraging reality: the negotiations, though tough, have not gone off track.
Given the record of the last two years, when the two sides moved close to a potentially hostile confrontation, the fact that the discussions remain businesslike and are continuing counts as real progress, even if a breakthrough seems remote.
On a more subtle level, the nitty-gritty nature of some of the discussions, and the fact that they concern nonmilitary issues, has helped begin the process of breaking down the cold war stereotypes the two countries hold of each other. "The old caricature of a bumbling, almost oafish bunch of blind Communist ideologues is no longer there," one American official said.
Those are what might be described as the side effects of the talks, and they are meaningful. Each side knows that a lot of confidence building will be required to alter four decades of bitterness and to pave the way for broader agreements.
But there is still the substance of the negotiations, and that is where the problems remain formidable.
The United States has still not persuaded North Korea to take the first and most important step in any agreement -- to allow nearly 8,000 spent nuclear fuel rods sitting in a cooling pond to be removed from North Korea so bomb-grade plutonium cannot be extracted from them.
North Korea violated an international order by removing those radioactive fuel rods from an experimental reactor this spring. After much prodding, it has only agreed to place them in a safer form of storage within the country. That shows some flexibility, but only to a point.
The United States has demanded that the rods be removed from North Korea for fear that the Koreans could reprocess the uranium in them and produce enough plutonium to build four or five nuclear bombs.
North Korea has also refused to allow international inspectors access to two key nuclear waste sites, where it is believed there may be evidence of how much bomb-grade plutonium the North Koreans have.
This week, the North Koreans permitted the inspectors access to two sites at its nuclear complex at Yongbyon, about 60 miles north of Pyongyang, the capital. But they were two low-level sites the inspectors had been able to visit previously.
"No, this is not a breakthrough," said David Kyd, a spokesman for the International Atomic Energy Agency. "It is a sign of slight additional flexibility." Thus, there was the hint of a change rather than substantive progress.
"My anxiety is that we're reliving last summer," said Leonard S. Spector, a nuclear expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington. "If you go through the press clips from last year, you'd find the same pattern as now."
For instance, North Korea already agreed once, in 1991, to forgo reprocessing spent nuclear fuel to produce plutonium. Now, Mr. Spector said, the situation has progressed to where it had been, but North Korea's agreement is considered a sign of flexibility. "The history of this thing leads one to caution," he said.
Indeed, one senior American official rejected the idea there was any optimism in Washington, saying such an assessment was premature. "The road is not well lit," he said.
And yet there has been enough movement for each of the warily circling competitors not to give up, to continue a process of changing their positions little by little.
"United States policy has not changed in 15 months," the senior American official insisted. "It doesn't mean there haven't been adjustments. There have been some tactical modifications."
