HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Cuomo Courts the Voters, One Interest Bloc at a Time

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Throughout the last year, with a tough re-election campaign ahead, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has romanced discontented New Yorkers with the candy and flowers of tax cuts and crime bills, proposals calculated to seduce middle-of-the-road swing voters.
But as the election nears, Mr. Cuomo is also working aggressively to shore up his base among traditional Democratic constituencies, including trade unionists, women and black, Hispanic and Jewish voters. And so even as his television ads seek to persuade undecided voters, Mr. Cuomo's schedulers have him sprinting from union halls to black churches, from yeshivas to Caribbean parades. 
 Everywhere he goes, he practices the politics of empathy, seeking to connect by casually dropping a phrase in Hebrew or Spanish, by addressing union members as "brothers and sisters," by praising a Baptist choir as sounding sweet enough to make God smile. He tells Jews it was "a man by the name of Kessler" who first helped his father, an illiterate immigrant, establish a grocery store. He reminds Hispanic people that he and his wife, Matilda, honeymooned at the Condado Beach Hotel in Puerto Rico, "cuarenta y uno anos" ago.
While flattering these audiences with idiom and anecdote, Mr. Cuomo also is not above playing on his listeners' fears of Republicanism, which he equates with political Darwinism. In the process, he paints his campaign in epochal terms.
"The question, really, in this race and all across the country," he said last week in accepting the endorsement of the Council of Black Elected Democrats, "is whether we will be a confident nation that will find a way to do for everyone, or whether you will shrink back and say no, we cannot afford to do it, let the fit survive. If you announce in New York State that we're going to give up on our poor people, that will be a signal to the whole United States of America that they should do the same."
Mr. Cuomo's dual strategy of seeking to capture the center while invigorating the left -- and other longtime loyalists, like Orthodox Jews and trade unionists -- is not without risk. As his campaign against State Senator George E. Pataki becomes increasingly ideological, the Governor cannot afford to reinforce Mr. Pataki's new advertising slogan that he has been "too liberal for too long," strategists in both parties agree.
The state's swing voters, including many of the 1.1 million New Yorkers who sided with Ross Perot in 1992, may be exactly the kind of people who would respond to the Governor's calls for cuts in taxes, mandatory life sentences for repeat violent offenders and revamped election laws. But they also may be the kind who would be most alienated by his eager courtship of Democratic interest groups.
Furthermore, Mr. Cuomo must walk a precarious line between effective campaigning and perceived contradiction.
In selling himself to fiscal conservatives, for instance, he has worn his willingness to deny raises to state workers as a badge of courage and leadership. But Mr. Cuomo now finds himself begging for union help and describing himself, as he did this week to leaders of the Transport Workers Union, as a stronger backer of organized labor than ever before.
Recent polls have indicated that the race is tight, and that perhaps 15 to 20 percent of the electorate is undecided. The Cuomo campaign is pursuing those voters with ads that highlight Mr. Cuomo's record and depict Mr. Pataki as untrustworthy, inconsistent and too close to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
And yet, top Democrats acknowledge that after 12 years of incumbency and a four-year economic decline, Mr. Cuomo is not popular enough to defeat Mr. Pataki without an enthusiastic turnout of the faithful on Nov. 8. Mr. Cuomo expects help from other members of the ticket, Karen S. Burstein, who is running for Attorney General, and State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, who is black, but realizes he cannot totally rely on them.
"I think he understands not only that keeping the base deep and highly motivated is the most important thing in this race," said Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president.
Mr. Cuomo put it more bluntly last week when he accepted the endorsement of black Democratic officials. "I must have their community's votes," he said. "If I don't get them turning out in very large numbers, I lose."
Simple mathematics suggests that Mr. Cuomo is right. He starts the campaign with a significant advantage in Democratic enrollment. Forty-eight percent of the state's voters are registered as either Democrats or Liberals, the two ballot lines Mr. Cuomo will hold in November, compared with 32 percent who are Republicans or Conservatives, Mr. Pataki's two lines.
But Mr. Cuomo also is fighting several electoral trends. The proportion of the statewide vote cast in New York City, the Governor's geographic base, slipped from 31 percent in 1982 to 29 percent in 1986 to 27 percent in 1990. A continuation of that slide could be decisive in a close race because Mr. Cuomo has won 67 percent of the votes cast in New York City in his three elections, compared with 48 percent in the rest of the state.
Surveys of voters leaving polling places show that Mr. Cuomo's support among women, union members, minorities and Jews has generally exceeded his support statewide. It is those crucial elements of the Democratic coalition in New York that Mr. Cuomo is pursuing with a breakneck schedule and with the wily charms of a consummate New York politician who understands the power of ethnicity and shared struggle.
On Sunday, Mr. Cuomo is to tour the Lower East Side, sampling sour pickles and shopping for a black fedora, before racing to Harlem in time for the African-American Day Parade. In Brooklyn last Sunday, he darted from the First Baptist Church of Crown Heights to the Church of the Transfiguration, where the Roman Catholic Mass is said in Spanish, to the synagogue of the Bobover Hasidic sect. At each appearance, he expressed humility for past support, boasted of spoils he had delivered and ingratiated without shame.
At the Hispanic church, he reminisced about crying in frustration as a boy because his school taught English and he spoke only Italian. "I do feel especially close to people who are Latino and people who are like me," he said. "Why? It's human nature. I feel at home with Latinos. I can converse with them. Our instincts and our impulses and even our rhythms are very, very similar."
Mr. Cuomo told the Hasidim that as a child he was a "Shabbos goy," a Gentile who works in the synagogue on the Sabbath, when observant Jews are prohibited from performing even menial tasks like turning on lights. And he heaped blandishments on Shlomo Halberstam, the chief rabbi of the Bobovers.
"I speak to President Clinton from time to time," Mr. Cuomo said as dark-suited men crowded against each other. "I was invited by President Bush and by President Reagan. That happens to governors. I've been with Rabin and Peres. I've been with the emperor and the empress. I've been all over the world with great leaders. There is no leader in the world that I have been prouder to be welcomed as a guest by than Rabbi Shlomo Halberstam."
Rabbi Halberstam told Mr. Cuomo, "I wish you should be our Governor for the future." To which Mr. Cuomo responded, "If God wishes, I will be here for four more years, and I promise I will be useful to you every way I can be." The Governor later explained that Rabbi Halberstam did not make endorsements but was simply offering his "broche," or blessing.
The pattern is much the same when Mr. Cuomo speaks to trade unionists. In addressing a conference of the Laborers' International Union last week, he joked that he was "comfortable in the pockets of the unions."
When he accepted endorsements this week from the state's corrections officers and from New York City transit workers, he recited a high-minded history lesson on organized labor. Then he pointed out that he walked picket lines during strikes at The Daily News and Eastern Air Lines. "I'm very proud of that," he told leaders of the Transport Workers Union on Wednesday. "Is it a political plus? They tell me it's a political negative. I don't believe that anything that makes as much sense as my position on unions could be a political negative."
Jan D. Pierce, the vice president of the Communications Workers of America and a longtime Cuomo supporter, said the Governor's attentiveness is paying dividends. "He has been to a couple of our events, and it has shown results in the number of volunteers we've been putting into phone banks," he said. "He has a way of making people proud of their heritage and affiliations. And it is paying off because I see the enthusiasm being reignited in the rank and file."

HEADLINE: After Half a Century, the U.N. Tries to Redefine Itself for a New World

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 16

 BODY:
The United Nations, which opens its 49th General Assembly session on Tuesday, is heading into a year of unusual scrutiny as diplomats, bureaucrats, scholars and a throng of increasingly powerful nongovernmental pressure groups are prodding the vast organization to reinvent itself for a world very different than the one it has known in its first half-century of life.
The task lurks behind the celebratory hoopla planned for the coming months, when symphony orchestras and rock groups will play, thinkers will think aloud at countless seminars, dancers will dance, and children all over the world will collectively write and illustrate a book about how the United Nations looks to them. A roster of special events that have already begun and will continue into 1996 is already nine pages long. 
 By contrast, the coming General Assembly session is expected to be subdued, with few explosive issues on the agenda.
Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali calls this "a time to rekindle the ideals of the Charter." The aim of the United Nations Charter -- to be commemorated in San Francisco in June, 50 years after the document's signing -- was to cement a lasting peace and international well-being after devastation of World War II.
Now, after the cold war has ended, and with it the superpower standoff that often paralyzed United Nations debate, there are more calls for the world body to turn its attention to safeguarding the planet's resources, starting with its environment and its poorest people, who are the majority and are the source of its migrant populations.
Others suggest that the organization could move more aggressively into controlling the spread of nuclear weapons or intervening in human rights disputes before they become new ethnic wars.
The Secretary General has said he would like to see the organization become more active in building democratic institutions, from parliaments to a free press -- as it tried to do in Cambodia -- though this would certainly lead to a dispute over national sovereignty and the limitations of the United Nations rights to interfere in domestic politics.
There are also renewed proposals for reform and reduction in the huge international civil service the United Nations has spawned in New York, Washington, Geneva, Rome, Vienna, Bangkok, Nairobi and other cities.
But these demands come at a time when regional conflicts preoccupy the United Nations -- causing even more appointments to be made and staffs created -- and when peacekeeping operations tax the organization's finances.
"The developing countries say that the agenda for peace is consuming too much time," said Stanley Kalpage, Sri Lanka's chief delegate. "They want an agenda for development."
Small nations also fear the precedent of military intervention by bigger powers acting under United Nations sanction.
There seems to be broad agreement that the support of the United States is critical if the United Nations is to become more than an international police agency carrying out punitive expeditions against rogue governments.
"Peacekeeping, which has all the financing -- and all the heartaches -- will take up all the attention," said Shirin Tahir-Kheli, a fellow with the Woodrow Wilson School of International Affairs at Princeton University. "But I do think that the nuclear issue, for example, should be taken up by the United Nations, and with a fraction of the cost."
Ms. Tahir-Kheli, who has been director of political-military affairs and head of Near East and South Asian affairs on the National Security Council, said only the United States has "the clout, the stakes and the relationships" to force this issue in places like India and Pakistan, where local conciliation has always failed and the fear of nuclear war is always present.
"From the 1950's, the United States has been vibrantly active in the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna, and at least in part the success of the I.A.E.A. is very much a testament to our staying the course," she said in an interview from Islamabad, Pakistan, during a visit to South Asia. "But that's a technical agency. We have been very reluctant to become involved politically."
 
New Attitude
High Marks For Clinton
 As the new General Assembly approaches, a variety of diplomats at the United Nations say they like what they have seen of the Clinton Administration.
"We are not always sure whether Clinton will move this way or that way, or whether he will move at all, but the feeling is that the Clinton Administration is much better than its predecessors at the U.N.," an Asian delegate said. He added that this change in the American attitude could not have come at a more propitious time.
President Clinton, who is to address the General Assembly on Sept. 26, can point to a series of policy changes. Congress has released about $1.2 billion to pay some of Washington's peacekeeping bills.
American officials, led by Timothy E. Wirth, Under Secretary of State for Global Affairs, have made a point of listening to the concerns of developing nations and working to build consensus on issues of importance to them and to the Islamic world. This was demonstrated at the recent conference on population in Cairo, where American delegates won praise from former critics on many issues.
Steven A. Dimoff, editor of Washington Weekly Report, which monitors Congressional action affecting international organizations, said there were indications that Mr. Clinton might formally announce that the United States would return to to Unesco, the United Nations cultural agency from which it withdrew under President Reagan.
The agency, which was widely accused of mismanagement, corruption and undermining the free flow of news and information, has since been reformed under a new Director General, Federico Mayor of Spain. But returning to Unesco, which is based in Paris, could cost Washington more than $50 million a year.
"Everybody in the Administration loves Unesco, but nobody can find the money to get us back in," said Mr. Dimoff, whose newsletter is published by the United Nations Association.
 
Old Mistrust
United Nations Still a Hard Sell
 Points of friction remain, among them concerns among American diplomats that Secretary General Boutros-Ghali has thrust himself to the forefront of too much United Nations activity, not always consulting the Security Council, which has assumed a major role in world affairs since the collapse of the Soviet Union.
Some American officials argue that it is harder to sell the idea of more American participation in the United Nations if a single figure is perceived to be towering over the President. Mr. Boutros-Ghali has announced that he will seek another five-year term in office after 1996.
Mr. Dimoff agrees that if the Clinton Administration is friendlier to the United Nations, the same can still not be said of many members of Congress and the American public.
"The legacy of the 1970's still haunts the policymakers' views," he said. "They define the U.N. by the experiences of the 70's, when contentious debates led to polarization."
He said teaching about the United Nations appears to have fallen off in American schools; he recently found only one reference to the organization in an 11th-grade history textbook. The United Nations Association is directing its special publicity efforts toward children in the anniversary year.
 
The Future
New Alliances Are Forming
 As the United Nations moves into its next half-century, old alliances are in flux and new ones are forming within the organization.
"I think the emergence of the European Union is very important to this process," said Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, United States delegate to the United Nations in the Reagan Administration and who now teaches French politics at Georgetown University. "It is more important than I think Americans have generally understood it to be, and I think it has big consequences for us in multilateral institutions like the U.N.
"The European Union has developed institutions for reaching agreed consensus positions on issues before they come to a discussion of those issues with the United States, or before they come to discussion in U.N. arenas," she said in a recent interview. In effect, she added, this will mean a solid bloc of votes not subject to division by American persuasion on issues where in the past a few European nations might have sided with Washington.
"It's going to be a shock to Americans to find that our best friends, the countries with whom we have been most closely associated in all these arenas, will be committed to positions almost written in stone," Dr. Kirkpatrick said.
Diplomats and nongovernmental organizations working with United Nations agencies echo those conclusions. At the population conference in Cairo, some groups bemoaned the loss of independent Scandinavian voices that could have been counted on to take more liberal positions than nations of southern Europe.
But if Europe is coalescing, the developing nations are in disarray, having lost the support of Moscow in confrontations with the richer industrialized countries.
"The unity of the Nonaligned Movement, the unity of the G-77 is not there," said Dr. Kalpage, Sri Lanka's chief delegate. "These countries are building their policies on bilateral ties with more powerful nations or with the international lending organizations -- the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund."
Sri Lanka was a founding member of both the Nonaligned Movement, which often sided with the Soviet bloc, and the Group of 77 (now with 134 members), which concentrated on economic and social problems in the third world, often demanding compensation from the West.
Third world organizations are not only weaker after the cold war, Dr. Kalpage said, but are also threatened by the economic demands of Eastern Europe and the new countries created by the breakup of the Soviet Union.
"The countries that call themselves economies in transition are vying for funds in every agency," he said. "On any issue they want to be mentioned. This is causing problems for developing countries."
The United Nations is going to try to address the problems of world poverty and the development of human resources at a conference that is to be attended by heads of state in March in Copenhagen.
Diplomats from developing nations say that the Russians have all but disappeared from view after decades of courting third world support with a variety of enticements.
"Now Moscow goes out of its way to support the United States," Dr. Kalpage said. "Or they speak for the economies in transition. They don't come around to us. They are not heard much. Their presence is diminished."

HEADLINE: Hasidic and Hispanic Residents in Williamsburg Try to Forge a New Unity

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
Division Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is just that: a demarcation line between Hasidic Jews, who live, for the most part, to the north, and Hispanic residents to the south. But there is no dividing the air over Williamsburg.
In that irrefutable fact lie the roots of a budding cooperation between two groups that have, for three decades, written a history of contention and sometimes violent confrontation. 
 "We all breathe the same air," said Luis Garden Acosta, president of El Puente (the Bridge), a nonprofit organization that provides services to Hispanic residents, particularly the young.
It was a common concern over the quality of that air, mainly among young people, that planted seeds of cooperation for a campaign against a host of environmental ills afflicting the neighborhood. Now, Hasidic and Hispanic leaders are increasingly working together to solve problems like unemployment, lack of housing and the appropriate balance of municipal services.
It is an unlikely turn of events in a crowded neighborhood where the demand for scarce housing and city services has led to violence between Hasidic and Hispanic residents. In the past, leaders of the two groups were as likely to encounter one another over police barricades and at sit-ins as at community meetings.
But today they are writing a 10-year plan for Williamsburg. Their hopes include providing shared services for fledgling businesses, rehabilitating an apartment building that will be shared by Hispanic and Hasidic residents and winning Federal designation as an Enterprise Community -- a prize that would bring $10 million in grants to the area.
Mr. Garden Acosta and others credit the neighborhood's young people, particularly a group called the Toxic Avengers, as the initiators behind the closer ties.
"It was nothing but confrontation before young people from the Toxic Avengers came to me and said, 'Isn't it time to ask the Hasidim to join forces with us in reclaiming our environment?' " he said.
The Toxic Avengers are members of El Puente's youth group, concerned principally with plans to construct a garbage incinerator with a 500-foot stack at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and the continuing operation of Radiac, a low-level radioactive waste storage operation on Kent Avenue by the East River, one block from both a public school and a Roman Catholic school. They are still fighting those battles.
They found an ally in Rabbi David Niederman, a leader of the Satmar Hasidim and director of the United Jewish Organizations of Williamsburg. As Mr. Garden Acosta recounts those events in May 1991, "it was a historic moment when a Hasidic rabbi, a leader of the Satmar, walked through the doors of El Puente. We were planning a march to a hearing on Radiac emergency procedures, and Rabbi Niederman volunteered to help lead that march through Latino streets. I can't describe what a change that meant. It was a clear act of courage on the part of David Niederman."
Rabbi Niederman did not see it as courageous, just necessary. "We were facing the incinerator, lead poisoning from the garbage transfer stations, chemicals from abandoned factories around here, sandblasting from the bridge and Radiac," he said. "We held rallies together, meetings with the former mayor."
A year later, 1,200 people squeezed into the auditorium at Public School 16 to voice anger over the proposed incinerator. Out of that meeting came the Community Alliance for the Environment, a group of 20 organizations representing the neighborhood's ethnic groups.
It was not always so in Williamsburg.
For three decades, Hispanic and Hasidic residents clashed, particularly over housing, in the tightly packed community of century-old walk-ups, abandoned factories and warehouses. Each group, in its own way, was clinging to its toehold in a new land. At the heart of the discord was population growth. Between 1980 and 1990, the Hasidic and Hispanic populations in the Community Board 1 area both increased by 14 percent. The Board 1 area has 156,000 residents, 44 percent Hispanic and 46 percent non-Hispanic white. A study by the United Talmudic Association last year reported that the average Hasidic family in Williamsburg has 7.8 children.
When urban renewal in the 1960's and 70's razed scores of old buildings in favor of high-rise housing projects, Hispanic residents grew suspicious that most of the new apartments were going to the Hasidim. One night in 1974, just before the federally subsidized Roberto Clemente Houses were to open, 500 Hispanic people cajoled a sympathetic superintendent to let them into the apartments. The subsequent occupation turned violent, and bottles were thrown from windows. A 1977 consent decree stipulated that 51 percent of the project's apartments must go to Hispanic families.
Throughout the years, Hispanic residents have also contended that the area's Jewish residents received a disproportionate share of city services and that the police both protected the Hasidim and were reluctant to arrest them.
In 1990, tension turned to violence when 300 Hasidim protesting the arrest of a sect member on sexual assault charges demonstrated outside the 90th Precinct station house. Forty-five police officers were injured. Then, in July 1992, the beating of a 13-year-old Hispanic boy by a Hasidic man who had accused him of shoplifting prompted a demonstration by 75 Hispanic residents.
"This was Crown Heights before Crown Heights," Mr. Garden Acosta said.
Today, partnerships between Hasidic and Hispanic groups are flowering to fight the neighborhood's myriad problems. Under an agreement between El Puente and the United Jewish Organizations, all children in Williamsburg will be offered a screening test for lead poisoning this year. Last year, nine groups representing all segments of Williamsburg's population formed the Neighborhood-Based Alliance to coordinate and channel state grants for developing community resources.
The enterprise community designation, sought under Federal legislation that also created the larger empowerment zones, is being pushed by a partnership made up of the United Jewish Organizations, the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation, the St. Nicholas Neighborhood Preservation Corporation and Los Sures, a Hispanic low-income housing group.
Elizabeth Colon, executive officer of the Navy Yard corporation, said that changing economic realities are behind the closer ties between Hasidic and Hispanic residents. "Unemployment and a deteriorating economic base have surpassed housing as an issue for Williamsburg," she said. That, along with environmental issues, has spurred the "two groups to work together toward the future."
But in a community long clenched by distrust, good intentions do not always translate into reality.
Los Sures has entered into a partnership with Rabbi Niederman's group to rehabilitate a six-story building at 907 Driggs Avenue, in the heart of the Hasidic area, for eventual occupancy by both Hispanic and Hasidic tenants. But last November, after 200 Hispanic people occupied a new housing project on Berry Street, voicing concerns reminiscent of the Clemente Houses battle, Rabbi Niederman pulled out of the Driggs Avenue project. Feeling betrayed by anti-Semitic remarks made by some protesters and pointing out that a worker for Los Sures participated in the occupation, the rabbi said then, "I don't know if they would alert me if they saw someone running at my back with a knife."
Soon after, however, Rabbi Niederman said, the head of Los Sures, David Pagan, called, saying the anti-Semitic remarks and occupation did not reflect the feelings of the group, which was committed to working with the rabbi. Since then, plans for the Driggs Avenue project have proceeded.
Rabbi Niederman sees improved relations with the Hispanic leadership as the beginning of "a new era for the community."
Mr. Garden Acosta was more cautious. Asked if the spirit of cooperation has filtered down to the street, he said: "Do I think this new era is so rooted that we may never see the clashes we've seen in the past? The answer is that I pray every day to find ways of bridging what is still a formidable gap.
"While many of us have embraced this new spirit of dialogue and coalition building," he said, "we have lived with the albatross of suspicion and even physical confrontation around our necks for so long that I cannot say we've entirely thrown it off yet."

Rabbi Niederman's group has joined with Los Sures, a Hispanic housing group, to turn the building into housing for Hasidic and Hispanic residents. (Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Electric Car Debate Continues

 BODY:
To the Editor:
S. David Freeman gives the wrong conclusion about electric cars. They are not practical for most uses because they are too costly to produce. 
 Wider understanding that electric cars are not competitive in an unregulated market may improve government policies. Increasing use of electric cars is in the national interest, but we are about to embark on a bad way to make this happen: government mandates that each automobile company must sell a minimum number of electric vehicles.
Imposing minimum-sale requirements is an easy solution for politicians, but a bad one for the economy. Electric-car development will be paid by people buying new gasoline-powered cars, because costs of those cars will increase to cover electric-car losses. One result will be decreased new-car sales and more polluting old cars on the road.
A better way would be cash subsidies to electric-car buyers to get the targeted number sold. The money could come from general tax funds or a higher gasoline tax. Such a policywould eliminate the disincentive for new-car purchases and would not require that every automobile company produce electric cars immediately -- allowing for economies of scale that could mean huge savings.
 
JAMES L. HECHT
Wilmington, Del., Sept. 1
 
The writer is an affiliated professor at Temple University.

HEADLINE: Sept. 11-17: A Near Miss;
A Suicidal Pilot Sets Off Alarms At the White House

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

 BODY:
Call it the curse of Blair House.
 The Clintons became the first First Family in more than 40 years to move temporarily to Blair House, the official guest quarters across the street from the White House, so that the executive mansion could be renovated. The last Presidential occupant was Harry S. Truman, and while he was at the guest residence in 1950 a pair of Puerto Rican nationalists tried unsuccessfully to shoot their way in to assassinate him. In the shootout, a bodyguard and an assailant were killed.
 
 Early Monday morning, while the Clintons slept in Blair House, an unemployed truck driver stole a single-engine plane and crashed it onto the lawn right under the President's bedroom at the White House. No one tried to stop the plane, and by some accounts, White House guards spotted it only seconds before it crashed.
 The Secret Service said its early investigation indicated that the pilot, Frank Eugene Corder, was suicidal.
 His third marriage and his small trucking business in shambles, Mr. Corder had moved to a shabby motel room in Aberdeen, Md., and, on the day before his final flight, he had been smoking crack and drinking beer and cheap wine.
 Security officials were rattled. If a confused, unhappy and intoxicated man with limited flying skill could blunder into a near-hit on the President's bedroom with no resistance from the President's bodyguards, then what might a determined, skilled and knowledgeable assassin accomplish? STEPHEN LABATON

HEADLINE: Senator Dole vs. Free Trade

 BODY:
The Senate minority leader, Robert Dole, tried hard to sabotage health care reform this year. Now he threatens to sabotage open trade -- by blocking approval of the international trade accord the Administration signed last April in Marrakesh, Morocco. That is an odd stance for the leader of the party that has traditionally stood for free trade. But Mr. Dole appears more intent on humiliating President Clinton before the November elections than on serving the nation's 250 million other citizens. The danger is that U.S. delay encourages protectionists abroad who desperately search for any excuse to sidetrack ratification of free trade.
The Administration bears some blame for Mr. Dole's chokehold. It waited too long to make a key concession. There are only about 20 working days left before Congress breaks for elections; the time crunch puts Mr. Dole in charge. He can say that he wants a trade pact this year -- mollifying his big-business and farm constituencies that have the most to gain from the Marrakesh accord -- while dallying so that the legislation dies from neglect. 
 Last week the Administration acceded to political reality. It dropped a provision from its draft bill to implement the accord that would have granted the President the right to negotiate future trade agreements under a legislative rule known as fast track -- which requires Congress to vote on a proposed trade pact quickly and without amendment. Opponents of fast track feared the Administration would use the hurry-up procedure to ram through undesirable provisions on labor conditions and environmental protection. Even some advocates of fast track opposed its inclusion in the bill because they wanted Congress to have the opportunity to vote on it as a separate matter. The Administration conceded in order to break the logjam.
Having won on fast track, Mr. Dole now says he is dissatisfied with several other provisions, such as the Administration's plan to make up for the Federal revenues that would be lost when tariffs are lowered. True, the Administration's revenue-raising estimates look optimistic. But Mr. Dole surely has seen studies showing that the trade pact is likely to raise revenues by triggering economic growth and, thereby, raising tax collections. Also, Mr. Dole says fellow Kansans are worried about the World Trade Organization, which the Marrakesh accord establishes to adjudicate trade disputes. But rather than assuring his constituents that the W.T.O. was built to U.S. specification to protect its exporters, Mr. Dole panders to unwarranted fears.
The Marrakesh accord will open up foreign countries to U.S. exports of insurance and other services, protect U.S. sales of computer software and other intellectual property and guarantee U.S. investors fair treatment. That may raise living standards in the U.S. by as much as $1,700 a family. That would in effect honor Mr. Clinton's campaign pledge to help the middle class. For the sake of his political ambitions, Mr. Dole is asking Americans to sacrifice quite a lot.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: How Cairo Conference Echoed Health Debate;
California's Better Deal

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Michael Goldeen (letter, Sept. 11) argues that you can buy a "truly affordable" medical insurance plan in California for $39 a month if you're younger than 30, provided you "take responsibility for the first $2,000 a year" and "some of the next $10,000." This, he implies, would be a much better deal than paying 7 percent to 14 percent under the proposed California Health Security Plan. This is simplistic at best.
 
 First, the 14 percent figure would only apply to those with taxable incomes above $250,000 ($500,000 for families). The maximum rate on all other Californians ranges from 8.9 percent to 12.4 percent. The imaginary 29-year-old who pays a premium of $468 a year would be liable for out-of-pocket medical costs of $4,000 a year assuming a co-payment of 20 percent out of the $10,000.
 Even if we assume this Californian were taxed at the maximum 12.4 percent rate, he or she would not pay the state as much as it would cost for medical care as under Mr. Goldeen's "truly affordable" insurance plan, unless that individual earned $36,000 or more a year.
 According to the 1990 Census, half of the full-time male workers in California earned less than that; 48.8 percent of all households earned less than $35,000 a year. That's a high percentage for whom the California Health Security Plan is a better deal.
 With everyone in one large insurance pool under the state's single-payer plan, the trade-off of an increase in customers for the end of price inflation will be satisfactory to the health care providers, as well as patients.
MICHAEL MEEROPOL
JAMES DEVINE
Springfield, Mass., Sept. 13, 1994
The writers are economics professors at, respectively, Western New England College and Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles.

HEADLINE: How Cairo Conference Echoed Health Debate

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The news from the United Nations population conference in Cairo was depressing in its avoidance of central issues, namely that any child conceived, let alone born, should have the nurture, education and work opportunity to realize his or her capabilities; and second, that the increasing load of humanity this earth must bear is making the first objective very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve for most people.
 
 Pope John Paul II's proscriptions appear to contradict these fundamentals: to advocate means of population control that can be successfully implemented only by the disciplined and educated is to advocate population of the world by the careless and ignorant.
 Surely the Pope realizes the consequences of his rules. Such policy is particularly perverse when the pattern of economic development favors the disciplined and educated, as shown by the East Asian countries that are rising in affluence.
 The Cairo debate recalls the health care debate in the United States. The Pope appears to agree with Hillary Rodham Clinton that Madison, Hamilton, Franklin and other framers of our Constitution in 1787 were wrong in believing that the way to bring about fundamental change is to bring representatives of all views together, to work out a few basic principles that can be expressed in a dozen pages or less and then to explain these publicly, so that a well-informed public opinion is brought to bear on legislators.
 While health care reform is more complicated, a better statement could have been made on the principles behind the details, like bringing the cost-consciousness of free enterprise to bear on rising medical costs.
WILLIAM M. KAULA
Prof. of Earth and Space Sciences
University of California
Los Angeles, Sept. 12, 1994

HEADLINE: In the Land of the Orthopedic Implant

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: WARSAW, Ind.

 BODY:
HERE in the town that is to bone surgery what Detroit is to cars and Hollywood is to movies, the inability of Congress to agree on health care reform is widely seen as a blessing. Not only is the northeastern corner of the state politically conservative, but some of the measures that have been proposed could make life difficult for orthopedics manufacturers, a $6 billion-a-year industry born here nearly a century ago.
Manufacturers of artificial knees, hips and other orthopedic devices based here these days include Zimmer, a Bristol-Myers Squibb Company subsidiary that is the market leader; DePuy Inc., a Corange Ltd. subsidiary that was the industry pioneer, and Biomet Inc., a fast-growing, publicly traded upstart. These companies, along with smaller competitors and suppliers, helped Warsaw sail smoothly through the recessions that socked most of the Midwest during the 1980's. They account for more than 40 percent of the nation's output of orthopedic implants, a share that has been creeping up as they acquire smaller players. 
 "We are sympathetic to their complaints of overregulation," said Jeffrey Plank, Warsaw's mayor, smiling at the understatement.
Warsaw's special ties to the orthopedics industry are not immediately obvious to a visitor to the community, which has 11,500 residents. The town is home to other manufacturers, including a mammoth R. R. Donnelley & Sons printing plant that employs 1,550 people and is about to expand. And Warsaw is the commercial heart of Kosciusko County, one of the nation's most fertile farming regions and a popular resort area because of its many lakes. There are no statues of the orthopedics industry's founders, no parks or schools named after them, and the local school mascot is not a surgeon but a tiger.
Still, Warsaw is the only place in the world that not only has a rock band called Morris Taper and the Reamers but also thousands of residents who appreciate the joking reference to an artificial hip joint design -- the Morse taper -- and the devices used to prepare bones for an implant. And where else would a golf competition between teams from major employers be known as the Lesser Trochanter Open, a reference to a bony protrusion on the hip where leg muscles are attached?
"I'm always amused at how many people from this small town I run into in places like Seoul or San Francisco at international medical meetings," said Ron Davis, president of Zimmer.
In all, the orthopedics manufacturers employ more than 4,000 people in Warsaw and the surrounding region. Hundreds of them are employed by a host of specialty manufacturers that have grown up to serve the big orthopedics companies. Othy Inc., for instance, processes components for the manufacturers and many of their out-of-town rivals on its computer-controlled machine tools and makes specialty screw drivers, mallets, orthopedic forceps and tools that clean debris from joints before implants are placed in them.
Other suppliers cast metal into shapes approximating implants, which are then shipped to manufacturers for precision work, put the final polish on metal joints made by the larger companies or provide specialized heat treatments. One company, the manufacturing arm of Memphis-based Sofamor Danek Inc., started out as a supplier when half of it was locally owned and known as Warsaw Orthopedics but now is the market leader in the rapidly growing, $200 million market for spinal implants.
Danek's evolution is only the latest sign that today's employee, supplier or partner can be tomorrow's competitor in the orthopedics business. The modern industry was born in 1895 when Revra DePuy began making wire splints here as an alternative to the barrel staves doctors had traditionally used to set broken bones. Justin O. Zimmer, his first traveling salesman, went into business for himself in 1927 when Mr. DePuy's widow refused to give him part ownership of the company and to follow his advice to add aluminum splints to the product line. Mr. Zimmer foresaw that such splints, which do not interfere with X-ray imaging, would quickly become preferred by doctors.
Seven years later, another DePuy salesman founded Richards, a Memphis-based company that is now a subsidiary of Britain's Smith & Nephew P.L.C. and one of the industry's major players. More recently, Biomet was formed in 1977 by Dane Miller and Jerry Ferguson, two Zimmer executives who felt that company had become too bureaucratic as it grew in the years after its 1972 acquisition by Bristol-Myers.
THE Warsaw companies cooperate locally on a number of social and educational activities. They provided much of the machinery and cash the town needed to match a $250,000 state grant to build a machine tool complex for high school and vocational college students that is specially geared toward training students for jobs in the industry. More recently, they provided a large chunk of the money to turn more than 60 acres of land donated by Donnelley on the western outskirts of town into a complex of baseball and soccer fields. But there is intense rivalry too.
"There aren't enough restaurants in town so that you are bound to bump into the others," said Todd Smith, director of research at DePuy. "We have to converse very quietly to keep our secrets."
Mayor Plank is well aware of such minor drawbacks and a few larger ones, such as the lack of commercial air service to accommodate the thousands of surgeons, technical experts and sales people the companies bring to town each year for meetings. "This community isn't just where they make products," Mayor Plank said. "It's also their sales room."
Unless industry trends change, the companies may find it increasingly difficult to be as generous to Warsaw as they have been in the past. The orthopedics industry has run into slower growth than it has been accustomed to as health maintenance organizations and hospital administrators strive to drive down spending. The inability of the overburdened Food and Drug Administration to act quickly on petitions to approve new medical devices is also hurting.
Growth rates for both hip and knee replacements, the biggest chunk of the market, fell sharply in 1993. The increase in the number of operations did not keep up with the trend projected from the aging of the population, price increases were smaller than in the past and the mix shifted toward less expensive products, according to industry analysts.
Joel Zimmerman, who follows the industry for Lehman Brothers, estimated that domestic sales of hips and knees rose just 5.7 percent in 1993, to $1.62 billion, compared with a 15.4 percent increase in 1992. Nor does he see any reason for traditional double-digit growth rates to resume soon. In fact, although he expects the number of artificial knees and hips implanted this year to inch up from 344,000 to 355,000, he projects a drop back to the 344,000 level in 1995. In a truly strict cost control environment, he figures, the number of knee replacements could fall by 25 percent and hip replacements by 10 percent.
COMPANY executives here say the slowdown in unit sales is harder to explain than the cost pressures. Longer-lasting products, growing conservatism among surgeons and uncertainty about insurance coverage may all be factors.
"We are learning to speak the language of managed care," said William Tidmore, president of DePuy. "We were always aware of things like how long it took to put one of our products in a patient and how quickly they could be released from a hospital, but now we are more concerned about documenting the costs."
The one thing the executives agree on is that there is more danger than hope on the horizon in Washington. Congress has been considering proposals that could cap spending on orthopedic devices along with drugs and other medical treatments. The proposals also include various types of Government review and management agencies that the companies say would stifle innovation.
The company executives here say such inhibitions on research and development would come at a crucial time in the industry's history. While further improvements in materials are expected, several of the companies are betting that the next big breakthroughs will come from using biological agents to stimulate restoration of human bones, either alone or in connection with mechanical implants.
The direction of orthopedics research and product development could also be thrown into turmoil if pharmaceutical companies can successfully develop drugs to prevent osteoporosis or osteoarthritis, diseases that account for a large percentage of bone replacement surgery in older people.
To defend their point of view, the executives have been relying largely on the lobbying expertise of the Health Equipment Manufacturers Association in Washington or of their parent companies.
Among those most affected by the market-driven changes already under way are Zimmer and How medica, a Pfizer Inc. subsidiary based in New Jersey that is the industry's second-largest company. Analysts believe both are losing market share. Zimmer has cut its workforce here by 350, to 1,900, since 1992, partly by layoffs that were the first ever in Warsaw by one of the major orthopedics companies.
But even Biomet, which has been gaining on its competitors, has been hurt by failing to keep up with Wall Street's expectations -- its stock topped $23 in early 1992 but then fell in stages to a low of $8.875 in September 1993, before edging back up. It closed Friday at $11.875.
"A lot of my neighbors bought near $20 so you can bet I hear about it," said Mr. Miller, the company's chief executive.

 CORRECTION:
An article about orthopedic implant manufacturers based in Warsaw, Ind., misidentified the trade organization that represents the industry in Washington lobbying. It is the Health Industry Manufacturers Association.

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 1; Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1640 words

HEADLINE: Crime Moves Into New Arenas And Justice Rushes to Catch Up

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
THEY lurk along the back alleys of cyberspace scouting out new territory and victims for their crimes. Their milieu: the bulletin boards and chat rooms of on-line interactive services. Their marks: computer-literate children on the Internet.
Take the case of 51-year-old Alan Paul Barlow. The County District Attorney's office said he traveled from his home in Seattle to a candy store in Mamaroneck early this summer to meet a 14-year-old girl with whom he had been corresponding by way of sexually explicit E-mail messages. 
 Prosecutors also said Mr. Barlow, a post office maintenance worker, had found other victims on the Internet with his modem, allegedly sending semen samples to one girl in Montana, along with photographs of his penis. He has since been extradited to Seattle where he was subsequently arrested on a felony charge of sexually exploiting a minor. He also faces statutory rape charges in another case there. Charges of endangering the welfare of a child are still pending in Westchester.
Jeanine Pirro, the Westchester District Attorney, said Mr. Barlow's case was typical of a new wave of high-technology lawlessness that her office was dealing with -- what she described as "old crimes being committed in new ways."
 
Search Warrants Issued
 "He is what we would have called in the past an old man in a trench coat without pants," the District Attorney said. "The difference is that kids now are being molested in their own homes with their parents in the kitchen."
In addition to on-line pedophiles, the District Attorney's office is seeing an increase in other crimes involving high-tech tools: cellular phone rackets, videotape piracies and crimes committed by computer against corporations. It is what many law-enforcement officials nationwide are calling a new age of crime and what Ms. Pirro described as "not just cops and robbers anymore."
In Alexandria, Va., at the National Center for the Prosecution of Child Abuse, Dyanne C. Greer, a senior lawyer, reported that law-enforcement officials were struggling to counter the "high-tech invasion of child abuse."
The center, part of the federally financed National District Attorneys Association, did not have numbers for the incidence of child-abuse cases involving on-line services like Prodigy, America Online and Compuserve. But Ms. Greer said that her organization was receiving many more calls about such cases and that search warrants for computers were increasingly being used to find child pornographic materials.
Generally, pedophiles and others who are sexually attracted to children scan the teen-age bulletin boards of computer on-line services to find their victims, with the relationships beginning as simple friendships, Ms. Greer said. Often, the victims do not know the real age, name or address of the perpetrator and think he is another teen-ager. An intimate and sexually explicit correspondence can follow, with children who lack outside interests being the most vulnerable to a pedophile's advances.
Graphic child pornography, which traditionally has been sent through the mail, is now often transferred by modems in computer files. Ms. Greer said that computer-generated "kiddy porn" was more detailed and technically of much better quality than photographs. It is also more difficult for law-enforcement officials to find and use pornography buried in a computer file as evidence.
 
'Anarchy on the Internet'
 The Westchester District Attorney's office, like others across the country, has also turned its attention in recent years to the computer underground and young hackers, also known as crackers, who commit crimes.
Gail Thackeray, deputy county attorney in Phoenix, said the new criminals, who often started at "an incredibly young age," were creating "anarchy on the Internet."
She described a class of young, highly computer-literate males who formed "electronic street gangs" and instead of engaging in drive-by shootings "released viruses and sniffer programs and collected accounts and passwords."
Hackers tend to be "boys who don't play football or kiss girls" and are not getting feedback in other aspects of their lives, she said.
 
A Night to Remember
 In Westchester in October 1992, the District Attorney's office investigated what came to be known as the Pumpcon case, named for a yearly underground computer convention held on Halloween. (Such conventions or cons, as they are also known, are often given names relating to the time of year during which they are held. For example, the annual underground computer convention in Austin, Tex., at Christmas is called the Ho Ho Con.)
Pumpcon in 1992 was convened over a weekend at the Courtyard by Marriott in Greenburgh, and law-enforcement officials were watching the proceedings because people who allegedly broke into the Westchester County telephone system and were using it at night were supposedly in attendance, said Kenneth C. Citarella, deputy bureau chief in economic crimes for the District Attorney's office.
Those attending, aged 16 to 25, "got rowdy like a bunch of college kids," vandalized vending machines and stole room keys at the hotel, Mr. Citarella said, and the Greenburgh police were called in. When three computers were found hooked up to telephone lines along with calling cards, the situation was considered suspicious by the police and the District Attorney's office was notified.
Four arrests were made, but only one man was indicted. He pleaded guilty to two misdemeanor counts of computer tampering in the second degree, was placed on probation and paid $1,000 to a clothing store chain because he had invaded and tampered with its computer system. The 22-year-old man said his actions had just been meant as a joke, but Mr. Citarella said that he had the potential to scramble sensitive corporate information, affect credit balances of customers and access the credit ratings of people who shopped at the clothing chain.
 
$1 Million Involved
 This spring, the District Attorney's office, battling another type of high-tech crime, smashed what it called the largest cellular telephone scheme in the New York City area. Four men were arrested on charges of stealing several hundred cell phone numbers and selling them on the street for $150 to stockbrokers and drug dealers.
The brokers and dealers would use the telephone numbers for only a single billing cycle, the time it usually takes for legitimate customers and the carriers to discover the theft, before dumping them and buying new numbers.
Ms. Pirro said that a big-business ring was connected to the scam and that more than $1 million in usage fees were involved. She said that during a series of "buy-and-bust operations," the District Attorney's office seized six computers capable of illegally cloning telephone numbers, along with computer chips, cellular phones and beepers, a handgun, ammunition and a machete.
Computers programmed to clone cell phones can be used to change the identification numbers stored inside a phone on the computer chip, and they can also be used to reprogram the phones with stolen identification numbers so that the carrier will recognize calls as legitimate.
 
Corporate Espionage
 The counterfeit phones are especially useful for narcotics traffickers because they can conceal the identity of the user. It is estimated that the wireless communications industry lost about $300 million last year to cellular fraud, and although the carrier is responsible for the cost of stolen air time, it is expected that unless more rings are cracked, legitimate users will in the long run begin bearing the cost.
The District Attorney's office has also focused in recent years on computer crimes involving corporate espionage -- an AT&T consultant involved in the sale of proprietary software and an MCI employee who allegedly stole customer-access codes.
Five defendants were eventually charged with breaking into the Westchester County government's telephone system and reconfiguring it to operate as a private nighttime phone system, Ms. Pirro said. The cost in unauthorized calls reached $20,000. Four of those arrested were youthful offenders, and the fifth was prosecuted as an adult and placed on probation. All five had to make restitution.
Ms. Pirro said that her office and others around the country were racing to keep pace with the new breed of criminal. "It seems that they are always one step ahead of us in law enforcement," she said.
 
'There Are Holes'
 Kenneth Rosenblatt, deputy district attorney in Santa Clara County, Calif., who is writing a book on high-tech crime, computer intrusions and the theft of trade secrets, said law-enforcement officials were in "unchartered territory" and had been behind the trend for about a decade.
Mr. Citarella in Westchester said that not only was there a shortage of trained personnel in the growing field of computer forensics but there was also a need to draft statutes to address the new direction of crime.
"The Fourth Amendment laws," Mr. Rosenblatt said, "have not accommodated well to the advent of computers; there are holes there. As with the closing of the frontier in the Wild West, there will be increasing pressure to regulate cyberspace."
Howard A. Schmidt, vice president of the International Association of Computer Investigative Specialists, a nonprofit training and research organization based in Portland, Ore., said that high-tech crime and computer forensics had taken a back seat at times to the more immediate issues of "blood spilled on the streets and saving kids' lives."
But he said that "cyber rangers" had begun to patrol the information superhighway, sometimes going undercover on on-line bulletin boards -- posing as juveniles in some cases to apprehend pedophiles and watching for stolen credit card rings.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jeanine Piro, District Attorney, with electronic equipment confiscated after a cellular-phone ring was smashed. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 5; Part 2; Page 16; Column 1; Sophisticated Traveler Magazine

HEADLINE: SOUTHERN BELLE WITH A COUNTRY TWANG

BYLINE: By By Lee Smith; Lee Smith is the author of "The Devil's Dream" (Ballantine), a novel about a dynasty of country musicians.

 BODY:
NASHVILLE is like a big-haired old-country girl all dressed up for a night out on the town -- she's wearing red lipstick and snakeskin boots, she's got a Bible and a pint of Jack Daniel's stashed in her purse. She looks so good, you'd never guess how smart she is. You'd never know she's got that M.B.A. But, in fact, she's just as contradictory as her famous music.
Country music is all about contradiction. It tells a story, and since it is above all else a profoundly American music, that story is the story of conflict and change. The music chronicles our lives as we move from the farm to the city ("Last night I went to sleep in Detroit City/And I dreamed about the cotton fields and home," Danny Dill and Mel Tillis); as our roles change ("Oh we've burned our bras and we've burned our dinners/And we've burned our candles at both ends," K. T. Oslin); as we fall on hard times (Clint Black's "One More Payment"), and even as our language changes ("Call me Cleopatra everybody/'Cause I'm the Queen of Denial," Pam Tillis). If you want to know what's on people's minds in this country's heartland, listen to country music. And if you want a close-up look at that heartland, make a date with Nashville. 
 Only you've got to keep an open mind, the kind that can accommodate conflict and appreciate paradox. This is a city where you can hear Bill Monroe playing bluegrass at the Grand Ole Opry one night, then the Nashville Symphony (or Opera, or Ballet) at the Tennessee Performing Arts Center the next. This is a city whose elegant, white-tie, debutante-laden Swan Ball finds its counterpoint in the equally well-known but funkier, bohemian Swine Ball -- with the proceeds of both going to charity. Worlds apart, too, are the Opryland Hotel (serious big-time twang) and the 1853 Belle Meade Plantation house or Andrew Jackson's home, The Hermitage, now a national landmark.
Let's start with the Opryland Hotel. The main thing is, it's big. It's the biggest thing you ever saw. And it's fun, too, especially if you don't mind walking a lot, or waiting a long time for your bags to get to your room. This is because it has 1,891 rooms, including 120 suites. The centerpiece of the Opryland U.S.A. entertainment complex, this sprawling place offers six restaurants, several nightclubs, lots of shopping and four acres of water and tropical gardens (all of this is inside, mind you!). The Conservatory has 10,000 tropical plants covering a two-acre area crowned by a glass roof six stories high. Walkways, streams and statuary can be found amid the tropical plants. You can get a drink of Tennessee whisky in a grotto, which is not a bad idea. You will need all your strength in order to hike over to the Cascades, another "interiorscape" involving more water -- brooks, a waterfall and a lake covering half an acre. Don't miss the laser-lighted Cascades fountain show, called Dancing Waters. Until his recent death, the harpist Lloyd Lindroth performed there six nights a week. On my last visit, I watched the show with a group of ladies who had come on a tour bus from South Carolina. An involuntary "Oh!" went up from our whole bunch as the magic doorway high up in the hotel wall opened and Lloyd Lindroth emerged onto his little balcony, majestically dressed in a white sequined tuxedo. He flipped up his tuxedo tails, seated himself before his giant harp and flexed his fingers in the air. "Irene, Irene, is it Elvis?" one of the ladies from South Carolina kept asking too loudly (they just knew she would embarrass them all, they should have made her stay home). At Christmastime, the Opryland Hotel outdoes even itself, with 1.4 million Christmas lights.
If the Opryland Hotel is the essence of the New South, the Belle Meade Plantation surely epitomizes the Old. Often called the "Queen of TennesseePlantations," this Greek Revival mansion was a 5,400-acre working plantation in the 19th century. Now reduced to 30 acres, it remains imposing, a monument to a way of life that seems utterly unbelievable today. The cream-colored mansion features two-story columns supporting a rose-colored roof. Especially interesting to me were the outbuildings, the stables and the extensive carriage collection. When I told one of the guides that I was impressed by how beautifully everything had been restored, she came as close to snapping at me as her Southern drawl would allow: "My dear," she said, "Belle Meade Plantation has not been restored. It has been maintained."
So has The Hermitage, home of the military hero and our seventh President, Andrew Jackson. Though Jackson held slaves, loved horse racing and the patrician way of life he led here, he really thought of himself as a Westerner rather than a Southerner. He remained a staunch Unionist throughout his lifetime; perhaps it is his legacy that rendered Nashville ambivalent about secession before the Civil War. Today's visitor to The Hermitage can see a film about Jackson's life and take a self-guided tour of the Hermitage mansion and grounds, including a formal garden, slave cabins and Jackson's tomb, as well as Old Hermitage Church and the neighboring Confederate Cemetery. You can get in free on Jan. 8, the day Jackson defeated the British in the Battle of New Orleans in 1815. As the first President ever elected from the land across the mountains, Jackson represented the frontier.
So did Nashville itself. Traditionally a frontier town, a river town, it has always been in some ways more attuned to the bustling, open West than to the deep South or the cultured, anemic East. Founded as Fort Nashborough on Christmas Eve, 1779, by North Carolinians led by the explorer James Robertson, this outpost became a thriving center for trade and land speculation. Set strategically between the Midwest and the plantation belt, it was the northern terminus of the Natchez Trace and the major port on the Cumberland River. You can visit a fine replica of early Fort Nashborough today; children will also enjoy nearby Riverfront Park.
During the Civil War, Nashville was spared major damage by being the first large Confederate city to fall to Union forces in 1862; it actually flourished during the war as a Union supply base and emerged as a major economic center, led by railroad and manufacturing interests. In the 20th century, banking, brokerage and insurance became important industries. As the state capital, Nashville has always counted government as big business; as the buckle on the Bible Belt, it has more than 800 churches and the one of the largest religious publishing industries in the nation. Another of Nashville's biggest employers is Vanderbilt University, along with the Vanderbilt University Medical Center. Nashville has 16 institutions of higher learning all told, with traditionally black Fisk University and Meharry Medical College notable among them.
Commercial giant or Southern belle? Nashville's contradictory nature encompasses it all. Consider the Parthenon, in Centennial Park. It certainly epitomizes something, but I can never decide what. It is either the essence of classic beauty or ultimate tackiness. The only full-scale replica of the Greek Parthenon in existence, it was originally built for Tennessee's 1897 Centennial Exposition. It now houses a collection of works by 19th- and 20th-century American painters and a 42-foot-tall Athena. She's something to see. So is the Parthenon itself, especially by moonlight. And as you view this amazing edifice, you just might hear echoes of plaintive strumming from a few blocks down the street, where the Parthenon boarding house was for years home to any number of those boys who still come in on the bus every day from all across America with a great song written down in pencil on a sheet of notebook paper folded up real little in their back pockets. . . .
Myself, I'm addicted to Nashville. I used to live there, and I would be living there still if my ex-husband had not dragged me off kicking and screaming to North Carolina, where I have fallen into complications. That sounds like a country song, doesn't it? But then everything sounds like a song if you've ever lived in Nashville.
Fact is, music has long pervaded this city. Early Tennessee settlers loved to sing, and their Anglo-Celtic folk songs and ballads were enhanced by African influences and instruments, especially the banjo. A lively tradition of Southern song ("pickin' and singin' ") existed throughout the rural South. America's showboat circuit of the 1800's started on the Cumberland; Fisk University's Jubilee Singers popularized such black spirituals as "Swing Low, Sweet Chariot" as early as the 1870's. The city's thriving gospel-music business began in the early 1900's. So Nashville's trademark Grand Ole Opry was actually a Johnny-come-lately on the scene. Now the longest-running live radio show on earth, the Opry started out in 1925 as the WSM Saturday Night Barn Dance with its announcer, George D. Hay, presenting an 80-year-old fiddler named Uncle Jimmy Thompson and his piano-playing niece Eva. Uncle Jimmy swore he knew a thousand tunes, and his fiddle playing brought a flood of requests from listeners. More and more entertainers hired on, most of them amateurs, among them Dr. Humphrey Bate and his Possum Hunters, the Fruit Jar Drinkers and the Gully Jumpers. Despite some lean years -- especially during the advent of rock in the 50's, and a downturn in the mid-80's -- the early and enduring popularity of the Grand Ole Opry promised country music's present success. Such young stars as Garth Brooks, Trisha Yearwood and Mary- Chapin Carpenter add excitement to the lineup these days
Today's visitor will find Nashville's musical history everywhere available. Not to be missed is the Ryman Auditorium, historic home of the Grand Ole Opry from 1943 to 1974, which has just reopened following major renovation. Known as the "Mother Church of Country Music," it's a converted red-brick tabernacle still replete with church pews, stained-glass windows and a balcony originally built to accommodate a convention of Confederate veterans in 1896. You can stand right on the stage where Kitty Wells sang "It Wasn't God Who Made Honky Tonk Angels," and you can see the original flats advertising Opry sponsors from the early days (Crazy Water Crystals' "See for yourself what Nature can do!") to the more recent Martha White Self-Rising Flour and the Tennessee confection called Goo Goo Clusters. Now the Ryman is hosting live concerts again, as well as a musical show about the life of Patsy Cline.
Go out of the Ryman and straight into Tootsie's Orchid Lounge, equally historic. Generations of Opry stars have, and their signed pictures cover the walls. You can hear great music anytime, night or day, in Tootsie's, where newcomers and has-beens play for tips. The old Opry posters on the wall came from Hatch Show Print, which claims to be the oldest poster print shop in America. It's been in business since 1879 and still prints posters in the same way, on the same machines, so you can buy yourself some great-looking things at a reasonable price (including a reprint of the advertisement for Hank Williams' show set for New Year's Day, 1953, the one he never got to).
You will also want to check out the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, where the exhibits are wonderful and so is the shopping -- I bought my Elvis placemats here. Or you can shop at Barbara Mandrell Country, the late Conway Twitty's "Twitty City," the Hank Williams Jr. Museum, Ernest Tubb Record Shop, Johnny Cash's House of Cash. The Country Music Hall of Fame is right on Music Row, which started in the early 50's when Owen Bradley and his brother, Harold, built their Quonset Hut, the first studio on fabled 16th Avenue, soon joined by RCA's Studio B, on 17th Avenue, which you can tour. There you can see how Brenda Lee, Chet Atkins and the Everly Brothers recorded in the late 50's and early 60's. Nashville is now home base for somewhere around 70 record labels, with some 200 professional recording studios and more than 25,000 people in the music and entertainment business. Bill Ivey, the director of the Country Music Foundation, points out that it's "the only real entertainment center you can walk up and touch -- see where the stars live, where the writers write, see a recording room. It's hot." Indeed it is. As you stroll along 16th Avenue, you'll see them all -- big stars with big hair and scurrying P.R. people; harassed executives and laid-back session pickers; faithful fans from all over the country.
Although more than a million people live here, Nashville retains the feel of a smaller town. There are real neighborhoods; there's a lot of civic pride. And it's so pretty -- green and leafy, Nashville encompasses more than 8,000 acres of parks, said to be more per capita than any other city in the United States. These include the enormous Percy Warner and Edwin Warner Parks right in the city; the Tennessee Botanical Gardens at Cheekwood; Grassmere Wildlife Park, where you can see such native Tennessee animals as cougars, bears, bison and wolves in big open spaces. There's a state-of-the-art Nashville Zoo, with new red panda and pink flamingo exhibits. Opryland U.S.A. is as remarkable for its landscaping (flowers everywhere) as it is for its musical shows and rides.
Actually, my favorite place to hear music in Nashville is the Bluebird Cafe in Green Hills. This is a place so plain I can't even remember what it looks like. They've got beer, of course, and tables and chairs, but the music's the thing, and the music is simply wonderful. Songwriters' night is the best of all, when the songwriters sit in a circle taking their turns, and you can hear the likes of Billy Joe Shaver, Marshall Chapman, Don Schlitz, Janis Ian. And the Station Inn, down in the railroad gully below Union Station, is always reliable for great bluegrass; the open jam session on Sunday night is a lot of fun. It's a real listening place, as is Douglas Corner Cafe, which also features writers' showcases and an occasional open mike. A nice cross section of music (good alternative rock, in particular) is found at the Ace of Clubs.
The new dance clubs are the hottest thing in country, of course. Even if you'd rather die than two-step, let alone line-dance, you might want to go look anyway. Try Rodeos Dance Club or the South Fork Saloon out on Murfreesboro Road, or the huge, new Wildhorse Saloon downtown by the river. I myself can be found dancing away at the Bullpen Lounge underneath the Stockyard Restaurant (Motto: "You never know who'll be seen at the Stockyard!") with a whole bunch of cowboys, white-belt types and the occasional big star. I recommend it. I recommend Nashville, in fact -- she's a good old girl who knows how to have a good time.
