ROOMS WITH A VIEW
 Nashville has ample accommodations for visitors, including a number of chain motels, where double rooms average about $55 a night. The following hotels offer unusual attractions.
OPRYLAND HOTEL, 2800 Opryland Drive (telephone: 615-889-1000), has 1,891 rooms and suites; rates range from an average of $175 for a standard double to $2,000 for a suite with two bedrooms, a reception area, an entertainment area with a grand piano, two wet bars and a view of the Conservatory, a vast glassed-in area with streams, walkways and statues. Restaurants include the jackets-preferred OLD HICKORY, which specializes in seafood, game, and lamb and veal preparations; dinner for two, with wine, is about $80.
HERMITAGE HOTEL, 231 Sixth Avenue North (615-244-3121), is a grandly Beaux-Arts establishment, built in 1910, with a Greek marble and Russian walnut lobby under an enormous stained-glass skylight. There are 112 suites, which range in price from about $120 for a one-bedroom suite to $195 for a suite with two bedrooms. Many rooms are currently being refurbished, and a renovation, scheduled to be completed by the end of this year, will transform the glassed-in veranda that runs the width of the building into a cocktail lounge. THE GRILL restaurant specializes in regional American fare; dinner for two, with wine, is about $60.
UNION STATION HOTEL, 1001 Broadway (615-726-1001; reservations: 800-331-2123), is a converted 1897 Romanesque Revival railroad station whose soaring lobby incorporates a stained-glass arch; some of the bedrooms have 25-foot vaulted ceilings. There are 138 rooms and suites, with rates ranging from an average of $120 for a standard double to $400 for a one-bedroom suite on a high floor overlooking the city. ARTHUR'S restaurant (615-255-1494) offers a menu of Continental specialties that changes daily; dinner for two, with wine, is about $100.
 
SIGHTS TO SEE
 OPRYLAND U.S.A., 2802 Opryland Drive (telephone: 615-889-6611), is open daily from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. until Oct. 2, and from 10 to 9 on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays only until the daily schedule resumes in late March. A one-day ticket, good for all rides and shows, is $23.95 for adults and $13.95 for children from 4 to 11.
BELLE MEADE PLANTATION, 5025 Harding Road (615-356-0501), is open from 9 to 5 on Mondays through Saturdays and from 1 to 5 on Sundays. Admission: $5.50.
THE HERMITAGE, 4580 Rachel's Lane (615-889-2941), is open daily from 9 to 5. Admission: $7.
FORT NASHBOROUGH, 170 First Avenue North (615-255-8192), is open daily from 9 to 5, weather permitting. Free.
THE PARTHENON, Centennial Park, West End and 25th Avenues (615-862-8431), is open from 9 to 4:30 on Tuesdays through Saturdays; from April through September, it is also open from 12:30 to 4:30 on Sundays. Admission: $2.50.
GRAND OLE OPRY, 2804 Opryland Drive (615-889-3060), performs every Friday and Saturday night, with additional matinees in the summer months. Tickets: $12 to $16.
RYMAN AUDITORIUM AND MUSEUM, 116 Fifth Avenue North (615-889-6611), is open daily from 8:30 to 4. Admission: $5. Call for schedules of evening performances, ticket prices and reservations.
COUNTRY MUSIC HALL OF FAME AND MUSEUM, 4 Music Square East (615-256-1639), is open from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. on Mondays through Saturdays and from 9 to 5 on Sundays. Admission: $7.50, which includes tours of RCA's Studio B on nearby Roy Acuff Place. Elvis placemats are $2.99 each.
HATCH SHOW PRINT, 316 Broadway (615-256-2805), is owned by the Country Music Hall of Fame. It is open from 9 to 5 on Mondays through Fridays, 11 to 5 on Saturdays and occasionally on Sundays. Reprints of classic posters range from $3 to $50.
CHEEKWOOD (Tennessee Botanical Gardens and Art Museum), 1200 Forrest Park Drive (615-356-8000), is open from 9 to 5 on Mondays through Saturdays and from 1 to 5 on Sundays. Admission: $5.
GRASSMERE WILDLIFE PARK, 3777 Nolensville Road (615-833-1534), is open daily from 10 to 5. Admission: $5.50.
NASHVILLE ZOO, 1710 Ridge Circle, about 18 miles out of Nashville in Joelton, Tenn. (615-370-3333), is open daily, from 9 to 6. Admission: $5.50.
 
 
MEAT-AND-THREES AND MORE
 "Most people who come to Nashville under tow of somebody local get taken to the wrong places," said John Egerton, a Nashville resident and the author of "Southern Food" (Knopf). "We all want to impress our visitors with how urbane and sophisticated we are. So we take them to our French restaurants or to our Italian restaurants. But if a visitor wants to get a real sense of what is the most authentic, natural and original cooking in Nashville, I would direct that visitor to one of our meat-and-three cafes. We have lots of them, more than most towns, and I'm not sure why this is. They seem to breed each other, like car dealerships and mass murderers."
A meat-and-three, John explained, means a plate lunch, basically: meat loaf, roast beef, or fried chicken, say, with three such vegetables as turnip greens, creamed corn, green beans, fried green tomatoes or mashed potatoes. "The best time to go is the noon meal," John said. "They all tend to close early, and some are not open at supper."
The four SYLVAN PARK restaurants are typical meat-and-threes; the SYLVAN PARK MURPHY ROAD (4502 Murphy Road; telephone: 615-292-9275) is where Charlesetta Hughes makes her legendary pies -- 40 or 50 of them a day. (Try the chocolate meringue.) The clientele is as steady as the quality. You'll find the same two old guys out in the parking lot every day, waiting for the little restaurant to open. About $8 for a full meal,
including dessert and beverage; closed Sundays.
You might find Randy Travis sitting on a stool at HAP TOWNES RESTAURANT (493 Humphrey Street; 615-242-7035), another meat-and-three near Music Row. This small stone diner owned by the two Hap Towneses, father and son, has been a Nashville favorite for decades. Open Mondays through Fridays, with fried chicken on Tuesdays; about $6.50 for a full meal and beverage.
Plate lunches are a feature at the ELLISTON PLACE SODA SHOP (2111 Elliston Place; 615-327-1090), pictured on the front of one of George Jones's albums, as well as great milkshakes and real ice-cream sodas. With those little jukebox-things on the walls, its tile floor and lunch counter with stools, it hasn't changed since the 1950's. James Dean would feel right at home here. Open Mondays through Saturdays; about $9 for a plate lunch with a milkshake. Malts are $3.10.
My own favorite restaurant is the LOVELESS CAFE, a large white house out on Route 5, Highway 100 (615-646-9700), surrounded by rusting car bodies that create exactly the right atmosphere and attest to the authenticity of the food. The Loveless is full all the time, so call ahead -- especially on Sundays. My husband ate nine biscuits at a recent breakfast there, along with sausage gravy, grits, eggs and wonderful preserves, all dished up by Mary Lou Perry, who has been in the kitchen for 16 years. A large breakfast costs $7 or $8; a lunch or dinner of fried chicken
is $8.95, a steak dinner is $12.95 and a four-vegetable plate is $5.95.
There are a couple of other places I like a lot. One thing you'll notice when you walk into JIMMY KELLY'S RESTAURANT, in a renovated Victorian house at 217 Louise Avenue (615-329-4349), is that everybody seems to know everybody else -- but you'll get a warm welcome, too, as well as good food and lots of it. The first thing they bring you is a plate of tiny, delicious hot corn cakes. A dinner of, say, a blackened catfish appetizer, a steak, and pecan pie is about $60 for two, with a bottle of wine. Open for dinner only, closed Sundays.
And lots of people think 12TH AND PORTER (114 12th Avenue North; 615-254-7236) has the best food in town. The restaurant -- the decor is yard-sale chic -- also houses a wonderful music club. Appetizers at our recent dinner there included blue corn hoecakes with Boursin cheese and caviar; baby crab pizza; spicy potato pie with salsa, sour cream and green onions. Some entrees: roast duck tortellini; pasta ya-ya, fettuccine with sausage and chicken in a Cajun cream sauce; brie, tomato and basil pizza with pine nuts. Desserts? Coconut cake, Hershey bar cake and Porter passion -- an apple-cinnamon-cream cheese-peanut butter pie in a graham cracker crust. They also serve "Low Death Factor (lite)" items. A three-course dinner for two is about $60, with wine. Open for lunch Mondays through Fridays and for dinner Mondays through Saturdays. LEE SMITH

HEADLINE: SHOWDOWN IN HAITI: CARTER;
Carter's Diplomatic Mission Was a Last-Minute Gamble

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
That Jimmy Carter had a place on center stage in the final act of President Clinton's end game with Haitian leaders was a last-minute improvisation.
Mr. Clinton had always intended to send one last emissary to persuade Haiti's military leaders to step down voluntarily, his aides said today. But it was only late last week, as he stood on the brink of an unpopular military operation, that Mr. Clinton decided to accept Mr. Carter's offer that he head the team that would try one last time to find a peaceful way out. 
 For the former President, who helped make way for peace in the Middle East but who suffered humiliation in the Iran hostage crisis, the starring role is his most prominent in a retirement devoted largely to a career as free-lance diplomat.
For Mr. Clinton, the mission presented such potential political and practical risks that some of his top advisers warned strongly against it.
But with Congressional and public opposition to an invasion mounting, the President saw in his predecessor a key that might forestall a military and political clash, Clinton aides said today. Mr. Carter had already begun to establish his own contacts with Haiti's military leaders, with whom he had worked over the years in making the monitoring of democracy and human rights in Haiti something of a crusade.
With American warships on the horizon off Port-au-Prince and American warplanes in the air, his entreaties to them -- echoed by Americans with the stature of Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia and Gen. Colin L. Powell -- apparently persuaded the Haitian leaders that there were better options than braving an American military invasion.
"Either way you've gone the extra mile," a senior White House official said of the shift in Mr. Clinton's strategy that gave Mr. Carter another chance to be seen as a peacemaker. "If it works, you've probably prevented some bloodshed. If it doesn't work, you show that you've exhausted all options, which probably helps us build public support."
But as Mr. Carter's talks wore on, with Mr. Clinton left to rely for most of today on telephone reports from Port-au-Prince, it was plain that the unorthodox nature of his final diplomatic gambit had left some top advisers far from comfortable.
If Mr. Carter had failed, or was seen as pursuing his own agenda -- as he seemed to when he traveled to North Korea earlier this summer to help defuse a standoff there -- Mr. Clinton would have been left to bear the burden of having to order an invasion that did not have the backing of Congress and the public.
And even with the agreement that he announced tonight, the President is forced to share with Mr. Carter some of the glory that would otherwise fall to the White House for having averted a military clash.
After months in which Mr. Clinton delivered carefully calibrated threats, and weeks in which the military has mounted an extensive buildup in the Caribbean by a precise clock, what made Mr. Carter the Administration's last-ditch envoy began only on Wednesday when he telephoned his successor to renew an offer that had been rejected.
By today, some of Mr. Clinton's aides were arguing that Mr. Carter, Mr. Nunn of Georgia and General Powell constituted a team that could not have been better suited for the mission. They said the combination of a former President, a former military commander and a leading lawmaker virtually guaranteed that their efforts were seen as credible both by Haiti's leaders and the American public.
But Administration officials said Mr. Carter's request had been greeted with little enthusiasm by some of Mr. Clinton's top advisers, including Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Anthony Lake, the national security adviser. They remembered how his quasi-diplomatic trip to North Korea left the Administration seen as speaking with two tongues.
Mr. Clinton was similarly not comfortable about sending Mr. Carter alone, Administration officials said today. But even as the President began to talk with Mr. Carter about ways to include others in the delegation, Mr. Christopher and his deputy, Strobe Talbott, seemed to others in the Administration to be arguing that any final American emissary should be a representative of the United States Government.
That had been the working plan for several weeks, when Administration officials discussed a last-ditch plan to send a Central Intelligence Agency officer or William L. Swing, the United States Ambassador to Haiti, to meet with the military leaders to deliver an ultimatum.
But the Haitian leaders signaled about 10 days ago that they did not want to meet with Mr. Swing, Administration officials said today. And by the middle of last week, with public opinion running strongly against a possible invasion and the House preparing to vote on a resolution opposing military action, advisers to Mr. Clinton said he became attracted by the prospect of a highly visible attempt at peace.
In extemporizing while his aides were saying publicly that an invasion could be just days away, Mr. Clinton kept his decision making tightly held, consulting with only about a half-dozen top aides. Among those excluded from the deliberations, officials said today, were some of those who have been deeply involved for months in shaping Haiti policy, including Alexander F. Watson, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, and David R. Gergen, the special adviser to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Christopher.
After watching Mr. Clinton warn the Haitian leaders from the Oval Office on Thursday night that "your time is up," most of the Administration's foreign-policy experts, like most Americans, learned only on Friday that he had decided to send Mr. Carter on the mission. Some made no secret of their bitterness about the latest swerve in the Administration's planning.
While Mr. Clinton also said in that speech that the time for talks had passed, Administration officials said his language had been carefully drafted to leave a door open for a last-ditch mission. It was not long after the cameras stopped rolling that he, Mr. Lake, Vice President Gore and Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, retreated to a small study off the Oval Office to tell Mr. Carter to stand by for a mission to Haiti and to invite Senator Nunn and General Powell to join him.
Aides to Mr. Clinton said he felt comfortable enlisting Senator Nunn and General Powell even though they had voiced skepticism about an invasion.
Officials involved in the discussions about what form a final diplomatic mission should take said Mr. Clinton had concluded that a mission of high stature would help to "maintain the dignity" of Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras and his colleagues at a time when they might be uncomfortable about meeting with United States officials. At the same time, the officials said, the President felt that enlisting those opposed to his policy could boost his own credibility, if their mission failed, in insisting that he was using military force only as a last resort.
Beyond the ties that Mr. Carter had already forged with General Cedras, officials said, Mr. Clinton saw other particular advantages: He recognized that General Powell, the former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the architect of the Persian Gulf war, was highly respected by Haiti's leaders for his military expertise and as a black American. Others said the fact that his popularity among Americans transcends political boundaries was seen as a way to protect the Carter-led mission from criticism from the right.
At the same time, the officials said Mr. Clinton saw Senator Nunn, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, as someone who could tell Haiti's leaders that strong opposition in Congress would not necessarily be an obstacle to Mr. Clinton's action.
By broadening the mission beyond Mr. Carter, the officials said, they argued that the emissaries would be less likely to exceed what Mr. Clinton intended as a narrow mandate.
Administration officials said today that Mr. Clinton had not made a final decision to send the three emissaries until Friday afternoon, when General Cedras told Mr. Carter that he wanted to meet with them.
Today, Administration officials were uncharacteristically circumspect about the debate in the White House. But officials made clear that the support had not been universal.
"All of the issues were aired in full," said a senior Administration official. And Mr. Panetta, when asked in a television interview today about divisions within the White House, said only, "When the President makes these kind of decision, I think the reality is that he is trying to exhaust the last effort for peace."
For Mr. Carter, who was forced into retirement in 1980 and has tried to redeem his foreign policy reputation, Haiti could be the clear triumph he has been seeking. He proved at least temporarily right this summer after he proclaimed that the crisis over North Korea's nuclear weapons programs was over, but it is not yet clear that the North Korean leadership will prove as accommodating as he had suggested.
Since forming his own private foreign policy apparatus, Mr. Carter has also monitored elections in Panama, Nicaragua, the Dominican Republic, Haiti, Zambia, Guyana, Ghana and Paraguay; worked with Ethiopia, Zambia, Guyana and other countries to strengthen their economies, and made several high-profile missions to Syria, the former Soviet Union and other countries.

HEADLINE: Crisis of Bread and Land Afflicts Russia's Hard-Pressed Farmers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: STUDENETS, Russia

 BODY:
The fevered days of autumn have descended heavily upon the farmers of Russia. An unusually cold summer stunted their crops and late rains nearly washed them away. Now the frosts are only a few weeks off, and if they come any sooner the nation will suffer its worst harvest in three decades.
"A lot in our country depends on the weather this autumn," Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin told a German television reporter recently, voicing the common concern that a particularly poor harvest will hasten the effects of an already visible farm crisis. "What happens in the fields also has its effect on the political climate." 
 That has been true here for hundreds of years, of course. Almost nothing means more to Russians than bread, and debates about the annual grain harvest always herald the fall political season.
As a practical matter, Russia's anemic harvest -- estimates suggest that it will be less than 85 million tons, not nearly enough to feed the people -- will hurt only the nation's pride and its pocketbook. The United States has already agreed to ship some of its surplus to Russia again this year. Nobody will go hungry.
But despite the frenetic pace of the fall harvests, production of meat, milk, grain and vegetables has slipped each year since 1989. Clearly, weather is not the only problem confronting Russia's troubled farmers. Suspended between the lumbering world of a collective farm system that ran solely on the whims of the state and the brutal necessities of the free market, no section of the struggling economy has foundered as badly as agriculture.
A year after President Boris N. Yeltsin issued a historic decree guaranteeing Russians the right to buy and sell private land, fewer than 5 percent of the nation's 10 million agricultural workers own anything that could be described as a farm.
Government officials estimate that by the end of 1994 at least 30 percent of the farmers in Russia, big and small, will be bankrupt, although in today's Russia bankrupt industries and farms carry on like phantoms. Huge segments of society simply live by barter or in debt.
Private farmers have fared worse than the others. In 1992, 4 out of every 100 farmers who went out on their own were driven to bankruptcy. Last year the figure rose to 14 percent, and in the first half of this year to 70 percent.
By the end of the year, only a smattering of the farmers upon whom President Yeltsin once placed "all the main hopes for a fundamental transformation of the agrarian economy" will remain solvent.
"The facts are sad but simple," said Aleksandr A. Nikonov, president of the Agrarian Institute, a branch of the Russian Academy of Sciences. "The transition to a free market has hurt farmers more than any other sector of this economy. The old system was irrational, but it has been replaced by no system. There are no supports, no credits, no loans or guidance. It is as if the Government said, 'You are free now; do it by yourself.' "
 
Farm Crisis Spreads To Rest of Economy
 The farm crisis has rippled through the economy with amazing speed. Tractor manufacturers -- once the glory of Soviet industry -- have virtually gone out of business from one end of the country to the other: nobody can afford their merchandise. Miners are threatening to strike, saying farmers are charging too much for grain, destroying their incomes.
The results have embittered private farmers as well as employees of state kolkhozes, or cooperatives, whose average salary in May was 88,000 rubles (then worth about $46) -- lower than those for workers in any industrial segment of the economy. And they have postponed the day when Russia, one of the world's agricultural giants, will be able to feed itself.
The politics of the farm crisis -- and of private land in this new democracy -- are complex, but the math is simple. Five years ago a pound of wheat bought twice its weight in diesel fuel. This season, farmers here need to trade nine pounds of wheat for two of fuel.
In 1991 grain cost twice as much as fertilizer. Today, with much of the grain and livestock industry near collapse, fertilizer cost eight times as much as grain.
Most economists say it will take years to turn the huge collective farms into competitive enterprises.
"We should be proud that there is no hunger," said Viktor F. Lishchenko, director of agricultural business studies at the Academy of the National Economy of Russia. "That itself is an achievement. You couldn't invent a more difficult task than turning this command farm economy into a free one."
 
Supply System Falls Into Chaos
 Clearly nobody could have expected the revolution to be finished in a day. But there are still almost no cooperative banks here. The supply system vital to food processing has been sundered.
As a result, as much as 40 percent of all vegetables rot before they can be taken from the fields. Without money, new farm machinery is impossible to buy, and old machinery is hard to maintain. The State Agriculture Ministry says 68 percent of the farm machinery used in Russia today is more than 21 years old.
Everyone agrees reforms are needed, but to the men and women who toil in the fields, much as they have since before the serfs were freed in 1861, reforms are only words. And the Russian peasant has never had a great regard for words from Moscow.
"I was prepared to try it," said Vasily A. Starodubtsev, former head of the Soviet collective farm union and a member of the group that attempted a coup against Mikhail S. Gorbachev in August 1991. He is still head of the Lenin Collective Farm not far from here.
"I was prepared to try reforms and see what it would bring us," he said. "What it has brought is the most well-developed disaster in 50 years. Even under bad Communism we lived fairly well. We were the masters of our own lives. We had hope. What he have now is nothing."
As head of the region's largest collective, he long ago decided that the new way was a bad way. The picture of Mr. Gorbachev attached to his wall five years ago is gone. Lenin is back above his desk now -- and so, apparently, are the principles he stood for.
 
Though a Leninist, An Innovative C.E.O.
 Nonetheless, Mr. Starodubstev has earned a reputation as an innovator and a creative, if autocratic, leader among the 1,500 farmers who live and work there. Grain yields at the Lenin Collective are higher than at any other farm in the region.
What is more, people live decently here. The bread is great and there is plenty of it. Workers put in 18- to 20-hour days this season, but there are always three meals, and there is always a bus to take them home when the day is finally done. When they get some free time, the farmhands can relax in the enormous sauna or swim in the indoor pool.
"I can't say this is the best system in the world," said Mikhail G. Baklanov, 40, a tractor driver who, like his father and grandfathers, was born on a kolkhoz. "But it is steady work. And I really don't see a path to anything better. I have friends who are on their own. They are trying to plow a field with three people. It's crazy."
Mr. Starodubtsev does all he can to hold on to his "comrades," as he still calls them.
When he realized that the Government would no longer buy his potatoes, he flew to Vienna and contracted to buy the finest potato chip maker he could find. Next year he plans to become one of the country's biggest chip manufacturers. The ovens in the Lenin bakery are all from Italy. The milking process is as automated and sophisticated as that on a technically advanced Wisconsin dairy farm.
But the farm's profits have fallen in each of the last five years. This year it expects the first loss in a decade.
 
Greater Suffering For Private Farmers
 "Everyone is now trying to portray the farming crisis as the battle of the old-time farm collectives against the entrepreneurs," said Viktor I. Pashinin, a farmer from Tambov who is vice chairman of the Association of Peasant Farms and Agricultural Cooperatives of Russia. "That is simplistic. When the Government yanked out the rug from beneath this industry they ruined all of us together."
Mr. Pashinin represents the new class of private farmer, a class that the Government has repeatedly sworn is vital to reform.
But the private enterprise that comes from these farms is weak because the Government is afraid to support them, and starting fresh with no capital is almost impossible. In the past farmers would demand that the state buy their property. These days, that no longer works.
"In Russia we always say how times are tough on the farm, but I know they have gotten worse," said Aleksandr G. Yefremov, Deputy Agriculture Minister. "We don't have any real cooperative movement in this country the way America does. Nobody talks about going back on reform. What we do talk about is how fast to go forward."
Even those who did break up their kolkhozes have sad stories to tell. Unlike the trend in the United States, where every year most Americans get their food from bigger and more automated farms and where farm produce is heavily subsidized by the Government, what has been happening here is often the opposite.
 
Land to the Tiller, Cows to the Milker
 Economists say the best way to break up a collective farm is to divvy it up like a New York City condominium apartment -- you don't own the actual place, just a portion of the building equivalent to the space you occupy.
But most Russian farms have been split into irrational duchies. Milkmaids got cows and a plot of land. Mechanics got tractors.
"We used to live on one big farm," said Raisa A. Sokovlkov, 53, a former head of the town council in Studenets. "Now we live on 300. I am a milkmaid. I was given two cows. If you worked with chickens, you were given chickens. But I can't plow the 50 acres of land with a cow. And what if we could get it all out of the ground? Where would we sell it?"
It is a common complaint, particularly because criminal gangs tightly restrict access to big cities like Moscow. As a result, dozens of farmers stand all day long on the exit ramps of highways surrounding the city, selling produce the only way they can: out of the back of a truck.
"We never lived well here," Mrs. Sokovlkov said. "But aren't reforms supposed to make you live better?"

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
In Race for California Chief No Candidate Is Favorite

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18

 BODY:
The candidate to watch in the California governor's race, the most important state election in the country this year, is None of the Above.
Officially, the polls show that Pete Wilson, the stolid Republican incumbent, has taken the lead after a slow start, again demonstrating that he is the California master of the confound-the-experts political surge. 
 State Treasurer Kathleen Brown, his Democratic opponent and the latest member of the Brown political dynasty to seek the California governorship, has slipped into second place after leading the race for the better part of a year, at one time by more than 20 points.
The momentum now seems to be with Mr. Wilson. But the polls also show something else about this contest, whose outcome will almost certainly affect the political climate leading up to the 1996 Presidential election, given California's national political power as the most populous state.
Buried under the figures, which have the Governor leading by 2 to 10 percentage points, are other figures that show both candidates failing to win a favorable rating from a majority of voters.
"What we have is an unhappy electorate looking for any excuse to abandon Pete Wilson but far from ready to settle on Kathleen Brown as the alternative," said Larry Berg, the director of the Jesse M. Unruh Institute of Politics at the University of Southern California. "Even though Wilson would seem to be the favorite now, the contest is still not decided and could swing either way, subject to the influence of television advertising, debates and anything else that helps define one candidate more clearly than the other."
As elsewhere in the country, a deep current of discontent with politicians is coursing through the California electorate, creating many undecided voters. This being a midterm election year during the tenure of a Democratic President whose popularity is slipping here as elsewhere, California Republicans, like others, hope to benefit.
But as the Governor's contradictory poll figures indicate, that is by no means a sure bet. While voters say they believe that Mr. Wilson is a more capable leader than Ms. Brown on most issues, he not only falls short along with her when it comes to winning a favorable rating from a majority of voters, but he also draws a larger unfavorable rating.
The issues in the campaign are weighty, notably the still-struggling California economy, crime, immigration and education. Mr. Wilson has done the better job of defining and exploiting them, in the judgment of many political analysts.
"People may not like him but at least he has defined himself on a number of issues," said Mark DiCamillo of the Field Institute, a nonpartisan polling organization in San Francisco. "On the other hand, a lot of voters say that while they like Kathleen Brown, they don't really know what she stands for because she mostly criticizes Wilson while offering no clear alternatives of her own."
Early in the contest, Mr. Wilson, a 61-year-old centrist, struggled to overcome Ms. Brown's contention that many of the state's economic problems were his fault. But in recent months, as the economy has begun to tick up, he has managed to make crime and immigration the hot issues.
Indeed, the latter has become the hottest issue in recent weeks as voters have begun to focus on the steadily rising monetary and human costs of an increasing influx of illegal immigrants from Mexico.
As the Governor has edged ahead in the polls, the rhetorical tone of the contest has changed, too. At times the exchanges are sharply personal and mean-spirited.
Ms. Brown, a 47-year-old moderate liberal who is the daughter of former Gov. Edmund G. (Pat) Brown and the sister of former Gov. Edmund G. (Jerry) Brown Jr., is normally smiling and affable on the campaign trail. But in recent weeks she has become increasingly acerbic as she focuses her frustration on Mr. Wilson's character.
"He's a dangerous, hypocritical, phony politician who doesn't lead but instead slavishly follows what the polls indicate will win him a few more votes," she says at rallies and fund-raising events.
The Governor counters by calling Ms. Brown a "political cipher" and "a total nonplayer," and says her political and governmental experience is limited mainly to a term as State Treasurer. By way of contrast, Mr. Wilson notes that in three decades of politicking he has run successfully -- often plodding impassively but steadily from behind -- for the State Assembly in 1966, Mayor of San Diego in 1971, United States Senator in 1982 and Governor in 1990.
"The people want performance instead of talk and fluff, and I can perform," he said. "Kathleen Brown is without real experience, a total nonperformer."
Whether or not Mr. Wilson is a slave to the polls, the polls show that in hammering on crime and immigration -- many voters see a connection between these issues -- he is responding to gut voter concerns. Two of every three California voters favor doing more to control illegal immigration, and four of every five list crime as their greatest concern.
The Governor favors cutting off most government services to illegal aliens and wants the Federal Government to strengthen border patrols. He also wants Washington to pick up a greater share of California's cost of dealing with the flood of aliens. "They keep coming," his television advertisements lament.
Ms. Brown also favors stricter control of illegal aliens. But she says Mr. Wilson's approach, much of it included in a referendum on the fall ballot, is too hard-line.
She says that it will result in intrusion into the lives of legal immigrants and work hardship on the children of illegal immigrants, particularly if the children are denied schooling.
"We'll be throwing them into the streets," Ms. Brown warns, "and they'll learn things there that will cost us a lot more in the end."
On Saturday, the Clinton Administration dispatched Attorney General Janet Reno to California to announce still another plan to beef up controls and patrols along the Mexican border, a move that could help both President Clinton and Ms. Brown with California voters.
Ms. Reno said the program was "specifically tailored for California" and would bring more money and 200 agents to the border in the San Diego area in the next 100 days. Over all, she said, she planned to send 700 new agents to the Southwest border in the fiscal year 1995.
But Mr. Wilson, in an unusually ebullient mood on Satuday at a meeting in San Diego with state Republican leaders, called the plan "tinkering" and "a Band-Aid for a hemorrhage," and predicted a Republican landslide in elections this fall.
The crime issue is a particularly difficult one for Ms. Brown because law and order generally tends to be a tougher sell for female candidates. She has made the sell even more difficult by opposing the death penalty, leading her critics to say that her liberalism is typical of the kind that ultimately cost her father and brother elective office.
Ms. Brown also faces another sexual obstacle in that she is asking California voters, who already have made electoral history by sending two women to the Senate, to elect still another woman to the top of the state's political hierarchy.
"We haven't reached the point yet where we don't have some voters who simply won't vote for a woman," said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a political scientist at Claremont Graduate School in California. "The question is, Just how many of those voters are still out there?"
Finally, as always in statewide races here, there is the matter of money for the advertising blitzes so necessary to reach into every corner of this huge, diverse state.
The most recent fund-raising reports, in midsummer, put Mr. Wilson ahead in both cash raised and cash still available to spend. He had pulled in $15 million as against $12 million for Ms. Brown, and he still had almost $5 million of that in hand, twice as much as Ms. Brown.
To help close the cash gap, Ms. Brown scheduled a fund-raising event tonight in Los Angeles, with the President as the featured speaker. But Mr. Clinton sent his wife, Hillary, when the Haiti situation tightened.
His trip will almost certainly be rescheduled.
Given the President's increasing unpopularity here, he might well cost Ms. Brown votes when he shows up with her. Offsetting that, political experts say, would be the $1 million or more that his appearance would net for the hard-pressed Brown campaign.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Boom in Latin Business Reading

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Where can you find a report on Paraguay's new stock market, a three-page spread on Ecuador's Brady bond deal and a glowing Man of the Year cover article on Peru's President, Alberto K. Fujimori?
All this and more ran in recent issues of Latin Finance, a glossy magazine that fills the coffee-table niche in a rapidly expanding publishing industry devoted to covering business in Latin America. 
 On long flights south, American business passengers can pull out of their briefcases Latin Finance and U.S./Latin Trade, both monthlies, and Business Latin America, a weekly bulletin published by the owners of The Economist.
For Spanish-speaking executives, Dow Jones & Company offers America Economia, a monthly, and The Wall Street Journal Americas, a two-page insert in eight Latin American newspapers that began publication on Aug. 1.
"We have to get out there first," said Elias Selman Carranza, managing editor of America Economia, which is 50 percent owned by Dow Jones and has a paid circulation of 55,000. "In five years, there is going to be a Latin American Fortune or a Latin American Business Week."
Since 1990, the Latin American economy has grown by an average of 3 percent a year, a higher rate than in any region of the world other than Southeast Asia. And higher growth is expected after elections this year in Mexico and Brazil, the largest nations in the region.
"We are on the threshold of a potentially unique situation: the two biggest economies in the region with their acts together," Peter A. Conway, president of Latin Finance, said in a telephone interview from his office in Coral Gables, Fla.
Billions of dollars in United States investment are flowing into Latin America's seven big stock markets, reversing the flow of capital in the 1980's. With the debt crisis a memory, American banks are lending again. And with free trade a mantra chanted from Bogota to Buenos Aires, United States trade with Latin America is expected to surpass United States trade with Western Europe by the end of the 1990's.
"There is a Eurocentricity to reporting in the United States," said J. P. Faber, editor in chief of U.S./ Latin Trade, which is based in Miami. "Very few people in the United States are aware that Mexico is our third-largest trading partner, after Japan and Canada. You look in Business Week and you will see three articles on Germany for every one on Mexico."
Previous attempts to create a regional press for Latin America have fallen victim to the continent's far-flung dimensions and its irregular postal services. "Distribution in Latin America is a complex and difficult challenge for any publication," said Mr. Conway, who has published Latin Finance since it started in 1988. "The local mail stinks, so we have to send by courier."
To reach their largely American business audience, Latin Finance and U.S./Latin Trade distribute most of their copies through airlines and hotels. Paid subscriptions account for about 10 percent of Latin Finance's circulation of 50,000 and for about 35 percent of U.S./Latin Trade's circulation of 65,000.
"We catch the readers on the way down," Mr. Conway said of his strategy of distributing his magazine in first- and business-class sections of planes leaving the United States. In May Mr. Conway began a stepchild publication, Latin Finance Mexico.
The Wall Street Journal Americas is prepared in New York, sent digitally to Miami and then beamed by satellite to newspapers in seven Latin American countries.
"Latin America is so geographically huge that you have to print in each country," said Edward Schumacher, senior editor for the insert, which is placed in the business pages of subscribing newspapers. "For the Asia and European editions of The Journal, we print in two or three sites and reach the whole region. You can't do that in Latin America."
"Fortunately," he continued, "satellite technology and desktop publishing have brought a lot of the expenses down."
From Business Latin America, the 25-year-old veteran on the block, to the 18-month-old U.S./Latin America, these regional publications rely primarily on a network of American and British freelance writers.
The key to success these days, editors say, is satisfying the growing need for regional business news.
"When we started our publication, in 1987, it was the time of the Latin American debt crisis, and people thought we were crazy," Nils Strandberg, president of America Economia, said in an interview in his office at the Dow Jones headquarters in New York. "With all the bilateral trade agreements, Latin American managers are thinking regionally. Chileans now have $3 billion invested in Argentina, and more than $300 million in Peru. It's more than interest -- they have to follow their investments."
Mexico, Colombia and Venezuela signed a free trade agreement in June, forcing many local business executives to think beyond their borders for the first time. Beginning in January, most trade will be duty-free between Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Paraguay and Uruguay. In the last several years, Chile and Colombia have signed individual free trade agreements with most of Latin America's largest nations.
"Increasingly, Latin America's most aggressive corporations are looking to global markets," Mr. Strandberg said. "There is also a new generation of managers. Instead of American expatriates, you have American-trained Brazilians, Colombians and Mexicans."
Some readers maintain that at times Latin Finance and U.S./Latin Trade tailor their editorial copy to please advertisers.
"Space is given to a company according to the size of its ads," said Jerry Haar, director of Inter-American Business at the University of Miami's North-South Center. "Stories are skewed to getting ads on a particular issue."
Editors deny this, contending that they are highlighting business opportunities and fast-growing sectors of Latin American economies.
"We are trying to make Latin America a user-friendly place for our readers," Mr. Faber of U.S/Latin Trade said. "There is a huge amount of ignorance in the United States about trade and investment in Latin America. A lot of people think it is a guerrilla-infested jungle."

Roger Conkling, left, vice president of Northern Telecom, assisted by Claudia Berger, a United Airlines employee, at United's lounge at Rio de Janiero airport, is among the executives reading magazines like Latin Finance. (John Maier Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fight Looming in Congress Over Panels That Regulate Commercial Fishing

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
A major fight is shaping up in Congress over the role of eight little-known committees created by Federal law two decades ago to protect American waters from overfishing by foreign vessels.
Critics of the committees, who include members of Congress, environmentalists and even some committee members, say that in some cases the panels have proved to be their own worst enemies by allowing overfishing of those same waters by American vessels. Such overharvesting has helped to bring about the fishing industry's drastic decline. 
 The regional councils set fishing limits and allocate catches between competing fishermen. While Congress specifically proposed that council members be knowledgeable about the fishing industry and be exempted from conflict-of-interest statutes, critics say panel members are prone to favor industry interests over those of the public or the long-term health of the fishing industry.
"Tough decisions have not been made," Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who is vice chairman of the Commerce Committee's National Ocean Policy Study, said recently. "People who have been responsible for trying to curb the process have not done so and, most importantly, fishermen themselves, who for years under the management councils were given the responsibility to conserve, have not been conserving."
Most council members reject any suggestion of conflicts, and some councils have been credited with moving swiftly to avert economic and ecological problems.
The role of the councils is emerging as a major issue as Congress prepares to take up reauthorization of the law that created them, the Magnuson Fishery Conservation and Management Act. The 1976 law extended the nation's coastal waters to 200 miles from 3 to drive out foreign vessels that had been overharvesting the fish in those waters. Should Congress fail to amend the Magnuson Act, members would probably pass a resolution continuing the current law.
But the critics say that the council members have allowed domestic fishermen to pick up where the foreigners left off. For example, two council members from Alaska, who own fishing boats or processing plants, voted with other state representatives in 1991 to allocate more pollock and cod to fishermen from their state than to competitors from Washington State.
The New England council, faced with complaints from fishermen and pressure from politicians, was unable for years to agree to reduce catches of cod, haddock and yellowtail flounder even though data showed that stocks were catastrophically low. Last Monday, the council discussed the possibility of shutting down the once-rich Georges Bank fishery off Cape Cod, possibly for years, because new data indicated that stock losses were far greater than previously realized.
For their part, panel members attribute the fisheries' decline to the Government, which imposed regulations that slowed responses and provided millions of dollars in low-interest loans to the industry in the 1980's.
Over the last decade, consumer demand for fish has risen sharply.
James McCauley of the New England council said that the complex issues required members to know the industry, a requirement called for by the Magnuson Act.
"Yes, there is a conflict in a sense," said Mr. McCauley, chairman of the Point Judith Fishermen's Co-op in Rhode Island. "But they are using the knowledge I have and they could not do it any other way. I know what the bottom looks like, and I know the resource out there."
In establishing the council system, the Magnuson Act created one of the more curious entities in the Federal Government. It first charged council members, who are paid $300 a day for some 30 to 35 days of service annually, with a difficult balancing act: preserving the nation's marine resources while minimizing damage to the fishing industry.
A council plan is reviewed by both the National Marine Fisheries Service and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. They forward their recommendations to the Commerce Department, which can reject the plan though it has rarely taken such action.
Frank DeGeorge, the Inspector General of the Commerce Department, which oversees the councils, testified before Congress recently that the conflict-of-interest exemption covering the councils appears to be the only one affecting some 1,000 councils that advise the Government on various issues.
In an analysis delivered to Congress on Friday, the World Wildlife Fund, an environmental group in Washington, D.C., found that 84 percent of council members in 1992 were drawn from the commercial or recreational fishing industries.
"It is like timber companies deciding on the quantity of timber sales," said Michael Sutton, a vice president of the group, which is lobbying Congress to get more non-industry representatives on the panels.
Council members counter that they sometimes vote against their industry interests. But an investigation by Mr. DeGeorge's office of the Northern Pacific fishery council showed the fine legal line on which council members walk.
The Northern Pacific council manages fishing within the Bering Sea north of the Aleutian Islands. The fishery has become the scene of bitter in-fighting between fishermen from Alaska who process most of their catch of pollock and cod on shore and Washington State fishermen who operate trawlers that process fish at sea.
In 1991 the council, which has a majority of representatives from Alaska, voted to shift the fishery's allocation to favor on-shore processing. A subsequent inquiry by Mr. DeGeorge's office found that two of the Alaskan representatives, Ronald E. Hegge and Oscar Dyson, had boats or companies that would benefit from the vote.
But while Mr. DeGeorge found abuses in the vote, his report concluded that no action could be taken against the men, who denied any wrongdoing, because they had disclosed their holdings as required.
"We found that conduct that is forbidden under criminal conflict-of-interest laws in other contexts is permitted," his report stated.
Legal troubles do not appear to be a bar to council service. Last year, two companies, which were partly owned by two members of the Western Pacific council, acknowledged their involvement in the harvesting of 1,500 illegal lobsters off Hawaii and had paid $30,000 fines to the Commerce Department. The councils voted to take no action against the two members, both of whom said they had not been directly involved in the incident, a meeting transcript indicates.
Some councils with industry's aid have taken positive steps. In 1977, for example, the Mid-Atlantic council revived stocks of surf clams and ocean quahogs by placing strict quotas on their harvesting. But elsewhere, like New England, councils have been virtually paralyzed, some council members said.
"There was a reluctance on behalf of the council to change the makeup of the fishing industry socially or economically by fishery management," said Thomas Hill, a council member who is also the president of Atlantic and Pacific Marine Consultants Inc., a firm in Gloucester, Mass. "But by not making the changes, the council has backed into the very problems it was trying to avoid."
In 1977, the New England council adopted quotas to restore cod, haddock and yellowtail flounder, but five years later, it dropped the restrictions after fishermen protested that they were no longer needed.
At the same time, the Government made low-interest loans available to help build up the number of boats in the industry after the departure of the foreign vessels. That led to a dramatic growth in boat building. And with more vessels on the water, catches of cod at Georges Bank dropped by more than half from 1982 to 1986, according to Federal data.
For the next five years, scientists urged the panel to take strong action. But council members argued that a series of half-way measures would enable stocks to rebound. "They were grasping at straws," said Vaughn Anthony, the chief scientific adviser with the National Marine Fisheries Service in Woods Hole, Mass.
In 1991, after the settlement of a lawsuit against the Commerce Department by the Environmental Law Foundation, a group in Boston, the council began to develop a plan to reduce fishing pressure by placing a freeze on the number of vessels and by limiting a boat's days at sea.
But plan elements were still contested by fishermen and state representatives worried about constituents. The plan was adopted this year, but last Monday new data suggested that a shutdown of Georges Bank might be needed.
Even the councils' harshest critics agree that industry should be part of the councils, but several bills to reauthorize the Magnuson Act seek to reduce the possibility of conflicts by requiring members to disclose interests at times of votes or require a broadening of the councils to include more non-industry representatives.
William N. Myhre, a lawyer and lobbyist in Washington who represented some companies in the Bering Sea debate, said it was inevitable that industry-backed council members would vote their interests if only out of fear that their opponents would do so.
"You'd have to be naive not to," Mr. Myhre said. "To remain pure is to lose."

HEADLINE: SHOWDOWN IN HAITI: THE ACCORD;
Text of Haiti Agreement

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Following is the text of the agreement reached today in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, between the United States and the ruling junta in Haiti:
THE PURPOSE of this agreement is to foster peace in Haiti, to avoid violence and bloodshed, to promote freedom and democracy and to forge a sustained and mutually beneficial relationship between the governments, people and institutions of Haiti and the United States. 
 TO IMPLEMENT this agreement, the Haitian military and police forces will work in close cooperation with the U.S. military mission. This cooperation, conducted with mutual respect, will last during the transitional period required for insuring vital institutions of the country.
IN ORDER to personally contribute to the success of this agreement, certain military officers of the Haitian armed forces are willing to consent to an early and honorable retirement in accordance with U.N. Resolutions 917 and 940 when a general amnesty will be voted into law by the Haitian Parliament, or Oct. 15, 1994, whichever is earlier. The parties to this agreement pledge to work with the Haitian Parliament to expedite this action. Their successors will be named according to the Haitian Constitution and existing military law.
THE MILITARY activities of the U.S. military mission will be coordinated with the Haitian military high command.
THE ECONOMIC embargo and the economic sanctions will be lifted without delay in accordance with relevant U.N. resolutions and the need of the Haitian people will met as quickly as possible.
THE FORTHCOMING legislative elections will be held in a free and democratic manner.
IT IS UNDERSTOOD that the above agreement is conditioned on the approval of the civilian Governments of the United States and Haiti.

HEADLINE: Dishing Out TV Menu to 'Dogpatch';
A Remote 3-Channel Town Suddenly Gets Oodles of Choices

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PISECO, N.Y., Sept. 17

 BODY:
Veronica O'Rourke said her family's television viewing choices have long been a simple matter. "You've got three channels and you watch whatever one comes in that day," she said.
The place with almost no television suddenly had as much as just about anybody in the world, with the added bonus of perfect reception -- and all free for the first three months. Arietta, a sprawling "town" of nearly 500 square miles peopled by 301 scattered souls, about 70 miles northwest of Albany, had become a company's demonstration site for a television technology that beams signals into individual homes by means of umbrella-sized satellite reception dishes. 
 "It's like bringing cable to Dogpatch," said Laura Morehouse, who works in a health clinic and likes to watch nature shows. "We're coming up in the world. We're now like everyplace else."
Arietta was chosen for its bad reception, lack of cable, low economic levels and general remoteness after consulting a 131-page Census Bureau list of very small communities.
Executives of Primestar Partners, a partnership of General Electric and six cable companies, thought a highly publicized focus on one town would dramatize their mission of capturing an estimated 12 million households unprofitable for traditional cable.
"People have never seen CNN or TNN or what the heck," allowed Henry Rogers, Supervisor of the town of Arietta, which has its offices in the community center of the village of Piseco. "And we've been trying to get cable for 10 years. The whole town is wound up like a clock today."
And as two dozen crews worked to hook up more than 80 homes, the company presented its technology, which it said was unusual in that it uses more advanced digital codes, to a standing-room-only crowd in Arietta's community center. The size of the crowd was deemed commendable by local people because the occasion coincided with the first day of bear-hunting season.
"This is the first digital town in the history of the world, since the Egyptians built the Pyramids," said John J. Cusick, the company president, not shying away from hyperbole.
None of those gathered seemed inclined to bite the hand that was feeding them free doughnuts as well as three months of 77 channels, including 10 audio ones. Within two years, the company promises, its ability to compress digital information will allow it to offer more than 200 channels. It is already supplying 14 regional sports channels.
"To me, it's the circus," allowed Paul Schlansker, a dentist. "But on the whole, it's good for people to know what's going on in the world."
At a time when even Eskimo communities in the High Arctic have full cable service, the remoteness of Arietta would indeed be difficult to surpass. Only two of the three major networks come in -- and then not between 4 and 8 P.M. Mrs. O'Rourke says the Fox network is viewable only by means of a device on the antenna to enhance its signal -- and then only when the leaves have fallen from the trees.
A nearby cable company decided there were too few people to justify the service economically. Mr. Cusick said that would have cost $1,400 a subscriber, roughly twice the expenditure considered profitable. Primestar's service costs $300 to install (and will cost about $1 a day for those who keep the basic service after the three-month trial).
Conventional satellite dishes, which cost in excess of $3,000 and then require service payments to cable companies supplying programming, are economically out of reach for most residents.
Half the families in Arietta earn less than $25,000 a year; a doctor or full-service supermarket is at least a 50-mile drive away, and the nearest movie theater, which is a minimum of eight miles away for all residents, opens only in the summer. Telephones are still on party lines, and many houses run generators because they are not hooked up to electricity.
But it was less like television arriving on some South Pacific island where people had never seen it, than it was a leap from scratchy 1950's reception and choices to a communications world in which residents are painfully aware that people only a few miles away have enjoyed variety for years. Many rent videos and ask friends in nearby towns to tape shows.
"Especially in the winter, people up here kind of rely on a TV," said Charles Brown, who drives a school bus. Some winters, the snow is 15 feet deep. "We're hoping for educational programs to keep the kids occupied."
What is new is the thought of a new and more complicated relationship with the piece of furniture that is the television set. In particular, parents are wrestling with how to set limits. "I've got to figure out how to deal with the kids on this," said Mary Schlansker, a psychologist with two children. She said she hoped to concentrate their viewing, as well as her own, on programs on public television.
When Ashley Chamberlin was asked if she would play as much, the 3-year-old chirped, "I'm just going to watch TV."
Her family was one of four hooked up earlier this week in a test run, and so far she has been as good as her word. Her mother, Sadie, said Ashley had been up until midnight watching cartoons. "This is good and it's bad," Sadie said. "So far, it's like Saturday morning every day."
The importance of television is indicated by the fact that Charles Morehouse several years ago decided to move the trailer of his stroke-stricken mother from Arietta to a community 30 miles away with better reception.
An unknown is whether the new TV era will change a local life style that includes a well-attended weekly community dinner and occasional ice cream socials. "Come back in six months and see if we're all sheltered in," Ms. Schlansker said.

HEADLINE: A Hopeful Turn in Algeria

 BODY:
Very late in the game, Algeria's army-backed regime has just taken its first big step back from the brink of a catastrophic showdown with Islamic politics. It has released top Islamic leaders from jail and invited them to talk about a compromise solution to the violent conflict that began when the army blocked an Islamic electoral victory in 1992.
Algiers is responding to a deteriorating security situation that has led many to predict that the present secular regime could fall as early as this year. But it is also acting in accordance with the wise and consistent advice of the Clinton Administration. Algeria is one case where the Administration has played an exemplary role, distancing itself from the rigid and uncompromising position of France, Algeria's former colonial master and the foreign country with the most to lose should Algeria violently collapse. 
 Already, Islamic terrorism and Government counterterrorism have killed more than 10,000 Algerians and created a climate of terror that has led many foreign businesses and diplomatic missions to withdraw or sharply reduce their staffs. It has also understandably frightened hundreds of thousands of secular Algerians, many of whom would try to flee if a violent Islamic takeover seemed imminent.
That prospect particularly upsets France, their most likely destination. Italy and Spain also fear refugees, economic disruption and political instability, while Tunisia and Morocco and Egypt worry about the boost an Algerian takeover would give to their own violent Islamic groups.
France, its domestic politics roiled by anti-immigrant demagogy directed mainly at its already sizable Algerian community, has reacted to the current crisis with panicky denial. It sees no alternative beyond propping up the present authorities as long as possible. But Washington, having practiced denial itself in the Shah's Iran and then having paid a price for it, now accepts that some accommodation with Islamic forces may be inevitable and that a negotiated transition could prove more comfortable than a violent one.
It is not yet clear whether serious negotiations can begin. The Islamic Salvation Front, the main Islamic group whose leaders the Government just released, has issued a conciliatory statement envisioning new talks. But the Front's own exile leadership demands further concessions before negotiations. Other, more radical groups that have gained strength since the Front was outlawed in 1992 oppose any negotiations at all. Nor is it known yet how much the Government is willing to concede for the sake of a solution.
The new peace initiative could still easily unravel. But at least there is now a chance to avoid the catastrophe so many could foresee, but so few seemed prepared to head off.

HEADLINE: Another Sellout On Bosnia

BYLINE: By Marshall F. Harris and Stephen W. Walker; Marshall Freeman Harris and Stephen W. Walker resigned from the State Department in August 1993.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A year ago, we resigned as the State Department's desk officers for Bosnia and Croatia to protest the Clinton Administration's policies on Bosnia. Since then, little has changed for the better and much has got worse.
Serbia's vicious assault on Bosnia and its non-Serb population continues, making it even more imperative that we end the arms embargo so that Bosnia can defend itself. 
 Instead, the five-nation "contact group" -- the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Russia -- is promoting its plan to partition Bosnia and to monitor the trade embargo on the Bosnian Serbs.
The Administration says it is a positive sign that the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, is cooperating with the plan. Yet it should realize that Mr. Milosevic supports it not because he has finally come around to our way of thinking; rather, we have given in to his.
The plan gives him what he has wanted all along: an ethnically "pure," contiguous greater Serbia carved in blood from vast swaths of Bosnian and Croatian territory.
The West's acceptance of Belgrade's proposal to have international monitors certify the uncertifiable -- that Mr. Milosevic has actually cut off his Bosnian Serb proxies -- makes us even more complicitous. (Last week, the Bosnian commander, Gen. Rasim Delic, said the flow of weapons, ammunition and personnel across the border had not stopped since the embargo went into effect in August.)
Under the proposal, about 135 international observers will be concentrated at a few of the 48 major crossing points along the 375-mile border. Rather than actually check vehicles, they will only observe Serbian police inspections. This will not be nearly sufficient to keep the border secure.
But even if 10,000 monitors were sent to police this extremely porous border, the plan represents an ignominious retreat. In the face of daily Serbian violations of dozens of U.N. Security Council resolutions, the contact group has the means, authority and cause to compel Serbian compliance rather than simply monitor it.
In late July, it agreed to take steps in this direction by tightening sanctions, actually protecting the "safe areas" in Bosnia and ultimately ending the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government. Now the U.S. and its allies have reversed course.
President Milosevic understands that by declaring a pause in his overt support of the war he can get the Bosnian Serbs to follow his lead by signing a partition plan that realizes his goal of a greater Serbia. At the same time he looks like a peacemaker and can obtain relief from the economic sanctions against his regime.
Significantly, the Administration's agreement to relax sanctions contradicts U.N. Security Council resolutions that require they be maintained until Serbian forces in Bosnia disband, withdraw or surrender to the Bosnian Army.
Mr. Milosevic also understands that a U.S. Administration willing to tolerate the worst atrocities in Europe since World War II -- and to allow him to keep most of the territory he has captured -- is unlikely ever to force him or his proxies to retreat from current front lines, as the plan stipulates.
So the Administration's assertions that Mr. Milosevic has changed course and that the new policy is a success are a combination of self-deception and self-aggrandizement. They also disguise policy retreats that come at a great price.
First, by maintaining the arms embargo and allowing Serbia to keep the fruits of its aggression, Mr. Clinton has abandoned our treaty obligations to protect states' right of self-defense, respect international borders, prevent genocide and promote regional stability.
Second, appeasing Serbia will surely prolong the war, if not widen it. Feeling no threat of retaliation, Serbian forces have escalated their purge of non-Serbs from Bijeljina, Banja Luka and other Bosnian towns. And they are continuing their ethnic cleansing in Serbian regions that have non-Serb majorities, including Kosovo, the Sanjak and the Voyvodina.
Mr. Clinton's promise to introduce tens of thousands of U.S. troops once the Bosnian Serbs sign the plan -- a settlement neither the Bosnian Government nor its aggressors like or intend to honor -- threatens to make us a direct participant in a prolonged conflict.
Third, by capitulating to European and Russian willingness to reward Serbia, the Administration has weakened its hand in the struggle to end the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government. Well into the second third of his term, Mr. Clinton has still not attempted, either directly or through the U.N., to enact his "preferred policy" of ending the embargo.
As a result, large majorities in Congress have already voted in favor of binding measures mandating that the President end the embargo. Conferees debating amendments to the military appropriations bill may turn these measures into law before Congress adjourns next month.
Senators and representatives who want to end the embargo understand that Serbia's assault will continue until it is met by force or until all remaining non-Serbs are driven out of its self-styled greater Serbia. And they understand that the reason the Serbs have got away with more than two years of genocide is the embargo, which has left the Bosnians virtually defenseless.
They also know that a unilateral lifting of the embargo by the United States would soon become multilateral. The 109 U.N. members already on record in opposition to the embargo would join us immediately, and, though they might balk at first, our NATO allies would almost certainly follow.
As it proceeds blithely with plans to invade Haiti, the Administration is not listening to what majorities in the House and Senate are saying about Bosnia. Until President Clinton finds the political will to lead, our nation will continue to slide deeper and deeper into the abyss of unchecked Serbian aggression. It was true when we resigned, and it's even more true today.

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI;
Text of Agreement Adverting U.S Invasion of Haiti

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Following is the text of the agreement reached in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, on Sunday between a United States delegation and the military-dominated leadership in Haiti:
The purpose of this agreement is to foster peace in Haiti, to avoid violence and bloodshed, to promote freedom and democracy and to forge a sustained and mutually beneficial relationship between the governments, people and institutions of Haiti and the United States. 
 To implement this agreement, the Haitian military and police forces will work in close cooperation with the U.S. military mission. This cooperation, conducted with mutual respect, will last during the transitional period required for insuring vital institutions of the country.
In order to personally contribute to the success of this agreement, certain military officers of the Haitian armed forces are willing to consent to an early and honorable retirement in accordance with U.N. Resolutions 917 and 940 when a general amnesty will be voted into law by the Haitian Parliament, or Oct. 15, 1994, whichever is earlier. The parties to this agreement pledge to work with the Haitian Parliament to expedite this action. Their successors will be named according to the Haitian Constitution and existing military law.
The military activities of the U.S. military mission will be coordinated with the Haitian military high command.
The economic embargo and the economic sanctions will be lifted without delay in accordance with relevant U.N. resolutions and the need of the Haitian people will met as quickly as possible.
The forthcoming legislative elections will be held in a free and democratic manner.
It is understood that the above agreement is conditioned on the approval of the civilian Governments of the United States and Haiti.

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI: IN PERSPECTIVE;
The G.I.'s Are in Haiti: Now for the Hard Part

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

 BODY:
The agreement he and his two fellow negotiators reached on Sunday night with the Haitian generals, Jimmy Carter told Congressional leaders yesterday, has "many imperfections." It is also full of ambiguities, some of which could easily prove its undoing.
But it has already had important substantive and political results, and it may eventually have more. To state the most obvious first, the American troops who landed in Haiti yesterday morning faced no hostile fire. Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras of Haiti and Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Shelton of the United States confronted each other across a conference table, not in the streets of Port-au-Prince. And the crowds gathered outside military headquarters there were docile, not hostile. 
 For President Clinton, the events of the last 24 hours produced an undoubted triumph. However sloppy or confused the buildup may have looked, the denouement could hardly have been better. In the hope of averting an invasion that neither he nor most other Americans wanted, he gambled, turning to three men with whom his relations have been difficult, and won.
His credibility with other countries and his standing at home will no doubt improve, at least in the short term, although many Americans still think the Haitian problem unworthy of the commitment of troops, even as peacekeepers and nation-builders. Democratic candidates in the midterm elections have been spared a fresh burden.
Now, however, comes the hard part. Like the French in the 19th century, like the Marines who occupied Haiti from 1915 to 1934, the American forces who are trying to impose a new order will confront a complex and violent society with no history of democracy.
"Each day that goes by, there will be more confusion and uncertainty," said Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia.
For two centuries, political opponents in Haiti have routinely slaughtered each other. Backers of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, followers of General Cedras and the former Tontons Macoute retain their homicidal tendencies, to say nothing of their weapons.
General Shelton said at a news conference that keeping them from each others' throats would be the responsibility of the reformed Haitian police, aided by the American military. But that is a tall order. Who is to be disarmed? Who is to control the police?
If widespread violence erupts, it will not be easy to keep United States forces out of harm's way, and if they take casualties in any significant number, Mr. Clinton could find himself in political hot water once again. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, said yesterday that he would be better able to evaluate the situation "in 60 days, 90 days, six months, who knows how long?"
Mr. Clinton and his aides can only hope that no one emerges to lead a revolt of those who hate Father Aristide or the United States or all foreigners who would seek to force Haiti to change its ways.
One potential rebel leader is the chief of the Port-au-Prince police, Lieut. Col. Michel Francois. He appears to have taken no part in the negotiations, and his whereabouts is unknown.
Presumably because they had no choice, the negotiators left open the question of when or whether General Cedras and his right-hand man, Brig. Gen. Philippe Biamby, would leave the country. Lynn Garrison, one of General Cedras's advisers, said yesterday afternoon that the general had no intention of leaving Haiti -- ever -- and they have formally agreed only to yield power, no later than Oct. 15.
Perhaps General Cedras will spend his time, Mr. Garrison said, scuba diving or writing his memoirs. But with the amnesty he is to be granted under the deal, he could presumably do whatever he wanted; so could General Biamby. If they chose, they could be a powerful destabilizing force.
General Cedras gave his word that he would cooperate, and he did so in his initial meeting this morning with General Shelton.
But the underlying problem in this whole enterprise is that Mr. Clinton is counting upon people who have repeatedly broken their word in the past to keep their word this time. General Cedras, after all, is the same man who signed the Governors Island agreement, then blatantly defied it. He is the same man whom Mr. Clinton accused on Thursday evening of ordering a vicious campaign of rape and murder.
It sounded weird to hear Gen. Colin L. Powell, one of the negotiators, discussing his appeals to the "military honor" of a man whom the President had so recently condemned as a butcher. It sounded equally surreal to hear President Carter praising the peacemaking role of President Emile Jonassaint, whom the White House has been denouncing for months as the illegitimate head of an illicit Government with whom the United States would never do business.
Current plans call for American forces to be supplemented and then replaced, for the most part, by an international police force operating under United Nations auspices. But it is not clear how soon that will take place. It depends in part on how soon Father Aristide, a man of widespread political appeal but questionable governmental skills, can re-establish his legitimacy and form a viable team.
The mood of some Aristide supporters who gathered at the port yesterday to watch Americans coming ashore was depressed, almost sullen. Many said they feared for their lives because General Cedras was to be permitted to stay. They -- indeed, most Haitians -- are looking for the kinds of guarantees that it will be hard for Father Aristide or anyone else to make good on.
Democracy-building such as he is undertaking is no easy thing, as the experiences of a dozen African nations richer and less inured to violence than Haiti have demonstrated. In Haiti it is vastly complicated by the influence of the voodoo priests and secret societies that formed the backbone of the Duvalier dictatorship.
Whether Mr. Clinton's decision to use American troops in Haiti and President Carter's peacemaking mission have opened the way for real change, or simply inaugurated another futile effort to reshape a society that has long resisted reform, may not be known for years.
The President himself made no sweeping claims of victory yesterday, confining himself to the declaration that the agreement "has dramatically increased chances for a peaceful transition."
Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who served with Mr. Carter and General Powell on the negotiating team, commented pointedly yesterday that returning Father Aristide to Haiti did not constitute democracy and would not by itself solve the nation's problems. Doing that, he said, would require the development of political institutions, the creation of a workable economy and the protection of political and other minorities.
Even if no violence develops in the coming months, even if the flood of refugees is not resumed, it will not be clear until the next scheduled presidential election, in 1995, whether democracy has put down roots. Father Aristide has promised to step aside then, but few would be astonished if he changed his mind, and many forces in Haiti might find it in their interests to sow discord and disruption.
