HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI: DIPLOMACY;
On the Brink of War, a Tense Battle of Wills

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times; The following article is based on reporting by John H. Cushman Jr., Steven Greenhouse, Douglas Jehl and Elaine Sciolino and was written by Ms. Sciolino.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The talks in Haiti on Sunday dragged on past a noon deadline, then past a 3 o'clock extension. By early evening, President Clinton was pacing the Oval Office, visibly impatient with his three envoys, who had not yet persuaded the military leaders to resign.
On an ordinary, unsecured telephone line from Port-au-Prince, former President Jimmy Carter, the chief emissary, begged over and over for more time, but Mr. Clinton was insistent. "We've been friends for a long time," he said, "but I'm going to have to order you out of there in 30 more minutes. You've got to get out." 
 What concerned the President was that at 6:47 P.M., the first planes had left Pope Air Force Base in North Carolina to begin the invasion of Haiti.
Mr. Carter had tried to keep himself ignorant of the military timetable, to give himself as much room to maneuver as possible. But even before he spoke to Mr. Clinton, the talks had been interrupted by Brig. Gen. Philippe Biamby, Haiti's army chief of staff, who burst into the room to alert the Haitians that they would soon be under attack.
"We can't trust the Americans," he blurted out, according to an American in the room.
In the end, according to accounts today by Mr. Carter and others who took part in the weekend's events, it took the mediation of Emile Jonassaint, the 81-year-old President installed by the military junta, to push the generals into a deal -- a one-page, single-spaced document that allowed American soldiers to enter Haiti today as friendly occupiers rather than as hostile invaders.
"I say to you that we'll have peace, not war," Mr. Jonassaint said as his ministers sat in stony silence.
After three years of policy shifts, increased economic sanctions and military threats, it finally came down to two days of intense personal encounters in Washington and Port-au-Prince.
The negotiating that averted combat became a test of wills among an American Commander in Chief reluctant to use force in the face of overwhelming Congressional and popular opposition, Haitian military officers as determined to hold on to power as they were to preserve their place in history, and a stubborn ex-President who specializes in peace talks and was hungry for a deal.
Thus resulted a deal that requires Haiti's three military rulers to relinquish power but grants them amnesty for the violent repression committed in their name.
For Mr. Clinton, an imperfect deal was more important than being consistent with his earlier tough talk about refusing to negotiate with the junta, if consistency meant spilling what Secretary of State Warren Christopher has called "the blood and treasure of the United States."
To get to that point, the three negotiators had to leap a number of hurdles -- delicate political and diplomatic issues, a rapidly expiring military deadline, a vow by General Biamby to commit suicide rather than to relinquish power, and a desperate, emotional outburst from the wife of Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, the leader of the Haitian junta.
On Saturday, her son's 10th birthday, General Cedras' wife, Yannick Prosper, told her husband that she would rather die with her children during an American invasion than see her husband forced from power.
The next morning, after a long night of talks, Mr. Carter and his fellow negotiators went to the Cedras home for an emotional meeting.
Gen. Colin L. Powell, a man deeply respected by the Haitian military, personally persuaded them that it would be more honorable to give up power than to die. "This is what military honor is, this is what courage is," was general's argument, Mr. Carter said today.
 
The Threat
Clinton Prepares To Use Force
 On Aug. 26, at a meeting of his top advisers, Mr. Clinton approved the final version of an invasion plan that the military had been drafting for months. He set the clock ticking: unless Haiti's leaders stepped down, he wanted the military to be prepared to launch an invasion during the week beginning Sept. 19. The decision capped months of growing frustration over the failure of economic sanctions to pry the Haitian leaders from power.
During his vacation on Martha's Vineyard, Mr. Clinton kept a deliberate public silence about Haiti, even though some were saying that he should take his case for military action to the nation. Mr. Clinton was in a political bind: Polls showing that two-thirds of Americans opposed his policy, and he feared that when the issue came before Congress, lawmakers would try to block any military action.
Aides including David R. Gergen and George Stephanopolous won approval for a strategy calling for Mr. Clinton to ratchet up his language in the 10 days before an invasion. The strategy was aimed at avoiding the kind of prolonged attention that might give Congress time to head it off.
"We needed to get as much positive impact as we could without opening a debate that would be harmful, not helpful," a senior White House official said.
But once Mr. Clinton returned from his 13-day holiday, the blitz came hard and fast. In beating the war drums, the White House all but announced the convening of closed-door councils. The State Department issued a report calling the Haitian military's human-rights record the worst in the hemisphere. The President himself summoned wire-service reporters to share gruesome photographs of murdered Haitians who had been supporters of Father Aristide.
To further show Haiti's rulers that he was serious, Mr. Clinton began a highly visible military build-up in the Caribbean. This was possible partly because Haiti's tiny army posed so inconsiderable a threat that the Pentagon had little need to keep its movements secret.
At the same time, the Administration began to drive home a new message: it would send troops into Haiti even if the leaders stepped down. Whether or not the American operation would be a 20,000-man invasion, the so-called Plan A, or a 15,000-man mission to secure the island, the nearly 20 American warships in place by the end of last week had a reason for loitering on Haiti's horizons.
With Congress and public polls against an invasion, President Clinton made a belated effort to rally the nation behind him. He took to national television to deliver his first speech on Haiti and his most explicit threat: "Leave now," he told the Haitian junta on Thursday, "or we will force you from power."
Mr. Clinton kept secret the date of the invasion, which was set early last week. Barring a last-minute breakthrough, they decided, American commandos and paratroopers would begin to storm ashore in Haiti shortly before 2 A.M. today.
 
The Diplomacy
Jimmy Carter Seeks a Role
 Mr. Clinton had another secret: the calls he had been receiving from Jimmy Carter offering to mediate the crisis.
For months Mr. Carter had badgered the White House to give him a role in resolving the Haiti crisis, just as he eventually was given a role with North Korea. He had got know General Cedras as head of an election team monitoring the December 1990 election, when the general, then a colonel, organized security for the balloting.
Upon arriving home early last week from a long trip to Africa and Russia, Mr. Carter found a letter from Charles David, the de facto Foreign Minister of Haiti, asking him to serve as a mediator.
Mr. Carter sent his phone number to General Cedras through intermediaries. A few minutes later, the general called, and with his brother Alex acting as interpreter, suggested that he wanted a deal, Mr. Carter said.
Mr. Carter called Mr. Clinton with the news. Today, the former President said that even before the mission was approved, he had done another bit of free-lance diplomacy. He had approached the two men who would become the other mediators -- Gen. Powell and Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat, to ask them whether they would be willing to go with him to Haiti "if it came to that."
Mr. Clinton always had hoped for a last-minute breakthrough that would compel the Haitians to step down. The White House had been bombarded for days with messages that the military leaders wanted a deal -- from relatives of the civilian leaders, from retired Haitian military officers with ties to the Pentagon, even one relayed from the Haitian President ousted earlier, Jean-Claude Duvalier, from his exile in the south of France.
But several top advisers, including Secretary Christopher; Anthony Lake, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, and Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, expressed strong reservations about using Mr. Carter to make the final moves. In a private hourlong meeting with Vice President Al Gore, a strong promoter of the Carter mission, hours before Mr. Clinton's speech on Thursday, Mr. Christopher insisted that any such mission must seek to "clarify" rather than "complicate" the situation.
But Mr. Clinton was not content with the way the game was ending. Mr. Carter's approach had left him enamored of the idea of a high-profile action -- even at risk of relying on a predecessor with a record as an unpredictable emissary.
Within minutes after the television cameras stopped rolling, Mr. Clinton retreated with Mr. Gore, Mr. Lake and Leon E. Panetta, his chief of staff, to a small study off the Oval Office to tell Mr. Carter, Senator Nunn and General Powell that he wanted them to stand by for a last-minute mission.
They should try to strike a deal, he said. But under no circumstances should they offer to derail or delay the invasion.
 
The Clock
Negotiations Drag As Deadline Nears
 It took only the slightest signal from General Cedras that he would receive such a delegation before the White House announced its surprise swerve in strategy. Early Saturday morning the three men were bound for Haiti aboard a United States Air Force jet. From the moment it touched down in Port-au-Prince, Mr. Carter and his team began a non-stop blitz to cut a deal.
They met with Mr. Jonassaint, the provisional President whom the United States had refused to recognize; with business leaders, members of Parliament and a retired general who was one of Mr. Carter's old contacts. From Saturday afternoon until 2 A.M. that night, and then through the day on Sunday, they met with General Cedras and General Biamby, whose refusal to step down had put the United States on the brink of combat.
Lieut. Col. Michel Francois, the police chief and the third member of the ruling junta, boycotted the talks, although he once pledged to follow the lead of the military and leave power.
Throughout the talks, on the second floor of the white, two-story Army headquarters, Mr. Carter told the two men that invasion was imminent, that Haiti's military would be destroyed and that they and their families would suffer. In what he today called long and painful conversations, General Powell reminded the leaders that he was also a military man, and told them: "You have no idea of the firepower we have."
Senator Nunn noted that he had made a speech on Friday opposing an invasion, but told the leaders that despite Congressional opposition, Mr. Clinton's mind was made up, and that once an invasion started, Congress would back its President.
The broad mandate Mr. Clinton gave to the emissaries meant that they could discuss much more than just the narrow arrangements for the leaders' departure, which the White House had long said would be the only focus of any last-minute talks.
They promised amnesty to the Haitian leaders Mr. Clinton had accused of murder and mayhem. They indicated that despite Mr. Clinton's demand that they step down "now," he might be willing to allow them a few more face-saving weeks in office.
But as Sunday's talks wore on, Mr. Carter and his partners remained unable to persuade the military leaders to step down by a specific date. And as General Powell had been told but did not share with his companions, the clock was ticking down.
From the Oval Office, Mr. Clinton had told Mr. Carter and his team that they must conclude their negotiations by noon, so that they could return to Washington in time for him to put the invasion plan on hold. He later pushed back that deadline to 3 P.M. Twice he allowed them to remain in Port-au-Prince for just another hour. But Mr. Carter repeatedly asked for more time, saying he was getting close to a deal.
With the invasion set to begin shortly after 2 A.M., that left the President and his advisers increasingly anxious.
At one point Mr. Lake, the national security adviser, turned to Gen. John M. D. Shalikashvili, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, with a question he asked only half in jest: Could the Marines poised to evacuate Americans from Haiti be used to withdraw the former President and his team?
Mr. Clinton remained unwilling to postpone the invasion. On Saturday, as Mr. Carter and his team began their talks, he gave an oral order that set the military operation in motion. Told by Defense Secretary William J. Perry at 1 P.M. that he needed to give a go-ahead to paratroopers to load their equipment if the invasion was to proceed on schedule, the President instructed: "Pack 'em."
At about 5 P.M., General Powell telephoned Mr. Clinton to say that the team had reached a deal under which the leaders would step down -- but not until Parliament approved a general amnesty. Lawrence Rossin, a National Security Council staff member who accompanied the team to Port-au-Prince, quickly faxed a copy of the agreement to the White House.
Mr. Clinton pored over the document and found it wanting.
"Clinton's instant reaction was that it was totally unacceptable," a senior Administration official said today. "We could not let the departure date be dependent on something beyond our control."
The Administration was also apparently mindful that General Cedras had made his resignation last year contingent on a parliamentary amnesty, and then cited the failure to approve the amnesty as a reason for remaining in power.
As the invasion clock continued to click down, the President told his advisers he feared there was not enough time to make an agreement work.
Secretary Christopher argued that "it was essential" that the plan include a fixed date for the departure of the military leaders. Mr. Talbott, a journalist and author before joining the Administration, furiously rewrote the agreement. At Mr. Christopher's insistence, he inserted a departure deadline of Oct. 15, regardless of whether the Parliament passed a general amnesty.
Mr. Clinton grudgingly said he could live with that date.
 
The Haitians
Breaking News To Father Aristide
 The White House had another problem: how to break the news to Father Aristide that an imperfect deal was in the works.
When the ousted priest was informed about the Carter mission, he expressed the hope that no concessions would be made to the men who had ousted him from power.
After the American delegation relayed the outlines of a deal to the White House on Sunday afternoon, William H. Gray 3d, the Administration's special Haiti envoy, and Mr. Lake, the national security adviser, paid a call on Mr. Aristide.
The two men were in deep pain -- Mr. Lake had just undergone emergency oral surgery and Mr. Gray had lost a cap on one of his teeth.
"Things are moving very quickly, much faster than we thought," Mr. Lake told him. "We've got a lot of decisions to make and we need your input."
The exiled President was not at all happy with the agreement. In a two-hour meeting, he charged that the deal went further than the United Nations-brokered accord he signed with the military at Governors Island in July 1993, which made a vague reference to his right to grant amnesty for people who had committed political crimes.
The new agreement, he said, talks of "general amnesty." He peppered the officials with questions: What government did the document refer to -- his Government or the military Government in Haiti? Did the reference to American coordination with the Haitian military command refer to commanders he would name or to General Cedras' colleagues?
"I don't agree with these points," he said.
As for a clause in the agreement to lift the economic embargo, Mr. Aristide had already made clear that he staunchly opposed such a move until he was back in the Presidential Palace in Port-au-Prince.
His most serious complaint was that to allow the military to stay in power for a few weeks gave it legitimacy and delayed his return to power, according to people familiar with the meeting. He wanted to know why the deal included no demand that the military leaders leave the country.
"Mr. President," Mr. Gray replied, "with our military there and your return, do you really think the junta leaders want to stick around?"
The two American officials sought to play down the problems in the accord, dismissing them as minor details that could be worked out.
Father Aristide said he understood, but asked if it would not be better to clarify everything in writing?
Back at the White House, Mr. Lake and Mr. Gray reported Father Aristide's concerns.
Yet even as Mr. Carter and his team returned home triumphant today, Administration officials acknowledged that their problems had just begun. A sign of what remained to be done had come after midnight this morning, when Mr. Carter was awakened from a mid-air nap by a call from an aide at the United States Embassy in Port-au-Prince.
The Haitian leaders were upset, the aide told the former President, because Mr. Clinton's speech announcing the mission's success referred to them as dictators.

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI: IN WASHINGTON;
As President Claims Victory, Doubts Remain

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
President Clinton and his three high-level envoys declared success today in their last-gasp bargaining to avert an invasion of Haiti.
Mr. Clinton pledged that a peaceful American occupation now under way will "make sure that the leaders keep their word" to restore that country's first freely elected President. [Excerpts from the news conference by Mr. Clinton and his envoys, page A14.] 
 At the same moment, the first nagging differences over just how to pull that return off began surfacing in the White House, in Congress and in the offices of the Haitian leader Mr. Clinton seeks to reinstate, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
In separate remarks, the White House and the head of its delegation to Haiti, former President Jimmy Carter, appeared to disagree over whether the accord Mr. Carter helped negotiate on Sunday will -- or even should -- force Haiti's military dictators into exile. Some of Mr. Clinton's strongest supporters on Capitol Hill expressed doubt that Mr. Aristide would be able to rule effectively if the dictators remain on the island, as the agreement permits.
And Father Aristide's supporters expressed deep concern over parts of the agreement, including a provision that allows the dictators to remain in power for another month, although Father Aristide himself appears resigned to its terms.
The President, savoring a diplomatic victory whose nail-chewing drama seemed almost written for television, was having little of nay-saying today. Barely six hours after Mr. Carter and the other two envoys, Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia and Gen. Colin L. Powell, arrived in Washington from Haiti, Mr. Clinton hauled them to breakfast at the White House and, later, to a broadcast news conference in the chandelier-studded East Room.
There Mr. Clinton declared that "American steadfastness" had forced the Haitian military rulers, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras and Brig. Gen. Philippe Biamby, to finally adhere to a year-old promise to surrender power.
The three negotiators heaped praise on the President, who pressed his plans for an invasion most of this month with little visible support in opinion polls and less than that in Congress. Mr. Carter called him courageous; General Powell called the accord "your enormous achievement"; Senator Nunn hailed his "strong leadership."
Mr. Clinton chose to hedge his bets on the success of the operation, noting that Haiti has a history of violence and a military unaccustomed to relinquishing power freely.
"I want to emphasize that the situation in Haiti remains difficult; it remains uncertain; the mission still has risks," he said. "But clearly we are in a better position to work for peace in a peaceable way today than we were yesterday."
On Sunday, Mr. Clinton stepped up to and over the brink of military action, ordering American warplanes into the air to ferry paratroops to Haiti, before Messrs. Carter, Nunn and Powell finally won a promise from General Cedras and General Biamby to give up their power.
Lieut. Col. Michel Francois, the Port-au-Prince police chief and a third leader in the dictatorship, was said to be in hiding. Although other top Haitian officials strongly opposed the dictators' decision to resign, and Haiti's Defense Minister quit in protest, Administration officials said they did not expect Colonel Francois to be able to rally serious resistance to the occupation.
As 15,000 American troops began landing by ship and helicopter and fanning out across the island, General Powell praised Mr. Clinton's leadership and said that the President's willingness to enter into last-minute talks had averted a potential disaster.
"The image that we were all afraid we would see sometime this week has been avoided," General Powell said. "And that image was of American youngsters killing Haitian youngsters and Haitian youngsters killing American youngsters. Instead, what we see on our television screens this morning are tentative beginnings of the new relationship, where these armed forces are talking to one another."
The seven-point accord signed on Sunday is unusually vague, partly reflecting the haste in which it was drafted. Administration officials nevertheless anticipate no problems in interpreting its terms to their taste, largely because they believe the swarm of American troops in Haiti leave the generals little choice.
The agreement calls for "certain military officers" in Haiti's military command to resign their offices by Oct. 15 and for a new Parliament -- the current one is stacked with military supporters -- to be elected later "in a free and democratic manner."
It also calls for the Parliament to grant a general amnesty to an unspecified number of military officers, and for a rapid end to economic sanctions imposed by the United States, the Organization of American States and the United Nations.
Administration officials hope to replace the occupying force, which is to include small contingents from 24 other nations, with a smaller United Nations peacekeeping force within months. That army would number about 6,000 soldiers, perhaps half of them American.
General Powell urged the public today not to dwell on the fine points of the agreement, saying the details "will be worked out in due course."
"Let's not lose sight of the overall achievement," he said. "The U.N. resolutions will be executed. President Aristide will return. And we have the opportunity for a future of peace and democracy in Haiti and a superb relationship between our two countries."
Still, key parts of the accord seemed to turn on its more devilish details, a fact not lost on the participants today. No one knew for sure what would become of Generals Cedras and Biamby once they resign.
The Administration agreed in Sunday's talks that the generals would not have to leave Haiti, but only resign. Mr. Clinton said today that the Administration dropped suggestions of exile to keep the talks alive.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher said Sunday that while exile was not formally part of the accord, "for all practical purposes they are certain to leave."
"I doubt that they will want to stay there when President Aristide is returned to power," he said.
Mr. Carter, speaking this morning on CNN, called it "a serious violation of inherent human rights for a citizen to be forced into exile," and said the issue of whether or when to leave Haiti was for the generals to decide. Later, at his news conference, Mr. Clinton urged "that we not let this issue cloud the enormity of what has occurred."
But it was of clear concern to Father Aristide's backers and some members of Congress, who suggested that the generals might try to seize power again.
Randall Robinson, a Washington rights advocate and Aristide supporter whose hunger strike last spring spurred Mr. Clinton to decide to oust Haiti's dictators, said today that their exile "should be non-negotiable."
"Mr. Aristide only has a promise, the same promise he got last year at Governors Island," Mr. Robinson said, alluding to the 1993 agreement that General Cedras signed, and later abrogated, which called for him to cede power to Father Aristide by Oct. 15, 1993.
Senator Christopher Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat who is one of Mr. Clinton's most solid supporters in Congress, expressed skepticism about Sunday's agreement for similar reasons. "Unfortunately, we've seen the Haitian military make promises before that they haven't kept," he said. "And I, for one, am skeptical that they've changed their stripes."
A second pressing question is what the signers of the accord meant when they called for a general amnesty for the military.
Secretary Christopher said on Sunday that the United States believes that an amnesty should cover all 7,000 members of the military, and Mr. Clinton noted that Father Aristide had already agreed to an amnesty in the ill-fated Governor's Island accord.
But that amnesty covered only political crimes, not the murders, torture and other human rights abuses that Mr. Clinton and others insist that the dictators have engineered.
Father Aristide was not talking today. His allies said he has reservations about amnesty and other key parts of the accord. Representative Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., a Massachusetts Democrat, said Father Aristide told him today that he "was concerned by the notion that crimes against humanity, murders and tortures can be amnestied."
Equally uncertain was the true meaning of the agreement's call to lift economic sanctions "without delay," a phrase the Administration seemed to suggest today is meaningless. Instead, officials said, the United States will probably seek to link the easing of embargoes and thawing of frozen assets to the dictators' progress in filling their end of the bargain.
The United States representative at the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, said the timing of any action on sanctions must be "recalibrated."
Separately, the United Nations said it would soon send 100 civil rights experts to Haiti, as well as 60 military experts who will monitor the conduct of American forces.

LENGTH: 1316 words

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI: OVERVIEW;
3,000 U.S. TROOPS LAND WITHOUT OPPOSITION AND TAKE OVER PORTS AND AIRFIELDS IN HAITI

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept.19

 BODY:
As Haitian soldiers watched impassively, more than 3,000 American troops landed here today, taking control of airfields and ports in the first phase of a military operation that has forced recent enemies to become reluctant partners in the restoration of the country's elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
Descending from a fleet of Blackhawk helicopters just after 9:30 this morning, units of the United States Army's 10th Mountain Division landed at the same civilian airport where about 12 hours earlier a diplomatic delegation led by former President Jimmy Carter had departed after averting an American invasion. 
 The troops immediately dropped into traditional combat positions, lying prone on the ground and pointing their rifles toward the airport terminal. There was no hint of resistance from Haiti's small and ill-equipped army.
Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Shelton, commander of a military force that is expected to grow to 15,000 soldiers from 25 nations, went straight from the airport to military headquarters downtown, where he conferred with Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, the Haitian military commander in chief, who has been denounced by President Clinton for his junta's violations of human rights. Later the American commander described the one-hour meeting as cordial.
Outside military headquarters, curious Haitian civilians snapped photographs of the American soldiers and stared into the sky as Cobra helicopters flew overhead. At the port Haitian onlookers, who for weeks had been warned that an American invasion would endanger their lives, gaped, smiled and waved as soldiers in camouflage uniforms were disgorged from Navy landing ships.
"This is a nice Caribbean vacation," Lieut. Michael Tunnell of Kingsport, Tenn., said after arriving in the first contingent.
Emboldened by the presence of American troops, supporters of Father Aristide, who gathered at the port this afternoon, erupted in spontaneous cheers and chants, saluting the arrival of the Americans. In a country where skin color is a major source of class conflict, one poorly dressed, dark-skinned vendor of souvenirs approached a group of lighter-skinned Haitians sitting on the hoods of their expensive cars and began to berate them, calling them a pack of thieves and freeloaders.
"Yesterday you were saying 'no' to Aristide," he said. "Today you're watching the helicopters land, and you're not saying a thing. You've put me in jail, shot at my house and beaten me on the head, but not anymore. I have a right to live in this country too."
Late this afternoon, police and paramilitary troops armed with semiautomatic weapons broke up one pro-Aristide rally at the port, beating participants with nightsticks and planks of wood and chasing them for several blocks. Many demonstrators lost their shoes in their haste to escape beatings, and when they returned to retrieve them, the police again chased them away. American troops nearby watched but did not intervene, witnesses said.
To calm civilians, American helicopters flew low over the capital, broadcasting a message in Creole: "This is not war. Stay calm. We are here to bring democracy and humanitarian aid."
For their part, American soldiers said that they were relieved, and that the negotiated settlement announced on Sunday night made their job easier and reduced the likelihood of combat.
After the meeting at military headquarters, General Shelton spoke warmly of General Cedras and said the Haitian military chief would play an important role in many of the decisions made in the days ahead. He said he intended to "clear the rules with General Cedras" on such crucial questions as where Americans troops should be deployed and how Haitian paramilitary forces should be disarmed.
"We have stressed from the beginning that this is not an occupation force," General Shelton said at a news conference.
Maj. Gen. Jared Bates of the Pentagon's Joint Chiefs of Staff, who accompanied Mr. Carter on his diplomatic mission over the weekend, went even further. He said American forces here were working in partnership with the established Haitian authorities that Washington was deriding as a band of thugs only a few days ago.
"The Haitian Government is in charge," General Bates said in an interview this morning. "We are cooperating with them and they are cooperating with us."
General Bates also expressed optimism that the Haitian armed forces, whose history of human rights and other abuses has been widely documented, could be reformed.
"I do not know enough about this army to speak with you in any detail," he said. "But I can tell you that the people I have talked to over the last three days are prepared to make this arrangement work, and that's the most important thing. I'm looking to the future, not the past."
Though American officials here expressed satisfaction with the agreement that requires General Cedras to give up his post no later than Oct. 15, there were strong reservations from many quarters.
"I am perplexed," said a diplomat from a country that supports the restoration of Father Aristide. "Why give these guys three extra weeks?"
Several diplomats complained today that the Carter mission had made unnecessary concessions and had gotten too little in return. The United States "had them with their backs to the wall and a gun to their head, so why give them anything?" one asked.
Ever since General Cedras installed Emile Jonassaint as the country's de facto President in May, the Haitian authorities have said their two main goals were to force the United States to grant some form of diplomatic recognition and to obtain a commitment to lift the United Nations economic embargo that has strangled the Haitian economy.
Haiti achieved both those goals in the agreement Mr. Clinton approved, in exchange for promises of the sort the military has made before and always broken, diplomats here argued.
Indeed, in anticipation that economic sanctions will soon be lifted, vendors of black-market gasoline, which has been selling here for more than $8 a gallon, were frantically trying to unload their product today.
Many of Father Aristide's supporters said they too were unhappy with the agreement, which does not specifically oblige General Cedras and other military leaders to leave the country, but only to step down. They expressed alarm at the signs of coziness between American and Haitian military officers and said they feared a repetition of the Governors Island Agreement, in which General Cedras promised to step down and hand power back to Father Aristide in October 1993, but then reneged.
"I do not understand this course," said the Rev. Hugo Triest, coordinator of the Haitian Conference of Clergy. "What democracy can they restore with the military? What credibility can you give to a military that has not honored its word?"
Eudrice Raymond, a pro-Aristide Senator, said, "It is a Haitian custom not to admit you are wrong," adding that the agreement paves the way for military leaders to return to public life, and perhaps even run for office.
Despite statements by American officials that they expect their stay here to be brief, some Haitians were skeptical.
"You cannot ask me if I'm happy under a U.S. occupation," said Senator Ebrane Cadet, a supporter of General Cedras.
But Haitian military officers seemed eager to cooperate with the American forces. When Gen. David C. Meade, commander of the 10th Mountain Division from Fort Drum, N.Y., approached two members of the high command at the airport this morning, he was greeted with a crisp salute from Col. Marcial Romulus, the Haitian Army's chief of operations.
Moments later, an American soldier in full combat gear approached the terminal, surveyed the scene, saw that all was calm, and relaxed. "Slow down," he ordered another soldier. "There's nowhere to go."

INITIAL OPERATIONS
 Three battalions of infantry moved into Haiti yesterdya, landing in helicopters at the civilian international airport in the suburbs of Port-au-Prince. Battalions vary in size, but could number as many as 900 troops each. A total of 15,000 jtroops are expected to enter Haiti through the main port and the civilian airport over the next several days.
 Blackhawk attack helicopters andCobra gunships are patrolling the skies over Haiti.
 
IN CAP-HAITIEN
 The amphibious assault ship Wasp carries 1,900 marines from the Special Purpose Air-Ground Task Force based inCamp Lejeune, N.C. They are waiting to enter northern Haiti, including the city of Cap-Haitien. The mariners have been sailing off the coast of Haiti for several months.
 
IN DOWNTOWN PORT-AU-PRINCE
 
1. At dawn yesterday, two U.S. warships and a Coast Guard cutter glided into port and secured the main harbor. Derelict vessels were being removed to open the port.
 
2. Troops from the 10th Mountain Division, shuttled in by helicopter from the aircraft carrier Eisenhower, jumped to the tarmac at the airport and took up positions. The troops are from Fort Drum, N.Y., and are trained to move fast, without heavy tanks or artillery.
 
3. The troops secured the U.S. Embassy, the civilian airport, key roads and the area around the main port. A few troops were also dispatched to the Haitian military headquarters.
 
4. In the harbor last night: the Mount Whitney, an amphibious command ship used to control the Haitian operation, the Eisenhower, a U.S. frigate and a U.S. coastal patrol ship.

HEADLINE: Custody Fight in Capital: A Working Mother Loses

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA 

 BODY:
When Sharon Prost surrendered her two sons to her former husband's custody 11 days ago, it was the climactic act in a cautionary tale of two-career couples in the '90's.
To Ms. Prost, 43, a counsel to Senator Orrin G. Hatch, and the feminist legal groups rallying around her, the decision by a Washington judge to remove the children is chilling evidence of a judicial backlash against professional women. 
 To her former husband, Kenneth Greene, 48, the assistant executive director of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, and his supporters, the decision is an overdue affirmation of fathers who have long been victims of bias in the courts themselves.
It is a tale unfolding under the klieg lights of professional Washington, with a high-powered cast of players and some unexpected alliances. On one side are feminist legal groups whose outrage at the decision is matched only by that of Senator Hatch, the Utah Republican who angered many feminists with his combative questioning of Prof. Anita F. Hill during the Clarence Thomas hearings. And in Senator Hatch's generally conservative home state, several women's organizations have been collecting money to contribute to Ms. Prost's legal costs.
On the other side are fathers who say most judges automatically, and unfairly, favor mothers and who are hailing the ruling, made by a judge who is herself a mother.
The decision comes as more mothers of young children are working, as more fathers are aggressively seeking custody, and after a well-publicized Michigan case in which a mother going to college lost custody of her daughter because she had been placed in day care. And it raises questions that men and women are still struggling to answer -- how to balance motherhood and professional ambition, and how much fathers are willing to buck tradition by putting their children before their careers.
"I've had women all over Capitol Hill say, 'That could be us,' " said Senator Hatch, who has persuaded the Senate Ethics Committee to allow him to establish a legal defense fund for Ms. Prost. She is appealing the decision, which also requires her to pay $23,010 a year in child support, and hopes an appeals court will hear the case in November.
But David L. Levy, president of the Children's Rights Council, a Washington-based fathers' rights group, said the case showed that fathers were finally getting some credit as parents. "This was not a double standard," he said. "It's entirely consistent with who is perceived as doing more of the daily care of the child. It was all in favor of women before."
The battle lines were drawn after a July decision by Judge Harriett R. Taylor of the District of Columbia Superior Court. Ms. Prost, Mr. Greene and Judge Taylor would not comment for publication on the case, but their stands are vividly presented in the legal documents.
In a sharply worded opinion that offers a glimpse into the lives of two Washington professionals who married in 1984 and separated eight years later, Judge Taylor painted Ms. Prost as a driven workaholic who seldom arrived home before dinner and Mr. Greene as a doting father who put his children first.
In her opinion, Judge Taylor quotes friends and relatives of Mr. Greene's, as well as a baby sitter, who said Ms. Prost often ate dinner alone and very late at night, "while sitting on the kitchen floor, with her plate on the floor, talking on the telephone or writing while she was eating."
Friends of Mr. Greene described Ms. Prost as working even during her children's birthday parties, of "barking orders" at them, and of being "very tightly wound."
By contrast, the judge said Mr. Greene was a playful, affectionate parent to his two sons -- Matthew, 7, and Jeffrey, 4. Mr. Greene, Judge Taylor said, insisted that his current job, which he obtained after a nearly two-year bout of unemployment, offer him flexible hours.
In granting Mr. Greene custody, Judge Taylor said Ms. Prost was "more devoted to and absorbed by her work and her career than anything else in her life, including her health, her children and her family."
But Ms. Prost's supporters, including the Women's Legal Defense Fund, which filed a brief in the case, called that picture a distortion that reflected a common courtroom bias against working mothers.
"This is an injustice," Senator Hatch said. "Here's a professional woman I have seen day in, day out anguished over her children. This judge ignores the maximum effort that she made while rewarding the minimum effort that he made."
While Judge Taylor praised Mr. Greene for attending the parent interview for his son's kindergarten, going on class trips, and dropping by occasionally to read children a story, Ms. Prost's supporters argued, the judge ignored the testimony of the kindergarten teacher who said Ms. Prost was a "surrogate room mom."
Mr. Greene got credit for arriving home first, Ms. Prost's lawyers said, but Ms. Prost was not praised for getting up every morning at 5:30 and playing with her sons before she left for work at 8.
Moreover, Ms. Prost's supporters said, the judge ignored the testimony of a psychiatrist approved by both sides who said the children's primary attachment was to their mother, and failed to take into account that while Mr. Greene was unemployed, he did not take care of the children full time.
Joan Entmacher, senior policy counsel of the Women's Legal Defense Fund, a Washington-based legal advocacy group, asserted that such selective use of the testimony revealed that Judge Taylor was holding working mothers to a higher standard than working fathers.
Ms. Entmacher and Nancy D. Polikoff, a law professor at American University who has studied custody disputes, said several researchers had found that while in general mothers were usually awarded custody, fathers won a majority of the cases in which custody was contested. And, they said, the decisions reveal that when both parents have jobs, the courts judge mothers more harshly for working than the fathers.
Whether the Prost-Greene case shows discrimination against working mothers or an embrace of nurturing fathers depends on which of two bitterly contested accounts is given credence. For example, Ms. Prost testified that she never worked as late as Mr. Greene's witnesses said. Her job as chief minority counsel to the Senate Judiciary Committee, she said, forced her to work late only a few times a year, chiefly during confirmation hearings like those for Clarence Thomas and Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
Although he has opposed requiring employers to provide generous maternity leave, flexible working hours and job sharing, Senator Hatch testified that as a father of six, he instituted such benefits for his own workers.
Mr. Hatch said his office officially closed at 6 P.M. when the Senate was in session and 4:30 P.M. when it was in recess -- about half the year. In chiding Ms. Prost for her hours, Ms. Prost's lawyers said, the judge had clearly wrongly thought that the Senate was in recess only on Federal holidays. And Ms. Prost pointed to five and a half months of Senate day care logs showing that she never signed her younger son out of the center after 6 P.M., and often did so before 4 P.M.
But Sandra G. Wilkof, Mr. Greene's lawyer, said the judge was right to believe those witnesses who testified that Ms. Prost did indeed often return home after 7 or 8 P.M. "She couldn't convince the judge that a chief minority counsel works less than 40 hours a week, and I'm not surprised," she said. She asserted that the day care logs proved only that Ms. Prost was "showboating" by leaving early during the custody battle.
Ms. Wilkof, as well as two other lawyers and custody experts who reviewed the legal documents, Ellen Effron and Jeffrey Atkinson, dismissed the idea of sex bias. The real bias, Ms. Wilkof said, lies at the door of Ms. Prost, who expected that she should get the children because she is the mother.
Judge Taylor, in turning down a motion to alter her judgment, wrote that the bias assertion "boggles the mind." The judge, who is 62 and worked part time when her children were young, wrote, "A woman is as entitled as defendant, or any other man, to put her work and career ahead of the other demands in her life."
But she added, "Having consciously or unconsciously made that decision, however, plaintiff must live with its consequences."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Regain a Little From Big Friday Losses

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices recovered somewhat yesterday from a plunge on Friday as some investors took advantage of lower prices to buy.
The bond market was jolted on Friday by a Government report on industrial production that revived fears of accelerating inflation. Bond prices fell sharply, pushing yields, which move in the opposite direction, out of a trading range they had been in since July. Yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond rose 5/32 , to 972/32 , for a yield of 7.75 percent, down from 7.77 percent, a two-year high, on Friday. 
 "The market is getting pretty cheap," said Tom Carpenter, chief economist at ASB Capital Management in Washington, which has $10 billion in assets. "How much more it can get beat up is difficult to say."
Still, gains were limited by a perception that faster economic growth will push bond yields to 8 percent by the end of the year, traders and investors said.
The industrial production report on Friday suggested that the ecomomy would continue to grow briskly despite five increases in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve this year. The report fueled speculation that the Fed would need to raise rates again after its policy meeting Sept. 27 to slow the pace of inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income securities like bonds. Many analysts had expected the Fed to wait until its November meeting before acting.
"I guess the bond bulls are getting pretty bloody here," said Larry Marks, director of fixed-income research at Harbor Capital Management in Boston, which has about $600 million in fixed investments. "I've been on the bullish side, expecting the economy to slow down and bonds to respond. That keeps getting pushed further and further back."
If the Fed plans another rate increase, "Why buy?" said Charles Quigley, a trader at Chemical Securities in London. "On Friday, I felt yields had in no way begun to discount the next move by the Fed. If that's the case, backing up the market 10 or 15 basis points has only just begun the next leg lower." A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
Some investors said they would not place any major bets on the direction of interest rates until the Fed's next move is clear. "We'd like to wait until we see the whites of the Fed's eyes before making a major move," Mr. Marks Harbor Capital Management said.
Even though bonds have risen to their highest yields in more than two years, some investors are not convinced that inflation is accelerating.
"What we have done is more or less stay the course, because real rates of return are abnormally high," said John Ray, who manages a $400 million bond portfolio at Commerce Capital Management in Memphis.
At an economics conference at Boston College yesterday, Robert E. Rubin, the head of the National Economic Council, said the so-called inflation premium had been eliminated from long-term interest rates. He said the rise in rates came from a growing economy and modest inflation, not high inflation and slow growth.
At the regular weekly Treasury auction of three- and six-month bills yesterday, rates were mixed. The Treasury sold $11.6 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 4.61 percent, the same as last week, and $11.7 billion in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 5.05 percent, up from 4.99 percent last week.

HEADLINE: Tourism Rebounds in Affordable New York

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

 BODY:
Helped by favorable exchange rates and a growing domestic economy, New York City drew more tourists this summer than in any of the previous six years.
Not only did tourists visit traditional attractions like the Statue of Liberty and the Empire State Building in increasing numbers, but many, particularly those from overseas, ventured to less likely destinations, like Brooklyn and Harlem. 
 "This has been the best summer in recent memory," said Richard Altman, a spokesman for the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau. "For starters, New York is now more affordable for foreign tourists, and we've gotten a lot of good coverage lately in travel trade magazines."
The outlook for the rest of the year is also strong, he said.
"So far, we've beat every month over '93, and we expect that trend to continue well into '95."
Hotel occupancy in June was the highest in 14 years, and July's figures were the best since 1986.
New York City was not the only area that benefited. From Cape May, N.J., to Mystic Seaport in Connecticut and the beaches and resort towns of Long Island, the numbers of visitors surpassed those of last year, which was rated among the best ever.
At Mystic Seaport, for example, which is Connecticut's most popular tourist attraction, attendance over the Labor Day holiday weekend far surpassed last year's, said Liz Gwillim, director of external affairs.
Mike Beringer, spokesman for the tourism division of the Connecticut Department of Economic Development, said calls to the state's toll-free tourist information line had increased to 212,601 this summer, from 127,214 last year. "And that's a good barometer for the tourism industry here," he said.
In addition to a relatively weak dollar -- which makes travel less expensive for foreigners -- and a stronger domestic economy, the region's tourism industry was helped by major events like the Gay Games, the World Cup soccer matches and the United States Open tennis championships. Pope John Paul II's visit next month is also expected to increase tourism.
Roland Zochbauer, 32, who works for the public transportation system in Linz, Austria, said he had stayed away from New York for nine years because it cost too much the last time he visited.
"It cost me twice as much then," said Mr. Zochbauer, who had walked up Broadway and visited Times Square, Battery Park City, Liberty Island, the Empire State Building and Greenwich Village in the same day. "Now the dollar is much lower."
The World Cup soccer games pumped an estimated $400 million into the region's economy, and the Gay Games added an additional $111 million, officials said. The United States Open tennis tournament attracted 529,687 fans -- its largest attendance ever -- and contributed $112 million, said David Neustadt, a spokesman for the City Comptroller's office.
Tourism officials said many of the visitors, particularly those from Europe, were venturing to areas other than the usual destinations.
"There's a lot of interest in Harlem and the city's wide range of ethnic neighborhoods in Brooklyn and Queens," said Mr. Altman of the Convention and Visitors Bureau. "The American culture is something that folks from Japan and Europe really gravitate to."
Jannes Vanderwal, 45, a computer specialist from Utrecht, the Netherlands, was visiting New York City with his wife, Mariana, 44, a preacher, and said Harlem was on their list of places to visit.
"People in my country, and my friends here, say Harlem is terrible, but I don't believe it and I want to see it for myself," Mr. Vanderwal said.
A survey of 25 of the city's major hotels showed that 70 percent of the visitors were from the United States, 12 percent from Europe, 6 percent from the Far East and Pacific Rim, 4 percent from Canada and Mexico, 4 percent from South and Central America and 4 percent from various other locations, said John Fox, senior vice president of PKF Consulting, an international company specializing in the hotel and real-estate industries.
Compared with 1993, he said, the biggest increase was from the Far East and Pacific Rim, which showed a 7 percent gain, while the number of European guests increased 6 percent.
Hotel occupancy rates were also solid in other parts of the region. Michael Davidson, president of the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau, said the occupancy rates there were up 9 percentage points from last year and 10 percentage points from 1992.
"Even though we had a hot and muggy July and some cool days in August, it was a good weather year for tourists, and advance reservations indicate that the fall is shaping up very strong as well," Mr. Davidson said.
This summer was also lucrative for the travel and tourist business in New Jersey, said Karen G. Shaffer, spokeswoman for the travel and tourism division of the New Jersey Department of Commerce and Economic Development. She said hotel, motels and inns reported a strong increase in bookings over last year.
Some visitors to New York City said they were drawn by the city's allure. Fernando Herrero, 37, a banker from Madrid, hiked over the Brooklyn Bridge on Friday.
"It's the capital of the world more or less, culturally, economically and socially," he said. "I have seen a lot about the city on TV and in pictures -- the movie 'Manhattan' by Woody Allen, for example."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
 
First Financial won the bidding for Western Union Financial Services in an unusual bankruptcy court auction after Forstmann Little and First Data withdrew. First Financial, an Atlanta company in credit card processing and debt collection, offered $1.193 billion for the New Valley subsidiary. [Page D1.] 

Federated will close six stores in metropolitan New York in its merger with Macy, including Abraham & Straus, Herald Square. Separately, Myron E. Ullman 3d, Macy's chairman, said he would resign at the end of January. [D1.]
Prudential Securities agreed to pay $1.1 million in fines and restitution to settle charges of securities law violations with Idaho state regulators. In settling the case, Prudential admitted that it had failed to supervise some of its brokers adequately. [D1.]
In another salvo in the Haft family battle for Dart Group, Herbert H. Haft sued a son, Ronald S. Haft, accusing him of taking part in a plan to misappropriate at least $7 million. [D2.]
Nestle will buy Alpo Petfoods for $510 million in cash. The purchase, from Grand Metropolitan, should strengthen Nestle's strong presence in the United States pet food market. [D5.]
The $12.6 billion AT&T-McCaw deal was completed, with the F.C.C's approval. AT&T is expected to move swiftly to invest in new digital equipment and introduce new services. [D5.]
Cooper Industries plans to spin off its petroleum and industrial-equipment business into a separate company. [D5.]
Coca-Cola forecast that international sales would grow by 14 percent in the third quarter, and its stock jumped. [D5.]
Micron Technology's chief and two other top officers quit, citing personal reasons. The departures surprised analysts. [D6.]
A Federal court refused to reinstate Apple Computer's 1988 copyright suit against Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard. [D6.]
 
The Economy
 
Alan Greenspan urged that banks be allowed to sell stocks and insurance. Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, called on Congress to lift barriers to these businesses. [D2.]
Tourism boomed this summer in the New York region, helped by favorable exchange rates and a growing domestic economy. [B1.]
 
Markets
 
The collapse of the market for bonds backed by home mortgages is being mourned on Wall Street. The bonds, known as mortgage-backed securities, make up $1.5 trillion, or 30 percent, of the total U.S. bond market. In recent years, they accounted for half or more of the earnings of some firms. But when interest rates shot up, mortgage refinancings fell and the firms lost money. [D1.]
Stocks ended little changed despite big gains in Coca-Cola and Eli Lilly. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.37 points. [D10.]
Crude oil prices jumped as traders focused on winter heating demand and tensions in Saudi Arabia. Coffee prices surged. [D17.]
The dollar fell against the yen amid expectations that a report would show a wider United States trade gap with Japan. [D17.]
Bonds posted a modest recovery from a steep fall on Friday as investors took advantage of lower prices. [D20.]
 
Today's Columns
 
The speculative tide in bonds is rising again, despite the large losses suffered by many investors this year. The optimism of investors shows that many think the worst is over and reflects the fact that they have not grown concerned about the poor returns of the Treasury market. But the heavy borrowing of money to buy bonds alarms some analysts. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
To promote its fall lineup, CBS is pulling out all the stops, including a late-night infomercial, pullout magazine ads, T-shirt offers and a CD-ROM. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D21.]

HEADLINE: Cuomo Proposes a Cut in Utility Tax

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FARMINGDALE, L.I., Sept. 19

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo traveled today to Long Island, where residents pay among the highest electric rates in the United States, to propose an election-year cut in a state tax on utilities that is passed on to consumers.
Four years ago, the Governor and the Legislature raised the tax, which is known as the gross receipts tax, by 15 percent to help balance the state budget at the height of the recession. Mr. Cuomo said he was not prepared today to say how much the tax should be cut or how the state would compensate for the lost revenue. 
 With utility rates a major business and political issue on Long Island, and with Long Island an important battleground in this year's gubernatorial race, Mr. Cuomo used his speech at the State University at Farmingdale to propose other measures aimed at reducing rates. All of the proposals made something of a bogyman of the Long Island Lighting Company, which holds a virtual monopoly on providing electricity in Nassau and Suffolk counties.
"We hold the proposition that the rates are too high and that they are unnecessarily high," Mr. Cuomo said. He added that he wanted the savings from the tax cut to be passed along to consumers. "We're in no mood to cut taxes to increase the profits of utilities," he said. "We want to reduce the costs of the ratepayer."
Besides proposing the tax cut, Mr. Cuomo called for a decrease in Lilco rates, instead of the two-year freeze that the utility has proposed to the Public Service Commission. He also said he would ask the Public Service Commission, whose members he appoints, to open Long Island to competition from other energy providers, possibly by forcing Lilco to transport electricity from other utilities over its lines. And he said he had asked state officials to study the feasibility of a public takeover of Lilco, a threat that has been used in the past.
Tax cuts have become a major issue in the Governor's re-election campaign against State Senator George E. Pataki, the Republican nominee. Mr. Pataki also has pledged a significant decrease in state taxes, but has yet to release a detailed plan. He is expected, however, to call for cutting the utilities tax, his aides said.
Mr. Pataki's aides depicted Mr. Cuomo's announcement as a campaign ploy. "It's a shame there isn't an election every month or we wouldn't have to be rolling back any of Mario Cuomo's massive tax increases," said Zenia Mucha, a Pataki spokeswoman.
During the recession, Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature canceled the third installment of a three-year cut in personal income taxes and raised taxes on businesses, petroleum and cigarettes. One of the increases was a 15 percent surcharge on the gross receipts tax, which is set at 4.25 percent of the revenues of utility companies.
Both business leaders and residential ratepayers have criticized the tax as regressive and a deterrent to growth, particularly in industries that use a lot of electricity, like high technology, and in regions like Long Island where the cost of power is already the highest in the continental United States.
This year, with the economy improving and the election approaching, the Governor and Legislature cut taxes by about $475 million, an amount that is expected to grow to about $1.6 billion when the reductions are fully implemented in 1997. One of the cuts reduced the surcharge on the gross receipts tax to 12.5 percent from 15 percent.
Last month, Mr. Cuomo said he would propose an additional tax cut of between $1 billion and $1.5 billion before the Nov. 8 election. Today was the first time he specified a tax to be cut under his plan. But he said he would not provide further details until he receives recommendations on tax cuts from his tax commissioner, James W. Wetzler, presumably within the next few weeks.
While the Governor's tax plan would affect the entire state, his other proposals were targeted at Long Island. He said he would ask the Public Service Commission to promote competition for Lilco by providing open access to the transmission lines owned by the utility. And he said the state would study the feasibility of constructing a transmission line of its own.
A Lilco spokeswoman said the company would cooperate with those studies and said it supported the Governor's plan to cut utility taxes. "We would welcome relief for our customers from the burden of these high taxes," said the spokeswoman, Suzanne Halpin. "If adopted, the Governor's proposal would be a step forward in reducing energy costs."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Three Top Officers To Leave Micron

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The chief executive of Micron Technology Inc., Joseph L. Parkinson, and two other top officers resigned from the computer chip company yesterday, citing personal reasons.
Top officers of Micron's largest subsidiary, the chip making operation, were named to lead the parent company. 
 The action surprised analysts because Micron, the world's ninth-largest maker of memory chips, has had no apparent financial trouble.
It is expected to report its performance for the fiscal fourth quarter later this week. Analysts have forecast a profit of $1.21 a share, down from $1.52 a year earlier.
"Usually, when you watch a company you see some shuffling around that suggests a transition," said Jim Handy, principal analyst at Dataquest Inc., in San Jose, Calif. "We didn't see anything that indicated to us there would be any change that way here."
A spokeswoman for Micron, Julie Nash, said she could not elaborate on the resignations.
Micron, based in Boise, Idaho, has grown steadily in the last five years, taking advantage of the recession in Japan to gain market share against its toughest competitors.
Mr. Parkinson, who is also the chairman and co-founded the company with his brother, Ward, in 1978; the president, James W. Garrett, and the chief financial officer, Reid N. Langrill, will leave Micron during the next month.
The head of Micron's semiconductor subsidiary, Steven R. Appleton, will take over as chairman and chief executive. The division's chief technical officer, Tyler Lowrey, and chief financial officer, Bill Stover, will assume those titles for the entire company.
"The guys who are coming up are very strong," said Thomas Thornhill, an analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. "It is a surprise that these other guys are leaving, unexpected."
Mr. Parkinson, Mr. Garrett and Mr. Langrill will continue to consult with Micron for six months after their resignations are effective.
Micron's stock has risen during the last year, although the climb has sometimes been unsteady. Like other technology stocks, it is sometimes subject to sudden swings.
Shares of Micron fell $1.75, to $39.675, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, before the resignations were announced.
"With them all leaving at a time when the stock is flying high, I think people will be able to look onto the fundamentals of the business," Mr. Handy of Dataquest said.
But, he added, "I sure wish I knew what precipitated it."
The company's growth in the last two years has exceeded that of virtually every other memory chip maker, with the exception of Samsung Electronics of Korea, which emerged last year as the No. 1 manufacturer. Its products are used in personal computers and other electronic products.
Earlier this summer, Micron announced that it would expand its test and assembly plant in Boise, where it employs 5,300 people.
Micron earned $259 million on sales of $1.14 billion during the nine months that ended on June 2. In addition to chip manufacturing, Micron builds computers, communications systems and display devices.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mostly Flat but a Few Big Names Surge

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market closed little changed yesterday. But the final figures masked some notable rises in stocks, like Coca-Cola and Eli Lilly, as well as trading heavily influenced by high-speed computer-aided transactions.
Stock traders largely ignored the peaceful resolution of the Haitian crisis, and international currency traders paid more attention to anticipating this morning's release of July trade-deficit figures than they did to peace in the Caribbean. They bid down the value of the dollar in advance of the figures, which are expected to show a wider deficit and thus lead to a weakening of the dollar. 
 Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.37 points, to 3,936.72, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.34 point, to 470.85. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index was off 1.19 points, to 776.72.
The Dow rose early, setting a gain of almost 20 points about 10:45 A.M. But a spurt in trading around 1:40 P.M., detected by Birinyi Associates, quickly clipped about 8 points off the average. After that, the Dow fell steadily for 50 minutes, then oscillated. A surge in buy orders at the end of the session, probably computer related, lifted the Dow less than 3 points.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was below normal, with 277.1 million shares changing hands, about 3 percent below this year's average of 286 million shares.
Coca-Cola rallied the markets early with a forecast, released before Wall Street trading began, that its worldwide sales would be up 12 percent in the third quarter, probably producing its best quarter in five years and significantly exceeding analysts' estimates. Coca-Cola rose 1 1/4, to 49, on heavy volume of nearly three million shares. Coke, one of the 30 Dow stocks, added almost 4.5 points to the Dow average.
Eli Lilly also rose sharply, up 2 3/8, to 58 3/8, after several analysts revised their assessments of the drug company. In addition, Lilly reported that it and Somatogen, its partner in developing artificial blood products, had made enough progress that Lilly was increasing the venture's research funds by $1 million.
Shares of Time Warner were up 1 3/8, to 37 5/8, after Dan Dorfman, a financial columnist in USA Today, reported that General Electric might be studying a bid for Time Warner. G.E. denied the report; its shares were off 1/2, to 50 1/2.
McGraw-Hill, another media giant, saw its shares drop 1, to 75 1/2, but they remained close to their 52-week high of 77 1/4, set on Friday. McGraw-Hill had no comment that day when the New York Stock Exchange asked if it had any news to report. McGraw-Hill has been the subject of rumors about a takeover by Bertelsmann of Germany or another large European conglomerate.
Andrea Electronics, whose stock more than quintupled to 53 a share in the summer of 1993 and then fell to around 12 recently, zoomed again yesterday. It rose 7 7/8, to 19 5/8, on heavy volume after announcing that BellSouth would use Andrea's noise-reduction technology in some of its telephones.
Safety Components International rose 2 3/4, to 17 1/4, yesterday after the company said that its military subsidiary had won a $65 million United States Army contract to supply mortar cartridges.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.14 point, to 259.63, with advancing stocks lagging behind those declining, 1,214 to 966. The American Stock Exchange market-value index rose 1.27 points, to 461.13.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 14 rose, led by International Paper, which gained 1 5/8, to 78 1/4, on no immediate news.
Among the stocks that make up the S.& P. 500 index, 221 fell, led by General Electric.
The most active stock, at 4.7 million shares, was Intel, which rose 3/8, to 67 1/4, after a recommendation by the manager of a Fidelity fund.

HEADLINE: Scrappy Arcade Owner Gives Up the Fight

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 19

 BODY:
For the first time in 12 years, Pac-Man and Turbo aren't working at Arnie's Place. The arcade, which divided this wealthy suburb and led to repeated court battles, closed Sunday after customers played their last rounds of pinball, air hockey and shoot-'em-up video games like Revolution.
In the end, Arnie Kaye, the flamboyant owner, said he was worn out from his disputes with town officials. 
 "I've spent more than a million dollars in legal fees fighting for my right to stay open, and we're not doing the business we used to do," he said. "It's a combination of economics and disgust. I feel I have been harassed by the town long enough and it's time to pack it in."
Town officials, however, say the harassment went both ways. They recall Mr. Kaye's threats to turn the arcade, located on Post Road, into a pornographic theater and to let members of the Hell's Angels take up residence there, as well as his refusal to comply with zoning regulations.
Still, there is nostalgia about the closing of the arcade, which Mr. Kaye, 53, said was moving to Brewster, N.Y., about an hour away, under new owners.
"I'm saddened that it's closing," said William Seiden, a former First Selectman who opposed the arcade's opening and once had Mr. Kaye arrested for trying to force his way into Mr. Seiden's office.
"I made a mistake on the game room, no doubt about that," Mr. Seiden said. "I thought it would be detrimental to kids, but it wasn't. He ran it well, and it ended up actually being a big asset for the town. It became a good place for young people to play."
Most town officials felt otherwise in 1982.
"We were initially concerned about traffic, and parking in particular," said Constance Greenfield, who was a member of the Zoning Commission when it rejected Mr. Kaye's original request for a zoning permit and who later, as chairwoman of the commission, battled with Mr. Kaye over other zoning issues. "We had never had anything like what he was proposing.
"We wanted to keep this a beautiful, quiet New England suburban town. We didn't want it to become a city."
Mr. Kaye, calling town officials snobs, did not give up. To draw attention to his plight, he chained himself to Town Hall, hired someone to dress as Pac-Man and hand out $50 bills to anyone wearing an "I Support Arnie's Place" T-shirt and appeared on national talk shows.
"Their opposition boomeranged on them," Mr. Kaye said. "We opened up anyway and all the notoriety and attention helped to bring in thousands of people in the beginning. I was in business, and Mr. Seiden lost the next election."
Three weeks after the arcade was opened, on June 14, 1982, it was closed by a Superior Court judge, who then ordered the Zoning Commission to reconsider Mr. Kaye's application. A month later, the commission granted approval, but limited Mr. Kaye to 50 machines. He installed 80 machines, prompting the town to take court action that led to removal of the extra machines.
Then, things got nasty.
Mr. Kaye, saying it was hypocritical for the town to allow a topless bar but deny his request for more machines, threatened to turn his property into a pornographic theater and name it after Mr. Seiden. Then, he invited members of the Hell's Angels Motorcycle Club to town and offered them a rent-free home.
There have also been fights over parking and over what the town contends is Mr. Kaye's use of more square feet in his business than is allowed under the zoning codes, an issue still being fought over in the courts.
"My threats got more and more bizarre as my frustrations grew," Mr. Kaye said. "All I wanted to do was provide a clean, wholesome environment for kids where they could play and have fun. I'll always be proud of having done that."
Mr. Kaye said he planned to rent out the building, form a political watchdog committee and run for selectman so he could change Westport's zoning laws.
Many longtime patrons stopped by Arnie's Place over the weekend to play a few last games.
"It really stinks that they forced him to close down," said Daniel Schine, who brought his four children and four of their friends. "It's one of the few places in town where kids can do something at night that doesn't involve trouble. I always felt my kids were safe here."
Jonathan Stichel, 14, said, "It's our last chance, and we're going to play as many games as we can for as long as we can."
His 12-year-old brother, Alexander, added sadly: "There's no other place around here like this. I guess we'll just have to watch a lot more television now."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Although Arnie's Place in Westport, Conn., was intended as an arcade, the wars there went beyond Pac-Man and video shootouts to battles with town officials over zoning regulations. "My threats got more and more bizarre as my frustrations grew," said Arnie Kaye, in his arcade, which closed Sunday. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Losing Bond Investors Are Betting Again

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
This year is shaping up as the worst ever for bond market investors -- and yet there are signs that speculation in bonds is building again as investors who lost money betting on bonds decide to step up and place new bets.
It is that speculation -- which shows up as the heavy borrowing of money to buy bonds -- that alarms some bond market analysts and persuades them that bond prices might have farther to fall. 
 The clearest indication of that is the amount of money that the largest bond dealers are lending to investors to buy Treasury securities. That figure peaked at $216 billion last fall, not long after the bond market itself peaked. Then, as bond market losses grew and speculators fled for cover, it fell to $125 billion in April.
But it has been rising since then, and last week the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported that the lending was back to $206 billion as of Aug. 17. To be sure, the figures are volatile from week to week, but even looking at them on a five-week moving average the figure has risen from a low of less than $150 billion to $189 billion now.
"These numbers show there is no fear" among bond investors, said James A. Bianco, the director of research at Arbor Trading Group, a brokerage firm in Barrington, Ill. "People are still comfortable doing this even after a year in which the market has not rewarded them for doing this."
Much of that borrowing -- as well as borrowing from other lenders such as banks -- is for a strategy of borrowing at short-term rates and buying longer-term securities. That produces a clear profit -- it is called a "carry" in the business -- if rates remain level. But if short-term rates rise, the cost of financing the position goes up, eroding or even wiping out the profits. And higher rates for longer-term securities can drive down the value of the longer-term securities that were purchased.
The sheer amount of speculation earlier this year was widely held responsible for the rapidity with which interest rates rose. Many speculators, ranging from huge hedge funds to small investors who thought they had found an easy way to make money, unwound their positions quickly, driving interest rates higher. But many analysts had thought the speculative tide in the bond markets had eased.
There is no clear measure of the total amount of bond market speculation. The figures on borrowing from the leading bond dealers -- called primary dealers -- is only a small part of the speculation. But the fact that it is headed up has caught attention as a sign that many investors believe the worst is over for bonds, and that the big profits of the past three years are the norm.
"There has been a great speculative mania in bonds, conditioned by these three years in which you could do no wrong if you were long," said James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, a New York financial newsletter. "The reflex in the bond market is to be long and levered," he added, using market slang for owning bonds purchased with borrowed money.
The data on lending by primary dealers cover the period only up to the last increase in short-term interest rates by the Fed in August, and reflect a widespread confidence at that time that the Fed's move would be the last one for a while and that bond prices were likely to rally.
They did for a time but recently fell back and the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds rose to 7.77 percent, the highest since June 1992. Yesterday, bond prices rallied a bit, pushing the yield on 30-year bonds down to 7.75 percent.
The optimism of investors shows that many think the worst is over in the bond market and reflects the fact that they have not grown concerned about the poor returns of the Treasury market. According to figures compiled by Ryan Labs of New York, the worst 12 months ever for investors in 30-year Treasuries was from April 1979 through March 1980, when an investor lost 17.2 percent of the value of such bonds, even after considering the income from the bond's coupon.
But, Mr. Bianco said, a buyer of 30-year bonds at last October's high for bond prices, when the 30-year bond yield fell to 5.78 percent, has seen a loss of 18.3 percent since then through Friday.
Most bond market investors own bonds with maturities far shorter than 30 years, and as a result suffer less when interest rates rise. But even so, this has been an unusually bad year for bonds. Ryan Labs computes a total return index for the entire market of Treasury notes and bonds, and calculates that from the start of the year through Friday the market had taken a loss of 3.54 percent. That is, the capital losses on longer-term bonds have offset the interest income by that amount.
Given the nature of the Treasury markets, such losses are highly unusual. The last full year in which Treasury investors incurred a loss was in 1969, when the deficit came to seven-tenths of 1 percent. Ryan Labs has computed its index back to 1950, and reports that the worst calendar year was in 1959, when the loss came to 2.34 percent.
To Mr. Bianco, the fact that speculation in the bond market has come roaring back, even amid such losses, is proof that investors remain overconfident. When the market really bottoms, and interest rates top out, he believes that there will be far fewer investors willing to speculate on bonds. For now, he says, the current wave of speculators is unlikely to make money.
