HEADLINE: Major Tokyo Quake Would Cost $1.2 Trillion, Study Says

 BODY:
THE economic damage that would be caused by a major earthquake in Tokyo could reach $1.2 trillion, enough to send tremors through global economic markets and disrupt the economies of other countries, a researcher says.
"The effect would be massive and worldwide," forcing Japan to withdraw its foreign investments and focus on rebuilding its capital city, said the researcher, Dr. Haresh Shah, a professor of civil engineering at Stanford University. 
 Dr. Shah led a team of Stanford researchers in a recent study that assessed potential losses from great earthquakes in Tokyo, San Francisco Bay and Los Angeles. In all three places, the study predicted economic damage would be twice as great as previously estimated while the number of deaths would be cut in half.
The results, which have not yet been published in a scientific or academic journal, are similar to figures compiled in a separate study to be made public later this year by the California Office of Emergency Services. Risk Management Solutions Inc., a private company in Menlo Park, Calif., that represents more than 100 insurance agencies, sponsored the study after deciding that earlier estimates were not realistic. A 1981 report of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, for example, warned that its findings contained an error potential of a factor of two or three.
The Stanford researchers found that a repetition of the Great Kanto earthquake that demolished Tokyo in 1923 and killed 140,000 people could cause 40,000 to 60,000 deaths today. That earthquake is estimated to have measured 8.3 on the Richter scale of ground motion. In California, a recurrence of the 8.3-magnitude earthquake that struck San Francisco in 1906 and killed 3,000 people could cause 2,000 to 6,000 deaths and $115 billion to $135 billion in economic damage, the study found.
And a 7.0-magnitude earthquake on the densely populated Newport-Inglewood fault in the Los Angeles area could cause 2,000 to 5,000 deaths and $125 billion to $145 billion in losses. By comparison, the Northridge earthquake of 6.7 magnitude on Jan. 17 killed 60 people and caused up to $20 billion in financial losses.
Experts say the lower casualty figures are not surprising and are mainly due to improved building codes, which aim to save lives rather than minimize structural damage.
"Some damage is a positive thing because energy of the earthquake is dissipated," said Dr. Andrei M. Reinhorn, professor of structural engineering at the State University of New York at Buffalo. But he said that preserving lives had come at a cost. Many buildings, even some that appear sound, require extensive and costly repairs after an earthquake. Sometimes they must be demolished.
The study concluded that about 40 percent of estimated economic losses constituted brick-and-mortar repairs. An equal amount was attributed to the costs of business interruption, a category that was not included in previous studies. Repairs to roads, bridges and utilities, and workers' compensation claims accounted for the remainder.
The researchers' estimates have potentially devastating consequences for the insurance industry and could bankrupt some companies, said Robert B. Downer, vice president of the actuarial department at Farmers Insurance in Los Angeles. "We just don't have the surplus at this point to incur a loss of that magnitude," he said. "Most insurance companies would be in the same position."
The science of calculating loss estimates in earthquake-prone areas is still a developing field. Risk Management Solutions used a new computer mapping technique that combined data about individual structures and geological conditions to determine, house by house, the consequences of a catastrophic earthquake.
The study did not seek to predict the probability of such an event, but earthquake experts say a California earthquake of 7.0 magnitude or higher is likely in the next 30 years.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
The Strike Hits Home: Mets Drop 28 From Front Office

BYLINE: By JENNIFER FREY 

 BODY:
Craig Sanders worked in media relations. Bob O'Hara was the team traveling secretary, the person who made the hotel and plane reservations for the Mets. Vinny Greco helped care for the team's equipment. Randye Ringler worked in communications.
Today, they are all out of work. Sanders, O'Hara, Greco and Ringler were among 28 members of the Mets' front-office staff who found themselves unemployed when the Mets pared their front-office staff yesterday as a result of the cancellation of the remainder of the season. 
 In a release issued late yesterday afternoon, the Mets announced that they had trimmed their front-office staff to 51 people, the latest cuts coming in addition to earlier cutbacks that affected 38 part-time, seasonal, or full-time employees.
"If I were in Fred Wilpon's or Nelson Doubleday's shoes, I don't know that I wouldn't have done the same thing," said Sanders, a four-year employee, referring to the team's co-owners. "I appreciate the organization and everything it has done for me. But it was a really sad day. Some people were really hit hard."
The cutbacks were heaviest in the area of ticket operations, but affected personnel ranging from Greco, who worked in the Mets' clubhouse, to Ringler, who was the director of communications. Secretaries in several departments -- some with more than 10 years of service -- also were affected. Some employees were terminated, but "a large majority are layoffs, with the hope they will return," according to David Howard, the club's general counsel.
More than a dozen clubs have made front-office layoffs.
Both the Reds and the Padres have released their directors of public relations, and calls to Jim Ferguson's former office in San Diego are greeted by this message: "This is Jim Ferguson. Press zero to return to the switchboard. You'll have to talk to somebody else. I don't work here anymore."
The Yankees have refused to release specific information regarding their front-office cutbacks, but David Sussman, the team's general counsel, said yesterday that of the the approximately 50 employees at the New York office, the Yankees had "furloughed a significant percentage." Most employees will be eligible to reapply for their positions when the labor situation is resolved.
"The majority of my time the past few weeks has been listening to fans who are unhappy about the strike," Sanders said. "Now, I guess I have something more to complain about than most people."

HEADLINE: The Fall of a Baseball Autumn;
The Ballplayers' Strike Seems to Have Been Inevitable

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The baseball season was about to expire when management and union representatives met in New York to try to find some common ground on which they could salvage negotiations and forge a new collective bargaining agreement. At one point, Stan Kasten, the Atlanta Braves' president, rose and made two columns on a blackboard, and then began drawing connecting lines.
Whatever Kasten intended, the union didn't get his point. According to a person who attended the session, Kasten said: "Well, my first idea didn't work, so I'll go to my second." 
 "What was your first?" he was asked.
The extent of this miscommunication at a meeting Sept. 10 points up the breadth of the gap the two sides were trying to bridge as they worked, unsuccessfully, to settle the labor dispute that was keeping the players out on strike. That it still existed even at their last face-fo-face meeting and only four days before the season was called off underscores how totally the players and owners had failed to bridge that gap.
Nearly 775 players are in the 40th day of their walkout today, but the number has become meaningless. The shutdown, the eighth work stoppage in 23 baseball seasons, has become the most devastating in sports history and threatens to become worse, holding the potential to wreck the 1995 season as well.
In retrospect, the strike that began Aug. 12 appears to have been inevitable. The two sides entered the negotiations so distant in their economic thinking that they never were able to traverse the gulf between them. In fact, interviews in recent days with members of both sides have established that there were few moments in the talks that offered even the barest hint of movement.
Some of the most experienced minds on the players' side saw the owners' actions over the last four years as providing footprints that form an unmistakable trail. From the lockout-ending agreement in 1990 to the ouster of the commissioner in 1992 to the vote that changed the ratification requirement in 1994, the owners, in the union's view, had led the players to a strike that has wrenched the World Series out of its permanent place in the nation's psyche.
The owners' current labor initiative began with the desire of some lower-revenue clubs to create a system under which the wealthier teams would share a greater portion of their revenue. But they linked that system to a salary cap for the players, reviving an idea they had proposed in the 1990 negotiations.
Fay Vincent was baseball's commissioner then. When the clubs' negotiators were making no progress toward reaching agreement and ending the owners' lockout in March 1990, Vincent offered to lend his conciliatory hand to the talks.
For some owners, his hand was too conciliatory. Two years later, Bud Selig of the Milwaukee Brewers and Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox, who as members of management's labor relations committee had endorsed the agreement Vincent negotiated, led a movement to force the commissioner's resignation. No commissioner, they vowed, would undermine the owners' bargaining position again.
"This effort was undertaken shortly after Fay Vincent took the salary cap off the table in 1990," Eugene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, said of the owners' current strategy. "Some people realized then that having a guy like that around was an obstacle, and this has been in the works the past four years."
Selig denied the existence of any link between any previous negotiation and this one.
"I've heard that theory and I reject it totally and completely," he said. "All the events that have happened have happened for a myriad of reasons and each event has happened for different reasons. The Fay Vincent thing, in my mind, was not because of labor. It was for many things that were not happening. As to what happened in 1990, now you have this huge turnover of owners who came in and became convinced that they can't live with this system."
But a person intimately familiar with the thinking of Selig and Reinsdorf echoed the view of the people on the players' side.
"They didn't plan in any great detail how this would work," said the person, who has worked with both Selig and Reinsdorf and spoke on the condition of anonymity. "But once the 1990 negotiation ended, Selig and Reinsdorf immediately thought that 1994 was going to be the year, and they'd have to do things differently."
The idea, the person related, was to remove Vincent and anyone else they perceived as soft on labor. That included Steve Greenberg, the deputy commissioner and a former player agent. The owners didn't fire Greenberg, but they kept him out of labor matters and he eventually resigned.
Selig and Reinsdorf both have talked about the damage they felt commissioners have done owners in labor negotiations.
"They felt that if Vincent hadn't done what he did, they would've made a breakthrough in 1990," the person familiar with their planning said.
As far as Donald Fehr, the union chief, is concerned, Exhibit B was the owners' action at a meeting in Cincinnati last June 8. With Reinsdorf the architect of the plan, the owners changed from a simple majority of 15 to a three-fourths vote of 21 the required number of owners needed to ratify an agreement reached during a strike. This meant that a smaller group of moderate owners couldn't form a coalition to push for an agreement against the wishes of the hard-liners.
Fehr called the change "ominous" and said, "That is an act of people preparing for war."
The war has only escalated since.
 
Selig Produces Solidarity
 Selig has been the acting commissioner since Vincent was deposed. The owner of the Milwaukee Brewers, he also has spearheaded the effort to induce high-revenue clubs to share more of their local revenue with low-revenue clubs like his.
In a remarkable display of consensus building and power of persuasion, the 60-year-old Selig has held his colleagues together as they have marched toward the goal they failed to attain in 1990 -- a cap on payrolls in the face of soaring salaries.
With help from a corps of tough-minded owners, Selig has succeeded in molding a solidarity the owners never have shown in labor negotiations and one that would have brought a beaming smile from Vince Lombardi, the fabled coach of Selig's beloved Green Bay Packers.
The owners, in fact, seem to be pleased that they have reached this point without doing their quadrennial surrender. The only other time they held together this long was during the 50-day strike in 1981, but the glue then was their strike insurance. They don't have that crutch this time.
"The owners remind me of a team in the locker room at halftime of a football game," Randy Hendricks, a player agent, said. "The scoreboard says 0-0, they've lost two of their star players, half the fans have gone home and they're celebrating because they wondered if they could play the game hard against the other side."
Selig said he hasn't seen that reaction. "It's absolutely foolish because no one has won anything," he added. "All parties are suffering economically and psychologically. Yes, the owners held together, but no rational person could be gleeful. There's nothing to be gleeful about because it's in no one's best interest to be where we are. If they're gleeful, they're misguided."
 
A Moderate Owner Makes No Difference
 Toward the end of the second week of the strike, a group of 12 owners and club executives, at the urging of Federal mediators, met for two days with a group of players in New York. The mediators decided to adjourn that effort, though, when dialogue became heated, especially between Reinsdorf and Lauren Rich, a tough union lawyer who, like Reinsdorf, grew up in Brooklyn.
"Can you believe how she treated us?" Reinsdorf said angrily after the owners broke for a caucus.
"Jerry," said Jerry McMorris, owner of the Colorado Rockies, "you've led a very sheltered life."
McMorris, a trucking magnate, proceeded to relate stories of behavior he had experienced in bargaining with the Teamsters union. "That was a civil meeting," he remarked of the session with the players.
Most of the talking occurred away from the bargaining table and did not include Richard Ravitch, the clubs' chief labor executive, but those discussions didn't lead to anything either.
McMorris, meanwhile, became a focal point for the players because he, a moderate among numerous hard-liners, was willing to explore ideas other than a cap. He began having phone conversations with union officials and also met with them in in New York.
Diligent as his efforts were, they were unproductive. So were the ongoing conversations that four agents -- Tom Reich, Hendricks, Ron Shapiro and Tony Attanasio -- had with such owners and club executives as Selig, Reinsdorf, Paul Beeston of Toronto, Peter Angelos of Baltimore, Kasten of Atlanta and John Harrington of Boston.
In many of the instances, it was management people who initiated contact with the agents to explore ideas that might lead to a breakthrough in the dispute. In the end, the efforts failed.
But telephone conversations on Labor Day weekend did produce something. Through McMorris's efforts, union officials, who had tried unsuccessfully to get a computer disk that had all of the details of the clubs' revenue-sharing plan, received by fax on Saturday night a document with those details.
Discovering different details from those they had received last April, the union people formulated their own tax plan that would produce revenue to be shared with the low-revenue clubs. They presented the plan to management negotiators Sept. 8, and it was rejected the next day, Friday.
Selig, joining the talks for the first time that day, met with Fehr and his colleagues after the formal session.
"I told our people to stay over the next day and examine the tax idea," Selig said. "Brainstorm it. Maybe it will come up with something. But everything our people brought up, they said no."
That day, Sept. 10, McMorris left New York to fly back to Colorado. "We're a long way apart," McMorris said. "I wish we weren't, but we are."
Four days later, Selig canceled the rest of the season and the post-season.
 
Misperceptions And No Movement
 Just as the players had their position, the owners wouldn't budge from their salary cap. Although some other teams very likely would accept something less than a cap, the only clubs prepared to agree to any reasonable deal to save the season and the post-season were the two New York teams, the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Toronto Blue Jays, the Baltimore Orioles and the Rockies.
Through it all, miscommunication and misperceptions characterized the talks. Less than 15 hours before Selig announced the cancellation of the rest of the season, union officials, who had heard of Selig's intentions, received a message indirectly from an owner wanting to know why the union hadn't made a counteroffer to the owners' new offer.
What new offer? they asked.
It was based on a luxury tax, the owner sent word back, with the payroll limit being somewhere around $40 million and the tax escalating from 25 percent to 50 percent to 75 percent depending on the level the payroll reached. The union never had received the proposal.
Although union officials said the plan didn't do much for them, they said they might have made a counteroffer if they had received it a few days earlier.
The World Series died because neither side was ready to accept the other's position or move close enough to it to produce an agreement. Both sides, of course, blame each other, but the players can't shake the belief that this was all preordained.
Attanasio, the agent, likened the result to a battlefield scene.
"They give the coordinates and call in an air strike," the agent said. "Then they use heavy artillery, bring in antipersonnel stuff and lob mortars. Nobody can live. After that, they use flamethrowers and small-arms fire. When you go in, you stand on top of the hill and proclaim you've won. You look around and see nothing but bodies. Then you ask yourself, 'What did we do and why did we do it?' "

HEADLINE: Fierce Competition Marked Fervid Race For Cancer Gene

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER 

 BODY:
WITH the discovery of a gene that causes inherited breast cancer, the many competitors in this most impassioned and publicly visible of all genetic races find themselves blinking in the sun, still a bit shocked that the long hunt is over.
No one is more surprised, and gratified, than Dr. Mark H. Skolnick of the University of Utah, whose team plucked the gene from a crowded stretch of chromosome 17, and out of the grasp of 12 other teams that had thrown hats and hopes into the ring. 
 "It was a hard problem and it took almost two years just to get to the right region," said Dr. Skolnick, who worked with 44 colleagues from five institutions. "It's very exciting to win such a race."
With the welcome advantage of hindsight, Dr. Skolnick ascribed his success to relentless hard work, a few missteps by his competitors and an extraordinary genetic resource: Utah's large, stable families and the vast genealogical archives of the Mormon church. Others on the team admitted there was also a strong component of the scientist's best friend. "What do I attribute our success to?" said Dr. Roger Wiseman, one of Dr. Skolnick's collaborators. "Luck."
The losers in the contest express a mixture of relief that the fugitive gene has been found, disappointment that it was not found in their laboratories, and, in some cases, frustration at knowing they probably had a piece of the desired gene but had failed to recognize it for what it was. A number of the defeated had devoted the entire effort of their laboratories for the last four years to the search for the gene, called BRCA1, and some are questioning whether the extreme competition accelerated or impeded the quest.
The medical, emotional and economic stakes were unusually large for a gene hunt. Not only is breast cancer the most hated scourge among women today, and a subject on many a politician's and activist's lips, but the identification of a gene linked to the disease offered great practical value in the form of tests to identify women at high risk of the disease and perhaps even new therapies.
Matching the high profile of the coveted gene were the high profiles of many of the contenders. Dr. Skolnick, 48, a former mathematician, made a name for himself 15 years ago, when he helped invent the technique that led to DNA, or genetic, fingerprinting. He has restlessly migrated from one project to another, working in Italy to track genetic changes among different human populations and this spring discovering a widely publicized gene linked to melanoma, a deadly skin cancer.
Three years ago he helped found a biotechnology company, Myriad Genetics Inc., of Salt Lake City, to seek out genes involved in common human diseases. The fledgling company now has a bonanza in BRCA1, for which it has filed a patent.
Among his most fervid and celebrated competitors were Dr. Mary-Claire King of the University of California at Berkeley, who got the race going when she announced the approximate chromosomal location of BRCA1 in 1990; Dr. Francis S. Collins, the director of the National Center for Human Genome Research at the National Institutes of Health and a certified gene jockey who helped find such previous prizes as the genes for cystic fibrosis, Huntington's disease and neurofibromatosis, and Dr. Raymond L. White, another geneticist at the University of Utah, who also helped discover the neurofibromatosis gene and genes involved in colon cancer.
The race was enlivened by longstanding feuds among the principal players, all of whom are known for their intensity, ambitiousness and competitiveness. Many of the quarrels, which are well known in the biomedical field, stem from past collaborations that fell apart, as high-powered scientific collaborations so often do. Like rock musicians, scientists thrive on recognition, and it is harder to get full recognition when one is part of a band.
"There's always competition for a limited resource, and here the resource is genes," Dr. White said. "We're in a world where affiliations come and go, the rules are rather poorly defined and there are lots of opportunities for misunderstanding." Besides, he said with a whooping laugh, "some of us take pleasure in people not liking us."
Perhaps the main reason behind the intensity of the race was the clarity of the goal. Most scientific problems are amorphous and difficult to frame. In this case, researchers knew that a gene associated with familial breast cancer was located somewhere on the bottom half of chromosome 17. Dr. King and others had demonstrated as much through molecular studies of families in which many women suffered from breast cancer, ovarian cancer or both.
Researchers knew that mutations in the gene gave carriers an 85 percent lifetime risk of contracting breast cancer, often before the age of 50. And they estimated that as many as 5 percent of all cases of breast cancer might be due to inherited defects in the gene.
Knowing the approximate neighborhood of the gene, scientists had only to narrow it down to a particular address. They had to pick through an undifferentiated morass of about a million subunits, or base pairs, of DNA, which probably held scores and scores of genes, as well as confounding stretches between genes.
To do that, all who leapt into the fray took fairly similar approaches. Looking through the DNA in blood cells from families with hereditary breast cancer, they searched for telltale patterns, or genetic markers, that would point toward the gene proper. And when they unearthed promising candidate genes, they checked to see if the gene differed at all between a family member who had the cancer, and one without the tumor.
As always happens in a scientific race, the contenders knew through the genetics rumor mill roughly where everybody was positioned from one month to the next. For a long time, nobody seemed to have the advantage. "Six months ago, I don't think you could have predicted from looking at anybody's strategy who would get there first," said Dr. Collins.
But in mid-July, the Skolnick team realized it had what almost certainly was the gene. "When we finally got toward the end, my first reaction was disbelief, that we can't possibly be correct, we must be missing something," said Dr. P. Andrew Futreal, who works in Dr. Wiseman's laboratory at the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences in Research Triangle Park, N.C. "But the data kept coming back from Utah, confirming that we had finally landed on the right gene."
In recounting his triumph, Dr. Skolnick emphasized the importance of his team's access to the unusually large families of Utah. One of them, for example, had 40 women who suffered from breast or ovarian cancer. A few revealing patterns in the family's chromosomes allowed the scientists to narrow down the DNA region of study to almost half what the other groups were scratching through.
Some groups went down a dead end by seeking the gene through comparisons with the DNA of other animals, thinking that BRCA1 would very likely be conserved from one mammalian species to the next. As it turns out, said Dr. Wiseman, the breast cancer gene has changed significantly in its passage through evolutionary time, so the zoological approach was doomed to disappointment.
Dr. Walter Gilbert of Harvard University, a co-founder of Myriad Genetics, suggested that Dr. Skolnick succeeded because he kept his collaborative team running smoothly and relatively harmoniously, while some other groups worked under a kind of fission-fusion system, with collaborators sort of collaborating, and sort of competing.
For some of the scientists in the race, those with less astral reputations than the celebrity contestants, the search for the gene was at least partly motivated by pragmatic career concerns. A big discovery brings attention and all the essential sequelae.
"You get more grants, more money, more speaking engagements at scientific conferences, better graduate students and postdoctoral fellows applying to your lab," said Dr. Barbara Weber of the University of Pennsylvania, an unsuccessful contender who said her entire laboratory had devoted every minute of the last three years to finding the gene. "It's also very glamorous. So of course I'm disappointed and frustrated." On the other hand, she said, "you can still look around and say you have your kids and your health. On a scale from 1 to 10, good to bad, this is really no worse than a 5, or maybe a 6."
Dr. Wiseman said of his successful search for BRCA1, "It was the most extraordinary scientific endeavor I've been involved with in my short career." Nevertheless, as someone who came from the relatively obscure and comparatively civilized world of mouse genetics, he found the vitriol surrounding the search for the breast cancer gene hard to believe. "I was shocked by the competitiveness," he said. "It was a real eye-opener."
Despite any lingering grudges, the losers conceded the race with graciousness, complimenting Dr. Skolnick and his 44 collaborators at five institutions for their evident hard, meticulous work. Dr. King, for example, who may have been the scientist most obsessed with finding the gene -- "It was her reason for getting up in the morning," said Dr. Collins -- and whose personal less-than-tender feelings about Dr. Skolnick are well known to her colleagues , nonetheless described the discovery as "beautiful" and "lovely" and deserving of all the praise it might win.
The researchers realize that their ego disappointments must take a back seat to the considerable and far more pressing problems at hand. Among them are figuring out how the newly discovered gene works in both its healthy and mutant state; how many different mutations in the gene give rise to cancer, and whether some mutations are associated more strongly with breast cancer, and others with ovarian cancer, which is also linked to BRCA1; and what can be done to reverse the effects of a mutation in the gene, resulting in a cure for the disease.
The next question for all researchers in the field is, of course, what now? Some say they plan to study the gene in mouse experiments. Others are already trying to learn where the protein produced by the gene labors in the cell, and what its task is.
Myriad Genetics is moving forward as swiftly as possible to develop a screening test to check for mutations in the gene. Who will benefit from the test and how is not yet clear. Women from high-risk families with mothers, sisters and aunts affected may want to know if they inherited a faulty gene. Others who have only a relative or two with breast cancer may also consider being tested. Yet should a woman test positive, her choices are limited. She can watch and worry and go in for regular mammograms. She can opt for prophylactic mastectomy or try taking the experimental drug tamoxifen, but neither course has been proven to prevent cancer. And she can always hope that a medical breakthrough arrives before her cancer.
"Women will have to be very careful," said Frances Visco, president of the National Breast Cancer Coalition in Washington. "You're talking about giving them a test telling them they have an 85 percent chance of getting a disease that we don't know how to prevent, and for which there is no known cure."

HEADLINE: Emissions Must Be Cut to Avert Shift in Climate, Panel Says

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
EVEN if worldwide emissions of carbon dioxide were capped at present levels, atmospheric concentrations of the heat-trapping gas would continue to increase for at least two centuries, rising well beyond the point at which the earth's climate would be disrupted, an international panel of scientists has reported.
Just holding the atmospheric concentration at double today's amount would require cutting global emissions below 1990 levels, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change said in a report last week. A doubling of today's concentration would raise the earth's average surface temperature by 3 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit and cause substantial climatic change, the panel found earlier. 
 The latest report from the panel, which advises the United Nations, is designed to guide parties to the climate treaty signed two years ago at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro as they discuss whether the treaty should be strengthened. The discussion is expected to begin at the parties' first meeting next March in Berlin. As ratified by more than 80 countries, including the United States, the agreement requires developed countries to take actions aimed at capping carbon dioxide emissions at 1990 levels by the year 2000. There are no specific requirements for other countries.
But even if this target were applied globally and fully met, the new report says, the atmospheric concentration of carbon dioxide would still approach a doubling of its preindustrial level by the end of the next century. The reason, essentially, is that too much of the gas is already being spewed into the air as a result of the burning of coal, oil and natural gas and the destruction of forests to be absorbed quickly by remaining terrestrial vegetation and the oceans. As a result, the gas builds up.
Atmospheric carbon dioxide is the most important of a number of trace gases, including methane, that trap heat in the form of infrared radiation emitted by the earth after its surface is heated by the sun's rays.
It has long been recognized in a general sense that stabilizing carbon dioxide concentrations would require cutting emissions, and the Rio target has been widely considered a first step only. But the new analysis is the panel's first attempt to pin down more specifically and quantitatively the relationship between various levels of emissions, the long-term concentrations that result and the time periods involved.
"If you want to stabilize eventually, you've got to consider what you do now; that's a message that comes clearly through from the figures in our report," said Sir John Houghton, a British atmospheric physicist who is co-chairman of the intergovernmental panel's scientific working group, which issued the new report in Maastricht, the Netherlands. Dr. Houghton said he was speaking for himself, not the group.
The intergovernmental panel, which consists of 2,500 scientists and experts from around the globe, was created by the United Nations in 1988 to assess the state of knowledge about climate change. In scientific reports in 1990 and 1992, the panel said that a doubling of atmospheric carbon dioxide would cause the earth's climate to warm by 3 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit. By way of comparison, various estimates say the earth has warmed by 5 to 9 degrees since the depths of the last ice age.
This magnitude of warming, many climatologists say, would at the very least upset the earth's climate by altering atmospheric circulation patterns that determine where it is hot and cold, where and how much rain falls, where and how often storms strike and how violent they are.
Since cutting carbon dioxide emissions would have major economic impact, the idea that the emissions could bring climatic disaster has been disputed by political conservatives and some industry spokesmen. The intergovernmental panel's assessments on the climatic impact of carbon dioxide have also been attacked by scientists who reached contrary conclusions. The panel is preparing a reassessment of the response of climate to the continuing rise in heat-trapping gases, to be completed in about a year.
In the meantime, the group's new report outlines a daunting challenge to parties to the climate treaty as they grapple with the question of stabilizing carbon dioxide at a safe atmospheric level, as the treaty requires.
The new findings are based on a range of computer models of the global carbon cycle, in which recycled carbon moves continuously, over varying periods of time, among animals, plants, microbes, the atmosphere, the oceans and sedimentary rocks. In recent millenniums, scientists say, this flux produced a concentration of atmospheric carbon dioxide that was more or less constant at about 280 parts per million. Since the dawn of the industrial age, the level has risen to about 360 parts per million, an increase of 28.5 percent.
In the last century, the average surface temperature of the earth has risen by about 1 degree, but scientists say this warming could as easily have been produced by the climate system's natural fluctuations as by the increase in heat-trapping gases.
Many uncertainties surround the new analysis of emissions and concentrations. The carbon-cycle models differ in their estimates by plus or minus 15 percent, and they include a number of simplifications, assumptions and missing elements. For instance, scientists have long been unable to account for the fate of about 20 percent of the carbon dioxide emitted as a result of human activity. The oceans and the atmosphere take up the bulk. The new report says that some of the remainder is probably being absorbed by the regrowth of forests in the Northern Hemisphere. And a substantial part of the missing fraction may be residing in the deep roots of grasses planted to make way for cattle in South American savannas, according to a report by scientists at the International Center for Tropical Agriculture in Cali, Colombia, appearing in the current issue of the British journal Nature.
In any case, the model studies found that if carbon dioxide emissions were maintained at today's levels, atmospheric concentrations of the gas would increase for at least 200 years, reaching about 500 parts per million -- almost twice the pre-industrial concentration -- by the end of the next century.
The analysis also found that concentrations can be stabilized at any and all levels up to 750 parts per million, about twice today's concentration, only by cutting emissions below 1990 levels. The ultimate stabilization level depends on total accumulated emissions and is unaffected by the schedule on which they are reduced, the report said. But it said higher emissions in earlier decades would require lower ones later. "You can have a bonanza for a time and burn what you want," said Dr. Houghton, but "then you've got to come down with a bang." In that case, he said, higher emissions in the earlier decades would cause some measure of climate change.
Since bringing an immediate halt to carbon dioxide emissions is considered an economic and political impossibility, some further rise in overall concentrations appears inevitable. Environmentalists consider it unacceptable to settle for a capping of emissions at today's levels -- itself no easy task -- because, they say, it risks a highly unstable climate. The task before parties to the climate treaty may be to seek some climatically, economically and politically acceptable middle ground.
For instance, said Dr. Houghton, again speaking as an individual, a reasonable goal might be to stabilize the carbon dioxide concentration around 450 parts per million. This might be accomplished, he said, by holding global emissions roughly constant for the first half of the next century, and then beginning to reduce them.
"That would be a pretty demanding target, but one that might be just about achievable," he said. "I think that to talk about tougher targets than that would be extraordinarily difficult."
In any case, he said, "we should start to do what we can do now and also begin to plan to do more" and "not wait 10 or 20 years till things are more clear." If climate change turns out to be on the mild end of the range predicted by the intergovernmental panel for a doubling of carbon dioxide, he said, it might be possible to stabilize concentrations at 650 or 750 parts per million.
But to stay at even those levels, he said, emissions "need to come down."

Concentrations of the gas averaged 280 parts per million before the industrial era. Now, as a result of fossil-fuel burning and deforestation, it is about 360 parts per million.

HEADLINE: Let's Try Cooperation In Japan Auto Talks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As the United States Government heads down to the wire in trade negotiations with Japan (news article, Sept. 14), some analysts wrongly conclude that difficulties in the auto talks arise from fears in Japan that import sales may increase. A bit of background might be enlightening. 
 The so-called Framework discussions started more than a year ago with the purpose of establishing a new economic relationship between the United States and Japan. Autos and auto parts were included in the Framework, not because of any identifiable barriers, but rather because Japan sold more automobiles in the United States than United States companies sell in Japan.
The hangup in the talks is negotiating future indicators, criteria yardsticks or whatever else one wants to call numerical targets. This approach violates the basic principles of trading relations between countries.
More to the point, however, is that it simply can't work. Taking the next step, which is now being openly discussed in Washington, of retaliating against Japan for refusing to agree to such proposals would lead to chaos in world trade.
Sales of foreign automobiles in Japan have been increasing in recent years more from the European makers than from the United States Big Three. Now that the Big Three have begun to build cars for the Japanese market and are intensifying their marketing efforts, their sales are also beginning to jump dramatically.
In August, imports captured 10.7 percent of the Japanese passenger-car market, while Japanese purchases of American auto parts have increased 500 percent since 1986 to $15.5 billion.
The real solution to developing business is to keep working cooperatively between companies and industries, rather than pursuing the counterproductive approach of mandating results.
 
WILLIAM C. DUNCAN
General Director, Japan
Automobile Manufacturers Assn.
Washington, Sept. 14, 1994

HEADLINE: America's Meat Eaters Don't Get the Message

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A 2,000-page report published today by the Environmental Protection Agency concludes that dioxin levels in the fatty tissues of Americans who consume meat, fish, eggs and dairy products pose significant health risks. 
 These include elevated incidence of cancer, disruption of the immune and hormonal systems, sexual abnormalities and stunted fetal growth. (Dioxins are released by industrial processes, settle in soil and waterways, and accumulate in animal tissues.) The conclusions are based on an exhaustive three-year review of dozens of medical studies.
Meat industry and supportive government agencies are already working to subvert the report's startling conclusions and to reduce their economic fallout. The National Cattlemen's Association, following the lead of the tobacco industry, complained of insufficient evidence. And this year, Lynn Goldman, assistant administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, assured reporters that "the benefits of a balanced nutritional diet" -- presumably the cholesterol and saturated fat in meat -- "far outweigh the risk of dioxin."
During the last two decades hardly a month has passed without the disclosure of another report linking consumption of animal fat and meat with elevated risk of heart failure, stroke, cancer, diabetes, atherosclerosis, immune system disorders and other chronic diseases that each year maim and kill 1.5 million Americans. How many reports will it take before American consumers get the message?
 
ALEX HERSHAFT
President
Farm Animal Reform Movement
Bethesda, Md., Sept. 13, 1994

HEADLINE: Greenspan Wants Laws To Let Banks Expand

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 19

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, called today for Congress to expand banks' business options by allowing them to sell insurance and stocks.
Mr. Greenspan also suggested that some limits could be placed on bank deposit insurance and seemed to imply that these limits might be imposed as part of a compromise that would allow banks into securities and insurance activities. 
 Depository insurance makes it possible for banks to hold larger and riskier asset portfolios than otherwise, distorting the economy and exposing taxpayers to possible significant losses, Mr. Greenspan said.
Last week, Congress passed legislation allowing banks to do more business across state lines. But Mr. Greenspan cautioned today that if banks were not allowed to diversify into these new lines of business, they might still prove uncompetitive.
"So far, banks have been adept at finding ways to better serve their customers by taking advantage of new technologies and markets," he said. "However, I am concerned that they may be reaching the limits to efficient and low-cost ways of doing so. The unanswered question is: Will we continue to rescind and modify outdated laws and regulations in order to permit banks to serve the needs of their customers?"
Mr. Greenspan issued similar warnings during the Bush Administration, which tried unsuccessfully to persuade Congress to pass interstate banking legislation and remove other restrictions on banks. While his position is not new, he is the first senior banking official to put forward the next agenda for American banking deregulation after approval of interstate banking.
Insurance and brokerage companies remain hostile to any move by Congress to allow banks to move into their industries, making it unclear when any further legislation may pass.
The Senate gave final approval on Sept. 13 to a bill that eliminates the remaining restrictions in a dozen states on interstate banking and wipes out the costly requirement that banks set up a separate subsidiary in each state. President Clinton lobbied for the legislation and is expected to sign it in the coming days.
Mr. Greenspan did not discuss short-term interest rates today, which the Federal Reserve has raised five times so far this year.
The Federal Reserve chairman was one of eight Washington policy makers who spoke at a conference here at Boston College. The turnout was unusually large, but when academics try to attract prominent Federal officials to academic conferences, nothing quite matches an influential alumnus in Congress.
Boston College has Representative Edward J. Markey, '68, a Massachusetts Democrat who heads the House Energy and Commerce Committee's panel on financial and telecommunications regulation. He is known for summoning Government officials to numerous, sometimes confrontational hearings and when he agreed to serve as co-chairman of the conference, they leaped at the chance to attend.
So enthusiastic was the turnout that the college, seeking to avoid ticklish decisions on prestige, labeled four guests as keynote speakers: Mr. Greenspan; Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers; Robert E. Rubin, the head of the National Economic Council, and Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich.
All but Mr. Reich, who fell ill this morning in Washington, spoke today. So did Robert D. Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office; four of the five commissioners of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the chief executives of several big financial firms, including Daniel P. Tully of Merrill Lynch & Company and John C. Bogle of the Vanguard Group.
Also attending were Franco Modigliani, a 1985 Nobel laureate in economics; Martin Feldstein, a Harvard economist and former adviser to President Ronald Reagan, and Peter Lynch, former manager of the Magellan Fund at Fidelity Investments.
Mr. Markey, the loyal alumnus, contended that the turnout reflected "the prestige of Boston College."
But Mr. Rubin put it much more bluntly. "You ever look at Ed Markey's subcommittee and who they've got jurisdiction over?" he joked at the beginning of his luncheon address, adding, "Whenever Ed calls and asks me a question, I find it very simple to answer -- I say 'Ed, what do you want it to be?' "
The turnout did not appear likely to affect Mr. Markey's prospects for re-election, which already seemed assured. His district, which lies five miles from Boston College at its closest point, has four times as many Democrats as Republicans. He ran unopposed in the Democratic primary, has raised far more money than his Republican opponent and has won every general election since 1976 by wide margins.
All of the Government officials chose to emphasize themes from previous speeches rather than making new statements. Mr. Rubin and Ms. Tyson did make pre-emptive criticisms of several ideas that Congressional Republicans are likely to emphasize when they present their autumn campaign themes next week.
"We're now entering a political climate, the November elections and the Presidential elections two years from now," Mr. Rubin said. "There's going to be a tremendous tendency, you can see it already coming, for a lot of political people to come up with lists of goodies -- a middle-class tax cut, capital gains tax cuts, expansions of I.R.A.'s."
 The caption also reversed the names of the president of Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. She is Cathy Minehan.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 22, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption in Business Day on Tuesday, with an article about the remarks of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, at a conference at Boston College, misidentified one panelist in a discussion of financial markets. The panelist, fourth from the right, was William C. Ferguson, the chairman and chief executive of the Nynex Corporation, not Martin Feldstein, a Harvard economist and former adviser to President Ronald Reagan. Because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly to Mr. Feldstein. His office said he did not attend the conference.

HEADLINE: Transportation Workers Face More Frequent Tests for Drugs

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Thousands of bus drivers, train engineers and other transportation workers in the region will face more frequent random testing for drugs and alcohol beginning in January under a Federal law that is expected to cost regional transit operators millions of dollars a year.
 The New York Transit Authority expects its annual cost of testing to rise to $5 million from $1.5 million. 
It's going to be a complicated proposition," said Jared Lebow, a Transit Authority spokesman, "with some overtime or regularly scheduled extra train operators or bus operators, to make sure we don't impact service too greatly."
 The law requires that transit systems conduct one random urine test for drugs each year for every two employees in "safety sensitive" jobs, and one breath test for alcohol for every four "safety sensitive" employees.
 The degree to which alcohol is a problem is not clear. In August 1991 a drunken subway operator killed five people in a crash in Union Square, which prompted New York to increase its testing. In contrast, Connecticut Transit, a bus system with 775 employees, conducted 1,172 random tests over three years from 1991 to 1993 and found no alcohol use. It did find more than a dozen with traces of marijuana or cocaine, though.
 Some bus drivers in Connecticut and New Jersey have never been subject to random alcohol tests.
 At the Federal Transit Authority, Judy Z. Meade, the senior drug and alcohol program manager, said that some systems that had never tested would find "in the neighborhood of 5 to 6 percent positive tests."
 "Rates will be fairly high for the first two years, because it takes time for corporate climate to change," Ms. Meade said. "It takes time for John Doe to see his buddy Sam Smith be hauled away." But the deterrent will grow over time, she said.
 The Federal rules, issued by the Department of Transportation in February under the Omnibus Transportation Employee Testing of 1991, requires testing in the middle of workers' shifts, which means having substitute workers available. Most systems that test now do it at the beginning or end of the work day.
 Conducting even half as many tests as there are employees will not insure that everyone is tested. Michael A. Sanders, the Transit and Ridesharing Administrator at the Connecticut Department of Transportation, said that despite having conducted nearly 1,200 random tests in three years on a work force of 775, about 200 people have never been tested.
 While the Connecticut tests found no alcohol, Mr. Lebow said that at the New York Transit Authority in 1993, 0.47 percent tested positive for alcohol on random tests, and 1.85 percent in drug tests. The drug rate was comparable to Connecticut Transit's.
 The Transit Authority and other systems also conduct tests as part of pre-employment physicals, when workers return to duty after extended absences, after accidents, and whenever the authority is suspicious.
At the Port Authority, about 1,400 employees who drive snowplows, dump trucks and runway sweepers will be subject to testing for the first time, said John M.Kampfe, a spokesman. Another 450 workers on the PATH system, including engineers, train dispatchers and signalmen are already tested for drugs, but not alcohol.
 At New Jersey Transit, existing drug tests nearly meet the new Federal standards, said Elizabeth Schneider, director of medical services. But alcohol tests will be new and will probably turn up a substantial number of people working under the influence, especially in rail operations, she said. "People work unsupervised," she said. "It's a traditional railroad problem."
 Under the new Federal regulations, breath test readings showing a blood-alcohol concentration of 0.02 to 0.039 constitute grounds for taking an employee out of service for up to eight hours. From 0.04 up, the employee must be removed from the job and referred to a substance abuse program for professional evaluation, she said.
 In most states a blood-alcohol concentration of 0.1 (or two and a half times as high as 0.04) is sufficient to convict the driver of a private automobile of driving while impaired or drunk.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 9, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sept. 20 about newFederal requirements for drug and alcohol tests for transit workers in cluded a statement, attributed to a New Jersey Transit official, suggest ing that new alcohol tests will proba bly turn up a substantial number of people working under the influence, especially in rail operations.
In letters dated Sept. 20 and Oct. 18, officials of New Jersey Transit say that the remarks of Elizabeth Schneider, their director of medical services, were misinterpreted. They say she was talking about potential problems in the rail industry in gen eral, not about New Jersey Transit, and that she did not characterize the numbers as substantial in any case.
 The agency's letters were delayed in routing between editors at The Times.

HEADLINE: New York City Hospitals Chief to Lay Off 3,000

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

 BODY:
The president of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday that he plans to lay off about 3,000 workers and eliminate hundreds of hospital beds to close a budget gap and make the hospitals more competitive in a shrinking industry.
The president, Dr. Bruce Siegel, who oversees the city's 11 public hospitals and several dozen clinics, said the cuts would be made before the end of the fiscal year next June and would be scattered throughout the system. 
 Dr. Siegel said that one hospital likely to be hit with "potentially hundreds" of layoffs was Harlem Hospital Center, many of whose 746 beds have been empty on any given day in recent months.
Beds will be taken out of service at other hospitals as well, he said.
Though he does not need formal approval to proceed, he said he would give more details of his plan to the agency's board tomorrow.
Union officials said they were flabbergasted by what they knew of the Health and Hospitals Corporation's plan and said that two discussions with the agency earlier this week about the possibilities of such cuts had been extremely contentious.
"They said it translates into 3,000 workers, but they won't give us any details," said Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. "It's a disaster."
"At Harlem Hospital, they want to eliminate beds and people, but their attitude is not to cooperate and work with us," Mr. Hill said. "You're talking about people's livelihoods and about community services."
Dr. Siegel said the cuts were needed to close a $356 million gap in the agency's $3.6 billion budget and to lower costs to attract referrals from managed-care companies. The Health and Hospitals Corporation has about 8,000 acute-care beds and employs 48,000 workers.
An official involved in meetings about the proposed cuts, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said some treatment programs would be merged, laboratory operations would be consolidated and two surgery units at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center would be combined.
The corporation's difficulties are partly due to the city's financial problems. The Giuliani administration has reduced the city's subsidy to the agency by $50 million as it grapples with its own deficit.
But most of the shortfall is related to the changes taking place throughout the nation in the medical industry. Hospitals everywhere are shrinking as medical care moves into outpatient clinics because of technological advances and efforts by managed-care companies to contain costs.
And Dr. Siegel said no place would be exempt from reductions.
"We're looking at layoffs all over the place -- some administrators, managers, aides, nurses, housekeepers," he said. "As our patients stay less time in the hospital and we close units, these are people we're not going to be able to employ any more."
Dr. Siegel said there would prOE bly also be staff cuts in clinics.
"We have a huge amount of staffing" in the clinics, he said, with "lots of very senior nurses and administrators, lots of aides, lots of techs, and that makes it difficult for us to get contracts with HMO's. They look at this staff, this overhead, and say forget it."
In addition to staffing cuts, roughly 4 percent, or 320 hospital beds will likely be taken out of service, though they will not be officially decertified by the state, officials said. Other economies will come from merging two alcoholism-treatment programs at Queens Hospital Center and Elmhurst Hospital Center, and from centralizing laboratory operations at one site within each of the system's six new regional networks, while closing the other labs.
Since January, the corporation has already trimmed 1,052 jobs from its central office, through attrition and 226 layoffs. And the new cuts would include another 300 layoffs at the city hospitals' headquarters, officials said.
Only days ago, most private hospitals in New York City guaranteed job security for many hospital workers, in exchange for a one-year wage freeze, a deal considered a major coup for the union in the current environment.
But several hospital executives say that industry-wide trends are hitting the public hospitals hardest for a variety of reasons, including the fact that the city hospitals have been slower to adapt to the newly competitive market.
In recent months, Dr. Siegel has been pressing the corporation's hospital administrators to come up with ways to save money. But none of the plans came close to solving the problems, he said.
Dr. Siegel said that, on average, patients in city hospitals stay longer than those in private hospitals, "not because they're getting better care, not because we're nicer people, but because we're not as organized." Hospitals are trying to reduce the length of in-patient stays because no matter how long a patient stays, Medicaid and other insurers pay the same amount for treatment.
Pamela S. Brier, executive director of Bellevue Hospital Center and head of one of the newly organized regional networks of city facilities acknowledged that some cuts were probably inevitable.
"It's very painful and very difficult, but there's no question we're going to have to do some things we don't want to do," she said.
Ms. Brier said that she expected some staffing reductions at Bellevue, but along with other hospital administrators was still working on the particulars of where the cuts would be made.
"From our perspective, we've been working on this for a long time, but we're not there yet," she said.
Dr. Siegel said that a general agreement was hammered out in the weekend meetings with administrators, but that many of the specifics were still being fine-tuned by hospital officials. And though he said the board does not need to formally approve the plan at tomorrow's meeting, he added that board members "have to feel comfortable with it."
Meanwhile, union and elected officials said they are lobbying the Mayor's office to derail the plan.
"The Health and Hospitals Corporation tells me that next month 3,000 people are going to be laid off, and we don't know what impact that's going to have," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York. "I've talked to the city and told them this is a crisis. You can talk about empty beds all you want, but I think you've got an explosive situation on your hands. You don't just fire people based on economics."

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI: ARISTIDE;
Exiled President Urges Quick Disarming Of Haitian Troops and Paramilitary Units

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, called on the United States today to rapidly disarm his country's military and paramilitary groups.
Father Aristide, who had been silent since an agreement was struck on Sunday with Haiti's military Government, issued a statement that did not even mention the accord. Instead, he indicated in elliptical language his disappointment with the terms of the accord, which his aides said he considered to have no legitimacy. 
 But in meetings and telephone conversations today with American officials, the exiled leader voiced dismay, his aides said, that American troops in Haiti stood by while Haiti's military police clubbed Aristide supporters at demonstrations in Port-au-Prince.
Father Aristide's advisers said that, for fear of appearing ungrateful, he was loath to express public criticism of the agreement reached by a delegation led by former President Jimmy Carter. But he allowed his Ambassador and attorneys here to articulate his principal message: that the Administration needed to disarm Haiti's 7,000 soldiers and paramilitary groups opposed to Father Aristide.
"To have true democracy in Haiti, you must disarm those people whom the President of the United States has called thugs and murderers," said Ira Kurzban, general counsel for President Aristide. "If you don't disarm the Haitian Army and the paramilitary organizations, not only could you not have democracy, but you're putting American soldiers in harm's way."
These public statements, and Mr. Aristide's private complaints, prompted Mr. Clinton to dispatch Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, and Lieut. Gen. John J. Sheehan, the director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to meet this evening with the exiled leader in an attempt to reassure him about the military mission, senior Administration officials said.
The White House issued a statement after the meeting saying that Father Aristide had accepted an invitation to visit the Pentagon on Wednesday for further briefings from Defense Secretary William J. Perry and from General John M. D. Shalikashvili, the chairan of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
The statement said Mr. Lake had told Father Aristide that the President was committed to working with him and others among Haiti's legitimate authorities to prepare for their return, even as the United States is cooperating now with the country's military leaders.
Although several Administration officials acknowledged their anger at seeing Haiti's military police clubbing demonstrators, the Administration insisted that the military's mission was not to intercede in violence between Haitians or to play cop on the beat.
Mr. Kurzban and other Aristide aides said the exiled leader was essentially treating the agreement as irrelevant, partly because he believed it conflicted with United Nations resolutions. They said the agreement had no legitimacy because it was signed by Haiti's military-appointed President, Emile Jonassaint, who is not recognized by Father Aristide or by the Administration.
Michael Barnes, an adviser to Father Aristide, said the Haitian leader thought it was improper for American forces in Haiti to deal only with the military Government.
"President Aristide wants the U.S. to begin dealing with the legitimate Government in Haiti, to start talking with the Defense Minister he appointed, who has courageously remained in Haiti," Mr. Barnes said.
Father Aristide's advisers said the agreement made too broad a promise of amnesty for the military and should have required Haiti's coup leaders to cede power immediately and leave the country. The Aristide camp faults the Carter agreement because it calls for a general amnesty that would absolve the military of all crimes.
Father Aristide's advisers insist that this action is unconstitutional, because amnesty may be granted only for "political crimes," like ones related to the September 1991 coup.
"We must build a state of law so that there will be neither violence nor vengeance in our nation," Father Aristide said in his formal statement. "We remain vigilant to the declaration of democracy expressed by the people of Haiti, as, together with the people of Haiti, we move toward a new beginning."
The Administration sought to shrug off Father Aristide's lack of praise for both Sunday's agreement and the landing of American troops to help restore him to power.
"When some time has gone by, when he is able to resolve in his mind some of the details of this and put it in the larger perspective, I think that he will be supportive," a senior Administration official said.
But some members of Congress were more blunt in suggesting that Father Aristide seemed ungrateful. Representative David Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, said in a speech from the House floor that only two words would have been appropriate from the Haitian leader: "Thank you."
Mr. Kurzban, the Aristide adviser, criticized the Pentagon for shunting aside its own plan to disarm Haiti's military and paramilitary groups within days of landing in Haiti. While the Administration is moving gradually to buy back guns from paramilitary groups, officials say they do not plan to begin disarming Haitian soldiers until the leader of Haiti's military Government, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, fulfills his promise of stepping down by Oct. 15.
"When Baby Doc Duvalier fled in 1986, everybody was dancing in the streets, then all these Haitians were killed because the Tonton Macoute who did all the killing under Duvalier still had the weapons," Mr. Kurzban said. "Unless you disarm these people, there are going to be lots of problems."
In a White House news briefing today, General Shalikashvili, head of the Joint Chiefs, praised the Carter agreement because it allowed the United States to land thousands of troops in Haiti "without a single shot fired up to now, without a single American having been wounded and died or without a single Haitian being wounded and died."
A senior Administration official who briefed reporters at the White House acknowledged that Mr. Clinton had grown concerned by late last week at the prospect of a power vacuum in Haiti if General Cedras stepped down immediately, as he had demanded.
The official said that concern had left Mr. Clinton willing, in principle, to accept an agreement negotiated by Mr. Carter that would allow General Cedras to remain in power for a short time. Mr. Clinton saw that as an acceptable trade-off because he believed American forces would be safer if they could count on cooperation from the Haitian Army.
As for the Administration's promise to lift economic sanctions, a senior official emphasized today that the agreement had said sanctions would be lifted in accordance with Security Council Resolution 940. That resolution, he noted, does not allow the sanctions to be lifted until General Cedras relinquishes power; in any case, he said, there is little sentiment within the United Nations for lifting them immediately.
In addition to the United Nations, the Organization of American States and the United States maintain sanctions against Haiti. But the official suggested that if the Administration considered exceptions to the sanctions, it would look first to what steps might help in providing "what our troops need in their mission."

HEADLINE: Study Says Small Schools Are Key to Learning

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Year after year, small rural schools in the Midwest and West register the highest Scholastic Assessment Test scores in the nation, a phenomenon usually attributed to the racial homogeneity of places like Iowa, the consistent leader in the rankings.
But a study challenging those assumptions as inaccurate, as well as racist, has found instead that rural schools do better because they are small. Minority children in rural states outperform their counterparts in the rest of the nation, according to The Report Card on American Education, a study conducted by the American Legislative Exchange Council. 
 "There is this unspoken message that places like Iowa do better because there are fewer black kids," said Bill Meyers, vice-president of the council, an association of state legislators. "It's one of the more subtle forms of racism, and it's just plain wrong."
The study found that school size, not classroom size, was the key in the performance of students. Children do better in places small enough that "the principal knows the name of each student." Schools with fewer than 300 students showed the best performance, Mr. Meyers said, even though class size in many of these schools was higher than the national average.
Moreover, schools in the rural Midwest placed more emphasis on core subjects, like reading and mathematics, than did schools in urban centers. Schools in these rural states, he said, more clearly viewed themselves as "places of learning, rather than social service agencies."
The states whose students performed highest in 1994 were: Iowa, Kansas, Minnesota, Montana, Nebraska, South Dakota, Utah, Wisconsin and Wyoming.
None of these states ranked among the top 10 in spending on education. In fact, most of them spent less than the national average. Utah, ranked last in spending among the states.
"We already know that money will not solve our education problems," the study said. "There is a growing consensus that successful schools have three key qualities in common: a belief that all children can learn -- and challenge their students academically; local control; and a high degree of parental involvement. These are things that money cannot buy but that concerned communities can provide."
Over all, the performance by American students on achievement tests this year showed no improvement from last year. Since 1972, the average score on the Scholastic Assessment Test, the most widely used college-entrance examination, has declined by 35 points.
The high school graduation rate in 1994 was 71.2 percent, unchanged from a year ago.
An important advantage for smaller schools was the ability of parents to become involved in a significant way, Mr. Meyers said. In a small school, a parent can attend a school board meeting and have some chance of being influential, but parents in big school districts more often believe it is futile to navigate the bureaucracy.
In addition, students in a small school stand a far better chance of participating in extracurricular activities, which boosts confidence levels. In a school of 3,000 or 4,000, only the very top students can get a chance to play football or edit the school newspaper.
"When a student cannot participate, he or she gets the message that, 'I'm not good enough,' " Mr. Meyers said. "There has been a lot of social engineering-type thought about ways to raise students self-esteem. Part of the problem might be that we're putting students in these big environments where their self-esteem is going to take a beating."
In smaller schools, Mr. Meyers said, teachers and administrators were more demanding of students and more likely to communicate with parents.
"Many of these things were once accepted as the norm," he said.
The study also found that spending for teachers since 1972 increased by only 3.5 percent after accounting for inflation. Meanwhile, spending for everything besides teachers increased by nearly 90 percent after inflation, in the same time.
The states in which students scored best were those which spent a bigger share of the education budget on teachers, Mr. Meyers said.
Despite the seeming advantages of small schools, public education in America has been moving toward bigger schools for more than a generation. Nationally, just over 10 percent of students attend schools with enrollments of 300 or less.
Mr. Meyers said some urban schools recently moved toward the small-scale approach, dividing a big school into five or six smaller ones.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Falter On Rise in Trade Deficit

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities slipped yesterday after a Government report showed that the nation's trade deficit had widened in July. The larger deficit also weakened the dollar, which put further pressure on bonds. Treasury securities also suffered from higher commodity prices.
The Commerce Department's report of the July trade balance was a little worse than expected. The report showed the nation's trade deficit in goods and services widening to nearly $11 billion, compared with $9 billion in June. Exports were a little weaker than expected and imports were stronger. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 8/32 yesterday, to 9626/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 7.77 percent, from 7.75 percent on Monday. Inflation jitters and concern about further rate increases by the Federal Reserve helped to keep buyers at bay, as sellers used each uptick in prices as an opportunity to sell.
The yield is at its highest level since Aug. 24, 1992, when it was 7.82 percent.
Before the trade data were released, bond prices were already declining from overnight selling in Europe and Japan amid concern about inflation and its negative impact on the value of investments.
 "Japanese accounts have been selling all their foreign holdings, including U.S. Treasuries as well as European bonds," said James Hale, a fixed-income analyst with MMS International in San Francisco. "It's not that they hold large amounts of these securities, but when they sell they influence other investors."
And while both the dollar and Treasury prices recovered some losses, traders called it a difficult day.
Late yesterday, Johnson Redbook Services released its latest weekly survey on retail sales. The survey showed sales up 3 percent, weaker than the 4.2 percent increase for the previous weeks of September.
Charles Roden, managing director and head of fixed-income investing for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said that aside from the trade data, the market was also pressured from the supply side by a $1.5 billion global bond issue from the World Bank.
The global bonds, which mature in five years and are not callable for the life of the issue, were priced at 99.471 to yield 7.253 percent through underwriters led by UBS Securities.
Mr. Roden also noted that the market might have been concerned about yesterday's announcement regarding the size of next week's Treasury auctions of two- and five-year notes. "With all the negatives, there were a few plus sides today," Mr. Roden said. "The dollar rebounded and that helped the market psychologically.
"My guys tell me that some economists on the Street are telling institutional investors that they are now expecting not just one rate increase from the Fed, but multiple short-term rate increases," he added. "If you believe that, then many money managers will have to rethink their strategies."
Gains in commodity prices, especially precious metals, also helped to undermine bonds. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 1.56 points, to 230.97. Gold prices jumped $3.60 an ounce yesterday, to $397.20.
 In the municipal market, the Puerto Rico Municipal Finance Agency sold $273.5 million of tax-exempt bonds through CS First Boston. The issue, most of which is insured by Financial Security Assurance and rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, was initially priced to yield a maximum of 6.35 percent for an issue due in 2019.
Serial bonds with shorter maturities were priced to yield from 4.60 percent in 1996 to 6.10 percent in 2009, with another long bond due in 2014 priced to yield 6.30 percent.
Among corporate issues sold yesterday was a $500 million debt offering by Wal-Mart Stores through Goldman, Sachs and Merrill Lynch.
The discount retailer sold $250 million of 8 percent notes due in 2005 at a price of 99.767 to yield 8.03 percent and $250 million of 8.5 percent debentures due in 2024 at a price of 99.031 to yield 8.59 percent.
Underwriters said the issues were rated Aa1 by Moody's and AA by S.& P.
