HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
Survey Finds Voters in U.S. Rootless and Self-Absorbed

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
As they turn inward and worry about their own financial difficulties, American voters have become less compassionate about the problems of the poor and minorities, a study of public opinion shows.
The finding was part of a wide-ranging study, conducted by the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press and made public today, that found an electorate that is "angry, self-absorbed and politically unanchored." 
 It concluded that there is "no clear direction in the public's political thinking other than frustration with the current system and an eager responsiveness to alternative political solutions and appeals."
The changed attitudes on race and social welfare, and a growing resentment toward immigrants, were striking given the relatively healthy state of the economy. The finding helps explain why President Clinton has not reaped much political benefit from an improved economy; most people say they do not feel the improvements and appear uncertain about their own economic future.
For the first time in the seven years of Times-Mirror surveys, a majority of whites, 51 percent, say they agree that equal rights have been pushed too far; in 1992, only 42 percent shared that view.
The racial attitudes tracked in the poll show considerable shifts. People now are less inclined to express concerns for the plight of black Americans than they were only two years ago, after the trial of four white police officers charged in the beating of Rodney G. King and the riots that followed in Los Angeles.
Fourty-four percent of whites say there has not been much real improvement in the position of blacks in the United States; 54 percent gave that response in 1992.
The poll also found a striking decline in public support for social welfare programs. Fifty-seven percent said it was the responsibility of government to take care of people who cannot take care of themselves, down from 69 percent in 1992 and 71 percent in 1987.
There were some demonstrations of tolerance for minorities, AIDS patients and homosexuals, so long as people's pocketbooks were not affected. In the biggest shift, 65 percent agreed that it is all right for blacks and whites to date, a 22-point increase over the figure for 1987.
The poll depicted an electorate that is so embittered and cynical that it is far less likely to believe in political parties and veteran politicians.
The disaffection is demonstrated by the finding that many young people, whose allegiances are often a gauge of future ideological trends, are politically rootless. The Republican Party squandered an 11-point advantage it held among adults under the age of 30 at the beginning of George Bush's Presidency, according to the survey. But Mr. Clinton has also failed to hold the support of a large segment of the young people he won over in the 1992 campaign.
Among adults under the age of 30 who identify with a political party, Republicans have a slight advantage over Democrats, 30 to 26 percent. But the highest proportion, 41 percent, call themselves independents.
"Neither party has an advantage with people under 30, or with voters 30 to 49, for that matter," the study said. "The slight numerical nationwide advantage held by Democrats results from a lingering preference for the Democratic Party among older voters still influenced by the Kennedy years, or more distantly, by the New Deal."
The Times Mirror Center has conducted a series of major surveys since 1987 to analyze public views in more depth than many public opinion surveys. For this survey, 3,800 adults nationwide were interviewed by telephone from July 12 to July 25. The poll's margin of sampling error is plus or minus two percentage points.
Another sign of voter unease is that the dynamics that led Ross Perot to win 19 percent of the vote in his independent bid for the Presidency in 1992 has not abated. Today 53 percent of the nation's voters said there should be a third major political party in the United States, the survey found.
The survey also found that 20 percent of the electorate was ready to bolt to a third party. This group of swing voters, which the survey labels "new economy independents," fits no easy political mold: It consists largely of high school graduates under 50 who are not optimistic about their future job opportunities. They are fed up with political parties and opposed to government regulation, yet they are strong environmentalists. They believe in social welfare programs but are not sympathetic to blacks. And though they are religious, they are moderate on social issues like homosexual rights. Three in 10 of this group voted for Mr. Perot.

Telephone interviews were conducted July 12-27 with 3,800 people age 18 and older. Margin of error: plus or minus two percentage points.)

HEADLINE: On the Trail of 10 Tons of Garbage, and Bursitis

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
Before the sun rose, the sanitation crew bounced down Delancey Street yesterday past the tall, resolute buildings and headed uptown to pick up the rotting food remains and discarded shreds that were the city's detritus.
At 6:15, traffic was light. As was customary, John Viglietta drove and Bill Corcoran rode beside him. It was clear out, thankfully for Mr. Corcoran, who, at 38, already suffered the sanitation worker's trademark arthritis and bursitis. On rainy days, they exact their price. Every day, the men pick up about 10 tons of garbage, the weight of 66 refrigerators. 
 The first load was small yesterday. In dulled light, Mr. Corcoran, a burly man with short-cropped hair, hoisted the bags one by one and, with practiced ease, tossed them into the cavity of the truck. The odor was enough to weaken the knees, though Mr. Corcoran seemed oblivious. "It smells like money to me," he said. "That smell pays my mortgage."
As the malodorous leavings flew into the truck, the two men contemplated, among other things, their sentiments about the new labor agreement they must vote on that raises their wages but also requires the work force to pick up 20 percent more garbage. Mr. Corcoran and Mr. Viglietta have been advised that, starting next month, their route will be expanded and their quota will be more than 13 tons.
"That's tough," Mr. Corcoran said. "I'm not kicking up my heels."
Crews citywide now collect an average of 8.5 tons of trash a shift, below the high of 9.8 tons in the early 1980's, before recycling eased the workload. The contract proposal calls for new routes defined by the city that will mean an average load of 10.1 tons. Since some routes are far more spread out than others, targets for individual crews will range from 8 to 14 tons. Crews that fall short will have their pay docked.
Yesterday, as they do every Tuesday, Mr. Corcoran and Mr. Viglietta were picking up the residential trash along 21st and 22d Street between First and Third Avenues, plus a slice of Peter Cooper Village and the United Nations International School.
The crew -- which was suggested by the sanitation union to a reporter who wanted to follow their day -- was not one of those able to complete its route in three or four hours, as some teams can. Still, while their shift runs from 6 A.M. to 2 P.M., they said that they often returned to the garage between 12:30 and 1 P.M. They conceded that they could probably pick up more garbage.
Like many others of the 7,400 sanitation workers, Mr. Corcoran and Mr. Viglietta were not buoyant about the agreement -- some workers were adamant that they could not pick up more garbage -- but they were resigned to accepting it.
"I think it's the best we could get in the economic climate and with the new mayor," said Mr. Corcoran, who has collected garbage for 13 years. "I don't think we got as much as we deserve. But there are no givebacks, no layoffs."
"I feel O.K. about it," said Mr. Viglietta, 41, who has 14 years of experience. "We could see it coming. Recycling took away a lot of the work."
With their experience, Mr. Corcoran and Mr. Viglietta are paid about $42,000 a year, which will go up to about $45,000 under the new contract.
Both men tackled a towering pile of trash bags on the other side of Second Avenue. Once enough bags were aboard, they flicked on the hopper. It began crushing the garbage. A loud, grinding noise, the city's early alarm clock, reverberated from the truck.
"All kinds of stuff people put out," Mr. Corcoran said. "One guy in our garage found a body once. I've only found prostheses."
In the summer, maggots crawl over the garbage. Mice and rats feast on it. On a previous route, Mr. Viglietta and Mr. Corcoran came to know a rat that fed every day from the same trash can. When it heard the truck coming, it would withdraw. "It was an educated rat," Mr. Viglietta said.
Besides the regular aches, both Mr. Corcoran and Mr. Viglietta have been cut by broken glass in garbage bags. Once Mr. Corcoran had a hypodermic needle puncture a finger. He dropped a trash can and broke his foot. Seven years ago, a car ran a red light and hit Mr. Corcoran, breaking his foot, ankle and several ribs. Mr. Viglietta suffers chronic back pain and is "working on arthritis."
They would not mind more respect. "The only time people notice us is when we don't show up or they're stuck behind the truck," Mr. Corcoran said. "Ninety-nine percent of the people don't know we exist. Ah, I guess if I wanted recognition maybe I would have become a ballplayer or a rock star."
By 7:35, the north side of 21st Street was done (another truck did the south side) and they moved to 22d Street. Again, they only did the north side, except between First and Second Avenues.
The piles were big, 40 to 50 bags. The work slowed near First Avenue. Cars and trucks were parked helter-skelter; traffic was thick. Every time the garbage truck stopped, a line of cars formed. So, every few minutes, Mr. Viglietta circled the block to let cars by.
Just as Mr. Viglietta returned from one of his laps, a woman pulled up behind the truck and leaped out of her car with fire in her eyes.
"I came down here and was behind the truck and I went around the block and now I'm behind it again," she said. "I need to get in my garage."
"What am I supposed to do?" Mr. Corcoran said. "I've got garbage to pick up."
The woman raised her voice: "I'm a doctor and I've got an emergency."
"I'm a sanitation worker and I've got garbage," Mr. Corcoran shot back. "What am I supposed to do? Disappear?"
"It's been 20 minutes now," the woman said. "I want to get in my garage. It's an emergency."
"It can't be too much of an emergency if you've waited 20 minutes," Mr. Corcoran said.
Finally, Mr. Viglietta agreed to circle the block yet again. The woman did not thank him.
"Now what makes her time more important than mine?" Mr. Corcoran sneered. "But she's a doctor!"
After parking her car, the doctor conversed with the parking attendant and then came strolling down the block. She passed by Mr. Corcoran without a word. To her back, he said, "Hurry to that emergency. Hurry to that emergency."
When Mr. Viglietta returned, both of them started lifting bags. The doctor still irked them.
"Oh, I get it," Mr. Corcoran said. "She had to get into that garage before 9 to get the early-bird special. In by 9, out by 6."
"Yeah, that's the emergency," Mr. Viglietta said.
They crept down the block. Now came a treat, an old stove squatting next to a pile of trash bags.
"I love crushing an appliance," Mr. Corcoran said. "It breaks up the routine."
At 9:30, halfway done in Peter Cooper Village, the bulk of the route had been picked up. The truck was close to full, so the crew retreated to one of the drop-offs, at 59th Street and the Hudson River, to deposit it in a garbage barge.
When they arrived, the place was uncharacteristically congested. More than 30 trucks preceded them. Not until 11:15 could they dump their load. Then they headed downtown for their lunch break.
At 12:20, they were back on Peter Cooper Road for three more pickups. The hammering sun brought perspiration to the men's faces.
Next, they circled around and tackled the south side of 22d Street, which was light.
The final stop was the United Nations School: 70 bags. It was 1:10, and they were done, later than usual because of the crowd at the drop-off. They had picked up about 11 tons of garbage.
Mr. Corcoran mopped his brow. "It's not as easy as you'd think," he said. "It's work picking up garbage."

HEADLINE: Deficit in Trade Surged in July; Markets Jolted

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
America's trade deficit with the rest of the world rose sharply in July to the second-highest level in history, the Government said today in a report that fanned inflation fears, rattled the financial markets and depressed the value of stocks, bonds and the dollar.
The worse-than-expected trade report came as Japanese auto companies, in a highly unusual move, warned the Clinton Administration that they might break off their cooperation with the American auto industry, particularly their purchases of American auto parts, if the White House imposed trade sanctions on Japan. 
 The Clinton Administration has threatened to put punitive tariffs on Japan on Sept. 30 if Tokyo does not agree to open its markets in insurance, government procurement, automobiles and auto parts. The two sides began their final round of negotiations on market-opening this week and currency speculators are already placing their bets as to whether the talks will succeed or fail.
If the negotiations fail, the dollar is expected to weaken even further against the yen; if they succeed, the dollar is likely to strengthen, as speculators conclude that the Administration will not want to use currency to put pressure on Tokyo.
There was some positive news on trade matters for the Administration today, though. The Japanese Finance Ministry informed Washington that the Government in Tokyo intended to put off imposing a consumption tax for three years instead of the two-year delay originally planned. A longer delay in the tax should help stimulate the Japanese economy and the purchase of American goods by Japanese consumers.
There was also some good trade news for the Administration from Capitol Hill, where members of the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee agreed on legislation that would approve and put in force the global trade accord known as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said the White House would like to see the legislation be introduced on Monday. Under the fast-track rules governing trade agreements, the House and Senate would then have 90 working days to vote on the measure, with no amendments allowed. President Clinton told reporters today, "I hope it can be completed in a speedy and bipartisan fashion this year."
The GATT agreement is expected to stimulate billions of dollars in new world trade by lowering and eliminating tariffs, quotas and subsidies in 123 countries. The United States could use the boost. The Commerce Department reported today that the trade deficit in goods and services widened to $10.99 billion in July, up 21.6 percent from June's level. Sluggish summer sales of American commercial aircraft and an unexpectedly sharp rise in imported oil prices were cited as the main reasons for the wider deficit.
It was the second-largest monthly merchandise deficit in American history, topped only by a $15.9 billion gap in December 1985. The deficit with Japan alone soared to $5.67 billion in July, the widest since March, while the deficit with China expanded to a record $2.67 billion.
With only 10 days left before the American-imposed deadline in the Japan trade talks, each side is seeking to bring maximum pressure on the other.
In a speech in Tokyo today, Lawrence Summers, the Treasury Department's Under Secretary for International Affairs, attacked the Japanese Government's overall economic policies as misguided, self-serving and harmful to other industrial countries.
While America has put its economic house in order, Mr. Summers said, Japan is failing to push deregulation vigorously, failing to make domestic consumption rather than exports the engine of economic growth, and failing to stimulate its growth with proper fiscal and monetary policies.
From the Japanese side came a different message. In an open letter published in Japan and addressed to Mr. Kantor, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said that any American sanctions would cause its members "to determine whether continued industry-level cooperation is justifiable."
The association, which represents all 13 of Japan's major vehicle manufacturers, insisted that Japan was not engaged in any unfair trade practices in the auto markets. It contended that the list of American suppliers of auto parts to Japanese auto makers has grown from about 300 to 1,250 over the last five years and that purchases of American auto parts have jumped by more than 500 percent since 1986.
Nevertheless, automobiles and auto parts still account for two-thirds of Japan's $60 billion annual trade surplus with the United States. Andrew H. Card Jr., president of the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, said the Japanese association's statement offered further evidence that Japan "is simply ignoring the problem."
Mr. Kantor said, "It is unfortunate that the Japanese auto manufacturers have articulated their concerns in an unrestrained manner."
Privately, other American officials and analysts scoffed at the threat by Japan's auto makers to break off cooperation. They reasoned that Japan has much more at stake in automobile exports than the United States does and that Tokyo would feel more pain than Washington in a tit-for-tat sanctions war.
Officials say they expect one of three outcomes from the Japanese-American trade talks in the next 10 days.
In the best-case outcome, they said, the two countries would reach agreements for opening Japanese markets in insurance and government procurement. Japan might also agree to some further purchases of American auto parts, but other auto issues would be dealt with later.
A less preferable outcome, American officials say, would bring agreements on insurance and government procurement, but nothing on automobiles. The Administration might go ahead in the non-auto areas but put some symbolic sanctions on Japan in a sector like glass manufacturing, where the Japanese have frozen out American producers. This would signal Washington's displeasure that Tokyo was not making any move to open its car market.
The worst-case outcome, they said, would be to have no agreements in any area, with the talks collapsing as they did last February and the dollar plunging against the yen. Because many people believe that the White House cannot afford such a crisis while it is embroiled in Haiti, it seems possible that some way will be found to make a deal.

HEADLINE: Store Closings in Merger Seen as an Unwelcome Change

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

 BODY:
Patrick James is suddenly worried about the future of his Garden City art shop, located in one of the most upscale shopping districts on Long Island.
In White Plains, the Mayor, S. J. Schulman got the news and wondered where the city would find another first-class department store for its downtown district. 
 And in Flushing, Queens, a community planning official, Regina Colletta, is baffled that just as the once-struggling commercial hub is beginning to thrive, one of its biggest stores is scheduled to close.
From Suffolk County in Eastern Long Island north to White Plains in Westchester to Herald Square in Manhattan, shoppers, small merchants and local officials were stunned to learn yesterday that a half-dozen upscale department stores -- two Abraham & Straus stores, two Stern's stores, a Macy's and a Bloomingdale's -- were scheduled to close in the next two years as a result of the pending merger between R. H. Macy & Company and Federated Department Stores Inc.
The looming departure of these businesses -- high-end retailers that in some cases served as magnets for their local shopping districts -- will be felt in a lot of people's day-to-day routines. As Barbara Lubel, a shopper at the Bloomingdale's on Franklin Avenue in Garden City, put it: "I just heard the news last night and it really saddened me. The Island has become mostly large shopping malls with very few upscale department stores left. Closing Bloomingdale's would be like the end of an era."
Some customers saw the closings as an inconvenience that would force them to change shopping habits that they had developed over years and even decades. Many small merchants, who have relied on the department stores to generate traffic, gloomily predicted the demise of local retail hubs already struggling to compete with modern malls and large discount retailers like The Home Depot, Bradlees and Kmart.
The decision to close the stores was in response to the concern of the New York State Attorney General, G. Oliver Koppell, that the merger between Federated and R. H. Macy would reduce business competition. Under the plan, Federated agreed to keep the stores open until it was able to sell them. If the stores are not sold in two years, Federated will hold further meetings with the Attorney General's office.
Mr. Koppell defended the agreement, under which the stores must be sold to another retailer who would be willing to hire the employees of the stores that Federated would close.
"We're very pleased that there's going to be a divestiture of these six stores," he said. "It's going to open competition and bring new department stores into the area. If these stores were not divested, there would have been a virtual lock on the department store business."
But around the metropolitan region, the question for many was which retailers, if any, would come forward and replace the six department stores.
Mr. James, the owner of the art shop in Garden City, said his business relied, in large part, on the kind of well-to-do shopper that Bloomingdale's was able to draw to the area. He said the closing would be devastating, even if another store moved in.
"In all honesty, Bloomingdale's brings a certain type of client, who buys our paintings," Mr. James said. "The closing will have an effect, even though we still have a Lord & Taylor and a Saks Fifth Avenue. But how long will they stay? I don't know."
Frank Georgiou, owner of a restaurant on Franklin Avenue in Garden City, doubted that any major retailer would want to open in a shopping district so dominated by furriers, jewelers, antiques dealers and bridal boutiques.
"The rents are too high," Mr. Georgiou said. "I don't think anyone will be able to afford it."
In White Plains, shoppers and small merchants said the closing of Macy's would kill the main reason people shop along Mamaroneck Avenue instead of in nearby malls.
"It's the last nail in the coffin for the little merchant on Mamaroneck Avenue," said Mark Lederman, whose family had already decided to relocate their camera store, Colortone Camera, to Elmsford, N.Y. "Macy's was the last thing to bring people to the avenue. It's extremely upsetting."
Mr. Schulman, the Mayor of White Plains, said the key to maintaining the downtown shopping district's "middle-market" niche is finding a retailer "that is of similar quality to Macy's."
"I certainly don't want a store that is on the lower end of the retail scale," he said. "And I certainly don't want a warehouse-style store without much customer service."
Many shoppers agreed. "For this location, we need a good store with quality merchandise," said Madeline Johnson, a retired teacher who was browsing the clothing section on the second floor of Macy's. "I'd hate to see it turn into something like a Filene's Basement."
At the same time, many felt that interest in the operation of the store had long ago waned. They mentioned a decrease in the variety of merchandise, and said any replacement would be welcome.
"I like J. C. Penney much better," said Marilyn Mazzella, after arriving at the Macy's to register at the bridal registry. "I get a little upset when I come in here because I end up walking in circles and never find what I want."

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI: VICTIMS;
In Sight of U.S. Ships in Port-au-Prince, the Killing Continues

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 20

 BODY:
He was a frail man who eked out a living selling coconuts on the streets.
A Haitian policeman clubbed him to death today with a stick of wood just a few feet from heavily armed United States infantrymen who, obeying their orders, did nothing to stop it. 
 The death of the coconut vendor, at 11:30 A.M. just across the street from the docks here, was part of a daylong assault by the Haitian police on people who came to watch the American military deployment.
People had streamed there by the thousands to gaze at the American ships as they docked, helicopters thundering overhead, and wave to and kiss the sober-faced soldiers.
"They've oppressed us," Marie Aliencin said of the Haitian Army as she waved to the arriving United States forces, adding in wonder, "We're getting beat up in front of the Americans."
The beatings led to recurring demonstrations by groups of people chanting democracy slogans and praising the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haiti's deposed President-in-exile.
Over and over, they danced in rare, open defiance of the police, who responded with gun butts, tear gas, tire irons and clubs made of sticks of wood.
Some, including Ms. Aliencin, admitted that they were glad of the small army of reporters, photographers and camera crews recording the violence. "We want the world to know what we've been through in the last three years," she said.
But the Haitians could not understand why the American military stood by in their helmets and flak jackets and watched it all happen from atop concrete walls and behind fences.
The challenge posed by the demonstrators, who hurled rocks and curses at the police, is one that the Haitian security forces have not to deal with here in Port-au-Prince since September 1991, when Father Aristide was overthrown in a violent military coup.
"We do this because these are very bad people," said Robert Louis, one of several protesters who taunted the police. "These people have beaten us and humiliated us and made us less than men."
The blue-uniformed Haitian police, some wearing helmets and others carrying shields, charged into the ranks of the demonstrators, hitting anyone in reach. One police officer repeatedly fired tear gas at the crowds, but his aim was bad. He bounced one canister off the headquarters of the Foreign Minister, lobbed another onto the roof where it smoldered for several minutes and blasted another at head-level through a crowd of journalists.
Some did find their mark, however, and demonstrators fled choking and weeping from the gray smoke. "They act like they want to kill us," said Jimmy Fresnel, a teen-ager who said he came to the docks just to see what all the excitement was about.
"Because I love Aristide, this is what they do to me," said Jean Stevenson, an unemployed mechanic who was beaten on the head and shoulders by four police officers while standing on Harry S. Truman Boulevard.
"I'm going to kill one of them," an officer at the scene told his colleagues. "I don't want to get hit by rocks."
At one point a truckload of uniformed soldiers arrived as backup. Most who suppressed the crowd were in uniform, but mixed in were a few so-called "attaches," plainclothes thugs who have no official authority but wreak violence on behalf of the security forces.
Some of the attaches, armed with pipes and sticks, beat and chased the onlookers. One man in a yellow polo shirt and black sunglasses hit a young boy in the face with a club and then laughed as other attaches beat the boy as he ran down the sidewalk. A teenager, a girl of about 14, stood bleeding profusely from her mouth and smashed nose.
"What we're watching here is a big thing," Mr. Joseph said of the beatings. "But at least we hope that things will get better."
Though his name was not known, the slain coconut vendor became a sort of a battle cry as the day wore on. "They have already killed one of us," said one woman, with tears streaming down her face.
The man's coconuts had been neatly stacked in a shopping cart when the police attacked him. Much later this afternoon, when most of the demonstrators had given up and gone home, the coconuts were still there, some left in his neat pile, others scattered and crushed.

HEADLINE: Trade Data Spur a Big Stock Drop

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
America's mounting trade deficit was bad news for the dollar yesterday, and that, in turn, meant bad news for the stock market. Its fall accelerated by high-speed computer-guided trading near the end of the session, the Dow Jones industrial average lost all its hard-won gains since Aug. 30 and slipped below 3,900.
The Dow index of 30 blue-chip stocks, the best-known measure of stock performance, lost 67.63 points to close at 3,869.09, and the other leading indexes also fell. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 stock index fell 7.49 points, to 463.36, and the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 9.98 points, to 766.74. 
 Stock prices usually fall because traders dislike a stock or are pessimistic about the economy, or both. But sometimes, as happened yesterday with the computer selling, factors that have little to do with market fundamentals or the world economy also play a large role.
Traders were dumping stocks all day after the release of worse-than-expected figures concerning the July trade deficit, which at $10.99 billion was the second highest in the nation's history. Then, a huge computer-guided "sell" program further reduced leading stock indexes at 3:36 P.M. Minutes later, when the Dow fell 50 points, the program activated the New York Stock Exchange's "circuit breaker" rules, which are intended to curb the computerized trading known as index arbitrage.
The probable identity of the computer trader will not be clear until the exchange publishes its computerized trading figures later this month. Nor was it clear why the trader was selling stocks in a falling market, when bargain hunting might have seemed more likely.
Jeffrey Rubin, a market analyst at Birinyi Associates, which tracks such trading, estimated that the sell program involved some 28 million shares in 360 S.& P. 500 stocks. It reduced the Dow by 20.10 points and the S.& P. 500 by 2.49 points, he said.
Christine A. Callies, an equity market strategist at Brown Brothers Harriman, said the market had risen too high on technical factors, rather than market sentiment. "This just wipes the slate clean," she said.
The market had been rising for three weeks, partly because of such factors as "short covering," by which traders who had sold borrowed shares betting that stock prices would fall were forced to buy shares when prices unexpectedly rose. Traders also bid up stocks because they believed that the Federal Reserve, which raised short-term interest rates by half a percentage point on Aug. 16, would not act again until after the November elections.
But now, that consensus has melted away. Yesterday's near-record low for the dollar versus the Japanese yen in the currency markets worried stock traders. That prompted the leading stock indexes to retreat from further assualts on their records for the year. The Dow's high this year is 3,978.36 points on Jan. 31. The S.& P. 500's high is 482.00 points on Feb. 2, and the Nasdaq's peak is 803.93 points on March 18.
The immediate cause of yesterday's fall was the Commerce Department's trade report. Wall Street economists had expected the deficit would total a worrisome $9.8 billion. When it exceeded that by a startling $1.19 billion, and included a wider deficit with Japan, the dollar fell to a New York close of 97.65 yen, just a fraction above the closing low set on July 12 of 97.40 yen after hitting a post-World War II low of 96.60 yen in intraday trading.
Japanese are paid in dollars for Japanese goods they sell in the United States, and then exchange those dollars for yen or other major currencies. The resulting glut of dollars has pushed the dollar's value to the lowest point in nearly 50 years. A weak dollar means foreign investors are less likely to buy stocks and bonds because gains will be cut when converted to their own currencies.
Amid the general retreat, some stocks advanced. Magma Power, which operates geothermal power plants, rose 7 1/4, to 34 3/4, after receiving an $840 million takeover bid from a rival, the California Energy Company. Shares of the 3Com Corporation, a computer company, rose 1 1/8, to 38 3/8, after it said its first-quarter profit had more than doubled.
Shares of First Alert and American Sensors, the two principal makers of carbon-monoxide detectors, rose on expectation of higher sales after reports that Vitas Gerulaitis, the former tennis star, died accidentally from carbon-monoxide poisoning. First Alert rose 2, to 27, and American Sensors rose 1 3/8, to 20 1/4.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was far above average, with 326.1 million shares changing hands, about 14 percent above this year's average of 286 million shares.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 3.72 points, to 255.91, with declining stocks far outpacing advancers, 1,812 to 492. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 2.98 points, to 458.15.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 28 fell, led by E.I. du Pont de Nemours, which gave up 1 3/4, to 57 3/4.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Concerns Over Trade Deficit Push Dollar Lower vs. Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell near its all-time low against the Japanese yen yesterday, weakened by a worse-than-expected report on the American trade deficit and fading prospects for a trade accord between the United States and Japan.
But the dollar gained against most leading European currencies as market demand for yen and a recovery in American bond prices helped limit selling pressure on the dollar. 
 The dollar began to weaken against the yen after the Commerce Department reported a 21.6 percent rise in the United States trade deficit in July, to $10.99 billion, putting the country well on track toward its worst trade imbalance in seven years. The shortfall with Japan increased 3 percent, to $5.67 billion.
The currency market had expected at most a small rise in the overall deficit. And yesterday's report reminded dealers not to expect a letup in the sale of dollars by Japanese exporters, a key factor behind the currency's 13 percent slide this year.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar settled at 97.65 Japanese yen, down from 98.44 on Monday. Yesterday's close was the lowest since July 12, when the dollar closed at 97.40 yen after hitting a post-World War II low of 96.60 yen in intraday trading.
The selloff of dollars was also fueled by comments by the United States and Japanese Governments, seeking to apply pressure on each other ahead of a Sept. 30 deadline for a trade agreement that has been imposed by Washington. The United States has threatened sanctions on Japanese exports unless the two sides reach an agreement on government contracts by then.
"The market's reaction today has more to do with concerns that we won't get an agreement by Sept. 30," Chris Iggo, an economist with Chase Manhattan Bank, said.
A recovery in the American bond market and reports of dollar buying by large institutional investors helped to push the dollar up against European currencies.
In New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5520 German marks, from 1.5480 marks on Monday. The dollar also rose to 1.2868 Swiss francs, from 1.2850.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Prices Surge on Fears That Inflation Will Pick Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Gold prices surged yesterday, stopping just short of $400 an ounce, amid growing concern that a strong United States economy will accelerate the pace of inflation.
Silver and platinum prices also gained as investors who are concerned that inflation will erode the value of their stock and bond holdings buy precious metals, which hold their value when inflation picks up. 
 On other markets, orange juice and wheat prices rose. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities gained 1.56 points, to 230.97.
Recent reports have shown that the United States economy is expanding quickly, which could lead to faster inflation growth.
"Everybody's worried about inflation; we know it's coming," said Leonard Kaplan, vice president of the Imperial Bank in Los Angeles. "The market is saying it's going to be worse than we think."
The gold contract for December delivery rose as high as $399.10 an ounce before retreating to settle up $3.60, at $397.20, a 13-month high, on the Commodity Exchange of New York. December silver gained 20.3 cents, to $5.67 an ounce, while October platinum rose $7, to $420.70 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Orange juice prices jumped 3 percent amid concern that high temperatures in Florida may reduce next year's crop.
The hot weather "might not allow the first bloom to take very well," said Bob Tate, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Orlando, Fla. "It's still too early to say."
Orange juice for November delivery rose 3.70 cents, to 91.40 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Wheat futures rose on signs of increased demand for American wheat.
The Agriculture Department said Egypt had bought 390,000 metric tons under an export bonus subsidy program, and traders said the country could buy another 1.5 million tons soon.
Egypt usually buys as much as 2.5 million tons of Australian wheat each year, said John Kleist, director of agricultural research with Quantum Financial Services in Chicago. But a drought has slashed Australia's harvest by more than 38 percent this year.
"The possibility exists that Egypt may be in for additional wheat because of the problems in Australia," he said.
September wheat gained 5.25 cents, to $3.8275 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade.

HEADLINE: Martha Graham Company Reaches Pact With Dancers

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING 

 BODY:
The Martha Graham Dance Company reached a settlement with its dancers on Monday night after labor unrest threatened its "Radical Graham" season, which is to open the Next Wave festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Sept. 28. The dancers ratified a contract after a 10-hour meeting on Monday at the offices of the American Guild of Musical Artists, the dancers' union.
As part of the agreement, the dancers withdrew their demand for a guarantee of employment amounting to 20 weeks a year. Such a guarantee was the major sticking point in the negotiations, which have gone on for 10 months. Management withdrew its demands for concessions on travel overtime. 
 "The Martha Graham Dance Company continues to be the only AGMA dance company without a minimum guarantee of work weeks," the dancers said in a statement released after the meeting, which was attended by most of the company's 21 dancers and two board members, in addition to representatives of the union and management. "The artists understand financial constraints of any company in this economic climate, but there is a great sense of frustration among the dancers that the management and its board of directors are unable to make a commitment equal to the one that the dancers must make to be trained and available for 52 weeks in each year."
In a statement this morning, Ron Protas, the company's artistic director, said: "I and the Martha Graham board of trustees rejoice at the news that after much reasoning together, the Martha Graham dancers and management have reached an agreement that will enable the 'Radical Graham' season at BAM -- which celebrates Martha Graham's centennial -- to go on as planned."
The new contract expires on June 30, 1996. The dancers had been working without a contract since June 1993, although the company agreed to pay the minimum salaries the dancers would have received if a new contract had been ratified. The salaries increase 3 to 4 percent, with first-year apprentices receiving $247 a week, up from $240, and first-year principal dancers receiving $735 a week, up from $714.
Last week, the union issued an ultimatum to the company, suggesting that the dancers might take action if a new contract was not signed by 12:01 A.M. next Wednesday, the day of their scheduled opening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. On Thursday, Graham employees received paychecks for about half their weekly salaries because of late receipt of a confirmed grant. The dancers refused the checks and walked out on Friday afternoon when they were not paid their full salaries. They were paid yesterday and reported back to rehearsal at the Graham headquarters on East 63d Street in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: A Cool Quest: One Wine Lover's Search for the Right Cellar

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
IF there's anything more intimidating than shopping for wine, it's shopping for a wine cellar. My desire to keep my wine from becoming something worth pouring only onto salads soon confronted cooling contraptions with the size, complexity and price of intercontinental ballistic missiles.
Not that I have any great collection. Maybe eight or nine cases, much of that bought before leaving New York last fall, knowing that prices and selection in Dallas were no match. The closest thing I have to a wine cellar is a closet in the coolest room of my house. 
 Those who sell wine cellars would have us believe that momentary exposure to more than 70 degrees turns cabernet into vinegar. Who knows? But in Dallas, the temperature reached the mid-80's in March, the 100's by June. This year, New York was almost as scorching.
By late spring, I was sweating. Every time I saw a newspaper advertisement for wine cellars with a headline like "Mouton melting?" my temperature rose another few degrees, even though my collection runs more to California Chateau Technoburb than to Mouton.
I was in a race against the thermometer, and I was losing.
I bought the Wine Spectator magazine and hurriedly called some of the cellar sellers who advertise there and in some newspapers. First, I had to discuss how much room I needed. When I told sales clerks over the phone that I had about 100 bottles, they advised providing enough space for at least 100 more.
Then I had to choose between a free-standing refrigeration unit or the conversion of a closet or part of a room. For more than 600 bottles, a build-it-yourself conversion was much cheaper than a free-standing unit, the sales clerks said, not counting the loss of household space.
In the International Wine Accessories catalogue, I saw kits starting at $849 that store as many as 700 bottles. "It has insulation and a cooling unit, so you're ready to rock 'n' roll," a salesman told me. Or maybe just fox trot. Shipping and racks, it turned out, were several hundred dollars more.
Would I ever have enough wine to justify the labor and the cost? Not if I wanted to afford food to accompany that wine. As a corporate vagabond, I also realized that I wouldn't want to install a new wine room each time I moved. What's more, the older houses my wife and I prefer have too few closets to begin with, and in many parts of the country, including Dallas, basements are rare.
Thus I went looking for a free-standing cellar. My first source of confusion was the brand names listed in the catalogues. Three of the major makers turned out to be Vinotemp, Vinocraft and Vinotheque.
Then there was the techno-babble. A Vinotheque brochure boasted that the Vintronic III temperature stabilizer is "a digital, microprocessor-based wine temperature thermostat," featuring "a smart binary encoder" and "triac relays." The Vintronic III, I read, takes the wine's temperature 120 times a minute to maintain the temperature within 0.05 degrees, as if national security depended on it.
Buying a wine cellar was clearly too vital to do over the phone. I sought counsel and a tour of the International Wine Accessories store in Dallas. Considering the ponderous tone of the catalogues, the company president, Robert S. Orenstein, was surprisingly bubbly.
"I'm going to take a little of the mystique out," he said with a knowing grin. "Then I'm going to put more back in later."
He confessed that his best-selling item is a $16.95 T-shirt with a grape cluster and the words, "Whip me, crush me, make me wine." As he spoke, he strolled through rooms of hulking wine cellars, some plain but others with as much carved oak and leaded glass as the front doors of a striving Dallas subdivision.
He stopped at one cellar. "Stand back and look at this," he said. "What do you have? You have a box with two doors, a cooling unit and a rack. There is no magic."
He moved on. "Here's the competing brand," he said. "The only difference is the racks."
But what about all the different brand names, all those Vino's? "None of these people have any imagination," Mr. Orenstein said. Most retailers who sell their own brand of cellar actually have one of the three Vino's manufacture them, he added.
Then came the matter of space. To boast the largest capacity, many manufacturers have racks so narrow that only Bordeaux and California cabernets can fit, Mr. Orenstein said. Some have racks large enough for other wines, but few could handle many rotund bottles of Champagne. "The manufacturers are all so sneaky," he said. "It drives me nuts."
Me, too. Finally, I asked him whether my spare refrigerator wouldn't do. Well, no, he said. It would be too cold, keeping my wine in suspended animation instead of graceful maturation. It would also dry out the air, eventually crumbling the corks.
How about one of those cheaper wine cellars that look like deli cases on steroids? It was time for the mystique, at least as it pertains to design.
"A lot of people miss the boat," Mr. Orenstein said. "They say, 'I'm just going to throw it in the laundry room.' Well, yes, but then they move and it has to go in the bedroom."
"Men always go for functional stuff," he said. "But if you want to say esthetics doesn't matter, think it through."
The catalogues and advertisements show seemingly functional 200-bottle wine cellars for less than $1,000. Esthetics are extra. A lot extra. A plain 250-bottle Vinocraft with an unfinished oak cabinet that Mr. Orenstein recommended has a base price of $1,399. A furniture finish adds $195, and shipping from California is at least another $300.
If I want a real piece of furniture rather than an intimidating wooden box, it's still more. A door with some simple flat moldings around the edges adds $450, some curving moldings instead adds $599, and curving moldings with a window adds $995.
"If you don't have the windows, it would look like a coffin," Mr. Orenstein advised.
My likely expense for the Vinocraft was zooming past $2,000 and on toward $3,000. For a glorified fridge. It was time to call an economist, Orley Ashenfelter of Princeton University, who publishes Liquid Assets, a wine buying and price guide.
Mr. Ashenfelter was as ready to dispose of wine cellars as a punter is ready to dispose of a football. Except for wines that are very hard to get -- 1978 Italian Barolos, maybe -- buying a wine cellar makes much less sense to him than buying wines that need no long storage.
"If you like mature wines," he said, the best thing to do is "not to store them yourself, but to buy them at auction." He finds that auction prices for aged wines are often as low, or lower, than retail prices for young wines.
I already had young wines, but I soon found another reason for hesitating to order a cellar. Wine collectors, acting almost as slowly as their Bordeaux ages, usually delay placing their orders until the weather is hot. By the summer, the wait for a wine cellar is usually several weeks, sometimes months. My race was already lost.
No wine cellar before its time, it seemed. And for me, the time to order a wine cellar might be next year. Or the year after.

HEADLINE: Immigration Chaos Keeps U.S. in Cheap Labor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The gross ineptitude and mismanagement that pervades the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, described in your "Chaos at the Gates" series (front page, Sept. 11-15) cannot be dismissed as a Government bureaucracy that does not work. The real question is: Why is there no serious pressure from the public or from Government officials to improve the agency's performance? What purpose is served by an inefficiency that allows three million to four million undocumented immigrants to reside in this country? 
 A major segment of the United States economy benefits from the presence of undocumented immigrants, and therein lies at least part of the answer. The United States is in the enviable position of having a nearly limitless supply of inexpensive labor clamoring at its gates.
Moreover, in recent years it has been attracting skilled, highly motivated immigrants for even the most menial jobs. And, through legislation and selective enforcement of immigration law, the Government not only creates a supply of cheap, powerless labor, but can also partly regulate what immigrants are admitted and under what conditions.
The presence of undocumented immigrants is also advantageous because, for many, the sojourn in the United States is temporary. Most, at least initially, view their stay as transitory, and it is this ready-made impermanence that meshes so neatly with the kinds of jobs they fill.
Undocumented immigrants are overwhelmingly employed in the secondary sector of the United States labor market, which is characterized by low-wage jobs, with no job security, few or no benefits and little or no advancement opportunity. Because of the disadvantages, finding native-born workers to fill such jobs can be a problem.
Enter undocumented immigrants. Seeing themselves as "here today and gone tomorrow," they are less disheartened by the lack of career prospects and other drawbacks of the secondary job market.
Undocumented immigration to the United States channels in low-cost, often well-educated workers, who are willing, even eager, to take jobs that otherwise might go unfilled. It is well to recall this when we condemn the immigration service's "inefficiency." What appears as ineptitude may actually be tacit Government policy.
 
MAXINE L. MARGOLIS
Gainesville, Fla., Sept. 16, 1994
The writer, a professor of anthropology at the University of Florida, is author of "Little Brazil: An Ethnography of Brazilian Immigrants in New York City."

HEADLINE: More Recycling Reduces Dioxin Better Than an Incinerator Ban

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Environmental Protection Agency report on the health risks from dioxin is welcome (news article, Sept. 14). Dioxin, which is a probable cause of cancer and of developmental disorders, is largely produced from the combustion of such chlorine-containing substances as plastics. Therefore, the main source of dioxins is incinerator smokestacks. In addition, incineration releases other pollutants and also contributes to global warming.
Yet instead of outlawing incinerators, worldwide experience suggests that it is better to create a recycling-friendly economic environment. This is achieved by mandating that newspapers be printed on recycled paper and that soda be sold in recycled bottles.
Once such laws take effect, a market develops for used newspapers and soda bottles, and consequently they disappear from regular garbage. The combustible fraction in municipal waste drops to the point where the garbage can no longer be burned, and therefore incineration is phased out.
Worldwide experience also shows that when regulations treat the dioxin-containing fly-ash from incinerators as toxic waste, resulting disposal costs tend to work against incineration and in favor of recycling.
It can be concluded that if the proper regulations exist, economic forces will support recycling. On a per-ton basis, recycling in populated areas will cost half as much as landfilling and one-third as much as incineration. In addition, the recycling industry creates low-skilled jobs and reduces pollution.
 
BELA LIPTAK
Stamford, Conn., Sept. 14, 1994
The writer is the author of "Municipal Waste Disposal in the 1990's."

HEADLINE: U.N. Chooses An African As President

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The General Assembly opened a new session today that is expected to draw the largest number of heads of state and prime ministers ever to address the forum.
In its first order of business, the assembly elected Amara Essy, a 49-year-old former Foreign Minister of the Ivory Coast, as president. Mr. Essy, who has also served with the United Nations in New York and Geneva, replaces Samuel Insanally of Guyana. 
 Though the post, rotated annually among the five major regional blocs, is mainly ceremonial, the president has the power to set the agenda, control the order of speakers and resolve intractable disputes within the Assembly.
At least 59 leaders are to address the 49th session of the General Assembly, among them President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin, who are to speak next Monday, and Pope John Paul II, who is to speak on Oct. 21.
Rosario Green of Mexico, the Assistant Secretary General in charge of the assembly meeting, said the large number of leaders scheduled to attend "reflects the attention the assembly is getting" and "more commitment to the United Nations today than in the past."
Ms. Green noted that the United Nations was going through a "difficult transformation period," as an increasing number of smaller member nations seek "landing places" for their views and expertise for solving to their own problems.
Assembly leaders said they would seek to steer the 184 member nations toward issues like economic development, social ills and the environment, though those issues were likely to be overshadowed by the American intervention in Haiti, the civil war in Bosnia and the continuing turmoil in Rwanda.
The Assembly's actions on the 157 items on its agenda carry no force of law, but positions taken here during the next three months carry international weight and affect the votes of the 15-member Security Council.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 26, 1994, Monday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the opening of the United Nations General Assembly referred incorrectly to its new President, Amara Essy. He is the current Foreign Minister of Ivory Coast, not a former one.

HEADLINE: Report Says New York Taxes Are the 2d Highest in the U.S.

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
New York's state and local tax burden remains the second highest in the country, according to a new report by the State Business Council, and the gap between New York and other states is widening after a slight narrowing in the late 1980's.
Taxes paid in 1992 by businesses and individuals to New York State and local governments averaged $3,531.85 per resident, 62.5 percent above the national average and second only to Alaska. But Alaska's figures are distorted by the overwhelming share of its taxes that is paid by a handful of oil companies. 
 Just behind New York in the state rankings were Connecticut and New Jersey. Per capita, however, state and local taxes in Connecticut, at 40.8 percent above the national average, and New Jersey, 35.2 percent higher, were significantly lower than in New York.
The report highlights a longstanding issue -- New York's heavy state and local tax burden -- that is at the center of the election race between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and State Senator George E. Pataki, his Republican rival for governor. The report, based on Census data, was prepared by the research arm of the State Business Council, a lobbying group that has long argued that lower taxes for businesses and individuals would improve the state's economy.
While the figures, based on a common way of looking at Census data, are not in dispute, their interpretation is.
State officials said that New York stands out largely because local taxes in places like New York City, its suburbs, and other large cities are much higher than in other states. They also point out that New Yorkers generally earn more than residents of other states, which makes it easier for them to pay higher taxes.
"We've reduced the state tax burden," said Tom Conroy, a spokesman for Governor Cuomo. "If you look at state taxes as a share of personal income, New York has gone from 14th in 1982, when Governor Cuomo was first elected, to 22d today."
Looking at state taxes on a per-capita basis, rather than as a share of personal income, New York ranked sixth among the 50 states. Its per-capita state tax burden of $1,661.96 was 28 percent above the national average of $1,290.34.
Among the states, New York has by far the highest overall local taxes, averaging $1,869.88 per capita, 112 percent above the national average of $882.91.
But David Shaffer, president of the Business Council's Public Policy Institute, said the "distinction between state and local taxes is mostly of interest to politicians trying to shift blame from their constituents away from themselves."
"From the point of view of the taxpayer," he said, "the total of what they have to pay is what counts."
He added that New York's high local taxes, including local property taxes, often reflect obligations imposed by the state government.
Mr. Pataki, in a statement, said the report demonstrate that taxes in New York "are out of control."
He added, "I will cut taxes and create an atmosphere for economic renewal."
Frank Mauro, executive director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, which is sponsored by labor and community organizations, said the figures in the Business Council report overstate the tax burden on New Yorkers. This is because the report include taxes paid by outsiders, like residents of other states who work in New York and tourists who pay sales taxes on goods bought in the state.
"We export a lot of our taxes to other places," he said. "These aggregate numbers do not really tell you how much individuals are paying out of their own pocket."
The tax gap between New York and other states widened in 1992 partly because state and local governments in the state raised taxes more than other states and partly because the recession of the early 1990's hit harder in the Northeast, holding down income gains in New York and other nearby states, Mr. Shaffer said.
New Yorkers have long paid higher state and local taxes than people elsewhere in the nation. The gap grew sharply in the 1960's and 1970's before leveling off during much of the next decade. Between 1987 and 1991, the difference between New York and other states narrowed a bit. From 1991 to 1992, state taxes grew more than local taxes by a small amount.
Measured as taxes collected per $1,000 in personal income so as to reflect differences in income among states, state and local governments in New York took in 14 percent more than the national average in 1964. The gap between New York and other states widened to 41.1 percent by 1980, then narrowed slightly before peaking again at 41.6 percent above the national average in 1986 and 1987. It dropped as low as 34.6 percent in 1991 before rising again to 36.9 percent above the national average in 1992.
On that basis, New York state and local taxes in 1992 averaged $157.71 per $1,000 in personal income, compared with the national average of $115.22.

HEADLINE: Pataki Is Criticized by London, Party's Comptroller Candidate

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
In a surprising assault on party unity, Herbert London, the Republican candidate for comptroller, criticized his own party's nominee for governor yesterday, saying State Senator George E. Pataki "has not clearly defined himself or his plan to cut taxes and stop runaway spending."
The criticism from Mr. London, who had been Mr. Pataki's chief rival for the Republican nomination this spring, came in a one-page statement only hours after the question of comptroller independence emerged as the defining issue in a debate between Mr. London and his Democratic opponent, H. Carl McCall. 
 Mr. McCall has also taken care to distance himself from the head of his ticket, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a longtime friend who is considered vulnerable this year. But Mr. McCall has never attacked Mr. Cuomo so directly.
Mr. London said that as an independent comptroller candidate, he was compelled to speak out. "As the titular head of the Republican Party, George Pataki is obligated to give the voters a reason to chose him over Mario Cuomo, based on clearly defined policies," his statement said. "Voters must not be forced to choose the next governor of this state based solely on an 'Anybody but Cuomo' campaign."
The statement came after weeks in which Democrats, as well as a handful of Republicans, have said Mr. Pataki has not specifically outlined what he would do if elected. Earlier in the day, Mr. Pataki released a welfare plan that Democrats said called mostly for speeding up or expanding policies that have already been proposed by Mr. Cuomo. [Page B13.]
Last night the Pataki campaign appeared to be taken by surprise by Mr. London's attack. A spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha, would say only that Mr. Pataki would release an economic plan soon. But many campaign workers had expected that after a contentious fight leading up to the party's nomination, Mr. London would work for the ticket.
Mr. London's motive was unclear last night. While he could be helped by appearing independent -- New Yorkers often choose comptrollers from the party opposite the governor's -- he could be hurt in raising money if Republican leaders are upset enough by his attack. He was not available for comment last night, but a spokesman released a statement hinting that he wanted to distance himself from Mr. Pataki as a qualification to run for comptroller.
"It's just something he feels he's morally obligated to do," said a campaign spokesman, Anthony DeStefano. "Nothing will prevent him from fulfilling his obligation to the taxpayers, either during the campaign or after he is elected."
Michael Long, the chairman of the Conservative Party, which has been a strong backer of Mr. London since he ran as its candidate for governor four years ago, said he too was surprised by Mr. London's statement.
"He didn't talk to me about it," Mr. Long said. "I would like to think that he was just trying to show his independence."
"Herb has a lot of enthusiastic supporters around him, and I certainly am one of them," he said. "But I think the enthusiasm may go a step too far. There was probably no intent meant here except the enthusiastic feeling that maybe if he was in the position, he would already be putting out his plan."
Mr. London, a New York University professor and former dean, came in a close third four years ago against the Republican candidate, Pierre Rinfret, in the race against Mr. Cuomo. Since then, he had run an exhausting four-year battle for the party's nomination for governor, but was shut out at the convention in May when most party leaders, including Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, backed Mr. Pataki.
Mr. London had said he would take no other spot except the gubernatorial nomination and called Mr. Pataki "unelectable" and "more interested in the advancement of his own political career" than in helping New York. But the pressure was intense to unite the Republicans and Conservatives -- to prevent splitting the anti-Cuomo vote again this year -- and by the convention's end, Mr. London had agreed to sign on as the comptroller candidate.
In the debate yesterday, Mr. McCall used the means of Mr. London's ascent to question his ability to be independent -- a charge Mr. London fired back at Mr. McCall and his ties to Democratic leaders.
"He made a deal with Pataki and others," Mr. McCall said at a debate sponsored by the Citizens Budget Commission, a private fiscal monitoring group. "After he called them assassins for rejecting his bid to be governor, he then sat down with the assassins and decided to become their candidate for comptroller. How can he talk about independence?"
In the kind of indirect attack that has angered the Cuomo campaign, Mr. McCall also put distance between himself and Mr. Cuomo during the debate, mentioning that he had sued him last year and criticizing the state's record in promoting economic development.
"In New York, what have we done for the private sector?" he said, not mentioning Mr. Cuomo by name. "Instead of rolling out the red carpet, we have rolled out red tape."
Neither comptroller candidate lost an opportunity at the debate yesterday -- their first public encounter -- to question the other's qualifications and integrity.
"It seems to me that the forgotten New Yorkers need a representative -- not a political insider, not simply somebody who is going to represent the political machine, not somebody who is going to do Mario Cuomo's bidding," Mr. London said, "but somebody who will serve as an independent, fair-minded broker."
For his part, Mr. McCall asserted that he was better qualified and that Mr. London, a longtime conservative who opposes abortion and gun control, was running only "to insinuate his ideas into the caldron of Albany politics."
"Let's look at Mr. London's ideas -- ideas that are out of step with the people of New York," he said.
Mr. London said he was only interested in insinuating his fiscal ideas.

HEADLINE: Rejecting New York City's Bid, Bank to Move to Connecticut

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
The Swiss Bank Corporation, rejecting offers of tax incentives to keep 1,500 workers in Manhattan, said yesterday that it would move 1,300 of those workers to a new office tower it planned to build in downtown Stamford, Conn.
Swiss Bank, an investment banking concern, said it would hire an additional 700 workers, bringing total employment in Stamford to 2,000 when the new building opens in 1998. 
 The announcement, made yesterday in Hartford, came as a blow to New York City, which has scored repeated successes in recent years in persuading companies not to leave Manhattan, largely through the use of tax breaks.
But it was a major victory for Stamford, which has been plagued by a glut of office space and has lost some of the luster, earned in the 1960's to the early 1980's, as one of the nation's fastest growing business centers outside big cities.
Connecticut's prize did not come cheaply. The state agreed to provide tax breaks that could amount to $120 million over 10 years, or $60,000 a worker, more than twice as much as New York City has ever offered in incentives.
The Connecticut tax break could grow to $165 million if Swiss Bank remains and expands in Stamford for 15 years.
"This is the largest entry of a new corporation into the State of Connecticut in my lifetime," Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said yesterday.
With several large banking, securities and insurance companies already based in Fairfield County, he said the Swiss Bank move would make Connecticut "one of the great financial centers of the world."
New York City officials said that they had put up a determined fight to retain Swiss Bank, one of the largest of 350 foreign-owned banks with offices in Manhattan. John Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, flew to Basil, Switzerland, to meet with top executives of the bank at their international headquarters.
"The city worked very hard," said Forest Taylor, a spokesman for Mr. Dyson. He declined to say what tax breaks the city offered to Swiss Bank.
In the past, the city and the state used tax incentives to retain Morgan Stanley & Company, Kidder, Peabody and other financial-service companies that threatened to leave.
The city has never offered packages valued at more than $25,000 per employee.
"The Mayor is being very frugal with scarce financial resources and he is not about to give away the store to any company that threatens to leave," Mr. Taylor said.
Swiss Bank said it planned to build a 20-story tower on 11 acres next to the Stamford railroad station and Interstate 95. The land, which is partly owned by the city and has an estimated value of $5 million, is to be turned over at no cost to the bank.
The site is the same one on which Morgan Stanley had an option. That deal fell through in 1992 when the brokerage firm accepted a 10-year package of New York City tax breaks and other incentives worth $39 million and agreed to keep its headquarters and 4,100 workers in Manhattan.
Although it appeared unlikely yesterday to be a major impediment, one hurdle remains to Swiss Bank's move to Stamford. Connecticut law prohibits foreign-owned banks from doing business in its borders.
But a bill to lift that restriction for banking concerns like Swiss Bank that are engaged mainly in investment banking, not customer deposits and lending, is expected to face little opposition in the Connecticut legislature when it is voted on at a special session next month.
The measure has the support of many in the Connecticut business community, including bankers.
"Ninety-five percent of the banks in Connecticut have no problem with it," said Gerald M. Noonan, president of the Connecticut Bankers Association, a trade group. "We think of it as a real plus."
Swiss Bank, which has been expanding rapidly, in currency trading, international lending and other investment banking activities, now has its Manhattan workers divided between the upper floors of the Swiss Bank Tower at 10 East 50th Street, a 27-story building on which it holds a 100-year lease, and another building it owns at Broadway and Park Row.
The bank said it would retain 200 workers in the East 50th Street building, including those in charge of its Latin American operations, and would retain a currency trading floor at the building it owns on Broadway, or another in lower Manhattan.
After its move to Stamford, the bank said it might seek a buyer for the Broadway building and tenants for the space it frees up on East 50th Street.
Connecticut's incentive package entails a 50 percent reduction in the state's 11.5 percent corporate-income tax over 10 years.
Whether the tax breaks reach the maximum of $120 million depends on how profitable the company is.
The package includes other incentives to keep Swiss Bank in Stamford. If, at the end of 10 years, the bank has increased its Connecticut employment to 3,000 workers, it is to receive a 25 percent reduction in its corporate-income tax bills for the next five years.
For Stamford, which attracted more than a dozen headquarters of large American corporations in the 1960's and 1970's, the Swiss Bank move will mean new construction after years of little activity.
Among the largest companies with headquarters in Stamford are the Xerox Corporation, the GTE Corporation Champion International and the General Reinsurance Company.
Although the movement of such highly diversified corporations to Stamford had ended by the mid-1970's, hundreds of smaller companies followed over the next decades as law firms, advertising agencies, accounting concerns and others set up shop, largely to provide services to the city's corporate giants.
The migration to Stamford, however, slowed after the 1987 stock market crash and in the ensuring recession, when many the same large companies that are based in STamford and elsewhere in Fairfield County sold off operations and shed executive workers.
That led to a glut of vacant offices across the county, with vacancy rates exceeding 20 percent for the last four years.
According to an analysis by Edward S. Gordon, a real-estate firm, Fairfield County's vacancy rate stands at 20.5 percent, compared with 14.5 percent in midtown Manhattan, 16.7 percent in Northern New Jersey and 23 percent in lower Manhattan.
Despite its excess office capacity, executives said that the city has begun attracting an influx of small financial-service firms.

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI;
More Aid, but No End to Sanctions

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Relief supplies to Haiti will increase sharply as American troops are deployed, easing the effects of the United Nations embargo that has devastated the Haitian economy, the United States delegate to the United Nations said today.
But the United States will not ask the Security Council to lift the embargo until Haiti's junta steps down and the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, returns to office, the delegate, Madeleine K. Albright, said. 
 Before the arrival of troops, Haiti's military often blocked deliveries of relief supplies. Now, Ms. Albright said, "it is possible to make those deliveries more robust and they can be delivered better thanks to the American military."
She acknowledged the "pain that is caused to Haitian society" by the sanctions, but said lifting them "should be tied to the return of President Aristide."
Relief supplies are exempt from the United Nations embargo, which bans trade and most financial transactions with Haiti. Unicef also announced today that it was immediately expanding its distribution of food, water and vitamins in Haiti. More than two dozen relief groups are at work in Haiti, where they feed 1 of every 7 Haitians.
