HEADLINE: Old Flame Burns the Housing Secretary

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The extramarital affair that once threatened to destroy the career of Henry G. Cisneros, the current Federal Housing Secretary and former Mayor of San Antonio, is again complicating his public life.
The new complications spring from telephone conversations, secretly taped by his former mistress over the course of three years, in which they discussed his payments to her that ultimately amounted to about $200,000. 
 The tapes, which the woman, Linda Medlar, has sold to a tabloid television program, provide no evidence of wrongdoing. But they have prompted Mr. Cisneros to acknowledge that he paid Ms. Medlar more than $50,000 in 1993, in apparent contradiction of his public statement this summer that the payments had ended by the time he joined the Clinton Cabinet early last year.
Tape transcripts issued by the television show "Inside Edition" have also led him to acknowledge that after becoming Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, he approached a wealthy Texas businessman, Morris Jaffe, to seek financial help for Ms. Medlar. Ms. Medlar herself has said that after Mr. Cisneros's visit to Mr. Jaffe, the businessman sent her a $5,000 check with the notation "loan."
The tapes have placed Mr. Cisneros in the uncomfortable position of defending his character and candor in the handling of an episode he has long struggled to put behind him. At one point in the transcripts, involving a 1992 conversation with Ms. Medlar about his approaching confirmation hearings to be Housing Secretary, he seems to contemplate misleading a Senate committee about the matter, although in other places he emphasizes a need to tell the truth.
In a recent interview, Mr. Cisneros said he had been steadfastly honest in describing the financial transactions to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which routinely performs background checks on Presidential nominees, and to members of the Clinton transition team. He said that Ms. Medlar, in secretly recording their telephone discussions, had tried to steer him into making embarrassing remarks and that it was unfair "to use those conversations as proof of anything."
He also said there had been nothing improper in the payments, which he said were not "hush money or blackmail" but rather a well-meaning attempt to help Ms. Medlar get back on her feet after their relationship ended. He described Mr. Jaffe as a longtime friend and said that, despite extensive real estate holdings, the businessman had "no connection to HUD that I'm aware of in any way."
But Mr. Cisneros also acknowledged that the tapes had complicated his attempts to disentangle his political life from the damaging personal affair. Parts of the transcripts even quote him as being critical of President Clinton. At one point, Mr. Cisneros says that Mr. Clinton "just can't seem to decide hard things" and that meetings with him "sort of lolligag." On another occasion, he says, "Bill is too much of a hail-fellow-well-met politician, willing to do a deal with the business interests."
The transcripts also quote him as referring to F.B.I. agents checking his background before his appointment as "gossipers and scandalizers" who are "real bad at tracking down financial things."
The Secretary, who has generally received high marks for his leadership of the housing department, apologized in the recent interview for those remarks, calling them "a lot of foolish talk." He said Ms. Medlar had been "purposefully drawing me out," and stressed that he had "the highest respect for President Clinton."
Mr. Cisneros first acknowledged his relationship with Ms. Medlar in 1988, when he was still Mayor of San Antonio and a rising star in the Democratic Party; she was a former worker in one of his election campaigns. After leaving office the next year, he ended the relationship and reconciled with his wife. But in 1990 he also began to make sizable payments to Ms. Medlar -- by her accounting, about $200,000 from 1990 through 1993, a figure he does not dispute.
Mr. Cisneros's tax returns show that his earnings as a partner in an investment company averaged about $198,000 a year from 1990 through 1992.
In the interview, he said the payments had been a voluntary attempt to help Ms. Medlar, a political fund-raiser by vocation, since the publicity from the affair had hampered her efforts to find work. "There was enough difficulty about this for everyone," he said, "and enough dishonor, if you will. I felt it was honorable to help her if I could."
But once he sold his business and joined the Clinton Administration, he said, he could no longer afford the payments.
Ms. Medlar, unemployed and living in Lubbock, Tex., is now suing Mr. Cisneros in a state court there for $256,000 in further support. She says he has broken an agreement to pay her $4,000 a month until her daughter, now a teen-ager, graduates from college in 1999. Mr. Cisneros says that they had no such agreement and that Ms. Medlar is making the tapes public in a campaign "to turn up the pressure to exact a settlement."
Ms. Medlar, who has acknowledged that she taped the conversations to protect herself in the very event that Mr. Cisneros stopped making payments to her, seems at some points in the transcripts to be trying to lure him into an admission of improper or even criminal activity. For instance, she suggests that on one occasion, when Mr. Cisneros was Mayor, Mr. Jaffe gave him an envelope filled with $10,000 in cash. "Absolutely not," Mr. Cisneros responds on the tape. On another occasion, Ms. Medlar warns him: "Honey, I'm as smart as they come. I know exactly what would do you in."
In the interview, Mr. Cisneros acknowledged having feared that Clinton transition officials would misconstrue the payments as "hush money," even though the affair had been widely publicized. He said he had taken pains to be "forthcoming at every step of the vetting process."
Webster L. Hubbell, who was a senior Clinton transition official and later Associate Attorney General, said in an interview that Mr. Cisneros had been "totally forthcoming" about the matter. He said that the transition team had accepted the explanation that Mr. Cisneros had been providing money to help Ms. Medlar, not to silence her, and that the team had found it "quite admirable."
Ms. Medlar's lawyers this week played a tape that they said dated from Dec. 24, 1992, in which Mr. Cisneros discussed what he would say if asked about the payments at his confirmation hearing. "I'll tell them what we agreed," he said, "and the only person in the world who can sink me at that point -- and I mean serious, I'm talking contempt of Congress, jail -- is you."
But in the recent interview, Mr. Cisneros said he had never had any intention of misleading Congress and had simply been trying to convince Ms. Medlar that he needed to tell the truth. "I'm describing how serious misleading the Senate in a confirmation hearing would be," he said, "knowing full well that if it came up, I would do nothing but tell the truth."
Mr. Cisneros pointed to other parts of the transcripts where he insisted he would tell the truth, at times to Ms. Medlar's evident displeasure. "Henry, I could just brain you for that," she says. Noting that Ms. Medlar had been hospitalized for depression and had often cried on the phone, he said that at times he had simply been trying to calm her.
As it turned out, Mr. Cisneros was not asked about the payments at his confirmation hearing, before the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs. He said he later discussed them in a private conversation with Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the committee.
Mr. Riegle did not return phone calls seeking comment. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, the committee's ranking Republican, said: "This is a personal matter. I do not believe this in any way reflects upon the Secretary's performance." Calls to Barry Toiv, spokesman for the White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, went unanswered.
Ms. Medlar said she had about 40 hours of tapes, covering three years, 1991-93. She made about a third of them available to "Inside Edition" after the show paid her a sum that her lawyers described as reaching "five figures." After broadcasting part of the tapes last week, the show distributed transcripts without her permission, she said.
Ms. Medlar said she plans to use the tapes in court to bolster her contention that Mr. Cisneros had promised to continue paying her.
When she filed suit in July, Mr. Cisneros issued a statement through the press office of his department that said, "I have not provided any assistance since assuming office in January of 1993." He now acknowledges making payments in February, March and June of that year, totaling more than $50,000.
But Mr. Cisneros said in the interview that those payments had been part of an agreement reached with Ms. Medlar before he entered the Government and that he did not consider them 1993 assistance. He said his statement, which referred vaguely to a 1992 promise to help Ms. Medlar "transition to a job over the forthcoming year," had been hastily drafted and should have been more precise.
Mr. Cisneros said that in late 1993, after he had stopped paying Ms. Medlar, he approached Mr. Jaffe, the Texas businessman, in an effort to identify business opportunities for her. Although Mr. Cisneros said there had been nothing wrong in those conversations, the transcripts clearly make him seem uncomfortable about it.
The 71-year-old Mr. Jaffe is a well-known figure in Texas politics, with holdings in oil, real estate and aerospace ventures. He helped arrange a lucrative oil deal for Jim Wright, then Speaker of the House, that was a factor in the ethics investigation that ultimately drove Mr. Wright from office.
The transcripts quote Mr. Cisneros as saying in late 1993 that he is worried that Mr. Jaffe's office "has a tap, because the Feds were after him." He adds that when he speaks with Mr. Jaffe, "I am very cryptic in the things I say."
But in the interview, Mr. Cisneros said he had been concerned only that someone listening in might misconstrue their conversation and think he was approaching Mr. Jaffe for aid for himself.
He said Mr. Jaffe had considered helping Ms. Medlar start a travel agency and had directed some business to a lighting company run by Ms. Medlar's family, in an unsuccessful attempt to produce a job for her.
He said he had learned about the loan only from Ms. Medlar. "Jesus!" he exclaimed when Ms. Medlar informed him of the loan in a taped conversation. "This guy's a savior."
Mr. Jaffe did not return phone calls seeking comment.

HEADLINE: China Is Planning a People's Car

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TIANJIN, China, Sept. 15

 BODY:
In the People's Republic it is being called the people's car, an affordable compact sedan for the masses in the world's largest untapped car market.
The car is the focus of an ambitious effort by leaders of China's Communist Party to double the nation's annual production to three million vehicles, half of them automobiles, by the end of the decade. Increasingly, the cars would go to individual consumers; in the past the emphasis had been on larger vehicles like mini-vans that could move groups of people. 
 American, Japanese and European auto makers are scrambling for the right to participate in a handful of joint-venture partnerships with China's state-owned auto combines to produce several versions of the family sedan.
But many Chinese and Western experts, drawing from what happened in the United States and other industrial nations, contend that a transportation system dominated by the automobile could become a huge mistake in China, which already suffers from traffic congestion, choking pollution and dwindling supplies of oil. A big increase in gasoline consumption in China, they say, could hasten the next worldwide energy crisis.
"The automobile cannot be extended to 1.2 billion Chinese, not even to 100 million or 200 million," said Vaclav Smil, a Canadian scientist who studies the challenges to China's growth in the next century.
"That is an insane route," he continued. "There is not a single Chinese city that does not suffer from gridlock already."
Still, according to an industrial policy announced in July, China seeks to develop its automotive sector into a "pillar industry" of the national economy "as soon as possible."
China's state planners under Prime Minister Li Peng have seized on the auto industry as one of four heavy industries whose growth can help sustain the country's rapid economic expansion over the next two decades. The other three are telecommunications, computers and petrochemicals.
Just as the automobile captured the American dream at the expense of mass transit, China's leaders are eager for the giant internal consumer market to move to the next stage of materialism. Sustained economic growth is an urgent political requirement for the leadership, whose legitimacy flows from the ability to deliver prosperity to the masses.
The Chinese family car for the coming century will emerge from a competition that is pitting the world's leading auto makers against one another to design and produce economy models that individual consumers could buy for under $5,000. While no detailed specifications have been issued, the car would be made in China but incorporate Western technology of the 1990's, with emphasis on modern safety standards, pollution control and fuel efficiency.
Foreign auto makers already in China may finally see the big payoff. Chrysler produces Jeep Cherokees in a joint venture with a Chinese auto maker in Beijing. Volkswagen has been producing its Santana model in Shanghai since 1985. Citroen is active in Wuhan, Audi in Changchun and Peugeot in Guangzhou. To create a modern, vertically integrated auto industry, the Chinese Government has been pressing foreign auto companies to make more parts locally as a condition of participation.
Because of such intense competition, Western auto makers are keeping their plans confidential. But Chrysler's chief executive, Robert J. Eaton, accompanied Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown to China last month. And Chrysler has been vying with Daimler-Benz for a contract, potentially worth up to $1.2 billion, to make mini-vans and engines in Hainan.
General Motors established a $100 million partnership foothold with the Jinbei Automotive Company in 1993 and began assembling kits of its S-10 pickup truck in Shenyang, though many Chinese customers found them too fancy and costly. And this summer, Ford Motor signed agreements worth $50 million to make auto parts in Shanghai.
But what all three American auto makers seek is a full-fledged partnership with the Chinese in the mainstream of the developing domestic automobile market.
The competition is still heating up. This month both Toyota and Mitsubishi sent their corporate presidents to court China's state auto plant commissars. Nissan's delegation is due in November.
"China offers the greatest potential market in the world and that's why everyone is coming," said Toshiaki Yasuda, who heads Nissan's effort to find a Chinese partner by next year.
At the Tianjin Automotive Industry Corporation in this industrial port city, 70 miles southeast of Beijing, the general manager, Ji Xuecheng, says he thinks the Charade subcompacts that his factory is turning out under a licensing agreement with Daihatsu of Japan could be the starting point for what he, too, calls the people's car.
"Society is making progress and the people's living standards are being raised," Mr. Ji, 60, said. "So there will be a big demand for passenger cars in the future."
The three most successful joint ventures between Chinese auto makers and their Western partners will be allowed to dominate 70 percent of the domestic market with their competing small sedans. The Government described its goal as one of "mass production and fewer factories and a market structure with orderly competition among a small number of large-scale enterprises."
Under the new industrial policy, China will begin producing the new sedans in 1996 or 1997, on assembly lines modernized and streamlined with technology from Japan and the West. By the year 2000, the Chinese auto industry will theoretically produce three million vehicles a year, half of them passenger cars, and Chinese leaders see nothing but growth beyond.
"The problem is, they don't think about traffic or people's lives, they just think about production, production, production," said Prof. Ding Jingping, an industrial economist at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. "This is one of the aspects of the centrally planned economy."
In the 15 years since China's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, began his effort to overhaul the economy, millions of Chinese have bought their first refrigerator, telephone, clothes washer and television set, driving the economy's growth.
The next consumer quest, Communist Party leaders have figured, will be for high-end products like computers, fax machines and automobiles. They may be right, judging by the record crowds that mobbed this year's auto show in Beijing.
Chinese schoolchildren memorize the specifications of new-car brochures as American youngsters do baseball cards.
The first Ferrari was sold in China this year -- to a Chinese developer who already owned black and white Mercedeses.
Even Chairman Mao's grandson, Wang Xiaozhi, confided in a newspaper interview that he dreamed of owning a car.
Today across China, only about 700,000 out of seven million cars are private. Most vehicles are purchased and operated by the workplaces where most Chinese are employed. In Beijing, Shanghai and other large cities, bicycles remain a primary mode of transportation.
The country's total vehicle production this year could reach 1.5 million, about one-tenth the level of the United States or Japan. But China's auto production has been growing at an annual rate of 17 percent since 1979. In 1993, production jumped 22.8 percent, outpacing overall economic growth of 13 percent.
With supply still unable to keep up with demand, China's leaders overcame arguments about traffic, pollution and mass transit to endorse even greater automobile production.
The Chinese fascination with cars, recalling that of Americans, occurs while big cities choke on traffic, air pollution grows worse and scientists are raising alarms that China's precious base of arable farmland will shrink further under the press of any road building campaign.
As for energy consumption, China became a net importer of oil last year after production in its major oilfields failed to keep up with demand. Discoveries in the South China Sea and Tarim Basin in western China have been slow to produce results.
"Forty percent of United States energy consumption goes into private cars, and the United States is importing half of its crude oil," Professor Smil, the Canadian scientist, said. "If the Chinese try to model themselves on the United States, or Japan or South Korea, there is simply not enough crude oil on the planet for them to import and, of course, it will speed up the arrival of the third oil crisis."
To create a true automobile economy would require a huge investment in roads and highways in China, which today has about as many miles of road as existed in the United States at the end of the 19th century. The few dozen short stretches of modern freeways built in the last decade are almost lost in a rural landscape where dirt paths and narrow farm-to-market lanes still predominate.
"If China only worries about production, without any overall transportation planning, then China is headed for big trouble," said Guocang Huan, an economist for J. P. Morgan in Asia who visited Beijing last week.

$100 MILLION TO FINANCE NEW SCHOOLS
In one of the nation's most ambitious efforts to improve public schools, New York City will receive $100 million -- half of it from the Annenberg Foundation -- to replace some of the city's large, overcrowded neighborhood schools with 50 small experimental schools in the next five years. The former Gulf and Western Building, 40 Wall Street and the China Trust Bank in Queens are among projects in which developers called in feng shui experts. A1.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Economists step up to the plate on ways to reorganize baseball for the benefit of the fans.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WITH baseball junkies suffering from World Series withdrawal, Congress is in a mood to make the club owners share their pain. At very least, there will be a concerted effort in coming weeks to strip the owners of their antitrust protection, which in turn would eliminate their right to cap salaries without the players' consent.
But some wonder whether it is time to think bigger -- to reorganize Major League Baseball in a way that puts the fans' interests first. And, surprise, surprise, economists are happy to rush in where tradition-bound commentators fear to tread. 
 Two approaches are especially provocative:
Playing the N.C.A.A. Way. Major League Baseball is confined to 28 cities when it is being played at all. Why not 38 or 48? Because the owners of the existing franchises make the decisions, and have every reason to believe that expansion does not pay: local revenues from increasing league size would not offset the dilution of national television rights. Indeed, the $90 million franchise fee charged to the latest applicants, was explicitly intended to compensate for the bite into broadcast revenues.
That arrangement suits George Daly, dean of the Stern School of Business at New York University, who thinks the owners' interest in keeping baseball small coincides with the public interest. In an era of television, he suggests, fans can as easily grow attached to teams whose stadiums are 1,000 miles away as those 100 miles away. "For all I know," he concludes, "baseball is too big" in the sense that fewer clubs playing with the cream of professional athletes could generate as much pleasure for the public.
But that is not how Roger Noll, an economist at Stanford University and consultant to the players association, sees it. The logic of free markets puts the burden on those who would restrict entry to an industry. And in Mr. Noll's view, the most practical way to let the market decide how many teams play in the majors would be to break baseball into a half-dozen smaller (perhaps regional) leagues and let them negotiate playoffs for a national championship.
Weakening the leagues would reduce the financial barriers to starting yet more leagues or reorganizing existing ones. Baseball, Mr. Noll hopes, would then evolve into a system similar to N.C.A.A. basketball, with teams operating with lower costs in dozens of smaller markets.
The catch, argues Gerald Scully, an economist at the University of Texas at Dallas, is that fans would trade "quality for quantity." After all, he notes, "you can't replicate 500 Bobby Bonds."
But Mr. Scully does concede the attraction of the Noll vision. Baseball would, in a sense, return to its roots, with much lower salaries, more dependence on local fan loyalty and stronger intercity rivalries. And the likely dilution in the quality of play might paradoxically increase interest in the game. The best of college basketball and football are no less exciting than their professional counterparts, at least in part because ordinary mortals are occasionally inspired to play beyond their capacities.
The British Option. Remodeling the professional game after the N.C.A.A. may seem a bridge too far for traditionalists. But Philip K. Porter, an economist at the University of South Florida, offers an alternative that seems far less disruptive, though no less revolutionary in impact.
In Britain, he notes, professional soccer clubs compete in A and B divisions, much the way American baseball is divided into the major and minor leagues. There is one gigantic difference, though: Whole teams, rather than players, switch leagues when they excel or fail. Specifically, an A division team must trade places with the best of the B division when it finishes at the bottom of its division standings for two consecutive years.
Think of the implications: First and foremost, baseball-crazed cities would no longer be at the mercy of major league club owners. If the professional team in, say, Tampa invested enough in players and management, it would probably get a crack at joining the big leagues. Only slightly less important, incompetent or cynical major league owners would no longer be secure. "Only the best-managed teams could stay at the top," Mr. Porter explains.
Major League Baseball would thus become a truly national game, one in which any city able to support the costs of a big league team would have a crack at same. By the same token, though, there would be no tendency to dilute player quality. And even the fans of teams that could not aspire to major league performance would be better off since they would catch the excitement of competition with other minor league clubs still on the way up.
Is any of this possible? Not if Washington leaves it to professional baseball to clean up its own mess. But if the fans -- and thus Congress -- are angry enough, the legal leverage is there to reshape the game.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
City Is Fighting Garbage, But Will It Sweep Crime?

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
IT seems almost unfair, sort of raining-on-the-paradelike, to ask this question, but here it is anyway: Will City Hall take the same tough stance with police officers as it did with its sanitation workers?
Under the city's tentative and roundly praised contract with its sanitation union, garbage collectors may finally work a full day for a full day's pay. If the deal develops none of the loopholes so common to city labor accords, the contract is great news for those who favor cleaner streets and greater economy. 
 But what of the police? Will Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who says, "There are no sacred cows," really admit the Police Department into his not-so-exclusive club of budget-cut victims?
The Sanitation Department is to the Police Department as Staten Island is to Brooklyn: small. Sanitation's budget is $542 million; the police budget is $2.1 billion. Sanitation employees number about 10,000 people to the N.Y.P.D.'s 38,000, most of them officers. If economies are possible in Sanitation, just think of the prospects in the Police Department.
A police force of more than 30,000 officers sounds large. It is. But in fact, fewer than 11,000 are out fighting crime each day, unevenly distributed over three shifts. Why? Because duly trained cops are otherwise occupied. They are cleaning out horse stables, painting street barriers, mopping up police precincts, delivering mail, doing research, keeping logs, teaching other officers to drive or running the supply bureau.
DEALING with queries from the press takes 23 uniformed officers, and the City Council has found that uniformed officers spent 12,390 shifts in 1993 loading, unloading and ferrying police barriers to parades or demonstrations. "We were incredibly upset by this and anticipated a change," said the chairman of the Council's Finance Committee, Herbert E. Berman. "But change does not take place easily in the Police Department."
Certainly not without a push from City Hall. But so far, the Mayor has treated police officers like princes of the city (and princesses). Except for imposing a two-month delay in the starting date of classes at the Police Academy, he has protected the department, saying savings will come from the proposed merger of the housing and transit police with the N.Y.P.D. With even more cuts looming, the Mayor indicated this week that the department might have to tighten its belt but gave no details.
Critics keep pointing out that Mr. Giuliani need not lay off a single officer, or cut one penny out of the police budget, to make the department more efficient. "You can spend the same amount of money and provide more services," said Raymond D. Horton, the President of the Citizens Budget Commission, arguing for reforming the Police Department.
If he did that, though, Mr. Giuliani would risk the disapproval of his police friends -- staunch supporters during last year's mayoral campaign -- because police officers and their union resist the very changes that would save the most money. They are heatedly opposed to increasing the number of cars assigned to one officer instead of two; increasing the average number of days an officer works (200 a year, says the Budget Commission, including about 40 days spent in court, in training or doing paperwork), or letting lower-paid civilians take over safe and comfortable jobs so that more officers can go into the streets.
WHEN David N. Dinkins was Mayor, Police Commissioners Raymond W. Kelly and Lee P. Brown planned to hire many more civilians. But they couldn't afford it because, to get state funds for the Safe Streets, Safe City program, they locked themselves into an agreement with the Legislature to expand the uniformed force. That agreement has had the effect of preventing the hiring of civilians, and Mr. Giuliani contends it would be futile to try to renegotiate it. Nor does he or any other elected official show any inclination to try; hiring police officers is popular.
So police officers do jobs that don't require police training, because somebody has to. "There are jobs to be done," said former Commissioner Kelly. "If you don't have a body in civilian clothes, you're going to have a uniformed officer do it."
The city could hire more civilians, once funds from the new Federal crime law are appropriated. But Mr. Giuliani is considering making cuts in the Police Department's civilian ranks in the next round of budget reductions. If he does, then the money from Washington would only be substituting federally financed bodies for city-financed bodies. That would save city dollars but would not free more officers for crime-fighting.
Where does all this leave New Yorkers? With more police officers than ever -- but not any more on the streets. Then again, those streets may soon be more efficiently swept.

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI: SECURITY;
From the Shores of Haiti Into Hearts of the People

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAP-HAITIEN, Haiti, Sept. 21

 BODY:
A small drama unfolded this morning at the crowded main traffic circle here, where half a dozen United States marines stood sentry in two light armored tanks surrounded by concertina wire.
As two Haitian soldiers approached on foot, two M-16-toting marines in battle dress hopped down and walked to the edge of the wire. Haitians and Americans eyed each other in tense silence as the Haitian soldiers strode through the suddenly hushed crowd and up the road. As they left, a lusty cheer and waves of clapping suddenly erupted from the people. 
 "Before, the people were afraid of the Haitian soldiers and would have scattered when they came," explained Israel Lager, a 30-year-old handyman. "But the soldiers have no more importance now in front of the Americans."
Since a last-minute accord averted a United States invasion, American and Haitian security forces ostensibly have been partners in policing this impoverished country. But the people here in Haiti's second-largest city know that's just politics and window dressing. They view the 1,900 marines patrolling this northern coastal town as their saviors from years of state-sanctioned violence and their hope for a shot at democracy.
Late Tuesday night, a parade of Haitians trailed marine Humvees through the streets, celebrating the end of evening curfew. Marching along, they sang in Creole, "Chains that are binding us are loosening up."
In addition to lofty ideals, the people of Cap-Haitien have concrete needs they expect the Americans to deliver. The city has been without electricity, save a few generators, for more than a year. Prices for rice and cassava have more than tripled in that time. Justinien Hospital is desperately low on basic medicines, gauze, bandages and ambulances.
And just about everyone interviewed today in the slums near the airfield said he needed a job. "The Americans have come to fix our country," said Mr. Lager.
These high expectations have some marines worried. "They want everything now and all at once," Capt. Gregg Lyons, the grim-faced commander of F Company, Second Battalion, said as he looked anxiously at the swelling crowd outside a wire fence his troops erected at the airport entrance. "We'll do what we can. But I'm afraid if we don't deliver all they expect in the next few days, they'll turn angry."
Marines today sent a front-loader and a truck to scoop up some of the piles of stinking garbage and debris that block the rutted city streets. A medical survey team visited the hospital to promise delivery of 200 pallets of medicine and supplies from the amphibious ship Wasp offshore. And Col. Tom Jones, the Marine commander here, met with the president of the city's chamber of commerce and other civic leaders to find out what Cap-Haitien needs.
Residents throughout the city voiced their needs in interviews. Jean Diessel, 28, wants a job so he can build a house for his wife and five children and move out of the one-room apartment he now rents. Suzette Mondesir, 47, wants food prices to go down so she can afford to feed her three children more than a single midday meal of rice, beans and sugar cane. "I have no money to send my children to school, or even to buy clothes and shoes," she said, pointing to the worn sandals her 5-year-old daughter Genie, wore.
Many residents expressed hope the international economic embargo against Haiti would be lifted soon. Some signs indicated a change soon. Gasoline smuggled in from the Dominican Republic cost $30 for a one-gallon jug today, down from $40 a jug two days ago. Pierre Sem, a 29-year-old student, said the sanctions had crippled the job market. "If the embargo is over, I can get a job and pay for my law studies."
Some Haitian women see the marines as a one-way ticket out of the poverty most people here suffer. Along the airport's perimeter wire, an attractive young woman in a pretty white dress, blue shorts and small hoop earrings quietly handed a crumpled note to Ruddy Jean-Louis, a Navy dental technician who is one of 35 Creole-speaking interpreters assigned to Marine units here. Inside the note: her name (Anna) and her address. "I don't think these people know what democracy is, they just want a change," said Mr. Jean-Louis, who left Haiti 16 years ago as a child.
Most of the poorer people interviewed today said they supported the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, because he championed their cause. But wealthier residents were more skeptical and said it would be America's job to insure that Father Aristide reached out to all classes of Haitians and established a fair system of governing.
"If he comes back as a President of all Haitians, rich and poor, he'll be O.K.," said Rudy Stephan, a 42-year-old sugar cane plantation owner who attended Montclair State University in New Jersey and served in the United States Air Force as a radar operator from 1973 to 1977. "But if he appeals only to the masses, we will just be plunged into more chaos."

A group of Haitians gathered near the airport yesterday to watch marines fill sandbags to set up a defensive position. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Pataki Offers Welfare Plan; Critics Say It's Like Cuomo's

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
Continuing his efforts to define his candidacy for governor, State Senator George E. Pataki called yesterday for reducing the number of people on welfare by requiring more of them to work, penalizing welfare families whose children routinely skip school and creating an independent monitor for welfare fraud.
But while Mr. Pataki, a Republican from Putnam County, called his proposal a "dramatic" effort to "break the cycle of dependency," much of the plan called for speeding up or expanding policies that have already been proposed or put into effect by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, his three-term Democatic rival. 
 "It's good to know that he has accepted the Governor's agenda on welfare," said Michael J. Dowling, the State Commissioner of Social Services.
In a news conference in Manhattan, Mr. Pataki acknowledged that the state had instituted a range of welfare-to-work programs. But he contended that Mr. Cuomo had not pushed those programs aggressively, saying: "The record, I think, is quite clear. Welfare has gone up, but workfare has gone down."
Mr. Pataki released state statistics showing that since Mr. Cuomo took office in 1983, the percentage of childless, able-bodied welfare recipients in workfare, a state program to place welfare recipients in jobs with nonprofit or government agencies, has dropped from 34 percent to 14 percent. And the welfare caseload has risen by 300,000 to 1.6 million.
The Cuomo administration said Mr. Pataki's figures were misleading with a rising number of welfare recipients in educational and job-training programs that did not exist in 1982. Mr. Dowling said 38 percent of all childless, able-bodied welfare recipients are either working or enrolled in such educational programs.
The Pataki campaign began airing two commercials yesterday attacking Mr. Cuomo on welfare. "We must give people the skills they need to get off welfare," Mr. Pataki says. "But under Mario Cuomo welfare spending always goes up while workfare has gone down."
Mr. Cuomo's aides said the commercial was inaccurate because welfare spending was static throughout much of the 1980's, declined in one year and began to balloon only in the 1990's with the national recession.
Yesterday's events marked the second consecutive week that Mr. Pataki, who has been criticized by Mr. Cuomo for not detailing his positions on many issues, has coordinated the release of a policy paper with new television commercials. Both times, he has sought to underscore what he considers sharp differences between him and Mr. Cuomo.
But unlike last week, when Mr. Pataki called for term limits and citizen initiative -- proposals not supported by Mr. Cuomo -- this week's welfare proposal surprised some political analysts as being remarkably similar to Mr. Cuomo's own initiatives.
Some analysts said Mr. Pataki might have decided that proposing more sweeping changes -- like imposing time limits on welfare, something Mr. Pataki has endorsed in the past -- might alienate the large block of moderate voters who remain undecided in the race.
At his news conference, Mr. Pataki allowed two county executives who have advocated workfare, Andrew P. O'Rourke of Westchester and Raymond Meier of Oneida County, to speak almost as long as he did.
Mr. Pataki said he would encourage counties, which administer welfare programs, to increase workfare enrollment by requiring that the state pay part of the clerical costs involved in finding jobs and monitoring compliance. Under workfare, the state docks welfare payments for clients who fail to show up for work.
Mr. O'Rourke said the program has helped reduced welfare rolls in Westchester by 15,000 since 1989.
Under the Pataki plan, a tax credit for low-income families scheduled to be phased in by 1997 would take full effect by 1995. In June Mr. Pataki voted against the state budget that included that tax credit, saying the budget called for too much spending and not enough tax cuts.
Mr. Pataki would also seek Federal approvals to require welfare families to keep their children in school or face a cut in their welfare grants -- a plan the Cuomo administration is already pursuing.

HEADLINE: Supermarket Invests in Harlem, Long Shunned by Chains

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
For years, residents in inner-city neighborhoods like Harlem, Jamaica and East New York complained that the giant supermarkets that serve the suburbs and wealthier parts of the city had shunned their neighborhoods, forcing them to shop in overpriced and understocked bodegas and other small stores.
But in an unusual retail program to be announced today, a nonprofit community development group has collected $24 million from 10 major corporations to help finance a proposed 53,000-square-foot Pathmark store on 125th Street in East Harlem as well as similar stores in inner-city neighborhoods across the country. 
 The program, organized by the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a community development group started by the Ford Foundation, is intended to use private money to build supermarkets in low-income neighborhoods, giving the investors a stake in the stores.
Details of the Harlem project, which is expected to be built on a city-owned site between Lexington and Third Avenues, are still being completed.
But Stan Sorkin, a spokesman for the Supermarkets General Corporation, the Woodbridge, N.J., company that operates Pathmark supermarkets, said that he expected construction to begin in the first half of 1995 and that the supermarket would open within two years.
The company expects the supermarket to employ about 250 people.
In addition to the Harlem project, the community development group expects the corporate fund to provide start-up money for two supermarkets in the South Bronx and one in Newark. The other cities intended to receive the retail investment money are Los Angeles, Chicago, Miami, Washington, Kansas City, San Diego, Houston, Philadelphia, Boston, Phoenix, Seattle and San Francisco.
The initial investment of $24 million will come from 10 corporations, including Prudential, G.E. Capital, Bank of America, Home Savings of America and J. P. Morgan. Officials say the program is expected to produce 2,000 permanent jobs across the country in the first two years.
The effort will provide community developers with initial financing as well as low-interest loans for up to 30 percent of the development costs. The balance will be provided by conventional bank loans or investments from retailers.
In the case of the Harlem project, the money is expected to go to the development arm of the Abyssinian Baptist Church and the Community Association of East Harlem Triangle, which would build the store and lease it to Pathmark.
In return for their money the corporate investors are expected to earn 10 percent annually over a 10-year period. But beyond the investment, there is a public relations value, since many of the nation's top corporations have been accused of ignoring the inner city in their investments.
Charles Rinehart, chairman and chief executive of Home Savings of America, said the company's involvement in the program was part of a continuing investment in inner-city neighborhoods.
"As an S.& L. we have a tradition of making long-term loans in inner city neighborhoods," Mr. Rinehart said. "This investment is part of our commitment to the neighborhoods we serve. It gives a stake in the communities in central cities where we have been lending for 25 years. It is important to make as many people as possible part of the economy."
Officials of the development group declined to discuss specifics of the Harlem project, but a person familiar with the negotiations said $4 million of the $24 million fund would go to the 125th Street project, which is expected to cost $12 million. A city official said the developers were seeking the rest of the financing.
Supermarket chains have often refused to do business in low-income, inner-city neighborhoods. They said the difficulty of finding suitable sites, the high cost of security and the poverty of residents made such investments risky.
As a result, consumer advocates say, residents must make do with poorly stocked stores offering low-quality, overpriced food. Prices in local stores can be 50 percent higher than the cost of the same items in stores in middle-income neighborhoods.
Over the years, several attempts to attract major supermarket chains to Harlem have failed. Pathmark has been negotiating with the city and various community groups in Harlem for more than three years to try to open a store on 125th Street.
But Paul S. Grogan, president of the community development group, said that the success of two supermarkets in which Pathmark has invested, in Newark and in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, demonstrated that inner-city supermarkets can be profitable.
The Brooklyn supermarket, a 44,000-square-foot store that opened as part of the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Project in 1978, has annual sales of $25 million.
Those success stories, Mr. Grogan said, usually follow years of complicated negotiations and require a patchwork of financing sources.
Mr. Grogan said the retailers who have been profitable in such neighborhoods have discovered that while incomes are lower than in other neighborhoods, the population density increases the buying power in these communities.
Ellen C. Weiman, a spokeswoman for the New York City's Economic Development Corporation, the agency negotiating the supermarket deal for the city, said the Abyssinian Development Corporation and its partner are completing the public review process and arranging for the rest of the financing for the project.
Ms. Weiman said the Harlem project was part of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's neighborhood retail program.

HEADLINE: Pessimism Takes Hold On Wall St.

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
A quickening pessimism, based on recent economic data, has suddenly soured the mood on Wall Street and sent stock and bond prices sharply lower.
Many traders say the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates as soon as Tuesday, when the Fed's policy-making committee meets, battering both stocks and bonds just three days before the end of a problematic third quarter. 
 Yesterday, in the second consecutive day of sharp decline, the stock market gave up another 17.49 points on the Dow Jones industrial average to close at 3,851.60. Since Monday, the Dow has dropped 85 points. Indeed, if the market had closed at 3 P.M., instead of 4 P.M., the Dow would have been clocked at a 115-point fall for two days.
During the next few days, traders are likely to trim stock prices further in advance of the Fed meeting, analysts say.
What had steadied the financial markets in the last month, and helped rally the Dow to near its all-time high of 3,978.36, was a shaky assumption: that both economic growth and inflation were contained well enough that the Fed would forgo a sixth increase in short-term interest rates, at least until after the November elections.
"There was a naive belief that the Fed wouldn't have to tighten," said Dennis Jarrett, chief market analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company. "That naivete has been shattered."
John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, added, "The midsummer night's dream that the U.S. was in for a period of moderate economic growth with no inflationary pressures has evaporated."
Trading was heavy yesterday at more than 355 million shares on the New York Stock Stock Exchange, almost 24 percent more than this year's daily average of 287 million shares. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 1.90 points, to 461.46. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 6.03 points, to 760.71.
Unlike Tuesday's fall, which was deepened by high-speed, computer-guided trading of large blocks of stocks, yesterday's decline showed little such trading and signaled a genuine shift in market sentiment.
Stock and bond traders trace the change in mood to an unexpectedly high Producer Price Index on Sept. 9, indicating higher inflation to come. The Consumer Price Index on Sept. 13 did not surprise the market, only because Wall Street analysts hastily revised their estimates to reflect the producer figure.
Subsequent economic data, including factory use and Tuesday's trade-deficit figures, further darkened the outlook.
The Dow, S.& P. 500 and Nasdaq composite index all fell sharply until 3 P.M. The Dow, for example, dropped more than 47 points. But in the last hour, prices lifted a bit and the Dow closed down less than 18 points.
"People are always worried about another crash," said Thomas Gallagher, head of equity trading at Oppenheimer & Company. "So they sold stocks for most of the day. But when they saw that prices weren't falling, they started buying again."
The event preceding yesterday's decline was a prediction by Wayne D. Angell, a former Fed governor, that his old colleagues would raise the Fed's target for the Federal funds rate and the discount rate by half a percentage point each on Sept. 27. But it was unclear whether traders were reacting to Mr. Angell's remarks or Mr. Angell was simply saying out loud what Wall Street was already thinking.
The target for the Federal funds rate, which is the interest on overnight loans between banks, is 4.75 percent, up from 3 percent in February, when the Fed started raising interest rates. The discount rate, which is the rate charged on the Fed's loans to banks, is 4 percent, up from 3 percent in February.
The forecast by Mr. Angell, now an economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, hit the news services about 10 minutes before the New York Stock Exchange opened at 9:30 A.M. Bond traders, already nervous from Friday's sour bond market, immediately bid down fixed-income prices. The drop in bonds helped snuff out a small gain in the Dow and S.& P. 500, and a flat opening in Nasdaq stocks.
Bond yields are now at their highest level in more than two years and have become an even more attractive place for investors to place their money, analysts say. The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.80 percent yesterday, from 7.77 percent. As bond yields near 8 percent, they are almost triple the 2.86 percent dividend yield of the S.& P. 500.
After coming tantalizingly close to exceeding their record highs last week, the leading stock indexes are now 3 to 6 percent or so away from their highs for the year. The Dow's high point for the year was 3,978.36, on Jan. 31. The S.& P. 500's high was 482, on Feb. 2, and the Nasdaq's peak was 803.93, on March 18.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.20 points, to 254.71, with advancing stocks lagging behind declining stocks by 1,586 to 642. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 3.38 points, to 454.77.
Of the 30 component stocks of the Dow industrials, 20 fell, led by Caterpillar, which dropped 1 1/4, to 54 1/8. Of the 500 component stocks of the S.& P. 500, 309 fell, led by General Motors, which dropped 1 1/8, to 48 5/8.
The most active stock, with 5.6 million shares traded, was Digital Equipment, which rose 1 1/8, to 29, after an analyst for Cowen & Company reiterated his reassessment to "strong buy," from "neutral."

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI: CRITIC;
Former U.N. Envoy Deplores Haiti Accord

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The former United Nations envoy to Haiti, Dante Caputo, who resigned his position last week, said today that he had grave concerns over the last-minute Haitian-American accord that allows the Haitian military to remain in the Caribbean nationas United States troops arrive.
In interviews with local and international news organizations here this week, Mr. Caputo, a former Foreign Minister of Argentina, has assailed the Clinton Administration for failing to obtain written assurances that Haiti's military leaders will leave the country. 
 Without such an agreement, Mr. Caputo said, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras will not leave Haiti, and once he steps down the military leader will build a political force with Haiti's ruling class, leaving most of the country's current military and economic power base intact.
"As written, it is an unbelievable agreement, and I don't like it," Mr. Caputo said in a telephone interview from his home here. "How can you accept the idea that those guys will leave quietly without that being specified. It's so weak that the agreement could become a danger."
Under the agreement, negotiated Sunday by former President Jimmy Carter and General Cedras, the military leaders promised to resign by Oct. 15 and allow exiled President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to return to power. While the military leaders did not agree in principle to leave Haiti, Mr. Carter has said that such a departure was understood.
"Cedras will not budge," Mr. Caputo told the DYN news agency here.
As part of the United Nation's special mission charged with resolving the Haitian crisis, Mr. Caputo was the architect of the 1993 Governors Island agreement on Haiti, under which the military leaders agreed to step down last October. But they reneged.
"I'm not upset, and I don't think this is a slap in the face to the Governors Island agreement, but they got a much weaker agreement with 60 military planes in the air than we got at the negotiating table on an island," Mr. Caputo said in the telephone interview.
Mr. Caputo resigned his post at the United Nations in a letter to the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, that was made public on Monday. "The events of the last days show that the Haitian question has changed its nature," Mr. Caputo said in the letter.
"In effect the total absence of consultation and information from the United States Government makes me believe that this country has in fact taken the unilateral decision of acting on its own in the Haitian process," he added.
As a result, Mr. Caputo said that he felt he no longer had a role to play in the negotiations. Mr. Caputo said that Mr. Boutros-Ghali had asked him to reconsider his resignation but that he had declined.

HEADLINE: Groark Joins Connecticut Election Fray

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn. Sept. 20

 BODY:
After sitting on the sidelines during the Republican and Democratic primary campaigns, Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark, the nominee of A Connecticut Party, took center stage today in the first debate among the five gubernatorial candidates.
While her four opponents provided examples of the state's economic malaise, Ms. Groark, who has spent the summer impatiently listening to criticism of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker's administration, dismissed it as the talk of desperate candidates willing to say anything to get elected. 
 "We are in the midst of an economic recovery, ladies and gentlemen," she told about 450 business leaders at the Sheraton Hotel in Stamford, and then rattled off a string of measures -- balanced budgets, the creation of about 13,400 new jobs in the last year and strong bond ratings from Standard & Poor's -- as proof.
She later added, "Don't listen to the easy talk you can hear from the candidates who want to be elected," and urged voters to be "careful about what they hear," referring to what she called inflated job-loss statistics in a commercial for her Republican opponent, John G. Rowland.
Her assertions about the state's economic turnaround set Ms. Groark apart from the field in a debate in which all the candidates tried to stake out positions to distinguish themselves. And in a freewheeling five-way debate with its share of backbiting, clear differences emerged on taxes, crime and school desegregation.
The 75-minute debate, sponsored by the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association, included State Comptoller William E. Curry Jr., the Democratic candidate; Tom Scott, a former Republican state senator who is running on the Independence Party line; Joseph Zdonczyk of the Concerned Citizens Party; Mr. Rowland, a former Republican congressman, and Ms. Groark.
It is to be broadcast again on Saturday at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 6 P.M., as well as at 2:30 P.M. on Sunday on C-Span.
Many had expected Mr. Rowland, widely considered the front-runner in the race, to bear the brunt of the attacks in the debate, but little criticism was directed at him. Through much of the event, he appeared relaxed, without a jacket and in rolled-up sleeves, quipping that the job market was so bad that "you have five people running for the governor's job."
And Mr. Rowland, who has called for repealing the state income tax over five years, spent almost as much time talking about New Jersey and Massachusetts as Connecticut, in an attempt to place himself in the company of two other Republican Governors, Christine Todd Whitman and William Weld.
"There's been a lot of talk of cutting taxes, but most of it's been taking place outside the state of Connecticut," he said, noting that he recently met with Ms. Whitman to discuss her approach to cutting taxes, a program he said has brought 6,000 new jobs each month to that state.
In contrast, Mr. Rowland said, Connecticut has the third-highest tax burden in the nation, and spending has increased 23 percent over the last four years. "People of this state want to see what happened in Massachusetts and New Jersey," he said.
Mr. Scott, who entered the race largely because he believed Mr. Rowland was not committed enough to cutting taxes, questioned why Mr. Rowland had yet to provide a detailed tax plan. A former radio talk show host known for his conservative views, Mr. Scott was the only candidate in the debate to oppose the state's recent ban on assault weapons and also promised to fight any court order to desegregate Connecticut schools across town lines.
And he also referred to the American Civil Liberties Union as the "leading lobbying group for criminals."
Mr. Scott led the opposition to the income tax that Mr. Weicker pushed through, with Ms. Groark casting the tie-breaking vote in the State Senate. In the debate today, he accused her of "propagandizing" about the state's economy, said she had "massacred" the middle class and complained that she and Mr. Weicker had lied in the last campaign when they said they opposed an income tax.
While Mr. Curry, the Democrat, also offered his criticisms of the economy, he largely steered clear of the fray. He called for $800 million in property tax cuts and said the state should make small businesses the focus of its economic development efforts.
"There's a fundamental difference in the ideas here of what's wrong with the economy," he said. "Tom and John believe that the income tax destroyed it, and Eunice believes that it saved it." He argued that the property tax is the real problem.
After the debate, Mr. Curry said it felt as if he had "gotten the week off," as his candidacy was not the focus of the debate. Instead, he described it as a "turf battle among the three Republicans," including Ms. Groark, a former Republican, and Mr. Scott, along with Mr. Rowland.
And in a strange twist, Mr. Curry even complimented Mr. Rowland for his positions on two occasions.
Later when Mr. Curry ran out of his allotted time, Mr. Rowland remarked, "I'd be glad to give him some of my time, because he's said so many nice things about me today."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Owner of Arby's to Buy Long John Silver's Chain

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
In a merger of roast beef and popcorn shrimp, the Triarc Companies, the owner of Arby's Inc., will acquire Long John Silver's Restaurants Inc. for $525 million.
The deal will bring together Arby's, a chain of 2,800 outlets specializing in slow-roasted beef sandwiches, and the nation's largest fast-food fish and seafood chain, with about 1,450 units. Triarc will try to turn the acquisition into a venture that would be the most ambitious attempt at fast-food dual branding, the retailing of two separate brands from the same restaurant outlet. 
 "This will make the new combined Triarc No. 8 of the 100 largest restaurant chains, when it used to be 15th," said Ron Paul, president of Technomic Inc., a restaurant industry consulting firm in Chicago. "That's a big leap for them."
Analysts said it would be the largest merger of fast-food chains in recent years.
"It appears to be another good acquisition for Triarc," said Allan Kaplan, a securities analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company. "It gives them a bigger base, some potential synergies, economies of scale and more flexibility." Triarc, based in New York, is also the owner of the Royal Crown Cola Company.
Shares of Triarc fell 25 cents yesterday, to $15.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
"Multiple branding is the next wave in the restaurant business," Don Pierce, chief executive of the Triarc restaurant group, said in an interview.
He noted that "two-thirds of Arby sales volume is at lunchtime and one-third at dinner, and for Long John Silver's it's the reverse." He added, "This way there will be more customers in the units all day."
Mr. Pierce said that 1,000 Arby and Long John Silver's locations could be revamped as dual-restaurant outlets during the next three years. He will oversee both chains.
The attempt to dual-brand the Triarc restaurants will be "much watched," Mr. Paul of Technomic said, "to see if the franchisees will go along with the corporate plan, and to see if the synergy is correct."
An important question is whether the holders of Arby's and Long John Silver's franchises will agree to Triarc's dual-branding plans. According to Mr. Paul, 32 percent of Long John Silver's units are franchised, while 89 percent of Arby's are owned by franchise operators. The transaction will increase the number of Triarc's company-owned fast-food restaurants to about 1,300.
Pepsico Inc. has attempted to combine its Pizza Hut, Taco Bell and KFC units in some locations, but "for whatever reason, Pepsi hasn't rolled out combinations as much as had been expected, despite the synergies involved," Mr. Paul said. "It has worked in some places, but it hasn't been a major factor as far as chain expansion has been concerned."
Food-industry analysts say that the danger in dual-branding is that the identity of one or both brands could be negatively affected by the combination, or that a well-known, high-quality brand might be combined with a lower-quality, lesser-known chain.
Triarc said the total number of Arby's and Long John Silver's locations, including both franchises and company-owned outlets, would exceed 4,200 units and generate more than $2.5 billion in annual sales. The company said that in the 12 months that ended June 30, Long John Silver's generated revenue of about $640 million and operating cash flow of approximately $88 million. In the same period, Arby's generated $210 million in revenue to Triarc and $26 million in operating cash flow.
Long John Silver's offers menu items like Fish and More, a platter of fried fish, a hush puppy and cole slaw. Although its core product is fried fish, the chain has introduced some nonfried items, like baked fish platters and sandwiches.
Mr. Pierce of Triarc said the company had tested the dual-restaurant strategy in Fogelsville, Pa., for the last four months in a restaurant that combined Arby's and Long John Silver's outlets. "Sales went up in both restaurants," he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Fall on Fear Of Fed Move

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities sagged again yesterday, after a report of higher-than-expected housing starts for August and a prediction by a former Federal Reserve official that an increase in interest rates was imminent.
Wayne D. Angell, a former Fed governor who is chief economist for Bear, Stearns & Company, predicted that the Fed would raise interest rates by 50 basis points at the meeting next week of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-making body. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 Investors and traders are skittish not only because of Mr. Angell's knowledge of the Fed but also because if the prediction is accurate, the rate increase would come when the Treasury will be trying to sell $28.25 billion of new two- and five-year notes.
According to market analysts, a rate increase, or even the threat of one, makes it more difficult to sell the new securities and puts more downward pressure on prices.
Traders noted that economists at Goldman, Sachs & Company had said there was a better than 50-50 chance that the Fed would raise rates on Tuesday, when the open market committee is scheduled to meet.
The price of the 30-year bond dropped 11/32 , to 9617/32 , for a yield of 7.80 percent, up from 7.77 percent on Tuesday and the highest level since June 24, 1992, when it was 7.82 percent. Short-term interest rates, which would feel an increase first, rose sharply, with a three-month maturity up 18 basis points, to 4.79 percent, and a six-month issue up 10 basis points, to 5.17 percent.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist for the Money Fund Report in Ashland, Mass., said investors and traders took the path of least resistance, which was to sell. "It didn't make any difference what the news was today," he said. "Just as long as the news was not profoundly good, they sold."
Mr. Frank said the Government's housing data should have had a positive influence on bonds, because much of the gain in housing starts was influenced by a strong rise in multifamily units.
"Multifamily start numbers are a wild card and behave similarly to food and energy components, which bounce around a lot," Mr. Frank said. "The important thing is that single-family starts, which make up about 80 percent of new housing construction, dropped 2.7 percent. Permits were up, but I don't think they are great leading indicators."
The bond market should have accepted the data as good news, but instead was focused on the Fed and the next rate increase, even though there is no context for one. "All it took was for some 'authority' to tell the market that the Fed is about to raise rates, and it sold off," Mr. Frank said. "It appears that the lemmings are still running."
Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said she saw the housing numbers as a prelude to a moderation of housing activity.
As for another rise in rates, Mr. Frank said: "I think the Fed needs more data, and needs the employment report for September. I don't think it will act before November. All of the data up to now point to a slowing of the economy, and under those conditions the case for Fed tightening does not exist. I for one am baffled by Mr. Angell's view."
Housing starts rose 2.1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.44 million, slightly higher than the 1.4 million that was expected. Permits showed an unexpected gain of 1 percent, to 1.35 million.
The market tried briefly yesterday morning to extend Tuesday afternoon's rebound, but the selling pressure was too great. Firmer European bond markets and a stable dollar lent the market some support.
Market analysts said that with two- and five-year note auctions next week increasing supply, and with the Fed's credibility again coming into question, the upside of yesterday's market was very limited.
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's sale of new Treasury notes, the two-year issue was being offered at a price to yield 6.53 percent, while the five-year issue was being offered at a price to yield 7.23 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Stays Flat as Dealers Monitor Trade Negotiations

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed yesterday as dealers took a wait-and-see attitude toward trade negotiations between the United States and Japan.
The dollar eked out a small gain against the Japanese yen, a day after falling close to its postwar low on an unexpected widening of the United States trade deficit. In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 97.75 yen, from 97.65 yen on Tuesday. 
 Currency dealers largely ignored more warnings that the United States would take punitive action against Japanese exports if the two countries failed to reach an agreement on Government contracts, part of broader trade talks.
Market participants fear a breakdown of the talks, which are seen as crucial to limiting the steady flow to Japan of dollars that must be sold for yen. That selling erodes the value of the dollar.
"All eyes are on the trade talks, but the market is becoming wary of jumping at every pronouncement out of Washington and Tokyo," said Dave Glowacki, senior trader at NBD Bank in Detroit. "We've seen enough hot air. The market wants something concrete one way or the other. Until that's resovled there aren't going to be any big movements. "
Margaret Kudarauskas, an analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said reports of dollar buying by the Bank of Japan and big United States investors may also have made dealers hesitant to push the currency to a new low.
The Japanese central bank is seeking to slow the rise of the yen, which has hurt Japan's exporters by making their products more expensive abroad and stymied the country's recovery from a protracted economic slump.
The German mark weakened broadly against other Euroepan currencies amid uncertainty about federal elections in Germany next month and a reported slowdown in German money supply growth. But that weakness failed to bolster the dollar, which fell to 1.5468 marks, from 1.5520 marks on Tuesday.
"Today was a day of pausing," said Robert Ryan, a vice president at the Bank of New York. "People are trying to figure out where the dollar is going to end up."
In other currency trading in New York yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.2830 Swiss francs, down from 1.2868 on Tuesday; 5.2850 French francs, down from 5.3045, and 1,563 Italian lire, up from 1,561. The British pound rose to $1.5785 from $1.5735.

HEADLINE: ON COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
At Michigan, a Return Fraught With Risk

BYLINE: By Malcolm Moran 

DATELINE: ANN ARBOR, Mich.

 BODY:
Barring unforeseen complications between now and Saturday, we can expect Tyrone Wheatley to make a dramatic entrance onto the biggest football stage of any campus in America this week. At some point during the game between Michigan and Colorado that has suddenly attracted the hot lights, the preseason favorite for the Heisman Trophy should take his rehabilitated right shoulder onto the field at Michigan Stadium and become a factor. There will be little margin for error.
When Wheatley, the Michigan tailback, made his surprising and inspiring decision last January to postpone his first check from a National Football League team, earn a degree in education and a chance at a Heisman and remain a part of the student economy, this week was a nearly inevitable part of the plan. 
 In no other college sport does the playoff process begin so soon, in this case before the leaves here turned yellow and before Wheatley turned a corner. If Chris Webber had chosen to remain with Michigan basketball's Fab Five last winter, would there have been any urgency behind a return from an injury for an early-season game against, say, Duke?
The Wolverines benefit from the support of more than 100,000 football fans every time they open the doors. They occupy a spotless complex with state-of-the-art whistles and bells. They have also inherited the legacy of a program that, for all its excellence, last won a national championship 46 years ago.
That is the spot Wheatley will walk into at some point after "The Victors" is played for the first of who-knows-how-many times. Colorado's unexpected trashing of Wisconsin last Saturday night, in part a result of a punishing defensive front, turned Wheatley's speed and power into an even more precious commodity and made his personal spotlight that much hotter. The pros, as they wait for the opportunity to poke at his shoulder and any other vulnerable joints behind closed doors next winter, will examine his response to a physical setback. The selectors of Heisman candidates du jour will determine whether to place a star next to his name or take one down.
Wheatley could have been playing against the Arizona Cardinals, for serious money. Instead, if everything goes right and Michigan goes to the Rose Bowl, Wheatley may have to deal with the Arizona Wildcats for free.
And if everything does not go right, there will be the inevitable question: Did he make the right decision?
"Right decision?" Wheatley said when the subject was raised again after practice on Tuesday. "What was wrong? I didn't do anything wrong. I'm here. I'm graduating next May. Because my shoulder's hurt, if I don't win the Heisman or any other award, does that say my career is over now? No."
His decision cannot be declared right or wrong after the fact, because the risk was understood from the start. The all-America receiver J. J. Stokes returned to U.C.L.A., bruised a quadricep, and was temporarily reduced to a nonfactor. But before the decisions of Wheatley and Stokes can be debated, Gary Moeller, the Michigan coach, asks a question: "How much would your grandfather, or my grandfather, or any older people that went to college, after they had millions of dollars, sell their last two years of college for?"
The cynical response is that the head coach of an elite-level program is hardly an appropriate spokesman for the value of a big-time player's educational future. But unlike those self-serving coaches who insist they would never play an injured athlete if he tells me he can't play, the coach of the Wolverines appears to be accepting responsibility. Moeller said he has been told Wheatley's separated shoulder has healed. He also said a positive diagnosis is not enough.
"If he says, 'I want to do it,' then I'm going to say O.K., and I'm going to watch him hang on to a football," Moeller said. "I'm going to watch him do those things. I'm going to go back to the doctors. I'm going to see how strong and how physical he is in practice. See, the thing you can't do is send a kid out there with one injury, and he protects that and gets another one. That's why you've got to know as a coach. For the team, he can't lose the ball. For him, he can't receive another injury."
For both, a rare talent and a team pointed toward Pasadena, the risks are as great as the hopes. "You really don't know until you get in there and somebody lights your tree up," Moeller said. The first of many tree-lighting ceremonies will take place Saturday afternoon. Until then, Wheatley is apparently somewhere in that football nether world, an odd, temporary stop that occurs when an injury has healed but the athlete has not yet become productive.
The immediate results of a hoped-for Heisman season are simple: No pain, no gains.
