HEADLINE: A Film Maker and the Art of the Deal

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Lawrence Bender has, without question, the smallest office of any big-time producer in Hollywood. It's a windowless and cramped space, with a rental desk and couple of movie posters tacked onto a wall. And Mr. Bender doesn't limit his frugality to the workplace. When the 36-year-old producer flies to New York, his hometown, to make a film, he sleeps on sofas in his friends' apartments.
"Someone said to me: 'Don't they put you up in a hotel? Why are you sleeping on people's couches?' " he said. "And I say: 'You don't understand. "They" is "me." ' Instead of spending $10,000 on a hotel, I could get another crew person. I can't get away from the fact that I want to put everything in the movie." 
 Mr. Bender's latest project is "Pulp Fiction," directed and written by his friend Quentin Tarantino. A violent and often comic drama inspired by the lurid crime fiction of the 1930's and 40's, it was the winner of this year's Palme d'Or at the Cannes International Film Festival. With an ensemble cast that includes John Travolta, Bruce Willis, Uma Thurman, Harvey Keitel, Christopher Walken and Samuel L. Jackson, it will open the New York Film Festival on Friday, and arrive at theaters on Oct. 14.
"Pulp Fiction" is one of three films produced this year by Mr. Bender. The others are "Fresh," an urban drama that opened last month to generally positive reviews, and "Killing Zoe," about a Paris bank heist. His first movie was the 1992 cult hit "Reservoir Dogs," also written and directed by Mr. Tarantino. The film cost $1.5 million, and has grossed $20 million worldwide. It also established Mr. Tarantino as an director of significance.
Now, as part of a new wave of film makers whose idiosyncratic tastes and sensibilities have seized the attention of the Hollywood establishment, Mr. Bender, a onetime ballet dancer and a sometime actor, and Mr. Tarantino, have been sought out by many studios.
Except for a loose arrangement with Miramax, a division of the Walt Disney Company, however, the two have steered clear of any involvement with a studio that would erode their independence.
Characteristically, Mr. Bender's next two films carry an individual stamp. One of them, "White Man's Burden," starring John Travolta and directed by Desmond Nakano, depicts a racially charged world in which blacks are a powerful majority while whites are a poor, unemployed, powerless minority. The other, "Four Rooms," involves a bellman in a Los Angeles hotel who moves from room to room and copes with four totally disparate couples. "Each couple is crazier than the next," said Mr. Bender. The film has four different directors, one of whom is Mr. Tarantino.
Mr. Bender, a casual and friendly man who speaks with an unmistakable New York accent, has an obvious talent for raising money and financing movies. But he plays it down in favor of his esthetic side.
"I hate to say I'm a creative type because it sounds so funky," he said. "But because of my background I look at movies differently than other producers. I look for things with movement and character and color."
Still, there are other personal satisfactions. "What I like about producing," he said, "is the feeling you have when you get the money and make the deal. Making the deal is like the thrill of victory. It's empowering."
How he turned into a deal maker, after years in New York as a struggling actor and dancer, amazes him. "I had, like, six call-backs for 'Cats,' " he said with a laugh. "Didn't make it."
He was born in the Bronx and brought up in New Jersey, the child of parents who were teachers and later became psychotherapists. He earned a degree in civil engineering at the University of Maine, but his heart was in dancing. He won a scholarship to the Louis Falco dance troupe and supported himself by working as a flamenco dancer. A series of injuries ended his dance career and he turned to acting.
"I was a triple threat," he said. "I was a dancer, singer and actor. But I was threatening nobody."
He moved to Los Angeles in the early 1980's to pursue his acting career, worked for three years in various film production jobs and decided the only way he would ever act was to produce a movie and put himself in it.
After meeting several friends, among them the director Scott Spiegel (who later was co-author of "The Rookie") and Boaz Yakin (who directed "Fresh"), Mr. Bender began eking out a living producing horror films that went straight to video. (One of them is the video cult favorite "The Intruder.")
In 1990 he met Mr. Tarantino, who had been struggling for years to have one of his scripts produced. Mr. Tarantino gave Mr. Bender a screenplay about a bank robbery gone awry. It was called "Reservoir Dogs."
"He had written it in three and a half weeks, and it was amazing," said Mr. Bender. "The dialogue was incredible. I told him I could raise money for this. He didn't know I'd never raised money for anything."
A Texas businessman vowed to help out. But then Mr. Bender had a stroke of luck: "My acting teacher, Lilly Parker, read the script and asked me if there was one actor in the world I'd want in this movie. I told her Harvey Keitel. And she knew him."
Within a week Mr. Keitel had phoned Mr. Bender to tell him he wanted to appear in "Reservoir Dogs." Mr. Bender said: "I had two very different feelings. One was that this was the most exciting thing in my life. I was going to make a real movie, something special. At the same time, I knew that once Harvey was in, it was going to be a bigger movie than I thought and it would somehow be impossible for me to be in it as an actor. It was complete elation and sadness. I was going to have to put off this part of myself."
The bulk of the cost of "Reservoir Dogs" was paid by Live Entertainment, a video company that a friend of Mr. Bender's, the director Monte Hellman, persuaded to back the film.
Although several top actors sought roles in "Pulp Fiction," Mr. Bender and Mr. Tarantino insisted on casting Mr. Travolta, whose career had not flourished in recent years.
"People said, 'John Travolta, you're kidding, you can get any actor in the world,' " he recalled. "We said John was the bottom line. People didn't understand why we didn't want to use a superstar. But John was the guy Quentin wanted."
Ultimately, though, in casting Mr. Travolta as well as Bruce Willis, Harvey Keitel and and Uma Thurman in "Pulp Fiction," Mr. Bender received the full cooperation of the top talent agencies in Hollywood -- Creative Artists Agency, International Creative Management and William Morris -- who are generally adverse to placing high-priced performers in risky, inexpensive movies. The film cost $8.5 million.
"Harvey Keitel said that as long as you're being fair, then actors will work for any amount of money," Mr. Bender said. "Everyone was treated the same. There was no star with one big trailer. There was no star, except the movie." Most of the actors received relatively small salaries along with a percentage of the profits.
Mr. Bender has lived for several years in an apartment in Hancock Park, a stolid Los Angeles community, with Joelle Bentolila, a French writer. He said that he was still not sure how his career would evolve, and remained uncertain whether he would remain a producer or try to return to acting, or even seek another career outside movies. But leaving the movie business seems, at this point, improbable.
"Many times people write scripts because they want to write a screenplay, not because there's anything they need to say," he said. "And I want to make movies with people who need to say something, whether it's a political statement or a pure cinematic statement. I want to make movies that come from some inner being. And those are hard to find."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lawrence Bender, producer of the film "Pulp Fiction," on the roof terrace of his Hollywood apartment house. (Marissa Roth for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: GIULIANI WEIGHING FURTHER CUTBACKS AS COSTS ESCALATE

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Only three months after the city balanced a $31.6 billion budget with sharp spending cuts, the Giuliani administration is struggling with a further gap that city officials say will require another round of cuts that could reach $800 million.
To fill the gap, the administration has embarked on a high-gear search for spending cuts, agency consolidations and work-force reductions that could include as many as 7,000 layoffs. Administration officials said Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wants to use severance offers as much as possible to soften new rounds of personnel reductions. 
 The full scope of the reductions will be decided by Mr. Giuliani over the next few weeks, city officials said. They would come on top of the $1.1 billion in spending cuts and 15,000 job reductions already called for in the budget, which took effect on July 1. Officials say the extent of the fiscal problems will be clearer at the end of the month, when the first-quarter tax receipts are counted.
Mr. Giuliani, in recent days, has been setting the stage for dramatic steps. He has crusaded against his own government and portrayed himself as the leader who will tame it. "The city is doing what it traditionally does," he told an audience of Wall Street bankers and lawyers on Wednesday. "The city is attempting to spend more money than we planned to spend and this is why we're making cuts."
Some of the emerging fiscal difficulties are beyond the control of city officials, most notably the Wall Street slump that suggests that tax receipts will come in below what had been anticipated.
But fiscal monitors, who warned in July of risky budget assumptions, say the budget agreement between Mr. Giuliani and the City Council was also based in large part on high hopes of how much help the state and Federal governments would provide and how efficient the city government could be.
Already, for example, there has been a surge in overtime, particularly in the uniformed services dealing with Mr. Giuliani's law-enforcement crackdown. City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi reported this week that the Correction Department had spent $7.7 million in overtime by August, 144 percent more than in the corresponding period last year.
The city had also counted on receiving $150 million from the Federal health-care initiatives that stalled in Congress. And it had assumed the State Legislature would approve two crucial pieces of legislation: one relieving the city of $45 million in costs by setting a cap on legal settlements and another allowing the city to consolidate fee collections in one agency, which had been projected to increase revenues by $25 million. The Legislature adjourned without acting on the two proposals.
"There's only one reason they're in this hole again and that is, for better or for worse, the Mayor and the Council decided to do half the problem at the time the budget was adopted and do the rest later," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group financed by businesses.
Mr. Giuliani's budget director, Abraham M. Lackman, yesterday stoutly defended the decision to include the aid assumptions in the budget. He noted that Mr. Giuliani had inherited a $2.3 billion deficit in January and had had to come up with a plan that was palatable to the City Council.
"We recognized that in putting together a plan like this and being able to get a political consensus that we were going to have to take some risks and we recognized that up front," he said.
He added: "We are recognizing these risks very early on. The Mayor is trying to stay ahead of the curve."
Mr. Giuliani first ordered agencies in July to recommend 2.6 percent in across-the-board budget cuts and contingency plans for further spending reductions of 2.2 percent. Administration officials now believe that the full 4.8 percent reduction, or $450 million in spending cuts, will be needed -- and possibly as much as $800 million in cuts.
Mr. Lackman and other fiscal analysts said the most troubling sign for the city was the slowdown in the financial-services industry. While city officials say Wall Street represents only 4 percent of the city's employment base, it constitutes 14 percent of the wage base and can have a broad effect on the city's tax revenues. In addition, Mr. Lackman said a falloff in profits on Wall Street could also hurt the state's tax collections. "Generally, that becomes a risk to the city," he said.
Other analysts said the national economy was starting to slow, which would be a double blow to the city, which has lagged behind the rest of the nation in coming out of the last recession.
Since last weekend city commissioners have been scrambling to find new ways to make savings. They are to report back to the Mayor this weekend.
The Human Resources Administration, which handles the city's vast array of social programs, has been told by the administration that it may have to offer severance packages to a new round of 2,700 employees and cut an additional 3,000 workers through layoffs unless it can come up with alternative savings, officials said. As of June the agency had 20,750 employees.
The agency already lost 2,500 workers through an earlier severance program offered by the city and the redeployment of some of its workers to the agency for the homeless. The staff cuts have already led to a rise in caseloads for social workers who monitor child abuse.
Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that it was premature to predict what would happen at the agency. "As we found earlier this year and as you find throughout the history of this city, some of the cuts you become concerned about don't happen and some of the cuts that do happen people are surprised about," he said. "So we might as well react to the decisions we actually make."
With the city facing multibillion-dollar deficits for several more years, and the Republican Mayor adamantly opposed to tax increases, a growing number of officials say the city must move away from across-the-board budget cuts and start determining which services it can no longer provide.
Peter J. Powers, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, said agencies had been asked to assess what their core functions are, and what are nonessential services.
Mr. Hevesi, the City Comptroller, who is a Democrat, said he was considering ways to start a public debate on city priorities.
"We've come to a point where if you consider cutting across the board, you end up providing lousy services to everybody," he said. "It may mean we have to start thinking about what our priorities are, what services we have to provide on an excellent basis and what services may have to be eliminated."

Companies
 Northrop Grumman will cut its work force by more than 18 percent, or 8,650 jobs, by the end of 1995, as the newly combined company seeks to adapt to a fast-consolidating arms industry. HEADLINE: Halting Cash for Cuba Is a Delicate Task

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Aida Perez looked like a Mardi Gras queen. A man's shirt draped her shoulders, her colorful skirt topped layers of other skirts. In one arm, she clutched a giant teddy bear, in the other a bag with several sausages.
To her friends and family in Cuba, she is a treasure trove. To the United States Customs officials here she is, potentially, a walking violation of the prohibition on sending cash to Cuba. 
 And since late August, when the restrictions took effect, travelers have presented customs officers with a challenge in duty and tact.
To make sure that returning Cubans -- who literally wear gifts to circumvent a 44-pound-per-person baggage limit -- do not take more than $100 in cash, the officers have had to ask some travelers to hoist their skirts or drop their pants. The extra skirts, pants, hats and teddy bears -- possible hiding places for contraband dollars -- have only complicated the procedure.
Mr. Clinton imposed the cash limit in August to punish Fidel Castro for encouraging refugees to leave Cuba, hoping to weaken an already shaky Cuban economy.
Some Cuban-Americans may circumvent the law by going to Cuba through third countries, but a spokeswoman for the Treasury Department's Foreign Assets Control Office, which oversees restrictions on travel to Cuba, said it was too early to tell how much money passes along other routes. "It is probably no more than a trickle," she said.
Meanwhile, customs officers here have had to look more closely at garments and undergarments of the Cubans returning to Cuba and the handful of Cuban-Americans still allowed to travel to the island.
This morning at 6 A.M., 152 passengers lined up for a once-a-week C & T Airlines flight to Havana, scheduled to depart at 10 o'clock. Customs officers told them they each were limited to $100 or, if they were Americans, $100 for each day they were staying in Cuba. Luggage was X-rayed and passengers were asked about the amount of money they were carrying. Any carry-on luggage was also searched. The process took five minutes for most of the passengers. C & T is one of three airlines authorized to fly charters into Cuba.
Mark Stump, who supervised the eight Customs officers, said the passengers had gotten the word about the money. Still, he noted, many were wearing several layers of clothes.
David Samora, a church musician who had been in the United States since July, stood quietly as an officer went through the dozens of small bundles of papers he had packed into one of two small suitcases. "I want to be honest," he shrugged. "I only have what is allowed."
A female officer opened up Mrs. Perez's teddy bear to reveal a stuffing of underpants and pantyhose for her children and grandchildren. Mrs. Perez was escorted to a closed room for a more thorough check. She emerged a short while later, slightly disheveled, her hat askew, apparently unperturbed. "No es nada," she said. "It's nothing."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: Washington Talk;
Both Parties Study the Lessons of '78

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Politicians in both parties remember well the last time there was a midterm election with a Democrat in the White House. It was 1978. Republicans from coast to coast promised tax cuts. The Democrats did not take them seriously.
The Republicans did not do so well that year, picking up only three seats in the Senate and 11 in the House. But the tax cut idea took hold. Two years later, Ronald Reagan rode it into the White House. Republicans won control of the Senate and gained 33 seats in the House. 
 So this year, Republican strategists have hearkened back to 1978 and have broken again with the custom that off-year elections are not national plebiscites, but merely 435 separate elections for the House and 35 or so for the Senate.
On Wednesday afternoon, 16 Republicans who are running for Democratic or open Senate seats gathered on the Capitol lawn and presented a seven-point plan that they promised to put into place if the G.O.P. wins control of the Senate on Nov. 8. Republican candidates for the House plan to offer a similar list on Tuesday.
Point No. 1 on both lists is a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget. With seeming shamelessness, other points include tax cuts and more money for the military. Spending reductions are not specified.
But unlike 1978, Democrats this year are not sitting on their hands. Instead, they launched a pre-emptive strike this week.
At lunch on Wednesday, before any announcement from the Republicans, top White House officials met with a couple of dozen reporters and columnists to denounce the Republican plans -- which they had not yet seen in any detail -- as fiscally irresponsible.
A few hours later, the White House invited a few reporters into the Roosevelt Room to hear the plans assailed again. Reaching for the kind of snappy phrase that might be remembered by voters, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, called the Republican plans "Voodoo II," a reference to George Bush's description of Ronald Reagan's economic proposals in the 1980 Presidential primaries as "voodoo economics."
Representative Vic Fazio of California, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, had a news conference at noon today on the Republican plans. They were nothing more, he said, mixing metaphors, than "generalized cotton candy without a bottom line."
Then this afternoon, at the instruction of the Democratic leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, senior Democrats on the Budget Committee called yet another news conference about what the Republicans were up to. "It looks like Reagan redux to me," said Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina.
At this point, the plan offered by the Republican candidates for the Senate consists of only three pages; the House proposal only one paragraph. But this time the Democrats swear they will not be caught by surprise.
"Unless we energize our people," said a Democratic strategist, "we'll be right back where we were in 1980."
With that in mind, Mr. Gephardt ordered a professional staff review of a proposal by Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas, to scrap the current income tax system, with its progressive rates and many deductions, and replace it with a flat tax of 17 percent on personal income and business profits. The proposal by Mr. Armey, who is one of the main Republican policy designers, is not part of the overall Republican plan to be offered next week. But it has, Mr. Gephardt observed, been discussed publicly by some columnists and academics.
"We can't just stand by when they come forward with such bad ideas," Mr. Gephardt said.
The staff review was somewhat inconclusive but found that under one interpretation, Mr. Armey's sketchy proposal would reduce Federal revenue by more than $200 billion a year. Mr. Armey shrugged off such a calculation as the work of a partisan staff.
What the Republicans are proposing does sound more than a little like Reaganomics -- lower taxes, higher military spending and promises of a balanced budget down the road. In the first Reagan term, as the Democrats have been pointing out over and over this week, the Federal deficit grew to well over $200 billion, from about $70 billion.
The Republicans favor a reprise nonetheless, believing that what Americans want most of all is a tax cut. And they are still convinced, despite the Reagan experience, that lower taxes will generate so much economic activity that revenue will actually rise.
Even if the Republicans win control of Congress in November, the theory cannot be tested right away, not so long as Bill Clinton is President and has a veto.
No matter. For the Republicans, 1994 is 1978; 1996 is 1980.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
Clinton Links Unpopularity To Voter Fear Of Shake-Ups

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Unable so far to say that his efforts to change the Government have made him popular, President Clinton is opening a string of pre-election political speeches by arguing the opposite: that his low popularity stems from a determination to shake things up, whatever the penalties.
Speaking at a Democratic dinner here, Mr. Clinton suggested on Wednesday night that his efforts to reduce the Federal deficit, increase global trade and rewrite foreign policy had not yet restored optimism about the future -- and about his Presidency -- because their very nature is to make the future less predictable. 
 And he acknowledged that the Republican Party had done a better job of exploiting people's fears than the White House had of allaying them.
That fear of change, he said, is "not right and it is not rational," and he asserted that his party had no choice but to tackle it head on.
"What we have to do is to make this election our friend," Mr. Clinton said. "We have to go home and say: 'Look, you know, we've done a lot of stuff up there. You may not have liked it all, but we're finally getting something done.' "
Those comments recall Mr. Clinton's repeated exhortation to voters during his 1992 campaign to "make change our friend." The implication then was that Democrats would improve Americans' lives by throwing out tired old ways while Republicans clung to the status quo.
On Wednesday, he seemed to concede that whatever the changes he had wrought, voters either had not yet grasped them or had been persuaded by the Republicans that they were not in the voters' interest. It was a theme that Mr. Clinton has struck in past speeches, most recently at a convention of Baptist ministers in New Orleans this month. But he has seldom been so blunt.
The President began by stating that he had run for office with "very little illusions about how the politics at the national level in this country had become so abstract, so rhetorical and so subject to distortion, so totally divorced from the real life experience of real Americans, that change had become very difficult indeed."
As he has before, he recited a list of positive developments, from peace in the Middle East to a tax cut for the poor, which he said have been widely ignored in the public's evaluation of the state of the nation.
"I ask you," he said, "if we have a good economy; if we face the challenges of trade and crime; if we have reached out to families who are trying to keep their families together and raise their kids with the family leave bill and by giving 15 million working families tax cuts; we've put on the table a welfare reform program that is both compassionate and tough -- why would anyone think there would be any problem?"
Answering his own question, Mr. Clinton suggested that the White House had failed to communicate its successes to some voters, and that others were simply unsettled by global economic changes that might affect their standard of living. Finally, he said that Republicans had taken advantage of both factors to persuade the public that the White House's policies are either ineffective or wrongheaded.
"They are still profoundly concerned that maybe if all this happened, it won't make a difference," the President said of the electorate. "They've been told for so long that government can't do anything but mess up a one-car parade, it's hard to imagine that what we do here can make a difference."
Nevertheless, Mr. Clinton said the prevailing view of government is wrong, citing the recent passage of anti-crime legislation as one example. And he said the Democratic Party's principal task in the midterm campaign would be to convince voters that this view is wrong.
The President will take that argument to New York and three Midwestern cities this weekend, in a round of fund-raising events for Democratic candidates, before he makes a speech at the United Nations on Monday.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton is arguing that the way for Democrats to succeed this fall is to confront people's fears about the changes he has made. He used the theme on Wednesday at a dinner of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee in Washington. (Agence-France Presse)

HEADLINE: Japanese Cabinet Approves Tax Cut as Economic Spur

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 22

 BODY:
In a move sought by the United States as well as businesses here, Japan's Cabinet tonight approved a long-stalled plan to cut income taxes in a bid to stimulate its puttering economy.
The immediate income tax cut will be compensated for by an increase in the sales tax to 5 percent from the current 3 percent. The raise will take effect in April 1997. The plan is expected to be approved by Japan's Parliament this fall. 
 The announcement, made by Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama, comes as the United States and Japan near the end of negotiations to reach trade agreements under a so-called framework accord signed last year.
Japan has been promising the United States that it would cut taxes to stimulate its economy, which theoretically would encourage Japanese consumers to buy more American products.
But the Japanese Government has changed twice since the beginning of the year and was unable until today to agree to more than a one-year tax cut, because of a dispute between Japan's Ministry of Finance and the Socialist Party of Mr. Murayama.
The Finance Ministry, which fears a growing national budget deficit, has insisted on offsetting any income tax cut by raising the consumption tax, as the sales tax is called here.
The Socialist Party has resisted an increase in the sales tax, viewing it as falling heaviest on people with lower incomes. But Prime Minister Murayama convinced his party today to accede to the sales tax rise by promising to allocate some of its revenues for social programs.
Washington has worried that the increase in the sales tax will dilute the impact of the income tax cuts. Partly because of that, the Government decided to postpone an increase in the sales tax until 1997.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Compuserve Backs Internet Leader

BYLINE: By LAURIE FLYNN 

 BODY:
Compuserve Inc., the nation's largest consumer on-line service, said yesterday that it would announce today an equity investment in a one-year-old spinoff of Novell Inc. that provides Internet publishing services to commercial customers.
The company, Network Publishing Inc. of Provo, Utah, is one of only a handful that have expertise in conducting business on the Internet. Compuserve will work with Network Publishing to help Compuserve's customers establish a presence on an area of the Internet known as the World Wide Web. Together, the companies will help Internet customers manage security, perform customer billing and handle customer support, according to James Hogan, director of product marketing at Compuserve. 
 "We share the same vision of where electronic publishing is going," Mr. Hogan said.
The Internet is a global web of more than 30,000 networks that are used by roughly 20 million people to exchange files and electronic mail. The strongest growth on the Internet is coming from exactly the kind of business that Network Publishing seeks: companies that view the Internet as a new and increasingly effective way to communicate with business partners and customers.
Officials of Compuserve, a division of H & R Block Inc. that is based in Columbus, Ohio, declined to detail the amount of the investment, which is part of Compuserve's overall strategy, announced last month, to provide a variety of Internet services to its customers. Mr. Hogan said that the investment "rounds out the spread of electronic publishing and Internet access we announced."
Compuserve already provides similar services to commercial customers that wish to maintain their own areas on Compuserve's network, Mr. Hogan said.
Given the explosive growth of the Internet, commercial on-line services like Compuserve have no choice but to change their business models or be left behind, said Mary Modahl, senior analyst of people and technology services at the Forrester Research Corporation in Cambridge, Mass. Whatever advantage they now possess will disappear within the next year and a half as the Internet becomes more commercialized and easier to use.
Network Publishing was founded last year by three former Novell executives: Richard Maw, who is president and chief executive; Richard Farr, who is vice president of development and engineering, and Michael Donahue, who is vice president of consulting services and marketing. The team had been responsible for Novell's Internet publishing activities, which included creating a presence, or "home page," for Novell on the World Wide Web.
Network Publishing, with a current staff of five, will maintain corporate independence from Compuserve. "It's the 10 guys in a garage mentality -- nimble and quick," Mr. Hogan said. "We don't want to do anything to subvert that." Compuserve will hold an unspecified number of positions on Network Publishing's board of directors.

HEADLINE: Clinton Warns Japan of Trade Sanctions

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
President Clinton bluntly warned Foreign Minister Yohei Kono of Japan today that if Tokyo did not reach agreements with the United States in the next week on opening Japanese markets, the Administration would consider imposing trade sanctions on Tokyo.
The President and the Foreign Minister met in the Oval Office for nearly an hour, accompanied by Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Vice President Al Gore and the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor -- a gallery of power players meant to underscore to the Japanese visitor how seriously the Administration takes this issue. 
 By talking tough on Japan, the White House was probably also sending a message to Congress. Taking a hard line against Tokyo is good politics for the Clinton Administration at a time when it is desperately trying to win Congressional approval for the new global free-trade accord, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Many Democrats are uneasy about voting in favor of the agreement and it is much easier for them to side with the Administration if the White House appears to be squeezing the Japanese at the same time it is asking Congress to approve another accord liberalizing trade.
Both Japanese and American officials said ideas were exchanged in talks throughout the day, but that there was still no breakthrough in the efforts to reach an agreement on opening Japan's markets in insurance, glass, autos, auto parts and government purchases of telecommunications and medical equipment.
The Clinton Administration has said it is prepared to impose economic sanctions on Japan, as provided under the Super 301 and Title VII provisions of American trade laws, if no agreement is reached by Sept. 30. Mr. Clinton reiterated that position today.
The President stressed "his firm commitment to opening Japanese markets to American goods and services," the White House said after the meeting with Foreign Minister Kono. "The President emphasized that unless agreements are reached under the framework agreement by the Sept. 30 deadline, he will have to consider remedies under U.S. trade laws," it said.
This virtually commits the President to adopt trade sanctions against Tokyo if the talks fail; otherwise, his own credibility on this issue will be shattered.
Currency speculators are monitoring the trade talks with Japan carefully for any indication of a breakthrough or a breakdown, according to market analysts. They say billions of dollars in bets are being placed in the world currency markets, with some traders expecting a breakthrough, which would strengthen the dollar, and others anticipating a breakdown, which would further weaken the American currency and strengthen the yen. Senior American officials intimately involved in the talks insist that the outcome at this point is uncertain.
This is the state of play in the talks, according to officials involved:
The two sides have ironed out virtually all the details of an agreement that would open Japan's relatively closed insurance market. They have reached substantial agreement on opening Japan's government procurement market. The Japanese have committed to the principle of a "significant" or "substantial increase" in Japanese government purchases of foreign medical equipment and telecommunications gear. But Tokyo is resisting linking that general commitment to some numerical indicators that would measure in a hard and fast way whether the Japanese are actually making substantial progress. The Americans want a specific link.
However, there is no progress on the market for automobiles and auto parts. And after signals that the Administration is preparing to impose sanctions on Japan in glass, where Japan has maintained an almost entirely closed market that freezes out all American glass makers, the Japanese side last night suddenly sent their senior glass negotiator from the Ministry of Industry and Trade in Tokyo to try to work out a deal with Washington.
A report on Japan trade was issued today by the Labor-Industry Coalition on International Trade, a coalition that brings together the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and major American steel, textile and semiconductor workers, along with the Economic Strategy Institute, an industry-financed research group that advocates more open markets with Tokyo. The report urged the Administration to stand firm in pursuing its "results oriented approach" to negotiations with Japan.
The report said the difficulties with Japan were deep-seated, structural barriers erected by Tokyo and were resistant to standard macroeconomic remedies. The coalition recommended the establishment of a task force from Congress, organized labor and industry "to review the entire United States-Japan economic relationship" in order to confront the Japan trade imbalance with a national strategy.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
LEHMAN BROS. HOLDINGS INC. (LEH,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. said Wednesday that third-quarter earnings fell more than 80 percent amid a slump on Wall Street.
Earnings fell to $22 million, or 10 cents a share, from $114 million in the quarter a year earlier, when the firm was still owned by the American Express Company. The year-ago earnings included net income of $2 million from businesses that have since been sold. 
 This year's quarter ended on Aug. 31, while the quarter a year earlier ended on Sept. 30. The results exceeded the mean estimate of 3 cents a share by seven analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research.
"Difficult market conditions persisted throughout the quarter, as interest rate uncertainties and inflationary concerns continued to dampen the activities of both issuers and investors," Richard Fuld Jr., the firm's chairman, said.
The results were buoyed by pretax merchant banking gains of $21 million, said Steven Eisman, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company, who took part in a conference call with Mr. Fuld for analysts on Wednesday. Lehman did not say where the gains came from, Mr. Eisman said.
At Lehman, net revenue, or gross revenues after interest, declined 19 percent, to $719 million. Investment banking revenue fell 8 percent, to $172 million. Commission revenue dropped 10 percent, to $113 million.
Lehman is in the midst of a cost-cutting effort aimed at reducing about 300 jobs, or about 3 percent of its work force. In the analysts' conference call, Lehman said it would wait to see how its business developed before making added cost cuts.
Lehman, the world's fourth-largest underwriter of stocks and bonds, was spun off from American Express in May.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Steady as Traders Keep Watch on Trade Talks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was steady against the Japanese yen and other leading currencies yesterday as traders watched for progress in trade talks between the United States and Japan.
Speculation that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates on Tuesday kept the dollar trading in a narrow range against the German mark as well. 
 In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.5470 marks, little changed from 1.5468 marks on Wednesday. The dollar was quoted at 98.02 yen, up from 97.75 yen on Wednesday.
The dollar has been largely unchanged against the yen for much of this week, as trade negotiators met in Tokyo and Washington. Many traders expect the dollar to tumble if the talks fail to produce an agreement before a Sept. 30 deadline.
"If there is an acrimonious end to these talks, the dollar will fall," said David De Rosa, director of foreign-exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation.
Without progress in the talks, there is less chance that Japan's $60 billion annual trade surplus with the United States will shrink. The surplus means that Japanese exporters have a constant supply of dollars to sell for yen when they send revenue home.
The weight of those sales and speculation that the Clinton Administration was willing to let the dollar fall against the yen to make Japan's exports more expensive helped drive the dollar to a post-World War II low of 96.60 yen in intraday trading on July 12.
In a meeting yesterday, President Clinton warned Japan's Foreign Minister, Yohei Kono, that the United States stood ready to impose sanctions if Japan did not make sufficient trade concessions by Sept. 30.
"It doesn't look good for the dollar right now," said Koichi Takenaka, assistant vice president at the Industrial Bank of Japan in New York. He said the dollar could fall as low as 93 yen if the United States imposed trade sanctions on Japan.
The dollar was steady against European currencies, as traders waited to see what the Federal Reserve and the Bundesbank would do with interest rates next week.
The South African rand, meanwhile, fell against the dollar after IBCA, a credit rating company in London, rated the country's debt as below investment grade, making it impossible for many investors to buy South African bonds. The financial rand, the special investment currency foreign investors are required to use, fell to 4.440 rand to the dollar, from 4.385 rand on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Higher On Fed Chief Comments

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices moved higher yesterday for the first time in three days as Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said that economic growth was clearly slowing.
But the gains are likely to be short-lived as more investors predict the Fed will raise interest rates next week. Some of the buying yesterday also represented traders covering short sales, which occurs when traders sell borrowed securities in hopes of buying them back at lower prices and pocketing the profit. Rising prices caused many short-sellers to take action sooner. 
 Market watchers said the scramble to cover shorts was apparently touched off by rumors that some Fed governors might not go along with a rate increase when the Fed's policy-making committee meets on Tuesday.
While many traders still expect a rate increase, Mr. Greenspan's comments yesterday helped to ease the nervousness about a tightening. Mr. Greenspan's testimony, in a regularly scheduled appearance before the Senate Banking Committee, indicated that the economy was doing well and that growth had slowed from an exuberant pace. Traders said the market reacted positively to Mr. Greenspan's testimony, even though he said nothing new.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 10/32 , to 9626/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.77, from 7.80 percent on Wednesday.
Shorter-maturity bill rates were mixed. In when-issued trading ahead of next week's Treasury auction of new bills, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.50 percent, and the five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 7.20 percent. Both yields showed marked improvement from the previous day.
P. Christopher Leary, a senior vice president and portfolio manager for SunAmerica Asset Management, said trading was thin, but noted that some investors sold two- , three- and four-year maturities and bought ten-year notes and longer maturity bonds. Over all, he said, investors were positioning for an increase in interest rates of 50 basis points next week. A basis point is 1/100 of a percentage point.
"Personally, one more rate hike is sufficient since we will see more indications of a slowdown in the economy over the next few months," Mr. Leary said. "It usually takes about nine months for a tightening to work its way through the econony."
But there are investors and analysts who predict the Fed will not act next week and will instead wait until November before pushing rates up for a sixth time this year.
The bond market brushed aside a report on unemployment claims yesterday, which showed initial claims down 7,000, to 320,000, for the week ended last Saturday. The number was slightly lower than expected, but consistent with the general theme of a steadily improving labor market.
In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan said there were signs that the product and labor markets might be nearing capacity limits. He said that the rest of the world was clearly doing better and the broad global expansion was the best in some time.
Elsewhere, IBCA, Europe's leading international credit agency, announced yesterday that it had established a rating of BB for South Africa, marking the first assessment of the country by a recognized rating agency since the elections on April 27.
The agency's rating puts South Africa in the same category as Argentina, Mexico and Hungary.

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Down

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
The Government reported a better-than-expected decline today of 7,000 in the number of Americans filing the first time for state unemployment benefits.
It was the third consecutive decline in the weekly number and the fourth in five weeks, unusual during a period when seasonal workers are normally laid off. 
 The Labor Department said the number of initial jobless claims totaled a seasonally adjusted 320,000 in the week that ended last Saturday, the lowest in seven weeks.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Congress Sends Baseball a Strong Message

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Striking major league players turned into lobbyists today, blanketing Congress in their latest effort to have baseball's antitrust exemption repealed in areas of labor. But the players' fervor paled in comparison to what they found to already exist on Capitol Hill: a blanket indictment of the exemption by many legislators angered by baseball's incessant labor wars.
The indictments, as well as an explicit call for baseball and its union to act before spring training, were both loudly stated in a hearing on the exemption by members of the House judiciary subcommittee on economics and commercial law. For three and a half hours, players and owners heard members question the propriety of Congress allowing baseball to keep the immunity granted by the Supreme Court in 1922 because the sport was not deemed an interstate business. 
 The lopsided nature of the questions and the constant correlation of the existence of the exemption to baseball's eight work stoppages -- twice as many as the other three major sports combined -- was not lost on anyone, especially owners.
"The message I read is that we'd better make every attempt to seek a resolution prior to Congress's return in January," said Bill Bartholomay, the chairman of the board of the Atlanta Braves.
Even though Bartholomay said he believed such efforts were going to be made through collective bargaining anyway, "this expedited it," he said.
"We certainly got a very strong, direct message, and it was far more than encouragement to get this thing fixed," said Jerry McMorris, the owner of the Colorado Rockies. "And I'm certainly very desirous to see that happen, the sooner the better."
Jack Brooks, a Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, encouraged such interpretations, spanking all parties, but especially the owners for what he called "the sorry spectacle" the sport had become since the strike began on Aug. 12 and the season was called off on Sept. 14.
More important, Brooks endorsed for the first time legislative initiatives that would narrowly repeal part of the game's antitrust exemption in areas of labor relations at the major league level.
However, he acknowledged that not much can be accomplished before Congress adjourns on or around Oct. 7.
"But," Brooks said, "I have come to the conclusion that legislation is now needed to restore the principles of competition and fair play to the business of baseball."
Brooks also reminded everyone that the Senate has already embarked on a path that also would limit the reaches of the antitrust immunity in areas of major league labor issues. "If, before adjournment, the Senate acts and sends it to the House, I would be very open to allowing it to proceed directly to the President," Brooks said.
This was a message that buoyed the players as much as it sobered a management team that entered the hearing on the defensive.
"I leaned over to Craig Biggio in the hearing and said, 'We're winning, aren't we?' " pitcher Bob Tewksbury of the Cardinals said after the hearing, which was attended by eight players, including Dodgers pitcher Orel Hershiser, who testified.
"It's always nice to know that you're persuading more people as time goes along," said Donald Fehr, executive director of the Players Association. "I'm the last person to judge what the entire Congress is going to do, but the temperature's going up."
Charles P. O'Connor, the general counsel for the owners' Player Relations Committee, stated the strongest arguments against such Congressional action.
"The worst thing to do, from a labor perspective, is to intervene because of a strike or a lockout," said O'Connor. "The reason we have the exemption is because, otherwise, the normal activities of the union would be violations of the antitrust laws because they are joining together to fix the cost of labor in the labor market."
However, Fehr stated time and again during his testimony and the questioning that followed that the players would take their chances in court if the exemption was rolled back. And he restated the union stance that if a bill bringing baseball labor relations under the antitrust laws passed, he would recommend the players go back to work.
One of the seven owners on hand, Bud Selig of the Milwaukee Brewers, the acting commissioner, spoke in defense of not only the exemption but also the divisive salary cap proposal. But he drew questions about the failure of owners to hire a strong commissioner, as Selig promised the same committee two years ago.
And finally, in a news conference afterward, Brooks vowed that Congress would not countenance replacement workers, an issue that came up because some owners have said they would open spring training camp on time, settlement or no settlement.
"There is a high level of frustration here," Selig acknowledged afterward. "It's merely another reason to get this done ourselves, get back to the table and establish a common ground. We've got to stop carrying on this fight everywhere but where it should be."

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
Players Seeking Antitrust Reversal

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
The legal power struggle between the National Basketball Association and the players' union yesterday moved into a Federal appeals court, where the union sought to reverse a lower court ruling that found that the salary cap, college draft and right of first refusal signing system do not violate antitrust law.
The union contends that after the collective bargaining agreement with the league expired June 24, the three disputed policies fell out of the jurisdiction of Federal labor law and became provisions restricting the free-market opportunities of players from the day they are drafted to when they retire. 
 The league disagrees. "This is a dispute over terms and conditions of employment that is governed by Federal labor laws," Jeffrey Mishkin, a league lawyer, told a three-judge panel of the Second Circuit United States Court of Appeals. "Antitrust law should not be used to subvert Federal labor law."
In July, the union failed to persuade United States District Court Judge Kevin T. Duffy that the expiration of the agreement extinguished its collective bargaining relationship with the N.B.A. Duffy ruled that the league is protected from the antitrust laws by a nonstatutory labor exemption.
The case is part of the continuing labor upheaval in sports. Baseball players are on strike because teams want a salary cap. National Hockey League players may be locked out as they fitfully try to negotiate a new labor agreement. And National Football League players are squabbling with their union over the effects of the first year of the league's new salary cap.
Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., a lawyer for the National Basketball Players Association, told the court that no collective bargaining relationship exists with the league, that any unilateral change the league imposes on the players will be challenged on antitrust grounds, and that the act of unionizing under the Wagner Act should not rob players of available antitrust remedies.
Schwarz added that Duffy erred by indefinitely allowing the N.B.A. to continue the salary cap, draft and right of first refusal. Schwarz said, "It doesn't make sense for a judge to impose a term upon the parties, a term of perpetual agreement that the parties did not bargain for."
Central to the union argument is the term of the nonstatutory exemption, which was created by the United States Supreme Court. Does it last until a new agreement is signed or until an impasse? The exemption provides no specific terms.
"We say there should be a 'when,' " Schwarz said after the hearing. "We say it should be at an impasse and we're at an impasse. They say they have a perpetual Shangri-La with everlasting protection."
Mishkin said: "They can't declare the collective bargaining relationship stopped because labor laws, not the courts, govern our relationship."
To the league, this is purely a labor dispute. It says no impasse with the union exists after only the few bargaining sessions that took place before the league sued on June 17 to prevent the union from suing on antitrust grounds.
"Even if you said these provisions violated antitrust law," Mishkin told the court, the parties must still negotiate a new agreement. "The courts should stay out." Each side, he said, has labor law remedies with economic clout: the union can strike or the league can lock players out.
The union has one other option: decertify itself as a union, then attack the league in Federal court on antitrust grounds. But a court remedy can take years, and decertification is not supposed to be a collective bargaining tactic.
"We don't think the union should have to commit suicide," said Charles Grantham, the executive director of the union.
After the hearing, David Stern, the N.B.A. commissioner, said: "We expect to prevail in this case. We've told the players we have to make a deal."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
After 334 Receptions, Giants' Jackson Catches Pink Slip

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
Mark Jackson read it in preseason and he read it in the regular season. He read it on the field and on the depth chart. The handwriting was never on the wall; it was always directly in front of the veteran wide receiver, a conspicuous little message from his employer:
Thanks for everything, but. . . . 
 The Giants waived Jackson, a nine-year veteran, yesterday, making room for Coleman Rudolph, the former Jets defensive end whom the club claimed off waivers. They also waived Jackson -- for the second time this season -- because they simply had too many young and talented receivers in the mix.
Jackson's agent, Lamont Smith, said he has been in contact with several teams, including the Indianapolis Colts, and the man who has caught 334 professional passes is expected to make a decision on his future today or tomorrow.
"The next 24 hours is critical," the agent said. "We've got a lot on the table.
"The door is cracked open for his return," added Smith, alluding to Jackson's chances of rejoining the Giants via the practice squad. "Mark took it amazingly well. He came into the league as a sixth-round draft choice and made $2 million last year. He's grateful for the ride with Dan."
"The good news is that we were able to pick up Coleman," Giants Coach Dan Reeves said in a statement issued by the club. "The bad news is that we have to let somebody go."
Especially someone with whom Reeves shared so much success in the last nine years. Jackson spent seven years with the Denver Broncos and Reeves, and was never more brilliant than when he hauled in a 5-yard touchdown catch from John Elway to complete the Drive, a 98-yard, 15-play piece of National Football League history that came against Cleveland in 1986.
Although he started 14 of 16 games last season, his first with the Giants, and caught a career-high 58 passes, N.F.L. economics and the emergence of the club's other receivers forced the Giants to release him.
Chris Calloway, 27, replaced Jackson, 32, as the starting second wide receiver opposite Mike Sherrard before the season opener. Jackson took the news rather well but added, "I don't think I did anything not to warrant starting."
Neither Jackson nor his agent, Lamont Smith, could be reached for comment today.
Jackson sensed the club's move toward the future during the preseason, when Dave Brown beat out Kent Graham for the starting nod, partly by finding Calloway open often.
Calloway, 26, has shown a knack for not only breaking the big play, but also blocking superbly when the ball doesn't come his way. Thomas Lewis, like Calloway a solid special-teams player, is the team's first-round draft pick. His potential intrigues the Giants.
Jackson, 31, played in only two games and was made inactive against Phoenix in Week 2. He had not caught a pass.
He could be as much a casualty of the salary cap as his advancing age. Cut by the team May 6, Jackson was brought back July 18 for between $200,000 and $300,000, a pay cut of more than $1 million from last season.
"It is tough to let anyone go but especially someone who has been a big part of any success you have had for nine years," Reeves said. "Mark wants to play and hopefully he will get that opportunity."
And quickly.

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: The Reach of Democracy;
Tying Power To Diplomacy

BYLINE: By Anthony Lake; Anthony Lake is President Clinton's national security adviser. This article is adapted from remarks to the Council on Foreign Relations on Sept. 12.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
To many Americans, the cold war divisions have given way to a confusing tangle of problems that prevent us from setting clearly defined goals for our foreign policy. These problems include aggression by regional bullies, transnational dangers like overpopulation and refugees, a global economic and information free-for-all that produces fear and uncertainty, and terrible ethnic conflicts.
Beneath the surface, however, there is an enduring truth about this new world. The same idea attacked by Fascism and Communism remains under attack today. Now, as then, we are defending an idea that comes under many names -- democracy, liberty, civility, pluralism -- but has a constant face. It is the face of the tolerant society, in which leaders and governments exist not to use or abuse people but to provide them with freedom and opportunity. 
 We are at the start of a new stage in this old struggle. This is not a clash of civilizations. Rather, it is a contest that pits nations and individuals guided by openness, responsive government and moderation against those animated by isolation, repression and extremism. The enemies of the tolerant society are not some nameless, faceless force. They are extreme nationalists and tribalists, terrorists, organized criminals, coup plotters, rogue states and all those who would return newly free societies to the intolerant ways of the past.
For all its dangers, this new world presents immense opportunities to reshape and create international structures that are adapted to post-cold-war realities and designed to consolidate the victory of democracy and open markets.
We are not starry-eyed about the prospects for spreading democracy, but we know that to do so serves our interests. Democracies create free markets that offer economic opportunity, and they make for reliable trading partners. They tend not to abuse their citizens' rights or wage war on one another.
The Administration has made a good start at building security and economic institutions designed to create the conditions in which democracy can flourish. In Europe, we are deeply engaged in transforming NATO to fulfill President Clinton's vision of an integrated continent by establishing Combined Joint Task Forces for peacekeeping and crisis management and the Partnership for Peace to begin expanding security in Europe eastward.
The new global economy requires that we design structures that produce tangible benefits for our citizens and turn their fears into hope. That is why the President went to the mat for the North American Free Trade Agreement, which has dramatically accelerated the exchange of goods and ideas between the United States, Mexico and Canada. That is why he has taken the lead in setting a pro-trade agenda in the fast-growing Asian-Pacific economies. And that is why our successful completion of the GATT world trade talks was so important: it promises to make a real difference in real lives by creating jobs and raising wages.
The challenges we face also demand the patient application of diplomacy and the measured exercise of power. We use diplomacy to pursue peace. But peace is not just an end in itself. It also creates conditions necessary for democratic values to thrive. Thus, when we foster peace in the Middle East, Northern Ireland and South Africa, we are promoting the tolerant society as well.
Effective diplomacy depends not only on the skill of our diplomats but also on power. Nothing better demonstrates this proposition than our approach to Haiti. There we have relied on diplomacy backed by power -- the threat of the use of force. The regime agreed to step down because of the credible and imminent prospect of a massive U.S.-led invasion. As a result, we are accomplishing a goal that this Administration -- and its predecessor -- have pursued for three years: the restoration of democratic government. And we are doing so peacefully, with less risk to our troops -- whose presence will guarantee that the Haitian military keeps its word.
The progress we have made in Bosnia came when power was tied to diplomacy. The Sarajevo ultimatum succeeded because the threat of NATO air power was judged real. The ultimatum also sparked the agreement on a federation between the Croatians and Muslims. And it was the threat of further action by NATO, combined with our sanctions, that led Serbia to close its border with the Bosnian Serbs when they rejected the recent peace plan. Now, we are firmly committed to increasing the pressure on the Bosnian Serbs to accept the plan, partly by enforcement of the ban on heavy weapons around Sarajevo and Gorazde.
It cannot and must not be the responsibility of the international community or this nation finally to resolve all deeply rooted conflicts. But where practical, we can save lives, as in Rwanda and Somalia, and we can offer conflicting societies a breathing space in which to sort out their own affairs. Whether or not they do so must be their own responsibility.
These explosions in states are also exacerbated by transnational problems -- refugees; population growth; an endangered environment; a nefarious nexus of crime, terrorism and the weapons of mass destruction -- whose dimensions have been clearly exposed by the end of the cold war and whose challenge we must meet.
We must also contend with regional rogue states like Iran, Iraq and Libya, which seek to traffic in the weapons of mass destruction, support terrorism and are dedicated to the destruction of the tolerant society.
For that reason, President Clinton will maintain and modernize the finest military in the world so that we can deter aggression -- and counter it when the need arises. We have also developed a strategy of dual containment of Iraq and Iran. And we will uphold our commitment to South Korea even as we negotiate a solution to the nuclear issue with the North.
Because we must fight on so many fronts at once, we will make prog ress only over time, in small victories, through persistence and pragmatism. These are not evidence of indecision: they are the hallmarks of determination, of a nation engaged in the long struggle for democracy and the freedom and tolerance it brings.

HEADLINE: Flat Tax Is an Idea That Just Won't Go Away

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The 17 percent flat tax advocated by Chuck Haytaian, the New Jersey Republican candidate for the Senate, would do much more than simplify the Federal income tax codes that have grown into the most complex on earth since 1913. It would produce explosive United States economic growth by dramatically reducing the cost of capital. The whole country would benefit, but because New Jersey is among the states with the highest per capita incomes, the benefits would be enormous here. 
 Senator Frank Lautenberg opposes the flat tax, arguing that it would benefit millionaires. Quite the contrary, only the wealthy are able to afford the costs dealing with the complexity of the tax codes. In 1992, when former Gov. Jerry Brown of California was seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination, our company in Morristown did an evaluation of his flat tax proposal. We concluded:
"Eliminating virtually all special treatment for taxpayers in favor of a low, easily collectible tax would generate enormous benefits for the United States economy as a whole.
"First, the barriers to small business, for whom tax compliance is a substantial expense, would be reduced; because small business is the largest generator of new jobs, the economy would benefit.
"Second, the tax base would broaden, as a result of reduced incentives to avoid taxation.
"Third, the activities of the thousands of America's best-trained professionals in the legal and accounting professions would be redirected toward creating new enterprises, rather than avoiding taxation.
"As Prof. Paul Samuelson, a liberal Democrat, writes in the 13th edition of his textbook 'Economics,' the flat tax 'would put thousands of tax lawyers out of business. The economy would become more efficient as people spent less time worrying about the impact of their actions on taxes and more time worrying about production of aircraft and computers, and generation of innovation.' "
The 17 percent flat tax would not only generate sufficient Federal revenue to exempt a family of four with income less than $36,800 from any income tax. But because income is taxed only once, it would also entirely eliminate taxation of capital gains and inheritances. The increased growth this liberation of capital would invite would greatly increase state and local tax revenues.
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, chairman of the House Republican Conference and the man who designed the 17 percent flat tax, correctly dismisses arguments that it would be a revenue loser.
Mr. Armey, who earned a doctorate in economics at the University of Texas, points out that individuals and businesses now spend at least $200 billion a year to pay their taxes, most of which would be saved by tax simplification, an idea whose time is coming.
 
JUDE WANNISKI
Morristown, N.J., Sept. 19, 1994
The writer is a political and economic consultant.

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: The Reach of Democracy;
Cold War Games Again

BYLINE: By Robert H. Johnson; Robert H. Johnson is a fellow at the National Planning Association, a research organization specializing in economic and social issues, and is author of "Improbable Dangers: U.S. Conceptions of Threat in the Cold War and After."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The intervention in Haiti is most disturbing for what it says about the Administration's post-cold-war strategy as defined by Anthony Lake, President Clinton's national security adviser.
To Mr. Lake, America is involved in an extension of the struggle for democracy and against authoritarianism that began with World War II and continued in the cold war. As in those conflicts, the struggle is Manichean: the forces of evil (rogue states, terrorists, tribalists) against the forces of good (democracies, tolerant societies). 
 From this perspective, Mr. Lake argued at the Council on Foreign Relations in Washington this month that the world no longer appears chaotic and incomprehensible -- that our enemies are easily identifiable. The threat is still authoritarianism; our goal is still promoting democracy.
Stated this way, America's goal remains the one that the Truman Doctrine established at the beginning of the cold war. That doctrine provided the rationale for interventions all over the globe in defense of freedom.
Mr. Lake argues that we must be selective in our interventions, and the President says the United States cannot be the world's policeman. But a policy based on principle risks either ever-widening commitments or double standards and growing cynicism. When our commitments are challenged, the willingness to carry them out becomes a test of Presidential and national credibility.
Thus, Mr. Lake sees Haiti as a test of the U.S. commitment to the defense of democracy, and views the demonstration of U.S. resolve to reinstate democracy there as having broad international implications.
As in the cold war, defending our credibility becomes an interest and a goal in itself, partly or wholly separable from the intrinsic value of the stakes in a particular conflict.
Viewing the world through such a wide lens tends to create a sense that the fates of related nations are connected -- that a country that "goes authoritarian" will destabilize nations that are geographically or politically related, and dominoes will fall.
Mr. Lake argues that if America fails to restore democracy in Haiti, a flood of Haitian refugees could have destabilizing effects throughout the Caribbean. How or why such events might occur is not explained. Despite constant fears of dominoes throughout the cold war, there was never a case that clearly demonstrated the validity of the domino theory.
The definition of democracy, as in the past, has become too elastic: one free election in its 200-year history did not make Haiti a democracy, nor necessarily make President Jean-Bertrand Aristide a democrat. In Somalia, Bosnia and Rwanda, the principle of support for democracy provided no useful guidance for policy.
The fundamental problem with basing foreign policy on the defense of democracy through intervention is that our Government lacks the means -- and will lack the domestic political support -- to carry out such a policy. When other countries lack the political and cultural roots of democracy, it is impossible for outsiders to create them, and the use of force in support of democracy will be unavailing.
Somalia provided an early post-cold-war lesson in the difficulties of using our power to produce political change in a society we understand imperfectly and can barely influence. The goal of nation-building, which came to symbolize American hubris in Vietnam, was unexpectedly revived during the Clinton phase of U.S. involvement in Somalia. Fortunately, its impracticality was quickly recognized. But the problem of political change is even more daunting in Haiti.
The limits of our ability to act since the end of the cold war have also been demonstrated in Bosnia, where neither politicians in the former Yugoslavia nor America's allies have bent to America's will. Their resistance, and the limits imposed by U.S. public opinion, have contributed to the unsteadiness of American policy.
The lack of public support for intervention in Haiti and the strong reaction to the relatively limited U.S. casualties in Somalia suggest that Americans are now unlikely to pay a substantial price on behalf of vague causes like world order, democracy or national credibility.
The incoherence of the Administration's foreign policy arises partly from its tendency to take broad stances based on principles, like the support of democracy against authoritarianism, that frequently conflict with other interests and political reality. Backtracking, as in the case of the Clinton policy toward human rights in China, creates an appearance of uncertainty and incompetence.
Administration spokesmen have tended to hype threats, implying that if this country does not take decisive action, American or global security will be put at risk. But when it has faced the implications of its statements, it has pulled back.
Thus, Secretary of Defense William Perry called the North Korean nuclear program a threat to the "entire world" and Mr. Clinton implied the possibility of a pre-emptive attack. But the Administration ultimately decided to negotiate.
While the U.S. must remain active in the world, it needs to undertake a much less ambitious foreign policy agenda. If it seeks to lead a movement for a world order based on democracy, it will exhaust itself in the effort. Its foreign policy will become ever more incoherent as domestic and international constraints limit its capacity to achieve its rhetorical goals. And its domestic politics will be roiled by the clamor over its foreign policy failures, diverting its leaders from more essential tasks at home and abroad.

HEADLINE: Harvard Club Strike Sticks Over Givebacks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I reply as an employee of Local 6, the union representing striking Harvard Club employees, to the Sept. 14 letter by Preston Townley, vice president of the club. Mr. Townley claims union leaders "participated grudgingly" in mediation and "walked away at the first opportunity," and that "work rules say bus persons in the dining room can't make coffee." 
 If Mr. Townley had attended a mediation session, he would know that a Harvard Club manager admitted to a Federal mediator that all employees do whatever jobs they are asked to do. And if Mr. Townley had read the union contract, he would also know bus persons do make coffee. The problem is that management's $300-an-hour lawyers are demanding the bus persons relinquish the 15-cents-an-hour "bonus" they are paid for this task.
The six-month strike has never been about union rules. It's about management's demand that employees begin co-payment for their medical coverage, give up holidays and sick days, accept wage reductions and trade in their full-time employment for part-time work.
And while Mr. Townley claims that Harvard Club employees "are paid better and receive better benefits" than workers in similar jobs at other New York City clubs, management was informed months ago that workers would readily agree to a contract similar or identical to those reached this year at other clubs.
Mr. Townley asserts the "employees are indeed valued members of the Harvard Club family." Yet he fails to mention that management sent club members letters suggesting employees were lazy and unproductive. Mr. Townley further insists employees "deserve the job security that comes from a club whose operations are economically sound."
Those are strange words from a vice president of the Harvard Club, a business whose recent economically sound operations have included prolonging a strike that has already caused the club to lose more than $1 million.
 
JOHN TURCHIANO
Long Beach, L.I., Sept. 16, 1994

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGNS;
Race for Governor: Pataki

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
CANDIDATE: George E. Pataki
 
PRODUCER: Russo, Marsh & Associates, Alexandria, Va., and Sacramento, Calif.
 

VISUAL: The 30-second advertisement begins with footage of Mr. Pataki looking directly at the camera. The camera then pans to a chart depicting welfare spending increasing and the workfare population decreasing, and the advertisement ends with the camera back on Mr. Pataki, and his campaign logo.
 
SCRIPT: Mr. Pataki: "People need workfare, not welfare. Today, 1.6 million New Yorkers are on welfare. That costs taxpayers billions of tax dollars every year. We must give people the skills they need to get off welfare. But under Mario Cuomo, welfare spending always goes up, while workfare has gone down. We must do better. We need workfare, not welfare."
Announcer: "George Pataki, the new Governor New York needs. George Pataki. It's time for a change."
 
ANALYSIS: Workfare, the requirement that welfare recipients work off their grants in public sector jobs, has become a buzzword in recent years. It has strong visceral appeal to those who work hard for a living and who recoil at the thought of able-bodied adults living off the Government dole.
Yet many welfare experts question its long-term utility, saying it may be more effective in soothing public frustration than in moving welfare recipients off the rolls. The Cuomo administration has no objection to workfare as a temporary measure, and is trying to expand its programs. But it believes that only job training and other employment programs will move people permanently off the rolls.
Mr. Pataki's statistics are accurate to a point but leave much of the story untold. The percentage of home relief recipients participating in workfare has decreased since 1982, when Mr. Cuomo was first elected, from 34 percent to 14 percent, according to the Department of Social Services. But in 1982, when there were 58,000 employable home relief recipients, workfare was the only job-related program available in New York. Now, with 195,000 employable home relief recipients, there are alternative programs, including job training and education, and a total of 35 percent participate.
It is true that there are 1.6 million New Yorkers on welfare (up from 1.3 million in 1982, when Mr. Cuomo was first elected) and that billions of tax dollars are spent every year ($4.1 billion in 1993, compared to $2.2 billion in 1982). It is not quite true, however, that welfare spending always goes up. Welfare caseloads tend to track economic conditions, and welfare spending remained static for much of the 1980's, even decreasing slightly one year, before ballooning in 1990 with the start of the recession. KEVIN SACK
