HEADLINE: Northrop To Cut 8,650 Positions

BYLINE: By SALLIE HOFMEISTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22

 BODY:
In a response to the nation's shrinking military budget that will strike the economies of Long Island and California, the Northrop Grumman Corporation said today that it would reduce its work force by 8,650 jobs, or more than 18 percent, by the end of 1995.
Consultants to military contractors and Wall Street analysts viewed the development as necessary for the newly combined company to survive in a fast-consolidating industry. "This is a healthy response as defense revenues shrink and it is the only way to justify the merger -- to cut costs," Robert Paulson, head of the aerospace practice for McKinsey & Company, a management consultant firm, said. In May, the Grumman Corporation and the Northrop Corporation merged in a $2.1 billion deal. "It shows that management is getting on with the business." 
 Yet it is another blow to the economies of California and Long Island, which will bear the brunt of the layoffs. About 3,500 of the job reductions will come from operations in Long Island, including approximately 2,500 previously announced by the Grumman Corporation as part of a restructuring planned before the merger. The additional 1,000 will come next year from the closing of Grumman's corporate headquarters at Bethpage, L.I. -- the new company is based at Northrop's headquarters here -- and from streamlining the company's remaining Long Island operations.
Today's announcement had been telegraphed by both Northrop and Grumman officials in the spring when they agreed to merge, but they did not then give any precise figures. When the ax finally fell, it caught few by surprise. [Page D11.]
According to the company, Northrop Grumman will employ only 3,800 on Long Island by the end of 1995. That is down from about 9,170 at the beginning of 1994, before Grumman undertook a payroll cut on its own, 7,300 workers at the time of the merger, and 25,000 in 1986, when United States military spending peaked.
Still, the bulk of the layoffs, 4,150, will come from California, which earlier this month was jolted by news that GM Hughes Electronics would lay off 4,400 workers, mostly in Southern California, and shut a plant in Fullerton.
"The trend among defense contractors is to cut costs, and that means not doing business in high-cost states like California," said Jack Modzelewski, an aerospace analyst at Paine Webber. "The state has a significant issue on its hands."
In California, the layoffs include 2,400 workers who are assigned in Pico Rivera and Palmdale, Calif., to the B-2 stealth bomber program, whose production is winding down. Those job cuts were first announced last week. Another 1,600 positions will come from the company's Military Aircraft division in Hawthorne and El Segundo, as well as 150 from the electronics unit in Hawthorne.
About 600 of the remaining 1,000 layoffs will come from the company's Vought Aircraft unit in Dallas, with the rest from various plants around the country.
Analysts were unfazed by the layoffs, calling them a natural response to a decline in the military budget for programs like the B-2 and to a merger predicated on the cost savings and efficiencies that would derive from integrating overlapping businesses in military electronics and in commercial and military aircraft. The company's biggest programs are the B-2 bomber, the fuselage for the FA-18 jet fighter and the Joint Stars advanced surveillance program.
Some reductions will be achieved through an early retirement program extended to about 5,000 employees in the Northrop Retirement Plan. The company said a 60 percent acceptance rate would result in a one-time charge against earnings in the fourth quarter of about $300 million. The deadline to apply for the program is Nov. 15.
Analysts said this could draw down an overfunded pension plan that has contributed nearly a fifth of the company's income in the past.Wall Street analysts said that the layoffs might not be the last hit to company profits. "I'm surprised that the charge for the employment cutbacks is as large, but we'll see one more charge in the same order of magnitude for plant and equipment closings," said Mr. Modzelewski of Paine Webber. He said that despite the cost savings that would likely result from the job cuts, he had still not revised his earnings projections.
Northrop Grumman shares closed at $45.125, down 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange today. But analysts expected the stock to rebound because of the promise of savings.
Still, some analysts were reluctant to offer too much praise, saying that cutting the company's work force is only a first step. "The more important challenge is how they will restructure their overall costs to reposition them to win new contracts," said Gary Campbell of A. T. Kearney, a management consulting firm.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 24, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about job cuts planned by the Northrop Grumman Corporation included erroneous totals supplied by the company in some copies. The work force is to be reduced by 8,650 jobs, or 18.2 percent, not 9,000 jobs, or 20 percent. The reductions will affect 150 jobs from the electronics unit in Hawthorne, Calif., not 500.

HEADLINE: Study Says Schools Must Stress Academics

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Saying that the American educational system is failing the nation's employers, a leading business organization called today for a new emphasis on basic academic training at the expense of social goals and services.
The Committee for Economic Development, an organization of executives at about 250 large corporations, called for an end to efforts to incorporate mentally and physically handicapped children in regular classrooms, and urged educators to move away from providing social services like pregnancy counseling, AIDS information and drivers' education classes. The group also said schools should not be battlegrounds over ideological issues like abortion, homosexuality and creationism. 
 "America's public schools are being spread too thin," said Education Secretary Richard W. Riley, who appeared at a press conference at which the organization released a report, "Putting Learning First." "Nothing will be gained by tearing down public education and making the public school classroom the Bosnia of America's competing factions. When a community is divided, the children always suffer."
Reform efforts of the past decade have been sloppy, said Roy J. Bostock, the committee's chairman. As a result, school programs are "diluted, distracted and diffused from the basic mission of education" despite the seemingly endless round of hand-wringing over the quality of education.
The result is an educational system that suits parents and students "who tend to feel satisfied with their schools," but one that increasingly fails the business sector, the report concludes. Employers, the report says, "feel that a large majority of their new hires lack adequate writing and problem-solving skills."
Albert Shanker, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, who attended the press conference, said, "From now on you should not get into college just because you're breathing and you're 18." Creating an achievement standard, he said in comments supporting the group's findings, is "a radical notion that is not radical anywhere else in the world."
The committee's report proposes applying to education the basic notions that have been championed in business circles in recent years, like group merit awards to encourage teamwork, the trimming of bureaucracy and limits on "micromanagement" of classrooms.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, who joined Education Secretary Riley this afternoon for a tour of a model school in New York City, lauded those goals. He said he hoped to see a new link between schools and business that would combine core academic studies with job training.
"You have an economy where you have spot shortages of skilled labor, and we don't yet have a system that integrates school and work," said Mr. Reich.
Some businesses are already experimenting with new ways to make the business-education link work. Last week, the I.B.M. International Foundation, the nation's largest corporate philanthropy, announced plans to donate $25 million over five years to help 10 school districts revamp their programs. The first project will be in Charlotte, N.C., where four new public schools will be built around lessons learned in business.
The foundation's president, Stanley S. Litow, said the schools would have interactive computer facilities, grade categories only loosely structured around age limits and intensive study programs. Most other details are now being worked out.
"If we do business with someone, we constantly invite them in to show them new products and how things are changing," said Mr. Litow. "Nobody does that for schools." The economic development committee's report encourages such communication. It also makes specific recommendations.
For example, it condemns the growing practice, called "intrusion," to move mentally and physically handicapped children to standard classrooms.
"Currently, communities, states and the national government are asking those who manage our classrooms to be parent, social worker, doctor, psychologist, police officer and perhaps, if there is time, teacher," the report says. "It seems that whenever a social crisis, such as AIDS, child abuse or drunk driving is perceived, the government looks to the schools to solve it," the report concludes.
Some state mandates also are criticized. Kentucky regulations, the report notes as an example, "contain such vague statements as 'students will make sense of the variety of materials they read . . . the various things they observe . . . and the various messages to which they listen' without defining what 'make sense of' might mean," the report says.
The comments are not just aimed at the regulations but also at the regulators. School boards are criticized as "attracting individuals who are poorly versed in educational matters, are more interested in using school board membership as a stepping stone to higher political office, have an ideological ax to grind or see school board service as an opportunity for financial gain."
The report calls for holding school board votes with general elections, to involve more voters. It also calls for better training of school board members.
The National School Boards Association responded that the committee detailed problems that school boards are already grappling with. "The report reinforces NSBA's own recent efforts to enhance school governance," said Boyd Boehlje, the association's president.
 As a result, the article also referred imprecisely to the group's position on the practice. It opposes the policy of including every disabled child in standard classrooms, but favors the incorporation of less disabled students who would not interfere with other students' studies.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 24, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a business group's study advocating a new emphasis on basic academic training misidentified the term for placing all disabled children in standard classrooms. The practice is called inclusion, not intrusion.

HEADLINE: U.N. Eases Curbs on Yugoslavia After Serbian Peace Concessions

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 23

 BODY:
The Security Council voted today to ease sanctions on Yugoslavia for 100 days in response to a pledge by the President of Serbia to support a peace plan for Bosnia and Herzegovina, halt the shipment of war supplies to the Bosnian Serbs and accept civilian monitoring of the Serbian-Bosnian border.
At the same time, the Council approved two additional resolutions intended to punish the Bosnian Serbs for continuing to carry out a "persistent and systematic campaign of terror" while interfering with United Nations relief and peacekeeping operations. Financial and commercial activity as well as all political talks with Bosnian Serbs would be frozen until they agree to a peace agreement reached on July 6 and backed by Russia, Europe and the United States. 
 The Security Council voted 11 to 2 with 2 abstentions on the resolution easing sanctions on the rump Yugoslav federation, comprising Serbia and Montenegro.
Quick action on the resolution was somewhat unexpected because all week there have been reports of war material being ferried into Bosnian Serb territory from Serbia, in violation of the embargo announced by the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic. The reports indicated that the shipments were being conducted by the Yugoslav Army.
There was additional confusion today, when Secretary of State Warren Christopher told reporters in Washington this morning that he thought a vote today would be premature. As he spoke, Madeleine K. Albright, the United States representative to the United Nations, said she had authority to vote for the resolutions.
This evening, a State Department official said Mr. Christopher decided to support the resolution after receiving assurances that it called for sufficient monitoring of the border between Bosnia and Serbia and a report certifying that the embargo would be respected.
About 135 observers have been assigned to monitor the 300-mile border, but not all are in place. Some experts think that, even at full complement, the number of observers is not adequate to the task.
Jamsheed K.A. Marker, Pakistan's delegate to the United Nations, criticized the monitoring agreement in a speech tonight, saying that "a handful of men cannot certify the uncertifiable."
Tonight, Ms. Albright defended the Clinton Administration's support for the easing of sanctions but said the United States had not made the decision lightly. "My Government continues to believe that Belgrade authorities bear primary responsibility for what has happened in the former Yugoslavia during the past three years," she said.
Djibouti and Pakistan voted against easing the sanctions, and Nigeria and Rwanda abstained. The rest of the Council members voted yes: Argentina, Brazil, Britain, China, the Czech Republic, France, New Zealand, Oman, Russia, Spain and the United States.
Reaction from a host of mostly Islamic countries was swift and sharp. Egypt's representative, Nabil A. Elaraby, told the Council before the formal vote took place that sanctions are being eased when "it is abundantly clear before world public opinion that no tangible progress has happened in the field."
Turkey's representative, Inal Batu, said, "The easing of sanctions on Serbia and Montenegro will constitute yet another wrong signal to the aggressor and undermine the peace process."
The resolution was defended by Germany's representative, Detlev Graf Zu Rantzau, speaking for the European Union and the Nordic countries. He said Serbia's willingness to cut supplies to the Bosnian Serbs should be rewarded.
Yugoslavia's representative, Dragomir Djokic, described the easing of sanctions as inadequate and merely a political maneuver. He called for the full and permanent lifting of sanctions as the best way to speed a peace agreement.
Croatia's representative called the move "a dangerous precedent."
Diplomats said the Council seemed to be propelled into action by a desire to complete work on these resolutions before heads of government and foreign ministers begin to arrive to address the General Assembly next week and the Council's work could be complicated by the reopening of debate.
The resolution easing sanctions will allow the reopening of Belgrade airport to all civilian flights and the resumption of ferry services between Bar, in Montenegro, and Bari, Italy.
Under the resolution, Yugoslavia could also resume participation in international cultural and athletic events.
But the resolution also demands the reimposition of sanctions within five days of any determination by Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali that Serbia had resumed shipping war material. Relief goods must be allowed to cross freely.
The move to ease sanctions on the Yugoslav federation -- couched in a resolution proposed by the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Russia -- came after President Milosevic of Serbia agreed earlier this month to allow civilian observers to be stationed along the border of Serbia, which has been the Bosnian Serbs' main supplier throughout the war.
An accompanying resolution, also sponsored by the same five-nation Security Council caucus that calls itself the "contact group" on Bosnia, puts more pressure on the Bosnian Serbs by tightening sanctions. It prohibits international travel by Bosnian Serb officials unless it is related to peace efforts. It bars trade and other economic activity with businesses or organizations owned or controlled by Bosnian Serb forces, except for relief goods. Bosnian Serb financial assets abroad are to be frozen.
No river traffic will be permitted to enter areas under the control of Bosnia Serbs. All goods destined for Bosnia will have to be inspected and cleared.
The third resolution, sponsored by a group of Council members from the developing world -- Pakistan, Nigeria, Oman, Djibouti and Rwanda -- condemns renewed evictions of Bosnian Muslims and others from Banja Luka, Bijeljina and other areas. It warns Bosnian Serbs that "ethnic cleansing" is in violation of international law and that any individual indulging in such behavior is personally accountable.
 
HIGHLIGHTS
U.N. RESOLUTIONS ON YUGOSLAVIA
 
RESOLUTION 1
 
Reopens airport at Belgrade to civilian passenger flights
 
Allows Yugoslavs to participate in sports and cultural exchanges.
 
Also allows passenger ferry service between the port of Bar in Montenegro and Bari in Italy.
 
These measures will be instituted for an initial period of 100 days following a report from Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali that Yugoslavia is implementing its decision to stop all but humanitarian goods to Bosnian areas under control of Bosnian Serb forces.
 
Sanctions will automatically be reimposes five days after any report from Boutros-Ghali that Belgrade is again shipping war materials or other proscribed goods across the Bosnian border unless the Security Council decides otherwise.
 
RESOLUTION 2
 
Calls on all governments to stop any political talks with Bosnian Serb leaders.
Prohibits travel by Bosnian Serb officials, including legislative authorities and their allies except if authorized for purposes related to the peace negotiations.
 
Prohibits trade or other economic activity with any entity owned or controlled by Bosnian Serb forces except for relief goods. Freezes financial assets held abroad.
 
Prohibits commercial river traffic from entering ports in areas of Bosnia under control of Bosnian Serb forces except if authorized by the Security Council.
 
Calls for all shipments of goods destinated to Bosnian Serb areas of Bosnia inspected and certified in advance.Neighboring states are to watch for any diversion of goods to Serb-held areas of Croatia.
 
RESOLUTION 3
 
Condemns renewed ethnic cleansing by Bosnian Serba in Banja Luka, Bijeljina and other areas and says any transfer of property under duress is null and void.
 
Demands Bosnian Serbs allow U.N. officials and international relief groups into Banja Luka, Bijeljina and other areas of concern.
 
(Source: Reuter)

HEADLINE: Criticizing Pataki, Giuliani Seeks Details on His Plans to Aid City

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday stepped up his criticism of his party's gubernatorial candidate, Senator George E. Pataki, saying that Mr. Pataki had taken positions that would hurt New York City. He vowed that he would not endorse Mr. Pataki unless the Republican candidate proposed specific fiscal policies that would benefit the city.
Mr. Giuliani has asserted before that Mr. Pataki will have to earn his endorsement by providing details about his governmental approach to New York City. But the Mayor went beyond that yesterday by attacking Mr. Pataki's legislative record. And like an opposing candidate, he did so by plucking specific votes from Mr. Pataki's Senate and Assembly career that he said showed Mr. Pataki "trying to deprive New York City." 
 "I think I'm exercising leadership by requiring the candidate to take positions that will help the people that I have the responsibility of serving," he said on his weekly WABC radio show. "So far, he hasn't done it.
"And this isn't a game," the Mayor said. "If he doesn't, my endorsement isn't there." He also continued to compliment Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who is seeking a fourth term.
The Pataki campaign strategy makes it difficult to satisfy Mr. Giuliani's demand for details. Believing he is ahead, Mr. Pataki is trying to provide few targets for Mr. Cuomo. He does not want to offend conservative upstaters by appearing too accommodating toward New York City. But neither does he want to alienate moderate swing voters by proposing fiscal and social policies that seem too severe. [Page 24.]
Mr. Giuliani's critique marked the second time in three days that a prominent Republican had publicly attacked Mr. Pataki for failing to disclose details about his plan to revive New York's economy. Herbert London, the Republican candidate for state comptroller, expressed similar concerns in a statement released on Wednesday. He, too, has refused to say whether he will endorse Mr. Pataki.
Mr. Giuliani's brinksmanship has infuriated Pataki campaign officials. Drawing out the endorsement has brought unwelcome attention to Mr. Pataki when Republicans want to keep the focus on Mr. Cuomo's Democratic record, several Republican officials said.
Besides criticizing Mr. Pataki yesterday, the Mayor once again had kind words for the Governor. "Some people disagree with things that he has done, as I do in some cases," he said. "But in other areas Mario Cuomo has been very, very good to the city of New York and he has the interests of the city at heart."
Mr. Giuliani's comments on his radio show, which he largely repeated at a civic club luncheon, came on the same day that Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers met with two Pataki aides -- Kieran Mahoney, a strategist, and Michael Finnegan, a campaign counsel -- to discuss the grounds for a possible endorsement. Both camps said only that there would be further talks, without indicating whether Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Pataki might meet anytime soon.
Asked yesterday about Mr. Giuliani's lack of endorsement, Mr. Pataki told reporters that he hoped to win the Mayor's support by continuing to outline his plans. He said he would detail a proposal for tax cuts in about two weeks. Mr. Pataki said that he was taking his time because he wanted to put forth a plan that would work -- a stand he repeated in an address to the Business Council of New York State, meeting in Bolton Landing, N.Y.
"I'm not going to stand up here and take a no-tax pledge," he told the council. "I don't want to release a plan that sounds great in September but you can't carry out in January. I don't want to be George Bush. I want to be Christie Whitman."
The Mayor's continuing refusal to back Mr. Pataki was in pointed contrast to the announcement that Mr. Giuliani planned to fly today to Connecticut to endorse John G. Rowland, that state's Republican gubernatorial candidate. The Mayor has also endorsed two members of Mr. Pataki's ticket, Mr. London and Dennis C. Vacco, the Republican nominee for Attorney General.
As for Mr. Giuliani's motive, many Republican leaders said they were bewildered. Some said they believed that Mr. Giuliani, who faces a new $800 million gap in his $31.6 billion budget, was simply trying to leverage as much state aid for the city as possible. Others said he wanted to indulge two of his closest political friends, David Garth, the media consultant, and Raymond Harding, the Liberal Party chairman, both of whom are working for Mr. Cuomo.
Still others said they believe that Mr. Giuliani is protecting his ability to run for Governor in 1998, which would be difficult if the incumbent is a Republican. And some see Mr. Giuliani's actions as the residue of his longtime feud with Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who is Mr. Pataki's chief political patron.
A number of Republicans pointed out substantial risks in the Mayor's strategy. If Mr. Pataki wins, the Mayor may have poisoned his relationship with the new Governor. And if Mr. Giuliani runs for re-election in 1997, state Republican leaders may pay him back by treating him as coolly as he has treated Mr. Pataki.
Some political strategists say they believe it could be a devastating blow to Republican prospects in November if Mr. Giuliani does not eventually validate Mr. Pataki with an endorsement. Mr. Pataki remains largely unknown to the public, while Mr. Giuliani is highly popular in New York City, where just under a third of the vote is typically cast in gubernatorial elections.
But several Republican leaders predict that the net effect will be marginal because they expect Mr. Cuomo to win a heavy majority in New York City anyway.
"You don't have to be a rocket scientist to know that a pro-New York City platform is going to hurt you elsewhere around the state," said Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island Borough President. "So what does Pataki gain? A relatively small percentage of the votes available to a Republican candidate in New York City as opposed to hemorrhaging in the rest of the state if he adopts such a program."
During his radio show, the Republican Mayor harshly criticized Mr. Pataki for being vague on issues, particularly taxation, and for his proposals on welfare, which Mr. Giuliani said were identical to those put into effect by Mr. Cuomo.
Mr. Giuliani also cited Mr. Pataki's votes in the Legislature against providing financing for the School Construction Authority. And he said that Mr. Pataki had lobbied against providing more state aid to New York City schools, which have about 37 percent of the state's students but receive only 34 percent of the aid.
"He's largely been in favor of maintaining that imbalance," Mr. Giuliani said. "Now he's a candidate for Governor. He has a right, as far as I'm concerned, to change his positions if he wants to because he's now taking over broader responsibilities than just representing his district."
Mr. Giuliani continued: "But he hasn't shown the broader understanding yet. He hasn't said that he's going to act differently than the way he voted two or three years ago that would be against the interests of New York City."

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Aid Haiti To Revive Economy And Monitor Police

 BODY:
The United States will take a series of steps to help Haiti improve its economy, including making a $200 million contribution this year to an international aid effort and increasing the amount of food it is sending to needy Haitians, Administration officials said yesterday.
Restrictions on flights to Haiti and on financial transactions will also be lifted, they said. 
 In the Haitian capital, Port-au-Prince, American military police began their first road patrols.
American military officials met with the Haitian police commander, Lieut. Col. Michel Francois, who is widely held responsible for much of the violence that the police and military, and shadowy civilian gunmen, have inflicted on the population over the last three years. The meeting was held to develop a plan to have American military police monitor Haitian police precincts.
In Washington, Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, sent a reassuring message to the White House, saying that he would reconvene his nation's Parliament so it could consider approving an amnesty for Haiti's military.

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI: IN WASHINGTON;
U.S. Plans $200 Million in Aid for Haiti

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Eager to revive Haiti's moribund economy, President Clinton will soon announce that the United States will contribute about $200 million this year to an international aid effort and will lift the ban on flights and financial transactions with Haiti, Administration officials said today.
And to improve living conditions immediately in the hemisphere's poorest nation, Mr. Clinton announced today that the Agency for International Development would start providing 1.3 million meals a day to needy Haitians, up from the 1 million a day it has been serving in recent weeks. 
 "All these moves should make a big difference," said a senior Administration official. "We want to begin to change the dynamics of Haiti's economy."
President Clinton sought to send a reassuring message today as some members of the House of Representatives maneuvered to set a deadline to pull out American troops. "The situation on the ground has become calmer and more peaceful," he said at a bill-signing ceremony.
At the same time, Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, told the White House that he would reconvene his nation's Parliament so it could consider approving an amnesty for Haiti's military.
Although President Clinton had accused Haiti's military of being thugs and murderers, the negotiations that averted an invasion included an amnesty for crimes by the military. Senior Administration officials applauded Father Aristide's decision because it would reduce tensions in Haiti by spurring reconciliation between the ousted President and the armed forces.
"This is another welcome indication that President Aristide is moving as quickly as possible to put in place an amnesty that will encourage the kind of reconciliation he has spoken about," a senior Administration official said.
Mr. Clinton announced today that hundreds of Haitian refugees being detained at the Guantanamo Bay Naval Station were so encouraged by recent events that they have asked to be returned to Haiti.
Michael McCurry, a State Department spokesman, said that 200 to 300 of the 14,108 Haitians at Guantanamo might be returned to their homeland as early as Sunday.
The international aid effort -- which is designed to provide $550 million over the next year and at least $1 billion over five years -- is unusually large for a country of 6.7 million people, economists said. It is designed to help Haiti across the board, including paying salaries for civil servants, improving ports and building roads, bridges and schools.
Despite the ambitious aid plans, some Administration officials and economists say Haiti has been so devastated by its repressive years of military rule and the three-year international embargo that it could take a year for the country's economy to crawl back to where it was in pre-embargo days -- to move up, in Father Aristide's words, "from misery to poverty." Per-capita income in Haiti is just $250 a year.
One move planned by the Administration is for A.I.D., to hire 50,000 Haitians in public works programs.
As the American military consolidates its control of Haiti, the Administration has focused increasingly on Haiti's desperate economic situation, recognizing that rooting democracy firmly in Haiti is closely tied to improving its economy.
The foreign aid plans were hailed by advisers to Father Aristide. Michael Barnes, his chief American adviser, said in an interview, "The aid is crucial. All of the important efforts of the last few days will be in vain unless the international community can jump-start this new Government and the economy of Haiti."
Several officials said President Clinton might announce the aid package next week, while others said he would probably wait to announce it as part of the celebrations surrounding Father Aristide's return to Haiti, expected shortly after Oct. 15.
"It's a U.S.-led international effort, and it will be time to assure it helps a peaceful transition," said a senior State Department official.
To provide Haiti with the $550 million that economists estimate it needs this year, the United States will provide about $200 million and the World Bank, Inter-American Development Bank and the International Monetary Fund will provide most of the rest, Administration officials said. In subsequent years, Washington's annual aid to Haiti will slip back to about $100 million a year, officials said.
Several senior officials said President Clinton might announce, as early as this weekend, that he would end most of the unilateral sanctions that he ordered against Haiti. These officials said that after conferring with President Aristide, the Administration would allow the resumption of flights and financial transactions between Haiti and the United States.
The Administration would also unfreeze American-based assets of many Haitians, but would continue to freeze assets belonging to the coup leaders and other top military officials. The Administration is looking into continuing to freeze the assets of the army's leader, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, not only until he cedes power, but until he leaves the country.
Under existing United Nations resolutions, the international trade embargo is to remain on Haiti until the military leaders step down.
While the agreement that former President Jimmy Carter negotiated last Sunday with Haiti's military leaders does not call for them to leave Haiti, Secretary of State Warren Christopher continued to hold out that hope the coup leaders would leave. Appearing the NBC "Today" show, he said, "They will probably want to leave the country after President Aristide comes back, and I think that may still happen. That would be our preferred outcome."

Dominican Border Curbs Eased
 SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- The Dominican authorities have eased restrictions on border crossings from Haiti for the first time in months, and Haitians have crowded into marketplaces on the Dominican side, officials said.
The Dominican military said that it had begun to permit Haitians to cross the border on Thursday to obtain food, and that they would be allowed to remain in the Dominican Republic until 6 P.M. daily.
The crackdown on crossings came in May, when the trade sanctions were imposed against Haiti.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Visa Wins a Key Round in Antitrust Suit by Dean Witter

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Visa U.S.A. won a key round in court yesterday in its effort to fend off an antitrust suit brought by Dean Witter, Discover & Company. The suit had been widely watched even beyond the banking industry because of the high damages at stake and the significant legal issues it raised.
A Federal appeals court in Denver yesterday reversed a jury verdict that Visa had violated antitrust laws by prohibiting Dean Witter from issuing Visa cards. Dean Witter said yesterday that it would appeal. 
 In 1990, Dean Witter bought a failed savings and loan in Utah that was a member of Visa from the Resolution Trust Company. It planned to issue a card called Prime Option, which would offer a low interest rate for the first two months after each purchase. The rate would then rise in the third month. Visa discovered the plan only when a plastic card manufacturer reported a large order by Dean Witter. Visa blocked the move on the ground that it violated its bylaws, prompting Dean Witter to sue.
Visa is a nonprofit association of banks that issue credit cards with its brand. Any bank can join with the exception of those owned by Dean Witter and by American Express. Visa argues that these companies are direct competitors to its brand and would have access to its systems and trade secrets.
Visa has also argued that a decision in favor of Dean Witter will imperil any joint venture between businesses, such as the alliance of American auto manufactures meant to compete with Japanese companies.
Dean Witter had contended that Visa's rule unfairly limited competition and denied consumers choice in credit cards.
The appeals court ruling yesterday, however, rejected that argument.
Dean Witter had sought $1 billion in damages to account for its lost opportunity in the credit card business. Were Visa to be forced to pay damages of that size, it could be forced to seek money from its member banks.
Last year, Mastercard International, also an association of banks, reached a settlement with Dean Witter mainly to avoid a potential damage claim. That deal allowed Dean Witter to issue Prime Option cards in conjunction with Nationsbank, which is a Mastercard member.
Analysts said that the impact of loss on Dean Witter was limited because it could still issue cards through Nationsbank and Mastercard.
"From a business point of view, it's not going to have much of an impact on Dean Witter, but they were looking for damages." said Guy Moszkowski, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 5.38 as Market Loses Almost 102 for Week

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market declined yesterday for the fourth consecutive session, and the fifth in six days, as traders continued to worry about another interest-rate increase.
"The mood of the market leaves a lot to be desired, as bulls, bears and Fed watchers all appear to be nervous," said Alan Ackerman, executive vice president of Reich & Company. "And this is taking a toll on confidence and capital commitments." 
 Some investors expect the Federal Reserve to raise rates on Tuesday at the next meeting of its Federal Open Market Committee. If such a tightening action is taken for the sixth time this year, it could slow both the economy and corporate profits, thereby pushing down stock prices. In addition, higher interest rates could lead investors to transfer money to bonds from stocks.
By the closing bell, all three major market indicators were lower. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 5.38 points, to 3,831.75, bringing the blue-chip indicator down almost 102 points for the week. Yesterday the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dropped 1.60 points and the Nasdaq composite index fell 2.98 points.
On the New York Stock Exchange, 1,274 stocks declined and only 891 advanced. Volume was slightly above the year's average, with 300.2 million shares changing hands, compared with 303 million shares on Thursday.
Among the economically sensitive stocks, auto issues were lower amid fears that consumer borrowing might slow down if interest rates are increased. General Motors fell 1 5/8, to 46 5/8; Ford Motor declined 3/8, to 26 5/8, and Chrysler dropped 1, to 43 7/8.
Many transportation stocks were also lower. AMR, the parent of American Airlines, closed at 53 1/8, down 1 1/2; UAL, which owns United Airlines, closed at 91 1/2, down 3/8, and USAir closed at 5 1/8, down 1/8.
Among the special situations, Quaker Oats fell 3 5/8, to 77, on profit taking that followed its 4 1/8 rise Thursday on takeover rumors. Digital Equipment dropped 2 7/8, to 25 7/8, after Paine Webber reduced its rating to "neutral" from "buy." Intel declined 1 1/4, to 63 1/4, as a result of a lowered earnings estimate by Montgomery Securities. And Discount Auto Parts plunged 5 1/4, to 17 3/8, after announcing fiscal first-quarter earnings below analyst estimates.
On the other hand, several small-capitalization biotechnology stocks rebounded after plunging on Thursday when D. Blech & Company, a New York brokerage firm, suspended operations. Six of 13 biotech companies for which D. Blech was the underwriter or leading market maker ended the day on the upside, including New Vision Technology, which gained 1/2, to 4 3/4. D. Blech agreed to sell its accounts and certain assets yesterday to Josephthal, Lyon & Ross.
Gold mining stocks were strong, as the price of gold flirted with $400 an ounce and reached the highest level since 1993. American Barrick was up 1/2, to 26 3/4; Homestake Mining was up 1/2, to 21 7/8, and Echo Bay Mines was up 3/8, to 13 3/4.
International Paper advanced 1 1/4, to 78 1/4, on a day that it announced plans to close four operations and consolidate its packaging product technology near Cincinnati. Union Carbide was another standout by rising 1, to 33 5/8.

HEADLINE: Working to End Landlord Role, New York Faces Hurdles

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Some nights, Diane Dawson lies awake wondering if the noises she hears are drug addicts creeping into the empty apartments scattered throughout her building in Mott Haven, the Bronx. The doorless entrance is like a welcome mat to squatters; because of constant vandalism, the owner has given up trying to keep doors or locks on the building.
Brenda Crandall, who lives with her son and daughter in a seven-unit building in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, never knows if there will be water for their showers in the morning. The superintendent tells her that the aging plumbing system and boiler are almost beyond repair and that he has not been able to get money for a replacement. 
 Beyond the decrepit condition of their buildings, what these tenants share is a common landlord: the City of New York. They live in some of the nearly 3,000 buildings the city has taken over through tax foreclosures.
If Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has his way, they and other tenants will soon be someone else's responsibility. Under the latest in a series of efforts to get the city out of the landlord business, housing officials last week presented a plan to rehabilitate and sell 250 buildings with 2,500 apartments to nonprofit housing groups, local entrepreneurs and the tenants themselves. The buildings represent about 10 percent of the foreclosed residential properties the city has.
It may be be a hard sell. Unlike the big, vacant multifamily apartment buildings that the city successfully recycled in the late 1980's, the vast majority of what the city now owns is much less attractive to potential owners. Many are small buildings, which cost more to administer than larger ones because owners do not get the same economies of scale that landlords of large buildings do. In many cases, they are occupied, which makes renovations much more complicated, and many of the tenants are very poor.
A look inside New York's real-estate portfolio shows thousands of worn-out tenements, rundown brownstones and row houses that have been carved into cramped rooming houses with more tenants than their building's aging systems were built to handle. Although the city has pledged to cover the costs of rehabilitation, the new owners would do the work.
"The easiest stuff to rehabilitate has really been done," said Susan Saegert, executive director of the Housing Environments Research Group at the City University of New York Graduate Center. "What remains is really tough. It will be much harder to do in every way. The buildings are in worse shape, they are occupied, and it will cost more to renovate them."
In addition, new owners will most likely to be dealing with very poor tenants who would have trouble paying the rents new owners would need to recover their investments.
The average annual income of tenants in the buildings is less than $7,000, officials say, far smaller than the $13,000 average income of tenants in the city's housing projects. In fact, some advocates for the poor say that the only way the new landlords can make the buildings profitable is to evict the poorer tenants, who would otherwise have nowhere else to live.
But Kathy Wylde, head of the New York City Housing Partnership, the nonprofit organization that will oversee the new program, said the initiative was the best opportunity for the permanent privatization of this housing stock.
"The city has been owner and manager of some of this housing for almost 20 years," Ms. Wylde said. "Not only has it been a drain on the city but it has kept small owners from building housing markets in their neighborhoods. With our program of technical and financial support for entrepreneurs and the subsidies for tenants, neighborhoods can be revived."
The city has not always been landlord to such a vast number of dilapidated buildings. While it has long had a policy of seizing properties when owners fall seriously behind in property taxes, until the late 1970's most of what it seized was sold off immediately.
But over the years, fewer and fewer buildings were being sold, and in the city's hands, they usually deteriorated.
In the 1980's, the city decided to use foreclosed buildings to help ease the critical housing shortage among working poor families and the homeless. The plan was to make sorely needed repairs and to spend enough money so that new owners could make a profit. But poor planning, shoddy work, cost overruns, lax monitoring and improper maintenance hampered the efforts.
Each failure brought a fresh attempt at finding another way to rid the city of its property, and some programs were successful. Through complete rehabilitations of vacant buildings and partial renovations of occupied buildings, the city sold hundreds of foreclosed buildings containing more than 18,000 apartments in the last 12 years.
But most of the sales involved larger buildings, and what remains in the city's hands, 30,000 units in 3,000 buildings, are mainly very small properties in very bad shape. More than a third of the apartments are in buildings of four units or fewer, and 70 percent are in buildings with 10 units or fewer.
While almost every component of Mr. Giuliani's new program has been tried before, one aspect is new: For the first time, both occupied and vacant buildings will be clustered and sold to the same owner. The city hopes this will encourage block-by-block improvements.
Such cluster sales will allow the city to mix potentially profitable buildings with those whose rents are unlikely to cover their costs. To further assist owners in closing the gap, many of the poorest tenants, officials say, will receive rent subsidies.
Even with renovation subsidies of up to $40,000 an apartment and rent subsidies, some experts are skeptical that the city will find enough qualified buyers. Under the program, new owners must live in or have businesses in the communities where their new buildings are located and have experience in property management and housing renovation.
"Local entrepreneurs are best able to manage these buildings," said Eugene Webb, a principal of one of Harlem's largest real estate companies. "But if it's going to work, whoever takes the buildings will have to have an easier time removing some of the tenants. Some don't pay rent; some tear up apartments. You have to get better tenants."
But Deborah C. Wright, Commissioner of the City Housing Preservation Department, has pledged that no legal tenants will lose their apartments. Other experts suggested that to make the buildings viable, tenants should be more involved in running them.
"There are aspects of the new program which I see as a positive recognition of problems in the past," said Ms. Saegert of City University. "The comprehensive block-by-block strategy is an improvement. But the city is always inventing expensive new programs, churning out one after another, spending time and talent on this instead of trying to find permanent solutions. I am worried that there is not more tenant participation."
Harry DeRienzo, chairman of the Task Force on City-Owned Property, a coalition of housing groups that assists tenants in city-owned buildings, said he was pessimistic about the long-term success of the program and concerned that if it did work it would squeeze out low-income tenants.
"What happens when the city is out of the picture?" he said. "Gradually, the housing opportunities for the working poor will be lost. It is not feasible for for-profit owners to operate housing where tenants earn, on average, less than $7,000 a year. The only way that this program can work is if much of it is eventually rented at market rates."
Most tenants who were interviewed said they did not care who owned their buildings; they just wanted livable conditions.
"I would be willing to pay more rent," Ms. Crandall in Crown Heights said. "But I don't see why I should pay more rent for such a terrible place. The window in my kitchen is broken, the door to my daughter's bedroom is off and sometimes we don't have water."
She said that as far as she knew, no tenant paid more than $300 a month. Two of the seven apartments are vacant. While it is not possible to say what it costs to operate Mrs. Crandall's building, the city spends on average $400 a month in maintenance and operating costs on each foreclosed apartment in its control.
Ms. Dawson, who lives in a 20-unit building in Mott Haven where half the apartments are empty, said she would like her building to be sold to its tenants. A private landlord, she suspects, would find new tenants and raise the rents.
"Over the years, the people who live here have put up with a lot, but we stuck it out," she said. "We don't want to see the buildings turned over to landlords. We want a chance to run them ourselves."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Has Quiet Session, With Focus on Trade Talks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed against most leading currencies yesterday amid signs that negotiators from the United States and Japan had made progress in trade talks.
Progress at the bargaining table would presumably make the Clinton Administration less likely to resume calls for a strong yen, a tactic it pursued last year. A strong yen could help reduce Japan's $60 billion trade surplus with the United States by making Japan's exports more expensive. 
 After meeting with Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, yesterday, the Foreign Minister of Japan, Kyohei Kono, said "the talks were good" and "very detailed." Mr. Kono said there would be more talks today.
Sudhir Patel, foreign-exchange manager at Nationsbank of Texas in Houston, said, "Everyone in the currency market is waiting for results from the trade talks."
Speculation that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates after a meeting of its policy-making committee on Tuesday is also keeping the dollar steady, traders said.
"We're being held captive by the Fed and the trade talks," said Lynn Tierney, vice president at Shawmut Bank of Boston. "A lot of people are afraid to take positions."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar slipped to 97.85 yen, from 98.02 yen on Thursday. The dollar edged up to 1.5486 German marks, from 1.5470 on Thursday
Analysts and traders said the dollar was weak against the yen this week in part because Japanese corporations had been selling American stocks and bonds to improve balance sheets before Sept. 30, the end of the first half of Japan's fiscal year.
"Balance sheets look better with a lot of cash on them," said Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics. "In Japan, cash is king at this time of year."
Mr. Weinberg said the dollar would stand a better chance of gaining against the yen in October, when Japanese corporations will venture back into American asset markets.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Touches $400.70 Mark On Fears of More Inflation

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Gold prices surged above the key $400-an-ounce level yesterday on fears of growing inflation before the market retreated to post only a modest gain.
It was the first time gold had hit $400 since August 1993, but traders said gold's luster might be a factor that could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, which could lure investors back to interest-bearing instruments. 
 "I don't think it's off to the races just yet," said Bernard Savaiko of Paine Webber. "We have a lot of uncertainty coming up next week."
The Fed's policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, will meet on Tuesday to discuss monetary policy.
Gold for December delivery closed 60 cents higher at $399.60 an ounce, after hitting a high of $400.70. Gold has gained $10 since the beginning of the month as investors have reacted to worries about inflation. On average, commodity prices are up 30 percent this year.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 0.64 point, to 232.73.
Among other commodities, silver and copper prices rose, oil prices were up, wheat prices posted another gain and coffee and cocoa were higher.
Silver for December delivery rose 0.5 cent, to $5.74 an ounce, and December copper gained 1.25 cents, to 118.75 cents a pound. Copper's rise has been built on solid demand from industry as global economies have strengthened.
Crude oil, one of the few commodities to have dropped in price in the last year, posted its highest close in more than five weeks.
November crude added 16 cents, to $17.83 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange; October heating oil eked out a gain of 0.01 cent, to 48.55 cents a gallon, and October gasoline dipped 0.26 cent, to 45.77 cents.
A continued lack of rain forecast for Brazil again sent coffee prices up on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, with the December contract 2.1 cents higher at 229.65 cents a pound. December cocoa surged $44, to $1,381 a metric ton.
Egyptian purchases of American wheat again lifted wheat prices. The Agriculture Department accepted a bid from Egypt for 300,000 metric tons of wheat, and the country immediately bid for another 550,000 metric tons.
Egypt and other buyers have turned to the United States for wheat because of drought-hit crops elsewhere, particularly in Australia. Some analysts estimated Australia's crop was about half the size of last year's 18 million metric tons.
December wheat advanced 3.5 cents, to $3.9675 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade.

HEADLINE: Beliefs;
A language barrier at the world population conference involved much more than words.

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
The language spoken at most sessions of the recent International Conference on Population and Development in Cairo was English. But the participants were unknowingly speaking three different languages, said William F. Vendley, executive director of the World Conference on Religion and Peace, who was an official nongovernmental representative at the meeting.
The result, he contends, was sometimes a broadening of perspectives and sometimes sheer Babel. 
 The first of these languages, he said, was the empirical language of demography, public health and international agencies, a language heavy on quantification and immediate problem-solving. It was, he said, the language in which much of the meeting's preparatory documents were drafted and initially discussed.
The second language, he said, was that of religious traditions, a language of moral norms rooted in some larger vision of the common good. It was the language of the Vatican, the imams and many other religious leaders at Cairo.
The third language was the language of specific situations, of sad instances -- rape, destitution, absent or unsafe medical care -- that seemed to challenge the applicability of the existing norms. It was the language of many feminists and religious dissenters at the meeting.
Mr. Vendley speaks from a special perspective. Last July, his organization sponsored a "multi-religious consultation" in Switzerland to look at the draft program for Cairo and explore where major religious traditions might diverge or converge.
Then, on the eve of the Cairo meeting, the group issued an impressive statement. Signed by scholars representing Hinduism, Buddhism, Islam, Bahai, Orthodox Judaism, Protestantism and Catholicism, the statement mixed strong criticism and high praise for the Cairo draft program.
It praised the draft for not framing population issues "in narrow 'demographic' terms" but in connection with the needs and rights of women. The group strongly supported "access to appropriate information and means" regarding birth control. But it no less strongly affirmed "opposition to abortion as a method of family planning."
During the Cairo meeting itself, the World Conference on Religion and Peace, a New York-based organization that promotes cooperative efforts among religions to resolve conflicts, sponsored daily open forums at which people could question panels of religious leaders.
Mr. Vendley recalled a session that illustrated his thesis about the different languages. When several distinguished Muslims presented their tradition's teachings on abortion as perfectly clear and settled, women veiled in traditional fashion ardently questioned the male leaders from the back of the room.
The women challenged the leaders to discuss situations where bearing children meant courting death or devastating shame or family ruin. He suggested that religious traditions could be enriched by these "voices refusing to allow the moral discussion to stop with the declaration of a norm."
Mr. Vendley, 46, who studied and practiced Buddhism in Japan and later taught in Catholic theology schools in the United States, said that all major faiths had developed ways of handling exceptional cases.
Many religious leaders realize this wisdom must continually evolve to encompass new circumstances, he said, but evolve in some way that "extends but does not contradict the tradition's core morality."
On the other hand, he said, deadlock is insured when critics believe that simply citing examples of suffering is enough to rebut a norm, or when religious leaders believe that simply restating the norm is an adequate reply to the suffering.
"The two forms of discourse cannot enrich one another unless people become aware that they are both legitimate but quite different," Mr. Vendley said.
He is more confident, however, that the world's religions have the language to articulate comprehensive visions of social development and the human good that can augment and correct the "somewhat impoverished language" of much economic and population planning.

HEADLINE: Supermarkets for Slums

 BODY:
The Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a nonprofit organization created by the Ford Foundation and located in New York City, has spearheaded over the last 15 years a successful program to rebuild housing in urban slums. The organization's novel approach has been to channel private and public money into community development corporations that take responsibility for reclaiming neighborhoods, often block by block, from drug lords and delinquents.
This week L.I.S.C. launched a second assault on ghetto blight: economic development. It announced commitments by 10 major national corporations, including Prudential, Bank of America, and J. P. Morgan, to contribute $24 million to a fund that will help community development corporations around the country build retail shopping centers. The fund will cover about a third of total development costs. The balance of the money will come from other private lenders and public sources. 
 To buttress the shopping centers, each will be anchored by a major supermarket. L.I.S.C. will start in East Harlem in New York City and later will start retail projects in Philadelphia, Washington, Chicago, Los Angeles, Phoenix and up to eight other cities.
For urban neighborhoods to survive, let alone prosper, residents need more than safe, affordable housing. They need jobs. They also need adequate places to shop. Poor inner-city residents often pay 50 percent more for food and other necessities than do their suburban counterparts. What's more, the quality of what they can buy nearby can be appalling. The retail initiative aims to provide both jobs and shops.
L.I.S.C.'s strategy is to rely on neighborhood development groups. The success of that strategy in housing suggests that it might well work again even in the new and largely uncharted waters of inner-city commerce.

HEADLINE: We Need Thinkers Instead of Memorizers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In all the arguments over what it means to get a degree from the City University of New York (letters, Sept. 15 and 20, and Op-Ed, Sept. 8), we seem to lose sight of the fact that what we really need are flexible, confident, curious and motivated people who can speak, listen, think, read, write, calculate, ask questions, analyze, imitate, work, cooperate, forget the outmoded and learn the job on the job -- very basic skills indeed, the foundation of which can be found in most children. 
 But what we have some trouble using are those passive, bored, demeaned and memorizing drones who have merely gotten through required and uninteresting courses in middle school, high school and college, Ivy or otherwise. Or as John Holt said in "How Children Fail": "The major difference between the good student and the poor one is that the poor student forgets right away while the good one is careful to wait until after the examination."
Now, 85 percent of achievement in life is a function of the socioeconomic background of the family or of success in extracurricular activities or both. But while a degree is one ticket to the credential society, we might recall the year 1900, a period of some quite impressive intellectual, social, scientific and economic progress, when 94 percent of Americans dropped out of school at one level or another.
 
ROBERT E. KAY
Paoli, Pa., Sept. 20, 1994

HEADLINE: U.N. Sex Harassment Hearing Lacked Fairness;
Flawed Institution

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The kind of ordeal described in "Catherine Claxton vs. the U.N." on Sept. 15 is not limited to the United Nations Secretariat. As Women's International Network News has documented and reported for years, all United Nations agencies and international bodies, including the World Bank-International Monetary Fund, the Development Program, the Children's Fund, the World Health Organization, the Food and Agriculture Organization and the International Labor Organization, are exempt from equal-employment laws and thus immune to all sexual harassment and discrimination complaints by women. Ms. Claxton's courage to stand up against this corrupt and obsolete system of employment is to be congratulated. 
 While the United Nations personnel system has rules about "geographic balance" no rules on gender balance exist. The women from overseas and especially from developing countries who work for this system are at the mercy of their male bosses: if they don't "please" the men they are sent back to the country they came from.
The situation is even worse outside the United States, where many of the United Nations agencies, including the Development Program, World Health Organization, the Children's Fund and the Food and Agriculture Organization, maintain offices. Anything goes, as I have had occasion to observe.
While every country that finances these international institutions, especially the United States, has had equal employment laws for decades, the United Nations bureaucracy operates a medieval type of exploitation of women, who are deprived of basic employment rights and human rights as the Claxton case shows.
This situation could be changed if all governments, especially the United States, the chief financial supporter of this system of entrenched discrimination and gender abuse, attached equal employment requirements to financial contributions.
What is especially important is the immediate institution of a system of adjudicating complaints where employment discrimination and sexual harassment complaints are heard and adjudicated independent of male decision makers, who have opposed all attempts to change the system of male power and male privilege that excludes women from positions of power and influence.
Entrenched discrimination is a reason for the ineffective, often badly flawed performance of the United Nations system and its mismanaged agencies.
 
FRAN P. HOSKEN
Editor, Women's International
Network News
Lexington, Mass., Sept. 19, 1994

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 
Legislation to overhaul the nation's telecommunications laws to permit open competition between telephone and cable television companies collapsed in the Senate. The bill's chief sponsor, Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, blamed opposition from the regional Bell companies. [Page 1.]
 
Detroit automotive workers are stressed out, union leaders contend, as the car makers order record overtime to meet demand for cars and trucks. The Big Three auto makers are reluctant to hire more workers, even though they are sacrificing sales. [33.]
 
The F.D.A. proposed requiring scientists to disclose whether they have a financial stake in the outcome of research on drugs being considered for Government approval. [7.]
 
 
Companies
 
Dickstein Partners will end its bid for control of Hills Stores, halting a fight between some of Wall Street's smartest investors. Dickstein, which owns 9.5 percent of Hills' stock, is also ending its demand for a $125 million stock repurchase program. [33.]
 
CBS Inc. is buying small UHF stations in Detroit and Atlanta. The purchase of inexpensive, little-watched properties with no local news reflected pressure to keep its national network intact. [33.]
 
D. Blech & Company's customer accounts and some assets are to be transferred to Josephthal Lyon & Ross, a regional brokerage firm and investment bank. David A. Blech was unable to save his biotech investment boutique from the one-two punch of a sagging market and an onslaught from short-sellers. [33.]
 
Northwest Airlines is abandoning its attempt to equip planes with interactive video because some units have been unreliable. Virgin Atlantic Airways and China Airlines also said the interactive systems on their planes were having problems. [33.]
 
Western Union Financial Services will fetch $1.193 billion from First Financial Management, an Atlanta company that won a bankruptcy auction for it, Judge Novelyn L. Winfield of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Newark ruled. [35.]
 
Borden signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company for $2 billion. [35.]
 
Visa U.S.A. won a round in court, when a Federal appeals court in Denver reversed a jury verdict that Visa had violated antitrust laws by prohibiting Dean Witter, Discover & Company from issuing Visa cards. Dean Witter said it would appeal. [35.]
 
 
Markets
 
Gold prices briefly surged above the key $400-an-ounce level on fears of growing inflation, but closed at $399.60 an ounce. [44.]
 
Treasury bond prices fell, sending the yield on the long bond up to 7.79 percent. The gold price rise fueled concern that inflation would accelerate and the Fed would raise rates again. [41.]
 
The stock market declined for a fourth consecutive session, and the fifth in six days, on interest-rate worries, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down 5.38 points to 3,831.75. For the week, the loss was almost 102 points. [34.]
 
The dollar was little changed amid signs of progress in trade talks between the United States and Japan. [44.]
 
Your Money
 
Investors should never buy stocks from brokers they do not know, S.E.C. officials say. Former employees of Stratton Oakmont, which settled S.E.C. charges, are now working at other aggressive firms that the S.E.C. calls boiler rooms. [31.]
 
Bonds issued by emerging nations are being snatched up by managers of a dozen new mutual funds, who say they see great growth ahead. Investing. [31.]
 
There are no simple rules for how much life insurance to buy. The basic purpose is to be sure that if a breadwinner dies, dependents will have enough money, and family circumstances vary. [32.]

HEADLINE: The Decline and Fall of the Russian Empire

BYLINE: By Bill Keller; Bill Keller, previously the Moscow bureau chief of The New York Times, is now the Johannesburg bureau chief.

 BODY:

IMPERIUM
By Ryszard Kapuscinski.
Translated by Klara Glowczewska.
331 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24. 
IT is not quite right to call Ryszard Kapuscinski a cult figure. His books are translated into 19 languages. His adoring book-jacket blurbs come from big names. His reviews are enviable. Still, he is one of those writers whose works are hard to find in chain bookstores but are objects of devotion in the home libraries of journalists and writers, who know from their own researches that his places and people are true, and who know that what he does is much harder than it looks.
For many years the pre-eminent foreign correspondent of the Polish Press Agency, Mr. Kapuscinski writes contemplative travelogues of wars, coups and societies in various states of upheaval. He is a kind of mosaicist, piecing together vignettes and encounters and trip notes and snippets of history until they add up to something rich. The book best known in the United States, "The Soccer War," is a sampler of dispatches from the third world, but even his two quasi-biographies, of the Ethiopian ruler Haile Selassie ("The Emperor") and the Shah of Iran ("Shah of Shahs"), are artful salades composees of oral history and observation rather than conventional portraits. This kind of reporting succeeds because Mr. Kapuscinski is an enchanting guide, combining boundless stamina, felicitous writing, childish curiosity and the literate authority of a true intellectual. In addition, his dispatches from Africa, Latin America and the Middle East, and especially his profiles of tyrants, were spiced by the subversive implications they contained for his own, then-sequestered society.
"Imperium," capably translated by Klara Glow czewska, compiles his journalistic travels into Russia and its colonies from 1958 until the early 1990's. The format is the same as in his earlier books -- the musings of a literate wanderer -- but the result is inevitably different.
Foreign correspondents often fantasize about going home to investigate their own countries with the distance and perspective of well-informed outsiders. It almost never works, because home is too much in us, and because the reporter knows he is now writing about his reader. For Mr. Kapuscinski and his first audience, the Poles, the Imperium, the former Soviet empire, is home, or awfully close. His opening chapter is a boyhood recollection of the Russians overrunning his hometown, Pinsk, then in eastern Poland, in 1939. He describes the boxcars of suspected wrong-thinkers singled out for deportation, the drunken Bolsheviks bombarding the city's great church with their cannon. It is a moving story, but it is also fair warning that what follows is not the detached reporting of his earlier works.
Because Mr. Kapuscinski is such a keen observer, there are treasures in this book. His visit to Vorkuta, the arctic mining and gulag city, is a triumphant combination of bleak history and black comedy. His account of feckless coal miners trying to organize themselves, but failing because only the bosses know how to run meetings, is a wonderful miniature of Russia's pratfalls in the theater of new democracy.
He mines wisdom from the excruciating dailiness of Soviet life: how the spirit of the Russian village survives in urban apartment blocks, how the art of asking questions atrophies in a totalitarian state. He renders perfectly the bedlam of the Yerevan airport; the uniquely Soviet absurdity of a mosque converted to a billiard parlor; the mutual incomprehension of the new Russian democrats and their Western counterparts. He sums up the militarized Soviet economy with a sardonic conceit: Why is it impossible to buy a hoe in Smolensk? Because the entire metallurgy industry is busy making barbed wire for the borders and concentration camps.
Perhaps because he believes Russia is inexorably mired in its history, he writes rather more of the past than the present. He tours the Stations of the Terror -- catacombs for secret prayer in Moldova, mass graves in Ukraine, gulag sites in Vorkuta and Magadan. He cites extensive passages from indigenous memoirs, all of which he seems to have read. His history is often vividly told. In Mr. Kapuscinski's version, the story of the Church of Christ the Saviour in Moscow, built by the czars in 45 years and demolished by Stalin in four months, is a chilling evocation of Bolshevik despotism. But one finishes this book feeling the author has communed more with the spirits of the dead than with the living.
About the Russians, he writes with the condescension of a European intellectual for the benighted Eastern peasants. Mr. Kapuscinski's Russians, except for a few dissident intellectuals held up as a rebuke to the nation, are willfully ignorant, joyless, expansionist in their instincts, servile in their acceptance of tyranny. Mr. Kapuscinski seems to agree with the Marquis de Custine, an earlier peripatetic in the Imperium, who wrote in 1839: "Men have adored the light, the Russians worship the eclipse: when will their eyes be opened?"
In contrast, he dotes on the colonized minorities. He is thrilled about the prospects of independent Ukraine (an optimism many Ukrainians have lost, as reflected in their recent election of a president who promises greater economic solidarity with Russia), and he waxes romantic about the historical consciousness of the Armenians -- although their virulent hatred of the Azerbaijanis finally drives him to a disclaimer on the folly of extreme nationalism. He seems to relish the prospect that Russia, having lost its outer colonies, will itself be pried to pieces by its Bashkirs, Yakuts and other minorities.
"Imperium" is full of infuriating loose ends. "Television gave to perestroika a dimension that no other event in the history of the Imperium had ever had," he observes, correctly. Then he drops the subject. He describes a journey back to his childhood home in Pinsk, now in the independent state of Belarus. After announcing his arrival, he tells us nothing about the place.
The book peters out with a chapter summing up the Gorbachev era. It is a disheartening muddle of historical synopsis, trite academic generalizations and term-paper notes -- the two theaters of perestroika, the three stages of social revolution, the three processes that "will come to predominate in Russian life." "And the future?" he writes, as the reader winces. "A difficult question." I like to think this chapter was the idea of a misguided editor who hoped to package the book as more than the sum of its parts, without realizing that a Kapuscinski book is already that.
 
 
 
'YOU HAVE TO GO OUTSIDE MOSCOW'
 Ryszard Kapuscinski is drawn to situations that repel other people: ethnic wars, the dissolution of nations, border conflicts between hostile cultures. "The border is the main problem of the end of our century," he said in a telephone interview. "Without abolishing borders we will never be able to solve the problems of our culture."
Mr. Kapuscinski is spending a year in Berlin on a cultural grant before returning to his home in Warsaw, although he is never anywhere for very long. He said he was compelled to begin the travels (of nearly 40,000 miles) that became "Imperium" when he realized that the Soviet Union was teetering and that the Western press would report on it exclusively from the capital. "To know something about the Soviet Union you have to go outside Moscow," he explained. "You must show what has happened on two levels: the level of Moscow and the level of the common Russian life. My book is all about this tension, this conflict, this contradiction."
The 62-year-old writer recognizes that something is lost when even the most repressive nations implode. "People in the West think that if the culture of Central Europe disappeared, that would be O.K. But it would be as if Venice were destroyed. You'd never be able to reconstruct it." TOBIN HARSHAW
