HEADLINE: Martha in Present Tense

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING 

 BODY:
THEY CAME FROM ALL OVER THE country in the 1930's to study and perform with a woman they knew little of, a woman whose dances were so starkly geometric that wags speculated that if she gave birth it would be to a cube. The woman was Martha Graham. The dancers were part of an early Graham company referred to simply as the Group. Together they worked long hours filled with exaltation and despair, love and anger and, most of all, the sense that something new and important was being done. Dance in America was growing and changing. Martha Graham was in the vanguard of that change with dances that were, like her, impossible to ignore.
Some of those dances will be performed in "Radical Graham," a two-week season of performances by the Martha Graham Dance Company that opens the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday. The event, which marks the centennial anniversary of Graham's birth, includes dances from the 1920's to 1958 and a few more recent pieces. 
 Each is the creation not only of one of the great innovators in American cultural history but also of her dancers, women like Dorothy Bird, Sophie Maslow, May O'Donnell, Jane Dudley and Yuriko, a member of the generation that carried the flame after the revolution. Now in their 70's and 80's, all five went on to marriages, families and other careers in dance. But Martha, as they called her, remains a vivid presence in their lives. Often jumping up to demonstrate choreography, they occasionally slipped into the present tense in recent conversations about Graham, as if she were still alive and working. This is what they remembered.
 
DOROTHY BIRD
(Danced with Graham from 1931 to 1937)
As a teen-ager Dorothy Bird studied dance at the Cornish School of Fine and Applied Arts, an influential experimentalist academy in Seattle. "I came from Victoria, up in Canada," she recalled. "My brother went to the Cornish School. He suggested I talk to Miss Cornish. She asked if I knew about Martha Graham. I said I never heard of her. She slipped a very severe photograph of her over to my mother. I said, 'She looks like a horse.' Then I quickly said, 'But I love horses, their velvety noses.' "
Miss Bird was enrolled in the first session of Graham's summer course at the school, taught with Louis Horst. A plump, cigar-smoking composer and influential dance theorist with a roving eye, Horst was Graham's accompanist, lover and mentor.
Even the first class was memorable. "Martha always used to make everyone wait," said
Miss Bird. "Then she walked in with great presence, with Louis behind her and Miss Cornish fluttering around her. I instantly felt comfortable with her. I had seen Pavlova. She had put her hand on my shoulder and kissed my forehead. Martha was very much like that. The same tremendous sense of power."
Graham, then in her early 30's, gathered her students around and talked about how to steal the audience by standing still on stage. But first they had to remove their ballet shoes.
"Ballet was out, finished, never to be mentioned again or thought of. Then she told us to stand with our feet three inches apart and imagine railroad tracks stretching ahead and behind us. 'You're pioneers,' she said to us.
"Martha went through every inch of our bodies. She went through percussive movement and sustained movement. She went through breathing. For each thing she had a whole way of catching your imagination, much of the time with images of animals and machinery. 'Like a train,' she'd say. 'Like a piston.' She had us shouting 'No!' then sobbing and hiding our grief.
"Then she told us that for dessert we would do laughter. She had us laughing so much that we pushed each other into somersaults and fan kicks.
" 'The Chinese think laughter is a very healthy thing,' she said. 'But we will not do it again. You have it in your muscular memory now. You will put it in muscles -- if it's in your rib cage, now you can put it in your knees -- so it's a secret. The audience will be terribly intrigued.' "
When Miss Bird returned for the second session, she found Graham sitting on the boat, coming back from a weekend in Victoria. "I got frightened. I said hello, then ran like a thief, but it was bitterly cold outside. I had to go back inside. 'Come to New York,' she told me. We would figure out how to do it. We took a cab from the boat to her apartment. 'Wait for me,' she said. 'I have something I want to give you. Keep it for three days and then return it.' " It was a magical necklace of Indian silk, and the shy young dancer fell asleep that night breathing its sweet scent.
The red-cheeked, blond young innocent soon followed Graham to New York with $20 in her pocket, which seemed a great deal of money. She got three part-time jobs in one day but failed at each. Pressed into studying choreography with Horst, she endured yet another disaster.
"I came into the class with my first prepared thing. He put his cigar aside, puffed a huge puff of smoke out and said, 'Well, are you pregnant?' "
Miss Bird wanted to dance, and she did. But new dancers eventually arrived. "I was always in the back, going up and down. I got very jealous," she admitted. "Then somebody woke me up to the fact that I was enslaved.
"I was driving Martha in her little car one day, up Fifth Avenue. And she said, 'Are you staying?' I turned my head, side to side. 'Are you leaving?' I moved my head up and down. Big tears came down her face. She got out of the car at 42d Street, into traffic. I had to drive on.
"Much later she told me, 'You know, I do work on the ones I love, and then they leave.' There were tears in her eyes. I don't think she knew she ate you up. And what you had lost its flavor."
 
SOPHIE MASLOW
(Danced with Graham from 1931 to 1944)
Sophie Maslow, who was born in New York, studied with Graham and Horst as a teen-ager at the Neighborhood Playhouse in a group that included Anna Sokolow and Jean Rosenthal, the pioneering lighting designer. "I was sold on Martha right away," Miss Maslow remembered. "I believed in what she was doing.
"True, I had sore muscles all the time. Her class was not balanced. She'd do what she was interested in at the time, to develop her technique. The reason for doing her movement was, it was valid emotionally."
Once in the Graham company, Miss Maslow started learning "Primitive Mysteries," a ritual of bracing simplicity for a Virgin-like figure and her female acolytes. Even then the masterwork had a special feeling. But it was a memorable start for another reason. "The first rehearsal I came to, Martha threw a book at Louis," said Miss Maslow.
Classes and rehearsals began early in the day and continued into the evening. "Always before a premiere, if the costumes were finished they would have to be ripped apart and remade. Mostly they were not finished. We would sit on the floor, and Martha would fit us. Jersey dresses. She would pin them on, then we would pull them off and sew them. I think that jersey was one of her contributions to costuming."
The dancers were all women until 1938, when Erick Hawkins, who married Graham 10 years later, joined the company. Graham divided the women into tall, medium and short performers. Other than that, there seemed no common denominator.
"Once a father asked Martha why his daughter had not been invited to join the company," Miss Maslow said. " 'She has no pedestal,' Martha told him.
"It was a time of unemployment, of the rise of the unions, of marches in the street and the Spanish Civil War," recalled Miss Maslow. "Martha was working on a new way of moving. I think all of those things must have been part of it. The outside world was part of her sensibility. When I see the old dances, the power and strength with which we moved reminds me of the women's movement today. 'Steps in the Street,' a section of 'Chronicle,' was to me like Picasso's 'Guernica,' " said Miss Maslow, who is helping to reconstruct "Chronicle" for the "Radical Graham" festival. "But she never did anything directly applicable to the specific situation. 'Chronicle' could apply to any war."
 
MAY O'DONNELL
(Danced with Graham from 1932 to 1938 and 1943 to 1953)
Born in Sacramento, May O'Donnell had had some dance training and performance experience when she left for New York to study the technique of the German Expressionist choreographer Mary Wigman. Disappointed in the Wigman classes, she moved on to Graham. "I was afraid of her temper, so I was cautious with her, though the New York girls didn't seem to mind," said Miss O'Donnell. "But I can understand better now in retrospect that she was in a struggle to get a foothold and carry on.
"It was a time when modern dance was beginning to definitely -- and desperately -- create its own identity in the whole wave of modernism in the arts. To make it different than ballet, modern dance was on the extreme side in that period. It had to be. Martha's technique was not too lush or decorative. It did what you had to do to move. The technique was very right for the kind of dances Martha was doing at that time, which were on the stark side and so controlled."
In 1934 an important place to exchange ideas about modern dance was created with the founding of the Bennington School of Dance at Bennington College, in Vermont, the forerunner to the American Dance Festival. During the Bennington summers, Graham came upon more experienced and better trained dancers. She began to think of working with men. Her technique developed in a new direction. "Modern dance was feeling its way, beginning to open up and move fast," said Miss O'Donnell. "It felt it had found, I think, a secure enough base. Martha's movement got a little more opulent and not quite so restrained."
By 1938 Miss O'Donnell was disgusted with the atmosphere of constant fighting. She became self-conscious around Horst after hesuddenly put his hand on her knee one night. She took off, leaving a note behind. But five years later Graham persuaded her to return to perform special parts.
"I think she had the Pioneer Woman in mind," said Miss O'Donnell of her role in "Appalachian Spring." "Everything was much fuller by then, not only in the use of the body but in the insinuation of what movement could do. There was still lots of fighting going on in the studio. But it was very easy to work with Martha. I could kind of sense what she wanted and what I was in relation to the piece. She didn't tell me anything about the Pioneer Woman. I put it together: a stable, forever thing that was always there, that could see futures, see the present."
In "Herodiade," she understood, Graham portrayed the eternal artist who animates all cultures, while she, as the Attendant, was the "earth person" who could never enter that realm. Few words were necessary. And Graham's silence conferred a peculiar privilege. "It gave me the power to keep things alive," said Miss O'Donnell.
"I remember sitting on stage as the Pioneer Woman. Martha rushed up to my little platform, turned and handed me something. It was a baby." Miss O'Donnell cradled the imaginary infant, making a first appearance in the dance. Later she teased Graham, who played the Bride. "Martha, you just got married!" she said. Graham, who confided to very few that she was unable to have children, smiled. "Oh, that was my dream baby," she said. And the baby remained.
 
JANE DUDLEY
(Danced with Graham from 1935 to 1946 and 1953 to 1970)
Though best known for her portrayal of the formidable Ancestress in "Letter to the World," Jane Dudley created the role of one of the two Bronte sisters in "Deaths and Entrances" (Miss Maslow danced the other Bronte role). The daughter of a dance teacher in Westchester, Miss Dudley had been warned by her mother and the modern dance pioneer Ruth St. Denis against becoming involved with Graham, whose work, St. Denis said, was "not beautiful." But it was not long before Miss Dudley joined the Group.
"Martha choreographed for herself. There was absolutely no doubt about her complete narcissism. We all learned by osmosis. She never taught us. But to listen to her was a very deep experience. Once, working on 'American Document' in 1938, she got up from the floor and improvised a study of about one minute for three women. We had to follow behind and pick it up from beginning to end. It was very angry, the anger and the desperation of total poverty. Martha had an amazing ability to know changes in the Zeitgeist around her," Miss Dudley said.
Miss Dudley and Miss Maslow argued over which Bronte sister each would play in "Deaths and Entrances." "But it didn't matter much because we were her sisters," said Miss Dudley. "It was a reconstruction of her family."
 
YURIKO
(Danced with Graham from 1944 to 1967)
Born in Sacramento and trained in Japan, Yuriko (who used only her first name on stage) brought a new quickness and lightness into the repertory through roles created for her, like the doomed young Princess in "Cave of the Heart."
"I came East from a relocation center in Arizona in 1943 to further my career," she said. "I had just secured a job as a seamstress. I had addresses for three studios. I was standing at 14th Street and Fifth Avenue, and Martha's studio was the closest. So I knocked on the door, and there she was.
"I still remember my first class. It was like a meditation hall, it was that quiet. Martha would get angry in class, but she was never nasty. She was poetic, in explaining. She brought in poetry, painters, music and very much philosophy, her beliefs, what she read. She was very, very stern. She was constantly walking around the class, watching each plie. You felt the presence, even if you couldn't see her. It was just amazing, her extraordinary power.
"Of course, we didn't get paid for rehearsals. For a while it was $10 a performance. But if you didn't perform, you didn't get paid."
Graham began to relinquish her roles in 1965, at the age of 71, some of them to Yuriko. She almost never came to rehearsals and gave Yuriko little help. It was a painful time in Graham's life. Drinking too much, she was slowly pulling away from the company. Sometimes she winced when she heard music she had once danced to.
"Martha was so intensely involved in her roles, though she always made her feelings into universal themes. Obviously 'Appalachian Spring' is about her and Erick. She had a question -- many, many questions -- about going into marriage, and the dance came out of the turmoil."
"Primitive Mysteries" was more abstract, and Graham at first ignored Yuriko at the single rehearsal she came to, two days before Yuriko was to dance the role of the Virgin Mary for the first time.
Yuriko picked up clues from what Graham told the women's chorus. Then suddenly Graham moved close and began to whisper to the young dancer, her voice taking on something of the character's pain and exaltation.
"You know, you're going to see your son," Graham murmured. "You don't want to go." Yuriko's hands flew up to cup her eyes as she remembered that gesture in the dance. "As adults, we never cry straight," Graham told her. "When you cry, it's a little to the left or right. The pull is to one side or the other, within oneself. Yuriko, when I saw my son, everything drained. And I swayed an infinitesimal sway. I was swaying, but no one saw me."
Was Graham truly a radical? "Martha was very practical," Yuriko said. "I don't think she thought that way."

SECTION: Section 5; Page 12; Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: EUROPE: THE NEW SEASON;
A City of Many Stages

BYLINE: By BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE 

 BODY:
FOR the American visitor, theatergoing in London normally means trawling the commercial West End for treasure, with side trips to see the great state-subsidized troupes -- the Royal Shakespeare Company and the National Theater itself. That's fine, but it is sometimes worth extending the search by the odd mile or so. What about a visit to Islington or Notting Hill or Shepherd's Bush or Swiss Cottage or Hammersmith or Greenwich or some other place that may well sound like a subway stop in nowhere-in-particular, but actually allows you a serendipitous ramble before you see a play that may well end up on Shaftesbury Avenue or even Broadway?
More details in a moment. First, let me do the conventional thing and pick some obvious plums from the metropolitan pie. The tabloids will probably make a particular fuss over Cameron Mackintosh's big Dickensian revival of Lionel Bart's infinitely hummable "Oliver!," in which Jonathan Pryce, late of "Miss Saigon," plays the satanic Fagin; it is expected to open at the Palladium on Dec. 8. The snobbier critics, however, will be awaiting an event a month earlier, on Nov. 4: Peter Hall's first production of "Hamlet" since he directed Albert Finney in the play 20 years ago and, with it, the rechristening of one of the West End's most famous theaters. 
 The Globe opened its doors on Shaftesbury Avenue in 1906, and since then has given house room to new plays by Somerset Maugham, Noel Coward, Graham Greene, Terence Rattigan and Peter Shaffer, as well as to performances by actors from Alec Guinness to Peggy Ashcroft, Paul Scofield to Ralph Richardson to the theatrical knight who has just celebrated his 90th birthday, Sir John Gielgud. It is, in fact, that eminent nonagenarian who is now giving his name to the place. Calling the theater the Gielgud will avoid getting it confused with the replica of Shakespeare's Globe, which will be opening next August south of the Thames in what was once Elizabethan bear-baiting territory. It is also particularly apt that the retitling should coincide with "Hamlet," for back in the 1930's Sir John played what is still rated one of the century's sweetest, most sensitive princes. His counterpart in Hall's production, Stephen Dillane, made a strong impression as the AIDS victim Prior Walter in Tony Kushner's "Angels in America" at the National, but he clearly has daunting comparisons to face.
The West End's impresarios are less pessimistic than usual, thanks to an improving British economy and a larger-than-expected influx of foreign visitors this summer, and some are even managing to overcome their fear of new work and unproven dramatists. In particular, much is expected of "Neville's Island," by Tim Firth, which opens at the Apollo on Oct. 3. The play, a comedy about middle managers doggedly surviving a company-organized adventure holiday, has been a big success at the tiny theater in the seaside resort of Scarborough, which is run by a more established dramatist, Alan Ayckbourn.
Shaftesbury Avenue is, however, still dauntingly dependent on revivals. A production of William Gibson's touching if clunky celebration of the Helen Keller case, "The Miracle Worker," recently arrived at Wyndhams, and has now been joined by a lavish one of Oscar Wilde's "Lady Windermere's Fan" at the Albery and, at the Globe, a sound, solid production of Terence Rattigan's "Winslow Boy," a 1946 play about a naval cadet unjustly accused of forgery. A revival of "Arsenic and Old Lace" is expected to follow later in the fall (though the theater has yet to be announced). "The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie" will open at the Strand on Oct. 25, with Patricia Hodge playing the Edinburgh schoolmistress first brought to life by Maggie Smith.
Do you recall Dame Maggie's precious manner, prim Scottish vowels and superb comic timing, if not on the stage at least in the movie version of Muriel Spark's novel? At least one of those qualities should be offered in the West End this fall, for she is leading a strong cast in the London production of Edward Albee's "Three Tall Women" at Wyndhams, opening on Nov. 1. That play, a huge success off Broadway, should give her the opportunity to demonstrate her talent for the wan and the droll, the witty and the desolate.
The pick of the impending arrivals at the National and at the Royal Shakespeare Company's London headquarters, the Barbican, are neither revivals nor new plays. They are adaptations and, if you look no further than their titles, rather unsurprising, conventional ones. But "Alice's Adventures Under Ground," which opens at the National on Nov. 8, actually comes with the warning "Not recommended for children under 12." It is clear that the author, Christopher Hampton, will be using Lewis Carroll's writings to explore the darker side of a man whose private feelings for little girls were hardly the most wholesome.
Similarly, "A Christmas Carol" seems an unadventurous choice for the Barbican in December. (It opens Dec. 6.) Marley's ghost is to be found clanking his chains and Scrooge rasping "Humbug" on the stage of every other repertory company around that time. But the R.S.C. radically rethought another Yuletide stalwart, "Peter Pan," a few years back, and may do the same with Dickens's most hackneyed story. The adaptor, John Mortimer, is a noted wit, and the director, Ian Judge, recently transformed Shakespeare's "Comedy of Errors" into a surreal frolic that might have been created by Dali and de Chirico; so the omens are not bad.
BUT I and my fellow enthusiasts will be spending a lot of time this fall at less-exalted addresses. We will be keeping a special eye on the Royal Court in Sloane Square, for its new director is the 32-year-old Stephen Daldry, who won a Tony this year for his revival of "An Inspector Calls." He is presenting no fewer than six premieres on his main stage and in the attic theater above it, as well as a minifestival of works by untried writers. On Nov. 2 he opens his own production of "Editing Process," by the unknown Meredith Oakes, about the publishing trade.
We will also be expecting much of the little Donmar Warehouse in Covent Garden, whose fortunes are being transformed by an even younger director. Sam Mendes, still only 28, has turned the place into a theatrical pacemaker in the aging heart of the West End, thanks to work as diverse as Brian Friel's "Translations" and Stephen Sondheim's "Assassins." A revival of Sam Shepard's "True West," opening Nov. 10, with the fast-rising Mark Rylance in the lead, is sure to get plenty of attention. But so will the offerings of the Almeida, in Islington, the Bush, the Gate, Riverside Studios, Hampstead Theater, Greenwich Theater and several other seemingly obscure playhouses.
These are the places where we expect to be startled and exhilarated these days. These are the theaters where things start small and sometimes end big. No new play has received better reviews this year than a gay coming-out comedy called "Beautiful Thing," by the unknown Jonathan Harvey; it was first staged by the Bush, a pub-playhouse in Shepherd's Bush, was taken up by the Donmar and is reopening at the Duke of York's, in the West End, on Sept. 26. The Almeida, a Salvation Army citadel that became a toy factory then a theater, recently moved Euripides' "Medea" with Diana Rigg to Shaftesbury Avenue, then to Broadway. On Nov. 3, it is staging the British premiere of Brian Friel's "Molly Sweeney," a play about a resilient blind woman, which got some ecstatic reviews when it opened in Dublin in August.
In addition, with Doug Lucie's "Gaucho," a new play about a British drug baron, opening Oct. 24 at Hampstead Theater, near the Swiss Cottage Underground station; the formidable Scottish actor Brian Cox in Ibsen's "Master Builder," from Nov. 10 at Riverside, five minutes' walk from central Hammersmith; a revival opening Nov. 7 at Greenwich of "Song at Twilight," Noel Coward's rarely performed, semiautobiographical play about a homosexual thespian in old age, and intriguing oddments at the Gate, the Bush and elsewhere, I don't think I shall have too much time to be bored this fall.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Survey Shows C.D.W.'s Raise Rentals 46 Percent

 BODY:
Collision damage waivers for rental cars cost an average of $11 a day in a survey of 32 cities conducted recently by the United States Public Interest Research Group. The waivers' cost increased the base price of an economy-car rental an average of 46 percent a day for a weekend rental.
Collision damage waivers are optional provisions in a car rental contract that relieve the customer from responsibility for damage or loss, if the terms of the contract are met. Because such waivers are often not mentioned when customers make reservations for car rentals on the telephone, "consumers often first hear about C.D.W. at the rental counter, when they do not have the time to research their existing coverage or compare prices with other rental companies," the report noted. 
 The survey was conducted in July and August and results were reported earlier this month by the United States P.I.R.G., the national lobbying office for state organizations, which are nonprofit consumer and environmental-advocacy groups.
Researchers called 229 rental agents at eight national car rental companies requesting information on an economy car. They first asked about the rental rate, cost of gas and mileage, then added, "Are there any other fees or taxes I should know about?" At that point, only 7 percent of the agents mentioned the waivers. That figure is, however, an improvement over a 1991 survey in which only 2 percent of agents mentioned the C.D.W. without prompting.
Illinois and New York have passed laws that eliminate the sale of C.D.W.'s.

HEADLINE: Meet the New Super Super Of the High-End Residence

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
THE classic image of a building superintendent is the jack-of-all-trades handyman who can fix the plumbing, run the boiler and handle minor repairs -- the guy who would run down to the basement with a big wrench and twist the big bolt.
Joseph Mazzucco is an example of the new breed -- the super supers, or, as they are increasing called, resident managers -- who are taking over in the larger luxury residential buildings. 
 Mr. Mazzucco, 42, received a degree in electrical technology from City College. He set up the engineering department and started the preventive maintenance program at the Hotel Macklowe in Manhattan; worked as an engineer at Merrill Lynch's data processing center on West Street, maintaining the air-conditioning system for computer trading in a million-square-foot building, and ran the engineering department at the Brookdale Medical Center complex in Brooklyn.
Now Mr. Mazzucco is building superintendent of the Alexandria, a 202-unit luxury condominium at Broadway and 72d Street.
"Today's super tends to be far more educated than in the past because buildings have become far more complicated," said Anthony E. Malkin, president of W & M Properties and co-project manager of the Alexandria. "In the new environmental era, supers need to know more about the complexities of central air systems. Computer skills are also increasingly important. And with residents more demanding, and often owning their premises or a stake in the building, supers must be more sophisticated about human relations. The super is becoming much more of a manager, much more of a professional."
Bill Martin, resident manager at 45 East 89th Street, a 250-unit "condop" -- the residential units are co-ops, the commercial areas condominiums -- said the number of his colleagues with advanced training had increased markedly in recent years.
"The day-to-day pressures in the industry have placed more and more demands on us," said Mr. Martin, who has a Bachelor of Science degree in education from the State University of New York at Buffalo and has been a resident manager for 14 years. "In the last five years there has been an absolute need to show that we are indeed trained. Without additional education and certification, we fall behind the industry too quickly and place ourselves and the people we work for in a certain level of jeopardy.
"As the laws change we have to keep ourselves up to date and current with all our responsibilities. For instance, as of Nov. 14 anyone who handles refrigerant will have to have an additional license."
The term superintendent is being phased out in better buildings, he said; in fact, Local 32B-32J has a separate contract for resident managers, those who run Class A buildings, which are defined as co-ops, condominiums and rentals with a minimum of seven staff members. (The contract provisions are pretty much the same as those for working superintendents.)
"BUT even though my title is resident manager and I have duties that exceed those of a typical superintendent, most people in the building refer to me as a superintendent," said Mr. Martin, who has both Accredited Resident Manager and Registered Apartment Manager certification and is employed by Rose Associates. "I'm comfortable with being called a superintendent. It describes my role."
Salaries for superintendents vary greatly. At Douglas Elliman, a highly qualified superintendent, or resident manager, can earn anywhere from $50,000 to $80,000 a year. He also receives an apartment rent-free, including all utilities -- gas, electricity, telephone -- and he may also be given a free parking space and a bonus.
And then there are the cash gratuities he is likely to get from tenants in the course of performing his duties.
Vincent Sultana, asset manager of W & M Properties, said that industrywide in New York, superintendent salaries could go as high as $85,000, plus benefits.
A decade or two ago, Mr. Malkin said, supers had to "make sure the trash was taken out, make sure the building works, make sure the staff is behaving and handle any plumbing problems." But then, he said, a decade or two ago "most buildings didn't have things like heat-pump units, highly efficient and more sensitive gas systems, booster pumps instead of water tanks, swimming pools, health-club facilities and common areas for entertainment."
Then there are the relatively new and complex city laws involving asbestos, facade maintenance and access for the disabled. "You need specific training to be an asbestos monitor," he said, "to know how to deal with an asbestos emergency. And asbestos air monitoring is now quite often the super's job."
In addition, new laws require the recapture of spent refrigerant from package heating and air-conditioning units -- in the past it could just be vented into the air -- and special training is required for licensing and certification.
"The level of compliance with city laws, Buildings Department codes and landmarking has really substantially changed the management business over the last 20 years," said J. Brian Peters, a vice president at Douglas Elliman-Gibbons & Ives. "It has evolved from being a very low-tech kind of thing, wandering around buildings once a week to see if things were going all right, into a much more professionally oriented business."
And the evolution is reflected in the type of person chosen as the building superintendent.
Mr. Mazzucco oversees a staff of 14 at the Alexandria: 8 concierge or door staff people, 4 porters and 2 handymen. He is employed by the condominium -- the individual owners and the management company, Akam Associates Management -- and he attends every meeting of the condominium's board, advising the members on cost decisions.
"The recent charges of mismanagement and fraud in building management have made it all the more necessary for the owners to have someone on their side who is used to bidding out jobs, collecting proposals and making sure they're getting the best deal," he said. "If you're not familiar with these technical disciplines, you can be taken for a bath. That's why the cost of any major contract goes by me first. That's what I'm here for."
A typical workday for Mr. Mazzucco begins at 7:30 A.M. with a chat with the night shift to see if there have been any problems, major or minor: "tenant complaints, elevator smoke alarms going off, that sort of thing," Mr. Mazzucco said.
After dealing with those problems, he usually sits down in his office at about 10 A.M. to deal with the contractors and vendors -- steamfitters, plumbers, electricians, cleaning-supply salesman -- whom he sees on almost a daily basis.
This was always a key part of the job, and the management scandal has made it more so, he said.
"Because of the scandal," he said, "you have to be extra careful if you're paying a little bit more, to make sure you get something that is worth the extra money, something that will reduce labor costs, last longer or clean better. You have to figure out who has the best deal."
IN the afternoon, Mr. Mazzucco will go along with the mechanic to check on the air-conditioning and other building systems. Or he may work on other projects: improving the waterproofing system for the sky deck or finding a more economical way to supply a small volume of steam in the summer for the building's health club.
"We have had to run the eight-inch winter steam line when we could run a two-inch steam line," he said. "It would be an economy move that would use much less natural gas. And we wouldn't create excess BTU's that have to be removed by the air-conditioning systems."
The day shift ends at 4 P.M., and when the evening workers come on he may write letters, send notes to tenants, deal with any staff problems and the security issues that are involved in having 25,000 square feet of commercial space on the street floor, occupied by an HMV music store.
There are also records to be kept on the computer: of the preventive maintenance program, of other projects, of what has been done in apartments and who is responsible for costs. The official workday ends between 6 and 7 P.M.
In his spare time, he will read to keep up to date on new laws involving refrigeration (he has a certificate on the subject issued by the National Association of Power Engineers), or boiler safety, or building engineering. Or take a course to keep up to date on management techniques, accounting, asbestos air monitoring, computers or locksmithing.
"My job is to look for trouble," Mr. Mazzucco said. "That's what I like best about it. It's always changing and there's always a problem. But I think I work better under pressure. I always have."
MR. MAZZUCCO is not alone. Almost directly across Central Park is another of the new breed, Thomas D. Riordan, superintendent -- or resident manager -- at 33 East 70th Street, and past president of the Metropolitan Building Managers of New York.
Mr. Riordan's tale is somewhat different from Mr. Mazzucco's, but the end result is similar. For the last six years he has supervised a staff of 24 -- 28 in summer -- at the 12-story, 65-unit blocklong co-op building at Madison Avenue, whose commercial space includes three art galleries and three Yves St. Laurent boutiques. The staff includes two sets of doormen, because the 65-year-old building has a separate entrance on 71st Street.
Like Mr. Mazzucco, Mr. Riordan attends board meetings and is responsible for every aspect of building maintenance and renovation.
"I'm much more involved than someone would have been 20 years ago," he said. "In those days you would have supervised the staff and taken care of the boilers and that would have been it. I review the building's monthly financial statement. I review all alterations in the building. I get involved with building projects."
"When I got here," he said, "there were people upstairs doing all kinds of work in apartments and I didn't know what they were doing. I want to know everything they're doing. I want the job done correctly so that in five or six years I don't have a problem. Even if they're just moving a radiator, I want to be involved."
Mr. Riordan was a licensed electrician in his native Ireland. When he came to the United States about a decade ago he began work as a porter at a Douglas Elliman building on Sutton Place.
"I started off mopping floors," he said. "I worked as a doorman, a relief man, worked my way up to handyman and finally became a superintendent" at 33 East 70th Street, which is a Douglas Elliman-managed building.
To do so, he needed several licenses. Among them are air-pollution-control certification, the No. 6 oil-burner license, a standpipe certificate and a sprinkler certificate. Superintendent requirements in New York City vary according to the type of equipment in a building; in addition to the above, most resident managers need a city refrigeration license.
BECAUSE of the growing emphasis on administrative and management duties, Mr. Riordan sought management training, and he got it through the Registered Apartment Manager program run by the National Association of Home Builders in connection with the New York Building Managers Association.
Other organizations offering an increasing array of courses and training programs for superintendents include the Institute of Real Estate Management (which runs a similar Accredited Resident Manager program), the Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York, the Building Owners and Managers Association, Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, Mr. Riordan's Metropolitan Building Managers of New York and several other local associations, or clubs, for resident managers.
Ronald Raab, a lawyer for Local 32B-32J, said that the union, through one of its benefit funds, ran a training school available to virtually all union members that offered myriad courses on preparing to become a superintendent. The courses, Mr. Raab said, include "air-conditioning, engineering, locksmithing -- all of the more skilled functions of building maintenance."
The New York Building Managers Association has a registered air-conditioning and refrigeration school; "its class of 40 has been full for the last four years," Mr. Riordan said. The Metropolitan Building Managers of New York runs monthly educational programs that include lectures on asbestos abatement and disposal of old refrigerants. The Manhattan Resident Managers Association holds computer courses. "Members of one group can also take courses at the others," Mr. Riordan said.
For Mr. Riordan, the key principle of building management is "public relations."
"THIS job is 90 percent public relations," he said. "It's how you present yourself to the people who live in the building, how you treat them."
Donald Trump agrees that the role of the superintendent is much different from what it was 15 years ago. And not surprisingly, Mr. Trump concurs with Mr. Riordan on the need for public relations.
"Perhaps the biggest difference is that a building manager must be better at the social graces," Mr. Trump said. "A manager must not only be good with nuts and bolts and pipes and electricity. He really has to know the social niceties, how to deal with a very high-level clientele. Everyone wears suits and ties now. I've even seen them wearing tuxedos when there's a luxury party at Trump Tower or one of my other buildings."
Bruce Mosler, president of Galbreath Riverbank, which specializes in commercial management, said that the super super had also evolved in the world of commercial real estate.
"Like everything else, people are demanding more service, more expertise and more capability, and that's what the manager of an office building has to supply," Mr. Mosler said. "The days of having someone in there who simply knew about the plumbing and the boiler in the basement are gone. You need someone who has engineering expertise and who can work with the outside vendors, someone who understands thoroughly and properly all aspects of a building's operation."
The need is financial, too.
"As markets have crumbled for commercial property and improved rental figures have diminished, there has been a tremendous focus on how to operate more efficiently," said John Wheeler, a senior managing director of Galbreath Riverbank. "You need to have people at the property who can identify ways to achieve savings and who can operate the more sophisticated systems that can be installed to obtain greater efficiency."
Those people include women as well as men. "As the position is becoming more professional, more and more women are getting involved," said Mr. Malkin of W & M Properties. "So far that's much less true in New York City, where there's a lingering perception that you have to be a tough guy to be a super. But outside of the city, in places like Chicago and St. Louis and Nashville, about 75 percent of our building managers or property managers are women."
H. Dale Hemmerdinger, president of Atco Properties and Management, a New York-based owner, manager and developer of residential and commercial property, said that there was still room for the old-fashioned super -- with one key change.
"People want the old-fashioned, wonderfully friendly attitude and the ability to fix things," Mr. Hemmerdinger said. "People don't want to give up the warmth that the old supers projected. But it has to come in a package that includes the skills -- especially management skills -- needed to run a modern building."
And some things remain the same. "What supers used to do that people remember so well is provide service," he said. "And that's what they still have to do."
Mr. Riordan agrees. "When it comes down to it, my job still involves letting somebody into their apartment when they've forgotten their keys and they're locked out at 2 o'clock in the morning," he said. "That has never changed, and it never will."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/The Swiss Home;
With Not Enough Old Indigents to Fill It, It's for Sale

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
ANOTHER lump in the melting pot is about to dissolve. The 1905 Swiss Home, at 35 West 67th Street, was built to house aged, indigent Swiss, but after 90 years of trying to fill it, the Swiss Benevolent Society is giving up and selling its building to concentrate on social services.
Although government now controls most charitable endeavors, mid-19th-century New York fairly bristled with improvement and self-help societies organized around religion or nationality. In 1846, upper-class New Yorkers of Swiss extraction founded the Swiss Benevolent Society, which finally bought an old rowhouse at 108 Second Avenue in 1883. 
 Prominent families like the Iselins, the de Coppets, the de Rhams and the Couderts supported the society and in 1904 it began a building from scratch on the upper West Side. It appears that the Swiss sought a site near both Central Park and an established neighborhood. They economized wisely by buying at 35 West 67th Street: their land backed up on an existing neighborhood of brownstones stretching north, but West 67th itself was then predominantly a street of light industry and stables.
The Swiss-American architect John E. Scharsmith designed the $117,000, five-story building, which "resembles somewhat the City Hall of Basel," according to the society's 1905 annual report. The report also praised the location as "in the most salubrious part" of the city.
The interiors had the plainness of sensible charity: a dining hall on the first floor and, above, rooms for up to 80 people in spaces that are, by New York standards, one notch up from a servant's room.
The opening ceremonies in December 1905 were in French, German and English, and attended by groups like the Helvetia Wheelmen and the Swiss Choral Society. They looked with pride on a building that still has the seals of the United States and Switzerland above the second floor and those of all 22 Swiss cantons in the cornice.
Histories of the Swiss Benevolent Society refer to a constant schism in the organization; apparently the French Swiss were generally better off than their German- and Italian-speaking countrymen, dominating the affairs of the society. Census records for 1910 show that almost all those living in the Swiss Home were of German extraction, like Adam Gasser, 74, a widower and retired machinist.
After the opening of the new home, the society adopted English as its official language to reduce tensions.
In 1916 a new president, Robert J. Schwarzenbach, expressed concern that the residents of the home were in danger "because of its proximity to saloons" on Columbus Avenue. He also said that, in part because the society could never more than half-fill the building with deserving poor, it was spending $400 a year per person. This was, he said, an extravagance "of which economically thinking and thrifty Swiss should not be guilty."
PERHAPS his judgment was also affected by the later development of West 67th Street, which had become a center for expensive apartment buildings, like the Hotel des Artistes.
Under Schwarzenbach's leadership, the aged occupants were moved to an estate that the society bought in 1923 for that purpose in Mount Kisco. In 1924 the Swiss Home became the Swiss Town House, a dormitory for working women; the stated purpose was to house women of Swiss extraction, but exceptions were numerous. The charge was $9 to $14 a week for room and board.
The 1925 census shows a new crop of residents, including a corset saleswoman, a child's nurse, a ladies' maid and a dental hygienist. Erma Ringh, a stenographer, 23 years old and nine months in the United States, lived in one room, and Ida Haas, a seamstress, 52 years old and 15 years in the United States, lived in another.
According to Annemarie Gilman, executive director of the Swiss Benevolent Society, in the early 1980's New York City threatened to begin charging real estate taxes on the West 67th Street house because it was no longer serving a tax-exempt function, and the society began restricting admission to students. By 1991 the building was costing it $50,000 a year and was far from its original mission. That was when the society closed the building, except for some office space.
This year Sotheby's International Realty began showing the 15,000-square-foot building to interested buyers at a price of $2.95 million. Robert Schulman, the broker handling the sale, said the building could be a small European-style hotel or be split into condominiums, although he said he saw it as "an extraordinary opportunity for a sizable private residence on one of the best blocks on the Upper West Side".
Ms. Gilman says that the society will use the proceeds from the sale to move to modest offices. From that base it will concentrate on its scholarship and social service programs. The latter functions as an "extended family" for the 1,200 aged Swiss in the metropolitan area with limited incomes, coordinating government programs and health services.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The drawing of the Swiss Benevolent Society's new building at 35 West 67th Street from the annual report of 1905 (The Swiss Benevolent Society); the entrance and lower floors recently. The Swiss group has put the building on sale. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Defense Of Urban Renewal

 BODY:
Richard B. Greene's letter, "A Revival Plan for New Haven" (July 17) states that Mayor Richard Lee destroyed New Haven in the 50's and 60's, that entire neighborhoods were bulldozed away and ugly concrete buildings were erected in their stead.
Nothing could be further from the truth. 
 I was responsible, under Mayor Lee's direction, for the design and implementation of his highly regarded urban renewal program.
The Oak Street area, which was indeed a slum, was cleared and rebuilt. The relocation, almost entirely within the city for both businesses and families, was done with special care. (Incidentally, New Haven was the first urban renewal program in the country to establish a business relocation office.)
Far from destroying neighborhoods, urban renewal preserved them.
The local residents participated fully in the preparation of the urban renewal plans and supported them, unanimously, at public hearings. The Wooster Square and Dixwell neighborhoods were, and are, notable examples.
If more cities had followed Dick Lee's example by planning with the community, not for it, and by emphasizing rehabilitation over clearance, the urban renewal program might be alive and well today.
It is also noteworthy that New Haven was the first urban renewal city in the country to recognize the social dimensions of urban renewal by creating, with funding from the Ford Foundation, the nation's first anti-poverty program. It is shameful to see this sensitive and sensible program so misrepresented.
EDWARD J. LOGUE
Boston

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Executive Suites;
A Private-Office Illusion, With Shared Amenities

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
FROM all outward appearances, Zephyr Management, an investment advisory firm, is an old-line Wall Street outfit gone north. It has an impressive address -- 630 Fifth Avenue, Rockefeller Center's International Building on 51st Street. A soft-spoken woman answers its phones with the company name and a smiling receptionist greets its visitors.
No one would guess that the receptionist, the phone answerer, the couches in the lobby, even the steaming coffee in the kitchen, all are shared with others. Or that the company leased the space for only nine months. Or that Zephyr itself is only three months old. 
 "We can't afford the kind of infrastructure that our clients expect," said Thomas C. Barry, Zephyr's chief executive, who is paying $8,000 a month for a suite of four offices. "For us, this was perfect."
Welcome to the Business Center in Rockefeller Center, the latest entry in the growing field of executive-suite operations. It is a place where, for a monthly charge of $900 to $4,500, small companies can rent furnished offices, have their phones answered and visitors greeted and reserve space in communal conference rooms.
For a per-use charge, they can also get their letters or proposals typed, use the copiers or fax machines or otherwise draw on resources and amenities once reserved only to business big-leaguers.
"This is not the real estate business, this is a service business," said Frederic Z. Sondik, the Business Center's general manager.
Other members of that service business profess to welcome Rockefeller Center to the fray. "When competitors run good operations it reinforces the concept's credibility," said Valerie Buckwalter, director of marketing and leasing for Alliance Business Centers, which has 293 offices in four Manhattan buildings.
Even those who are less sanguine about the supply/demand relationship are unconcerned. "I do feel New York is becoming saturated, but I don't think we have anything to worry about," said Sean Keegan, who owns International Office Centers, a 76-office operation in the World Trade Center. "Those of us who understand this business will survive."
Recent history seems to prove his point. For the executive-suite companies, the recession was barely a blip.
"In bad times we get people starting businesses because they are unemployed," said Kathryn J. Donohue, president of HQ Business Centers, which has about 500 small offices for short-term rent in seven New York buildings and is opening a new center in Uniondale, L.I. in November. "In good times we get people going into business because they feel confident they can succeed."
In a sense, the recent economic downturn helped the executive-suite companies. Before the recession, landlords were often loath to rent them space, preferring to avoid ever-changing lobby directory boards and a constant flow of traffic to the floors. But increased use of electronic lobby directories has mitigated that problem. And chronic space gluts not only made many landlords less choosy, it also made them look at executive-suite tenants as prime candidates for permanent leases down the line.
"People used to think executive suites only went into troubled buildings, but now everyone is sold on them as incubators for future tenants," said S. Harold Appel, a senior vice president of CB Commercial, who helped Alliance rent space at 230 Park Avenue, the Helmsley Building on 45th Street.
Rockefeller Center will have particularly good chances to play off synergies between its 67-office executive-suite operation and its regular space by letting any executive-suite tenant cancel its lease if it moves into a permanent Rockefeller Center space.
It is marketing the short-term offices to existing tenants who may need temporary space for a visiting executive or an audit team. Since Rockefeller Center operates its own telephone company, it can do temporary hook-ups between an existing tenant's phone lines and a temporary phone at the executive-suite operation. And it can let executive suite tenants who move to permanent space keep their phone number.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS technology, in fact, has made all of the executive-suite operations more palatable to small companies wanting to look and act big. Most executive suites have intricate phone systems that allow each tenant to have a separate phone number. When the phone rings, the tenant's preferred greeting -- "Mr. Smith's office," or "ACME Publications," or whatever -- flashes on a computer screen at the telecommunications desk, and the person on phone duty answers with that greeting.
If Mr. Smith has left instructions on how to deal with specific callers, that flashes on the computer screen as well. Otherwise, the caller is connected to Mr. Smith's voice mail or leaves a message with the message center.
Some message centers even take telephone orders. "We can act as a telemarketing or fulfillment house," Ms. Buckwalter said.
The executive-suite operations keep expanding options. Alliance now offers a concierge service: For an hourly fee, staffers will order limousines, send flowers, make dinner reservations and do other personal chores. And many of the operations let companies that haven't taken offices use them as high-tech mail drops. For a few hundred dollars a month the companies can use the address and the telephone services and a couple of hours of conference room time.
The executive-suite operations have drawbacks, of course. They rarely guarantee renewal rights. They charge hefty fees for their ancillary services. And they rarely let tenants put their own logos on their doors, or otherwise shout out their identities.
Still, they clearly meet a need. Without them, many fledgling entrepreneurs or regional salespeople would have to operate out of their homes or sublet an office from a larger company that will let them use its receptionists and office equipment. Neither arrangement impresses clients.
"All too often, the potential client says, 'Call me when you've got a real business in a real office,' " said Mr. Barry of Zephyr.
Even companies with a captive client audience say the centers fill a vaccuum. CODEP Management Services exists solely to help a Belgian savings bank evaluate potential American investments. Helen Gateson, CODEP's president and only employee, first figured she didn't need an office. Wrong.
"I tried working from home," she recalled. "I ran out of file space, I ran into my two children all the time and I found that when you work at home you never leave the job."
Now, for $1,500 a month, she has a tiny windowed office at Rockefeller Center and has signed a one-year lease. Next year she hopes to graduate to regular office space.
BUT not all executive-suite tenants are in a hurry to leave. "The space is modern, the office manager handles everything, a lot of these tenants get spoiled," noted James B. Emden, a senior managing director at the real estate firm Edward S. Gordon.
Take Dana Stetson, the regional sales manager for GNP Computers, based in Monrovia, Calif., which sells computer systems. Two years ago, he took a small Alliance office in the Helmsley Building. He soon moved into a bigger one, and just took an additional office.
"I don't want to deal with conference rooms or manage secretaries," Mr. Stetson said. "I want to focus only on sales."
Mr. Stetson's wife, Mary, is a convert also: She started Home Suite Home, to find temporary quarters in private homes for people visiting Atlanta for the 1996 Olympics. She is working from home but is using Alliance's mail and phone service.
Executive-suite operations, or hybrids thereof, are likely to keep growing. The World Trade Center, for example, plans to build a small business incubator operation next year, which would provide business strategy assistance as well as short-term offices for foreign start-ups. For now, the center is paying International Office Centers to provide six months of office space to selected European and Asian start-up companies. The hope is that, with ample strategy assistance from World Trade Center people, the start-ups will graduate to regular space.
In fact, the center recently converted half a floor -- about 20,000 square feet -- in One World Trade Center to small, fully furnished offices. It has 13 tenants, and George T. Rossi, the center's assistant director, plans to prebuild several other floors.
"It's all part of a program to persuade people overseas that you don't have to commit years and hundreds of thousands of dollars to explore the possibility of running an office in New York," Mr. Rossi said.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Yale Works to Break Down the Town-Gown Barrier

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
FOR 293 years Yale has been a pre-eminent institution of higher learning, in its lighter moments giving birth to the Whiffenpoofs and helping to popularize the button-down shirt.
It has also been a leading example of the condition known as "town and gown," a term that originated in England in the 17th century to describe the isolation of the universities of Oxford and Cambridge from their host cities and the frictions that flowed from the isolation. 
 For the last decade Yale has been seeking ways to repair its relationship with this city and create for itself a more socially responsible image.
Drawing on a $3.5 billion endowment, it is halfway through $50 million committed in 1987 by Benno C. Schmidt Jr., its former president. The money must be spent within 10 years in conjunction with public and private funds for the betterment of New Haven.
Initial projects added to Yale's real estate portfolio but for the most part had no effect on blighted areas and their low-income residents. A more hands-on approach, articulated by Yale's new president, Richard C. Levin, is evident in projects designed to rehabilitate districts and help small businesses and householders.
Foremost among the new projects is one that targets Broadway, a deteriorated but busy shopping street bordering the campus and plagued by traffic congestion and rampant shabbiness. It is being restored with $7.5 million from a Federal grant to the city and $1.9 million from Yale.
The project's designers, Herbert Newman, a member of Yale's architecture faculty, and Leonard Liss of the city's Department of Traffic and Parking, plan to widen cramped sidewalks, bury utility lines, reconfigure traffic lanes, work with stores to improve signs and facades and create a landscaped park.
Dozens of large, disease-resistant elm trees will be planted to shade Broadway and adjacent York Street and Tower Parkway, restoring credibility to New Haven's designation as the Elm City. Most of the elms succumbed to Dutch elm disease.
"We bought up almost all of Broadway to be sure that we had a critical mass of property to be able to redevelop the area," said Donna Dean, director of investments for Yale. Meetings were held with the retail tenants to gain their support and listen to their ideas for the project.
"We see this as good business for Yale, the merchants and the city," said Donna Hall, a city planner designated by Mayor John De Stefano Jr. to work with Yale. "Broadway has become the central downtown district, with the only movie theater and the only department store remaining in the city -- York Square Cinema and the Yale Co-op."
The decline of New Haven's economy, like those of many Northeastern cities, was accompanied by an increase in crime that spilled onto the seemingly impervious campus. Applications for enrollment plummeted in 1991 after a student was killed in a random shooting. And last month seven patrons of a local restaurant, including one of Yale's associate professors, were stabbed by a berserk city resident.
"It's come to the point where urban universities are severely challenged by conditions around them that interfere with their academic mission," said Mr. Newman. "Competing with more bucolic campuses becomes very difficult."
"CRIME was certainly a factor in our recognition that the university and the city are inextricably intertwined," said Linda Koch Lorimer, secretary of Yale. In the early 1700's, she noted, the students were notorious for conducting rampages through New Haven, creating a town-gown enmity in which the residents were the victims."By the 1780's Yale had to ban students from carrying weapons," she said.
In the Park-Howe-Dwight district, dubbed PhD for the many Yale graduate students who rent rooms there and faculty members who own handsome vintage homes, Ms. Dean, acting for Yale, and David Ornato, a local real estate operator, bought a drug-and prostitution-infested apartment house at 100 Howe Street for $600,000. Mr. Ornato evicted most of the tenants and restored the building as 83 studio apartments, renting to students and a variety of responsible townspeople for $385 a month.
On Park Street, four vacant university-owned stores are being renovated as a substation for Yale's 81-member police force and to accommodate the Yale Dramat, a student-run children's theater; a computer lab for public school and Yale students and a student publications office.
"We couldn't be more delighted with what Yale is doing," said Diana L. Mercer, a New Haven lawyer and resident of PhD. "They haven't transformed us into Litchfield, but the apartment house and the police station, and officers walking the beat have had an impact on crime."
Yale's contribution of $12.5 million to the redevelopment of Ninth Square, a $108 million retail and residential project bounded by Chapel, Church, George and State Streets, includes Mr. Newman's master plan for combining new construction and historic restoration. Construction of 335 residential units, 49,000 square feet of retail space and 850 parking spaces began in June 1993 and is expected to be complete by the end of 1996.
Apartments will range in size from 434-square-foot studios to 1,054-square-foot two-bedroom, two-bath units. Half will rent at market rates of $600 to $850; the rest, for moderate-income tenants, will rent for $503 to $625. Retail rents will be $14 to $17 a square foot, according to Beazley Company Realtors, the Ninth Square rental agent.
In a program begun last April, Yale offered to pay $2,000 a year for 10 years to any university employee who bought a home or condominium in New Haven through December 1995.
"There is no single more important thing that Yale has done than its home-buying program," said Paul Bass, associate editor of The New Haven Advocate, a 1982 Yale graduate and an outspoken critic of former university town-gown policies.
So far, 55 employes have bought residences, 31 of them in the $75,000-to-$125,000 range. "It has encouraged our union workers to buy their first homes," said Ms. Lorimer.
"We considered other towns," said Dianne Steele, a university accountant, "but when this kicked in we bought a 10-room house in New Haven. The first $2,000 payment was included in my paycheck after the closing. It will help pay the $3,600 tax bill."
"YALE is changing its attitude toward the city," said Margaret Brooks, owner of Audubon Associates Real Estate. "Yale people needed that extra push to move into New Haven -- taxes are high and the city has gotten a bad rap."
As a catalyst for encouraging outside investors, Yale has set aside $5 million as joint venture capital for biomedical and biotech companies moving to New Haven. And it has a contract to buy the mortgage on the bankrupt Chapel Square Mall and adjacent office tower, with the expectation of turning the property over to the Cordish Company of Baltimore for development.
This month Cordish bought the bankrupt 300-room Park Plaza Hotel on the opposite side of the mall at 155 Temple Street -- the only large hotel in the city. "Yale and the city made the $20 million renovation possible by getting a $10 million state grant," said David Cordish, the company president. "Yale made it feasible by committing its sizable hotel market."
The company indicated significant interest in the mall and office building as well.
"We can't cure New Haven's problems by buying huge amounts of property," said Ms. Lorimer, "but we can leverage our ability to make things happen."

HEADLINE: Under Financial Pressures, Duck Farms Dwindle

BYLINE: By REGINA MARCAZZO 

 BODY:
IN the 1950's, 120 duck farms flourished on the Island, producing products that spread the name of Long Island far and wide. Today five duck farmers remain, and two of their farms may close if the Brookhaven Town Board approves a zoning change on Bay Avenue in East Moriches.
A co-owner of one of the two farms on Bay Avenue that is up for sale, Bruce Vigliotta, said he was undecided whether he would stop raising ducks completely or move his business out of state. 
 The other owner, Roger Titmus Jr., said he would run his entire duck operation from a 10-acre farm that he owns on Barnes Road in Moriches.
"I don't want this business to fail in my hands," Mr. Titmus said. "I could keep it going without the property. I just don't want to see it die." Mr. Titmus's farm raises 150,000 ducks a year, but just his breeders are at Bay Avenue.
"We've already for the most part moved," he added. "I can't afford to pay the taxes."
Farmers fault high taxes and electricity bills and out-of-state competition for the decline of the industry.
"We don't know what we're doing," Mr. Vigliotta said. "It's getting tough on Long Island. We might move the duck business."
The Vigliottas have farmed ducks on the Island for 50 years and now raise more than 100,000 a year. The Brookhaven Town Board is considering zoning that would allow a condominium complex on their 60-acre farm. The condo plan, proposed by Bay Avenue Associates, calls for more than 200 units. Some residents oppose the size of the proposed complex.
"We're saying yes, there should be something done about the duck farms, but it should not be replaced by that type of development," a coordinator for the Citizens Campaign for the Environment, Daniel Bono, said. "You shouldn't replace one impact with another."
"I have lived here all my life," said Susan DiSario, secretary of the Moriches Bay Civic Association, who opposes the condo plan. "I have grown up with duck farms. We are not saying that we want the duck farms to stay here."
A former 56-acre duck farm in East Moriches is now the site of the 75-unit Harts Cove condominium. Mrs. DiSario said she thought that the community would accept such a density.
"I think that the duck farms are obsolete and the street has to be cleaned up," said James Brennan, who has live on Bay Avenue for 14 years and who favors the condo plan. "I think that it would be good for the town."
Most ducks in the United States today come from the Middle West, with 60 percent from one farm in Indiana, Maple Leaf Farms. Two of the Long Island farmers produce 15 percent of the national total.
Thomas Jurgielewicz, a co-owner of the Jurgielewicz Duck Farm in Moriches, which plans to stay in business, said his father did everything to try to talk him and his two brothers out of the duck industry. "It's been good to two generations," Mr. Jurgielewicz said. "Why shouldn't it be good for another two at least?"
Long Island growers have worked to make their ducks distinctive. They say their product is known for its meaty breast and unmarred skin.
The owner of the Crescent Duck Farm of Aquebogue, Douglas Corwin, said: "The only way we've survived is by trying to differentiate ourselves. The biggest thing is breeding year after year to develop better strains."
The Long Island climate is conducive to breeding, Mr. Jurgielewicz said, adding, "We've done more hands-on type breeding selection for a better product."
The executive director of the Long Island Farm Bureau, Joseph Gergela, said, "We capitalize on the tradition and the name."
Mr. Corwin said his ducks were often served at top restaurants in Manhattan. "We probably get about the best price in the country," he said.
For Mr. Jurgielewicz ducks are more than a business. He remembers chasing them and collecting eggs as a child on his grandfather's farm. His grandfather came from Poland in 1919 and opened the farm on Barnes Avenue in Moriches.
Rising grain prices , stringent environmental guidelines and declining consumption have played a part in the decline of the industry.
Eastport, which used to call itself the duck capital of the world, is now home to one duck farm. It is owned by Paul Massey and his father, Chester Massey Jr. Paul Massey said he was pleased that his two children were growing up on the farm. "I think it adds a lot to the quality of family life," Mr. Massey said.
The family tradition applies to the Corwins, as well. A drive around their farm passes a cemetery where Mr. Corwin's grandfather is buried, his gravestone marked with the etching of a duckling. "I'm going to be right there and I'm going to be watching," he told his grandson.
The 100-acre Crescent Farm slaughters 18,000 to 19,000 ducks a week, or 900,000 ducks a year, and employs more than 80 people. "I have no interest in getting any bigger," Mr. Corwin said.
The farm uses modern water treatment and is building artificial wetlands. The wetlands, which are to cost $150,000 to $200,000, will add a third layer to water treatment. A Federal grant will pay for one-third to one-half of the project's cost.
"All costs have gone up, and I haven't been able to get a penny more for ducks," said Mr. Corwin, adding that his electric bill has been as high as $33,000 a month.
Mr. Corwin said he did not believe there had been a decline in production because of the ducks' fat content, but did say that Americans were eating less meat. Mr. Corwin said that over the years he had reduced fat by genetic selection, by using ultrasound to measure fat content and new nutrition. "The fat is used by a good chef to naturally baste the duck," he said.
National production has dropped, from 24 million ducks a year to 20 million in the last six years, said Mr. Corwin, who added that his production had not decreased because he was growing larger birds.
The industry represents $20 million a year in economic activity on Long Island, Mr. Gergela said. At one time 98 percent of the national total was raised on Long Island.
Mr. Jurgielewicz runs his 50-acre farm with his two brothers. "We're nothing to sneeze at," he said. But this year "grain costs are up because of the Midwest flooding."
"It's become more profitable to raise ducks in the Midwest," said Nils Berglund, a former duck farmer and an agent at the Cornell Cooperative Extension. Mr. Berglund ceased production at his farm in Riverhead in 1988, along with about 12 other duck farmers. He had raised 125,000 ducks a year.
Many farms closed when the Long Island Packer's Plant in Eastport went out of business in 1987.
Mr. Jurgielewicz said he was concerned when he saw a duck whose label read "Farmer's Commission House" and "Eastport, Long Island" at a wholesale distributor in Philadelphia. He said he could tell from the plant-identification number on the duck that it was from Indiana.
Mr. Jurgielewicz called the compliance division of the United States Department of Agriculture. The product, he added, was taken off the market.
In 1990 local officials, including Representative George Hochbrueckner, Democrat of Centereach, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, informed Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter about the mislabeling. "We'll clear them off the market," Mr. Jurgielewicz said. "The groundwork has been laid."
When the Farmer's Commission House went out of business, Mr. Massey said, he had to make a choice, to go out of business or make a deal with another processor. Mr. Massey took his ducks to the Jurgielewicz farm. He now hatches 18,000 ducks every two weeks for the Jurgielewiczes.
The Masseys also raise 50,000 ducks a year on their own. At one time they raised 250,000 a year.
Although he said he did not intend to leave the business, Mr. Massey added that he was not worried about what would happen if he could no longer farm. "You have be everything, a mechanic, a carpenter," he said. "You have to do that if you want to stay in business."
Mr. Massey said his farm enjoyed lower taxes because it was in an agricultural tax district. "You have to sign a commitment that you won't sell the land for seven or eight years," he said. "The only thing that's keeping us in business is there's still a niche market."

HEADLINE: Ballet Theater and SUNY Team Up

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: PURCHASE

 BODY:
COMBINE spacious stages, ample rehearsal rooms and eager students with dancers of proven talent, masterful teachers and a whiff of Manhattan and the mix is irresistible. So said officials of Purchase College here and the American Ballet Theater recently as they announced with sudden fanfare that they would begin a five-year partnership this fall.
"This was one of the most delightful 'non-negotiation' negotiations we've ever had," said Christopher Beach, director of the college's Performing Arts Center. "It's a great fit for both of us." 
 Bill Lacy, president of Purchase College, said the agreement -- the specifics of which are still being worked out -- was sealed within two months of the earliest discussions. That was a relatively short time for a plan that includes performances here, educational programs, on-campus residencies and a new summer dance institute.
"We're a model for these kinds of collaborations," Mr. Lacy said, referring to another arrangement the college has with the New York Knicks. "This was what was always envisioned for this place -- the college was set up to be special."
Students in the school's dance division, who recently represented the United States at an international dance festival in China, are expected to benefit from the exposure to a professional company as it goes about the sweaty business of choreographing and rehearsing new works. Purchase students will also study with American Ballet Theater teachers and dance as supernumeraries in the company's productions here.
 
'Makes So Much Sense'
 "To have a company of their prestige affiliated with a professional training program is terribly exciting," said Carol Walker, dean of the dance division. She said the new agreement would formalize ties that the division has long had with American Ballet Theater. One of its former principal dancers, Cynthia Gregory, serves as the honorary chairwoman of Purchase College Friends of Dance, and other former Ballet Theater dancers teach at Purchase.
The dance division, a conservatory program from which 32 students graduated last May, also sponsors the Jose Limon Summer Dance Workshop and administers the Harkness Choreographers Space Grant Project, which selects professional dancers to work on campus when school is not in session. The American Ballet Theater is expected to begin its new summer institute here as early as next summer, bringing high school students from around the country to study with its faculty and live in Purchase College dormitories.
"It makes so much sense for us to join forces with Purchase," said Kevin McKenzie, artistic director of American Ballet Theater. He said that the company, which will remain based in Manhattan, has wanted to start a summer school but has "no facilities to house anyone" in the city. Also, he said, the arrangement would provide low-cost rehearsal space at the college's well-equipped theaters and studios, a luxury for a company that is "always under the gun."
The award-winning dance building, one of the first in the country to be designed exclusively for the study of dance, has 14 studios and state-of-the-art training equipment. The building also features a 270-seat theater, saunas, office and storage space and a whirlpool, which Ms. Walker said is closed because there is "no money to staff it."
 
'They're Broke and We're Broke'
 Mr. Beach said that no charge had been established for the company's use of the Performing Arts Center for a planned December run of "The Nutcracker" or for any other productions. "It's not really an economic arrangement," he said. "They're broke, and we're broke."
The Performing Arts Center, one of the most prestigious performance sites in the county, normally charges a rental fee of $3,000 to 4,000 for an orchestral concert, $4,500 and $5,500 for a dance performance. Rehearsals range from $1,500 to $2,500. Steve Grober, the center's booking manager, said the costs covered space, equipment, rent and labor.
Although these fees have driven some arts organizations to seek performance space elsewhere, Mr. Beach has maintained that the fees are necessary to keep the four-theater complex in business. The center presents its own wide range of programs, is available to students in the college's music, dance and theater divisions and can be rented by other groups on remaining dates.
At any given time, however, one or more of the theaters is dark, and Mr. Beach has sought to enliven the campus by inviting such groups as the New York City Ballet and the Bill T. Jones and Paul Taylor Dance Companies to exchange rehearsal time for residency programs. The center has also has a partnership with the Night Kitchen, a children's theater company. "My job is to be a resource for the students here and provide them with models of excellence," Mr. Beach said.
The American Ballet Theater will assume its presence here almost immediately as it prepares for "The Nutcracker," which will be presented in the center's Concert Hall from Dec. 12 through 24. The production, staged by Mr. McKenzie, follows a libretto by Wendy Wasserstein and features costumes by Theoni V. Aldredge.
 
Strong Relationships
 Students in the dance division will present their own version of "The Nutcracker" earlier in December, which somewhat worries Ms. Walker. It will be "an interesting juggling problem" to arrange rehearsal space for both productions and "to get both 'Nutcrackers' up and sold," she said. The college's production, which attracts many schoolchildren each year, uses professional dancers for some solos as well as members of the SUNY Youth Ballet a program of the division of continuing education of Purchase College.
In discussing plans for future partnerships with other groups, Mr. Lacy said talks were also proceeding well with the New York Philharmonic, which is in the market for a summer home. "We're next door to a reservoir of talent and should try to make those bridges," he said.
The president compared the current art scene, hard hit by financial cutbacks and often attacked by conservatives, to a foxhole where organizations can shelter each other. "Strong friendships are formed in foxholes under fire," he said.
