HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Trouble for Soros-Reichmann Team

BYLINE: By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
WHEN George Soros and Paul Reichmann teamed up last year to run a real-estate fund, they raised some eyebrows -- and a lot of hopes. Mr. Soros, after all, was the man with the golden touch, the trader who in 1992 made more than $1 billion by betting against Europe's central banks.
Mr. Reichmann, on the other hand, was the visionary who led Olympia & York into bankruptcy, the real-estate mogul whose empire collapsed under the weight of its grandiose Canary Wharf development in London. Wits joked that next Mr. Soros would hire Michael Milken to run a bond fund. 
 But the partnership was also widely hailed as a sign that commercial real-estate might be recovering from the brutal bear market that followed the overbuilding of the 1980's. If an investor as canny as Mr. Soros was swooping in to snap up office buildings, maybe there was hope even for all those "transparent towers," glass-walled structures that have never attracted tenants.
Recently, however, there have been signs that sailing has not been smooth for the $525 million Quantum Realty Trust, named after Mr. Soros's flagship Quantum Fund. (Neither fund is open to American investors.)
Mr. Reichmann is no longer involved in Quantum Realty's daily operations, though he remains "non-executive chairman" of the fund's manager, Reichmann International, which has had three chief executives in as many months. "Everybody's buzzing about it," said one real-estate executive.
And investors may have soured on the realty fund. Its share price, which is set by a dealer in London, has tumbled more than 22 percent from its peak in early January, far more than the British stock market's 12 percent decline in the same stretch. Mr. Soros's funds are not listed on stock exchanges, but are bought and sold by a small group of friendly dealers.
Even more surprising, perhaps, is that Quantum Realty's London dealer, Edgar Astaire & Company, is bidding less for the shares than Quantum Realty says they are worth based on the value of the fund's holdings. Last week, for example, the fund's net asset value was reported as about $135 a share, but the dealer bid just $121, a 10 percent discount.
Matthew Wilson, head of finance and administration for Edgar Astaire, said that Quantum Realty was trading at a discount "because it is in real estate; most real estate companies trade at a discount to their net assets." And in fact, the Soros fund for British real estate is trading at a similar discount.
But Mr. Soros's funds are famous for trading at a steep premium to the value of their holdings; the flagship Quantum Fund itself, which takes big bets in stocks, bonds, and currencies, maintained a double-digit premium even after Mr. Soros acknowledged he lost $600 million on Feb. 14 because of a bad bet on the yen.
And until recently, Quantum Realty had followed that pattern, generally trading at a premium, sometimes a very large one (in June 1993, that premium topped 18 percent). At worst, in September 1993, the dealer's bid had briefly hovered just below net asset value. But since May, the bid has been sinking steadily, while the net asset value has remained fairly steady.
Quantum Realty's recent discount "is a significant event in the way the whole empire functions," said the head of a large money management firm. "It's the first sign of any problems."
The new head of Quantum Realty's manager, Vernon Schwartz, acknowledged that to outsiders, Reichmann International might have looked like it was in some turmoil, but said the succession of executives "was not as disorganized as it appeared." He took over on Sept. 1, replacing Evan Marks, who runs G. Soros Realty, which manages Mr. Soros's real estate holdings. Mr. Marks took over from Mr. Reichmann on July 1.
As for the rumors that Mr. Soros and Mr. Reichmann have had a falling out, Mr. Schwartz said he had head them but declined to comment. "Now, if it wasn't in the past, Reichmann International is very focused on its game plan of continuing to actively manage Quantum Realty," he said. "Hopefully the fund's trading pattern will reflect that," he said, noting that he does not consider a 10 percent discount to be steep.
Mr. Schwartz is regarded as a longtime ally of Mr. Reichmann, who called Mr. Schwartz "one of the top executives in the real-estate development field today" when he hired him in May to head the other Soros/ Reichmann joint venture, a partnership that is building several large projects in Mexico. Mr. Schwartz was previously the president of Catellus Development in California, but left earlier this year under pressure from the board of directors led by Calpers, the state pension fund. Some analysts say that the board used Mr. Schwartz as a scapegoat, when the real problem was California's economic downturn.
Some of Quantum Realty's troubles may stem from investors doubts about how fast commercial real estate will rebound. It hasn't done so yet; the fund itself values its assets at about the same level as a year ago. This suggests that there may have been some truth in the Wall Street whispers that the fund did not get much of a bargain last year when it made its main purchase, a group of commercial properties it bought from the Travelers Corporation. The properties, including office buildings, shopping centers, hotels and some rental apartment buildings, mostly in the Southeast and Midwest, cost Quantum Realty $634 million.
Mr. Soros continues to say that he prefers real assets, as opposed to financial assets like stocks and bonds. Quantum Realty still has $370 million that it plans to invest in real estate; because the fund can use leverage, its purchases could reach $1 billion, Mr. Schwartz said. "In real estate, one must always be careful not to generalize, but overall we're very bullish," he added. "Sophisticated investors can still find values."

HEADLINE: Business Diary: September 18-23

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

COMAPNIES
 
For Northrop Grumman Workers, the Bad News Gets Very Specific
It's no surprise, really. The country is laying down its weapons -- well, except in Haiti -- and that's putting a lot of people out of work. And when Northrop swallowed Grumman earlier this year, everyone knew that spelled more sizable job cuts. But still, when the big shoe dropped last week, the numbers were stark: Northrop Grumman, as it's now known, is reducing its work force by 8,650, or more than 18 percent, by the end of 1995. That's a "healthy response" to Pentagon cutbacks, said one consultant. But don't talk about health on, say, Long Island. In 1986, Grumman gave out 25,000 paychecks there, making it Long Island's largest private employer; those days are already history, of course, but the payroll will soon shrivel even more, to 3,800. The bulk of the latest layoffs, though, will come in California -- 4,150 of them. And that comes just after word that GM Hughes would lay off 4,400. 

A Judge With a View?
Yes, Federated is closing six stores in the New York area as a prelude to merging with Macy's (it said so last week), but let's get to the important stuff: parades and fireworks. At a recent hearing, it seems, the bankruptcy judge, Burton Lifland, put great weight on keeping the Thanksgiving parade, and the fireworks -- on, he clearly specified, the East Side. He did make a compelling case: "More of the populace of New York can view the fireworks from the East Side." But in what is surely a judicial coincidence, he also has a compelling address: It's on East 53d Street.
 
Hafts: Keeping the Courts Busy
Most people wouldn't expect to get $34 million for losing a job unfairly, but then again most people aren't named Haft -- and aren't in the Hafts' tax bracket. Last week a Federal jury awarded that sum to Robert Haft, ruling that his father, Herbert, had wrongfully dismissed him last year. It was one of the biggest such awards ever. Of course, Robert's suit was just a drop in this family's legal bucket. The Hafts surely stand alone in the amount they sue one another. "I haven't even tried to count" the suits, one lawyer said. The lawyers are adding up the family legal fees, though -- $10 million and counting. One wonders if any family pets have been sued for misbehavior.
 
Did Disney Step on a Thorn?
Michael Eisner may be discovering just how valuable Jeffrey Katzenberg was. The two men built Disney into an entertainment colossus, a success story that keeps roaring as "The Lion King" heads further into record territory. But by all accounts, things have not gone well at Disney in the weeks since Mr. Eisner declined to give Mr. Katzenberg the No. 2 job. Some projects have been delayed, others discarded. Some Hollywood types, in fact, describe the cash-cow studio as paralyzed. Did this have to happen? Did Mr. Eisner see Mr. Katzenberg as a threat? He denies it. But there are some interesting footnotes: Animators wanted to give Mr. Katzenberg a farewell party; Mr. Eisner said no. And Mr. Katzenberg is no longer welcome at the London premiere of "The Lion King."
 
Kazarian's New-Age Finance
The takeover game isn't what it used to be. Now it's more like Donald Trump meets Yoda, or Zen and the Art of the Deal. Just look: Paul Kazarian says he should take charge at Borden, not Kohlberg, Kravis, and last week he lashed out at Borden for snubbing him. But what, exactly, has he offered? He talks of a deal valuing Borden shares at $16 to $18 (vs. $14.25 in the Kohlberg, Kravis offer), but gives no clue about financing. What he offers plenty of is Quotations from Chairman Paul -- like "Wear out the soles of your shoes before the seat of your pants" and a paean to his management philosophy of "Dynamic Tension." Hmmm. Didn't the folks who ousted him from Sunbeam-Oster have slightly less printable words for it?
 
Geritol Feels Peppy (Really!)
With apologies to 'enry 'iggins, it often seems that advertisers don't care what people say about their product as long as they pronounce it properly. And as "Quiz Show" came to your local sprawliplex last week, lots of unkind things were being said about Geritol, which as sponsor of a rigged game show is portrayed as a clear co-culprit in the affair. But Geritol is still around, as a "multivitamin for a female target" (such delightful marketing-ese; it sounds like a National Rifle Association slogan). And lo and behold, Geritol -- with new ad spots and consumer surveys -- is rushing to capitalize on its newfound infamy, to "seize the opportunity." Given Geritol's vanishing act since the days of "iron-poor blood," "they'll take any mention they can get," said a marketing consultant.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
The Open Road? Not in China
In China, an irresistible force is about to crash into an immovable body -- without seat belts. That force can be defined quite simply: as the Chinese enjoy steadily higher living standards, they want the goodies the rest of the world has. Like cars. And the Government is obliging, making ambitious plans to double China's car output -- with the focus on a "people's car," a compact sedan for the masses. Now no one wants to deny the people this badge of world citizenship, but many experts -- from East and West -- are saying, Hold it! With 1.2 billion Chinese, this isn't going to work. "Insane," said one. Not enough oil. Not enough roads. China's cities are plagued by gridlock already. Air pollution. But when Mao's grandson dreams of owning a car . . .

Tough Talk on Trade
President Clinton is talking tough on trade again, vowing last week that if Japan does not agree by this Friday to pry open its markets, the United States will impose trade sanctions. But a good part of this saber-rattling was surely for a congressional audience, for the President badly wants Capitol Hill approval of a new global free-trade accord, and legislators might be more willing to give it to him if they see him standing tall against Japan.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Trade Data Jolt the Market
Just when the stock market had relaxed somewhat about inflation -- as measured by various price reports -- a different breed of goblin gave it a scare on Tuesday. The nation's trade deficit made a surprise jump to its second-highest level ever, and this so rattled the financial markets that the dollar came perilously close to its all-time low, and the Dow industrials started sinking. Then, to top it off, a computerized "sell" program barged in and sent stocks down even further, making the day's loss 67 points.
 
A New Tally of Smoking's Toll
A report out last week paints a picture of smoking's damage even starker than what's appeared so far. Here's a sampling of the statistics from the report, an extensive study of data going back to 1950: worldwide, smoking kills three million people a year, or one every 10 seconds. By 2020, if current trends continue, that will hit 10 million a year. And about half a billion people now alive will one day die from smoking. It's "the biggest epidemic of fatal disease in the world," said Sir Richard Doll of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, adding, "I think it is immoral" that governments don't ban tobacco advertising.
 
And Pathmarks for Some
It's long been a frustrating urban fact: The rich get Pathmarks, the poor get bodegas. Supermarket chains often say it makes no economic sense to put stores in the inner city, which means those who can afford it the least wind up paying the most for their daily bread and bananas -- often 50 percent more (add that to a middle-class grocery bill and you'd hear some screams). But last week a nonprofit community group presumed to add a variable to this economic equation. The group, called the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, got $24 million from 10 big corporations -- like Prudential and Bank of America -- to help finance a Pathmark on 125th Street in East Harlem, as well as similar stores in poor neighborhoods nationwide.
 
Penn Station: Out of Its Hole?
You'd think that if Pat Moynihan and Al D'Amato agreed on something, it would be a shoo-in on Capitol Hill. But no -- you'd be forgetting that age-old Washington sport, New York-bashing. So at first last week it seemed that the House -- shocked! shocked! that Federal money would go to a pet local project -- would block any more money for a new Penn Station in the old Eighth Avenue Post Office. The project is dear to the hearts of New York's two Senators, as well as countless others disgusted with that "hole in the ground that is now Penn Station," as Mr. Moynihan described it -- the nation's busiest station, by the way, with 75 million passengers a year. But House and Senate negotiators finally agreed to retain $40 million for the project, enough to get it going.

HEADLINE: Welcome Back to Market

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

 BODY:
SHUNNED by American politicians and consumers for almost a decade, South African exporters are trying to re-enter the United States, a market that was off-limits to many of them until sanctions began evaporating in recent years.
Now the exporters are even hoping that the label that once repelled American shoppers, "Made in South Africa," will have cachet. Last week more than 120 South African companies brought their products to New York in what the South African officials described as the biggest trade exhibition they had ever organized. 
 "South Africa is the flavor of the month," said Martin Pamensky, whose company, Stanmar International in Markham, Ontario, distributes Ceres fruit juices from South Africa. "People are willing to try us, and we want to take full advantage of that."
Businessmen like Mr. Pamensky hope that the good will generated by South Africa's political transition crowned by Nelson Mandela's election as President in April may draw American consumers to South African goods. They are also counting on curiosity among Americans about items, once forbidden, like a bottle of South African wine.
Most of the exhibitors at the trade fair in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center were long-established white-run South African businesses. But among the handful of black South African business people who were there, some said they were counting on the goodwill they sensed among African-American importers they have dealt with.
"We're looking to Americans, especially black Americans, for help," said Hubert R. Matthews of the Macassar Small Business Forum, a cooperative venture that sells shoes and leather goods made in Macassar, a small township near Cape Town. "I'm selling not a product only, but a country."
One prospective customer, Mary Dowd, an African-American boutique owner from Durham, N.C., said she found Mr. Matthews's approach, and his products, appealing.
"I like the softness of the leather," Ms. Dowd said, as she fingered a pair of shoes on display in Mr. Matthews's booth.
With a nod to a cultural tie she feels, she added: "He's giving me more than a shoe. There's something extra."
Not everyone will have such an easy sell. South Africa's Trade Minister, Trevor Manuel, acknowledged that American investment in his country has been limited.
"After burning their fingers in the past, investors are cautious," Mr. Manuel said. "But some signals are positive. We will be attacking the U.S. market vigorously."
CERES FRUIT JUICES, for example, is expecting to go from zero to $20 million in sales in the coming year, with its guava, lichee and mango juices aimed at a niche market in Hispanic and Asian communities, Mr. Pamensky said.
Although Ceres juices were sold in the United States before sanctions took hold in the 1980's, re-entering the market is like starting over, Mr. Pamensky said, including having to meet strict new requirements set by the Food and Drug Administration. In South Africa, Ceres controls 95 percent of the domestic market for pure fruit juices.
Leather goods, jewelry and processed foods are among other exports that South African trade officials say they believe can sell well here, and help ease their country's current annual trade deficit of $350 million with the United States. American imports from South Africa reached $1.8 billion last year, and officials expect that figure to grow.
"It's very clear that there is a window of opportunity," said Wallace L. Ford II, a New York-based lawyer who advises the South African Government on attracting investment and trade. "Two years from now, it may not be the same."
Mr. Ford acknowledged that it is too early to detect any noticeable surge in South African exports to the United States. While the South African Government welcomes investment from African-Americans, he said, they do not want to limit themselves to any sector of the American market or offer better terms to any particular group.
THE South Africans are getting some support from the Federal and municipal governments here.
Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown called South Africa one of ten "big emerging markets" of opportunity for American businesses, and set up a joint business council with Mr. Manuel this week in Washington to encourage investment and trade in both directions.
"We ought to play a significant role in economic development there," Mr. Brown said. "It's in our interest to do so."
In New York, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced the establishment of a sister-city relationship with Johannesburg on the same day the trade fair opened.
"Just as enthusiastic as they were with sanctions, just so enthusiastic are they now to help out," said Len van Zyl, chief executive of the South African Foreign Trade Organization.
But South African exporters seem well aware that consistent sales are built less on political acceptance than on more quality and value for money.
Andre van der Walt, a distributor of South African wine, wants to try to duplicate the sales his wines have won in Europe, especially in the $5- to $15-a-bottle range.
"The market is bigger here, but we're starting at ground zero," said Mr. van der Walt.
Ken Onish of Cape Ventures Company in Stamford, Conn., an importer and distributor of wine from South Africa, hopes to carve out a niche for Pinotage, a South African favorite that was made by crossing a pinot noir grape with a cinsault in the mid-1920's.
"When you're the last in, you've got to have dramatically good value to win customers," Mr. Onish said.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING;
Chinese Cuisine As Smogasbord For the Intellect

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
There were burning questions about peanut oil. Should you really be using it? (yes) and how much? (enough).
There was a long debate on just how hot is hot when it comes to heating a wok. (Until it steams, it was revealed, although most cookbooks won't say so, because editors fear liability suits that could result from a kitchen that burns to the ground.) 
 These and other matters of Chinese cuisine were topics at the International Symposium on All Aspects of the Influence of the American Palate on Chinese Food, a three-day event last week at Queens College in conjunction with the colleges' Home Economic Department and Asian American Center, and the Institute for the Advancement of the Science and Art of Chinese Cuisine, which is in Manhattan.
Flushing, home to arguably the largest slice of the Asian diaspora in New York, seemed to be the natural setting for such an event, which drew anthropologists, nutritionists, chefs, sociologists and a curator who happens to have a collection of more than 1,000 Chinese takeout menus.
From Thursday to Saturday they sipped green tea, noshed on dim sum and mulled over the preparation, cultural significance and notable trends in what the symposium director, Jacqueline M. Newman, called the food that "a quarter of the world's population is eating at any given time."
Central to the symposium was the notion that American eating habits have influenced the preparation and form of Chinese food, for better (the addition of asparagus, not native to China) or worse (the chow mein sandwich). There were many and varied discussions about the American obsession with fat intake and how Chinese food rates (not as fatty as was stated in a recent study, the organizers maintained).
Some discussion topics included "Chinese-Vietnamese foods and food habits in Oregon," "MSG syndrome: realities and reason," and simply "chopsticks," a discussion of the social function of one of the oldest eating utensiles around.
One of the more popular panels was Jews and Their Passion for Chinese Food. The panelists included Prof. Harry G. Levine of Queens College, who referred to the heavily Jewish Upper West Side as Sichaun Valley. His hypothesis, he explained, was that the affinity was born on the Lower East Side, where, in the early 20th century, both Eastern European Jews and Chinese immigrants found a toehold in America.
While second- and third-generation Jews eat Chinese out, observed Norman Weinstein, another panelist, fourth- and fifth-generation Jews have taken to cooking Chinese foods. Mr. Weinstein, the program said, owns the Hot Wok in Brooklyn.
The symposium's keynote speaker, Ken Hom -- a cookbook writer, television program host and celebrated expert on Chinese food -- spoke at length about the influence of Hong Kong-style cuisine, which he described as the next global food wave.
The foods of Hong Kong, where Mr. Hom said 42,000 eating establishments thrive, are distinct in their preparations and ingredients, he said. Many rely on exotic wild game -- Anyone for bear paw? Try the left one. It's the one they lick, and is thus more tender -- imported foods, and lighter oils. And he said perceptions of Chinese food as unhealthy were due largely to those who cook with too much oil and the American passion for large portions of meat.
While Chinese restaurateurs have pleased palates from Jakarta to Jackson Heights, it was equally clear that some Chinese habits would not soon catch on in the United States: roasted goose wings won't be replacing popcorn at the movies any time soon. JENNIFER STEINHAUER

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
In the On-Line Market, the Name of the Game Is Internet

BYLINE: By Laurie Flynn 

 BODY:
AS the largest and oldest of the commercial on-line computer services, Compuserve Inc.'s Compuserve Information Service is like a staid reading room compared with a growing assortment of younger and flashier cyberspace hangouts like Prodigy Services and America Online. But with membership at 2.25 million, and growing at 80,000 a month, Compuserve, is still the place to be for many modem users.
Compuserve, founded in 1979, offers a broad range of general-interest services like news from The Associated Press, Roger Ebert's movie reviews and the deliberately misspelled Eaasy Sabre airline ticketing service. 
 But Compuserve carries many services intended for business computer users, like product-support forums by computer makers and software companies, which have become the first place many users look for advice in solving technical problems or to get the latest "bug fix." Compuserve's copious statistical databases and archives, moreover, attract serious researchers, despite the relatively high prices for accessing documents.
But like all commercial on-line services, Compuserve now faces a serious challenge from the immense popularity of the global web of networks known as the Internet. The fastest growth on the Internet appears to be coming from corporations that see it as a way to communicate with their customers and suppliers. It is the type of service that Compuserve has long provided through its Network Services Division to customers like Nike, Federal Express, Harley-Davidson and British Airways. Nike, the athletic shoe maker based in Beaverton, Ore., uses the Compuserve network to communicate with its salespeople in the field.
Given the changing landscape, the question for Compuserve is: How does one compete with the Internet, a network 10 times Compuserve's size with resources that in many cases are virtually free for the taking?
The answer appears to be, if you can't beat 'em, join 'em. Last week, Compuserve, a division of H & R Block based in Columbus, Ohio, announced it had acquired an equity stake in a tiny Utah start-up called Network Publishing Inc. as a way to help kick-start Compuserve's Internet business.
The idea behind the investment, says Compuserve's director of product marketing, James Hogan, is to provide a service for corporations that want to have a presence on the Internet but would rather not do the administrative work themselves. Compuserve intends to help these corporate clients set up shop on an easy-to-navigate portion of the Internet known as the World Wide Web.
"A lot of those companies building their own Web sites are telling us they don't want to take on the expense -- that they're more interested in outsourcing it," Mr. Hogan said.
Mary Modahl, senior analyst of people and technology strategies at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., said that providing Internet services is a necessary evolution for Compuserve. "Previously, they could go to corporate clients and say they could set up a corporate application on Compuserve," Ms. Modahl said. "Now, they can set up a corporate application on the Internet. That has a certain cachet and value."
Currently, Compuserve Inc. is divided into two entities: the Compuserve Network Services Division, a network consulting and services business, and the Compuserve Information Service, the on-line service.
It could be that the Internet service business someday becomes a third division, Mr. Hogan said. Sometime next spring, Compuserve intends to begin offering Internet access to the public, as a business separate from the Compuserve on-line service. In this regard it would be competing with established Internet access providers like Netcom On-Line Communications Services of San Jose, Calif. Some observers predict that providing Internet access could eventually become Compuserve's main business, as its consumer service finds itself increasingly squeezed out by the Internet.
"I think Compuserve as a business is going to change very radically," said David Strom, a communications and networking consultant in Port Washington, N.Y. "It could be they're going to become a pipe, an access provider to the Internet, rather than a content provider."
But Compuserve, like other on-line services, says it will continue to find ways to differentiate its offerings from databases of similar information on the Internet, by providing better search tools, a more organized approach and better customer service.
Compuserve has just released a CD-ROM, to be updated bimonthly, that works with its consumer on-line service to add video clips and music to the service in a magazine-like format. In the first edition, for example, users can view a video clip from a Jimmy Buffett concert and then with a click of the mouse connect to the Compuserve on-line service where they can order the audio CD. All the on-line services are working to add multimedia.
"Compuserve has 15 years experience in organizing that data and making it easy for them to find it and grab it," Mr. Hogan said. "It's not just a user interface issue but how content is packaged."
Disclosure Inc., a publisher of financial data including documents from the Securities and Exchange Commission, is one example of a content provider trying to walk the line. Disclosure's databases are currently available on 35 commercial services including Compuserve. But Disclosure is currently testing the Internet waters and will eventually offer versions of some its products there, said William O'Connor, executive vice president of the database division at Disclosure, which is based in Bethesda, Md.
Some companies that have databases to sell are asking themselves "why don't we just skip the middle man, like Compuserve, and offer our products directly on the Internet?" But Mr. O'Connor doesn't see the private on-line services going away.
"There's going to have to be an adjustment," Mr. O'Connor said. "Just as the Internet will move more to value-added services, the rest of us will just keep moving ahead of it."
Today the Internet remains difficult to use and too slow for many operations, and for this reason many users would prefer to get their Internet connectivity through an on-line service like Compuserve that they may already be familiar with. Today, only about 10 percent of Internet users have a graphical searching tool -- a popular one is called Mosaic -- to simplify the network for them. By contrast, most of the commercial online services already sport a graphical front-end.
"The Internet is not necessarily the panacea people paint it to be," said Amanda Hixson, general manager of industry publishing for Infoworld, a computer publication in San Mateo, Calif., that publishes an electronic version on Apple Computer's E-World on-line service. "On the Internet we can put up our own server, but until everybody has access to it, it makes sense to provide Infoworld through the services that support the access people have. We need to support our readers by being where they are."
Still, Compuserve, like every on-line service, is finding it must open itself up to the Internet or risk losing customers. Already on Compuserve you can send electronic mail across the Internet (just as you can from an America Online account or from the Prodigy Service) and access the Internet bulletin boards known as Usenet newsgroups. In the coming months, Compuserve will add support for two standard Internet tools: Telnet, which allows users to log on to other computers on the Internet, and FTP,, which lets users upload and download files. Once all the pieces are in place, a customer should be able to move easily from Compuserve to the Internet and the other way around, and will even be able to use any of the Internet's graphical user interface programs like Mosaic.
While there's no question that Compuserve and the other on-line services are feeling the heat from the Internet, they'd all prefer to portray the changing market as more opportunity than threat. Yet Ms. Modahl of Forrester estimates there is only a 12-to-18 month window before most of the difficulties of delivering information on the Internet are gone, and with them much of the traditional market for today's on-line services.
A decade ago, "there was an opportunity for I.B.M. in the PC business but it certainly wasn't good for the I.B.M. mainframe," Ms. Modahl said. "The fact is, all the on-line services must change."

HEADLINE: Technology;
Shrink Wrap Goes Really Big Time

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
IT is the hurricane season, when an insurance agent's fretfulness turns to thoughts of roofless houses filling with rain.
For insurance companies, protecting storm-damaged homes from rain can save billions of dollars in additional claims for walls, floors and furnishings destroyed by water. 
 It is a powerful incentive that is now pushing insurers to make new arrangements for quick, temporary covering of storm-damaged homes, and even to adopt new technology and materials.
An entrepreneur who hopes to capitalize on the impulse is Anthony Seraphin, the 49-year-old president of Global Wrap and Services, a nine-month-old company based in Chalfont, Pa.
Mr. Seraphin, it seems, is a shrink-wrap specialist, having started out in 1981 wrapping small pleasure boats for winter storage.
He moved on to building small temporary shelters for storage or protection from the elements, and wrapping larger, more irregularly shaped objects like moth-balled military aircraft and new industrial equipment that needed protection in transit.
Now, in starting Global Wrap and Services, Mr. Seraphin wants to apply his techniques to wrapping houses -- from chimneys and dormer windows down to the foundation.
Rather than soliciting individual homeowners, he is trying to reach large numbers by arranging with their insurance companies to provide his services after natural disasters.
"For a while, I was getting nowhere with the insurance companies," Mr. Seraphin said. "But now, several are talking like they are real interested."
The first big contract could come in Florida, where the state insurance department is pushing companies to cooperate with one another and make advance arrangements with contractors to handle temporary repairs of any home damaged by a hurricane, regardless of the home owner's insurance company.
"Global Wrap could be the perfect kind of partner for us and could have responsibility for handling several neighborhoods," said Marty Urra, chief executive of Smart, a Miami disaster-services company selected by Florida officials to coordinate disaster responses of insurance companies, contractors and the Federal and local governments.
Although Mr. Seraphin's techniques cost more than the standard practices of boarding up windows and covering roofs with tarpaulins, Mr. Urra said the higher protection from wrapping a house could appeal to wealthier homeowners.
Because Mr. Seraphin uses sheets of plastic seven-thousandths of an inch thick, or four times the thickness or ordinary household trash bags, it is far stronger than the thinner plastic sheets typically sold in the neighborhood hardware store.
The thick plastic, which he buys in 32-foot-wide rolls from various suppliers, does not include recycled materials, which Mr. Seraphin says makes it less likely to tear or rip. Buckles and cables are used to attach the plastic to a home, and then a hand-held flame thrower is used to shrink the plastic wrap and make it as taut as a drum.
Insurance companies have long had contigency plans for disasters, with warehouses full of cots, stepladders and cellular phones, plus emergency procedures to summon hundreds of claims adjusters to a disaster scene.
But what they have lacked is a method to quickly and economically seal-up damaged homes to protect against further destruction.
Immediately after Hurricane Andrew in August 1992, for example, homeowners lucky enough to still have a structure worth protecting were left to make their own arrangements for stop-gap temporary repairs, like boarding up windows and spreading tarpaulines over damaged roofs.
Those who were unable or unwilling to meet the often exorbitant cash demands of construction crews simply had to wait for their insurance claims adjuster.
Meanwhile, homes with relatively minor damage to roofs and windows became giant sponges, soaking up rain until the interior walls, as well as all furnishings, had to be replaced. Insurance companies say that about half of the average claim from Hurricane Andrew was caused by the days of steady rain that followed the damaging winds.
Raymond L. Stone, director of catastrophe claims at Travelers Insurance said sealing an home with plastic wrap "is an intriguing idea we are talking about" as Travelers cooperates with efforts in Florida to coordinate temporary repairs.
Mr. Seraphin said the idea of wrapping homes came to him while he listened to Pink Floyd and watched television reports of earthquake damage in Armenia in 1988.
With help from Union Carbide, a manufacturer of the material used to make the plastic sheet, Mr. Seraphin built temporary shelters in Armenia -- and again in Iran after an earthquake a few years later.
With that practical experience under his belt, Mr. Seraphin exudes confidence about the use of his wrapping techniques -- whether for disasters or any type of big wrapping job.
"If Christo and I ever got together, I would say, 'Look out.' We would be wrapping things bigger than the Pont Neuf," he said, referring to the conceptual artist Christo, who once wrapped the famous bridge in Paris, and is now planning to wrap the Reichstag in Berlin.
In the more mundane world of disaster recovery, Mr. Seraphin envisions crews of workers methodically moving down a row of homes, spreading 32-foot-wide sheets of plastic, strapping it to the building and heat-fusing seams, while leaving openings for ventilation and access to the interior.
The materials would cost about $73 a home, and a crew could finish an entire house in about an hour.
"It could be sort of like Henry Ford's assembly line," Mr. Seraphin said.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE;
The New Money: Patient and Realistic

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
In the late 1980's, speculation bottomed out around Tompkins Square Park, and the commercial investors that had hoped for million-dollar profits fled in droves. But Alex Lokshin saw the future.
"We believed that, no matter what, Avenue A was going to eventually become the heart of the East Village," said Mr. Lokshin, who, along with his brother and three other investors bought 10 properties near the avenue. 
 In July, the partners broke ground on their largest project to date, the $5 million East Village Gardens: 14,000 square feet of retail space in the basement and first floor, 28 luxury apartments upstairs at Third Street. It's the only new construction in the East Village.
"We looked here even in the bad days and we saw the best night life, the most action anywhere," said Mr. Lukshin, who owns a Brooklyn-based construction concern. "And we knew that people would be willing to pay a lot to live here."
Their patience is paying off, they said. The market has supported 10 percent rent increases in some of their apartments during the past four months alone, with some of their small one-bedrooms on Avenue A renting for $1,250 a month.
The Lukshins are not the only investors who have begun to open their wallets again recently on Avenue A, after a spurt of condominium development and a storefront art gallery scene died out in the late 1980's because of the economy and poor conditions on the avenue.
Pinchas Milstein and Amnon Kahati, the partners who started the Sidewalk Cafe and Bar eight years ago at Seventh Street, helped open Pisces, at Sixth Street, in May 1993, serving grilled salmon at $13.50 in a dining room with a carved-wood ceiling and linen napkins. "We thought it was about time to bring a midtown restaurant to the East Village," said Nir Adar, another partner.
Up the avenue, just south of Ninth Street, three former waiters and an interior designer started Zitella, which serves California-style Italian food, in December, joining what they now see as "gourmet ghetto."
Mark Christiansen, 30, one of the partners and an Avenue A resident for several years, said, "To tell you the truth, I don't think we would have decided to open this up here, especially right across from the park, five years ago." R.K.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPDATE;
Street Rebuilding Clears Another Hump

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Along Main Street in downtown Flushing, shiny black traffic-light posts tower over old gray ones inches away. Within weeks, the black posts will be equipped with traffic lights and the shorter ones will be felled, signaling the end of phase two in the reconstruction of the streets of downtown Flushing.
The City Economic Development Corporation, which is overseeing the repairs, expects to start repaving the street within days. 
 The $7.4 million resurfacing of Main Street, in downtown's most heavily traveled stretch between Northern Boulevard and Sanford Avenue, has created heavy traffic jams for two years in an area served by 23 bus lines.
The first phase of the reconstruction, on Prince Street, was completed in 1989 at a cost of $3 million. The city Economic Development Corporation says the third phase, Union Street between Northern Boulevard and Sanford Avenue, will cost $8 million and start in the fall of 1995. NORIMITSU ONISHI

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
The Parking Angel, Saint of Patrons

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
THE Angel peered down the street, a red forest of expired parking meters, and saw the Agent at the end of it.
It was his nemesis, a slight, smileless man who could ticket more illegally parked cars in one breathless trip than other traffic enforcement agents could all day. "He goes back to his car after every trip," the Angel said. "He doesn't have much stamina. But, boy, the damage he does in one round." 
 Fumbling for some quarters, he hurriedly slipped one in a meter as the Agent whipped out a notepad and began scribbling tickets.
"In three minutes, he got three cars," said David Sober, the Parking Angel of the Chamber of Commerce in Forest Hills, Queens. "I guess I got three, too. But he had to write down a lot of information."
Mr. Sober was recalling a war story in one business community's fight against the recent but seemingly inexorable spread in New York City of shopping strips blessed with bountiful, and often free, parking. Even as Mayor Giuliani's administration ponders zoning law changes that would let in ever more suburban-like, car-oriented mega stores and discounters, many neighborhood businesses worry that drivers will abandon stores on streets that are saddled with metered and time-limited parking.
In Forest Hills two months ago, the local business association started tackling what it believes is the biggest turnoff to shopping in the area -- parking tickets. Jack Partamian, the chamber's president and the owner of a video store, said the group had long tried to persuade the city to extend the time limit on the one-hour meter parking on Austin Street between Ascan Avenue and 69th Road, as well as at the 30-minute parking on Continental Avenue. Kathleen H. Reilly, the local community board's district manager, said the eight-block area was home to about 250 small stores, mostly longtime tenants, though a few national chains, like the Gap and Benetton, have opened branches in recent years. Since their arrival, the neighborhood has grown busier and parking scarcer.
Mr. Partamian said: "People'd come in and do some shopping and get stuck in line, and, boom, they'd be late and get a $55 ticket. Who'd want to come back here after that?"
So after persuading two local landlords to donate $600 each and adding $600 of its own, the chamber hired Mr. Sober. Every day except Sunday, between 11 A.M. and 5 P.M., the Parking Angel travels the area, dropping quarters into meters that have expired or have only a minute left. On the windshield, instead of a ticket, he leaves a note that explains the program.
"With a lot of small stores closing, you can't wait for the economy to turn around," he said the other day. "You've got to take the initiative."
The hiring of the Parking Angel may be the most quixotic attempt to hold on to shoppers with cars. But several other communities are reacting to the megastores' perceived threat, especially in Queens and Brooklyn, where they are concentrated.
The shopping district in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, along Third and Fifth Avenues and 86th Street, has always felt vulnerable because of its proximity to the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and the pull of four sprawling malls on nearby Staten Island and in New Jersey. But the arrival of several superstores in the borough prompted merchants to lobby for free parking.
Two years ago, after obtaining the city's agreement, merchants began offering customers vouchers for free parking at a local municipal parking garage. The program's initial success has waned somewhat because weekly costs of $500 caused one of the biggest participants to pull out, said John Logue, the president of the Voice of Bay Ridge Business, a local group. Nowadays, the group is weighing other possibilities, including pressing the city to turn Third and Fifth Avenues into one-way streets to accommodate more cars.
"It's unfair that the city offers all these megastores tax abatements when it's the mom-and-pop stores that have been the backbone of the community for years," Mr. Logue said. "We used to have to worry about New Jersey and Long Island. Now we have to compete against malls that are basically city-subsidized."
The City Planning Commission argues that because of the city's density and untapped disposable income, the large retailers will not jeopardize neighborhood businesses. Officials also say that small businesses have thrived for years against superstores a highway away.
"These stores are competing against the suburbs," said Barry Dinerstein, a senior planner with the commission who specializes in retailing. "They've been competing against them for 25 years. Parking has always been an issue for merchants on commercials strips."
Allan J. Fromberg, a spokesman for the City Department of Transportation, said that the point of meters was to provide turnover, not revenue, and that the effort to make the area car-friendlier may even be illegal. Feeding a meter to park past a posted limit is against the law, he said.
Back on the street, Mr. Sober deposited another quarter, one of the 40 to 50 a day. He marked the car's tire with chalk. "God's grace is limitless," the Parking Angel said. "But ours is limited to a quarter."
Having been given so much power, so suddenly, Mr. Sober can be forgiven for pronouncing moral judgments. A few weeks ago, he said, a driver waited inside a car until the Parking Angel was nearby and then left without putting a quarter into the meter. Mr. Sober was astounded, and became more so when he saw that the car was a 1994 Cadillac Seville. "I can't be bothered with that ilk," he said. "Women stuck in beauty parlors getting their hair done, O.K. Fathers picking up their daughters from ballet class, O.K."
Mr. Sober, 49, traces his moral authority to his college major, religious studies. After dropping out in the 1960's, he held a string of jobs until he returned to Fordham University a few years ago. He said he would like to keep this job until he finds one as a counselor. (Mr. Partamian, the chamber's president, said the program will keep running unless the financing runs out.)
It was a good day for Mr. Sober. So far, he had seen only two windshields with tickets, and his nemesis was nowhere near. Instead, one of the friendlier traffic enforcement agents was making the rounds. "I don't consider him my enemy or anything," said the agent, who declined to give her name.
Even the driver who had received one of the tickets was not too displeased. Inside the Elite Nails salon on Austin Street, Dawn Durso had looked helplessly as a traffic agent ticketed her Pontiac Grand Prix. As the manicurist painted her nails scarlet, Ms. Durso griped that a pedicure and manicure took far longer than an hour. But she brightened immediately when she saw Mr. Sober, who had saved her from a similar fate a week earlier.
"I do believe in angels. I have one tattooed on my leg," she said, lifting up her right cuff and revealing a cherub wrapped around her ankle.

HEADLINE: THE NIGHT;
It's a Fix-Up, Dress-Up, Button-Down World

BYLINE: By BOB MORRIS 

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I.

 BODY:
Many of the guests inspecting the mirrors on exhibit at the Parrish Art Museum's design biennial, benefit and auction on Sept. 17 couldn't help inspecting themselves as well. But they did so clandestinely.
During the cocktail hour, in bouts with the vice of vanity and with the expediency of the guilty sucking on cigarettes in stairwells, they snuck glimpses to check lipstick, lapels and bald spots. "It's very amusing," said Susan Soros, a co-chairwoman of the event and the director of the Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, where recently students have been studying Greek vases depicting women looking into mirrors. "Women go up to look at the frames, and they start fixing their hair," she said. 
 Ms. Soros, who is married to the financier George Soros, said she doesn't spend much time in front of her own mirror at home. "I get dressed in the morning in five minutes," she said, as she caught a friend checking herself in a fishbowl-shaped mirror. "You're looking at yourself!"
Robert Woolley, the director of decorative arts at Sotheby's, conducted the after-dinner auction of the artist-designed mirrors. "You all have a corner that needs something," he told the prospective bidders.
But if the face is the mirror of the mind, and speech is a mirror of the soul, then an art auction is a mirror of the economy, and even handsome mirrors by names like Richard Artschwager, Michael Graves and Christian Lacroix went for modest prices.
After the auction, the guests, including Sheila and Tom Wolfe (his last mirror of New York society was a bonfire), returned to the hall of mirrors, like so many Alices to the looking glass.
"I don't know where I'm going to put these," Beth Rudin DeWoody, another co-chairwoman of the event, said of mirrors by the artists Tom Otterness and Donald Baechler that she'd just acquired. "I don't have room in either of my houses."
Diane Kaplan, a museum member, seemed more excited about her acquisition, a Sylvia Plath-inspired bell-jar mirror by the artist Robert Dash. "Don't let people touch that," she told a guard. "I don't want fingerprints on it."
The guard nodded. "She's going to need a lot of Windex," he said as she walked away.
UPTOWN -- Don't mention the G-word around Rory Kennedy, who doesn't find the cloak of glamour easy to wear. Even at her own glamorous premiere screening, Ms. Kennedy, the youngest of Robert and Ethel Kennedy's 11 children and a 1991 graduate of Brown University who majored in women's studies, was doing her best to eschew frivolity.
"Making a documentary is expensive," Ms. Kennedy said in a no-nonsense tone from a rooftop garden at the Time & Life Building on Sept. 19, before the screening of "Women of Substance," the documentary she co-produced with Robin Smith about drug-addicted mothers. "It involves a painful amount of fund-raising."
Ms. Kennedy was in a rakish suit that a friend in the fashion business helped her borrow from Paul Smith Women but that she didn't want to discuss. She spoke of educational videos as a tool for the community good while the party filled up with those who are inclined to gather around many a cause for the community good, but perhaps more quickly when a Kennedy's attached to it.
"We provide this video at a low cost to organizations to use as a lobbying tool to help change policy," said Ms. Kennedy, whose politically idealistic train of thought was interrupted by a G-word type, the beautiful young actress Uma Thurman.
"Oh, look who's here!" Ms. Kennedy said.
"I flew in to see you," Ms. Thurman said as they hugged like schoolgirls. Ms. Thurman, slumming in a ratty overcoat of the nonmaterialist with a Hollywood income, admired Ms. Kennedy's dapper suit.
"Look at you!" she said. "It's your big night and your big photo session, Rory!"
A photographer took their picture. When Ms. Kennedy began to discuss her next documentary, about legal needle-exchange programs, she was interrupted again, first by her handsome brother Bobby and then by an administrator from the March of Dimes (a sponsor of the party), who said, "Excuse me, Rory, but did you know Joanne is here?" Joanne meant Joanne Woodward, who narrated the documentary.
Ms. Kennedy, 25, who seems to be learning at a young age how a little glamour can go a long way toward a good cause (even if she won't say so), started to work the crowd.
"Give us your best glamour smile," Patti Munter, the director of the National Organization on Fetal Alcohol Syndrome, told Ms. Kennedy, who ended up wearing borrowed Moschino for other screenings that week.
"Ugh," Ms. Kennedy said.
The G-word again.

 
 
Arthur Ashe, the Patrician
 "Arthur Ashe did not hang out," Alan King, the comedian and tennis buff, said on Sept. 19, before a screening of "Arthur Ashe: Citizen of the World," an HBO documentary about the late tennis star. Mr. King prefers saying he used to "spend time" with Mr. Ashe, whom he considered a friend.
"Arthur Ashe was a patrician," Mr. King said, as a crowd flooded into the Celeste Bartos Forum of the New York Public Library. "Arthur Ashe walking into a room quietly attracted attention. Arthur had a quiet style. He was the button-down guy of button-down guys."
He sipped his drink as the fog of memory cleared to reveal the telling details one tends to forget over time. "Actually, he did have some outfits he was being paid to endorse that were pretty loud," Mr. King said. "I'd tell him, 'Arthur, that outfit!' and he'd say to me, 'Alan, at these prices . . . ' "
Sometimes outfits speaks louder than words.

HEADLINE: THE GAP;
Compromise Is American, Not Haitian

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
THE thousands of American troops who landed in Haiti without resistance last week stepped straight from their airplanes, ships and helicopters into a conflict that bears no resemblance to the one for which they had trained.
They have been inserted into a society that has been at war with itself from the moment it became an independent state, and this makes them combatants in a struggle more complicated and perilous than an invasion. 
 At its core, the struggle is as simple and as hard to comprehend as this: The Haitian ruling classes have always viewed their country's poor as less than human. One of the Creole slogans associated with the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the champion of the poor whom President Clinton is trying to restore to Haiti's presidency, is "Tout moun se moun," or "every person is a person." To a G.I., this may sound innocuous. But to Haitian ears it has the ring of revolution.
 
Mission Impenetrable
This is one reason it is so hard to define just what the American soldiers are here to do. Gen. Henry H. Shelton, the commander of the American force, quickly proclaimed last week that "this is not an occupation force," but few Haitians believed him. The first sight of such formidably armed and equipped troops, pledged to bring Father Aristide back, brought the poor swarming out of their slums to applaud the Americans, certain they could now resume the process of social reform interrupted three years ago this week by the overthrow of their president.
More ominously, the elite that has run Haiti for most of the country's existence retreated behind the walls of its mansions in the cool hills of Petionville, above the fetid slums of Port-au-Prince, muttering darkly about betrayals and reprisals.
Therein lies the main danger for the more than 10,000 American soldiers and marines who have arrived so far. The accord allowing their "permissive entry," negotiated last Sunday by former President Jimmy Carter after two days of talks with Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, was a product of "the peculiarly American belief that all people are reasonable and you can always find common ground if you just look for it hard enough," one Latin American diplomat here said.
"But Haiti is not like that," the diplomat warned. "There are distinct visions here that simply cannot be reconciled and differences that cannot be bridged."
The gap between the classes, and American and Haitian views of the world, was made particularly vivid when a coconut vendor was beaten to death by police Tuesday as American troops, obeying orders, stood by. Had the incident not occurred in front of foreigners armed with cameras and guns, it would have gone unremarked here.
"They treat us like so much garbage," said Jean-Baptiste Polycarpe, a 35-year-old carpenter who moved to the sprawling slum called Cite Soleil eight years ago from the countryside, hoping to improve his life. "We are men too. But they do not see us. They do not care that we are hungry, that we have no work, that our children can get no medicine."
The Clinton Administration has repeatedly said that American troops are here not as part of a long-term nation-building effort, or to change Haiti's political and social culture, but on a limited mission to assure the "maintenance of a secure environment" for the return of the country's legitimate, popularly elected Government.
Yet to many Haitians, the whole point of restoring Father Aristide to power is to enable him to address those historic inequities.
"A lot of the things you Americans take for granted, when thought here are a revolution," said Suzy Castor, co-director of the Research and Training Center for Economic and Social Development, a private Haitian group. "People here are not asking for anything extraordinary, only the things that you have enjoyed since 1789, simple things: jobs, schools, lights, health care, water. For a peasant, a glass of clean water is a big thing."
Inevitably, the arrival of the American forces after three years of brutal repression has again awakened hope that those modest goals can be achieved. "We are not afraid of the Americans, because they are here to protect us from the devils," said Abner Jean, a 45-year-old vendor of chewing gum. "We are trying to welcome them here, but the police keep hitting us."
The inability or unwillingness of American military authorities to immediately control the Haitian security forces, which include hundreds of armed civilians acting like descendants of the Tontons Macoute (the secret police of the brutal Duvalier regime), baffled many Haitians. Under an occupation that is not an occupation after an invasion that was not an invasion, the extent of American authority was not clear, as it would have been had American troops come storming in, and the Haitian military and its civilian supporters moved rapidly to exploit every opening to make it appear they are allies and partners of the American troops.
 
False Assumptions
 At first, following the tone set by Gen. Colin L. Powell and other members of the Carter delegation, American military officials said they planned to treat General Cedras and his associates with "honor" and "respect," as if they were dealing with officers who shared their values and came from an institution much like their own.
But the 7,700 members of the Haitian military have been taught to see their role differently. As a policeman used his billy club to beat several people sitting on a wall one morning last week, an American reporter who had been talking with the group asked what he was doing.
"I'm doing my job," the policeman replied.
What exactly is your job, the reporter persisted.
"To intimidate the populace," the policeman responded, as he left in search of more people to pummel.
That type of routine official violence quickly forced the United States to toughen its attitude toward General Cedras and the forces he commands. On Thursday, the Haitian army's only heavy weapons unit was disarmed, its guns and armored vehicles seized and dismantled.
Some Haitians are convinced that the United States is pursuing a Trojan Horse strategy, waiting until all 14,000 troops are here before it cracks down on the military. But others have a different worry: that the Clinton Administration will merely tinker with an organization many wanted eliminated as a political force.
"Ours is an army of occupation, not a truly national army," said a prominent intellectual who is still afraid, despite the presence of American troops, to be identified by name. "The only things it really knows how to do are repress and exploit. I'm not saying there are no good soldiers, but the institution itself carries the stain of original sin, and while it exists, no government here can sustain itself. There has to be a clean break."
The Americans seemed to be taking much the same approach, many Haitians complain, toward other fundamentally flawed institutions, like the Parliament that the military's figurehead president, Emile Jonassaint, was trying to call into session in an effort to pass an amnesty for General Cedras and his associates. Throughout Haitian history, elected officials, from the President on down, have represented the will of those who have the money and influence to buy and sell seats and votes. That system, known as "politique de doublure," or "politics by understudies," has been one of the means by which the mulatto elite has controlled its black countrymen, and has survived every attack.
The United States has been down this road before, of course. American troops occupied this country from 1915 to 1934, withdrawing in frustration at Haitian opposition and their own failure to effect meaningful change. In an attempt to determine what went wrong, a Federal panel called the Forbes Commission investigated the occupation and concluded that blame should be placed on the inability of Americans to see Haiti as it really is.
"The failure of the occupation to understand the social problems of Haiti, its brusque attempt to plant democracy there by drill and harrow, its determination to set up a middle class -- however wise and necessary it may seem to Americans -- all these explain why, in part, the high hopes of our good works in this land have not been realized," the commission's report stated. More than 60 years later, the Americans are now back, still aspiring to do good works.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Who's Hot and Who's Not In the New Kremlinology

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
DECIDING who's who is a cruel game, particularly in Russia. In the last Soviet-era list of the country's most prominent people, published in 1989, Raisa Gorbachev was lavishly praised as "the First Lady of the U.S.S.R." By 1992, she was introduced rather unceremoniously as "Gorbachev's wife" and her date of birth revised from 1934 to 1931. In the new 1994 edition, her birthrate reverts to 1934, but the mention of one of her greatest sources of pride, her memoir, "I Hope," is brutally abbreviated.
The 1994 Who's Who of Russia, officially titled "The Biographical Dictionary of the Former Soviet Union," is about to be released. And though it is not the first such guide to emerge since the collapse of the Soviet Union, it is the first Russian-language version. 
 "Who's Who in America" is exactly that -- a quintessentially Yankee kind of snobbism, for which subjects are encouraged to submit their own biographical material (and buy their own copies). Notability is measured not by birth and breeding, but by fortunes and advanced degrees. Until now such a reference could not have been compiled by either the Communist Party of old (anyone who was anyone was already on the list of party members) or even the anti-Communist underground, which would have viewed it as self-indulgent.
But the 1994 Russian Who's Who is a reference book for its time. There are more than 6,000 names, and the several hundred changes since 1992 are a testimony both to the dizzying pace of upheaval in post Communist Russia -- and to who is no longer who.
The earlier editions of the Russian Who's Who were published in English by the German publishing house Bowker-Saud, a division of Reed Reference Publishing, which is also the parent company of Marquis, the publishers of the American Who's Who. But unlike its blander American cousin, the Russian Who's Who does not allow participants to supply their own material. Two London-based emigres, the journalists Jeanne Vronskaya and Vladimir Chuguyev, compiled the biographies with an idiosyncratic, sometimes peppery, but always revealing take on who is noteworthy and who is not.
Dozens of former dissidents have been dropped, ("No one has heard from them in years" is how Ms. Vronskaya explained the omissions) and scores of new business leaders have been added, including the dashing Irina Khakamada, one of Russia's few female entrepreneurs and a leader of the December 12 Union, a liberal, pro-business faction in Parliament.
Mikhail S. Gorbachev, ("political figure") and Boris N. Yeltsin ("first freely elected President of Russia") received long, respectful notices in all editions. But some return figures probably wish they hadn't.
Ruslan Khazbulatov, the former speaker of Parliament who led the failed insurrection against Boris N. Yeltsin last October and briefly went to jail, had this on his Who's Who record: "according to several sources, has a weak spot for drugs."
The 1989 edition did not include Nikolai Romanovich Romanov, the head of the Romanov dynasty and heir to the Russian throne, who lives in Rome. By 1994, reflecting the growing Russian nostalgia for an air- brushed pre-revolutionary past, the authors included him, and even restored his long-lost title of Prince.
Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky is described like this: "an effective orator, accused by the press of demagoguery, but enjoys some support of the public." The authors add, "The intelligentsia despises him."
The well-known television personality Vladimir V. Pozner also received a somewhat scornful review: "In 1986 a host of his own TV show. Continued to defend the Communist positions in the period of glasnost and perestroika until about 1989. Suddenly, according to him, 'he became disillusioned with the system.' "
Ms. Vronskaya said they had resisted offers from Soviet publishers to translate and publish their earlier editions in the Soviet Union, fearing censorship. In 1992, the Russian publishing firm Terra again asked to make the reference work available here, and the authors agreed. "It's very useful in the new Russia," Ms. Vronskaya said. "Business people need to see biographical material immediately -- they cannot be expected to plow through the 51-volume Soviet encyclopedia." (The Soviet encyclopedia is being revised for a post-Communist readership, but the project is expected to take years.)
Some of the most intriguing material is buried in between editions. The painter Ilya Glazunov was described in 1989 as "one of the most famous and controversial Russian artists" and also "one of the few Russian millionaires." In those days, money-making was still rather suspect, and the authors had politely added, "but his life-style is said to be very modest." In the 1994 edition, he remains a millionaire, but the mention of a modest life-style disappears.
While some of the best-known Russian businessmen are listed, such as Konstantin N. Borovoi, one of the founders of the Moscow stock exchange and a fledgling politician, the authors did not update his entry in time to mention that earlier this year he was forced out of the stock exchange by disenchanted partners.
Organized crime figures are not included. Neither is Sergei Mavrodi, who masterminded MMM, the pyramid scheme that collapsed this summer. From his prison cell on Friday, he registered as a candidate for the lower house of Parliament. Ms. Vronskaya said such oversights would be corrected. "We are planning an entirely new reference work with 1,000 names of the entire network of security and espionage." She paused, and added excitedly, "including foreigners."

HEADLINE: In Quest for Perot Constituents, Cuomo Attacks, Pataki Parries

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 24

 BODY:
Behind in the polls and facing a crowd of angry, independent voters, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo let loose a blistering attack today on Senator George E. Pataki, accusing him of raising taxes as Mayor of Peekskill, achieving nothing in the Legislature and unseating the only Republican woman in the Senate.
For his part, Mr. Pataki, appearing before the same crowd about a half hour after Mr. Cuomo left, seemed content to play the serene front-runner, and his treatment of the Governor was far more gentle than Mr. Cuomo had received from some disaffected constituents. 
 Mr. Cuomo was heckled relentlessly as he spoke to a small crowd at a candidate's fair on the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University that was sponsored by United We Stand, America, Ross Perot's political organization. But the Governor gave as good as he got. And when the heckling continued after his speech, he traded insults in a face-to-face confrontation with a pair of men who cursed him in both English and Italian.
Although the candidates never crossed paths, their exchange was about as close as they have come to a debate so far in the 1994 campaign. And the event showed the importance they attach to mining the voter discontent that won Mr. Perot 1.1 million votes, 16 percent of the total, in New York State in the 1992 Presidential election.
As arranged by his aides to avoid any sign of partisanship, Mr. Perot showed up after both candidates departed and delivered the last speech on a 10-city, two-week tour aimed at promoting interest around the country in the midterm elections. He spoke to 1,500 to 2,000 people.
Mr. Perot did not mention the New York race specifically. He said that he would begin buying time on powerful radio stations, starting with WABC-AM (770) in New York, for two-minute spots on political issues.
Immigration, the crime bill, the health care bill and the country's economic troubles were among his topics. "We're still shipping our jobs overseas at warp speed," Mr. Perot said. Full employment, he added, was needed to solve the country's deficit problems. "People making good money pay good taxes," he said.
During the Governor's speech, which was by far his strongest personal attack on Mr. Pataki, Mr. Cuomo painted the Republican gubernatorial nominee as a false prophet of change.
"You'll have some people telling you you have to change the political system," he said, his voice rising as he thumped the lectern. "Now one of them has been a candidate and a candidate and a candidate and a candidate and has served for 10 years. Never changed anything but his positions. Nothing.
"Never passed a bill that meant anything. Never got a single welfare person to work, never changed a single statute, never made an inch of progress in political reform. Spent a fortune running campaigns and never got anything done and now, suddenly, in a conversion, they're telling you they're going to change the political system."
Mr. Cuomo also referred to Mr. Pataki's defeat of Senator Mary Goodhue, who was the only Republican woman in the State Senate, in a 1992 primary. "They only had one female Republican, and the fellow who's running against me took care of her," he said.
Mr. Pataki responded calmly.
"I think it's just kind of sad that Mario Cuomo is talking about my record as Mayor of Peekskill when in fact people who know that record are very thankful for the impact that my policies had in that city," he told reporters. "I'm also very proud of my record in the Legislature and I think what this campaign is about is about the future and about the issues and how Mario Cuomo and I disagree. And we disagree fundamentally on the future of this state."
Mr. Pataki went on to accuse Mr. Cuomo of "record tax increases, record spending increases and record job losses," as well as a "failed criminal justice system."
Both Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Pataki have paid tribute to Mr. Perot's strength in New York by appearing regularly at United We Stand meetings. Last month, Mr. Cuomo spent more than three hours answering questions at a session in western New York.
The two candidates clearly believe it is vital to capture independent voters, particularly those who have demonstrated a willingness to channel their discontent into political action. But it is unclear whether those rebellious voters will form anything resembling a bloc this year. Mr. Perot's crowd today was highly amorphous, including supporters of Lenora Fulani, Lyndon LaRouche and the Right-to-Life Party's gubernatorial candidate, Robert Walsh, in addition to United We Stand regulars.
In their speeches today, both Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Pataki emphasized their pledges to cut taxes and open government, issues that were paramount to Mr. Perot in 1992.
The Governor focused on his campaign for a constitutional convention that would bypass the Legislature and change the state's political system. Mr. Cuomo said that such a convention could impose, among other changes, public financing of campaigns, campaign spending limits and stricter controls on lobbying. He said the convention also could vote on measures that he personally opposes, like casino gambling and the death penalty.
"I'm against a lot of things, but I'm for your right to vote on them," he said.
The State Constitution requires a referendum every 20 years on whether to hold a constitutional convention, which can devise proposals that are submitted directly to the voters. Nine conventions have been held, with mixed success, and the next vote must be held in 1997.
Mr. Pataki said that Mr. Cuomo's call for a constitutional convention only masked his inability to affect change.
"The Governor always has these ideas about how we can solve problems at some point after an election sometime in the future," he said. "We don't need a constitutional convention to change this state. We could have had a governor who pushed for initiative and referendum over the last 12 years when he's been governor. He doesn't support it and hasn't pushed for it. We could have had a governor over the last 12 years who fought for term limits but he hasn't because he doesn't support it."
As for the hecklers, the roughest treatment of Mr. Cuomo came from Michael Notti, 33, a payroll manager from Old Bethpage, who called Mr. Cuomo a "slob" and a "political prostitute," during a lengthy rant about the death penalty and violence in Crown Heights.
Mr. Cuomo tried to discuss those issues with Mr. Notti before giving up in frustration as Mr. Notti continued to scream. "You're so nice, Michael," Mr. Cuomo said. "You've got such style, such elegance. Do you have troubles at home, Michael?"
