HEADLINE: INDUSTRY LEADERS WARN AGAINST RISE IN INTEREST RATES

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
The nation's manufacturers, declaring that their businesses are prospering and their hiring is up, urged the Federal Reserve today not to raise interest rates again this year. They said higher rates would endanger their prosperity.
In taking this position shortly before a Federal Reserve meeting to consider another rate increase, the National Association of Manufacturers directly challenged a basic tenet of the central bank's policy. While most Fed officials insist that rising inflation poses the greatest danger to the economy and should be prevented, even at the cost of an economic slowdown, the manufacturers take the opposite view. They even prefer a little inflation, which gives them leeway to raise prices. 
 The manufacturers' association passed no formal resolution at a three-day meeting here, attended by 115 chief executives of large and small companies, from giants like Boeing and the Big Three auto makers to small machine shops in Midwestern towns. But in a poll taken at the meeting, the executives opposed higher rates, and many forcefully supported that view in interviews.
The poll is part of the association's emerging effort to prevent another rate increase that might slow the economy and dampen its members' sales. Summarizing the results of the poll at the final session today, Jerry Jasinowski, the association's president, said, "The overwhelming majority believe that the Fed should hold interest rates at current levels or delay any further action until late this year or next year."
Stanley C. Gault, chairman of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and a former chairman of the manufacturers' group, said: "We have to be particularly careful about what we do now. It is as hard or harder to reverse a slowdown in the economy as it is to reverse rising inflation."
The manufacturers rarely come out so publicly or bluntly against a rate increase. But this time, they said, higher interest rates would catch them just as their sales are expanding, mostly from the ripple effects of strong home construction and surging auto and truck sales. But even executives of companies removed from the auto and construction industries expressed concern about rates.
For example, Lawrence W. Clarkson, a senior vice president of the Boeing Company, said higher rates might discourage people from buying airline tickets on credit, just as air travel was rising and airlines might be ready to order more new planes. "Leisure travel is very interest-rate sensitive," he said.
In their poll, the manufacturers rejected a main argument for a rate increase intended to reduce consumer demand, and with it economic activity, by discouraging borrowing in a nation that runs on credit. The argument is that shortages of labor and of production capacity will force manufacturers to raise wages to obtain skilled workers and that the higher wages will force businesses to raise prices sharply.
"We have no strains on capacity, and there is certainly" no strong demand for wage increases, said Tracy O'Rourke, the newly elected chairman of the association. As for his own company, Varian Associates, which makes machinery for semiconductor manufacturing, among other products, he said, "Our orders for this machinery will be up 100 percent this year, but every order is a dogfight over prices."
Expectations on Wall Street of another interest rate increase -- either at a meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers on Tuesday, or at their next meeting, on Nov. 15 -- have played a role in the steady decline of stock prices in recent days, as well as the upward pressure on interest rates in the bond market. The manufacturers said that while the Federal Reserve's five rate increases since February had not been a problem, the next one could be. So they opposed any further action at either meeting.
"The issue is this: have we actually or psychologically passed the break point where people say they cannot afford things any more because interest rates are too high, or they get spooked," Mr. Gault said. "Higher rates can create uncertainty, and this can get translated into procrastination and delay in making purchases."
The manufacturers' association is a leader among Washington lobbyists. It played a big role, for example, in persuading Congress to block President Clinton's health insurance proposals. But while manufacturers account for nearly 30 percent of national economic activity, they have much less leverage with the Federal Reserve, an independent institution that is more insulated from political pressures than Congress.
Still, the manufacturers brought a powerful dissenting voice to a debate that has been dominated until now by bondholders and bankers -- a faction the Fed has traditionally sided with. In effect, this group lends out most of the nation's savings, and it is concerned that rising inflation will dilute the purchasing power of the money that is lent.
The manufacturers, by comparison, prefer growing sales and profits, which thrive on a strong economy and some inflation. The inflation gives them leeway for price increases, which a few manufacturers say they are just beginning to get three years after the recovery from the last recession began.
The differences show up in numbers. Bankers and bondholders say the annual inflation rate, now running at 2.9 percent, could spike up dangerously once it begins to rise. Similarly, bondholders argue that economic growth of more than 2.5 percent a year can be inflationary, while the manufacturers argue that 3 or 3.5 percent is the upper limit. In either case, they say, another rate increase could drive growth to less than 2.5 percent.
Actual growth in the 12 months that ended in June was 4 percent, and while the growth rate has probably slowed in the current third quarter, it is still rather healthy.
"My concern is that another rate increase could trigger a downturn prematurely," said Bernard G. Rethore, president of Phelps Dodge Industries, the manufacturing arm of a big mining company.

HEADLINE: Mexicans Sign New Accord On Economy

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 24

 BODY:
A group of Mexico's most powerful business and labor leaders today renewed a pact with the Government that will control prices and wages during the coming year. But the accord does not offer the kind of economic jump-start many people expected from the winner of last month's presidential election.
The agreement also does not change the exchange-rate policy for the peso. There was speculation the peso would be allowed to depreciate more quickly in order to make Mexican exports more competitive. 
 The new pact gives the first evidence that Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, who won the election, will side with stability over economic stimulus and follow the current President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, in fighting inflation even at the cost of workers' salaries. When the first pact was signed in 1987, inflation was 159.2 percent. Now it is under 7 percent.
The reaction of the more independent parts of unionized labor in Mexico was that workers had again been asked to bear the brunt of the stabilization program.
"It's an arrangement put together for the purpose of guaranteeing tranquillity during the process of political transformation," said Francisco Hernandez Juarez, president of the powerful telephone workers' union. "But from the point of view of salaries, we've insisted that the workers need much, much more."
But it has been the cooperation of Mexico's largest labor organization, the pro-Government Confederation of Mexican Workers, that has made the Government-business-labor pact succeed as the centerpiece of Mexico's anti-inflation policy.
Although Mr. Zedillo does not take office until Dec. 1, a senior Finance Ministry official said all the terms had to be approved by Mr. Zedillo's advisers.
The influence of Mr. Zedillo even extended to a change in the name of the agreement, which used to be the Pact for Stability, Competitiveness and Employment. The new agreement is the Pact for Well-Being, Stability and Growth, which most Mexicans would immediately associate with his campaign theme, "Well-being for your family."
The terms of the new pact tie several important indexes to a projected rate of inflation for 1995 of 4 percent. Thus prices for Government-controlled goods like gasoline, fuel and electricity will be allowed to increase by no more than 4 percent.
Increases for Mexico's low manufacturing salaries are also set at 4 percent. (The minimum wage is less than $5 a day.)
But since last year, when wages in Mexico became an issue in the debate over passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mexican officials have been pressed by the United States to raise salaries. In addition to the 4 percent increase, productivity bonuses can be added to union contracts.
The exchange rate policy will remain as it has been since 1992.

HEADLINE: On U.S. Visit, Yeltsin Looks For Investors

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 24

 BODY:
When Boris N. Yeltsin arrives in the United States this weekend, America will witness the return of a salesman. The Russian leader aims to do statesmanly things, of course. He will address the United Nations General Assembly. He will hold a summit meeting with President Clinton. But mostly, in business meetings in New York, Washington and Seattle, Mr. Yeltsin hopes to convince American executives that Russia is a blue-chip investment.
"His personal charm can do a lot," said Georgi A. Satarov, an aide to Mr. Yeltsin. "The American businessmen will tell him what are the necessary conditions for investment and our President will explain that such changes are already happening." 
 The Russian Government hopes that recent signs of greater economic and political stability, and particularly its success in reducing inflation to 5 percent a month, will stimulate trade and help overcome Americans' fears of doing business in Russia. That hope is shared by the United States Government, which reduced aid for Russia to $850 million this year from $2.5 billion in 1993. (Stability, however, is relative: on Thursday, the ruble dropped 5 percent against the dollar, its steepest dive in eight months, then bounced back 2 percent the next day.)
"We are encouraged by signs of stabilization and vigor in the Russian economy," said a high-ranking American official involved in preparations for the summit meeting. "We would like to use the summit to emphasize private-sector investment."
To sweeten the pot, Washington is reserving nearly $80 million of its 1994 Russian aid for programs like the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, which offers Government guarantees to American companies that invest abroad. The American official also said the Administration expected that nearly $1 billion in new American investment in Russia would be announced during the summit meeting.
Mr. Clinton will try to convince Mr. Yeltsin of the need to lower tariffs and to draft stronger commercial legislation to lure investment. And on Tuesday, to brighten the Russians' mood on the eve of the meeting, Mr. Clinton signed a declaration freeing Russia from the Jackson-Vanik amendment, a law passed 20 years ago to link the Soviet Union's trade privileges to its handling of emigration. Mr. Yeltsin considers the amendment obsolete and deeply humiliating, and has complained bitterly about it.
As if to underscore the friendship between former cold war enemies, Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Clinton are to address the General Assembly only a few hours apart on Monday.
The occasion provides Mr. Yeltsin with a spotlight in which to define Russia's role in a world free of superpower rivalry. But it also presents him with a daunting political slalom. "The President has to find the proper balance between articulating a pro-Western orientation and putting enough emphasis on the national interests of Russia," said Andrei V. Kortunov, a senior analyst at the U.S.A. and Canada Institute, who occasionally gives foreign policy advice to the Kremlin.
Mr. Yeltsin will probably also bewatched more closely than usual in Russia after his somewhat puzzling behavior last month in Germany during the final withdrawal of Russian troops. Russian television showed Mr. Yeltsin stumbling on the steps of the Berlin City Hall after a champagne lunch and grabbing the conductor's baton for an antic try at conducting the orchestra himself. Albert Plutnik, a columnist for the newspaper Izvestia, said Mr. Yeltsin's behavior prompted feelings of "acute discomfort, if not shame."
American businessmen in Russia say that the investment climate in Russia has improved over the last four months. "I've noticed a pretty significant upswing on fact-finding missions," said Peter A. Charow, the president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Moscow, whose members have already invested a total of about $1.5 billion in Russia. "I see a psychological shift over the past three months, due to the stability of the political situation now compared to last December."
Mr. Charow cited exorbitant tax rates and constantly changing regulations as some of the major roadblocks to greater American investment, issues that are on the summit meeting's agenda.
"We see great willingness in the upper reaches of the Russian Government to make these changes," he said. "But getting it implemented is a whole other issue."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: IN CALIFORNIA;
A Ballot Proposition Gives Voters the Opportunity to Influence National Immigration Policy

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24

 BODY:
As Election Day 1994 approaches, Californians are poised to vote on a ballot proposition that would take the far-reaching step of denying illegal immigrants most major government services, including schooling and non-emergency health care. Once again, the state's voters find themselves with the opportunity to influence the course the nation takes on a major issue.
Polls indicate that the rancorously debated measure, Proposition 187, put on the ballot by citizens groups, will win overwhelming approval from the nation's largest contingent of voters, sending to Washington a strong message of growing impatience with Federal immigration policy. 
 At the same time, passage of the measure would probably bolster the chances of Gov. Pete Wilson to win re-election in one of the most important state races in the country this year, a race whose outcome almost certainly will have an impact on the 1996 Presidential race.
Mr. Wilson supports passage of the proposition, fully embracing the argument that economically pressed California must take drastic action to stem a costly "invasion" of illegal aliens because the Federal Government either cannot or will not.
"It's the two-by-four we need to make them take notice in Washington," he said of the initiative. "We will finally force Washington to accept responsibility."
By contrast, his Democratic challenger, State Treasurer Kathleen Brown, opposes the measure on the ground that it would make a bad problem worse and eventually be declared unconstitutional.
"What we really need," she said, "is for the Federal Government to properly police our border and enforce laws already on the books."
Like many of the proposition's opponents, Ms. Brown is especially concerned about a section of the measure that would require parents of all schoolchildren, including American citizens, to prove legal residence. She calls that approach "invasive" and an affront to basic human rights.
No one disputes the far-reaching implications of the debate over Proposition 187.
"The fight over 187 is one with a lot of major legal, social and political implications, whichever side you take," said Ira Mehlman of the Federation for American Immigration Reform.
The federation, which favors passage, is one of the many national lobbying groups that have jumped into the fray alongside state lobbying organizations. Some groups are broadly concerned about immigration policy. Others are driven more specifically by economic, educational, health, police and civil rights concerns.
One main opponent of the ballot measure is a group called Taxpayers Against 187.
"Sure there's an immigration problem," said Joel Maliniak, the organization's spokesman. "But the answer is to strictly patrol the border and strictly enforce laws about hiring illegals, not throw kids out of school and their parents out of health clinics. If the Federal Government concludes 187 impinges on people's civil rights, the proposition will backfire because Washington will then cut off the $15 billion in health and school aid that it sends to the state each year."
Even the Mexican Government has become involved in the debate, saying on Wednesday in a sharply worded statement that it did not want to meddle in United States politics but nevertheless felt that discussions surrounding the proposition too often had "racist and xenophobic" overtones and unfairly blamed Mexican citizens for American problems.
The statement, issued by the Ministry of Foreign Relations, warned that the debate and its outcome could adversely affect "commercial and economic relations between our country and the state of California in this post-North American Free Trade Agreement phase."
Reliable figures on illegal immigration and its cost to Federal and state agencies are difficult to come by because of the inherently shadowy nature of the problem. But there is no real dispute that the hardest hit border state is California.
Supporters of Proposition 187 estimate that, at a minimum, there are already 1.7 million undocumented aliens living in the state, with another 125,000 slipping in annually because of the Federal Government's inadequate border patrolling.
They say California, in economic recession and already struggling to balance its budget, will be forced to spend at least $2.4 billion this year on government services for undocumented aliens, and they contend that the Federal Government should not only strengthen border patrols but should also reimburse the state for its spending on services.
Governor Wilson agrees, calling Federal immigration policy a "dismal failure." And he has repeatedly demanded, thus far without success, that President Clinton declare an "immigration emergency." He also has filed lawsuits aimed at forcing Washington to act more aggressively on the problem.
Many of his campaign advertisements stress the immigration issue, ending with scenes of aliens slipping across the border and an announcer intoning, "They keep coming."
Ms. Brown said that the Wilson advertisements were "cheap, inflammatory political scapegoating."
The United States Attorney General, Janet Reno, has come up with several plans to boost border surveillance but argues there is no immigration emergency. She has said that Mr. Wilson and the supporters of Proposition 187 are "caught up in politics." Still, last weekend she made a personal visit to the state to announce the latest increase in border patrols.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: IN TEXAS;
Rock-Star Appeal or Not, Governor Faces Tough Race in Lone Star State

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PALESTINE, Tex., Sept. 22

 BODY:
Gov. Ann W. Richards still has her rock-star appeal. She was mobbed after speaking to a conference of Methodist clergymen here in East Texas the other day, and one minister pushed his way through to plead for an autograph on his T-shirt, a Texas curio that depicts Ms. Richards in a white fringe-leather motorcycle suit, astride a Harley-Davidson emblazoned with the words "White Hot Mama."
That Ms. Richards retains all of her charm was abundantly evident a few hours later at a rally in Pittsburg, another little East Texas town, where she clutched 82-year-old D. H. Abernathy, the town's Mayor for the last 41 years. "I just love Mayor Abernathy," she said, stretching out "love" to five syllables or so and adding a wink. "You know, we've had this little thing." The crowd roared, the Mayor beamed. 
 But while the polls in Texas suggest that Ms. Richards is still widely popular near the end of her first term, they also suggest that she could lose the election on Nov. 8.
Two major polls released in recent weeks have indicated that Ms. Richards, a Democrat, is in a dead heat with George W. Bush, the son of the former President. Unlike voters elsewhere around the country, Texans are not grumbling about having to choose between the lesser of two evils -- at least not so far. Ms. Richards and Mr. Bush each enjoy a favorable rating of about 60 percent.
How could the 61-year-old Ms. Richards find herself so admired, in a state with a booming economy and a declining crime rate, and yet face the race of her life against a man who has never won elective office?
One reason is simply that the second-most-populous state has increasingly been voting Republican; last year voters here sent two G.O.P. senators to Washington for the first time since Reconstruction. Another is that Mr. Bush is benefiting from his father's popularity in Texas. A third is that Ms. Richards's friend and fellow Democrat, Bill Clinton, is definitely not in vogue here.
Ms. Richards has also had to wrestle throughout her tenure with a virtually unsolvable school-financing crisis that after tormenting state officials for 25 years has become a sort of a trap door of Texas politics, partly responsible for the fact that four of Ms. Richard's last five predecessors have been voted out of office. And while statistics indicate a drop in crime in the state during the last four years, the polls show that many people remain fearful.
Probably the most succinct analysis of the race is offered by Paul Burka, the longtime political editor of Texas Monthly magazine, who observes in the upcoming issue, "Bush is positioned better in every facet of the race except personality, and he has Barbara Bush waiting in the wings to campaign for her son."
But Mr. Burka also sees personality as giving the Governor a crucial edge, concluding, "The one area where Richards has the advantage is the one that counts the most."
As usual, Ms. Richards is playing the personality card for all it is worth. Widely regarded as one of the sharpest, quickest and most entertaining figures in American politics, she lives up to her billing.
Stopping at a Dairy Queen in Linden on her East Texas tour, Ms. Richards was greeted by an overall-clad man who drawled: "You're prettier than you are on the TV." Without missing a beat, the Governor shot back, "Oh, I bet you say that to all the girls."
Then Ms. Richards darted inside for her second chocolate-dip cone of the afternoon. The manager, Larry Bishop, broke into a huge grin as the Governor touched him on the arm and exclaimed with the gush of a fawning teen-ager, "Y'all have the best fish sandwiches and the best dip cones of anybody!"
Still, for all her charm, Ann Richards has become increasingly harsh in her attacks on Mr. Bush, the managing partner of the Texas Rangers baseball team whose only previous run for office, a 1978 bid for a West Texas Congressional seat, failed.
Ms. Richards frequently tells audiences that no one would take her opponent seriously if he were George Walker, not George Walker Bush.
Striding unannounced into another East Texas Dairy Queen, in Winnsboro, she virtually accosted James and Dorothy Holcomb, a retired couple, as they ate their hamburgers.
"Well, I have this boy," she told them, describing her 48-year-old opponent. "He's really a very nice man. Of course, if he didn't have his Daddy's name, he wouldn't amount to anything."
The theme has been repeated in a Richards radio advertisement that describes Mr. Bush as "that young Bush boy" and another that says "Daddy's friends" have helped bail out his businesses.
While such deconstructing of Mr. Bush could get her re-elected, some analysts suggest it could backfire.
"She's been condescending and demeaning, and that's a mistake," said Richard Murray, a political scientist at the University of Houston. Mr. Murray said that Ms. Richards's tone fit her last campaign, a bruising, nasty name-calling battle against an oilman, Clayton Williams, in 1990, but that it was out of line against Mr. Bush.
While Mr. Williams refused to shake Ms. Richards's hand and once threatened to "head her and hoof her and drag her through the dirt," Mr. Bush has been unfailingly respectful, even suggesting that he is among the legions of Texans who like the Governor personally.
On the other hand, Ms. Richards once described Mr. Bush as "a jerk," prompting a round of scathing newspaper editorials, one of which described Ms. Richards as "a supermegajerk" for calling Mr. Bush a jerk. The Bush campaign compiled the editorials for a recent fund-raising solicitation.
"They're fighting the last war," Mr. Murray said of the Richards campaign. "They ain't fighting Claytie anymore."
Whatever the voters wind up thinking of the candidates personally, the election is also playing out against a backdrop that in many ways favors Mr. Bush, who, paradoxically, could ride in on the same anti-incumbency wave that swept his father from the Presidency.
The dominant issues in the race are education and crime. Illegal immigration, a defining issue in states like California and Florida, has barely been a blip on the political radar screen this year in Texas, which has so clearly tied part of its future to free trade with Mexico.
On the face of things, crime should be Ms. Richards's issue. She has demonstrably toughened parole laws and is in the midst of building more prison cells than all 44 of her predecessors combined. Crime is down in virtually all major categories since she took office.
And yet polls suggest that crime remains the No. 1 concern of the voters, and Mr. Bush's television advertising pounds away at her for being soft on crime. Ms. Richards complains it is almost impossible to get her message of success out when television news broadcasts so often begin with murder reports.
Ms. Richards is challenged on another front. She may need some conservative support to win, but liberals in Texas -- and there are far more than a few -- often express disappointment with what they call the unrealized promise of her "New Texas" campaign theme four years ago. She dearly needs support from members of minority groups as well, since Mr. Bush holds a strong lead in the polls among white voters.
Mr. Bush may have spent most of his life in the state. But when he went on a dove hunt and accidentally -- and illegally -- bagged a protected Texas songbird known as the killdee, Ms. Richards's camp wasted no time in suggesting that the incident showed Mr. Bush, Connecticut-born and Yale-educated, to be a faux Texan.
While it was hardly the seminal campaign moment that Ms. Richards's supporters claimed, it clearly highlighted one of Mr. Bush's weaknesses.
And it also showed, once again, that Ms. Richards could seize on the smallest misstep with a vengeance. In fact, even weeks after the incident, she still somehow manages to draw howls of laughter from liberals and conservatives alike.
"You know," she deadpans to the audience, "guns don't kill killdee. People kill killdee."

ANALYSIS
Ms. Richards is personally popular, and since she took office, economic conditions have improved in Texas while crime has declined. Yet recent polls suggest the race is a dead heat, partly because Texas has been tending toward Republicans, partly because Mr. Bush himself has a popular family name and partly because Texans have voted all but one of their Governors out of office over the last two decades.

LATEST POLL RESULTS
A Mason-Dixon Texas Poll, conducted of 801 registered voters Sept. 16-18, showed 46 percent for Ms. Richards, 45 percent for Mr. Bush, and 9 percent undecided. Margin of error: 3.5 percentage points.

HEADLINE: MISSION IN HAITI: THE OBSTACLES;
Grim Shadow of Economic Reality

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 24

 BODY:
The Haiti that awaits the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide is a country whose political institutions and economy have been devastated in the three years since he was forced from power by a military coup.
If Father Aristide is restored to office under the protection of American troops, the initial wave of jubilation at his return is likely to dissipate once he and his supporters realize the extent of the problems they face. 
 "Beyond Aristide, there is the more basic question of the governability of the country," said Suzy Castor, co-director of the Research and Training Center for Economic and Social Development, a private academic research group here. "Our situation has been aggravated during these three years, and all the institutions in the country have been destroyed."
The sole exception may be the military itself, which has been crippled by what it calls the permissive entry of 10,000 American troops but has not been wiped out, as could have been the case in a full-scale invasion. Even if Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, Haiti's military leader, leaves the country after being forced to step down, a course of action he has ruled out, he is likely to be succeeded by officers with much the same background, philosophy and attitudes.
By destroying the guns and armored vehicles of the Haitian Army's only heavy-weapons unit, American troops have made it much more difficult for the military to stage another coup. But Father Aristide's supporters remain worried about the continuing ability of the military to make mischief.
Evans Paul, the Mayor of Port-au-Prince and an ally of Father Aristide who is regarded by many here as a strong candidate to succeed him, said from hiding this week that he will only be satisfied when he sees all gunmen disarmed, including the paramilitary "attaches" who often do the Government's dirtiest work.
Democracy, he added, will not be handed to the Haitian people; it will only be won through mobilization.
"People in this country are going to rest easy only when the military has been smashed to pieces," said one diplomat here whose Government supports Father Aristide. "But it does not seem that is what the Americans want to do."
The biggest immediate losers if the military is disbanded would be the economic elite that has traditionally controlled both state and army. Their dominance has been eroded somewhat as military officers have seized the opportunity to amass fortunes and reduce their dependence on the moneyed class.
But the arrival of American troops has further weakened and divided the handful of families accustomed to treating the state as their own property. "The Haitian elites are in a state of shock," Le Nouvelliste wrote in an editorial on Thursday. "Already one accuses the other for the historic responsibility for this new occupation."
That does not mean, though, that Father Aristide's own bases of support are powerful enough to guarantee an easy time in the 16 months remaining in his term. The military has devoted most of its energies over the last three years to eradicating the Lavalas political movement that he rode to power, and he has few alternatives within what remains of Haiti's formal political structure.
Some members of the Parliament who were elected as Aristide supporters have defected to the military; others, by their own admissions, have sold their votes to the highest bidder.
Father Aristide is also likely to have difficulties finding the people he wants to run Cabinet ministries, and state-owned companies. The estimated 3,000 Haitians who have been killed since the 1991 coup include many professionals who would have been expected to do those jobs; others have fled into exile.
Indeed, the only other institution truly national in scope that could serve as a counterweight to the military is the Roman Catholic Church. As Jean-Robert Vaval, acting director of the Ecumenical Center for Human Rights, puts it, "Any place you go in Haiti, you will always find a soldier and a priest."
But the church has never been of a single mind in its attitude toward Father Aristide, and that remains the case. The exiled President has the support of many priests at the parish level, and of lay people involved in community and social programs. But he is bitterly opposed by most bishops and the rest of the Catholic hierarchy.
"We have constantly been attacked by the military, by the bishops and by Rome," said the Rev. Jean-Yves Urfie, an Aristide supporter who edits Libete, a Catholic newspaper that speaks for the church's progressive wing. "But the popular church has survived," and Father Urfie indicated it will continue to be one of the bulwarks of support for Father Aristide.
Once Father Aristide resumes office, expectations for improvement in the quality of life will be high. He has encouraged those aspirations, promising to create thousands of jobs and invest heavily in social services, but he may find it hard to deliver everything the people want.
Even before the 1991 coup, Haiti was the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere, with the average income about $250 a year. By any standard other than Haiti's, Father Aristide's goals are modest: in his words, to raise the standard of living "from misery to poverty."
But the economy has disintegrated further since the coup. Most assembly plants, which employed as many as 100,000 people, have closed or moved elsewhere. Factories that made baseballs, for example, have shut their doors and shifted production to places like Costa Rica.
"I think that investors, whether from the outside or inside, are going to wait until the next election to see whether Aristide behaves himself in his last year in office," said Kesner Pharel, a Central Bank economist and radio commentator. "The best thing Aristide can do right away is to create public works jobs for the many people who are not skilled labor."
But when Father Aristide returns, his Government "will be flat broke," an American official here said, and "will need visible, demonstrable shows of political support from us" to get the economy running again.
And an aid official here said, "We found the money to run the economy into the ground over the last three years," referring to enforcement of economic sanctions imposed on Haiti. "The real test is coming up."
The United States, which has pledged at least $1 billion in aid over the next five years, met in Paris last month with other donor countries to discuss economic reconstruction. But American officials estimate it will be three to six months before aid begins flowing again substantially, though food and medicine should begin arriving much sooner.
More fundamental questions, like how to improve the distribution of income, must be addressed eventually. In 1991, the World Bank estimates, 1 percent of the population received half the country's income, and the income received by most of the population did not surpass $125 a year. For the Caribbean as a whole, average per-capita income is $1,950 a year.
That disparity is only one example of the "200 years of institutional failure," as one American official here puts it, that Father Aristide and his American patrons will have to contend with should the agreement struck with the Haitian military leaders be carried out as scheduled.
"But for me to stand up here and say we are wiser would be folly," the official said. "I've been around the bend too many times. I'm not going to make any predictions."

HEADLINE: Reich Urges Executives To Aid Labor

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Elaborating on his theory that America's middle class is being rapidly transformed into an "anxious class" squeezed between the wealthy and chronically poor, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich will urge business leaders in Dallas on Tuesday to develop ways to help workers increase their skills and add to their sense of security.
He calls for a broad commitment by private business to help train and educate workers and even raises a veiled threat of Federal intervention in the form of required contributions to such training if they do not do so. 
 His comments, prepared for a speech he will give before a conference of the National Alliance of Business but made public here today, describe the nation as moving rapidly ahead in a period of economic expansion, but at the expense of the workers propelling it. He illustrates that point by pointing to widening gaps in wages of educated and uneducated workers and to a tendency among many business leaders to focus their attention on competition overseas while ignoring the lives and welfare of workers at home.
"Ominous" forces in the way American labor issues are handled, he says, have physically divided the country, leaving an "overclass" in the safety of elite suburbs, an "underclass quarantined in surroundings that are unspeakably bleak, and often violent," and a new "anxious class" trapped in "the frenzy of effort it takes to preserve their standing," as more and more families try to patch together two and sometimes more paychecks to meet their basic needs.
He also points to widening income, health care and pension gaps spurring the "disintegration" of the middle class as it has historically been defined.
"Only 15 years ago," the Labor Secretary says, "a male college graduate earned 49 percent more than a man with only a high school degree. That's a sizable difference. But it's a divide small enough for both men to occupy terrain each would call middle class." Now, he says, a male worker with a college degree outearns a male high school graduate by a gap of 83 percent. Gaps in women's income are similar, but less drastic, he says in his speech.
Less-educated workers suffer not just at the bank. Their health care and retirement benefits also lag far behind those of better-educated workers, he says. Almost as many workers with college degrees have employer-based health care now as in 1976 (76 percent, as against 79 percent 18 years ago). But the percentage of high school graduates covered has dropped more sharply: about 60 percent of high school graduates are covered now, as opposed to 68 percent in 1976.
High school dropouts have suffered the most. In 1972, 52 percent of all dropouts had some health care provided by their employers. Last year, only 36 percent of them did. Retirement heightens that disparity. Two-thirds of college-educated workers have pensions. Three-fourths of all high school dropouts do not.
Mr. Reich has often spoken about the chasm that is dividing the nation's educated and uneducated workers in these times. But this speech, which is one of three he will give to elaborate on themes he first introduced on Labor Day, calls on private businesses to intervene aggressively.
"One means of committing American business to work force investment would be through a simple requirement that firms spend a small portion of their payrolls upgrading the skills of all employees," he proposes. Better approaches -- and ones certainly more palatable to the business community -- could include voluntary commitments to such expenditures, cost sharing for special training and the inclusion of employee education as a pillar of collective bargaining, he says.
The shrinking sense of security among American workers, he says, has occurred at a time when the engines of profit are turning smoothly. Noting that the nation not long ago was dismissed as "short-sighted, slow-footed and dim-witted," caught in a "cycle of inexorable decline," he points out that it now leads the list of the world's competitors.
But it is the human cost of that turnaround that he questions. "What do we mean by 'competitiveness' anyway? Rarely has a term of public discourse gone so directly from obscurity to meaninglessness without any intervening period of coherence."
His stark image of America in 1994 is filled with "conspiracy theorists," the alarmism of talk show radio hosts, distrust, dishonor and dismay. The solution, he posits, is for business to transform its vision of workers from expendable costs to ever more sophisticated assets.

HEADLINE: MISSION IN HAITI: THE WEALTHY;
Haiti's Elite: Resentful but Resigned

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 24

 BODY:
The art gallery has been dark for more than a year. Paintings of lush Haitian landscapes and dark voodoo ceremonies, priced as high as $20,000, are covered in dust. Mahogany sculptures, priced at $10,000, are stacked like firewood in the middle of the floor.
The gallery's owner, Johnny Saba, is one of Haiti's wealthy elite, the collection of old families and rich newcomers who backed the coup that toppled the populist President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, on Sept. 30, 1991. 
 As Haiti nears the third anniversary of that coup, his business, like others here, has all but died.
He cannot export the art because of the United Nations embargo, and his local customers, whose own businesses have closed down or dwindled to nothing, are not buying. When American troops landed in Haiti earlier this week to restore Father Aristide, Mr. Saba, like many others among the elite, was not so much angry as relieved.
The elite cheered when Father Aristide, whose talk of redistributing Haiti's wealth frightened them, was removed from power. But after three years of slow disintegration of the economy and the society, many rich Haitians will welcome him back if his return will breathe economic life back into the country.
"The people are tired of this situation," Mr. Saba said. "The people I talk to were happy to see the U.S. soldiers. We want them. Aristide is not the issue. Aristide is secondary to ending the embargo, and ending the situation we have lived under."
Mr. Saba and others of the elite did not go into the streets to welcome the soldiers the way poor Haitians did. But in Petionville, a wealthy suburb up the mountain from Port-au-Prince, people talked with enthusiasm about Haiti's future. "Things could not have gotten much worse," Mr. Saba said.
Not everyone is as welcoming as Mr. Saba. The richest families, many of them insulated by their huge wealth, could have ridden out an endless embargo, continuing to live in comfort behind high rock walls and armed guards.
Some older families, in particular, are insulted by the presence of the American soldiers, and they will never accept a Government headed by a man elected by the largely illiterate masses. Father Aristide, a dark-skinned man, was disregarded by many in the elite, most of whom are lighter-skinned people.
"It was a social thing," said Marie Henritte Roux, a dancer and artist. "It's a superiority complex. Some people would rather have 30,000 U.S. soldiers than one Aristide."
But others, like Jean-Max Vilmenay, from one of Haiti's oldest families, said the American occupation could save his country. The rich will just have to get used to them, even if that means Father Aristide. "The cost of the last three years," he said, "has been very high."
Although members of the elite, who financed and backed the coup, have not suffered the human rights abuses the military-backed de facto Government heaped on Father Aristide's supporters, they also suffered some of the same privations.
There is electricity only a few hours each day, and none at all in some neighborhoods. Gas stations are closed. Almost every major business and industry in Port-au-Prince has shut down, and the ones that remain have to pay bribes to highly placed officers in the military.
Little things, like ice cream shops, vanished. The beer selection in some bars dwindled to two, a toss between almost cold and room temperature. The airport closed down, and European vacations were canceled.
Many of the better restaurants closed, limited their menus or raised prices so high that even some of the wealthy refused to patronize them.
Miss Roux, whose family owns a chain of restaurants in Port-au-Prince, said business had fallen to below 10 percent and forced the layoffs of most of her employees. "Haiti was not functioning," she said. "It was dying. I can't even remember the last time my own family went out to dinner."
Many blame the United Nations embargo, but others said the Government slowly bled the weakened economy dry through its own corruption and greed. It became obvious that the military -- led by Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, who orchestrated the coup -- was no longer the tool of the rich, but their master.
One wealthy Haitian businessman, who spoke on condition that his name not be used, said it would only have been a matter of time before the military started to demand bribes beyond those already paid to keep businesses open.
Some of the elite said they had no idea what they had traded for in September 1991 when they financed the coup that overthrew Father Aristide. They only started to worry, beginning to wonder if they had made a tragic mistake.
Mr. Saba's family shut down factories and laid off 400 people, and his gallery became little more than a warehouse. All of Haiti seemed to be waiting for something, anything, to end the stalemate.
When American soldiers entered Haiti without bloodshed on Monday, it was perhaps the best possible solution to an ugly situation, some members of the elite said.
"At first we were very concerned, because we thought there would be bombs," Miss Roux said.
Many of the elite find the presence of American soldiers and even Father Aristide's return more acceptable now that the United States has obliged the exiled President to grant amnesty to those who took part in the coup.
Although most in the old families took part only in the shadows, they still fear reprisals. "The people have been called on to forgive," Mr. Vilmenay said. "And that forgiveness must come from both sides."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Gradual Loss of Support Is Cuomo's Silent Burden

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

 BODY:
Mario M. Cuomo has always liked being the underdog, whether he lost (the Democratic primary for mayor to Edward I. Koch in 1977) or won (the primary for governor over Mr. Koch in 1982). But there is a difference between being the underdog and being in the doghouse, which is where politicians agree Mr. Cuomo finds himself after 12 years in office.
New Yorkers can pick almost any index they like about their Governor this year, and the numbers will show how much they don't like him. Take his job-approval ratings (mid-30's), standing in the horse race (low 40's), even his modest majority against splintered opposition four years ago (54 percent). All bespeak a level of vulnerability that incumbents do not often overcome. 
 Add to that the magnitude of what Mr. Cuomo is asking, what only one Governor in American history has done before: win a fourth consecutive four-year term. (The first, Nelson A. Rockefeller, resigned at the end of his 15th year). Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, a Republican, is competing for the same distinction this fall. Only three other 20th century governors have managed even 14 consecutive years in office through a mixture of two- and four-year terms.
All that helps explain why a poll 10 days ago that showed Mr. Cuomo's Republican opponent, George E. Pataki, with a modest though statistically significant lead for the first time in the race -- 52 percent to 42 percent -- may be the least of the Governor's worries, the latest symptom of a more troubling, long-term trend of lost support. Even the good news -- Mr. Cuomo's continued high support among young people and minorities -- can be seen as bad, because those voters turn out on Election Day less reliably.
"He's had a negative rating for the last four years, in terms of favorable versus unfavorable," said Maureen Connelly, a political consultant who has worked for New York candidates of both parties over two decades. "He was vulnerable then, and he has been for a long time."
Polls are only snapshots, campaigns are volatile and candidates have overcome longer odds. But in recent New York State history, perhaps only one other 12-year incumbent with comparable negative ratings -- Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Mr. Pataki's patron -- managed to win re-election. He did so by utterly dominating the campaign and the terms of debate with his Democratic opponent, Attorney General Robert Abrams, something Mr. Cuomo has so far failed to do against Mr. Pataki.
The Governor's strategist, David Garth, has a fondness for underdogs and has made something of a specialty over the years of working for wounded incumbents. But Mr. Cuomo's posture as scrappy underdog now seems less a strategic pose than a pleading reality. He has met his enemy and it is him.
Campaign strategists say the negative readings on Mr. Cuomo are greater than the sum of their parts. If he were only behind in the polls, they say, or only in office a long time, or only lacked, by his own admission, a single overriding achievement for which he is known, beyond his eloquence, it would be bad enough. Instead, he faces all those problems.
He also faces a national mood of anti-incumbent sentiment so sour and pervasive that the old yardsticks of electoral viability have had to be lowered.
"It used to be that in the mid-80's, up until '88, if you had a re-elect score hovering somewhere in the low 50's, you were very, very worried," said Carter Eskew, a Democratic consultant in Washington, referring to a poll's reading on whether voters think a candidate deserves another term. "Now, if you have a re-elect score in the low 50's you're ecstatic, and if you're in the high 30's you're lucky."
It was by this measure, said Mr. Eskew, who worked last year for Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, that the Florio camp always knew it was highly vulnerable, even when public polls showed him with a lead over Christine Todd Whitman. The campaign's own polls never showed Mr. Florio surpassing 50 percent, even after poll takers, following standard technique for campaigns, led those being questioned through a series of inquiries intended to simulate the back-and-forth of Ms. Whitman's attacks and Mr. Florio's counterpunches.
Statewide polling over several terms in office has been relatively infrequent in New York so it has been hard to establish consistent trends in public opinion over the course of an incumbency as long as Mr. Cuomo's. But a Daily News poll early in June showed his re-election rating hovering around 30 percent.
Since the Governor's negative ratings seem so firmly etched, his challenge is twofold: to inspire his remaining core supporters, reminding them that he is the best defender of their interests on issues from abortion rights to gun control (polls show his supporters remain more intensely for their candidate than Mr. Pataki's for theirs), and also to chip away at the notion of Mr. Pataki as a plausible alternative.
Mr. Cuomo has pursued the first strategy on the stump, the second in his television commercials, while also suggesting a third: that he has unfinished business, and largely unspecified future plans for tax cuts and other desirable things.
"For most of this year, the only known quantity is Mario Cuomo, and it's been Cuomo against Cuomo," Mr. Garth said dryly. "In the abstract, there can be connotations that can be interpreted negatively. As the campaign proceeds, and we see who's waiting in the wings, and as the view gets closer, there may be some difference of opinion."
Mr. Pataki, a one-term State Senator and former Assemblyman, has never run a statewide campaign. He has largely avoided specific proposals, and could easily stumble or crumble under pressure of a debate or barrage of attacks. Already, his running mate for comptroller, Herbert London, has criticized him for lacking clear proposals on the economy, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has threatened to withhold an endorsement if Mr. Pataki does not offer more specific proposals on helping New York City.
But time is short -- only about six weeks remain to the election. Paradoxically, one of the Governor's strongest assets could be a growing public realization just how vulnerable many New York politicians from Albany to Capitol Hill believe him to be, to inspire the largest possible turnout among supporters so used to his incumbency that they may have failed to imagine he could lose.
"Energizing the base becomes absolutely critical," Mr. Eskew said. "The cliche in this business is that an Election Day get-out-the-vote operation is only worth two or three points. Well, guess what? That's what this race is going to be decided by."
All politics, politicians know, is local, and most elections turn on individual circumstances, foibles and fate. But no statistic may better sum up the odds against Mr. Cuomo than the rarity his victory would produce.
Besides Mr. Rockefeller, the only other Governor between Canada and the Caribbean to have won four consecutive four-year terms was Luis Munoz Marin of Puerto Rico, who served from 1949 to 1965, according to Samuel R. Solomon, a retired politics professor at Eastern Michigan University, who has studied the subject since he wrote his senior thesis at Syracuse University in 1930, and who recently published a study for the National Governors' Association.
If Mr. Cuomo won and served the full term, he would be the longest steadily serving Governor in the state since its first, George Clinton of Ulster County (from 1777 to 1795, and again from 1801 t0 1804). "Nobody even approaches that," Mr. Solomon said.
And it is unlikely that anyone ever will. In another sign of the way the wind is blowing, more than half of all states now limit governors to two consecutive four-year terms, or less.

HEADLINE: A Tide of Pollution Threatens China's Prosperity

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BENGBU, China, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Ru Fuyang, who has been fishing carp out of the Huai River most of his 60 years, says he has not caught a fish since mid-July when the waters here turned black and putrid for nearly a week.
At the time, a deadly mix of ammonia and nitrogen compounds, potassium permanganate and highly toxic phenols swept down the river from scores of factories that had flushed their waste tanks and ponds. When it was over in mid-August, more than 26 million pounds of fish had been killed and dozens of fish farms wiped out while some factories were forced to shut down for a week or more. Economic losses were estimated at $75 million. 
 The pollution spill was one of thousands of similar incidents that occur annually in China and demonstrate, Chinese and Western scientists say, that the country is in the midst of a national environmental crisis whose cumulative effect is an immeasurable but unmistakable threat to economic growth in coming decades.
"Though lacking an immediate, galvanizing crisis, China presents ecological problems so severe that they constitute a collective crisis with global consequences and powerful implications for America," warned a report prepared for the National Committee on United States-China Relations last year.
The Communist Party leadership has mounted an energetic campaign to combat pollution, but financing for environmental protection has lagged far behind investment to expand industry.
"Some enterprises pay fines in exchange for government consent to their spoiling of the environment," Qu Geping said in a report to the National People's Congress this spring. As chairman of the environmental protection committee of Parliament, Mr. Qu estimated that environmental losses total $12 billion annually.
International aid and lending agencies like the World Bank, the United Nations Development Fund and the Asian Development Bank have financed pollution control efforts, but these are generally limited to local projects.
"People caught trafficking 50 grams or even 25 grams of heroin have been jailed -- why can't we punish people who have polluted a river and affected more people?" Xie Zhenhua, head of the National Environmental Protection Agency, asked in a recent speech.
The answer appears to be that factory owners or managers tend to be senior members of the Communist Party establishment where they live, or they have connections that make them immune from shutdown or heavy fines.
Vice Prime Minister Zhu Rongji has told party cadres that central Government intervention to stanch industrial pollution "is a job that is going to require offending people." But the central authorities have so far not been able to devise a politically acceptable way to shut down hundreds of factories that dump their toxic waste into rivers or pump them into the atmosphere.
As a result, the degradation of China's natural resources is continuing:
*Half of the rain in Guangdong Province is now acidic, a problem that has become endemic in southern China.
*China's Agriculture Ministry revealed this year that more than 100,000 people were poisoned by pesticides and fertilizers used in agriculture during 1992 and 1993. More than 14,000 of them died.
*China's National Environmental Agency said in June that heavy atmospheric pollution is increasing the number of deaths from lung cancer, which climbed 18.5 percent in the major cities from 1988 to 1993. And mercury and lead poisoning is on the rise among children.
Last year, Chinese factories discharged 35.5 billion tons of sewage and industrial wastes into the country's rivers, streams and coastal seas. That volume of waste is three-fifths the annual flow of the Yellow River. The volume can only grow as China's industrial output races forward at nearly 20 percent annual growth, twice the level of overall economic expansion here.
"This rapid growth has had a devastating effect on the environment," the United States Embassy said in a recent report. "Solid wastes piled outside of cities have leaked toxins into the ground water and the water in many rivers does not meet the standards for bathing much less drinking."
The environmental degradation of the Huai River valley, home to 150 million Chinese, is deceiving. The four-hour drive from Hefei to Bengbu traverses a broad and fertile agricultural landscape where hundreds of thousands of farmers were visible harvesting the golden fields of rice. Every village thrashing ground was a tableau of sinewy peasants tossing bundles of rice stalks into the breeze to separate the grains from the chaff.
This summer's spill came after 40 days of drought, which may have added to the concentration of pollutants when the rains returned and upstream sluice gates began to open.
"Every year since the 1970's we have had pollution disasters," Mr. Ru said, "but this summer was the worst."
As the black current began moving downstream on July 15, hundreds of villagers who took their water from the river became ill with vomiting and diarrhea.
"The water turned black like soy sauce and there was an awful smell," said Cai Shaojia, 60, a bean farmer who lives near here. "You should have seen the size of the fish that were dying," he said, "fish that had lived so many years."
Mr. Ru added: "There were more than 10,000 fish floating here during the period of the pollution. People were out in boats lifting them in."
On July 16, the large waterworks at Lizuizi was overwhelmed by the sudden inundation of waste water that tested "several dozen" times beyond minimum safety levels.
The contamination affected 250,000 people in Anhui and Jiangsu provinces and several thousand peasants as well as city dwellers were treated for dysentery, diarrhea and vomiting. Anhui Province radio stations broadcast warnings to stay away from the river and to cease using Huai River water for drinking, cooking or irrigation.
On July 20, the volume of the black tide has risen so high behind the Benbu Dam that the local authorities suddenly and without warning to downstream cities or fish farms opened the sluice gates and released 200 million cubic meters of the heavily polluted water in a plume that stretched 100 miles by Aug. 5.
Just downstream of the dam, the Liu family lives on a 60-foot river barge from which they tend a patchwork of nets staked out in the current. In the early morning of July 20, Liu Mengcheng, 24, was about to step into a small boat to tend the nets when he heard the roar of the sluice gates opening in the dam.
"The water came like a giant wave," Mr. Liu said. "The current was so fast that we could not use the small boats."
When the waters settled, Mr. Liu said it was many days before the family could use even boiled water from the river.
And the fishing business all but died. Before the flood, the Liu family nets could harvest at least 20 pounds of fish per day, but now, two months later, the family is subsisting on a meager catch of a pound or more of stunted river fish.
Senior Chinese officials from the State Council under Prime Minister Li Peng sent investigators to the river basin in July, and Mr. Li later reiterated the Government's intention to force 190 of the 1,000 factories along the river to close or relocate by 1997.
Today, officials in Anhui Province said they had ordered 63 factories described as "the main polluting sources" on the river to shut down within one year, but no details were offered on how this would be accomplished.

Since then, Ru Fuyang, fishing above the Bengbu Dam, says he has not caught a single fish in the river. (Patrick E. Tyler/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Giuliani's Burden

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Just three months ago, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone were drinking a champagne toast to an austere budget agreement that wrenched down the size of the municipal government and curtailed the growth of city spending for the first time in 16 years.
But now, all too soon, they have received a sobering reminder of how grim the city's fiscal problems are. On Friday, mayoral aides told City Council leaders that the same budget now looks like it could be $1 billion out of balance. 
 That Mr. Giuliani faces a fiscal problem of such magnitude so soon after the $31.6 billion budget took effect in July is partly because of the scale of the problem he inherited. But his fiscal plan is also unraveling because state and Federal aid he had hoped for has not come through, because managerial problems have arisen as major agencies try to do more with fewer workers, and because economic recovery has been threatened by a slump on Wall Street.
Mr. Giuliani, New York's first Republican mayor in a generation, came into office pledging to end the city's tradition of expansive government. "New York City government is too large," he said in February. "It has grown beyond our ability to afford it."
But in preparing his first budget, he made a decision on how fast he could cut without fraying the political and social fabric of the city. And he decided that the most he could accomplish in his first budget was $1.1 billion in spending reductions, including a severance buyout of thousands of city workers.
"Agencies can manage only a certain amount of reduction in any given time period and be able to make readjustments," Mr. Giuliani said in an interview this week. "We could probably have managed more than we did but we also had to get a majority or more vote of the City Council. Otherwise, the city would have had no budget and you would have had chaos."
A result of that decision, however, was that the city had to find other ways to erase the remaining deficit, short of raising taxes, a move both Mr. Giuliani and the City Council leaders opposed. And so the budget counted on savings and sources of revenue that have not materialized, some of them reasonable assumptions and some of them less so.
The plan assumed that the city would receive $150 million in fiscal relief from the health care legislation under consideration in Washington. It counted on the State Legislature approving two measures that would have brought the city $70 million in revenue or relief from claims and judgments from lawsuits. It expected that the city would receive $75 million for renegotiating the amount of money it receives from the Port Authority for LaGuardia and Kennedy airports, and $65 million for selling the United Nations Plaza Hotel. And while overtime costs ran at $486 million last year, the budget projected overtime spending at $250 million.
Such assumptions led the state Financial Control Board to warn in July that while Mr. Giuliani had taken major strides in putting city finances in order, his budget still contained $1 billion in risky assumptions. "This much risk this early in the fiscal year is unprecedented and very worrisome," the board reported.
Budgeting is part science and part luck, and some of those risks would have become irrelevant if the economy had rebounded strongly, bringing in more tax revenues than projected. Instead, the economy has failed to perform even to the levels expected, and Wall Street has fallen into a slump. "There was a hope that things would break in the city's favor," said Thomas McMahon, the director of the City Council's finance staff. "Everything that has happened has broken the wrong way."
Mr. Giuliani has responded fast to the grim news instead of waiting until later in the year when it would become harder to make enough savings. He has cast the new gap "as an opportunity to accomplish what the city has to accomplish anyway," such as cutting the municipal work force still further and looking for ways to consolidate agency functions and shed nonessential services.
But as his aides consider reductions in financing for schools, ways to cut the costs of welfare for single adults, increasing the numbers of prisoners held in the city's jail dormitories to avoid opening new facilities, and vast new staffing cuts in the social service agencies, other officials were quietly starting to ask how long the city can keep making across-the-board reductions without resorting to raising revenues or taking more fundamental steps to solve its problems.
Over the years, academics and analysts have said that unless there is an economic boom, the city's chronic problems will only be solved by sweeping changes, such as the state's assumption of the total cost of Medicaid, a change in the city's tax structure so that the city relies more on the property tax and less on more volatile income and business taxes, which are highly sensitive to economic downturn, or fundamental and controversial decisions to scale back its services.
A panel that studied the budget deficit for former Mayor David N. Dinkins, for example, suggested such moves as eliminating city subsidies for day care and private bus routes and charging fees for residential garbage collection.
Mr. Giuliani is to unveil his new budget proposals at the beginning of October. Although the cutbacks will be submitted to the Democratic-run City Council, modifications of the budget can go into effect automatically if the Council doesn't vote within 30 days, which gives Council leaders the option of letting the Mayor carry out his plan alone if it looks like a majority of members would rebel against further austerity.
Some Council members said they were dismayed that they were facing deeper cuts in the government so soon. "What I wonder is whether we can run government this way," said Councilman Stephen DiBrienza, the Brooklyn Democrat who heads the general welfare committee. "We need to spend some more time on what the service impacts are and if it's a matter of raising revenue in some way."
And even Mr. Giuliani gave one indication that he knew he faced a precarious balancing act when he warned Friday that he wanted to know where George E. Pataki, the Republican candidate for governor, stands on aid to New York City, and how he would carry out his tax-cut proposals.
"There are ways to reduce taxes that would help the city and ways to reduce taxes that would be catastrophic for the city," Mr. Giuliani said during his weekly radio show. "If you reduce taxes but continue to keep mandates in effect that required the city to spend money that the state doesn't fund, then the city would have to raise taxes."

HEADLINE: Welfare for Middle-Class Elderly?;
In Final Years, Many Transfer Assets to Qualify for Medicaid

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
On a sunny floor in a New Jersey nursing home, two elderly women share a room, news about their grandchildren and a plight ever more common among their aging and ailing peers: both are poor, and their bills are paid by Medicaid.
But while one depleted her life savings in the first two months she spent at the nursing home, the other, a widowed homemaker debilitated by Parkinson's disease, intentionally reduced herself to poverty to qualify for Medicaid. Several years ago, she paid a lawyer to transfer $50,000 worth of stocks, bonds and cash to her sons and grandchildren. 
 For the last several years, thousands of middle-income elderly people, terrified that long-term health care costs could wipe out their savings, have transferred their assets to relatives to qualify for Medicaid.
The practice has created a swelling corps of lawyers who help people to pauperize themselves legally and has prompted an intense ethical debate over whether people with money should benefit from a medical program intended for the poor.
"It's a growing subterranean economy done with professional help," said Mildred Shapiro, associate commissioner of Health and Long Term Care in New York State's Department of Social Services.
Although the money is no longer in their names, the older people depend on a tacit agreement that those who control the assets will use some of the money to care for them. More importantly to many older people, such planning allows them to leave money to their heirs that would otherwise be depleted for health care.
But critics say that those who qualify for Medicaid through such financial preparations are getting middle-class welfare. They say that soaring Medicaid costs, which are paid through a combination of Federal, state and, in some cases, local dollars, are straining government budgets and that recipients should be limited to the truly needy.
"I don't believe the Medicaid system can sustain itself and serve the people it was intended to if it's being used this way by upper- and middle-income people," said Carl S. Young, president of the New York Association of Homes and Services for the Aged in Albany. "It's perfectly legal, and it's happening in the absence of any coherent public policy on how we're going to pay for long-term care."
The issue of such transfers has become so pervasive that both Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, and his Republican challenger, George E. Pataki, have had to answer questions about arrangements they made for their parents' long-term care.
In response to the criticism, Congress tightened some Medicaid rules last year to make it harder for wealthy and middle-income elderly people to qualify.
Supporters stress that the methods are legal and necessary, and not unlike tax planning that other lawyers perform. They say that while Medicare covers acute illnesses like heart attacks and cancer, it does not cover prolonged stays in nursing homes and largely neglects care for chronic, degenerative diseases like Alzheimer's or Parkinson's, forcing people to seek Medicaid's security.
"The real problem is that no one is forming a sound, workable policy for long-term health care at a time when demand for it is growing so quickly, so Medicaid becomes the answer," said Jane Gould, director of New York State's Office for the Aging.
Most Medicaid estate planning, as the practice is called, is being done with the help of a new cadre of lawyers who specialize in issues affecting the elderly. The Academy of Elder Law Attorneys, a professional society in Tucson, lists 4,000 members nationwide; 10 years ago, the group did not exist.
In the last few years, most state bar associations have started sections or committees on elder law, and law schools are beginning to offer courses on the subject.
"Our numbers are growing because health care costs are growing, the aging population is growing and nursing home costs are growing," said Peter J. Strauss, an elder law specialist with the New York firm Epstein Becker & Green. "People are afraid of becoming destitute."
Nationally, the cost of a nursing home, for example, is about $36,000 a year, and experts say that most people enter one after they have already had severe medical problems that have eaten away at their savings.
Private long-term care insurance is available, but its use remains limited, experts say. Although such insurance costs only a few hundred dollars a year for healthy people who sign up before they turn 60, it is unavailable to those who are already infirm, and the policies are often only good for a limited period.
The woman in the New Jersey nursing home who spent her savings paying for her own care, said it pained her to have worked her entire life as a seamstress, to have carefully set aside money for her grandchild only to lose it to poor health.
"I wanted to give my granddaughter a leg up," said the woman, who is 84 and partly paralyzed by a stroke. "Not to be able to leave her anything hurts." Like several other elderly people interviewed, she preferred to speak of her finances anonymously.
To be sure, many older people choose not to transfer their assets. Some feel degraded by accepting public assistance intended for the poor. Others are reluctant to cede control of their finances and worry that if relationships sour, their money will be jeopardized.
"Even those who think their money is safe find sometimes that it was used to pay for college or because some lazy son decided not to work for two years and to live off of it," said Rona Bartelstone, a geriatric care manager in Florida. "And the risk is not just losing the money, but losing the relationship when the older person realizes they've been swindled by someone they trusted."
But fear of poverty, experts say, is motivating a growing number of middle-income elderly people to shed their assets and assure their Medicaid eligibility.
"They're scared of being caught in a crunch," said Ruth Sabatini, a care planner with Loretto Senior Choices, a nonprofit social service organization in Syracuse. "They all want to know, 'How am I going to be cared for?' It's not necessarily verbalized, but it's what most of our conversations consist of."
To curb the growth of Medicaid estate planning, Congress approved legislation last year to limit the transfers.
For example, the Government can now check on any asset transfers made within 36 months of a person's application for Medicaid and penalize an applicant for resources transferred within that period. They may not, however, confiscate the transferred assets. The so-called look-back period used to be 30 months.
States are also required to recoup expenses from the estates of Medicaid recipients after they die. Since Medicaid rules allow people to keep their homes, personal property, a car and limited cash, there are often assets that can be sold to pay back the Government, although officials said enforcement of this was spotty.
Still, the Government's ability to take and sell these assets provides yet another impetus for older people to transfer them to their relatives.
The laws governing qualification for Medicaid are federally mandated, but they give states leeway in setting their own standards. New York, for example, has the most generous allowances for holding on to assets. Single people can keep $3,200, as well as property and limited money for funeral expenses.
In addition, the Government allows husbands and wives of Medicaid beneficiaries to keep money and other liquid assets without jeopardizing their eligibility. The amount varies by state, with New York, allowing about $73,000 per spouse. The intent is to keep spouses from becoming destitute in caring for their partners and to discourage people from hiding their wealth.
"But, there are still ways that you can get around the rules," said Sally Richardson, the director of the Medicaid Bureau in the Health Care Financing Administration, "and people are taking advantage of them."
Much of the growth of Medicaid estate planning, officials said, is because of more aggressive marketing and advertising by elder law specialists. Lawyers across the country regularly offer free seminars to urge older people to plan their financial futures and Medicaid eligibility.
Nursing home administrators say that lawyers increasingly prepare patients' applications to the homes and take care of filing the necessary forms with local Medicaid offices.
Many administrators have criticized the practice for creating a growing clientele of Medicaid patients in nursing homes. They say that since Medicaid reimbursement does not cover their costs, they depend on private-paying customers. The more Medicaid patients they have, the administrators say, the higher costs are for other patients.
"It's especially galling when Mother's Day rolls around and the kids come to visit mom who is on Medicaid in their chauffeur-driven limousines and B.M.W.'s," said the head of one Manhattan nursing home. Like most of his colleagues, he spoke anonymously because, he said, people tend to think that nursing homes gouge their clients.
Although there is some public perception that wealthy people are manipulating the system, government officials, lawyers and nursing home administrators say most people are trying to shelter modest amounts of money, from as little as a few thousand dollars to as much as a few hundred thousand dollars, with most around $50,000.
"You know who tends to come to me?" said Dean Bress, an elder law specialist in White Plains. "A middle-income person who sees a neighbor facing staggering costs because her husband is in a nursing home. Or one of the couple gets sick with the wrong disease and the other panics. Why should someone with a heart condition be covered and treated better than someone with Alzheimer's? They're afraid of getting stuck."
A retired teacher from Queens said she was embarrassed, but relieved, that she and her husband, who has Alzheimer's disease, had transferred almost all their liquid assets, about $60,000, to their two sons over the last decade, anticipating that her husband would soon need nursing home care they would be hard pressed to afford.
"I felt devious doing it, even though it was all technically legal," the woman said. "You think of yourself as comfortable, middle-class. You can afford a trip to Atlantic City when you want. A nice dinner in the city sometimes. Welfare, Medicaid, food stamps. That's for other people. For poor people. But then you look and realize, without this money, I am poor and this money will be devoured in a flash. I don't feel like I had a choice."
