HEADLINE: Company to Halt Improper Clinic Referrals

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
After a two-year grand jury investigation, the Government said today that a major health care company had agreed to pay $500,000 and halt "improper practices" involving doctors who send Medicare patients to clinics in which the doctors have invested.
Under a settlement to be announced on Monday, the company, T2 Medical of Alpharetta, Ga., near Atlanta, says it will change the way it does business to guarantee that doctors are not paid for referring Medicare or Medicaid patients to such clinics. 
 The action is the latest effort by Federal authorities to curb conflicts of interest and control health costs by prohibiting physicians from referring patients to medical enterprises in which the doctors have financial interests.
T2 Medical provides home infusion therapy, supplying medication and nutrition, either intravenously or through feeding tubes, to patients in their homes. The patients have cancer, AIDS or other serious illnesses.
June Gibbs Brown, the inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services, who supervised the investigation, said, "T2 paid physicians remuneration in order to induce the physicians to refer patients to T2 infusion centers."
The company, which was recently merged into a new corporation, Coram Healthcare, did not admit any wrongdoing. But Ms. Brown and the Justice Department said the company's business arrangements violated a Federal law that prohibits payment of kickbacks under Medicare and Medicaid. They asserted that some claims submitted to the Government by T2 were false and fraudulent because of the kickbacks. The Government did not specify the amount of money involved.
Reached today at his home in Georgia, Thomas E. Haire, who was a founder of T2 Medical in 1984 and served as chairman until he retired this summer, said of the investigation: "I'm glad it's over. It's been a hassle for us to deal with. We never broke any laws."
In a letter being sent to doctor-investors, the company says it will inform patients at centers owned by T2 Medical that "the doctors treating them may hold a financial interest in T2, and that they are free to seek care elsewhere."
Moreover, the letter says that the company will, "within the next six months, cease to be in the business of managing doctor-owned home infusion centers." The letter also says the company will pay $500,000 to the Federal Government. Federal officials said that the money, received this week, reimburses the Government for unnecessary payments by Medicare and for the costs of the investigation.
T2 (the name is pronounced "tee squared") was once a darling of Wall Street, but its stock plummeted from a high of $67 a share in early 1992 to about $8 this year as the company was hurt by internal turmoil, stiff competition and other problems. Congress, state legislators, even the American Medical Association have suggested that it is unethical for doctors to send patients to businesses in which the doctors have financial interests.
Nonetheless, T2 Medical was built on just such arrangements. Typically, T2 Medical helped doctors establish an infusion center. The doctors often referred patients to the center, and T2 managed the center for a fee. After a profitable referral pattern was established, T2 bought the center from the doctors, paying them with a special class of T2 stock.
In most cases, the doctors were not allowed to sell the stock for two years, so their economic fortunes were tied to the company's profits, which in turn depended on the continued referral of patients by the doctors, Federal officials said.
A Federal grand jury in Atlanta has been investigating T2 Medical for more than two years.
Kent B. Alexander, the United States Attorney in Atlanta, and Ms. Brown said the statute forbidding kickbacks must be aggressively enforced to curtail waste and fraud in Medicare and Medicaid and to reduce the economic incentives for doctors to order excessive services.
Numerous studies have found that doctors order more tests and procedures when they have a financial interest in the equipment and clinics used to perform such services. In Florida, for example, a state agency said that doctors' ownership of laboratories and diagnostic imaging centers tended to increase the use and cost of those services without improving access to care.
President Clinton's health care plan and other health bills considered in Congress this year sought to impose more stringent limits on doctors' ability to profit from the referral of patients. But the proposals appear to have died along with most other health legislation.
T2 Medical merged with three other health care companies in July. The resulting entity, the Coram Healthcare Corporation, is the nation's second-largest infusion therapy concern. With the merger, the corporation will not be dependent on the referral of patients by doctor-investors; instead, it can use the sales force of the combined companies to generate new business.
A top executive of T2 Medical resigned in August 1993, and the company said then that it had overstated its earnings for six months in 1992 and 1993 because of accounting irregularities and errors.
When home infusion therapy began, insurers encouraged its use because it was cheaper than hospital care. But in recent years, the industry has become highly competitive, and insurers have set strict limits on reimbursements, reducing profits for some infusion companies.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
A Switch in Bastion of Liberalism: Not Many Protesting Sex Zoning

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
For better or worse, New York City has always had a reputation as one of America's most permissive cities when it came to matters of free speech -- even when the freest speakers wore no clothes. Now, it seems, the city's tolerance, or at least its grudging acceptance, has reached a limit.
In a city where there are such things as an erotic bakery and cable channels with all manners of sexual explicitness, the proliferation of topless bars, X-rated video stores and other "adult" businesses has provoked an unusually concerted uproar, particularly in residential neighborhoods where they had rarely ventured before. 
 Now, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has proposed zoning changes that would restrict sex-related establishments to a few nonresidential neighborhoods. Not to be outdone, the City Council has scrambled to move ahead with its own zoning changes. Even one of the city's most prominent liberal officials, Ruth W. Messinger, the Borough President of Manhattan, has offered a set of restrictions, although far less sweeping.
What is remarkable is how far the Mayor's restrictions would go. The neon lights flashing "Live Nude Girls," the provocatively obscured windows of video stores and the tawdry, taunting placards -- in recent years as much a part of New York's image as the Empire State Building -- would be shunted to isolated industrial areas. The Mayor would even bar peep shows and topless-a-go-go's from Times Square, and that, regardless of one's point of view, is almost impossible to conceive.
But what is even more remarkable is how few elected officials in a city renowned for its liberalism have stepped forward with objections to the proposals, which are now subject to the city's planning process. When a City Council committee voted to initiate its zoning proposal last week, no one voted against the idea. The one member who abstained, Thomas K. Duane, the liberal Democrat, cited the First Amendment but said he also worried that under the restrictions, most of the X-rated businesses still allowed in Manhattan would be in his district, along the industrial stretches of Chelsea beside the Hudson River.
What's happened? Has America's most tolerant city suddenly turned Victorian? Not exactly, according to elected officials and others who support the restrictions.
The intent, they say, is neither to censor nor curtail businesses legally protected under the First Amendment, but rather to remove the spillover impacts of X-rated businesses from residential neighborhoods -- far away, as the political science goes, from the children of middle-class voters. To put it another way, "free speech" has nowadays become much less of a political rallying cry in New York City than "quality of life."
"I don't think the goal is to get into what's obscene," said City Councilwoman Joan Griffin McCabe, a Democrat whose avowed liberalism on First Amendment matters has run into the abrupt growth of X-rated video stores in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. "People just don't want it on their corner. They don't want it shoved in their face."
Hers is a sentiment heard more and more around the city -- and not just toward topless bars and X-rated video stores.
From liberal neighborhoods in Manhattan to more conservative ones in Queens, New Yorkers seem less willing to turn an accepting or resigned eye to the myriad annoyances of urban life: from aggressive panhandlers on the Upper West Side, to men wielding squeegees at Queens Plaza in Queens to young louts urinating on the streets of Greenwich Village.
"Not long ago there was a sense of allowing all people to do all things at all times," said City Councilman Charles Millard, the Republican who has campaigned against the opening of X-rated video stores in his district on the Upper East Side. "Suddenly people are realizing that they don't have to feel guilty saying 'I don't want somebody urinating on my building.' "
It is this frustration among residents in the city's middle-class neighborhoods that Mr. Giuliani, the first Republican Mayor in a generation, has tapped by proposing the restrictions on X-rated establishments. Raymond B. Harding, the leader of the state's Liberal Party and an important backer of Mr. Giuliani's, said that Mr. Giuliani was a result of that frustration.
"I think over a number of years there was a sort of breakdown of the social contract in New York City," Mr. Harding said. "In making the decision between David Dinkins and Rudy Giuliani, New Yorkers were sending a signal that they too wanted to restore the social order."
Of course, when it comes to matters of sexuality, the city's political moods, and social mores, have swung like a pendulum.
At the turn of the century, when Times Square was still called Long acre, prostitution and sexually explicit entertainment flourished, until the authorities responded to moral indignation. Then in the 1920's, burlesque revues grew wildly popular until the city's temperance changed again and the bawdiest of them shut down, a pattern that would be repeated over the decades.
"The alleged obscenity of the burlesque shows is exceeded by their external frowsiness," The New York Times wrote. "The neighborhood of such theaters takes on the character of a slum."
That was in 1933. But the same concern about X-rated businesses -- that the effects are spilling over some invisible line of acceptance -- still echoes around the city's residential neighborhoods today.
"The city is tolerant so long as it's not in their backyard,"' said Richard C. Wade, distinguished professor of urban history at the City University of New York's Graduate Center. "In a city as large as this, there have always been pockets of these things. The difference now is the ubiquity of them."
While few elected officials have openly opposed the restrictions, the new zoning proposals still face opposition that could scuttle them, which was the fate of proposed zoning restrictions in the 1970's, when the number of X-rated establishments grew from from 9 in 1965 to 151 in 1976. This is nearly the level today.
Some officials have expressed misgivings that the proposals may go too far to pass muster in court, including planners who presented Mr. Giuliani with less restrictive proposals only to be told, one official said, to go all the way. Norman Siegel, the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said that court was exactly where the restrictions would be decided.
Supporters of the zoning restrictions say the Mayor's proposals go no further than restrictions imposed by other cities, including Detroit and Los Angeles. But New York, the opponents counter, is New York.
Councilwoman Ronnie S. Eldridge, the Democrat from the Upper West Side, said that the anger over quality-of-life issues had caused many people to forget the city's tradition of tolerance. She expressed hope that a more sensible solution would be found to quell the anger.
"The liberal voice -- it seems to have disappeared in the city," Ms. Eldridge said, noting that few people were picketing bars or Off-Track Betting parlors that create the sort of nuisances regularly attributed to X-rated businesses. "Maybe we're just being quiet for a while."

Richard C. Wade
Professor of urban affairs at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York
History is replete with cycles of high tolerance, followed by restraints and reform. Usually cities, either by law or custom, accept a measure of what they thought aberrant behavior by permitting it in certain areas. What is new now is the ubiquity of adult entertainment establishments. Partially this is due to a more relaxed attitude toward them, the cheapness of videos and the small amount of capital required to get in the business. Containing their spread has always been a delicate balancing act, and solutions have seldom been satisfactory or lasting.

Joseph B. Rose
Director of the Department of City Planning, which is drafting the Mayor's new zoning restrictions
New York City's residential neighborhoods deserve as much protection from negative impacts of adult entertainment uses as are available to other communities around the country. Our studies have shown conclusively that negative secondary impacts -- such as declining property values, increased crime and diminished quality of life -- provide a constitutional basis for broad zoning restrictions. The materials sold in the kind of establishments we propose to regulate are now more widely available than ever before. This is not about limiting access to the content of the materials. It's about protecting the quality of life in New York's neighborhoods.

Stephen J. Morello
President of the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau
From our point of view, people do not come to New York for business or pleasure for these businesses like the ones the Mayor is referring to. There are a significant number who could do without this kind of entertainment. It gets in some people's way when they are here to do and see other things. Our sense is that whatever measures are taken to improve the quality of life for the benefit of residents also contributes to the benefit of visitors and the travel and tourism economy.

 Gretchen Dykstra
President of the Times Square Business Improvement District
Times Square is home to theaters, publishers, record companies and the American Civil Liberties Union. Many have benefited from First Amendment protections. Our concern is the sheer number, not the fact of these places. Everything that has driven our work concerning limiting adult entertainment has to do with concentration of pornography. People understand that you cannot sacrifice a commercially vital neighborhood like Times Square and write it off as a red light district. It did not work in Boston.

 Madeline D'Anthony
Owner of the Harmony Theaters in TriBeCa and Chelsea, and a founder of the Adult Industry Trade Association, formed earlier this year to fight restrictions
Everybody wants to point the finger at society's woes. They need something or someone to blame, and they've chosen the adult industry. It doesn't make sense. How does a man who walks into a store to buy an adult video emerge from the store as a criminal? How is it that he's destroying quality of life?
We're an easy target. The problems are still going to be here when they move the X-rated stores. They wouldn't be there if there wasn't business. I think the only concerns are the signs. While we don't believe in restrictions, we believe the signs can be a problem. It should be a self-regulation that we impose on ourselves to keep peace with the communities.

HEADLINE: CUTTINGS;
What's a Flying Female Gypsy Moth? It's Trouble

BYLINE: By Anne Raver 

 BODY:
ONE day last July, Donna Moramarco, a Cornell Cooperative Extension agent in Plainview, L.I., was working in the insect lab when she noticed a huge gypsy moth laying eggs on an alcohol bottle.
Then she noticed it flying around the room. 
 Wait a minute. Flying? The female North American gypsy moth can't fly.
Ms. Moramarco suspected the female was an Asian gypsy moth -- which can fly as far as 30 miles to lay her eggs and which has not been seen before in the Northeast. After a round of scientific telephone tag in New England, Dr. William Wallner, a entomologist at the United States Agriculture Department's Center for Forest Health in Hamden, Conn., and a few Federal officials began investigating some wooded areas on the North Shore.
The possibility of the Asian moth's entry into New York does not bode well for trees, because the insect appears to be an even more voracious leaf eater than its North American cousin. And because of the female Asian moth's ability to fly, the population can spread about three times as fast, Dr. Wallner said.
Egg samples are now being genetically analyzed at the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service in Falmouth, Mass., but whether or not the moths are Asian or a strain from Germany -- a close relative -- or North American is not yet clear.
In 1981, North American gypsy moths ate through 12 million acres of forest in 17 Northeastern states and Washington, D.C., causing millions of dollars' worth of damage.
"We anticipate that the Asian gypsy moth will be far more destructive than the North American, because its host range is broader," Dr. Wallner said. The Asian moth feeds not only on oak and birch but also on conifers like larch and Douglas fir, which are important economically to the Northwest. It is also fond of the red alder, which grows along riverbanks and is crucial to the health of riparian ecosystems.
It may also eat more plants in gardeners' yards, said Dr. Wallman, who was not big on home remedies. Even if you scrape off any egg masses you see and destroy them, there are many more that you will never see.
The most common treatment is the use of Bacillus thuringiensis, or Bt, a bacterium that paralyzes the gut of the insect and kills it, without harming its natural predators or leaving a poisonous residue.
Dr. Wallner has traveled about 40,000 miles throughout China and Russia studying the ecology and life cycle of the Asian gypsy moth. At Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay, L.I., he collected a number of egg masses that looked much like those he had seen in Asia and in the Rhine Valley, where forests have recently been defoliated. Interestingly, a number of egg masses on Long Island were stuck not only on tree trunks but also on leaves.
"That's very indicative of what I saw in the Russian Far East," Dr. Wallner said. "If eggs are laid on the sides of buildings or trees in Siberia, they'll die from exposure. But if they're laid on foliage, the leaves will drop and be insulated by snow."
The first sighting of the Asian gypsy moth was in 1981, Dr. Wallner said, when egg masses were found on Russian ships loading grain in Vancouver, British Columbia. In 1991, many more egg masses were found on Russian ships docked in the Northwest, coinciding with increased outbreaks in Asia.
Traps baited with a chemical that mimics the female moth's sex pheromones were set around Portland, Ore., and Tacoma, Wash., and after male Asian gypsy moths were positively identified, the area was sprayed with Bt.
The latest confirmed sighting was July 3, 1993, in Wilmington, N.C., as moths flew out of the hold of a military ship bringing troops and weapons back from Germany.
Dr. Wallner sees a direct connection between the opening up of the Russian border, as well as relaxed trade barriers, and the increased sightings of the Asian moth.
"As things move more freely the question becomes, How do we handle nonindigenous species -- I call them biological pollutants -- that are not normally found in the environment?" he said.
The gypsy moth is believed to have originated in Asia thousands of years ago, and to have spread to Europe, where it lost its ability to fly.
On the barren steppes of Russia, where trees are sparse and widely scattered, the farther a female moth could fly, the better chance she had of laying her eggs in a forest -- where her progeny could feast on leaves. They, in turn, flew on to the forests of Germany and France, where their cushy lifestyle apparently resulted in the loss of their piloting abilities. So it goes in evolution.
The gypsy moth was unknown to America until 1868, when Leopold Trouvelot, a French naturalist and entrepreneur, brought some to Medford, Mass., in an attempt to breed a disease-resistant silkworm, and some moths escaped. Twenty years later, when caterpillars skeletonized the trees of Medford, they were sprayed with Paris green, a compound of copper and arsenic. Another outbreak in 1923 prompted spraying with DDT from Long Island Sound to the Canadian border.
Though a lot of robins dropped dead, the caterpillars marched on. Since DDT was banned, carbaryl, which kills honeybees, and Bt, which is more environmentally benign, have been widely used. But the gypsy moth has continued to spread at a rate of about 12 miles a year, to Ohio and Michigan and into Virgina and West Virginia.
 
THIS WEEK
Move Things to Their Winter Homes
 Waste no more time planting small spring bulbs and daffodils. Hold off on the tulips and garlic until mid-October.
Make cuttings of geraniums, especially the fragrant ones, to be potted up for indoor plants this winter.
Fall is a great time to prepare new beds for next year and to move plants around the garden. I plan to double-dig the old rose beds, add plenty of manure and compost and replant only the most disease-resistant and fragrant bloomers. They'll have plenty of time to establish new root systems before the freeze.
Dig up parsley, taking care not to damage the tap roots, and put it in a big pot for indoor growing. Set it in your sunniest window, in a chilly room. Some people have luck with rosemary, too, but mine always limps along, just barely, until spring.
If you started perennials from seed in midsummer, the plants should be sturdy enough to move to their permanent spots in the garden. Mulch them well after the first frost.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 627 words

HEADLINE: New York's High Taxes

 BODY:
George Pataki, the Republican candidate for governor, looked at a report on state taxes last week and declared that New York taxes "are out of control" -- a condition he attributes in part to alleged spendthrift policies over the past 11 years by his opponent, Gov. Mario Cuomo. Mr. Pataki's remedy is to cut a bevy of personal and corporate taxes, though he conveniently sidesteps telling anyone by how much or how he intends to pay for this beneficence. Never one to miss an election-year trick, Governor Cuomo chimed in with his own tax-cut package. He too put off telling voters whose programs will be gored.
The candidates are right that New York taxes are sky high. Last week's report by the State Business Council confirms what many other studies also show: state and local taxes, measured as a percentage of personal income, are 40 percent higher in New York than the national average. Only Alaska is higher and Hawaii close behind. But oil companies pay over 85 percent of Alaska's taxes; tourists pay a large share of Hawaii's. In New York, New Yorkers pay most of the taxes. 
 But before taxpayers salivate over the prospect of lower taxes, they should note that the next governor will be hard pressed to deliver on his promise. A careful study by Frank Mauro of the labor-backed Fiscal Policy Institute estimates that the state budget will have a $3.5 billion deficit by 1997. If the next governor is to cut taxes, he will have to muscle large, unpopular spending cuts through the Legislature.
The obvious question is whether the state and local taxes are strangling the economy. The evidence is mixed. But as Steven Gold of the State University of New York at Albany points out, New York businesses operate in a climate of high wages, high energy costs, expensive regulations and slow regional growth. To add high state and local taxes to this anti-business cauldron is worrisome.
Even more worrisome are New York City taxes. They are higher than elsewhere in the state and a whopping 100 percent above the national average. A large part of the problem is state policy that forces the city to pick up large shares of Medicaid costs, welfare outlays and school expenditures. New York City is saddled with responsibilities unlike those of any other city in the U.S.
Mr. Pataki is trying hard to tarnish Mr. Cuomo with the state's high taxes. But when Mr. Cuomo took office in 1983, state and local taxes were slightly less than 40 percent above the national average. They remain so today. In between, he signed into law several tax hikes. He also signed several tax cuts. The truth is New York has been a high-tax state since Gov. Nelson Rockefeller reigned. It will remain so as long as New York provides a low-tuition university system, generous welfare benefits and costly local school systems (which on average provide higher teacher-student ratios than those in all but two other states).
Mr. Cuomo defends his record by pointing out the true, but irrelevant, fact that state taxes in New York are not high by national standards. That is because Albany increasingly legislates new public services by telling local governments to foot the bill. The only sensible way to discuss taxation in New York is to look at state and local taxes combined.
Taxes have a benefit, of course: they pay for services that many citizens prize. Indeed, Albany would need to cut public programs drastically, and therefore foolishly, in order to bring taxes way down to the national average. But there is good reason for the next governor to adopt a long-term plan to bring taxes back toward the levels in states with which New York competes for business. A sensible policy would be to target a modest tax cut where it is needed the most, New York City.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Justice Shines on the Baseball Players

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 When baseball's acting commissioner, Bud Selig, announced the end of the 1994 season, I was surprised at how many fans and even sportswriters blamed the players.
 
 Unlike other professionals, baseball players have a limited number of productive years. By the time they hit 40, they are history.
 A vicious line drive finished the careers of the pitchers Herb Score and Dizzy Dean when they were still very young. Pete Reiser was never the same after he crashed into the center-field wall at Ebbets Field.
 We should also remember how the ballplayers were paid in the years before players union, free agency and arbitration. While other top show business performers were raking in millions, superstars like Babe Ruth, Joe DiMaggio and Ted Williams had to beg for a pay increase.
 With players facing unemployment because of age and injury, the owners are asking them to risk their jobs and financial well-being by accepting a salary cap. When George Steinbrenner, owner of the Yankees, said he wanted his payroll down to $45 million, wasn't he setting a salary cap? A ballplayer, like any other employee in any other industry, should be free to seek the salary he thinks he deserves.
 The rebuttal to this argument is that the weak-market teams cannot afford to pay these players what they deserve and will lose them to another team. If so, for once Mr. Steinbrenner is right: these teams should close shop or move.
 By striking, the players sacrifice huge amounts of money they will never recover so that the young players coming up from the minors will have a better opportunity. They should not be criticized for this, but applauded.
 
ELLIOTT S. KANBAR
New York, Sept. 19, 1994

HEADLINE: Local Governments Lose Millions In Complex and Risky Securities

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
In 1990, Virgil Swartzlander, the treasurer of Sandusky County, Ohio, for more than 30 years, began investing in a new type of highly speculative security cooked up by Wall Street. So did his friend, Maurice Kline, treasurer of nearby Portage County. Now, after $10 million in losses of taxpayer money, they say they did not fully understand what they were buying.
These men, along with dozens of other officials of towns, colleges and at least one Indian tribe across the country, thought they could get higher returns from new and risky investments called mortgage derivatives. But as interest rates have risen, these investments have dropped sharply in value, and taxpayers now face multimillion-dollar losses. 
 In Ohio alone, municipalities lost at least $13 million. In Texas, Odessa Junior College has $22 million in investments that cannot be sold. The City Colleges of Chicago have $96 million in highly questionable investments. And the Shoshone Indian tribe in Wyoming has lost about $5 million -- leaving it without money to buy clothes and food for needy children or provide financial assistance to adults.
Now that these investments have gone awry, many local officials say they were pushed into unsuitable choices by aggressive brokers. But others say there was greed on both sides -- the brokers seeking large commissions and the local officials gambling for big returns that would make them look good, rather than placing public money into conservative investments like certificates of deposit that offered modest returns but virtually no risk.
"The profits to brokers for selling these derivatives have been fat and a lot of local officials wanted to stretch for higher yield," said Richard Y. Roberts, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission and a specialist in municipal finance. "Unfortunately, a lot of these officials were investing in something they shouldn't have been."
Mortgage derivatives are highly risky bets on the direction of interest rates. They get their name because they are derived from pools of home mortgages that are lumped together by investment houses and then re sliced to create different investments: some from just the interest portion of these mortgages and others from the principal only. About $125 billion of such mortgage derivatives are outstanding, mostly owned by banks and insurance companies that are seeking above-average returns and that are able to understand the risk.
Just how many have filtered into the hands of municipal treasurers is still anyone's guess, experts in municipal finance say.
Lawsuits and investigations in many of these cases have uncovered a common pattern: local officials, assured by brokers that these investments were safe, took public money and put it in mortgage derivatives. For the most part, these investors lost, because when interest rates fell in 1993, many people refinanced their mortgages and paid off the original loans. Because the original mortgages propped up these derivatives, once they were paid off and retired the derivatives fell in value.
Rosalie Townsend, treasurer of the Vermilion, Ohio, school district, was among the losers. In late 1992, she put $200,000 of the district's money in a mortgage derivative. "I was out-and-out lied to," Ms. Townsend said of her dealings with a broker from Hart Securities of Houston.
She said she had told the broker that "we were only interested in safe investments that wouldn't risk our principal," and added: "The broker ripped off the pages from the prospectus that said this was risky. He didn't give me the information to ever guess we could lose money."
After the investment plummeted in value, it was finally sold for $16,000.
Lawyers for the brokerage firm that sold the derivative, Hart Securities, which is the subject of complaints from four other Ohio municipalities, said the firm did nothing wrong.
"They are just looking for a scapegoat," said Paul S. Francis, a Houston lawyer representing Hart. "We never represented these investments as risk-free and they made these investments knowing that. Now they have selective memory."
Richard C. Yount Jr., a partner of Mr. Francis, said: "A lot of these treasurers characterize themselves as unsophisticated rubes. But a lot of them are very sophisticated."
 
 
Financial Crisis For an Indian Tribe
 Among the other losers on mortgage derivatives was the Shoshone tribe, which resides on the Wind River Reservation in southwest Wyoming. It invested $5 million in the derivatives in 1993 and lost nearly all of it. This wiped out a third of the tribe's $15 million operating budget and has created a financial crisis for the 3,000-member tribe, which has 70 percent unemployment.
"We are either going to have to cut services, or our entire budget will be depleted by 1997," said Robert Murray, a member of the tribe and its lawyer. Mr. Murray said tribal officials were approached by a broker who aggressively courted them for four years before convincing them in 1993 to buy derivatives.
"None of the six members of the tribe's business council are educated in finance or securities," Mr. Murray said. "And our financial officer is a tribal member who just graduated from college.
"The broker said these investments were 100 percent Government-guaranteed, that we could make money and that they were not as risky as buying stocks."
The broker, Tracy A. McKnight, and his firm, MGSI Securities in Houston, declined to comment on this case, which is now before the National Association of Securities Dealers, the brokerage industry's self-regulatory body.
The tribe's investment encompassed a variety of derivatives, none guaranteed by the Government. The tribe bought interest-only strip derivatives, which provide the buyer with the interest from mortgage pools, and which fall in value when home mortgages are refinanced. It also bought principal-only strip derivatives, which provide returns from the principal part of mortgages, and which decrease in value when interest rates rise. The tribe also bought inverse floater derivatives, which are intended to move in the opposite direction of interest rates and which float in value. These, too, declined in value.
 
Staff and Team Cuts At a Junior College
 The same firm, MGSI Securities, is one of six that sold Odessa Junior College in Odessa, Tex., more than $22 million of mortgage derivatives that are now almost impossible to sell. Among those six firms are two other Houston-based concerns that have caused problems elsewhere: the Government Securities Corporation of Texas was a big seller to many of the Ohio buyers and Westcap Government Securities sold most of the $96 million in illiquid mortgage derivatives to the City Colleges of Chicago, a group of seven community colleges.
At Odessa Junior College, the problems came to light in March, when the school's treasurer, who has since resigned, disclosed that he had invested the school's entire $22 million portfolio in mortgage derivatives, mostly the same ones sold to the Shoshone tribe. At first, these investments were profitable. But rising interest rates changed that. The school has sold about $6 million of these at a loss, and the remainder are considered illiquid, with no potential buyers.
As a result, the 5,000-student college has had to borrow $12 million from local banks to cover current costs. Its bond rating has fallen to the lowest possible level, which will increase the cost of borrowing in the future. Local taxpayers faced a 7 percent property tax increase and the Texas auditor's office is investigating. The college president is working without pay, athletic teams have been eliminated and the staff has been cut 10 percent.
"The problem was that none of us, neither I nor the board, understood what it was to be in derivatives," said Dr. Philip Speegle, the college's president. "None of us ever imagined the magnitude of the fluctuations possible."
At the City Colleges of Chicago, the entire $96 million investment portfolio was put into the same array of mortgage derivatives that have sharply fallen in value. In a lawsuit, the college asserts that Westcap misrepresented these derivatives as safe and that it gave no indication that they were volatile or that no buyers existed for them. Westcap declined to comment.
"Our treasurer came to us and said, 'I made a major mistake,' " said Jacqueline Woods, a spokeswoman for the colleges, whose operations have not been impaired by these problems so far. The treasurer bought the securities in 1993 and was dismissed in February after reporting the problems.
 And in Charles County, Md., outside Washington, $1.3 million was lost in derivatives. The county treasurer who made the investments has been dismissed.
 
 
Wall St.'s Siren Song Lures Ohio Officials
 A particular hotbed of investing was Ohio, where two brokers moved in like the Music Man and sang the praises of derivatives to 16 local governments, all of which now face losses. They include small towns like Jackson, population 6,000, which lost $380,000, and the counties of Sandusky and Portage, which have the biggest losses, a combined $10 million.
Among the busiest derivatives brokers in Ohio was James Winter, who has had a checkered history in the industry. He worked for the Government Securities Corporation of Texas, based in Houston, which is known in the industry as G.S.C. The firm has agreed to reimburse $5.5 million to Sandusky County and is in litigation with Portage County, which is claiming losses of about $5 million. Also prominent in the sale of derivatives in Ohio was Kenneth J. Schulte, a broker for Hart Securities, who sold derivatives to Vermilion and others.
Mr. Winter, whose lawyers would not allow him to comment, was popular in Ohio. He attended the state convention for local treasurers, met frequently with local officials, and sometimes stayed in their homes. For 10 years, he had been selling investments to Portage and Sandusky counties.
"Mr. Winter had a good reputation with us," said Virgil Swartzlander, 74, who has been re-elected Sandusky County treasurer 10 times. "We trusted him. We had invested in small business loans with him and made a profit. He was a pretty nice fellow. And he represented these as very safe."
Mr. Swartzlander and other local treasurers did not know that Mr. Winter, 56, had run afoul of securities laws before. In 1970 he was convicted in Arkansas for a "hot check," as the law there calls a fraudulent check; he was fined by the National Association of Securities Dealers in 1979, and he had his broker-dealer license temporarily suspended in 1981. Among the charges against him were that he bought securities without customers' consent and made unauthorized transactions of Federal Government securities. In 1987, he was also convicted of drunken driving in Texas.
When Mr. Winter sat down with the treasurers, both sides saw money to be made. Mr. Swartzlander anticipated yields that he said could be two to three percentage points above those of other securities. Mr. Winter and other brokers liked derivatives because of the fat commissions they paid -- The Cleveland Plain Dealer said Mr. Winter received commissions of up to 4 percent, an amount other brokers have said was not uncommon. This compares with commissions of one-quarter to three-tenths of a percent for most government bond transactions. G.S.C. would not comment on its commissions.
 
Officials Are Burned, Then Scalded Again
 In 1990 and 1991 Mr. Swartrzlander began buying interest-only mortgage derivatives. So did his friend, Maurice Kline, the 74-year-old Portage County treasurer. As interest rates fell in early 1992, and homeowners prepaid their mortgages, the value of these securities dropped. "People refinanced and these things went kaflooey," Mr. Kline said.
Concerned, the two men called Mr. Winter, who assured them that these securities would "come back," they said. And to offset these losses, Mr. Winter persuaded them to buy another uncommon investment, inverse floaters, as a hedge. Mr. Winter said the yield of these floaters would rise as interest rates fell, the treasurers said.
From April 1992 to October 1993, Mr. Kline bought four inverse floaters for $4.2 million and Mr. Swartzlander bought $6.5 million worth between June 1992 and March 1993. These investments also lost money; the lawsuits began after an Ohio state auditor's report uncovered the losses.
Part of the problem is that neither Mr. Swartzlander nor Mr. Kline, like many municipal finance officers, are schooled in finance or receive much help. "I've got no investment committee, no computers, nothing," said Mr. Kline, who manages a $20 million budget. "I do it all handwritten."
Ronald Mayle, the assistant prosecutor of Sandusky County, said, "Except for the things from G.S.C., the biggest decision Mr. Swartzlander had to make is which bank to buy C.D.'s for the county."
Representatives of G.S.C. dispute this characterization. "Lots of folks who invested in derivatives enjoyed attractive profits for several years," Frank Klaus, an executive vice president, said. "They understood them perfectly then. Then the market became less attractive and now they don't understand them."
 The article also misstated the location of Portage County, Ohio, in some copies. It is east of Akron, not near Toledo.

A front-page article yesterday about investments by towns and colleges in highly speculative Wall Street offerings referred incorrectly in some copies to the amount of public money that the treasurer of Sandusky County, Ohio, placed in an interest-rate investment known as an inverse floater. It was $6.5 million, not $6.5 billion.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By Terence Neilan

 BODY:

Tours of Japan
 Q. Do you know of any firms that offer small group tours to Japan to historic, artistic and cultural sites? -- Jack Economou, Poughkeepsie, N.Y. 
 A. Organizing small group tours to Japan is a specialized field with only a relative handful of full-time practitioners and a correspondingly small number of programs. A tour, say, to tea-ceremony centers might take two years to set up and yet because of its generally limited appeal might be repeated only every five years.
The following companies have wide experience in the field:
The North Group, 2250 Broadway, No. 20B, New York, N.Y. 10024, telephone (212) 875-8423, has organized and co-sponsored small, selective tours for the Japan Society for the past three years. Next year's trip, called "Journey to the Heart of Japan," will explore the Japanese esthetic "as it is expressed through ceramics and food and their presentation." The tour, from Oct. 6 to 23, will visit the homes and studios of ceramic artists, chefs, tea masters, calligraphers, textile artisans, gallery owners and collectors and will be limited to 12 or 13 people and three guides. It will be led by Jeff Shapiro, of Accord, N.Y., a ceramic artist who lived and worked in Japan for 10 years. Despite the $7,950-a-person price tag in double occupancy ($9,250 for a single), the organizers say the tour is selling fast. The price includes a $500 donation to the Japan Society, 6 breakfasts, 11 lunches and 9 dinners, but it does not include air fare to and from Japan.
Journeys East, 2443 Fillmore Street, No. 289, San Francisco, Calif. 94115, (510) 601-1677, organizes more frequent trips -- a total of 10 this year, the 10th year of what it calls "taking travelers on back country adventures in Japan." Its small groups are each accompanied by two leaders. This year's tours were designed under the headings of "Mountains, Temples and Hamlets," "Brushes With Inner Japan," "From Farmhouse to Teahouse" and "Arts and Crafts: Past and Present." "Mountains" concentrated on temples, gardens, villas and palaces as well as villages and the Japanese countryside; "Inner Japan" combined flower arranging, the opportunity for Zen meditation, an overnight stay at a Shinto temple and visits to arts and crafts museums and shops. Similar tours will be held next year but not all schedules and prices have been finalized. The "Farmhouse" tour will run from May 13 to 27 and cost $3,685 a person in double occupancy; the "Inner Japan" tour will be held from Oct. 28 to Nov. 11 and cost $3,785 a person. Round-trip air fare from the West Coast is available at $1,090 and from the East Coast at $1,390.
TBI Tours, 787 Seventh Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10019, (212) 489-1834, sells all the standard packages (among them: nine days in Tokyo, Hakone and Kyoto, or four days in Tokyo and three in Kyoto), but it also has tours designed to attract the second-time visitor that would tend to attract smaller groups. An example is "Imperial Japan A," 11 days spent visiting Tokyo, Hakone, Matumoto, Takayama, Kanazawa, Ama-no-hashidate and Kyoto. Its highlights include visits to a number of temples and religious shrines as well as castles and museums. This year's prices ranged from $3,475 to $3,580 a person in double occupancy, including air fare from New York or Chicago.
Although it does not act as an official clearinghouse for groups with special interests, the Japan National Tourist Organization, 630 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10111, (212) 757-5640, sometimes has information about trips being put together that might fit other people's plans. The organization can also help with general questions about travel to Japan.
 
From Turkey to Greece
 Q. I plan to travel to Greece in November, with a side trip to Istanbul. Will, as I have read, have any trouble getting back into Greece with a Turkish stamp in my passport? Should I have the Turkish stamp put on a separate piece of paper? -- Nancy J. Becker, Seattle
A. Travelers with a Turkish stamp in their passport have no problem gaining entry to Greece, according to the Greek National Tourist Office and the Greek Consulate in New York. The tourist office said it had had a number of inquiries recently about a potential problem in that area, prompting it to wonder "who it is who starts these kinds of rumors."
According to the Embassy of Cyprus in Washington, a Turkish stamp would also cause no problem for any visitor arriving on the Mediterranean island, which was invaded by Turkish troops in July 1974. Turkey later set up what it called the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus in the occupied area of the island, and a Cypriot spokeswoman said a stamp from that area would not be recognized and its carrier denied entry to the Greek Cypriot part of the island.
 
Down-Under Weather
 Q. I expect to be in the Sydney area of Australia for two or three months starting in November. What kind of weather can I expect? And how can I obtain a list of culturual progams and entertainment activities for that period? -- Irving Jacks, New York, N.Y.
A. The climate of the southeastern area of Australia, of which Sydney is a part, is best described as warm-temperate with no real cold season, warm to hot summers and rain well distributed throughout the year.
And as the seasons are reversed in the Southern Hemisphere, it happens that you have picked the summer to be there.
Average maximum highs in Sydney in November are 93 degrees, with lows at 63. Average monthly precipitation is 1.2 inches.
In December it heats up a little, with the average highs at 97 degrees and lows at 67. The precipitation level increases, too, to 1.4 inches.
January is usually the hottest month of the year, with average highs at 99 degrees (125 degrees was the hottest ever recorded there) and lows at a balmly 70 degrees. Precipitation remains at 1.4 inches.
For information on cultural events and other programs, write to the Australian Tourist Commission, Suite 1200, Avenue of the Stars, Los Angeles, Calif. 90067. The commission's theme for 1995 is "Celebrate Australian Art and Culture," which is also the name of a brochure highlighting what the country has to offer. The commission has also produced a "Directory of Events and Contacts." Both can be obtained from the commission or by calling (708) 296-4900 to speak to a travel counselor.
 
Mecano in Concert
 Q. My husband and I are fans of the Spanish rock group Mecano. We would like to plan a trip to Spain this fall around the group's concert appearances. Can you tell us how to get tickets? -- J. Martin, Providence, R.I.
A. You're out of luck, it seems. The group's manager, Rosa Legarrie, said the band had not made any records or given any concerts for the past two years because of disagreements among its members. And they have no plans to get back together in the near future, she added.
 TERENCE NEILAN

CORRECTION-DATE: October 9, 1994, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An answer in the Q & A column on Sept. 25 about the weather in Sydney in November, December and January misstated average temperatures and precipitation levels. The figures were for Bourke, New South Wales. The average high in Sydney in November is 74 degrees, the low 60 and the precipitation 2.9 inches. The corresponding figures for December are 77, 63 and 2.9; for January they are 78, 65 and 3.5.

HEADLINE: A Boy's Dream of Great Things Leads to a Publishing House

BYLINE: By DIANA LASSETER 

DATELINE: LAWRENCEVILLE

 BODY:
AS a boy growing up in the Eritrea region of Ethiopia, Kassahun Checole was always pouring his energy into creative endeavors. In high school he organized a music group called the Harambe, a Swahili word meaning "pull together." The Harambe traveled the community, celebrating the harmony of life through song.
Mr. Checole's other great love in those days was publishing the high school's first newspaper. As he strained to recall its name in his Lawrenceville office recently, he smiled and he clasped his hands together. Brightly colored books lined the shelf above his head. 
 "I was a poet in those early days," he said. "I would write silly poetry about love and humanity. Those were idealistic times. When you are youthful, you think great things."
Mr. Checole, 47, a poet turned businessman, has never lost that idealism, nor has he stopped pursuing harmony. That philosophy has helped propel the success of his company, the Africa World Press, and its distribution arm, the Red Sea Press. The Africa World Press publishes books on Africa and African-American affairs, mostly nonfiction works on history, sociology, politics and economic issues.
Children's books, though, like the recently published "A Is for Africa," by Ife Nii Owoo, are a fast-growing segment of the business. The catalogue of the Africa World Press includes such noted works as Sonia Sanchez's "Under a Soprano Sky" and "Afrocentricity," by Molefi Asante.
The Africa World Press has been growing at 17 percent a year, enough to enable Mr. Checole and his 12 full-time employees to move from their 5,500-square-foot warehouse in Ewing late last year to a 15,000-square-foot office and warehouse in Lawrenceville. The maroon leather chairs and teal green carpeting in Mr. Checole's office suggest prosperity, but the gleam in his eyes and the enthusiasm in his voice speak of a venture that has survived the unpredictable publishing industry to find success.
Mr. Checole, who has long resisted the label of businessman, is beginning to recognize what he calls the "humane, responsible and venturesome" dimensions of the corporate world. That recognition did not come easy for a socially conscious individual who has thrived on bucking the system.
While attending Haile Selassie University in Ethiopia, Mr. Checole became an anti-monarchist who fought, with other students, for democracy in Ethiopia. His radical ideas culminated in a bloody demonstration in 1969 at the university, during which the army killed many students and arrested many more. After spending two and a half years at Haile Selassie, Mr. Checole left school and worked for a year at a clearinghouse in the port city of Massawa.
In August 1971, Mr. Checole, eager to further his education, set out for the State University of New York at Binghamton, where he had friends.
"I got a lot of support at Binghamton from people who were excited about who I was," Mr. Checole said. "I had an adventurous spirit, and I worked hard."
In the early 1970's, when the struggle for independence in Eritrea escalated into war, Mr. Checole supported the revolution from upstate New York, speaking to churches and organizations on the upheavals in his native land. Drawing from his early school years, he began Third World Review, a monthly newspaper in Binghamton.
 
Taught at Rutgers
 Three years after his arrival in the United States, Mr. Checole's undergraduate degree in political science and African-American studies and his master's in sociology led to a position as a professor of sociology and African studies at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. He moved to Trenton with his wife, Ayo, and their baby to start the next chapter, which would prove to be the most crucial.
Early in his teaching career, Mr. Checole was repeatedly frustrated by the small supply of books on Africa and African-American issues. The written material that was available was all too soon out of print.
"Publishers saw books on African issues as not commercially viable," he said. "They also had the notion that black people didn't read. These publishers simply did not know where the market was. They were publishing books and putting them in Barnes & Noble. Black people don't go to those places. You have to put the books where the people are."
Mr. Checole set out to do just that. He began printing a handful of books from the third floor of his home in 1984. One of the first was "The Barrel of a Pen," a collection of literary criticism by an African literary figure, Ngugi Wa Thiongo. What started as a side endeavor, however, soon blossomed into a challenge that demanded all Mr. Checole's time.
 
'No One Doing What I Was'
 "There was no one doing what I was at the time," Mr. Checole said. "Traditional black publishers like Third World Press in Boston were very focused. My goal was more ambitious and perhaps foolish. I wanted to reach the widest spectrum of people I could."
His biggest obstacle was distribution. Traditional distributors resisted carrying books by the Africa World Press because they felt there was no market. So in 1985 Mr. Checole founded the Red Sea Press to distribute the books he published.
These days Mr. Checole's mail includes several manuscripts a day from as far as Australia and as near as Princeton. The Africa World Press publishes 80 books a year. Paul Coates, president of the Black Classic Press in Baltimore, said the Africa World Press is the country's most active black publisher.
"Kassahun continues to amaze me," Mr. Coates said. "I don't understand how he does it. When he first started, there were a few black publishers, but no distributors. He has made his mark in both areas. He is an entrepreneur who is not afraid to take risks. He dreams, and then he executes."
Mr. Coates is chairman of the National Association of Black Book Publishers, a group founded by Mr. Checole in 1993.
 
Goes by Gut Feeling
 Reflecting on the last 10 years, Mr. Checole is quick to admit it has not been easy. But he has developed a shrewd business sense and what he describes as a smell for a manuscript. "I go with what's in my heart," he said. "If it tells me something, maybe it can tell the rest of the world too."
He is working toward strengthening the Africa World Press's distribution and international presence. The company will have a London office by the end of the year.
With the recent opening of an Africa World Press office in Eritrea, Mr. Checole travels there once a month to monitor its progress. He says he is excited to be a part of the recent rebirth in his native Eritrea, which gained independence from Ethiopia in May 1993. Returning so often to his home, Mr. Checole recalls the image of that idealistic boy singing of the harmony of life, an idealism inherent in the Africa World Press.
"We are still young," he said of his company. "It takes a long, long time to establish a publishing company. We are in our teen-age years with a lot of energy. People say you can't be trusted when you reach 40. We can still be trusted because we're still dreaming."

HEADLINE: In Teacher Contracts, Money's the Word

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
WITH mixed emotions in Mount Vernon earlier this month, 900 teachers returned to work after a one-day walkout, having agreed to an 8.5 percent salary increase over four years -- far less than they had hoped for.
"It's no great contract, and there are no big dollars involved," said Geraldine J. Hegwood, president of the Mount Vernon Federation of Teachers, "but realistically, this is a hard time for teachers." 
 In Yonkers, teachers "haven't used the 'S' word yet," but they are poised for a strike, said Walter Tice, president of the 2,100-member Federation of Teachers there. The most recent teachers' contract in Yonkers expired at the end of June, and Mr. Tice, a social studies teacher, said the proposed school board budget had "no money in it for negotiations and no money for raises."
He said the union was worried that a wage freeze under consideration would push the median for teachers' salaries in Yonkers to one of the lowest levels in Westchester, which would be unacceptable to the union.
Similar issues were worrying teachers in Yorktown, where two contracts involving teachers, clerical workers and aides expired more than a year ago. "Along with some conditions, the sticking point here is money," said John F. Roden, president of the 450-member Yorktown Congress of Teachers.
Teachers in Yorktown, a rural northern community, are seeking salaries competitive with those in other school districts in Westchester, but they are also balking at class sizes in excess of 30 students in some cases, which Mr. Roden said was "more what you'd expect in a big city."
Edward M. Cocoran, regional staff director for the New York State United Teachers, which represents teacher unions statewide, reported that there were 35 unsettled teacher contracts in the four-county district encompassing Westchester, Rockland, Orange and Putnam.
"It's the most open contracts ever, the worst-ever situation of its kind in the region," he said.
Citing the competing interests of taxpayers and teachers, Mr. Cocoran said, "We have lost many, many school budgets throughout the region, and unrest becomes very real when boards don't have money for the bargaining table."
Alan B. Lubin, executive vice president of the 350,000-member New York State United Teachers, reported that 350 of 800 school districts in the state, have outstanding contracts. "Education is not in very good shape," he said.
Mr. Lubin, as head of the statewide union's office of legislative affairs, said he was lobbying for implementation of what is known as the Maintenance-of-Effort Bill. The measure -- which was passed earlier this year by both the Assembly and Senate but has not been sent to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for his signature -- would force New York's five big cities to give state aid money allocated for education to the school districts. It would not allow the aid to be put in the city's general fund.
"This bill says to the cities that they have to maintain their fair share for education," Mr. Lubin said, "and in Yonkers, for one, it would resolve the current situation."
Mr. Tice, the union leader for Yonkers teachers, said the Maintenance-of-Effort Bill could mean as much as an additional $5 million for the current education budget, which is now at $224 million, up from last year's budget of $211 million. Reginald F. Marra, Superintendent of Schools in Yonkers, said he had originally earmarked $2 million for teacher raises before the city cut his budget.
But Mayor Terence Zaleski of Yonkers denied that the city was holding back state aid funds from the school district, and he said that the amount of money provided by the municipality at least matched and possibly exceeded what the Maintenance-of-Effort Bill would require. He said that more than half of the city's budget went to the Board of Education and that members of the school board needed to become better managers.
He also said, "I'm confident the dollars are there for the teachers."
 
Allegations Called Unfounded
 The Maintenance-of-Effort Bill was drafted by Senator Frank Padavan, a Republican from Queens, to deal with complaints that big city mayors use state aid for schools to close budget gaps or reduce local tax rates. Several union leaders expressed concern that the bill was languishing because it would open a $70 million budget gap in New York City and create a politically sensitive situation for Mr. Cuomo in an election year when he is courting the favor of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Cecily Bailey, a spokeswoman for the Governor's office, said Mr. Cuomo had "not impeded the bill in any way." She said the allegations that Mr. Cuomo was delaying signing the bill were unfounded, and it was simply a case of the State Legislature's failing to send the bill along.
Meanwhile, union leaders have continued their push for raises to help teachers meet cost-of-living increases. And Mr. Cocoran, the regional staff director for the state teachers' union, said he was continuing to remind opponents that "teachers are not trying to get rich teaching."
"Just look at the Fords and Chevys in their parking lot, compared to the sports cars in the students' lot," Mr. Cocoran said.
But taxpayer groups and city administrators were of a different mind. John D. Williams, a member of the board of directors of the Taypayers' Alliance, a statewide umbrella organization based in Westchester, said teachers should refrain from demanding more money during difficult economic times.
 
Percentages in Decline
 Mr. Williams criticized Mount Vernon teachers for striking on the first day of classes this fall and not considering the needs of students returning to the classroom. And he said that teachers in many districts were being greedy, because they were "already making a bundle" of money.
But at the Washington offices of the American Federation of Teachers, which represents 860,000 public employees, Jewell C. Gould, director of research, said, "There's a perception that taxes are too high and there's a need to cut back, but times are really getting much better."
Mr. Gould also mentioned the following statistics supplied by the union: in 1964, the share of school budgets that went for teacher salaries in kindergarten through 12th grade was 51.7 percent nationally; by 1984, that figure had dropped to 41.3 percent, and by this year it was down to 39.1 percent.
"If teacher salaries had kept pace with total school spending, the average salary nationally would be close to $80,000," Mr. Gould said, "not the $32,000 or so that it is today."
In Westchester, a major concern among union leaders was that the salaries in their school districts compared favorably with those in other areas.
 
Tax Error in Yorktown
 In Yonkers four years ago, teachers struck for two days because their salaries were at the lowest level for the county, and Mr. Tice said the city was "hemorrhaging teachers to other districts." Their 1990 work stoppage won them a 4.5 percent retroactive raise for the previous year and 9 percent raises for the four ensuing years, "which closed the gap," Mr. Tice said.
The median teacher salary in Yonkers is currently $61,092, compared with the median overall for the county, which is $63,316. Hastings-on-Hudson has one of the lowest median teacher salaries in the county at $57,152, and Bedford has one of the highest at $71,503.
In Yorktown, where the median salary for teachers is $62,260, Mr. Roden said his union had considered a strike but put the idea on hold recently while the Board of Education resolved a $1 million tax error on its books. The error has resulted in tax increases for residents of as much as 16.5 percent, he said. Teachers in the Yorktown School District went on strike for a month in 1973, and 22 teachers, including Mr. Roden, were jailed for contempt of court.
The issue 21 years ago was also salaries and class sizes, but Mr. Roden said the union was now attempting negotiation rather than taking stronger measures.
 
Parents Mobilized
 In Mount Vernon, where teachers had been without a contract since June 30 last year, Ms. Hegwood, the union leader, said that senior citizens and young homeowners without children had objected to teacher raises and had expressed their views at Board of Education budget meetings even though the median teacher salary in Mount Vernon -- $60,909 -- is near the bottom of the scale for Westchester.
During the strike, teachers mobilized parents of school-age children and had them speak in favor of the teachers' demands at a Board of Education meeting. Ms. Hegwood said many of the parents were recent immigrants who were hesitant to attend school board meetings because they do not speak English well. The union provided interpreters for those parents.
Larry Rubin, a communications specialist for the National Education Association in Washington, which represents 2.2 million employees in public education, said there have been far fewer teacher strikes in recent years, a time in which teachers and schools "were being called on to do a lot more."
"Kids are coming to school with greater needs these days, with emotional and nutritional needs, for example, and it is a constant struggle for resources," he said. "Still, the big picture is that things are relatively quiet, even though there are these strains."
