LENGTH: 1742 words

HEADLINE: A Town Loses Its Hospital, In the Name of Cost Control

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DESTIN, Fla.

 BODY:
This resort town on a barrier island off the Florida Panhandle enjoys silken beaches, good fishing and a boom in real estate. What Destin does not have these days, to the outrage and despair of many residents, is its own hospital.
Last May the country's largest hospital chain, which had recently acquired the eight-year-old Destin Hospital, closed most of it in the name of efficiency. The only part left open was the emergency room, which, lacking the support of an intensive-care unit and ready surgeons, could not treat many life-threatening conditions. As of now, the hospital is completely closed. 
 Officials of the company, Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, noted that fewer than one-third of the hospital's 50 beds had been filled on average and that two other hospitals it owned were only about 15 miles away.
"We simply can't have a hospital on every corner," David T. Vandewater, chief operating officer of Columbia, said in a recent interview. "We just can't afford it."
But what Mr. Vandewater described as a sensible economic step created an uproar in Destin, where travel to the other hospitals can take as long as 45 minutes in the tourist season when the roads are crowded. People here see the hospital's closing as a threat to their health and prosperity, and as a callous move by a company that had gained a stranglehold on the medical market here.
"This company has basically lost our respect," said Charles Clary Jr., an architect and City Council member in Destin. "The community here doesn't trust them anymore to work for our good."
Even without strong direction from Washington, the nation's health care is being transformed by market forces and the search for lower costs. In the abstract, everyone agrees that waste must be wrung from a bloated system.
But as the conflict here shows, efficiency as defined in the emerging medical marketplace does not always square with the deeply felt needs of communities. And sometimes, unavoidably, it can mean longer drives for medical care, longer waits and even medical risks.
"Destin is a microcosm of what you're going to see around the country," said Douglas Cook, director of Florida's Agency for Health Care Administration, which supports the town's effort to regain a hospital."We were caught between what we feel is a legitimate need of a community and what a corporation is willing to do if it owns a hospital."
Painful hospital closings are by no means confined to the for-profit chains. As patients' hospital stays have shortened and payers -- Federal and private -- insist on lower prices, hundreds of hospitals have already shut down or merged with neighbors in recent years, especially in rural areas and small towns.
But Columbia, based in Louisville, Ky., has been a highly visible leader in bringing hard-nosed corporate tactics to the once-staid world of medicine: buying hospitals, closing weak ones, zealously competing for doctors and their patients. The company, after several recent mergers, owns 195 hospitals and 125 outpatient surgery centers. It says its size brings economies of scale, allowing quality care at lower prices. Indeed, Columbia describes itself as a grass-roots leader in the national overhaul of health care.
In Florida alone, Columbia has bought 45 hospitals, accounting for one-third of the state's hospital beds; it is now the state's largest private employer.
Columbia officials said they were surprised by the outcry in Destin, which they called the worst in their experience of numerous hospital closings. They said the attacks reflected nervous real estate interests more than legitimate health concerns. And they noted that Gov. Lawton Chiles has crusaded for leaner health care, but that now, immersed in a tough fight for re-election, has supported Destin's drive to reopen the hospital.
Dan Moen, president of Columbia's Florida Group, said that Destin residents still lived within 20 minutes of two other hospitals, also usually half-empty -- a 247-bed one in Fort Walton Beach and a 75-bed one in Niceville.
But Destin believes it has a strong claim. Not only are many residents and visitors are elderly, but each summer also sees serious water and road accidents. In addition, during high season, the roads to the mainland become so crowded that the drive to the other hospitals can take twice as long as it does at other times.
Destin's population is about 15,000 "on a Wednesday," as the city manager put it, and growing fast. That number jumps by several thousand in the winter as Northern retirees move in, and it doubles in the summer as vacationers come for the white sand beaches and emerald waters of the Gulf of Mexico.
The closing of Destin Hospital has left residents like Martha Coxe, 56, who suffers from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, scared. Living 10 minutes from the hospital had provided security and convenience.
"This has been a real upheaval for the community," Ms. Coxe said, describing her own feeling as desperate. "This is an added stress for me on top of my respiratory problem. It's just greed on the company's part."
Columbia's actions also seem to have wounded civic pride. The town has a sense of itself as independent, with bright prospects symbolized by several giant cranes along the shoreline, each heralding yet another high-rise condominium. "This community is large and thriving," said Philip G. Cook, the Destin city manager, "and we need a small hospital."
City leaders attributed the hospital's low occupancy and financial losses, reported by the company as $100,000 a month, in part to manipulation by Columbia and the previous owner, another private chain. They argued that Destin was treated merely as a feeder to other hospitals, that it never nurtured a corps of doctors who would bring in patients and that it did little marketing. They said a small hospital here should be able to make ends meet, a contention supported by outside consultants.
The company contends that the outcry has been driven by business considerations. "This didn't come down to a health care issue," Mr. Vandewater said. "It was about keeping property values up."
Destin leaders do worry that the loss of the hospital will deter migrants like John Rossi, a 62-year-old retiree from the Air Force who moved here last winter with his father. "I bought a home right here because the hospital was close by," Mr. Rossi said.
"This is disastrous," he said of the shutdown, noting the preponderance of elderly people in his neighborhood.
Dewey Destin, a commercial fisherman and City Council member, acknowledged that worry about the impact on business had figured in the outcry. But he added: "I have kids myself, and I've talked to many parents with young children and to old people who've lived here a long time. They're really scared that in an emergency they can't get in a car to get stabilized within 10 minutes or so."
Local doctors say the medical need is real. "I've personally taken care of a few patients who probably would not have survived the ambulance ride to Fort Walton Beach," said Dr. Travis Bolton Jr., an internist at a clinic next to the closed hospital.
Columbia officials wanted to retain the hospital's state license and certificate of need, arguing that the company might reopen beds some day as the population grew. Keeping the license would also freeze out potential competitors, since the state would not grant a new certificate in this overbuilt county. Throughout Florida, in fact, hospital occupancy averages only about 50 percent.
But in an agreement forced on it by the state last month, Columbia agreed to sell the hospital by Dec. 31 or lose the license and certificate.
Originally, the company said it would keep open an emergency room half-time. When the community protested, it said it would maintain the emergency room round the clock, as well as two inpatient beds.
Still, sicker patients who might need hospital admission were routinely directed elsewhere, and local doctors said that, without the backup of a hospital, the emergency room was little more than a walk-in clinic.
"That was an emergency room in name only," said Dr. George Novak, a plastic surgeon in Destin. "In my opinion, it was just an attempt to keep competition away from here."
In June, the City Council sued both Columbia and the state, arguing that the company had violated the licensing rules by no longer operating a hospital. In addition, thousands of residents signed a petition calling for reopening the hospital, and while campaigning in Destin, Governor Chiles, a Democrat, promised to try to help the town retain a hospital.
Then came a deadly incident on Aug. 3. A man with severe internal injuries from a jet-ski accident was taken to Destin Hospital for helicopter evacuation to a major trauma center. Ambulance workers said they had asked to bring the man into the emergency room for help in the minutes while waiting for the helicopter but were refused entrance. The man later died.
The hospital denies that it refused the man entrance, and while exactly what happened outside the hospital that day remains in dispute, doctors say it did not affect the patient's outcome. Nonetheless, the incident took on mythic dimensions for the town, proving in citizens' minds the vital need for a local hospital.
After a quick investigation, the state health care agency sought to revoke Columbia's Destin license on the ground that it was not operating a genuine hospital. In an Aug. 30 settlement with the state, the company agreed to make a good-faith effort to sell Destin Hospital, along with its certificate of need. In the meantime, the hospital has been completely closed.
So now, whether Destin can sustain a small hospital will be tested in the marketplace. The city's attorneys say that nearly a dozen private hospital companies have inquired about a possible purchase. Destin is also considering public ownership as a last resort.
The outcry has not changed Columbia officials' views; they say the shutdown of underused hospitals is both desirable and unstoppable. "It's going to happen again and again around the country," Mr. Moen said.
Councilman Destin, whose ancestors settled the area in the early 19th century, agreed that the trend might be unstoppable.
"That's the problem with the health care we're moving toward in this country," he said. "The bottom line's going to be profit rather than community welfare."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Workers on Sept. 18, covering up a sign that pointed the way to Destin Hospital, now closed. (Kiichiro Sato for The New York Times); David T. HEADLINE: TOBACCO INDUSTRY FIGHTS NEW YORK OVER SMOKING BILL

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
The tobacco industry is mounting an all-out campaign to derail or modify legislation imposing new restrictions on smoking in public in New York City. As part of that campaign, Philip Morris has warned that it will consider moving its headquarters out of New York if the bill passes.
Today the City Council's Health Committee is to hold a hearing and possibly a vote on the bill, which would outlaw smoking in nearly all restaurants and public places. While the bill will not be voted on by the full Council for weeks, lobbying is under way with a zeal that is rare in New York's municipal affairs. 
 In the last few days Council members have faced a barrage of letters, requests for meetings, full-page newspaper advertisements, nonstop faxes and unending telephone calls. The lobbying comes from opponents like the Tobacco Institute and the United Restaurant, Hotel, Tavern Association, as well as supporters like the American Cancer Society and Harlem Hospital.
Philip Morris, which employs about 2,000 workers in its Park Avenue headquarters, has heightened the pressure by threatening to leave the city and by mobilizing arts organizations that it underwrites.
"It has been communicated to officials of the city that if the bill is passed, it would cause us to reconsider having our headquarters in New York City," said Steven C. Parrish, senior vice president and general counsel of Philip Morris, the world's largest cigarette maker. "Our employees are concerned that the city seems to be attacking our company and our industry. This bill is very, very important to us."
The measure, introduced in March by Speaker Peter F. Vallone, would be one of the most stringent in the nation, banning smoking in all restaurants and in most office areas, as well as many outdoor places like stadiums.
As a result of fierce lobbying on both sides, some provisions have already been changed: a plan to exempt small restaurants has been shelved, for instance, and pro-tobacco forces were able to derail certain features of the bill, like a ban on smoking in all private offices.
The legislation expands a 1988 law requiring the establishment of nonsmoking areas in public spaces. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has banned smoking from Gracie Mansion, has not taken a position on the bill, but has generally supported antismoking initiatives.
Because the measure is sponsored by 32 of the 51 members of the Council, its passage is considered virtually certain. But it can be amended at any point. And with more and more states and cities restricting smoking in restaurants and the workplace, tobacco companies and smokers' advocates say defeating or watering down the New York City bill is a priority.
Philip Morris, a major supporter of New York-based cultural organizations, like the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater, Lincoln Center, the Joyce Theater and the Museum of Folk Art, has encouraged some arts groups to enter the fray. Officials of some organizations said they had been asked to contact Council members and tell them that if the company moved from New York City, so would its grants to many of the city's arts groups.
"They wanted us to stress to Council members that, if the bill passes, it will directly reflect on their funding to us," said a senior executive of a leading arts organization, who asked not to be identified.
Another arts administrator, Karen Brooks Hopkins, executive vice president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, said the academy was not pressed by the cigarette company to do any lobbying. But she added, "They have informed us how they feel about this bill and they have left it up to us to respond as we see fit." She said the academy had made "discreet telephone calls" to City Council members to express concern about the bill.
And that has led to letters and phone calls and faxes by the thousands, Council members say. In the Brooklyn office of City Councilman Enoch H. Williams, the letters have reached the point where they are no longer in stacks, but heaps that have to be stored in huge boxes. Across the bridge at City Hall, Mr. Vallone, the Council Speaker, has spent day after day in meetings, besieged by all manner of advocates, corporate executives, business owners and champions of smoking restrictions.
"I have had dozens and dozens of meetings with people who want to persuade me," Mr. Vallone said. "This is the most intense lobbying we have seen, other than with the budget, in some time. The tobacco companies have been the most intense because they realize that New York City is a bellwether. And they have pulled out all the stops."
Of Philip Morris's threat to leave the city, Richard A. Riley, a spokesman for Mr. Vallone, said: "Philip Morris and other interested parties on all sides of the issue will have an opportunity to testify about the bill and any potential economic effects. The Speaker is willing to listen to any suggestions to improving the bill while retaining its intent. But the goal of this bill is to protect the rights and health of nonsmokers from the danger of secondhand smoke."
In anticipation of the vote, several Council members have been wined and dined by representatives of the tobacco and restaurant industries. The United Restaurant, Hotel, Tavern Association, which opposes the bill as too restrictive, has taken out full-page ads in New York City newspapers denouncing the measure and asking people to call the Mayor's office or individual Council members.
"We consider this, short of alcohol beverage prohibition, the most serious risk to our bottom line," said Scott Wexler, executive director for the statewide industry trade association. Mr. Wexler said that his association estimates that restaurants would lose up to a quarter of their business if smoking were prohibited.
In addition to the newspaper ads, the association has mailed information denouncing the bill to 10,000 restaurant owners in New York City, asking them to contact their Council representatives.
Councilman Williams, who chairs the Health Committee, which is holding the hearings, said his phone has been ringing off the hook. "At first the calls were 10 to 1 in favor of the bill," Mr. Williams said. "Now we're seeing it swing the other way. The tobacco people have been gearing up in the last week."
So far, their efforts may have produced some small gains. In the latest version, the bill would allow smoking in some private offices, some hotel lobbies and in bars that are connected to restaurants.
To make its case, the tobacco industry has hired some of the city's best-known lobbyists, many with close ties to Mr. Vallone, including Martin J. McLaughlin, who heads a public relations and lobbying firm and is a friend of the Speaker, and Norman Adler, a consultant and former political adviser to Mr. Vallone.
"Our approach is simple," said Thomas Lauria, a spokesman for the Tobacco Institute, the industry's trade association. "We contact City Council members, articulate what the problems are. We help coordinate the efforts made by restaurant owners and people in the hospitality industry. Nonsmokers have an axe to grind, and we do, too."
Supporters of the measure have not been sitting idly by, either. The Coalition for a Smoke-Free City, an association of 70 organizations, including medical, youth, science and education groups, has also sent information to the City Council, including data on smoking-related diseases. In addition, the group has placed an advertisement on radio stations asking for citizen support of the bill.
"We have sent as much information as we can to the City Council on the disease and deaths caused by tobacco addiction," said Joseph W. Cherner, the policy chairman for the coalition, who is widely regarded as one of New York's leading antismoking campaigners. "We also want the Council to know how successful smoke-free policies have been in other cities."
Mr. Vallone, who smoked a pack of cigarettes a day before quitting 15 years ago, said his campaign to ban smoking has been inspired by medical studies on the dangers of secondhand smoke.
"I am open to discussing this," the Speaker said. "But the truth is that I no longer see this as a civil rights issue. It's a health issue."

HEADLINE: Clinton's Sermon in Harlem: Don't Desert Cuomo

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

 BODY:
Rocking to resounding gospel strains, President Clinton went to a black church in the heart of Harlem yesterday to rouse a vital constituency to turn out its vote for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the onetime rival whom he now praised as "the heart that you must not lose."
Mr. Clinton, in town for political fund-raising and meetings with international leaders before a speech at the United Nations today, took his sermon from an epigraph by the prophet Isaiah printed on the cover of the program at the Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church on West 132d Street: "They that wait upon the Lord shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings as eagles." 
 "But I want to talk to you about the rest of the verse," added the President, an old Sunday school regular who entered the venerable church -- once a stop on the Underground Railroad -- with a Bible under his arm. " 'They shall run and not grow weary. They shall walk and not faint.' "
This weekend, Mr. Clinton practiced the difficult task of promoting his party as a not-very-popular President, giving eight speeches in four cities in three days for Democratic candidates, plus the appearance for Governor Cuomo. [B8.]
The implication of the President's ad lib in Harlem could not have been plainer for the embattled Democratic Governor, who declined to seek the prize that Mr. Clinton won, nominated him with soaring oratory at the Democratic Convention two years ago and now needs every shred of support any surrogate can muster. The congregation of 350 worshipers responded with applause.
"The people who don't want us to get together, and who have a very different idea about moving forward than most of us do, are hoping and praying that you will grow weary, that you will not run, that you will not walk, that you will just grow weary," Mr. Clinton said in a not-so-veiled reference to the Republicans. He added: "Do not lose heart. Show up, talk to the people in your neighborhood, tell them to show up. Scripture says we're supposed to be good citizens, too. Mario Cuomo is the heart that you must not lose."
Black turnout is especially crucial to Mr. Cuomo's prospects against State Senator George E. Pataki, and although the Governor retains strong black support in the polls, he has been at some pains to energize black voters. The symbol of that trouble -- former Mayor David N. Dinkins, who has made no secret that he believes Mr. Cuomo did not work hard enough for his re-election last year -- was absent from the group of black leaders in the church.
Mr. Clinton, facing Democratic losses in Congress and statehouses in November, retains atypically high poll ratings in New York -- well above Mr. Cuomo's. So keeping a Democrat in Albany is squarely in the President's self-interest, and the Governor's aides said the White House late last week proposed a joint appearance at a black church. Bethel's pastor, the Rev. O'Neil Mackey, got final word of the visit at 7:30 P.M. Saturday, after a trip to Brooklyn was ruled out because of travel time. He stayed up until 2:30 yesterday morning working on the details.
The President managed a bipartisan moment, too: a courtesy call in his suite at the Waldorf-Astoria with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who ranks as one of his and Mr. Cuomo's favorite Republicans these days, having lobbied for the President's crime bill and lobbed grenades at Mr. Pataki's refusal to say how he would help the city.
"The only discussion we had of the Governor's race was a mutual agreement that it was very close," Mr. Giuliani said after the meeting.
Last night, Mr. Clinton spoke at the Waldorf to raise money for Democratic Congressional candidates from around the country, and was joined by big donors like Maurice Tempelsman. "Let's face it," the President said, "the guys we're running against are good at talking. And they have a simple system: Rule or ruin. They're not much interested in doing."
Throughout the morning church service, Mr. Cuomo was flanked on the altar by Representative Charles B. Rangel, who grew up down the block, and his Democratic running mates, Comptroller H. Carl McCall and former Family Court Judge Karen S. Burstein, the nominee for State Attorney General. The President praised them all, noting especially that Mr. McCall would become the first black man elected statewide in New York and thus, he said, a national role model.
Mr. Clinton sat on the aisle in the third pew from the front with his wife, Hillary, and daughter, Chelsea, until rising to speak at the end of the hour-and-45-minute service. He sang the hymns lustily, murmured the responsive refrains of the choral anthems and swayed to the jazz-gospel soloists, at several points putting his arm around Mrs. Clinton.
When a booming baritone began a bluesy plea for redemption that crested with the phrase: 'Oh, Lord, Oh, Lord, please work on me!" Mr. Clinton sat rapt, nodding intently. But Mr. Cuomo was oblivious, scribbling furiously in the speech notes on his lap.
For his part, the Governor also cited religious themes and maxims, albeit more eclectic and erudite ones, skipping from "Deo Gratias" (Latin for "Thank you, Lord") to "Tikkun Olam" (Hebrew for "Repair the World," one of the basic tenets of Judaism) to the writings of his favorite French Jesuit, Teilhard de Chardin, who held that one's endeavors should be based on the desire to do greater good, not ambition.
In stemwinding ad libs of his own, Mr. Cuomo barely pleaded his case, but he made one for the President, and the Democrats, that left his meaning clear, saying at one point: "I don't want a President who's going to take me wherever the political wind blows, because I don't know where it's going to blow, and maybe next year it's going to blow against Italians, and maybe it's going to blow against guys with baggy eyes. And I'll tell you, I've got to look out for winds that blow like that."
Mr. Clinton, whose talk had to compete with that archetypal New York annoyance -- a broken car alarm that began wailing just as he started -- said that Mr. Cuomo's "greatest failing is that he speaks about me better than he speaks about himself." He recited his own burdens in running for re-election as Governor of Arkansas, including an encounter with an old man at the State Fair who, asked by Mr. Clinton, "Aren't you sick of me after all these years?" replied: "No, but everybody else I know is."
But that is the price of grappling with governance, Mr. Clinton suggested, adding that for all of Mr. Cuomo's three terms in office, "in a lot of ways, this is his first term, and it's just started, because it's the first time we've had a chance to work together" as Democratic partners to face what the President said were 30 years of social problems, 20 years of economic trials and 12 years of Republican neglect.
The catch: Since Mr. Clinton took office, New Yorkers have just as often as not complained that his proposals in areas from taxes to health care to welfare would hurt wealthy states like New York, which are hardest hit by tax increases and whose rich social benefits could be squeezed in the wake of new national minimum programs and standards.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Economy
 Alan S. Blinder has stirred things up at the Fed by suggesting that creating jobs should sometimes take precedence over cutting inflation by a few points. The new Fed vice chairman has irritated some colleagues with tutorials on the economy. [Page D1.] At the Fed, officials are likely to respond to signs of strong growth by again raising interest rates this year, but economists are divided whether the bank's rate-setting panel will act tomorrow. HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATS;
Out of Fashion With, Clinton Campaigns in a Fashion for the Faithful

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

 BODY:
Politics is just an art. Campaigning for Democrats when you are a less-than-popular Democratic President, on the other hand, is nuclear physics. It is the science of embracing a candidate while remaining at arm's length, and giving a Presidential blessing to a man or woman who may not wish to look like your ally. It is being radioactive without giving everyone else on the dais a lethal dose of political roentgens.
This weekend, President Clinton went to four cities in three days and gave eight speeches on behalf of Democratic candidates, as well as making an appearance with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. If he did not win the Nobel, at least give him a Ph.D. 
 There is no simple way to measure Mr. Clinton's standing in Chicago, Minneapolis and Kansas City, Mo., the three Midwestern cities he visited. But the customary gauges suggest he is no more popular there than in the nation as a whole, where polls show that about 6 in 10 people disapprove of his performance.
For example, the President was greeted by sparse crowds at airports and light turnouts along the routes to his appearances. More telling, perhaps, was the turnout at the four fund-raising events that were the overarching purpose of his trip.
Mr. Clinton collected a total of $1.1 million at his three Midwest stops, including just $350,000 in Chicago, where a Presidential appearance 15 months ago had raised $1 million. By comparison, President George Bush collected $1.5 million in Minneapolis alone four years ago this week, on a midterm election jaunt similar to the one Mr. Clinton just completed.
One veteran Chicago fund-raiser said Democratic donors are "tapped out" by a series of expensive state races, but added, "The President's problems don't help any."
The President picked up another $350,000 for House candidates from about 70 donors last night in New York City, where his popularity is unusually high. (Separately, Mr. Clinton honored a group of New York Democrats who had raised $2 million for House races.)
Despite the seeming indifference to the President in most places, the national Democrats who arranged the fund-raising events and the candidates who will receive the money say that Mr. Clinton is in great demand as a campaigner.
"There's no dearth of candidates asking for his assistance," Don Foley, the executive director of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, said at Mr. Clinton's Kansas City stop, before perhaps 300 people in a plush hotel room distinguished by an ice sculpture of a buxom mermaid. "It's not his message that the people are going to vote on; it's the message the candidates are delivering."
Ann Wynia, the Democratic candidate for the Minnesota Senate seat being vacated by Dave Durenberger, a Republican, said she was "just delighted" when Mr. Clinton agreed to come to town.
"Here in Minnesota," she said, "I detect a huge reservoir of good will for President Clinton. They believe he is truly trying to solve the problems of the average American."
Perhaps so, but in Minnesota and elsewhere, Mr. Clinton and those around him tended to play matters more as if they suspected a drought.
The President did not go out of his way to lash himself to his party's candidates on this trip, and the same was largely true of the candidates themselves. Three of the six midwestern fund-raisers were closed altogether, and the remaining three were open only to journalists and the loyal Democrats who made large donations for the chance to attend.
Moreover, Mr. Clinton was circumspect in his remarks at those events where the cameras were rolling. In a Chicago speech that ran five-and-one-half pages -- single spaced -- the President named the three Senate candidates for whom he was stumping exactly once. (The candidates themselves were from Arizona, Montana and Michigan; they flew to Illinois for the event.)
In other speeches, the President was careful to note that his endorsement did not imply that a candidate would be loyal to him.
Here was Mr. Clinton in Kansas City, speaking of Representative Alan Wheat, the Democrat seeking the Senate seat being vacated by John C. Danforth, a Republican: "He's important to the country -- not because we will always agree, but because he will show up for work in the morning." (Republicans come only to talk and delay, he said.)
And here was Mr. Clinton in Minnesota: "I came here to ask you to help Ann Wynia -- not because, as she said, she would agree with me on every issue, but because she would bring common sense" to the Senate.
Such little dodges are part of what makes campaigning such a wondrous craft. But they are useless without a good campaigner, and it was when Mr. Clinton was forced to confront his unpopularity in public that his skills shone.
After groping for weeks to find a political explanation for his low numbers, Mr. Clinton finally squeezed his sour polls this weekend and made lemonade. The problem, he said, was not with his policies, but with the do-nothing, obstructionist Republicans who ruined the country and are blocking its rebirth.
"Sam Rayburn once said, 'Any old jackass can kick down a barn, but it takes a carpenter to build one,' " he said in Kansas City to cheers. "It also takes longer to build one than it does to kick one down."
And in Minneapolis: "The bad political policies that we've had, dividing us, the wealthy against the middle class, different races, different religions -- all these political and economic and social problems we have, we've had these for the last 12 years. I have just been there 20 months. We are going in the right direction. Do not turn back."
Anyone not in the room might have suspected that he was campaigning not for other Democrats, but for himself.

HEADLINE: Panel Weighs Indian Point 3 And Its Future

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
Safety concerns have shut the Indian Point 3 nuclear reactor for 19 months. Now the changing economics of electric power may shut it for good.
Four reactors around the country have already been prematurely retired in the last few years because the electricity they generated cost more than electricity from other sources. And at a legislative hearing beginning today, several witnesses are expected to testify that Indian Point 3 should also be closed. 
 Assemblyman Richard Brodsky, chairman of the Assembly's Environment Committee, said electricity from oil and gas is cheaper than buying power from the troubled plant in Westchester County, on the east side of the Hudson River just south of Peekskill, N.Y.
Mr. Brodsky's panel will hold hearings on the future of the plant, which is run by the New York Power Authority, the state-owned utility. The hearings will start at 10 A.M. in the Municipal Building in Croton, N.Y., not far from Indian Point 3.
The reactor is 18 years old, less than halfway through its planned life, but it runs badly, with one of the worst records for reliability in the industry. Not only has it been on the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's watch list of least-safe plants for more than a year, but it is also in the middle of a region with a huge electricity surplus and has long been unpopular politically.
In nuclear power plants, where fuel costs are small but capital and maintenance costs are high, the key to economical operation is reliability; the bills for debt service and maintenance pile up whether or not the plant is running. Plants in the New York area vary widely in reliability, but Indian Point 3 is at the bottom of the heap.
The plant supplies power to governmental customers, including the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the City of New York. But it has not run since February 1993, and will be shut at least until early next year because of safety problems.
Since starting up in 1976, Indian Point 3 has run only about half the time, but operating expenses plus continuing capital investment amount to $175 million a year, said Charles Komanoff, an energy analyst in New York. With the high fixed cost, the staff of the Assembly's Environment Committee calculates that its power costs 4.4 cents a kilowatt-hour. The committee says that power is available from Con Edison for a little over 3 cents a kilowatt-hour.
"For years this whole issue has been dominated by the widely accepted truism -- and I don't think it was ever true -- that this was a trade-off between economic benefits and the environmental and public health risks," Mr. Brodsky said. "Now there's a set of data that offers prima facie evidence that it's not just dangerous, it's more expensive."
Economics has already killed the reactor construction industry, with no orders for new reactors since 1978. All the plants ordered after 1973 have been canceled. Now competition is stalking the existing plants; two reactors in California, one in Massachusetts and one in Oregon have been prematurely retired in recent years because of a depressed market for electricity and high maintenance costs. Industry analysts predict more will follow.
But the president of the Power Authority, S. David Freeman, who is scheduled to testify today, said that the evaluation would have to include more factors than just the comparative cost of a kilowatt-hour. Closing a reactor, he said in an interview last week, is "like a divorce; not all of your costs go away."
Mr. Freeman is one of the foremost experts on that subject. Before Gov. Mario M. Cuomo appointed him in March, he was the manager of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District in California, where he was called in to manage the district's recovery after voters shut its biggest generating station, the Rancho Seco nuclear plant. Costs there remained substantial for years after the shutdown because of security and maintenance of the systems needed to tend to the spent fuel.
Indian Point 3, and its near twin, Indian Point 2, which is operated by Con Ed, are in Buchanan, N.Y., 35 miles north of midtown Manhattan. Nearly 300,000 people live within 10 miles, the highest number within 10 miles of any reactor in the country.
Indian Point 2, which is three years older, is not a target of the hearings. It runs better, and closing it would be more difficult because it is owned by an investor-owned utility.
Even closing Indian Point 3 might not be easy, though. The committee said it would require the Power Authority to take a $660 million write-off, which might result in higher costs for the agency's customers.
Ten years ago, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission was threatening to close the reactors because emergency plans for evacuation of neighbors were in poor shape. Officials in Rockland County, which is directly across the river, refused to participate in an evacuation drill, saying that an evacuation in case of accident would be impossible and that the plant should be shut. Governor Cuomo sent bureaucrats from Albany to play the parts of Rockland officials so the drill could be successfully conducted.
Since then, the price of oil and natural gas, two competing fuels, has dropped, and many private companies have built generating stations. The result has been to create a huge power surplus and a sharp drop in price.
The New York Power Pool, a consortium of utilities that coordinates power needs, said it believed that a surplus of more than 5,000 megawatts would persist for years. Indian Point 3 produces 965 megawatts. (A megawatt, one million watts, is enough power to light 10,000 hundred-watt bulbs.)
The plant would look more economical if it ran better, experts say, but some doubt it can ever compete. Mr. Komanoff said that if it resumed operation next year and ran with a capacity of 70 percent -- which would make it one of the more reliable plants and which Mr. Komanoff said was optimistic -- costs would still be about 3.5 cents a kilowatt-hour, the same as electricity available on the open market.
Mr. Brodsky said in a telephone interview that matching the market price was not good enough. "You'd have to have a relatively significant savings to justify the public health risk," he said. "And now the data is that it's more expensive."
Other issues include whether closing Indian Point 3 would result in significantly more air pollution from the plants that would burn coal, oil or natural gas to replace the electricity, and whether more transmission capacity would be required to bring in power from other sources.
Mr. Freeman declined to discuss his position in detail, saying that he would leave that for the hearing. He said when he was appointed that Indian Point 3 and the authority's other reactor, the FitzPatrick plant, near Syracuse, would have to prove to be economical or they should be shut.
Mr. Freeman said he would keep an open mind at the hearings, especially since those testifying would include "our biggest customer, the City of New York, and our next-door neighbor, Con Edison. It's going to be an interesting family gathering."
"I have never been associated with nuclear uber alles," he said. "I was never with the crowd that tried to jam nuclear down your throat." But if running the plant has economic advantages, he said, it would be wrong to close it for ideological reasons. "I don't feel the New York Power Authority is in some godlike position where we have to make that decision on behalf of the nation," he said.

HEADLINE: Machine-Tool Orders Fell 7.5% in August

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Orders for machine tools built in the United States fell 7.5 percent in August compared with July but were up more than 80 percent from a year ago, the Association for Manufacturing Technology reported yesterday.
The group also said orders rose nearly 29 percent in the first eight months of the year, compared with the corresponding period in 1993. 
 Taken together, the statistics are another sign of strength in the American industrial economy, which has been expanding fairly steadily since the summer of 1993. Higher orders for machine tools mean manufacturers are optimistic about sales growth and are buying equipment to refurbish and expand factories to meet future demand.
The association's report covers two categories, metal-cutting tools and metal-forming tools. Both are used to manufacture a wide range of finished products, from appliances like toasters and dishwashers to large-scale items like locomotives and jetliners.
August orders totaled $327.45 million, down from $354.25 million in July but up from $181.40 million in August 1993. Year-to-date orders totaled $2.83 billion, up from $2.20 billion in January-August 1993.
The August order backlog, a measure of the ability of American machine-tool makers to keep up with customer demand, rose to $1.87 billion, up from $1.77 billion in July and $1.46 billion in August 1993.
A sign of some recovery in the sluggish economies of Europe and Japan also emerged from the machine-tool data. Foreign orders for American tools rose 3 percent from July and nearly 51 percent from August 1993. Still, year-to-date foreign orders remain more than 14 percent below comparable 1993 levels.
Export orders totaled $24.20 million, up from $23.50 million in July and $16.05 million in August 1993. Export orders from January to August totaled $170.40 million, down from $198.65 million in the corresponding 1993 last year.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Wants to Cut Back Consumer-Protection Licenses to Ease Business Burdens

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Deciding that New York City no longer needs to exercise its regulatory authority over such things as masquerade balls and drive-in theaters, the Giuliani administration plans to stop requiring consumer-protection licenses for a variety of business activities, officials said yesterday.
As part of its efforts to reduce burdens on businesses, the city would no longer regulate 21 of the 72 categories of businesses now licensed by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs -- from auctioneers to used-car wholesalers, laundries, children's rides, sightseeing guides and movie theaters. 
 In each case, the officials said, the city's rationale for the licenses had either become obsolete, served little purpose or duplicated other regulations and inspections, like those under the health, building or fire codes.
At the same time, the administration wants for the first time to require licenses for furniture and appliance stores -- two businesses that are among the most frequent sources of consumer complaints but are not now regulated, according to the department.
"Government shouldn't be regulating and overregulating for the sake of it," said Alfred C. Cerullo 3d, the Consumer Affairs . "There should be a purpose. It's clear there are many categories of small businesses that no longer justify the license."
The proposal, which is expected to be unveiled by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani as early as today, would need the approval of the City Council, and at least some of the deregulations -- including those for used-car wholesalers and for laundries -- could encounter opposition from consumer advocates or other interest groups.
In 1992, the Consumer Affairs Department, then headed by Mark J. Green, proposed ending regulation of 24 activities, including many of the same ones on the Giuliani list. But in the face of opposition, the Council agreed to approve only 10 of them, leaving the total of 72 license categories now in effect.
"There is room to flatten the bureaucracy," said Mr. Green, now the city's Public Advocate, "so long as they don't jeopardize consumer health and safety." The Public Advocate has issued his own proposals to deregulate city licensing processes.
Richard Schrader, who served as Consumer Affairs Commissioner in 1993, said he had some concerns about deregulation, particularly in the case of auctioneers, laundries and used-car wholesalers. He acknowledged, for example, that there were few complaints about laundries, but said the licensing gave consumers protection that would otherwise not exist.
"To take away the regulatory scheme entirely," he said, "leaves the consumer vulnerable."
Representatives of business, however, welcomed the proposed changes. Evangeline Binder, vice president for government affairs of the New York City Chamber of Commerce and Industry, said that in many cases a license burdens a business without any public benefit. "It does not offer protection to the consumer, and it's a cost to the business," she said.
The administration's proposals, which were outlined for City Council members late last week, are part of a broader push by Mr. Giuliani to strip away regulations on businesses, particularly small ones, as he pledged to do during last year's mayoral campaign.
In addition to the deregulation at Consumer Affairs, the Mayor's office is planning to ease enforcement of such rules as those on sidewalk litter and to consolidate the process of applying for licenses, according to an internal memo circulating through the city's agencies.
The City Health Department also plans to stop regulating beauty parlors, clinical laboratories and blood banks, the report said, since changes in the law have increased the oversight of those businesses by state agencies.
Many of the city's proposals need approval from the State Legislature, like allowing businesses to pay fees or fines with credit cards, or require new computer equipment the city may not be able to afford, given the budget crunch.
The plan to deregulate comes as the Consumer Affairs Department, like other agencies, is enduring cuts in spending and staff. Commissioner Cerullo said the plan would help the department cope by reducing administration, but he stressed that the driving force was a desire to remove burdensome regulations on businesses.
Mr. Cerullo said the city would forgo about $2 million a year in fees for the licenses, which range from $5 for a sidewalk antiques dealer to $350 for a movie theater with fewer than 500 seats. At the same time, he said, the city would save at least that in the cost of administering the licenses.
More importantly, he said, the deregulation would allow the department to focus on the activities that create the most complaints -- from tow trucks to home-improvement contractors.
Chris Meyer, a lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group, which has been a strong consumer advocate, said most of the administration's proposals made sense. "Some of these licenses are so archaic and ridiculous that they deserve to be eliminated," he said.
Many licenses that would be deregulated duplicate other state or city regulations on businesses. The department, for instance, now licenses both billiard halls and the employees in them; employees would no longer be required to have a license. And it plans to stop licensing individual pinball or video games, while still licensing video arcades with five or more games.
The rationales for other licenses have become antiquated, said Marc A. Wurzel, the department's chief of staff. Since 1921, for example, the city has required a license for anyone holding a masquerade ball in a public catering hall. The licenses for laundries, including separate laundry drivers, date to 1938 and appeared intended to exact control over immigrants, particularly the Chinese, he said.
Other activities, according to the department's proposal, generate too few complaints to justify licenses. Mr. Wurzel said there was no need to regulate auctioneers, except for auto auctioneers, who would still be regulated as used-car dealers. As for the separate license required for auctioneers who work at night, Mr. Wurzel said, "While there might have been a rational basis for doing this many years ago, we can't find one today."
And the department wants to give up licensing private skating rinks since it currently licenses only one, Sky Rink in Manhattan. (The others are operated by public or quasi-public agencies, like the rinks in Central Park and Rockefeller Center.) "We're not getting a lot of complaints about broken-down Zambonis," Mr. Wurzel said.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "AT ISSUE: Removing Licesnce Regulations"
 
Jobs, activities or businesses in New York City now requiring licenses from the Department of Consumer Affairs that the Giuliani administration has proposed deregulating:
 
Billiard room employees -- There are 129 licensed employees. Under the proposal, the department would still license billiard halls.
 
Pinball, video and arcade games -- There are 7,136 in delis, bars, restaurants and stores. The department plans to stop requiring licenses for individual video games, but would continue to license video-game arcades with five or more machines.
 
Arcade game attendants -- There are 232 licenses for those who service the games.
 
Children's rides -- The city licenses 1,245 rides, like the gyrating ponies, boats, fire engines or planes in front of supermarkets. Under the proposal, the Department of Transportation would still enforce rules prohibiting such rides from cluttering the sidewalk.
 
Festival games -- Games like ring toss and other street festival favorites are supposed to be licensed, but 42 have been issued.
 
Laundry drivers -- Laundries used to deliver, but not any more, so there are none licensed now.
 
Sightseeing bus driver -- The department licenses 418 drivers. The license was originally intended to crack down on "hawkers" who solicited tourists on the street or curbside.
 
Motion picture projectionists -- The license was originally created because of the specialized skills required to handle film, which years ago was more cumbersome and flammable. The department licenses 648 projectionists.
 
Open-air theaters or drive-ins -- There are no longer any drive-in theaters in New York City.
 
Masquerade balls -- This license was established in 1921 and is required for anyone who rents a public or catering hall, which are also licensed, for a masquerade or fancy dress ball. Since the Department of Consumer Affairs was created in 1969, it has not issued a single license for such a ball.

HEADLINE: Koriyama Journal;
American Colleges Are Flunking Badly in Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KORIYAMA, Japan

 BODY:
Texas A & M University is one of the largest institutions of higher education in the United States and prides itself on the academic programs there. But that did not impress people four years ago when the college opened a campus in this city north of Tokyo and tried to attract Japanese students.
People "think this is an English-language school," Takeshi Watanabe, a student, said as he stood in the asphalt yard of the nearly deserted campus shortly before it was shut down in August. "They don't look at it as a university." 
 Texas A & M is only the most recent American college to fail in Japan. In the late 1980's, American colleges flocked to start programs in Japan, mainly to funnel students to their American campuses, but also to provide a place for Americans to study in Japan. By 1991, Japan had more than 20 American campuses.
But at least nine programs, including that of Lehman College of the City University of New York, have already been terminated, the victims of Japan's recession and recruiting difficulties. Many of the remaining programs are suffering from a shortage of students.
The closings could widen what both countries agree is a serious imbalance between the more than 40,000 Japanese students studying in the United States and the estimated 1,800 American students in Japan. The small number of American students here reflects Japan's high cost of living, the language barrier and a lack of programs for American students, experts say.
The Texas A & M campus here grew out of meetings in 1986 between American and Japanese politicians who felt that having American colleges in Japan would promote mutual understanding. Instead, it became the focus of a dispute between the college and its host city and another symbol of friction between the two economic superpowers.
Koriyama, a city of 320,000 that lies 90 minutes north of Tokyo by bullet train, wanted another campus to help keep young people from fleeing to the big cities. With the Mayor's strong support, the city assembly pledged about $25 million in 1989 to back the effort and to help build a permanent campus.
The college opened in 1990 in a temporary campus consisting of four prefabricated buildings surrounding an asphalt lot that doubled as a parking area and a basketball court.
The college offered freshman-level courses taught in English and intensive English lessons. After two years, students would transfer to the main campus in College Station, Tex.
But the campus had fewer than 100 students its first year and never attracted the 300 new students a year needed to break even. The city decided that it would be foolhardy to build a new campus. B. A. Stout, the director of the program here, said the city's reneging on the permanent campus was the "fatal blow."
College officials also say the campus had a poor reputation.
"Texas A & M was not understood for what it really was," said Demar Taylor, assistant director for external affairs at the campus. "It was looked at by most citizens as a place where students who couldn't make it elsewhere would come to school."
American colleges in Japan say such reputation problems result from unfair trade practices. Japan's Ministry of Education refuses to accredit the American branch campuses, so many Japanese students shun them and their American students cannot get student visas. Last year, in response to pressure from Washington, Japan agreed to give such students cultural visas, with some of the privileges of student visas.
Officials of American colleges here concede that they do not meet all the requirements for accreditation, nor do they want to. Offering an American-style education is their main selling point. An official at the American Embassy in Tokyo said Japanese colleges must specify four years in advance every course that will be offered and who will teach it, allowing little flexibility.
When the American colleges began to open here in the 1980's, Japan was in an economic boom. Many of the colleges that came were small, obscure ones invited to enter partnerships with Japanese businessmen who saw an American education as a marketable commodity in a nation trying to internationalize. And the colleges wanted the income.
But with the recession in Japan the last three years, their plans fell by the wayside. An early casualty was the U.S. International University, a San Diego-based college that was already in serious financial difficulty at home when it opened here.
"Certainly, there were too many at one time and many were here for the wrong reasons," said William Young, associate dean of Temple University Japan, which opened in 1982. It is the oldest American branch campus and has the most students, 1,800.
By the time Texas A & M Koriyama closed its doors, the campus had run up a $7 million debt. The city, the college and an entity set up by the city to run the college are fighting over who will pay. The remaining students have been sent to the main campus in Texas, even if they had not yet finished their English training.
"Eventually," Mr. Young said, "there will be only three or four American universities left here."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Texas A & M, which opened a campus in Koriyama four years ago, closed it in August, the latest victim of Japan's recession and recruiting difficulties. Shortly before it closed, its asphalt yard was almost deserted. (Kanji Takamasu for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Gold's Perch, Close to $400, Is Precarious

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The spot price of gold traded Friday at its highest level since Jan. 4, rising to more than $400 an ounce before falling back to $396.10. And futures contracts are feeling a similar push. Investors buying gold on Friday for December delivery paid $399.60 an ounce.
Yet whether gold continues its ascent or retreats as it has in three other climbs earlier this year is uncertain. 
 "There are two major factors working here, which I believe are moving the market today," said David J. Christensen, a gold analyst for Merrill Lynch in San Francisco. "First there is the supply-and-demand factor, which has been improving over the last year. Principally, mining companies have shown slow growth in new mine production in the face of improving demand for gold jewelry as the world economies start to improve."
The other aspect of the recent rise is psychological, he said, with investors returning to gold as a traditional hedge against inflation.
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, in his semiannual testimony before Congress early this year, showed unusual enthusiasm for using gold prices as a guide to monetary policy, which in turn led the financial markets to focus more closely on those prices.
Five year ago, the economics of the gold business turned down, Mr. Christensen reflected, and mining companies cut back on exploration. Consequently, there was a decline in production growth.
According to Gold Fields Mineral Service Ltd. of London, gold production in 1980 was 1,131 metric tons, while the demand for gold for use in jewelry was 542 metric tons. Last year, mining production was up to 2,280 metric tons, but jewelry demand rose to 2,501 metric tons.
"We are now looking at a macro-turning in fundamentals in the gold market, meaning supply is no longer as abundant as global growth," Mr. Christensen said.
Gold has a dual role, as a commodity and as a financial asset, he noted, adding: "On that basis the commodity side will give direction to gold prices over the long haul, but the short term is easily influence by fears of inflation. There is no doubt that over time the $400 level will be breached, but the short term is now an influence because inflation has embroiled the financial markets with so much uncertainty."
Traders are always amazed at the relatively small size of the market and how so few businesses can generate so much volatility. If all the publicly listed gold companies in the world were lumped together, the aggregate revenues would be less than that of Wal-Mart Stores Inc.
"So if you have a number of investors looking to put a small portion of their investment into gold, the impact on the share valuations in the sector could be dramatic," Mr. Christensen said.
It remains hard to say where gold prices are headed, particularly during this week, which mixes a heavy dose of economic data with a meeting of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee.
That two-day session, which starts tomorrow, sets the Fed's monetary policy for months ahead. Whether to nudge interest rates higher is at the top of its agenda. Any sharp rise in interest rates would certainly put upward pressure on gold prices.
Investors will also be watching the trade talks between the United States and Japan, and how well the dollar does on the world currency markets. While gold is a safe haven of choice for many investors, it remains extremely sensitive to pressures both obvious and unforeseen.

HEADLINE: Tough-Decision Time for the Federal Reserve;
New Vice Chairman Stirs the Board's Pot

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
When Alan S. Blinder worked at the White House, his usefulness to President Clinton went far beyond his job as economic adviser.
Mr. Clinton, stumped by the math homework of his 14-year-old daughter, Chelsea, sometimes pulled Mr. Blinder aside at economic policy meetings for advice. Usually they were "mind-twisting problems" that involved turning words into complicated equations, one Administration official recalled. "Alan would almost always have the answer," the official said. 
 A natural teacher, Mr. Blinder was able to build an easygoing relationship with the President that made such tutoring possible. But he has not had that same good fortune since he became vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board this summer -- the President's first appointee to the central bank, which has more influence over the economy than any other single government institution.
The answers to questions of how fast the economy can grow without threatening a surge in inflation are subject to much more passionate debate than the solutions to ninth-grade math problems. And Mr. Blinder's public tutoring lessons have irritated some of his Republican colleagues who prefer a different brand of economics.
He has dared, some would say, to suggest that the Federal Reserve should sometimes worry more about creating jobs than cutting inflation a few tenths of a percent. In the words of a friend, Mr. Blinder's comments are like "sticking needles in the eyes of central bankers."
Mr. Blinder has also stirred controversy by chastising European central banks for allowing high unemployment. And he has criticized the view, popular among Fed officials, that central banks are more effective in controlling inflation if they ignore unemployment.
He has hunkered down some since a speech a month ago in Jackson Hole, Wyo., opened this touchy debate. He gave a speech two weeks ago in which he minimized the differences; he declined to be interviewed for this article and he can point out that he did vote for the interest rate increase of half a percentage point that the Fed approved in August. But he has not backed down from what he said.
Mr. Blinder has come face to face with the problem of every vice chairman at the Fed in deciding how much independence to show, a situation that may help to explain why no vice chairman has ever become chairman.
After two decades as an outspoken liberal economist, Mr. Blinder faces an especially hard choice. He can parrot the utterances of the chairman, Alan Greenspan, or continue to educate the public about his own brand of economics -- which he would argue is, at the most, only marginally different -- while risking public speculation of a rift at the Fed.
Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman before Mr. Greenspan, said that while the extent of any actual difference of opinion was not clear to him, the current controversy underlined the risks for a vice chairman who speaks out.
"I think a vice chairman has a responsibility for supporting policy in public statements," Mr. Volcker said. "If he has a real difference of opinion, at the end of the day that shouldn't be disguised, but as much as possible he should support the institution."
The man at the center of this controversy is a soft-spoken 48-year-old balding academic. A 21-year career as a Princeton economics professor and his many influential academic articles on economic theory have made him one of a handful of leading economists active in public policy today.
He is best known by his critics and admirers alike for his brilliance, his sometimes reckless candor, and, particularly his sense of humor.
When he sprained his ankle this summer, for instance, he joked to an audience that he had hurt it while defending the plunging dollar. The White House's internal bulletin included the quip the next day in its compilation of humorous one-liners. "Alan Blinder is the only non-late- night comedian I've seen who ever made it," said Lawrence Katz, who was the Labor Department's chief economist at the time.
He is as quick at candor and contrarian opinions as he is at one-liners, often with little thought of personal gain or loss.
During the mid-1970's, for example, Mr. Blinder told a group of colleagues at Princeton that New York City bonds were severely undervalued even compared with bonds issued by financially distressed cities during the Great Depression. One of the professors, William J. Baumol, was so impressed by Mr. Blinder's reasoning that he called his wife immediately and had her invest heavily in the bonds.
The bonds climbed sharply in value in the subsequent days. But Mr. Blinder expressed surprise that Mr. Baumol had acted on his historical analysis.
"He said, 'You know, I didn't buy any,' " recounted Mr. Baumol, who has since written a highly regarded economics textbook with Mr. Blinder. "The moral of the story is Alan is extremely clear, he looks very clearly at the facts and is more concerned with that than pushing himself in any way."
Aside from Mr. Blinder's public candor, his difficulties now really have two origins -- the profession's mainstream has divided into many different rivulets and his colleagues are more conservative than the average economist. "He's certainly in what used to be in the mainstream -- he's in a mainstream that many people no longer consider very adequate," said Mr. Volcker, who went on to add that he considered Mr. Blinder to be "a first-class, middle-of-the-road economist."
Some of Mr. Blinder's allies contend that the anonymous criticism heaped on him in recent weeks by his current Federal Reserve colleagues reflects a desire to conceal from the public that raising interest rates to fight inflation can mean job losses and less short-term prosperity.
"I think there are a lot of central bankers who don't want Alan Blinder to wake up the public because that will make their job more difficult," said Robert A. Johnson, a managing director at Soros Fund Management in New York, who wrote his doctoral dissertation at Princeton under Mr. Blinder's guidance.
The same disregard of self-interest was evident when Mr. Blinder delivered his first major speech as vice chairman at the annual conference of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City at Jackson Hole in August
Federal Reserve officials usually speak cryptically and avoid references to unemployment at public events. They try to keep their personal reputations as tough inflation fighters intact by avoiding any comment that might frighten investors into believing that the central bank will inflate the economy to put Americans back to work.
But Mr. Blinder was visibly annoyed when he delivered his off-the-cuff speech after a succession of conservative economists had called for reducing unemployment by making it as unpleasant as possible, including through reductions in unemployment benefits.
Mr. Blinder responded with an eloquent call for central banks to show more compassion and take more responsibility for joblessness. Mr. Blinder urged central bankers to follow the views of the British economist John Maynard Keynes, who argued in the 1930's that aggregate demand for goods and services in an economy sometimes varied in erratic ways, and that Government policies could be used to steady the economy and employment.
"President Nixon had it right when he said we're all Keynesians now," Mr. Blinder proclaimed.
But most of the assembled central bankers did not consider themselves Keynesians, preferring other schools of economic thought that allow central bankers to focus on inflation and worry little, if at all, about unemployment. They sat silently through Mr. Blinder's comment.
After a short pause, Mr. Blinder quipped, "I shouldn't put it to a vote."
Mr. Blinder's forthrightness in the last month about monetary policy has divided his friends and colleagues. Some regard him as courageous for shaking up the nation's central bank. Others criticize him for endangering his prospects of becoming the next chairman of the Federal Reserve when Mr. Greenspan's term expires in 1996.
Frederick H. Schultz, a former Fed vice chairman appointed by President Jimmy Carter, was not at Jackson Hole. But when he heard reports of the speech, he said, "My first reaction was: He's about to learn that when you say something as a member of the Council of Economic Advisers, people may not notice, but if you belch as a member of the Federal Reserve, the wire services are going to pick that up."
For his part, Mr. Blinder has made no secret of his reason for speaking out. "When we take actions, they are not reversible by any other body of government, and I think that gives us a tremendous obligation to try to explain what we're up to, why we're up to doing it, and why we think it is the right thing," Mr. Blinder said in a speech two weeks ago. "And I hope for at least a little while longer to continue to do that."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, has suggested that the Fed should sometimes worry more about creating jobs than battling inflation. He sat beside Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, left, at his confirmation hearing in May. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Tough-Decision Time for the Federal Reserve;
Meeting Tomorrow Could Raise Rates

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Federal Reserve officials appear likely to respond to signs of strong economic growth by raising short-term interest rates again this year, but economists are deeply divided over whether the increase will come when the central bank's committee on interest rates meets on Tuesday.
Producer prices rose at a brisk pace in August, and American factories are operating closer to full capacity than they have in five years. This has convinced some that the Federal Reserve will nudge interest rates higher in an attempt to prevent the economy from overheating, which would add to inflation. 
 "I think they're going to do it," said James E. Annable, a senior vice president and chief economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. "This economy looks strong and it's an economy without a lot of excess capacity" for further growth.
But consumer prices have yet to reflect the increase in producer prices, and Fed officials announced after their last rate increase on Aug. 16 that they would not act again soon. "They said it should be adequate for a time, and six weeks doesn't seem like enough time," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch.
Indeed, there is pressure on the Fed from many sides to stand pat for now. Many Congressional Democrats have called for the Fed to stop raising rates, including Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, who heads the House Banking Committee. And on Saturday, the nation's manufacturers urged the Fed not to raise rates again this year and risk their resurgent prosperity.
The Federal Reserve's position is particularly unclear, since the Fed's top officials have made relatively few pronouncements on the economy since the Federal Open Market Committee, which sets policy, last met on Aug. 16.
The seven governors of the Federal Reserve Board, including the chairman and vice chairman, and the presidents of the 12 regional Federal Reserve banks are all members of the committee, which meets every six to nine weeks. The governors and the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York vote on interest rates at every meeting, while the 11 other presidents take turns doing so, with only 4 of them voting at any given meeting.
Two committee members said in recent interviews that they did not see the economy as growing quickly. While neither official was willing to discuss interest rate policy, their views suggested that they might be inclined to wait before raising rates again.
Cathy E. Minehan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, which oversees banks in New England, said that growth in the economy there was becoming less brisk.
"I think the sense that we have is that it's probably slowing a bit just like the national economy is slowing a bit," she said in an interview last Monday. "I think it takes a while for a monetary policy to have an effect, and I don't know whether it has been enough, but I think it's probably slowing a bit."
Lawrence B. Lindsey, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, made the same point. The economy "is continuing in a moderate growth path," he said. Still, he added, inflation "is always a matter of some concern."
Many members of Congress have criticized the Fed for raising short-term interest rates five times this year, most recently on Aug. 16. The discount rate, which banks pay to borrow money overnight from the Federal Reserve, has risen to 4 percent from 3 percent. The Federal funds rate, which the Federal Reserve controls and which banks pay to borrow money overnight from each other, now stands at 4.75 percent, up from 3 percent.
But while the economy may be slowing, Fed officials appear to feel no regrets.
"I think that what the numbers show is the wisdom of our actions earlier this year -- if we were still at 3, I think it would be a matter of serious concern," Mr. Lindsey said in an interview a week ago.
Federal Reserve officials are barred from granting interviews on the economy and monetary policy for a week before or after a meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee.
Senior officials in the Clinton Administration have avoided saying anything about interest rates, while emphasizing that consumer price inflation remains very low.
"They're the best numbers we've had in years," Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said on Friday at a White House news conference about bank regulation. Choosing his words carefully, Mr. Bentsen went on to say that while the Administration was always concerned about inflation, he did not see any immediate need for "deepening concern."
While Mr. Bentsen refused to say anything about short-term interest rates, he played down the significance of data showing high use of the nation's industrial capacity, pointing out that less than a quarter of economic output now consists of manufactured goods. Most output these days, roughly three-fifths, is made up of services.
Beyond all that, the Administration's tough stance in trade talks with Japan worries some investors and has complicated the Fed's decision. "What the Administration has done by talking in a way that pushes the dollar down is make the Fed's job a little harder because a weaker dollar acts as a stimulant" to the economy, Richard B. Berner, an economist at the Mellon Bank, said.

A front-page article yesterday about investments by towns and colleges in highly speculative Wall Street offerings referred incorrectly in some copies to the amount of public money that the treasurer of Sandusky County, Ohio, placed in an interest-rate investment known as an inverse floater. HEADLINE: For Safety's Sake, Reduce Arms

 BODY:
President Clinton and President Boris Yeltsin of Russia can spur efforts to curb the spread of nuclear arms when they speak at the United Nations today and then meet in Washington. They can do so only if they recognize that the fewer warheads they have, the better the chances of keeping them out of the hands of other countries. But a just-completed Pentagon review of America's nuclear posture could get in the way of deeper cuts.
The two leaders need to arrange for closer monitoring of Russia's vast stocks of nuclear material -- to keep any of it from slipping onto the black market. In view of alarming reports of attempted smuggling, the material needs to be collected at a few well-guarded storage sites while the Russians determine how best to dispose of it. Unfortunately, Russia's nuclear custodians are resisting any sharing of custody or help from the outside. Mr. Clinton needs to persuade Mr. Yeltsin to break down their resistance. 
 The two leaders also need to advance the larger goal of stigmatizing and reducing nuclear arms. They can expedite global bans on nuclear tests and on production of fissile material, commit themselves now to negotiate deeper nuclear arms cuts and reduce the role of these arms.
The Pentagon's posture review, by continuing to embrace an outmoded cold-war strategy, will impede any significant reduction in nuclear roles. The review does recommend removal of nuclear arms from all U.S. surface ships and a modest cut in bombers. That is not enough. The review also lowers U.S. warhead requirements, making talks on further cuts possible.
But the Administration says it will not pursue such talks until Russia implements the latest strategic arms reduction accord. Administration officials argue, shortsightedly, that proposing new talks would only invite the Russians to reopen that accord instead of ratifying it. On the contrary, deeper cuts would redress imbalances in the agreement, making Russian ratification of that agreement easier. Cuts would also leave fewer warheads to secure against smuggling or misuse.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin need to pursue further cuts to improve the political atmosphere for achieving two of their aims -- securing unlimited extension of the 1968 Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty at next year's review conference and advancing multilateral efforts to curb trade in bomb-making material and technology.
In the 1968 treaty, states without nuclear arms agreed to forgo developing them and to accept international inspection of their peaceful nuclear programs. In return, the nuclear-armed states pledged to negotiate in good faith on effective measures to end the nuclear arms race and disarm.
The U.S. and Russia have halted nuclear testing but have yet to conclude a formal ban. Even after the latest round of cuts is implemented, they will still have more warheads than they did a quarter-century ago.
The non-nuclear states, led by Mexico, are trying to get the nuclear powers to keep their end of the bargain. They are threatening to hold up unlimited extension of the Nonproliferation Treaty. That would be self-defeating since the treaty keeps their neighbors from acquiring these arms.
But they may have the votes to block extension. They also have a valid reason for encouraging the nuclear powers to do more to disarm: diminishing the status of nuclear arms removes one incentive for others to acquire them. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin cannot afford to miss this vital point.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
