HEADLINE: Coca-Cola to Put Another $100 Million Into Russia

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

 BODY:
The Coca-Cola Company and two bottling partners plan to invest $100 million during the next three years in Russia, where the foreign soft-drink market has long been dominated by a competitor, Pepsico.
Coca-Cola is scheduled to announce its plans today as President Boris N. Yeltsin begins a visit to the United States, largely to woo American executives with a picture of Russia that includes less inflation and lowered barriers to investment and trade. 
 Coca-Cola, to hear its executives talk, is already on board. Its new investment in Russia will follow $140 million it has already spent on bottling and distribution there in recent years.
The Russian market for Coke is tiny but growing rapidly. E. Neville Isdall, senior vice president of Coca-Cola, said he expected Coke's 1993 sales in Russia -- twice what they were in 1991 -- to double again by the end of 1995. He would not discuss its sales figures, saying he did not want Pepsico to know them, but he said he expected Russian operations to begin turning a profit by 1996 or 1997.
Polly Howes, a spokeswoman for Coca-Cola, said about $200 million worth of Coca-Cola products were sold by retailers in Russia last year, although this does not reflect actual revenue to the company. Pepsico, which began selling in Russia nearly 30 years before Coke, is estimated to have sold about twice as much.
Combined, foreign soft drinks represent about 10 percent of overall soft-drink sales in Russia.
"I am significantly more confident than I was a year ago," said Mr. Isdall, who noted signs of growing stability and a proliferation of small businesses that sold products like Coke.
"We're now seeing the first stirrings of Russian entrepreneurship," he said, referring to private kiosks and stores that he said would be a principal venue of soft-drink sales. "It's what we saw in Poland a few years ago."
Analysts who track Coca-Cola described the investment plans as a natural step for the Atlanta-based company, which needs to continue expanding overseas or see a downturn in its growth rates. In 1993, Coca-Cola earned 80 percent of its $3.1 billion operating income abroad. But only $152 million, or about 4 percent, was earned in the region that includes Russia, Eastern Europe and India.
"It's crucial to be competitive in these areas in the future," said Roy Burry, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company. "If they don't do it, they're dead meat."
Coca-Cola said the new investment would be used to rebuild plants in Moscow, St. Petersburg, Vladivostok and several smaller cities and to open a few others.
Of the $100 million investment, roughly $30 million will be spent by mid-1995 to expand a bottling plant in Moscow, which officially opened in April.
In addition, $40 million is to be spent over the next three years to upgrade seven or eight plants in southern and eastern Russia and $30 million is to be spent by two international partners, the Leventis Group, which already bottles Coca-Cola in Greece, Bulgaria and Romania, and EFES, a Turkish brewery.
Mr. Isdall said Coca-Cola planned to put in Russia the same kind of system of production, bottling and delivery that had allowed its sales in Eastern Europe to grow several-fold in recent years.
Ms. Howes, the Coca-Cola spokeswoman, would not discuss sales figures in Eastern Europe, but offered an alternative statistic: In Poland, the average person consumed three servings of Coca-Cola in 1991; by 1993, he or she consumed 23 servings. In Romania, the average consumer drank less than one serving in 1991; by 1993, he or she drank 26.
In Russia, the average consumer drank two servings of Coca-Cola in 1993, Ms. Howes said.
Mr. Isdal estimated that Coke's new investment would lead to the hiring of 1,000 to 1,500 employees, in addition to about 3,000 already working for Coca-Cola in Russia, nearly all of them Russian. In the past, Mr. Isdall said, each new employee hired by Coca-Cola typically meant that about five new jobs were created by Russian companies in related production, cooling, delivery and sales.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 29, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Monday about an investment by the Coca-Cola Company in Russia misspelled the surname of a senior vice president of the company. He is E. Neville Isdell.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
In Pennsylvania, Feeling the Consequences of One Vote

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 25

 BODY:
President Clinton's budget, increasing taxes and cutting Federal spending in a bid to reduce the deficit, is a hot topic across the nation this fall as Republicans seek to oust enough Democratic incumbents to seize control of the House of Representatives for the first time in 40 years.
The test case is Pennsylvania's 13th Congressional District. The target is Representative Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky, a first-term Democrat. Sometimes a Congressional race turns on a single vote among the hundreds any member casts on the floor of the House, and so it is here and now. 
 "You can't trust her," says her opponent, Jon D. Fox, a Republican county commissioner, stressing how deeply the new taxes bite into the incomes of the affluent people in the district. "She said she'd be different. She's not. She thinks higher taxes are the answer, just like Clinton."
"I'm no rubber stamp for the President," retorts the incumbent, who knows as well as anyone how unpopular Mr. Clinton has become. "According to The Associated Press, only three Democrats voted against him eight out of nine times on key parts of his economic program, and I'm one of them."
She backed the budget bill, she said earlier this month, "not because I liked it but because I wanted to break through gridlock, so we could move on to crime, health care and other major issues."
Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky won in 1992 by exactly 1,373 votes.
Then, on the night of Aug. 5, 1993, she cast The Vote. Hard-pressed on deficit-reduction, an issue he considered vital to the survival of his Administration's political credibility, Mr. Clinton had called Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky and implored her to support him.
If he needed her, she said, talking to Mr. Clinton by phone an hour before the voting began, she would be with him, even though she had publicly pledged that very afternoon to oppose the budget measure on the grounds that it contained too many taxes and too few cuts.
With the television cameras watching, the count crept forward until Mr. Clinton needed one more vote to give him 218, a majority. Without that vote, the tally would be 217-217, and the bill would fail. Telling herself that "you're not one-tenth as important as the President," Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky gulped and filled out the green card that signified an "aye" vote.
"Frankly, I think I lose my seat on this one," she says she told the President. "I think I fall on my sword."
Now, in a race that is gaining national attention, she is trying to prove herself wrong in a rematch against Mr. Fox, the 47-year-old journeyman politician whom she defeated last time.
She is philosophical about her chances, conceding that she is behind but arguing that it is encouraging, given all the things working against her, that she is viable at all in what looks increasingly like a Republican year.
"The biggest problem in the House is that people vote to hold their seats," she said. "That doesn't mean everything to me. Those of us who came here as outsiders, I guess, are not so defined by the place. If I'm re-elected, great -- I love the work. If not. . . ."
If ever there was a Congressional district that looked like prime Republican territory, it is this one, which includes most of Montgomery County, with its spine formed by the handsome suburbs strung out along the Main Line of the Pennsylvania Railroad running northwest from Philadelphia.
And if ever there was an unlikely Representative for such an area, it is Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky, a peppy, extroverted, 52-year-old Democrat -- the mother or stepmother of no fewer than 11 children -- who until four years ago made her living as a local television reporter in Washington. In her former life, people called her Marjorie Morningstar; in her present one, she is known as 3M.
A poll taken for the Fox campaign this summer showed the Republican ahead, 47 percent to 29 percent. But many politicians consider Mr. Fox a lackluster candidate and blame him for allowing the Democrats to take the seat two years ago for the first time since 1916. They give Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky a slim chance of survival.
Experts in both parties believe that the Republicans would have been wiser to nominate Mr. Fox's primary rival, Ellen Harley, a fiscally conservative, socially more liberal State Representative.
"Marjorie was dead," said Neil Oxman, a Democratic consultant based in Philadelphia. "But the Republicans nominated the wrong candidate; Jon Fox is the best thing going for her. Also, she'll have a bucket of money. Still, there are very few ways in America, short of committing a crime, that she could have defined herself so quickly, so clearly and so negatively as that vote."
Senator Arlen Specter, a Philadelphia Republican who is widely believed to have a magic political touch, said he considered Mr. Fox "a weak campaigner."
"She cost those people in her district a hell of a lot of money," Mr. Specter said. "There's a lot of resentment about that. But on the other hand, the whole thing has made her a celebrity. She's attractive, well financed, and the outcome still hangs in the balance."
Mr. Fox, who has been an Assistant District Attorney and a State Representative, is relentless in attacking Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky's record. Her budget vote, he asserted the other evening after a fund-raising event at a Capitol Hill bar, "cost people in my district $1.4 billion." She campaigned as a reformer, he said, "and she took more PAC money than any other freshman."
He vows to run a better campaign this time, though he concedes that he is still "no media star."
What he is, he says, is "the representative of the common folk" who live in the gritty old factory towns like Norristown and Conshohocken along the Schuylkill River rather than in the ample, tree-shaded fieldstone houses on big plots in suburbs like this.
There is, indeed, a cultural chasm as well as a partisan difference between the two candidates. Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky went to Ivy League universities (Penn and Columbia) while Mr. Fox went to Penn State and Widener University, a small local law school. She, he says, "lives in a $600,000 house and has eight cars," while he lives in a $120,000 house and has but one car.
Counterattacking, Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky pictures Mr. Fox as soft on crime, describing him as a foe of the ban on assault weapons. After much hemming and hawing, Mr. Fox told an interviewer that he did not know how he would have voted on that measure alone, though he opposed the crime bill as a whole.
Seeking to hold the votes of affluent Republican women who broke ranks to back her last time, in "the year of the woman," Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky satirizes his somewhat equivocal stand on abortion: "pro-choice, that's me, multiple choice, that's Jon Fox." And she reminds people that his supporters sang, "Ding-Dong! The Witch is Dead" at his post-primary victory party.
Incumbency confers advantages, even in this season of anti-incumbent fervor; Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky will probably outspend Mr. Fox at least 3 to 1. Hillary Rodham Clinton was here for a fund-raising event last Tuesday night, depicting Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky's budget vote as a rare act of political courage, not as evidence of spinelessness.
Quoting figures put out by the Tax Foundation, a Washington group that backs lower taxes, Mr. Fox has been asserting that the vote "put 21,685 Pennsylvanians out of work." Mrs. Clinton told 750 people who paid $150 each, it had helped create four million new jobs nationally.
But incumbency also has its demands. Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky missed the fund-raising event, stuck in Washington for a roll-call. "It was like I didn't show up for my own wedding," she said, rolling her eyes.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky, center, preparing to leave on a two-mile health walk in Bryn Mawr, Pa., on Saturday. She is in a tough race for re-election with Jon D. Fox, a Republican. (Chris Gardner for The New York Times)

ANALYSIS
 The race is becoming a test case of whether a vote for President Clinton's first budget, which raised taxes and cut Federal spending, may prove fatal for candidates this fall. Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky, whose position was shaky to begin with in a district that had long been Republicam, case the crucial vote for the budget and is now suffering for it.
